reviews.review: Nothing compares to this. The ultimate shopping experience. Not for the faint hearted. A thick skin and easy smile go a long way here. Best approached with a limited amount of money in your pocket and a fair sense of fun.

Fantastic . We enjoyed shopping and getting fake but good items at bargain prices. We did haggle but enjoyed the experience. There is so much to take in and look at. People can be persuasive and continue to talk to you when you have said you aren't interested which we found annoying but it was something we ignored. It's an exciting and vibrant part of Marrakech and worth a visit. Ideally I would recommend staying in a Riad closeby and go to the restaurants at night.

Colourful and mystic. Get lost! No, I mean that in the nicest way. This maze of alleyways and impasses will treat your eyes with a feast of colour, spices piled high in perfect pyramids every colour, under the sun, cumin and coriander, pumice and pumpkin, textiles and pashminas, carpets and rugs, copper and silver, nothing terribly valuable but all terribly overvalued by their sellers. Bargain them down, then walk away disinterested. They'll come running after you with a new offer. In three hours, I got a carpet I really wanted down from €2000 to €200. It now adorns my entrance hall with warmth and colour and happy memories.
amazing. Hard to find your way bu great experiance, not as much hustle anymore but still hard bargaining......
lovely little place. went on a horse driven carriage around old town and new town, this was a lovely way to see Medina and was only £20. You get to see the palace and casinos and also Louis Vitton.

Go with a professional guide - not with a group. I have visited the Medina countless times, but with a professional guide one really discovers fascinating, hidden parts - like where they make the babouche slippers, or auction the leather. Ask your hotel for a guide that knows the medina well, and make it very clear that you will not be buying any products from his recommended shops - as often one loses too much time being sold too. Best to say you just want to experience the souk - you can shop later on your own without the pressure.

Exciting . There are many stalls and a variety of products to shop from however the stall owners are a little forceful in persuading tourists to buy things. But mean no harm. The atmosphere is extrodinary with several things happening. There is so much colour and brightness in the Medina of Marrakesh with restaurants, shops and sightseeing. There are donkeys walking across the road with you. Overall I really enjoyed the experience and the people of Marrakesh are extremely friendly and welcoming. Especially at night where their is lanterns to bright up the square.

Please do not support the abuse of the animals. The medina is a great place to enjoy shopping, eating, and live music. However, Moroccans sadly abuse animals for income. The worse is the monkeys on the chains. It is horrible to see them tugging at the chain to be released. Many tourists do not see the sadness of the monkeys and think they are cute. Please be a responsible traveler and avoid these animal abusers at all cost. Be smart. Do your research first. Ask questions. Look at the animal. Does it look happy and healthy? Please do this before getting involved with any animal exploitation. Wether it be horse riding, camel riding, elephant riding, dolphin riding, etc. Some animals are not meant to be ridden. Some are but are overused for the day. These are not animals not machines.
shopping. if you have never been - ask the hotel to arrange a guide. Lots of fake goods, lovely souvenirs but you have to bargain!

Amazing!!. Very worth while visiting and having a look around!! The hustle and bustle of day time trading and even monkeys to be put on your shoulders along with snakes if you wish. The night time is just as amazing with lights and music and stunning sunsets.

Amazing chaotic whirlwind. Be wary of anyone approaching you as we were done by a lady. She aproached us and asked about henna but when we said no she grabbed my hand and by the time i realised what she was doing it was too late.
Guide. We were gilded through the medina with a registered guide but we fear he had ulterior motives in guiding for his own benefit. Having said the I guess it's the same the world over.

Magical Marrakech. Loved the Marrakech Medina, it was buzzing until late. Very safe with lots of restaurants shops and the best orange juice! We went to Rebat, Fez & Marrakech. Each is special in their own way but Marrakech was alive and well very late and is managable on your onw.

Waste your money elsewhere. This applies to the souks not the main city. Ubiquitous dirt, touts, conmen, mopeds and constant harassment. The priced for the tat is the souks is a joke and even bartering down to half their price is still an outrageous ripoff. They've seen it all before you are literally a cash cow to be milked. Third world rubbish at first world prices, you do the math. Been there seen it won't be back....To be fair they probably didn't enjoy my presence either....
Madness (in a good way) . The place is a complete attack on the senses! So much going on, it's hard to know where to look first. A great experience. The walls of the Medina are a must see. Enjoy!

The Medina at Night is terrific. We visited the Medina in the evening and were pleased that we did. it was and amazing experience and the place was "Alive" with traders and entertainers all over the place. The traders were all helpful and polite and didnt pester you which we pleased about and the entertainers had some amazing skills and tricks. An evening to remember and highly recommended just for the experience of "Being There".

Fabulous. Exciting, noisy, colourful, tasty, varied, musical, complex, challenging, fragrent, cultural, fascinating.......lots of words to describe it. Best things to do is go and see which ones fit your experiences, it is well worth it.

Oriental feeling!. Walking through the small streets in this large area gives you the real oriental feeling. Its one of the largest historic town centers in Morroc and its really impressive to discover the streets with all the tiny shops and cafes. Some of this shops or businesses survived since hundred years and more and are still in use. Fascinating!We felt very save with regard to pocket picker and beggars we saw just very few. We have been warned from aggressiv kids, but didn't see them either. Beware: except very few restaurants or the Riads the entire area is an alcohol free zone!

Busy busy busy. This place is fascinating but very busy and dirty. I wouldn't recommend with young children. At night it's a different atmosphere, the square is full of music and food stalls. Be careful when going through the souks, I wouldn't only recommending the souks during the day as it can be intimidating at night. I wasn't surprised by the chaos as I've visited similar places. The shops are pushy, if you're not interested don't make eye contact or say no immediately. They love to barter, literally make sure you pay at least half of what they originally ask. Don't let the henna ladies get near you. Even if you tell them you have no money they say ok do the henna and then cause a scene when they want paying and will follow you everywhere.Also saw a man having a poo in the busy street, bits and all. Not nice with young children around
Busy busy busy. Great central point to work from. Activity all the time it seems. Dont take photos of birds or animals unless you are prepared to pay. It is their living.

Perfect 4 nights. As other reviewers this was an amazing holiday with amazing weather.. so thought will add notes that may or may not help. But Never the less enjoy.Firstly WITHOUT FAIL PRINT your boarding passes.. although these budget airlines from UK accept boarding pass on apps and internet when coming back.. Marrakech airport DO NOT accept this and will want paper ones. Otherwise a lady is there and will charge you £15.00 and that is the exact price for now... ( if you have forgotton to print ask your hotel to print this off before you depart)Another thing HAVE A PEN !!Boarding pass needs to be filled in both ways coming and going and the very moment you need a pen there isnt one insight!Before boarding even though you may have checked in online and have your paper ready to go you still need to go to check in to verify your boarding passes.MONEY-The best way to exchange money is do enough for a taxi at the airport...and definitely the rest at your destination in local banks.. you will get much more than the airport rates!! Example Current offer was £1 = 11.5 DHS at airport and 11.82 DHS outside airport Taxi is available everywhere just make sure you bargain and fix your price before getting inside.Excursions..If you dont want to ruin your trip and just for a little less savings.. TRUST me use a well established respected travel agent for your excursions.People on the streets randomly call out to you to book excursions and usually 90% of the time these are companies that do have a travel agent but when looking at reviews people have had a bad time for many reasons. Another thing an excursion for example to Atlas Mountain they will qoute say 180-250 DHS...but for near enough the same amount 200-250 DHS you can still have a fantastic time with a reputable company.If it helps when you are there do a review to check before booking anything.Doing the very thing I booked to go with Marrakech tours who had no people on the streets trying to drag you in. I just saw an A board and decided to review this....they qouted us 250 for a trip to mount atlas but ofcourse I haggled and got this to 200 DHS per person.Alternatively you can take a GRAND Taxi the only difference is there will be no tour guide-- if you are an person who likes to take on information listen to talks learn about culture etc then book with a travel agent.. otherwise once you are there every one is going in the same direction so follow through.. IMPORTANT again without fail wear the correct footwear as technically you are going hiking.Plenty of food places to eat from and some even offer sheesha.Shopping Plenty of UK high street shops at Guillez but i found the price is much more than uk.Souks now be prepared to haggel this is now a tradition and so be patient cos they can sometimes sound very aggressive.Food- Plenty of food options around at night in the square outdoor barbecue type food stalls are set up and good luck trying to pass through them.Sheesha- place in Medina called La Selema which is at the turning just before you see a restaurant called Cafe de France.. they only have two flavours mint and apple cost is 150 DHS they do a tappas menu which I thought was decent portions ( but not if your a big eater )CHARITY.throughout your journey you will see adults children begging for money either asking for it or selling small items from tissues. Ofcourse Charity does not decrease your wealth and give as you wish but just a tiny note.. little kids do melt your heart and I easily felt sorry for them and natrually gave them more than anyone else.. but then i find out its is far better to give your change or charity to the families that have signs displayed they are from syria as they are more needy ( ofcourse God knows best)These kids who have these cheeky smiles and faces have chosen not to go school are able to eat do have roof over the heads and basically spend their time in getting money or free food.At marrakech airport if you want to purchase anything from duty free its only pounds or euros so dont try to carry any back thinking you can use this.

Just unsure....mixed feelings. After reading many guides about Marrakesh, I thought I was ready for the Medina and souk market....but it didn't prepare me enough. I dressed appropriately covering shoulders and knees. Wore sunglasses to make as little eye contact as possible. I walked around with my partner at all time.... that was not enough, you still get harassed! If you even dare looking at a store...boom they catch you and don't let go. The first morning was hard. If you start looking at your map the youngsters jump on you to give you directions. Without realising it one youngster pointed out the direction of our Riad. We said thank you and went. Within minutes he was following us "helping" to get there. We tried to get away from him telling him we knew where to go, even walked into a spa, hoping he would disappear. No chance. As we arrived at our Riad, he asked for money. We said no. He kept insisting. My partner reached for a few coins in his pocket (5dn) he said no I want 100. We told him this or nothing.... the Riad manager opened the door and we jumped in. He got rid of them. I felt very scared to leave the riad in case they were stil outside. We went out in the evening, much more assertive this time.Don t be scared to say NO and keep walking. If anyone is trying to give you directions just say you know where you are and carry on checking your map. Just ignore them.The souk itself is very vibrant and you can get things very cheap if you keep haggling.
Crazy place . Wow what a place. Very busy and not always for the faint hearted but you can't visit Marrakech without coming here

Not For The Faint Hearted. As we were two women on our own we were pounced on by a dirty so called official tour guide who was hard to shake off even though we kept saying we had no money & he was intent on taking us where we didn’t want to go. If not careful you will find yourself in a labyrinth of complicated irregular network of passages & alleys in which it is difficult to find one's way; a maze. Cars are too wide for the alleys but the wider streets allow cars to mix with the pedestrians, bicycles, mopeds, donkey carts and more.If you do not like getting lost in a maze, don't leave the "beaten track" The downsides are widely known - being approached by men with monkeys on leashes, snakes who they try to wrap round you & not forgetting the henna tattooists. Suggest you keep your hands to yourself to avoid unwanted Henna ladies who will try & grab your hand to ply their trade. Therefore keep pointing to a minimum to avoid attention.

PAST IN THE PRESENT . There are few places on this earth that remain connected to a way of being which permeates every experience you will encounter in the Medina.Hearts are open. You are in another relationship with yourself, if you are fortunate you remember a long, long time ago when you where here as you are now.

People watching!. Once you get over the 'sensory overload' this place is fantastic.Has an authenticity rarely seen in North africa .... although this is spoilt a bit by the 'Asda price', 'cheap as chips' etc from the stall holders.Sit in 1 of the cafes and watch the performers, tourists and locals.Try the food ... you know you want to.
very busy, very commercial. After seeing the Medina in Fes and Rabat we found the Marrakech Medina to commercial. Anyway it is nice to spend some time in the Souk.

well worth a visit. the Medinas of Marrakech are a sight to behold, there are many little work shops making allmost anything from leather belts to fancy metal gates, very poor area but really vibrant.

Beautiful a complete Morocco 🇲🇦 Experience . We loved this area. So vibrant alive and full of bargains to take home for the family. Needed to be quite assertive with all the sellers as they really do not like to leave you alone. However absorbing the atmosphere was a be of the most exciting and interesting experiences of our trip

Stalls galore. A very friendly place. Especially for children who are treated so kindly. The pressure to buy is there but not scary. Lots to see and do for a ten year old and lots to eat and drink .Many beautiful wooden boxes for sale with people to show you how they were made, scarves dyed in front of you.

Wher Old and New combine. Was a little apprehensive of going into the Souks but glad we did. The sights sounds and smells were amazing. How two worlds meet. The old generations in their traditional dress, with donkey and carts mixing with the Moroccans of today in their Branded trainers and zooming around on mopeds or in their Audi's. Poles apart. The snake charmers, sadly the locals with the Monkeys are still there. I didn't try the snails, couldn't bring myself to do it. Shame some of the sellers wanted to push Ebay rubbish onto us, the Fake watches etc.Also try a night ride in a horse and cart, then you'll see that the Traffic lights on the outskirt along with the Zebra crossings are only there for decoration. See a family of four including a babe in arms on one moped. Loved the experience. Would go again.

Amazing, like a 500 years trip to the past. It is quiet itneresting, people is very friendly, almost everyone speaks english. The market is everywhere, you can get lost easily but there is no problem, because at the end you can ask and they will help you.
you must see it!. it is a mix of all things, monkeys, musicians, vendors and juice makers, with tourists from all over, and hope to everyone.....safe.
beautiful. A beautiful place with lots of culture & so much to see, be careful of the child beggers though, they follow you around
Beautiful!. Lovely, juist walk around, get lost, have some food, talk to the locals, and have an amazing time!!!
Bustling and vibrant. The Medina is a bustling area with many souks and an abundance of character. You have to be quick on your feet to avoid the mopeds and donkey carts, but it is wonderful!
Horse and carriage.. Interesting night out in th Medina via a Horse and carriage ride.We paid about £12 for a 1hour ride which took in the New Marrakech and also the old. Give it a try!!

Amazing. A wonderful and colourful experience, the souks, narrow alleys with motorbikes, mopeds, bikes all speeding along. the cafes and restaurants with locally produced food. The main square in the evening full of life, with many food stalls, music and story telling. A truly amazing experience

Don't get lost!. We spent a few days in Marrakech on our trip to Morocco. It was amazing - so much stimulation for the senses. If you're not prepared for the madness of the Medina, you might get a bit of a shock but the best advice I can give is to just go with it.

Come experience the culture. There so much to stimulate the senses here! There are pedestrians, mopeds, taxis, donkey carts and touts going in all directions. There were some men playing music while the man sat there with live cobras! We did not venture too close to that. It is a good place to sit and have coffee or Coca Cola and people watch. Just a word of caution, a few of the touts there were fairly aggressive.
Enjoyable morning. Spent a short time here in the main square and the souks. Very enlightening as we had a superb guide. Good short insight into local culture.

It just blows your senses awy. Snake charmers, monkeys, leather goods, spices, clothing, and everything else. The Medina could totally shock you so be prepared for your senses to be set alight. It is so easy to get lost but we had a guide take us around one morning so got a feel for the place after that. It is all quite wonderful as so are the people. Gracious and polite and good fun especially if you speak some French.

Crowded and crazy!. This is a fun place to visit in the day time. Lots of shops and haggling. At night it was very crowded and my advice is to not take anything with you, no purse or camera or jewelry. It was fun and vibrant and I felt safe but did not want to temp anyone. If crowds are not your thing avoid at night. Be careful of the snake charmers as they ripped off several people while we were there.
Medina - The old city. The Medina in MArrakech is a must visit as it is like something out of history. Lively and narrow bazaars oening out into the main square.

Sensory Overload. WOW is all I can say, the colors and smells the hustle and bustle of the Medina is incredible. Shoes, clothing, silverware, leather goods, spices, foods, rugs, fresh meats, craftsman of all types including the hard working men in the tannery. It's all so amazing! If I were to give a suggestion it would be to try and pay attention to what's going on around you. While we tourist walk around all Google Eyed, people are hard at work in the Medina and you may find yourself standing in the way of a heavenly loaded animal headed down one of the narrow alleys. I may be writing it wrong but if you hear someone hollering "Bulack" it means get out of the way, don't think about it just move quickly to the side before you have an up close personal introduction to a not so happy beast of burden.It's an amazing place to visit.

different culture. it was amazing we stayed at the riad in marrakech, this medina is very easy to walk by yourself, it was pretty clean and I felt safe in here the best time to visit the big plaza is at night its an explosion of Moroccan culture

Vibrant. As a family- with two daughters in their twenties, Marrakesh medina is much better than Fez. It was also a better experience due to our guide in Marrakesh, Abdul, he was fantastic. Extremely informative, helpful and protective with our girls. The Marrakesh medina was cleaner, easier to navigate by ourselves and the square was vibrant and lively at night. Lots of fun.

Love the Medina. Came for a visit with two friends and thoroughly enjoyed our stay in Marrakech. Soaked in the exotic city, visiting many historical sights, shopping and eating. It felt very safe as we were 3 women, and the vendors were really not too pushy. Locals were extremely helpful

Excellent Day Out. we spent the day at the Medina browsing through the stalks and souks. it was an amazing experience. The people and traders were great. Everything here is quite cheap and you can haggle for everything and get the best price if you want.There are quite a few cafe and small restaurants you can grab lunch/meals for next to nothing.

Color - crazy - amazing. It is a sea of lights and colors ... it is a lot of trouble - people calling you - showing around - games - snack´s it is so much it is crazy. if you don´t like rush places stay away. From the Medina you can walt to the souks and get lost. I get lost 2 times. Small streets and people all over the places, shops and shops and open space cafes.. it is very difficult to explain because 5 minutes there and you can see crazy thing´s - JUST OPEN YOUR EYES AND GO WITH THE FLOW
In love with Marrakesh. The vibe, the food, the people, the smells (sometimes good sometimes very bad) and almost no European influence! I loved it there!

Very Noisy but Good Fun. Everyone should try to go in the late evening to see the place lit up.It looks great .Lots of traders who push to sell their wares and if you take photos they expect you to pay!Snakes and monkeys join the melee and keep your bag close to your heart!!Worth a Visit for this and the Souks

Labrynthine and bursting with something to explore . Colour ..streets and after streets and larger than life cafes...trsvel.bureus ..similar shops all over and touts and hawkers and passersby who say ' nice ' in appreciation of a good female ..and in acknowledgement of you looking attractive ..No touching .no needless heckling and no danger .no harassment .just curiosity ..and no medinas in marrakesh allow u free movement at all times in all kinds of short clothes without raising eyebrows .Good ol marrakesh is used to skin..unlike traditional fes where it was a tad uncomfortable. It is alive till approx 12 midnight with terrific night bazaars around jemmaa el fnaa..whereas deep within the labrynthine gullies...shops start shutting down .There are lanes dedicated to clothes ..to leather goodShoes and wares ..though many are over lapping ..just get lost and keep walking and u will discover dynamite after dynamite wondering what to buy ..what to leave ..and as u amble by...spot youseeff ben medressa. .and as u take and did detour from main medina square ..u reach bahia palace..and the spice market..andndndnd the mellah which is Jewish quarters ..all walkable with time on hand ..just explore .Medinas allow u latitude ..and stop by for the wondrous shwarmas..paninis..their special sandwiches and innumerable patisserie dotted all over ..superb ..their most famous being annakhil which I spotted in quote a few districts ..Marrakesh has bowled me ..and hopefully it bowls u too..

Medina. Stayed in a riad in the north of the Medina. A very interesting place, full of small streets, nooks and crannies, and high walls. Local people going about their everyday living. Easy to get lost amongst the similar looking streets. The original old town.

Buzzing electric, smell and sound all overwhelming!. If you come to Marrakech, you will definitely come to Medina, the square of Jamaa El Fna Square is full of life in the night, all the food stalls are buzzing with smell, sound and you just can't get enough of it; Medina is pretty big so make sure you know where you are heading into and making sure where you can find exit before you go in; I have had some very good shopping experience there haggling with silversmith and pottery shop, both has given me a significant mark down on the price, always smile and speak some Arabic greeting if you can learn some local language, otherwise, if you speak Spanish or French, that also helps rather than speaking English, I was told if you speak Spanish, you get treated it differently, weird huh, but that was true! Try to explore Medina during the day and taste the food in the night, you can go back once, twice doesn't matter, the taxi fare from Train station to Medina for one person during the day is 20-30dhm, so stick to this fare before you go in a taxi.
Magical!. think Indiana jones running through the market...there are snakes, monkeys, fortune tellers, gymnasts and million market traders ready to sell you their treasures...

A must see experience. The Medina is the centre part or Marrakech, the old town part. The main attraction as such is the markets or souks and the Jemaa el-Fnaa square. The souks sell everything from fancy scarfs and bags to household items. The main drags are more touristy, the side cuts are less so, and the prices vary accordingly. One thing you must do is haggle and haggle hard. The sellers are friendly and often a bit cheeky but it is all part of the fun. And at nighttime, as the sun sets, the square comes to life. Snake charmers, henna ladies and most of all, food stalls set up. The food is nice, almost the same everywhere so no matter which one you pick in general. It is safe to eat too. Been 3 years in a row and always came back with a full and healthy stomach. Its hustle and bustle is entertaining and make sure you check out one of the nearby rooftop terrace cafes for a drink.

Amazing . This was a great visit, went to the food market and watched how it changed from day to evening. This experiance is one of the best I ever had, it was so pulsing and intense, so full of impressions! One of the places I know I will visit again in my life, truly amazing

Best place in Marrakesh. This is a place where you can taste Marrakesh. Aromas, flavors, and why not meeting people? Also, you can watch some presentations. Just take care to not get lost there, and don't be fooled by people who pretend help you to take a taxi. I had some problems there because of this. Whatever, I really loved that place.
Great for People watching. Excellent food in the evenings and lots of choice - do pick from the menu though Snake charmers want a lot of money to display their wares to you

interesting, colourfu, dirty noisy. Some great photo opportunities but too many people harrass you to buy things and will try to charge you too much. The mopeds and scooters are also an issue. Needs to be experienced .....maybe just once

Another world.. The medina is the old town and like entering another world.The main square is a market by day with snake charmers and monkeys and by night a food lovers paradise.Be careful of the people trying to get your photos with monkeys as they will expect paying. Also the henna ladies can be pushy. At night the food stalls appear and these are desperate to get you in and can get very competitive. Most of it is friendly and light hearted. There are lots of cafes which are cheap and friendly for a rest. The medina is a must if visiting Marrakesh but I preferred the daytime as less hassle.
A place lost in time. You would miss so much if you didn't visit the Medina. It was so interesting to see at all times of the day and night - a pleasant shock to all of our senses.

A maze of shops. There is so much to buy when you visit from leather, wood, metal, fabrics, spices and other foods. It's hard to visit and not want to buy something! If you are going to buy something then you need to be prepared to haggle. Be aware that they will generally inflate the price a lot so don't be worried about offending them, go in with what you are prepared to pay and don't go above that, you have the upper hand! Is is very disorientating, very easy to get lost. At night it can be intimidating also with mainly men around. Do not accept directions from strangers!!
An impressive attraction. This is an iconic place in Marrakech and comes to life at night. The smells and buzz of the place is impressive but one visit is enough.

Great place, don't forget to bargain and watch your pockets!. Lots of inexpensive authentic stuff. Always bargain, try at least 1/4 of price and if you don't get 1/3-1/2 just walk away, you ll find it cheaper somewhere else. Watch your pockets.

Got to visit. The medina in Marrekech is definately worth a visit and unlike any other medina in Morocco. Hated seeing poor tortured monkeys and snakes being abused so unnecessary as the medina has enough to offer without this. Even if you are knackered venturing out at least for one night time visit is a must.

It's crammed full of people. As other have stated mopeds, scooters, Berber taxis (donkeys and mule carts) are everywhere. The shopkeeper's are full of themselves and always working to get you in the door and sell more than you want. My friend being hollered in all languages. Enjoy the shops and sites, take care and enjoy.

An Eye Opener. A beautiful city with lots of culture and mystery. The Jemaa El Fna Square is full of life at night and is a must to visit. If you have time, do explore the streets and get lost while doing so. You will definitely have fun trying to figure out the maze and enjoy the beautiful sights of the city. The people of the city were also very friendly and approachable even if they spoke minimal English. They will go all out to ensure that you are fine and taken care of. In terms of shopping, do be careful of scam artists and beggars. The scam artists may approach you and pull your hand to give a "sample" but you will end up paying for the said "sample". Thus, be careful and not fall or allow them to give you a "sample". I witnessed a women approached family with two small kids. As the parents were momentarily distracted when purchasing food, the scam artist went to their toddler and put on a bracelet on her left wrist. The scam artist then continued to say how pretty it was. Thereafter when the parents wanted to take it off as they did not want to purchase it, the scam artist tighten the bracelet making it impossible to take it out. The said parents had to pay 50 dirhams for it as apparently, they had "spoilt" it when trying to take it off.Additionally, the moment you give a beggar some cash, more beggars will approach you. As such, be mindful of your surroundings. I had no issues with the bargaining of prices as they were more honest with us who were Muslims. They did not quote too high of a price and furthermore, they did not know my country well which helped in the process too. In terms of the day tours, please be noted that the tour price only includes the drive to the location. You will still have to pay for the guide at the attraction itself. Usually a tour guide will cost about 20 - 30 dirhams each person depending on the attraction. They will bring you to an expensive restaurant where the food will cost at least 100 dirham for each person. The food cost, tour cost and any additional ride or item are not included so be prepared to pay more. My advise is to not purchase shared tours online or beforehand as the prices are more expensive. Unless you wish to go for a private tour that is. I paid at least 400 dirhams more per person for booking the trip online instead.

Great Shopping. Amazing shopping, but bargaining is a tiring, exhausting business. Stick it out. Start at one third and move towards 40-50% of first offer. Vendors never seem pleasedto make a sale. Patience is required. Best price i got for Moroccan slippers was dhr75 per pair. They start at dhr180 to 250. Guides are all on the make as well, and take you to their mates places. Souk des babouches is best for the girls.

Medina should be done with a good guide. It would be fun to explore on your own, but we found a guideleads the way and you do not have to concentrate on whereyou have been or where you are going. In addition, we wantedto go "deep" into the medina and felt it was easier and saferwith a guide. Also, our guide(first one ever) helped usbargain which we are not very good at the the Moroccanshop owners are superior at. We felt we got good deals withthe quide advising us.

Ruined by motorcycles. I used to love the Medina in Marrakech - and I still do, sort of. But the medina has been overrun by motorcycles, ruining any visit. Motorcycles rush through as fast as they possibly can, risking serious injury to pedestrians and generally harassing everyone. Before getting to Marrakech, we stopped at the Medina in Fez for a few days and it was absolutely wonderful. The very few motorcycles (less than 10 in 2 days) were very careful to not interfere or bother any pedestrians. The Medina was quiet, it was safe to walk and it was a great experience. In Marrakech there are no rules, no courtesy, and no respect for pedestrians. I won't return to this one wonderful Medina until the motorcycles are taken out.

A real taste of every day life. The Medina houses many raids, cafes, the souks and the main Square Jemma el-Fnaa. Walking through the 'streets' is a real experience as you try to negotiate, carts, donkeys, scooters and sometimes cars.

Medina visit. Great place to visit, be prepared to be hassled and shocked! There is lots going on from snakes to monkeys (in nappies and football shirts!). Lots of henna ladies (be warned - they 'offer' you a gift/present and then as you thank and walk away, that is not the end of it - they will not leave until you pay and if not enough will hassle you for more!) Lots of music, dance and fun things going on. Market stalls with interesting and not so interesting 'thing's! Fruit stalls, food stalls, snails and mint tea. Evening is great fun, great to grab a drink nearby and watch as it changes from day to night...lots of competitive food stalls, all trying to win you over and sell sell sell! Good food, cheap, although they will try and charge you more as a tourist. Have your wits about you, barter and have fun!

Chaotic and Colourful. We stayed in a riad in the Medina for four nights - an absolute warren of streets and souks, full of locals who offer to "help" and then ask for money at the end of it. As Canadians, we found it hard to say "no" at first, but got used to it really quickly.
A fascinating city. Take comfortable footwear ! There is so much to see and do ... soak up the sights and sounds of the city - a fantastic place to visit regardless of the weather

Exotic Labyrinth. The medina is not easy to navigate – even with a GPS we got lost. Be aware of con artists shouting and pointing directions, without you even asking – trying to lure you into dead ends and then demanding money to get you back to your starting point. The stall owners are rather aggressive – and you need to be a tough negotiator in order not to be ripped off. Best advice is, know our prices – check it at the fixed price shop before you even look at anything. Then act confident and aloof – never with a map in your hand. As a rule of thumb be prepared to spend time if you want to purchase something - offer a third of the asking price, argue politely, walk away, be called back and then settle on half of the asking price.
Riad Espagne . Hello ! This is Mohamed from riad If you want more information send me in the WhatsApp : 00212634599919

Night market is the best. The atmosphere at the night market is irrepressibly electric. Fell in love with Marrakech when the sun set and the locals came out to hear the storytellers' tales, eat some street food, etc. Don't miss this if you're making even a quick visit.

Other worldly. I felt like I was on a huge giant movie set. I hate shopping so the best place to be was above it all at the rooftop terrace bar which overlooks the entire medina square. You just pay for a drink to gain access. The sounds of the drums, the smoke and smells of food stalls let you know you're in Morocco. Go an hour before sunset which in September was around 5-6pm. Oh and don't even look at the monkeys on chains or cobra's if you don't want to pay. I saw numerous tourists collared after trying to take pictures.

Amazing experience . You have to go to Medina if visiting Marrkech! We went at night and it was buzzing with music, the Souk, dancers, food! In the souk always offer half of the price quoted or even less and then you can haggle down. The food section is really crazy as there is so much competition and you have menus thrust in your face. The prices are all pretty much the same but be careful as our bill was over 100 dirams more then it should have been! Only when we added everything up did we realise and payed the correct amount. For a cultural experience it was probably one of my best in Marrakech and a great place to pick up low cost gifts. The vendors are all really good natured and friendly and all spoke good English.

Wow!. This place is not for the fain hearted ! Prepare to be hassled, shocked but also amazed. Loads of stalls selling everything from fruits, nuts, clothes, trinkets and shoes! You have to barter a price as we very nearly got ripped off. Avoid going to far down the little alleyways. 3 guests from our riad got mugged! Lots of pickpockets about, local women grabbing your hand to inscribe with Henna, tiny monkeys on chains for a cute photo and snake charmers.The Medina comes alive at night when all the locals go to eat there, some wonderful street foods but again, you have to be careful. I'd advise taking hand sanitizer! Overall a fantastic experience and would return.

different place day and night. definitely go both day and night as the atmosphere is completely different. Its great fun haggling and the stall holders are good natured. What ever price they say half it and walk away if you still dont get to the price you want, they will usually come after you. If you are taking photos be careful as the vendors will want paying and if you dont the Police will come and tell you to pay. Its safe and there are a lot of Tourist and Normal Police around.

Just mental!!!!. This place is crazy!!!! In a good way! People, motorbikes, taxis, donkeys, carts, cat and chaos!!!! It's ace!Just walk on the right and pray nothing hits you!!!!!Our riad was right In the centre and we are so glad it was! Don't stay outside the medina it will be boring!
Amazing. In the daytime it is interesting but night time is best. Grab a seat on one of the restaurant rooftop terrace and watch the sunset

Bucket list of places to visit. Really vibrant place to visit. If you love the hustle and bustle of a market and people watching then this is the place to go. Your eyes ears and nose will be stimulated from the moment you arrive. Great Morrocan food vendors to snake charmers
brilliant place. A truly amazing place to visit - lots of culture to see. Its an eye opener to how other people live/

A must see. Our hotel organised a private guide to take us to the Medina and we had a fabulous 5 hours walking around and exploring the little back streets and many stalls the Medina has to offer. Some parts can be eye opening and may be distressing for some (think monkeys in nappies with leads on being lead around in the hot sun for tourists to have photos with and chickens being killed in public view in the food market) and you should be prepared to barter with the shop owners to get the best bargains but otherwise this is a great introduction to Moroccan culture. We will definitely return again but we would always take a guide with us.
Worth the trip. After visiting many other Medina's around Morocco this 1 was our favorite!! More spacious then the others. It was a little more pricey but we all felt like it was worth it.

Awakening of the senses. When visiting Marrakesh, a trip to the Medinas is a must. The sights, smells and experiences are like none other. A guide through the Medina is a great way to appreciate the full culture of the people.I loved the Medina, totally different to anything I have experienced in my travels.

Magical. What an amazing place this is, snake charmers, belly dancers, drumming and the smoke from dozens of cooking fires - this is the Jma at night . Stalls selling fresh orange juice, tagines, couscous and much more. Small boys performing acrobatics and women waiting to henna your hands. Three and a half hours from London and you are in a different world.

Just amazing!. the square is virtually a clear space during the day, as dusk falls sit at one of the numerous cafes and watch as the space fill with a myriad of stalls, storytellers, dancers and fire jugglers!!The stallholders and restaurant greeters are all pleasant, just say, "no thanks" with a smile on your face and walk on.there are some major price reductions to be had with some haggling, decide what you want to pay and just walk away if you can't get the price to that, don''t be insulting and make your set price too low, they still have to make a living!If you stop for a coffee expect to be approached by numerous watch, painting, clothing cigarette and tissue vendors who walk round the medina at all times of day and night, again a smile and a no thanks is sufficient for them to move on.The roads around the Medina need to be seen to be believed, non stop traffic, crossing the road involves quite alot of hope and dodging round cars, motorbikes and cycles, DO NOT think that traffic will stop for you on the crossings!!!!!Fantastic place !
Take a trip back in time!. Walking through the medina and the souks was like taking a trip back in time, the sounds, the smells and sights are mesmerising. Absolutely fascinating!

Overwhelming Exciting to the senses. A description can not do this Medina adequately. The Medina is a maze of shops and markets that requires experiemcing. Ask your hotel to recomment a guide to take you through the Medina ...in order to give insight to what you are seeing..The Medina offer a wonderful experience not to be missed so plan a couple of days for exploration.

Like stepping back in time. The medina was noisy, vibrant, smelly and full of life and colour. There are people on mopeds everywhere, beggars, snakes, acrobats and drumming. If you take a photo with anyone be prepared to pay. We ate street food which was delicious there is alot of completion and you will get approached often. The side streets seem quieter and there are amazing things to be found behind the smallest of doorways.

stay on a riad and walk, walk and walk!. as we got out from the transfer and met the riad person on El Moukef, we felt like we entered a movie, a distant magic world. Quiet caothic on that point, but as we eneterd the walk ( and bike) only old streets... no way to describe it. We got immersed on the old town and islamic culture. To see local life, markets, museums, mosques and other attractions, was wonderful. We did one day ourself and one day(5hs) with a guide . I wouldnt change anything.

A market of hustlers. I don't like to bargain so it was really downhill. I don't like to be hounded if I look at something or chased down a street or alleyway if I ask a question. I simply lost interest and the prices were much higher than I thought they would be. A lot of junky stuff that just didn't appeal to me.
Amazing. A very beautiful historic city with many riads worth visiting. The best place if you wish to know more about moroccan History.
The best and most genuine arab medina. Don't go along the touristic flow. Ask for a local inhabitant to guide you through. That's the best way to have a genuine experience.

A maze ing !! literally a baffling away of streets. Wonderful. Walk into the narrow corridors and streets of this breathtaking Medina. a marketplace of colour, smell and one that will tantalise your taste buds, hearing and sense of smell with so much to see. This is a maze, so take a good large scale map with you. Google maps on your phone do work so track your walk and then you can find your way back. This is an amazing place. The locals can be a bit pushy about showing you where the square is or the tannery. if you want or do use them, fine. But just a word of caution, they will ask you for money and will get stroppy when you decline. most will seem friendly enough and they appear to be just helping, its not the case. Sadly, they are making the Medina less desirable than it was ten years ago. ( just say no thank you and move on- if they stay with you, just walk into one of the shops and wait for them to move on ) Take comfortable walking shoes and be careful of the scooters and cyclists as well as cars and lorries that can come through these small streets at speed. There is so much to see and always bargain for what you want and don't be pressured into buying what you don't want. if you walk away the price will drop and if not, there is another shop very close by that has all the same stuff where you can try bargaining again. A lot of fake goods here and it is a real shame that there now appears to be a lot of imported Chinese clothing and cheap plastic toys and implements taking over. The Tannery is worth a visit and there are guides at the doors to try and ¨guide you¨fine if you want to spend 200 Dirhams, ( about 18 quid) for a few minutes in the Tannery and a brisk march to the carpet and leather shop. They all work together to fleece you of your cash.....it´s the way they earn a living...so accept it for what it is and enjoy it .....

Just perferct. The square is a amazing at night , the street food is so testy !!
the souks around the square are full of incredible art pieces,9 traditional clothes , ladder bags , accessories.....)
few bar around for refreshing drinks at good price .

Bustling, vibrant Medina. Busy! Vibrant! Colourful!! If you get the chance go! But!! Make sure you have a guide booked through your hotel, wonderful place, wonderful people, however! Animal abuse is rife, the state of two horses (standing in their own mess, skinny, wounds on their knees, not shod properly) left me in tears, monkeys on chains, snake charmers, I was praying the cobra would turn on their captors....
A Must in Marrakesh. The Medina of Marrakech is wonderful. Don't miss it! Its square, the food, the people, the markets...
The heart of Marrakesh. You cant visit Marrakesh without spending time in the Medina. Vibrant, energetic, colourful with a lot of soul.

Stay inside the medina. We had a riad inside the medina and it was great to be so close to everything I thought it would be noisy but it wasn't at all There's so much to see in the medina and all very walkable

Intense. The Medina is a mix of intense smells, sights and pushy market stall holders. Don't let the pushy people put you off, the Medina can be relaxing. The streets are a maze but you always find a city wall eventually, which is a bearing point. Stop for tea as it's always available and delicious.
beautiful. the night life family atmophere gathering some much to see and do. the food was also to die for great experience

Interesting. Busy and interesting, bustling and colourful. As with all of the city, must see. Take your time, soak in the atmosphere, sunshine, sights, sounds and smells (some of the smells better than others!)ENJOY
Hold your nerve and go for it!!!. fabulous experience visiting the square and souks by day and by night.Choose a restaurant with a terrace for a great view!

Don't even go there. Every shop keeper tries to shout on you and act all friendly but soon as you respond they do their best to rip you off, for example for a bottle of water which is 3 dirhams most shop keepers will try to charge you 10 dirhams or more, to buy a shisha they ask 600 dirhams when it's only worth 100 with very poor quality,people force you to go the wrong way so you can get lost,guys try to give you directions then ask for money,kids are all over the place specially at night, they come hug you and kiss your arms just so you buy stuff from them and they tell tourist double the price of the things, very dirty and smelly,would never go back there, they make fresh orange juice but it's so warm you won't enjoy it,too many people ripping you off from every direction you look

fabulous!. Narrow streets and crowded markets! You get transported to an undefined past time right away. First timers might get a bit overwhelmed initially. Just get over the fact that your personal space might be a bit reduced while inside. As soon as you stand and admire something, a vendor will board your space trying to convince you. People are very friendly but tough sellers. The first NO will not convince, so just remain patient. It is safe, so go on! Beware when taking photos, not to be irritant to locals. Try empathy by imagining it is you who is being shot by the lense

Not for the faint hearted. I took my intrepid mum to the pink city for a week. We had an interesting stay, with contrasting experiences. The Medina can be totally chaotic at times. There are many stalls in the souks where it would have even lovely to browse in were it not for the continual bombardment of traffic, mainly motorbikes. There are a lot of donkey carts, hand carts and bicycles to dodge but the motorbikes in the narrow walkways are a menace. The tourist authorities in Marrakech need to clamp down on this before it puts visitors off altogether.The shopping is exciting and the square after dark is magical. There are beggars and feral cats about. It is easy to get lost as the roads have few labels and the local maps are bad. Having said that part of the charm is to get lost in the ancient Souks. Be aware the Moroccans are very friendly and will help you if they can. We had trouble with the occasional lads who guided you to your destination and expected a large tip and also took you 'around the houses'. Also some lads don't know where they are, and guess badly where to guide you. The best way to navigate is to use the shape of the lanes and squares and ask vendors directions. If I go again I will take a compass!The medina is an unforgettable experience of North African life. We felt very safe. Just watch your back!

Fun to go browsing and bargaining with the shopkeepers.. Shopkeepers are aggressive don't be afraid to say "no" they will come after you with a much better price. But please be polite don't be an "ugly American".
Hectic but exiting . The medina is a hectic but exciting place to visit with many many merchants selling their wares and interesting place to browse through.

A mixed experience!. The architecture, museums, gadens, palaces and souks were both interesting and at times really beautiful. Easy to get lost in the Medina as many of the tiny alleyways do not display street names.Spent a spa day at Mamounia hotel which was special. Our riad Riad Dar Grawa was wonderful.However, we were approached at least 4 times per day by local con artists trying to 'guide' us (for money), take us to their uncles carpet/trinket/leather/spice shop (for money), show us an alternative route when a route was closed (for money) although the route was not closed, and even assist our taxi driver in finding our riad (for money).It is clear that there is much poverty in Marrakech so locals are looking for ways to earn money, but the overall feeling as a tourist was of being targeted for money to deliver services that weren't required. Some of you inhabitants of Marrakech have let your city and your country down.Left a bitter taste for us and we won't visit again even though we stayed in a lovely riad and visted some beautiful and interesting places.

Evening and Daytime walk/shopping. Visit both daytime and Night time. Full of local people and various shops with variety of local produce and imported goods. A lot of repetition with goods so check for prices and quality and always bargain the price down. Lots of places to eat and can find food for vegetarians too from TripAdvisor. Get a good feel of the old town.
Walk and get a feel for the city.. Shops, gardens, and various sites. Loved the feel in the older areas, walled city. Just be cautious with wallets and strange places at night.
Charming. A wonderful journey discovering the best of Moroccan culture. The people are very hospitable and kindo.

Intimidating, dirty and full of people out to con you.. It is always nice to experience different cultures however if you are a woman or dont appreciate being consistantly harassed/conned out of your money than I would not say it is for you.

Fantastic sensory experience. . If you're looking for a few days exploring somewhere totally different you'll really enjoy yourself. We read the rough guide so we're reasonably savvy about what to expect and it certainly lived up to our expectations.
An Experience. We only went for 2 hours and that was enough, there are people call themselves guides and from the moment you get there they are harassing you, the medina is amazing lots of tat to buy
A wow factor. well worth the visit although some tourists seem concerned, apply common sense and enjoy the shopping and experience

Well worth a visit. Very hot during the day, but such a differant vibe in the day to the evening. Plenty of places to eat and shop. Some people can be pushy but in general they are lovely. I came here last year in June as well. both visits were great but with very differant experiences. It can get very busy and it was too busy for my 15 year old daughter although she is glad she went.

The Square in Marrakech. The Square itself was ok, we enjoyed a nice walk on a cool evening. Its never worth going there during the heat of the day. We stayed away from the street food in case of food poisoning.However, we absolutely loved the souks that lead up to the main square. As long as you are able to ignore locals calls towards there stalls or there asks for 'help' you will be just fine. Make sure you know where you are going and have your own prices in mind for things to buy. Asking for directions is not a good idea, as they may charge you for it. Prices they quote you for a thing you want to buy maybe more than three times what they actually will charge you after the haggling. Overall a lovely and unique experience, as long as you are know exactly where you are so have a map in hand or download an offline map if you have no access to internet.
An amazing place where traders, artists and tourists get to meet. Very good place to buy souvenirs, eat like the locals, see and experience Moroccan culture & history

Amazing atmosphere!. That is what the real Marrakesh is about - the people, colors, tastes and so much more. Dont worry to walk there, even though it can be very hectic, we always felt safe and enjoyed local atmosphere. Such an unique and amazing place!
Wonderful experience in the Medina of Marrakech. This is a place which should be a must on your list. You see the culture here. Amazing feeling. You should go towards the evening.

Landmark of Marrakech!. Hate it or not, this is the most recognisable landmark of Marrakech. It is a must see place with all those crazy merchants and haggling people, horses, motocycles, cars, bikes and people trying to get through the square. The merchants get pretty pushy though so be careful...The lady offering henna tattoos almost dipped her needle in my arm when I was passing by. Still, experience not to be missed!
This is Marrakesh !. there is no visit in Marrakech without a visit in the Medina. but take your time. spare time to walk and feel.

Hustle and Bustle and Must-Do!. As with the main square, the Medina is bustling with life - people and animals! Comes alive at night with entertainment, eateries, traders, noise and fun. Wander round, take in the sights and enjoy.

An authentic mystique experience. Once you enter the Medina you feel you've entered a bazaar in Agraba (from the Cartoon Aladdin)..Street vendors selling anything and everything, from spices to crafted plates, the world-famous baboush (Moroccan leather slippers)... the list goes on and on.Great cultural experience, but you need to bargain your way through every purchase.. if you squeeze hard enough you can easily walk away with 1/10 the asking price.A definite must-see when in Marrakech
Bustling. We did not like this area due to the intimidation, and pushy sellers in the square.We only spent a couple of hours here to get souvenirs.Would not return.

A crazy bustling place not to be missed. The medina comes alive at night with every age and culture,a truly amazing experience that should be not be missed .you can tour the medina in a horse drawn carrage or just take in the sights by foot

This is why you came to Marrakech!. You have to come. Must be one of your reasons to come and visit this wonderful country in the first place. It is crowded! It is wonderful! Yes they have tourist traps but it's pretty much unavoidable. Try the food and ask for the final price when you order! They also have a few tea shops around the medina. Just walk around and have fun!

Awake your senses. Every sense is assaulted, in good and bad ways. The aroma of spices, sewers, and animals. Not stinky, but you are aware..Sounds - prayers from the mosque people talking, bartering, yelling suggestions to visit their shops...sight, all colors, and shapes...carpets, leather, pottery, silver, copper..

Marrakech medina - an UNESCO site. The old medina consisting of a fortified city along with a multitude of colourful shops is an UNESCO protected site. Some of the most important sightseeing spots like the Bahia Palace, the Saadia Tombs etc are located here. The shops display multifarious goods and really attract. Our guide told us to only see the goods and check the price, and to leave the actual shopping to Fes. The market place is very interesting. As the evening sets in the place gets very crowded with a number of local performing artists showing their skills. Variety of fruits are on sale along with fruit juice.But as per the guide we were asked to avoid this as the local water is bound to cause stomach upset. Beware of taking photo of persons without their permission. This applies to all over Morocco.

What fun. Be prepared to get wonderfully lost and be prepared to haggle and walk away if you cannot reach a mutually acceptable price. Don’t be bullied or feel harassed we have brought some amazing things from a metal lightshade that started at 2,800 Dirhams and we agreed on 750, after I walked away at 1,000 and was called back (you know if you walk away and that does not happen you are too low) to handbags, hats, slippers, shawls, bowls, lanterns, necklaces….We use an app called maps.me which is great for finding your way out when you have shopped enough.

A massive Market! with local input in every way. Complete madness but a lovely place you have to see, so much going on. please stay away from the Snake and Monkey charmers ( I felt they were not looked after well).

Crazy colourful but you will need a rest afterwards!!. This great square - a square for the people - is authentic Marrakech in all its glory - colourful, interesting - loads going on - same charmers, henna hand artists, all kinds of street food and entertainment! there are cafes too and shops surrounding the square! be warned of people offering to take you there as you near it, they will lead you astray, say they are lost, then find it again but demand money for doing so - we didn't bite but we saw loads who did! speak french if you can, just a few words is polite and will get you far - Non merci to those trying to sell you stuff goes a long way. ~but most people are lovely and friendly and this is a great place to experience all the colour and traditions that Morocco has to offer. Just book yourself into a calm hotel room after!
Fascinating. A must visit for anyone coming to Marrakech. Interesting and vibrant. If you come at night, lots of interesting places to eat.

Don't bother unless you like being hassled, Too hot , too busy , too pushy.. Never again , don't go if you don't like being hassled to buy. It's very hard to just window shop as they wont let you just look , Buy buy buy! No thanks isn't enough.

A buzzing maze but not intimidating. As with an walled centre, it is a mass of narrow allies that are easy to get lost in. Get a guide that knows the area as there are some lovely things to see and do

The Old Medina. The Old Medina is busy, a little manic, but amazing at the same time. Expect to get overcharged by massive amounts unless you're a bit careful....get a little advice from your Riad manager or staff on what you SHOULD pay for particular items you're looking for to buy and take home! There are a couple of co-operative wher4 everything is genuine, hand made, and reasonably priced...they'll give you a great idea of general prices. Beware of people who are doing "unofficial guiding" around the Medina, which is illegal in Morocco! Feel free to give them a little money if they're nice and helpful but don't ever give them what they ask...use personal discretion. Apart from that enjoy the haggling on the stalls (you'll get much better prices if you are firm with what you are willing to spend...if you're being pressured just smile, say thank you and politely leave - you'll find the same stuff in a hundred other stalls so don't worry!). Try the food stalls here and there for something quick and simple..the food is largely well cooked and a little more "Moroccan" than some of the more tourist-oriented restaurants, but we weren't disappointed with anything we had while there for a week.Take the time to really take in the ornate decoration on the buildings and old furniture etc..so lovely! Try a sunset meal on one of the roof terrace restaurants for a lovely view of the square as all the lights are coming on on the stalls and the smells of cooking are beginning to swirl around!
Busy busy. Hard to no where to look when you visit so much going on . keep your wits about you and haggle haggle haggle or no bargains to be had

Amazing, Thriving Experience. So many shops and not enough time! Very vibrant walking up and down the crowded alleys dodging motorcycles and horse carriages. You don't have aggressive shopkeepers trying to drag you into their stall like I have seen in other cities. Went carpet shopping and they excitedly showed us carpet after carpet; when we liked one their initial price was $2,200 and we bought it for $700 and they can ship to the US. Similar bargaining throughout the Medina.

Undisputed essential. We had been before, so we did not go again - but it is fabulous - haggle wisely and you will be happy - but perhaps once is enough! It's huge and picturesque and they are targeting tourists the whole time which is slightly annoying

Must visit . The medina has so many great stalls, we came during Ramadan and the difference from day to night is extraordinary! Definitely must see during the evening as the weather cools down and everyone comes alive

Medina shopping experience. We were mezmerized by all that we saw. It was like going through a maze. So many narrow winding alleys. The sights and sounds were like going back in time. Actual donkeys pulling carts, bikes loaded with baskets. The colors of Morrocco were so vibrant. We were lucky to have had a fantastic guide who led us through and actually kept the more aggressive vendors from following us too closely. I don't think I would attempt this area without a guide .
the best medina in morocco. we hade a travel in morocco 15 days and we hade a nice visite with our local guide Mouhamed.highly receommended.
excellent medina. we had a nice travel in Morocco included the visit of this medina and the medina tour was excellent .

Surrealistic Place. As many places in Africa, Marrakech is one example of how different cultures are in this continent. The Medina is specially caotic and attractive for those who like to try something different from western world. Despite its french influence, Marrakech offers the pure taste of the middle east world. If you are shy or don't like crowded places, Marrakech is not for you.

Take your life in your hands. We walked to the Medina from our hotel about 7pm with two friends and were hassled by taxis, horse and carriage drivers and untold supposed guides before making it to the Medina where the food vendors took over. I had to literally push them out of the way and make them let go of my partners arm several times. Admittedly some were amusing with their fake cockney accents but it became very tiring. Another very dodgy issue was snake people trying to drop a live snake onto our friends wife and Monkeys being thrust at us for photos. We finally retreated and gave up and found a restaurant away from the square. We returned about 10pm where the whole square had calmed down and we were able to actually walk around and really enjoyed the experience without nowhere near the previous hassle.

Jemaa el Fna. The main square. Vile.Very busy - have no idea what the attraction was for all those people. Animal abuse all around, snake "charmers" monkeys on chains with aggressive touts that treat the animals badly. It is illegal in Morocco but the police do nothing. Dirt,y street food, constant demands for money and being followed by a toothless wonder who exposed himself twice to my friend and me. Better places to eat in the Medina than here. As for the market (souk) as expected in a North African country - harassment - although not as bad as Egypt - and just selling spice and tat. So why was I even there?? It was a necessary, albeit unwanted, stop over before going to beautiful Imlil and the tranquil High Atlas Mountains

Amazing place full of character and shops. Came to the medina not know what to expect and visited before in the day and evening. The evening it's more relaxed, but in the evening is when it comes to life. The atmosphere is amazing and it's very busy. We didn't feel in danger or overwhelmed. You get asked to look at shops but the people take no and leave it. Worth a visit
Charming. It's wonderful to discover the beautiful medina behind the giant walls. Everything is discreet and one has to be attentive to discover the hidden secrets.

Very good place!. This is a busy square with a multitude of different stalls, food, juices and all of the usual souvenirs. There are also lots of ladies offering henna.Wonderful square to shop, people watch and experience the the sights , smells , colors of Marrakech! Quite noisy and hectic but what you expect a traditional market square in Morocco to be!Very interesting sights of locals selling everything. Able to browse and take wonderful photos.
Amazing town. When we planed to visit the medina (the old town), we prepared a short program, but during the visit, we extented until midnight.You will never this place.
Amazing. Fabulous both night and day completely different experience from other capitals cities we have visited

Have your wits about you. At night the central medina really came alive. The food vendors and street entertainers were plentiful. Monkeys, snakes, music....you name it but Ladies PLEASE just have your wits about you. Do not stand close to any man. I was sensibly dressed and respectfully clad and was groped twice! Even with my 6'5'' husband standing next to me. NOT enjoyable but the rest of it was pretty amazing.

Interesting during the day but comes alive at night. The square is surrounded by shops, cafes and restaurants, with a warren of alleyways of small stalls selling Morroccan goods. There are horse drawn carriages available for trips around Marrakech if you like that sort of thing. However at night it seems most of the inhabitants of Marrakech converge on the square with many street entertainers of varying descriptions. An experience not to be missed!

The Square at Night. THe square comes alive at night. Thousands can pack the square. Visitors can stroll about and find snake charmers, monkey and owner shows, storytellers surrounded by listeners, street music, market-type cafes and eateries, : children, young people, families, couples, elders. Everyone comes to The Square in Marrakech at night.

It's an experience. To be honest as great as our holiday in Marrakesh was. I was not too impressed with the Medina. You just got hassled from start to finish and the deeper into the Medina you get, the more hostile it starts to feel. It felt like a thrdr world country as the places to eat and drink were very basic and they will try and rip you off. Our companions had paid for the drinks and as I went to pay again not realising they were all too ready to accept my money again for the bill despite our guest leaving a generous tip.

Busy place with good choices.. We had a good guide & this is pretty important in the maze that is a Moroccon Medina. Beautiful palaces, mosques and all the usual people selling everything that you would expect in this huge market. Also a great choice of places to eat. I had rabbit (it appeared to be a whole one).

Vibrant and exciting. It's a good place to have a glance at the lives of locals. This Medina is very old yet vibrant, colorful, and interesting with everything in it-houses and lots of shops. The alleys are small and have many turns so you have to be observant or you will get lost. According to our tour guide, there are 12,000 shops in this Medina! Make sure you haggle (start at 30% of the original price according to our guide!) before buying anything. And if you don't intend to buy a merchandise, don't bother asking or the vendor will insist on you buying the item you asked, to the point of following you. Pay attention to the street also, as there are motorcycles that can bump you if you are not attentive. It is generally safe though to walk around. It is near the mosque too.

wow. i have never experienced shopping liked it, i have never been to a country where your barter for goods, even the taxis in and out the centre!!! in a week i went four times couldnt get enough of the experience and the local people bustling around, was even surprised to see and old guy making dentures sitting on a stool in the medina!

Crazy chaotic place. This place is just crazy. Scooters weaving in and out of people and lots of people ready to take your money! Its once crazy place but you have to visit to say you have been there - even if it is only once

A must for travellers visiting Marrakech. You cannot visit this city and not go to the medina of marrakech / jemaa el fna - it is the core of marrakech. Make sure you bargain, buy a moroccan keepsake (vases are a must!)

So much fun!. This old medina is huge, with so many shops and restaurants and riads, snake charmers, monkey handlers, orange juice vendors, spices, clothing, "antiques" and antiques... And what a place to haggle! Find out what fair prices are ahead of time, and dive in with a sense of humor and ramp up the drama. The shopkeepers are friendly and very funny... I could stay there all day. Although complex, it's pretty easy to find your way back when you are lost, the people very laid back... Be sure to go to the square at night, it really comes alive!

Not a patch on the Fes Medina. This place is ruined by the uncontrolled use of motorbikes and scooters in confined spaces. They are noisy, dangerous and polluting - this is shocking for breathing and food hygiene. some of the young riders are just cowboys who are very intimidating. Without these it is bustling and colourful and could be really nice. If you want to keep attracting tourists get the motorbikes out now before they make the place totally unbearable.

Bonkers . Wow what a crazy place the smells sights and the madness keep an eye on where you are going in the souks it is a proper maze be prepared for everything ,money is the key from the snake man to the monkeys to the henna ladies the guy you think is being nice to show your the way ,it's all about the dirhams ...but a must to see

Huge market. I found La Medina a bit intimidate surrounding by cars ..people ..donkeys coming and going ..A bit crazy tour we had ..Our rep warned us about pickpockets and theft in the surroundings of Medina. But amazing place ; a big market where you can find from a needle to the Aladin magic carpet.

Unique and authentic, if a bit rough. The old, walled Medina remains the heart of Marrakesh and is a must see sight in North Africa, although that does not mean it's always pleasant. It is where the medieval world meets the modern life. The winding alleys, ancient architecture, decorated mosques and bustling souks are the backdrop for daily life continuing here as it has for centuries. However, that means that as well as being interesting and at times beautiful, it is also dirty, smelly and challenging to maneuver, with some annoying touts and related frustrations. But that is because it is a real place with real people, not just an artificial or soulless recreation. It was substantially bigger than I expected. It was also frankly much less touristy than other impressive ancient sights throughout the world (although much activity is focused on the tourist industry, there are substantially more local people around - or Moroccans visiting from other cities - than foreign tourists). Not much left like this in the world, but I can see why it turns off some tourists who are hoping for a hassle free, packaged and antiseptic experience.

Hate this place, tourist trap, pushy rude con artists everywhere. Been here during the day yesterday , walked around and some nice bits like Moroccan lamps etc then the usual tat. Everyone hassling you, eyeing you up to rip you off, people calling to you, women trying to sell henna for your hand. If someone tries to help you in ANY way like show you directions DO NOT go with them as they are trying to rob you/rip you off or simply demand money from you for their help even though they will besides friendly and insist they don't want anything.We just came from having food at a stall called Chez el Maihdi Chraibi where super nice friendly guy will sit you down , you order 3 things they bring you 6 and you pay extortionately fir the privilege . Everyone wants to rip you off , I would say avoid this place as nothing redeemable about it, awful , chaotic and just people wanting to rip you off. But I have come to realise this is pretty much Marrakesh unfortunately !!

Another world. Worth experiencing, especially at night that's when it truly comes alive with all strange types of acts and amazing foods, the smells are unbelievable. Be prepared to be mithered to death by the people in the food stalls though!
Enjoyable. Experienced the whole feeling of what I imagined Morocco to be. Full of all kinds of merchandise.Friendly people.

Such a shame.... A little disappointed with the Medina, mainly because there's too much pollution from all the boys on mopeds racing around the narrow streets which really should be pedestrians only, and the drains when it's particularly hot.

Good day out. The medina was a very beautiful place full of culture! The medina is massive with over 6,000 souks!! You can booked a guided tour with your rep which I highly recommend as you get lost and dragged into all the shops you can see traditional trades still being used today by the families which is fantastic, the outdoor stalls are full of plenty of modern and traditional items for sale which make great presents! the locals love a good barter for prices so have a bit of fun there, the carpets,spices and lanterns are a must present but make sure if your going to have henna by the women in the open area agree a price first !!! as they like to start drawing then when finished charge a huge amount so be careful if they start and mention more money just get up and leave they can get quite angry! Also don't take photos of the locals or snake/monkey charmers as they expect tips so if you don't want to pay don't take photos or allow them to put the animals on you. All in all it's full of fun and culture, beautiful place definitely worth a visit, all I can say if enjoy and have a good barter and chat with the locals !

Arabian Nights. Make sure to visit at night as well as day time as its two totally different experiences. Don't go too early on a friday either as most shops remain closed until later in the morning. A very cool experience wandering through the market. Highly recommended!
busy and lively. a huge varity of sellers and stalls, variable food and drinks....entertaining to pass through..and experience the local charm....

Nothing else like it!. Where to start with this place?! There really is nowhere else like it. First went on our first night in Marrakech and we were totally blown away. It can be quite overwhelming at first as it is crazy busy, I had read reviews and thought I knew what to expect but really nothing can prepare you. Literally an overload for the senses! At night the square is lit up with entertainers, dancers, musicians as well as the usual food stalls and market sellers. By day it is more tame but still so busy! You WILL get lost, no doubt about it, but that is the magic of it :) Some top tips...• Do not let yourself get taken in by henna ladies! Within 5 mins of our first trip to the Medina I had a lady trying to sell me a henna tattoo, and before I could even choose one from her book she had drawn her own design up my arm and then charged me 100MAD for it (this was after bartering!!)• Don't go near to the monkeys if you don't want a picture with them. I personally found it very sad to see chained monkeys, but as soon as you walk near them the guys put them on your shoulder and get you to have a photo- they did this to my boyfriend and again we were made to pay a ridiculous price! • Barter and haggle to your hearts content :) a good tip I learnt is to say your final price, and then walk away, if the seller has a genuine price set they will let you walk away, if their price was too much they will call you back and continue to barter with you. • wear sunglasses and don't get eye contact if you don't want to get called to.• females- definitely cover up if you don't want to stand out. Embrace the dressing modestly culture! You can find some beautiful clothes there too, if you want to feel more comfortable a head scarf wouldn't be a bad idea but definitely not necessary. • Bring some coins if you want to take photos of the stalls (you definitely will!!) bring various denominations of cash to make it easier to haggle. • A cab from anywhere in town should be no more than 15-20 MAD/ dirham.
