We didn't learn this till a few days in and believe me the taxi drivers are more than happy to rip off tourists! Especially if going to or from a nice hotel! Definitely confirm a price before getting in the cab. • if you need directions ask a stall owner rather than a local stranger as they may lead you somewhere and try to charge you.• keep your eyes and ears peeled as motorbike / scooter drivers go crazy down the market alleys! • lovey Moroccan restaurants around the edges, most with rooftop views.• Enjoy and get lost! There really is nowhere else like it :)
Magic place Marrakech night day. Just loved the Adama Resort 5 star great value , Staff excellent , great facilities , quiet , will come back again

A must on your trip to Marrakech. The smells and sights of the medina are incredible. Have a bunch of small bills/coins for taking pictures of things such as snake charmers. Don't pay more than 25% of the original asking price for items.

Crazy medina . I went to Marrakech and definitely like it it's crazy city, but really cool and was busy I did the tour in the medina was nice but little crowded. The people were nice if you think in visiting Marrakech highly recommended u must visit.

La Medina. Come to Marrakech on a regular basis, and each time I am amazed by this magical place, morning afternoon evening ..... so different, You gotta try to come and visit at different time of the day, still a great place, MUST GO PLACE

Delivered on the hustle and bustle you expect. A veritable feast for the senses...all of them. It's busy, has loads going on. If you're willing to imerse yourself into the spirit of Marrakech it could be very enjoyable. Some beautiful pieces for the home to be found. If only I had a hotel to design... ☺
market square. this is a very different place.It is extremely busy with many stalls and snake charmers, water carriers.If you visit in the daytime it is not as busy but can be daunting at night.

Crazy and buzzing.. A very stimulating experience both during the day and at night when the food stalls are in full swing. The streets throughout the medina are small, not generally named, and can be busy with people, animals and the every present moped/scooter careening around right corners. Just be careful of the scooters as some go very fast. During the day it's a different experience than at night. And depending where you are, it can be a little intense with the locals pursuing you to buy something - just say no and keep moving, otherwise you can easily feel infringed. I did not buy anything there as all the merchandise looked like it came out of a shipping container from China. Otherwise a central experience you need to do and whether or not you like it will depend upon how open you are to letting yourself emerge into it.

fantastic place. if you go to Marrakech this is a must do. I highly recommended for first time visitors a private tour guide. They are not expensive.I visited with Marrakech private tour and my guide was Nour. Do bargain, very typical place in Marrakech

Magical experience. Wandering through the medina can be an amazing experience if you are in the right mood - there´s a lot going on there so you should be ready to be surrounded by crowds, to be approached by the Morrocans and to absorb a thousand of impressions at once. Despite the popular belief, apart from the pickopocketers, there is nothing to worry about (even for solo women) if you just follow a couple of basic rules: 1) dress appropriately (loose clothes, long sleeves and long pants), 2) walk on the right side of the street at all times, 3) stay concious of your surroundings and take good care of your valuables, 4) don´t even start discussing the price of something you are not interested in buying, 5) don´t stay out at late evenings. Please don´t get annoyed by people trying to sell you their stuff even if they follow you for a couple of meters (or blocks) - souk is the place to go shopping and this is the part of the Moroccan culture that you came to discover, so it´s unfair to complain about it. If you are not interested, just tell them, firmly, but politely, that you don´t need any of it. And the most important thing - enjoy the experience!

Step back in time. Some people stay in modern five star hotels elsewhere in the city but I have no idea why. The Medina is the place to stay, shop and eat. Narrow alleys, beautiful Riads, the souks and the restaurants are heart of Marrakesh. The Square at night is a must with its traders, street food, musicians and magicians.

Thank you Mostapha - MARRAKECHDAYTRIPS. We walked around the medina with a tour guide organised by Marrakechdaytrips , com and avoided all the hassle people complain about. It was worth to pay for a tour as it can be annoying to have tons of people trying to sell you stuff all the time. All kinds of shopping, snake charmers, dancers, food everywhere. Crowded lots of hustle bustle. interesting visit - this a must because it really define Marrakech and Morocco - i would recommend to hire a guide because we can get lost easily and waste time

Medina. Lots to see in the square but go with caution and protect your valuables. DO NOT get henna from the ladies there they will try to mug you off for all your money even if you agree a price and the henna looks terrible! All the restaurants will try to coax you in so unless you want to eat there (they all are similar) then just be polite and say la chakran (no thank you) and they should leave you or try to persuade you to visit later. If you play the fishing rod game just keep an eye of the timer as hey charge you for 10 mins but will try to let you run over so you pay more. The smoothies are great and cost about 80pence!
Still buzzing. Super exciting, evocative, stimulating and yet mannered and not at all threatening. Marrakech should be proud to have maintained a traditional souk in this day and age
Nice place. It was a nice place to take a walk. Especially, when the sun goes down and the medina is full of people.
A vibrant and crazy place- sensual overload!. Don`t eat all day before arriving here at night-plenty of food to consume! A myriad of sights, smells and sounds.....the heart of Marrakech :-)

Too full of hawkers. Thieves and dishonest people.. Went on the first day. Had a boy dip my pocket and steal my phone. Luckily confronted him and got it back. Loads of hawkers for food. Henna. And other bits of tat as well as the many stools of clothes etc. Best part was going into one of the restaurants with an upstairs terrace when you can look down on all the crazy madness below. If you must go. Then I advise going during day time. And be extra cautious if going as just females. If you can't be stern with the locals who are mostly rude and pushy, they will target and fleece you for cash.

Heart of the Morocco is Marrakesh . The first city for us was Marrakesh when we arrived Morocco. We stayed old Medina. Most of foreigners prefer to stay here because of closer area. We didn't have any reservations to accommodation. We just checked around and took a look and price. We selected cleaner one and of course cheapest one. It was also so closed the square of Cemael fna.(i am not sure, how it sould write) . Be carriful to tattoo women in the square. All of them want to make henna and take more money than reality. If you want to take a picture, you have to pay about 1 dolar. But you can bargain in there. All people in morocco are so friendly and helpful. But some of them want money if they help you to go somewhere. Despite everything i would recommend you to go there.
A feast for the senses. Go at night and you'll be overwhelmed by the sights, sounds and smells of this vibrant and lively place

The Place To Be!. This is what Marrakech is all about! The Medina is where you have el fnaa square and jamaa el fnaa alongside the souk, the restaurants, horse rides, snake charming, monkey holding, local bars...such amazing atmosphere!

Very good Medinah but a bit devoted to tourists. It's a good place to walk around. Get a guided tour, it worth it. Be careful to young boys trying to talk to you and also be careful about scams and false things they try to sell. Beside it, enjoy.

Very busy. Great entertainment . This place has lots of entertainment to offer. It's beautiful to see the Moroccan culture. Henna, dancing, lots of different kinds of foods to try. Plenty of cultural things to buy from clothing to house decorations to fragrances. Worth a visit for sure!!!
Wow. Colourful, fragrant, good and bad. Hustle and bustle. I had never experienced anything like this before! Loved

WOW. This is one experience I shall never forget. The noise, the smells are overwelming if you go into one of the many cafes with upstairs balconys the light are amazing. Dont go if you are squeamish or a vegy.
A must do!. A trip to Marrakesh is not complete without a visit here by night to enjoy the atmosphere food and music AND of course the markets

Go at night . The medina is world class. More action than in Cairo or Damascus. The only annoying thing is the touts that want to take you to their store or the snake charmers. Stand 1 - Aicha is the best. I come back time and time again for grilled meat. I have never gotten sick.

Dirty and dangerous. This is similar to other medinas, But dangerous. The people are driving motor bikes in the roads/alley ways and are on their phones, talking and texting. Not a lot of fun. The cats are in very poor shape and at times depressing.

Busy, exciting and full of culture. We visited the city 3 times over our holiday we enjoyed it that much.The moroccon people were very friendly and chatty. You have to remember they are trying to make a living and a polite 'no thanks' and a smile go a long way! Definately a must see place, full of culture and heritage.Advice: Stay away from henna ladies, snakes and monkeys in the centre square, be polite and you will be fine!! The best toilets to use are at KCF near the mosque

The most hectic market you will ever visit. Think of very narrow streets, very hot, small shops with their wares spilling out into the streets. People jostling each other and competing for space to walk, add in motorbikes, motorbikes with a trailer and a sheep in the trailer and it all sounds a nightmare! At the same time it is exciting and quite exotic. Be prepared to be hassled if you stop to look or just stopped on the street but it is all part of the experiance

Guided shopping trip. You need to have a clear idea of what you want to see if you tackle the medina - either ceramic or leather or the food area where they have amazing spices- store holders get offended if you don't haggle but it can be exhausting- as soon as you handle an item it indicates that a transaction is about to start! Keep your wits about you - also in the last two years they have set up artisan cooperatives where the locals get a fair price for their hard work - ask your guide but they will be reluctant to take you as they get a cut of the shops that they take you to - many lovely artefacts to buy but make sure that you dictate the price- happy haggling

Amazing city. A fantastic place to visit, 3-4 days is plenty as you could get fed up with the souks and being hassled by then, a trip to the Atlas Mountains is a must and also a guided city tour, don't go in September as temperatures just reached 46c. There are a couple restaurants serving alcohol, we avoided the street food as wasnt sure how it was kept 'safe' with the extreme temperatures!

Keep right and enjoy the bargain. It is all about bargain and keeping on the right side of the road!! Get lost in the little street and you just ask for Jemaa el-fnaa and you will be back to the start!!

There is nothing like this. The medinas can be very intimidating at first. The streets are narrow, and they are crowded. But once you get over your initial shock, they are fascinating. We spent a lot of time in the medina, and we loved it. So many delicious restaurants that cost under 150 DAR for a full meal! Amazing place!
Go get lost. Be ready to embrace getting lost in this maze and wandering to look at a new sight around every corner. We stayed in riads in the medina and shopped a lot too.

Worst market experience ever . I've been to several markets in asia, Europe , South America, Middle East and this is by far the worst everPeople are incredibly rude - calling me hey you China just to get me to visit their shops. When I tried to negotiate on prices they ask if i wanted free stuff instead, making snide comments eg - are you out of my mind , you are crazy, please get out. There were many beggars pulling your clothes asking for money food drinks etc. Some start shouting as well when you wave them away. There were guys on motorbikes going very fast inside the medina , a few almost hit me and some glared at me when I was in the way. This should have been banned - it's dangerous for shoppers on foot.Only good out of this market visit - I did not spend any money.

Red city Cool city. Morocc has become a very known place for tourism with it's cultural diversity and the very welcoming people, and marrakech, the red city as the locals call it, is the most famous now among all the cities in morocco, it offers a peacefull trip inside the old medina surounded by the rempards and it offers also a special night life style if you are into going out at night. It is really worth it.

Vibrant atmosphere . This is a dynamic and vibrant place. For a westerner it is difficult to describe. You can see snake charmers to herbs merchant. Except to be "harassed" by Street sellers and local merchants. The whole Madina is full of small streets and merchant stalls. Never felt unsecure but was very aware that I was a tourist :) Bargain hard if you want to buy something.

Fantastic place, you may get scammed.. It's a great place to visit with a really great atmosphere, I recommend visiting it at night (after the sunset), but you should be aware of scammers there they may try to sell you overpriced stuff, or try to convince that an item is very old and valuable.

Great fun but have your wits about you!. The Old town is brilliant fun to walk about in but keep your wits about you. You'll be dodging cars, motorbikes, cycles, donkeys, trolleys and shopkeepers ;) make sure you stay somewhere relaxing where you can escape the hustle and bustle. If you accept help or directions from a local be prepared to pay them. The best thing to do is acknowledge them and say "no thanks" and walk on if you don't need help. Going to the toilet - you'll need to pay. 1dh was the usual rate when I was here :) ATMs can be tricky to find but are marked on your tourist map.

Intrigue. I love this place. Though I did use my iPhone on GPS to keep from getting totally lost. The narrow, winding streets are full of intriguing sights. Merchants ply their trades and will often invite you in to their shops. Be polite and respectful. I speak French and find that if I am dressed casually and without fanfare, and take a deliberate approach to show I know what I am doing, they left me alone. Searching for that special silver pendant, I visited a number of shops in the jewellery street between the Bahi Palace and F'na. I had some great encounters and realised that as I admired their wares and asked about them, they would be only too pleased to show me items for me to appreciate. While they may not have had exactly what I was looking for, they bade me a sincere farewell, without a trace of trying to prevent me leaving. Rich experience for me, and eventual success I'm my quest.

Hated it. I would rather say that if you the chance; stay in a hotel and not in a Medina in Marrakesh; it is going to be much safe and easier to get by. Most medinas are in those Marrakesh labirynths and you can get easly lost and mugged.

amazing. a place worth visiting. we had a lovely day and a very good guide, he showed us around everything and explained things as we walked through. this was a very good visit. there is alot to see, night time is even better as the weather cools down and alot livelier. we really enjoyed the trip, hope to go again as we have'nt had enough, thinking of going again next year.

Hot and bargaining. went to medina by shuttle from hotelvery busy and lots to see will not take kids next time as we were constantly hassled they did not understand the word NO!saw snake charmers who were quite aggressive and the monkeys looked malnourished

Real life. Third time of staying in Marrakesh and we always stay in the medina. Why visit a country for its culture and base yourself in a hotel miles away? Yes you have the square enjoyed by locals and travellers alike, the souks great for trying out your bargaining skills, but this is also where locals live, work and get together.All manner of things are manufacured by hand here too. Every thing from leather goods to carpentry to ironwork.Its also kept clean by an army of street scene operatives. Its busy, but its safe feeling too and when in Marrakesh I couldn't consider staying anywhere else.

Get lost. Or hire a guide. Expert map-reading skills are not going to help you much in here. Just keep walking and eventually you’ll reach a landmark or a road, although considering the almost complete lack of signage this isn’t going to help much either. Best make peace with the prospect of getting completely lost and ignore the calls from locals trying to get you even more lost (for their own benefit) until you are ready to call or pay someone to get you back to where you want to be.

Stinky city, crazy drivers, barely any AC anywhere. Marrakech is a crazy place which stinks, there are no road rules with motorcycles riding on the pavement. Most people barely speak any English and are quite moody. The airport is a shambles, be prepared to show you passport 10 times and fill in the same arrival card to leave. As for the so called VIP lounge, be prepared for a shock. More like local cafe. We certainly won't be coming back in a hurry.

Awesome Local Shopping!. This place was amazing!!!! A must do! Almost surreal because its something you see only in movies or on TV. Shop colorful bags, shoes, scarfs, blankets and POM POMs everywhere! EVERYONE SPEAKS ENGLISH SO BE CAREFUL WHAT YOU SAY!TAKE LOCAL CASHBARGIN FOR EVERYTHING, MAKE DEALS IF YOU'RE BUYING MORE THAN ONEIt can be a little overwhelming at first because all the vendors are talking to you trying to get you to go into their shops and sell you their goods. You just have to be firm with them and only go into the shop if you really might want to buy something from it. They will keep you in there showing you everything they have. Its huge and you want to see as much as you can so say no thank you and keep walking.

A hive of activity. Once you digest the hustle & bustle of the volumes of people, get past the touristy front stalls selling their cheap poor quality rubbish then this place is truly a marvel. Walk deep into the Medina and enjoy this place like it should be enjoyed. I would highly recommend it

The heart of marrakeah. Colours, shops, spices, this is the hearth of Marrakech. You have to visit it but don't expect to find something relaxing. Two days is enough! Shop owners are too intrusive, there are motorbike running everywhere fast.

Nice but touristy. Very lively and touristy in parts but loved the more authentic parts like the mosque (beautiful architecture) and morrocan baths (segregated - great for relaxing and tea) Enjoy but stay clear of monkeys and tourist hustlers !!
Nice and dirty. Overall a nice experience. Beware of bandits, unsolicited advice and undercooked food. Spent two days on the loo with 39 °C fever, had to take antibiotics for it to get better.

Guaranteed to get lost . Our visit was a relatively quick one as my boys didn't really want to shop but I enjoyed it. Most people were very friendly and as long as you were prepared to say no then you had no hassles. The only "unfriendly" person we came across was when we wanted to take photos of the snake charmer and they insisted you pay them money. However as soon as I put my phone away without any photos taken he was fine.

Interesting. If traveling alone and I hate to say it and female be extra careful. Try not to get lost. Men will offer to help guide you out but then ask you for money. They can be quite aggressive. One lad told me I didn't give enough. I gave him the equivalent of 5 euros. He said he would take pounds euros whatever. Luckily a shop owner came to my rescue. No heavy presence of police in that area. Around the mosque yes.
Excellent memories. The Marrakech Medina is full of surprises. Behind many of thé discreet doors you can find hidden treasures, this is why it is better to have a guide.

Unlike anything I've ever experienced anywhere else. Where do you start with something so diverse?The fresh juices, dresses, crockery, ornaments, artwork, lanterns, shoes, food, sculpted ceramics and handcrafted metallic kitchenware, spices being hand-ground right in front of you, other detailed glass and wooden articles for a home, cushions, fabrics, fruits. If I had the room in my bags, I would have bought a whole tea set with matching multicoloured glasses and a metal tray, along with lanterns to place outside on the veranda, cushions and a big, main features hanging lantern for outdoor summer parties and BBQs. The only thing for me which really lets it down is that animals are not treated well there. I saw one kind man feeding starving, wild cats chicken legs, but there were countless others on top of that, and at least they were free. When you see de-fanged snakes being tamed by snake-charmers and monkeys pulling on their chains tying them to their owners who force them to flip and do tricks throughout the day, horses and donkeys walking on hot, dry concrete barely ever getting water and looking parched and tired, forced to pull a carriage purely for the enjoyment of the tourists, it's really depressing. It's an animal-lover's worst nightmare.Don't go for the animal welfare, but go for everything else. The culture and history and the completely different way of life.

Fes is Better. Marrakech is a historic city, and the souks and alleyways are definitely interesting, but honestly. I preferred the Old Medina of Fes. First of all, Fes is a pedestrianized area so no traffic is allowed through. We were able wander the streets completely relaxed and at our leisure. Moreover, peddlers in Fez are laid back. In Marrakech, on the other hand, you spend most of the time stressed out, trying to avoid motorcycles, cyclists, cars etc.. (I was hit by a cyclist, but no injuries). Peddlers are a little more aggressive. I'm glad we did Fes first, and if you are pressed for time in Morocco, I would skip Marrakech altogether.

a absolute must. you just have to go, try the orange juice stalls.avoid the snak men and monkey men and they wont hassle youbarter hard for everything but remember these people work to live not the other way round
Too crowded and to much hassle from locals. Too crowded and too busy on a hot day. The locals did not stop hounding us and when we asked for help navigated people expected tips! Ridiculous!

Amazing, crazy, busy!. The medina is fantastic!The sounds, smells and sites are too much to take it all at once. It seems a little overwhelming at first. Its busy with crowds most of the time but we found Friday was the quietest day and best for shopping.

Amazing place. An amazing place to visit. Although the you have to be careful of the locals as they are very pushy trying to get you to buy from them be wise and never take the first couple of prices haggle with them and you can normally greet them down to nearly half what they first asked for.
Market . Usual market a bit of hassle but nothing to strong. U just say no thanks and they leave u be. Avoid the snake charmers as they will insist on u buying pics if they put them on u .

History. The history of Marrakech is essentially concentrated in its impressive Medina. The buildings are centuries old and yet in excellent condition for some of them. So many things to see it is better to get a guide for the first visit and then explore it alone.

So much fun!. This was like stepping into a movie set. Be prepared to be cat-called from every stall, haggle and negotiate to the hilt, and just not know where to look next because there is so much to see! It was so much fun just wandering through the alleys seeing the hustle and bustle of locals and tourists alike. A great place to pick up some authentic Moroccan souvenirs like slippers, leather goods, silk scarves, and lanterns.

Taxis. We know what one bad apple can do. In Marrakech, the imperial city you can several bad apples called taxi drivers. Some them are just looking for an opportunity to charge 3 or 4 times what the regular fare should normally cost you, and then they will try to pretend that all is fine. Crooks I call them. Hopefully the city of Marrakech can help make an end to this by maybe sending out mystery riders to catch the bad guys in action...other than that the city in safe and pretty nice to visit ...

Busy, beautiful but be cautious. The medina and souk of Marrakech is one of the most lively I visited in Morocco but this positive aspect is mirrored by threats of mugging, pickpocketing or just being ripped off. As always in Morocco, the price you are offered for goods in the Souk is much beyond what they are worth, always haggle. I was cautious of my valuables and never had a thing taken out my pockets but I suspect it does happen. One night myself and three friends (all males) walked deep into the Souk to find somewhere to eat that might be cheaper and less touristy than the main square. As we walked further the streets became quieter and there were less and less stalls. A man started to lead us back towards the main square but suspecting he'd want money from us we insisted that we'd walk alone. He did not listen. It's worth noting, this was not just because of a language barrier since a member of our group speaks Arabic. After a while the first man left us and another man took his place, the two of them swapping roles as we walked. The second man insisted we pay the first although we had constantly said we would not do so, to both men. The second man became aggressive and threatened each of us with 'a problem' gesturing to his shorts as if he had a knife. Eventually we made it back to the familiar area of the souk unharmed, only shaken. Do not let this put you off visiting the Medina, only take this as a cautionary tale. Don't wander late at night without knowing where you are going. Do not let people follow you.
Good Atmosphere. There are many words to describe the Medina..... beautiful.... crazy.... traditional..... quaint..... a great place to get lost in

Something different from East and middle Europe. . Short streets, lot of sellers, orange juice, spices, cafes, motorcycles...soakes...one BIG soak. Right place where to develop your bargain culture. :)

walking into another world. I have been to Morocco before but it was my first time in Marrakech & of course I had to hit the Medina, but with a guide unless you have a compass and donkey. It is like stepping back into the past but into another world. The young men pride themselves on their bartering, but appreciate it even more if you get stuck in too. This is a city of hagglers so go for it .There are I kid you not thousands of traders in this Medina and I can bet that you will find something to barter for. Go visit the pharmacy where they have oils for everything, I kid you not as well as spices . A must see trip

Wow!. The medina of Marrakech is like nothing we've ever seen before (and we have traveled extensively through Africa, Asia and Europe) ! The sights the smells, the little corners and tights alleyways! Always keep and eye out for motorcycles, bikes and donkeys. You have no idea what's around each corner! We stayed in the Madina for 4 nights and eventually got comfortable in not getting lost - although they say getting lost in the walled city is one of the treasures of Marrakech! Enjoy, I know we did.

Varied . A huge square surrounded by cafes, bars and mosques. On the plus side there's lots to see and buy, on the downside though are the snake charmers, monkey owners and henna tattoo-ers who don't easily take "no" for an answer.

Its a must see. What a magical place. Its like seeing a part of old world history re-visited. There are some of the most gorgeous leather good and interior design things to buy that I've ever seen. I absolutely loved it.

Medina spectacular!. We stroll around the medina with a tour guide and avoided all the hassle people complain about. It was worth to pay for a tour as it can be annoying to have tons of people trying to sell you stuff all the time. As usual all tour guides take you to their friends artisans, we brought a lot of teas and Morrocan oil.

Never ending market! . Wow! What can I say, agree with lots of reviewers here it's a place must be seen but not a place for those who don't like being lost or feel overwhelmed walking in a crowded gigantic market. This souq is an Amazing place to buy traditional clothes, spices, oils and hand crafted goods, but over priced for what they should be. For me a souq is a place where you can get goods with bargains that are cheaper than any where else, but in this case everything was over priced and you think you are bargaining but really you'll end up paying the same amount as you would in any other market. Night time it turns out to be more colourful, as they set up numerous of food stalls, magic shows and some traditional acts. Be very careful with pick pockets and don't ask for dropping the price if you are not serious to buy. They won't like it and some shopkeepers can become very rude. Best time to go for shopping is early morning when there are less people, then the shopkeepers will listen to you! If you can't eat street food then don't worry there are plenty of good cafeterias and restaurants near by, you can dine in with a good price, in a cleaner and a calmer place.

Bargains galore. day time best for this as you can easily get lost,alleyways go everywhere.You have to haggle thou,what ever they say offer half,then if they dont match it shake your head and go to leave,they will ask you back and usually take half

Prepare to haggle. Went to the old market (Medina) twice due to my wife. On average the shopkeeper will be asking for 60% - 70% more so haggle hard. Be aware of the ladies doing henna in the square as they quote one price and ask for another once henna is done, also the henna will not last more than 2 days no matter what they say. Really good leather shop but be aware when they are wrapping!
Beautiful, day or night. The most happening spot in Marrakech! The old, walled part of the city. Be sure to take a map, or you risk getting lost.

Wonderful place, but constant hassle spoils it. It's a wonderful place with sights, sounds and smells (especially at night when the hot food stalls open) to overwhelm the senses.This was our 2nd visit here. 1st time was without kids 8 years previous. This time was with a 10 and 11 year old.My memory of the 1st trip was getting hassle constantly, night and day in every area. Stop to look at a map, sight, stool or anything and 2-3 people are on you, very forcefully trying to sell you something or get you into their shop. It really spoiled our enjoyment as you feel you have to constantly keep moving and can't relax. There is also the constant threat of having your wallet or purse lifted.This time around, with children was worse. We only spent an hour there as the hawkers now target you and your kids (two girls in my case ( which are soft targets and got quite scared at some points and they do not back off!We would not go back.It's a real shame, the place is magical but spoiled by the constant hassle. I appreciate it's a different culture but in such a poor country, a place with this many tourists becomes a massive target, to its detriment. It's not just an inconvenience, it's becomes the only thing you can focus on.We will be going to Essaouira next time as this is supposed to be authentic and less hassle.

A must see but be careful. . This is a must see when in Marrakech. Without visiting the medina you can never fully understand the city. Some sellers are friendly and they sell a range of goods from soap to shoes.However as 2 female travellers we did feel intimated by many of the workers. Be cautious and be ready to ignore the whistles, winks, stares and heckles.

Amazing vibes!. The vibes and the atmosphere is incredible, but if you are like me and don't like seeing animals being used for entertainment this is a place where you will have a hard time. Otherwise people are really nice and if want to go back in time and experience the real moroccan lifestyle, this is the place!
Highly Recommended. Close your eyes and imagine a winding, chaotic Medina filled with sights, sounds, smells and more. When you get there, it will meet if not exceed your wildest imagination.

What an experience. This is a must, visit twice once with a guide to get the local feel and history of the Souks then go back and have a wander around just taking in the colour and atmosphere of the place BRILLIANT

Crazy, beautiful, terrifying and a feast for the senses. I'm not quite sure where to start with the Medina. It was at once mad, crazy, beautiful, overwhelming, fascinating and terrifying. It is a feast for the senses. There is so much to look at and miles of Souks to explore.Things to beware of: the men walking round with snakes ready to drape them on your shoulders. I hate snakes, I'm petrified of them so this was a real fear for me, but if anyone approaches you just tell them very firmly to stay away from you and move off quickly. You do have to be on your guard and it did mean that I never felt particularly relaxed when walking round the Medina. Other things to beware of: the orange juice gave me a VERY upset stomach on my last day. They don't wash the glasses properly. On the whole, this is an unmissable experience. You basically have to go through the Medina if you're walking round Marrakech. It's the heart of the city and it really comes alive at night. We found a nice bar overlooking the Jemaa-El-Fnaa where we could enjoy the atmosphere with a refreshing drink. I would also recommend going shopping in the Souks in the evening - its thriving, and a lot of fun.Don't take any valuables. Don't take too much money out with you and just be aware of everything around you. But on the whole, it's incredible. Buy lots of spices and beautiful rugs and interesting teapots!

Thousand and one Night. We were in Marrakesh visiting the medina. It was very interesting, colorful and exciting! Still I would suggest not to go alone, even crime is that much of an issue, still some of the shop-owners can be a little aggressive by getting visitors in their shops. But all in once it is very interesting to visit!

In Marrakech? Must visit. The medinas of Marrakech are an experiece everyone should go through if visiting. There are a wide selection of shops/eateries etc. The one thing I didn't bank on was the hustle and bustle or the narrow walkways. In parts the area is a bit dirty and smelly however for the most part the medinas were fine.

Crazy..... What an experience! by day a bustling market with snake charmers and fresh juice stalls, by night thousands of people fill the square, the sound and smells of Africa, a nice change from Spain etc....
shopping with a difference. OMG. what an experience visiting the markets busy hectic crowded... overwhelmed...you have to barter for everything good fun

Must See!. When travelling to Marrakech you have the chose of staying in the new city or in the heart of the old town the medina. Offcourse you should opt for the hotel/riad in the medina, that gives you culture to breath in from the moment you open the front door of the hotel/riad.
5* ++++++. Amazing! Tasty food and negotiable prices for souvenirs! One of the best experiences! Been there for a week and enjoyed every moment!

CRAZY!. This medina is unlike anything else we have ever experienced in our lives, and we have travelled all over the world. I cannot say that any of us really enjoyed the experience as the merchants and other people on the streets would not leave us alone. I highly recommend hiring a guide, before you get to Morocco, and have them take you around. If not, make sure you have a good GPS, such as the citymaps2go App.
Full of life!. It is historically speaking a place to admire. This aside you can get lost thousand times and keep enjoying this piece of Africa.

Loved the medina!. Just be careful with those guys with snakes, they get very aggresive if you do not want to pay! And buy yourself a bottle of freshly pressed orange juice! And take a tea in a roof terrace around the medina!

JUST SAY NO!!!. Do not go the the Medina, unless you want to be hassled and ripped off, if they say it's FREE it's not and little kids pester you to give them your Pepsi or what ever you happen to be drinking at the time.I've been to Medina in Egypt and Tunisia and the Medina in Marrakech is the worst and most aggressive experience by a country mile!!

Got to be seen to be believed!. This is just the most hectic place ever! I didn't know if it felt like I was at a festival or a riot!From snake charmers, men with monkeys, henna artists and beggars - it has it all. At night it truly comes alive with the street food stalls out also.Once you get used to being asked to "look around my shop" for the thousand time, it's really ok. However I did feel really safe and was never intimidated by any of the shop owners.We much preferred going deeper into the Souks, down the narrow roads where the shop owners were less in your face. You are expected to haggle and they take it as an insult if you don't.We were helped out several times by men (when we appeared lost) to be shown the way, which we thought would be a money making scheme but more often than not it was just to show us where their uncle/cousin/brother had their shop!This is definitely a must see - just for the culture shock!!

scary at night. visited in the evening, which was recommended due to the temperature. The souk itself is a maze of alleyways. Yes people are trying to garner your business and drag you into see there goods, but a polite no thank you WITH A SMILE, was enough to stop them. Getting out of the souk was a nightmare, which turned very scary. We had asked some people for directions and they pointed us in a direction, which seemed to be going down smaller and smaller alleys, not going out into the wider main area. we stopped again to ask a couple of ladies who were buying food at a stand, and they looked alarmed and told us we had been sent in completely the wrong direction, and not to follow anyone and only ask women for directions. A couple of moments later one of the men we had asked directions of appeared and started shouting at the lady, her response was not good.We followed her advice, and only asked women for directions, and about 25 mins later we made it out into the main square.We did return to the souk, in daylight and it was a far better experience.

Crazy. Wild Place.. All kinds of shopping, snake charmers, dancers, food everywhere. Crowded lots of hustle bustle. Can't stand too long but great place to spend a few hours just people watching if nothing else.
Great Medina. Whenever I come to Marrakech, I have to walk in the medina, to feel the vibrant atmosphere, to watch people, to drink a meant tea and to buy some goods.

Amazing. Bit scary at first but by end of our stay totally comfortable walking round day & night just be polite at sellers who try to hassle you & they move on to other people lol loved it at night time

Complete culture shock but totally magical. Visited the Medina early morning in the month of August and the temp was 42 degrees. We managed to find plenty of shade and places to get cool drinks.The medina is busy day and night though far more crowded in the evening. I would recommend visiting in the evening if you don't have young or elderly people in your group.Haggle and stick to what you say, they really don't like it when you change your mind. Only distressing sight was the horse and cart... not a sight for animal lovers.

A great experience. Mostly very wonderful moments but a few just plain horrible!. I have to say this; overall its was a lovely and interesting place. BUT... there was some very strange things that threw us out of our comfort zones. Although this is not necessarily a bad thing as its good to be shook up a bit, it got a bit annoying and too persistent to be enjoyable. What I mean by that is when we went to the Souks (which are the hundreds of year old twisty, turney shopping streets that look like they’ve come out of an Indiana Jones movie!), but Im getting ahead of myself here.We had a few trips out to Marrakesh day and night and especially the old town where the souks are (as mentioned previously). Well to say that’s an experience is an understatement. What you have to understand is that this is a very old city that fuels itself with bartering and trying to get the best deals out of whoever wants to buy their stuff. You have to know how to deal with it and try to enjoy it. But that’s not the first issue I had with the place. As soon as I put my foot to the pavement from the coach, the touts all come flocking towards you to offer you exclusive trips around the souks and the places of interest. They spout on that they are the “official” tour guides of the place you are staying at... but they are most definitely not... all lies and they will not leave you alone. In the guide books they say that a simple clear “no thank you” will deter them and they will say thank you and turn away. Rubbish! I couldn’t get rid of this guy when all I tried to say is we wanted to do this on our own and had a limited time there (which we did of 3 hours). It eventually got through to him that he was now truly annoying me. I told him so and said in not quite friendly terms if he didn’t go away it may get very unpleaent as you are not listening to me and now your harassing me. This is all within 10 minutes of getting off the coach. Doesn’t put you in the best of moods to then go off a try and get yourself a good deal in the souks. And to top all that as we walked on another one came up, said to me “he was annoying wasn’t he?” and then started with the same guff as the last on!!!! Anyway once we got rid off these idiots we made our way into Jemaa el-Fnaa - which is the main square that lead to the souks. Absolutely chaotic but fantastic. Its used as a mad kind of intersection for traffic in the day but at nights gets closed off and they have a massive food market, street vendors selling all sorts of food and street entertainers. Anyway the souks are incredible, claustrophobic, and fascinating. Ive never experienced anything like it. It really is like a film set and the streets are narrow, covered above by wood panels and corrugated metal stretched across the buildings to offer a bit of shade from the relentless hot sun. This all gives it a mystical atmosphere and a twilight feel. They sell everything here, spices, leather goods, shoes, hats are the specialities but lots of knock off stuff and fakes that you cant tell the difference from the real ones.You have to barter and haggle for everything, even if you want to buy a can of coke! Its just how it is and they love to do it. I wanted a leather old school satchel and had a shop around, eventually after again lots of “come here sir and see my wears” we found a great shop that had just what I wanted. The prices start ridiculously high and you have to make a judgement and offer a 1/5 of that price. For example the one I wanted was 1200 dirham which is the equivalent of £94. So I offered £18. They look at you as if your mad (but this is all done very good natured) and then they take about £20 off. I say nope that nowhere near what I want to pay. They ask again what I want to pay and I say the most Ill go up to is £25. Again its “my friend I cant sell it for that, how about £50?”. And back and forth it goes until I decided to say well thanks but I’ll look somewhere else and they gently put a hand on your shoulder and say “how about £30?”. Which is exactly what I wanted to pay anyway and no higher. We shake hands and its a done deal. Lots of fun that and that’s why people really like it.But saying this it was then kind of spoilt as they tried to offload a very fake looking £50 note saying that they couldn't exchange it and could we buy it off them? Not very fair that and not selling me this "amazing experience" you read so much about from other reviewers.So, after a while you do get lost and have to use the Mosque Tower as a ref point to get back to where you started. Problem is you can’t always see it due to the coverings above and how unbelievably narrow the streets become. You have to walk sideways as there is produce on either side and they really do pester you (but in a friendly way). Another things to look out for is people offering you a way out, only to find out they are leading you to a shop they own, or a friends, a sisters etc... That’s annoying and we nearly fell fowl of that one, you just end up saying “no thank you, I think your taking me somewhere I don’t want to go”. Trying to take pictures is hard in there too as someone, somewhere will say that you need to give money to take them. Basically you have to pay for everything in there! All in all very, very interesting but like I said it does throw you well and truly out of your comfort zone. My youngest son loved it as he bought a fez; he’s always wanted a proper one and had a great time with the very friendly guy who sold it to him. My eldest enjoyed it to a point, but was fed up with the constant mithering. My partner said the same but even more so, she just didn’t like it at all. Too closed in for her and personal space invaded. Totally got where she was coming from but you have to try and rise above it.Finally “escaping” the ancient consumer jungle we headed for a cafe and had a lovely fresh orange juice. And got a chance to relax and talk over what we had seen and then it was time for the coach back. Now the night time experience is totally different and truly amazing... we all enjoyed that. The square transforms into something completely different. Yes again there is mithering but in a different way, this time they want you in their pop-up café’s. So we got into one and the food was beautiful, all sorts of dipping sauces for your kebabs, soups with lots of spices and the most tasty bread Ive ever eaten. The owners are friendly and offer free fizzy drinks so not too bad, and incredibly cheap (about £18 for all 4 of us, including starters, mains, soups, drinks). So with our bellies full, we fancied one of the much talked about freshly squeezed orange juice stalls that everyone talks about there. And for good reason... best juice I think I’ve ever had. The oranges there are huge and bright in colour, and the juice they get out of them is ridiculous, like a running tap!!! All done in front of you and then chilled very quickly in this blast chiller they all seem to have. Again my youngest fell in love with it and had quite a few. So cheap too, about 25p for the equivalent of a pint glass. After this we went to one of the sky cafe’s (which are basically café’s on top of the roofs surrounding the square), very stylish and friendly again, but with a lot of the more well-to-do locals having milkshakes and coffee’s. From here you can see all the square and well into Marrakesh itself, lots of bright lights and entertainment. This was worth it just for the view. Very beautiful. Walking back to the coach we looked at snake charmers, transvestite dancers (apparently a local custom for men to dress as women and entertain) magicians (really good) and storytellers. Those we couldn’t understand but didn’t really need to as they looked amazing and were all very much into the visual side of storytelling. All in all very enjoyable and I would love to do that again.

over-hyped tourist mecca. was hoping for a slice of morocco - make charmers, musicians, and obviously some stuff aimed at the tourist. but place stank of horse piss, was noisy, and very little to see culturally

A good days haggling! . I have to admit, I thoroughly enjoyed my time in the Medina. I haggled for everything under the sun, watched the sun set from a rooftop bar, and had a hearty meal near jmaa el finaa. Loved it.You can't come to Marrakech and not hang here.

Something to see. The medina was certainly something to experience. While we enjoyed our visits, the extremely pushy salespeople in the square were off-putting to start. Once we ditched them and made our way through the medina, we had a great time exploring.
Hot & very busy!. We visited twice, once in the afternoon and once in the evening - the evening was far busier! Definitely an experience! The tour of the old and new city was good to do.

Hustle and bustle. Very busy, good experience, lots of bargaining, near new town, touch if you really want to buy, picked up some good deals, be careful when buying Saffron, mostly its fake else all good.
Exciting!!. Nice experience and adventure to walk in the souk. Be aware of the hassle, some people give you directions but they are actually guiding you to their shops.

Exotic. The medina is a fantastic experience. It will give you a full sensory blast. Make sure you have a plan, or a guide before you take it in. Easy to get lost, however, the people are friendly and welcoming. We purchased a rug and enjoyed the process

Interesting Medina but bring a map!. Medina is great to walk around, plenty to see, but be sure to bring a map as it is really easy to get lost. Also be weary of people offering to give you directions, they will take you a round about way to get to your destination and then ask for money :)

Great Medina, but have google maps pre loaded!. Awesome Medina, great fun to walk around and explore, only tip that I would have is to have google maps pre loaded on your phone so that you're able to navigate out of there haha. Be weary of people offering to help, they will always ask for money.
Hidden away little gem. This hidden away little gem in Marrakech is great is you want to see some of the history of the city

Might need a tour guide. It's quite confusing going around the medina and the people can get pushy to get you in their stores but it's a fantastic experience - one that you shouldn't miss - might be better spent with a tour guide :)

Guide tour. Was nice to get out of the hotel. Had a picture with a cobra and held a snake, you have to pay to do this, they will hassle you to pay more . I gave them £2 and they were not happy, they wanted £20. We didn't even ask for this, they pretty much put the snake over my shoulders before I knew anything about it, they then pushed my wife to take a picture saying its free. then they demanded money so i gave them some, they then argued that they wanted more, one man even told the other to get my wifes phone off her and delete the pictures. I thought £2 to take a picture with our own camera was an acceptable price to pay, especially when £2 goes a long way there. I didn't give in to there demands, pay what you feel is right and nothing more.

Brilliant medina. Gets busy in evenings but a lot of variety if wanting to shop and see spectacle in square is brilliant
Old city fascinating go back in time

Best after sunset. One of those unique places in the world - has to be experienced to be appreciated. Snake charmers (don't worry - easy to avoid if you are snake-phobic - just avoid getting close to the guys playing the pipe!), food sellers, artists, story tellers - you name it.Food outlets on the edges are not too pricy in allowing views in the day (Cafe de La France great for soft drinks ice cream in the day in our experience and Marrakshi restaurant at night (book earlier in the day for a window table to watch the masses and the sunset!)

Active at night shop by day less hassle. In Marrakech nothing happens until the sun sets they say it's to hot to work. But as sun dips in the city comes alive as if you where back home. It is very weird to see quiet an experience

Crazy square. What a place , fun ,exciting, crazy, rolled into one must be experienced. Very hot during the day time its like a Hugh circus place from snake charmers to monkeys , food stalls, dancers henna tattoo artists you name it its there and last well past mid night.
Mel hovell. Must see fantastic stalls music food snake charmers monkeys never seens so many people at night at a market

Great fun - be brave. I went with my three children and its a great place to visit both day and night. In the morning and early afternoon it is a lot quieter and calmer. Don't waste your money hiring a guide it is so easy to navigate your way around the souks and if you get lost there are plenty of people who will help you and direct you the right way. In the Medina there are snake charmers, men with monkeys (did not agree with that), fresh orange juice and mixed fruit juice sold by men in carts, henna tattoos. Always negotiate prices in the souks. I always go half and a tiny bit less and stick to your guns!!!! Dont look at people otherwise they think that you are interested.

Total chaos. This souk is amazing place to visit. If you dont like chaos go by daytime, if you want to experience all juicyness and authenticity and great street traditional food and street performers of there traditional music you deffenetly need to go at evenings, it's bomb chaos time. I loved to get lost in small streets all looks the same ;)

A stones throw from our hotel. The Medina is a hive of activity but comes alive at night, with its market stalls and food sellers. Plenty of art deco 1930's buildings around the square that house hotels and restaurants. The Souk forms the out skirts of the Square it is to say the least massive.Be prepared to haggle with the sellers.My only caution, is the ladies that will suddnely pounce on you (Ladies) and try to give a Henna tattoo and then charge you a ridiculous price. You just need to be firm with them.

Fascinating but Stressful!. I hired a guide to take us through the medina which was a smart move! I've travelled quite a bit and am good at reading maps but this medina, especially the souks, are confusing and jam-packed with people making it a stressful experience. Definitely go, but definitely hire a guide!

A reminder of Ali barber and the 40 theives. We stayed here in the Medina to get the real feel of what it is like. We soon found out that you had to be careful. Unfortunately there are many scams and tricks that go on here. Times are hard and they are doing it tough. One thing to remember is not to make eye contact or speak with the locals in the markets otherwise they don't leave you alone. Do not take photo's of them or they will ask for money and won't leave you alone until you pay them. We were tricked into paying money to someone whom we asked to give us directions. They lead us around then told us a friend would show us the rest of the way. Once we got there were asked to pay money. They followed us so we ended paying them money. The next day we didn't speak or look at anyone. We just looked straight through them. It felt rude but it did work. Nobody bothered us.Everywhere else in Marrakech was great.
Afternoon visit . Very nice city but bit daunting with all what you hear from other people enjoyed the trip no problems

A charming,tiresome place. The medina is the old part of town,you enter by traditional,historic entrances.And then you have to be careful:do not get overrun by motorcicles or bicicles,and do watch your bags,your jewelery and cameras.The medina is filled with life,culture,and temptation.The tourists are ,often,absent minded,the thieves alert.There is police,undercover,there is the police touristique,but there are more potential thieves in the medina than police.Once said,just stroll.You l need a container to schlepp all the itmes home,you discover,carpets,antique furniture.The dealers will mention a price ,which was invented in Thousand and one night,a fairy tale.Illusions.Do negotiate,since the Medina ist that-a place you learn not to be cheated.You will never win,but you will enjoy the sweet tea offered for free.Much of the product is imported from China,or other Asian countries,but do not worry.You need to be an expert to know the difference.Just remember:the sales people are serving you to make a living.They are not selling to entertain you.

Get lost and be ready to negotiate . Good time and I never really felt unsafe. The girls with us spent us into oblivion looking for the one really cool souvenir. Watch for the beggars and snake charmers... Literally!

The Magic of Morocco. I love coming to the Medina in the evenings, there a lot of street shows, Music and games. A very wide verity of Restaurants and street food to choose from .You will also find people that approach you to sell you stuff , but a simple Thank you in Moroccan which is CHOKRAN should get them out your way .Try one the Coffee Shops or Restaurants that's over looking the Square for a better view especially at night ! It's really Amazing .

This the original Marrakech. It's possible to get lost here, because the streets are so curving and winding. Not to worry. Most roads lead to a destination you understand. Walking through the souks is simply overwhelming. Keep your game face on though. When the merchants know you're interested they tend to keep the price high.This was a great experience seeing a part of real Moroccan life.

Colourful & Loud. A cacophony of sound greets you when you enter the Medina. There are stalls everywhere as well as characters offering anything and everything for sale!It can be a little intimidating but overall I found that the locals were very friendly and a polite no usually worked

A maze of alleys, souks and a kasbah. The perimeter of the medina is about 11 km. So, while it is easy to get lost, the problem is not insurmountable. Do not panic, just walk out and follow the medina walls in the direction of where you started. Moreover if you ask for Djema el Fna most people will tell you where to go. Only some youngsters give wrong information on purpose. Ask elderly shopkeepers. East of the medina is where the poor people live. On the West side there is the new city with a shopping mall and residential areas where the wealthy live. If you like shopping the medina with its souks will feel like paradise, though the bargaining process may me cumbersome. The Kasbah area on the South side of the medina is more spacious and relaxed. This is where the royal palace and some sights are. Personally I liked the gardens which are just outside the medina and more quiet.

Everything you would expect it to be.. It's said to be the biggest Medina in Africa and it goes on and on with stalls selling everything from tourist tat to shrunken heads. Prices are massively negotiable and we came away with some items for about 10% of the original asking price, so absolutely be prepared to haggle or you will pay far too much. There's always another stall selling the same thing around the corner, so if you don't get something for the best price, walk away and find it elsewhere.

Medina Choas. 3 days in the Medina. Great experience, culturally different. Souks entertaining with persistent sales approach. Will scare some off but fun with the right attitude. Some may take offence to the behaviour of a minority of men encountered in the streets. You will probably get lost at some stage.

Fab. I stayed in March 2016 thought I had left a review but must of forgot. So won't be a long review as brain fog sets it. Room was clean and tidy little cramped but that was OK lovely balcony. The staff was lovely. Check in easy. Weather was gorgeous. Food was OK I am fussy but my husband loved it. Pool area lovely. Still had to put towels out early to get a bed were you wanted it. Ideal hotel located in a nice area. You won't be disappointed x
Why would you come here?. My youngest son summed the medina uo best " it's just a busy, hot, smelly poundland" Has long lost any of the charm it once had and is just a tourist hell-hole. Avoid.
A dream come true. Anything I write would be marvelous since visiting Morroco was a dream I always had... I loved everything about this place. Don't forget to barg whenever you buy something.
Medina. Nice history attached we took a horse and carriage ride around the medina taking in the locals and the views beautiful place
Jamma el fna. one of the famous places in the world i like being in this square i usually go with my friends to drink harira ..soup.. and eat some food
Really interestinf. You get really immersed in the culture within this square. Just be careful of the locals trying to mislead you or give you the wrong directions.

You have to like the world of ' illusion '.. During the day you will get a glimpse of Moroccan life - men sipping coffee in cafés, a hot August sun on your head - but a dryheat , so don't be put off by August 40°. But don't for a singlemoment listen to the prices of a jewellery shop - they will quote you 800 Euros for something worth 30€. At nightime its a different story.

One of the best medinas in Morocco. Jemaa el Fna at the entrance to the medina of Marrakech is best experienced at night. The food options are varied. There are cafes and restaurants around the plaza and within the medina. Spend the day in the medina shopping. It's easy to get lost in there so remember your route. Fantastic souvenirs, leather goods, spices, incense, clothing, artisan crafts, and furniture if you dare to buy something that large. Carpets too! Expect to spend a lot of time oogling and then drinking tea while you are talked into buying something amazing.

Bargain shopping at medina. If you looking to buy something cheap, this is the place to visit. Make sure you have good haggling knowledge, if the asking price for a dress is price is 500 dirham, don't pay more than 150.
1001 night. Did you imagine how the medina looks like in your dreams or while reading 1001 night? That's exactly the Medina of Marrakesh for me. Colors, smells, people, architecture... Ahhh, enjoy!

A must see in Marrakech!. I've never quite seen anything like it! Very lively when I went- particularly towards the evening and late into the night as the temperatures started to drop. There are snake charmers, musicians and people selling all sorts of goods. A great place to get a sense of the variety of people in Marrakech and a little bit of culture.

Electric. ..!!!. This is what we came back to Marrakech for. Having visited the Medina and night market whilst on a day trip from Agidir. There just was not enough time to explore and enjoy all the fantastic street food. I fell in love with the idea when I found myself watching Jamie Oliver in Morocco and a special part of that was the night market and it's food on offer. During the day. There is nothing happening and the square is mostly deserted. Come sunset.... a whole new, yet old world reveals itself. . The food stalls come alive. There is so much on offer that you have a hard time choosing. We picked No.22, there was nothing particularly different about this one other than they had a rather novel way of getting your attention. Once seated they were exceptionally friendly and dare I say efficient. Given everything is cooked from fresh on rather primitive grills. They are rather quick knocking the food out.We ordered our soft drinks. No booze served at the stalls. Straight away we got warm bread brought to us. Then the charming fellow took our order. We had a bit of everything.Mixed Kebabs, Fried Prawns, Grilled Lamb Chops, Vegetable Tagine. Followed this up with fresh Baklava style pastries from a passing seller and Berber Whiskey (minted green tea).The whole lot was 360 Moroccan Dirahms. Approx £25 This is one of those places where you don't need to look at things too closely. In today's world of fastidious health and hygiene. One look at thier practises would send an EHO into an apoplectic fit. That said. Everything was served at a good core tempreture and none of us got ill,and we ate there twice as it was that good.Couple of pointers that will make your visit even more enjoyable. 1. If you fancy a glass of wine with your dinner? Take it with you in a coloured soft drinks bottle. They won't mind.2. Hand wipes or wet wipes. Take some with you and no greasy hands after.3. Dress comfortable. . It can be very warm and lots of people. Leave fashion for another day.4. Keep your mind open. They have been cooking and eating this way since before the bible was written.All in all. A superb street meal and an amazing experience. .

Chaotic. Shocking and quite scary, people are very aggressive and annoying, can be rud. People wil do anything to take your money then guide you somewhere then try to con you. It's an experience but can be daunting.

This is Marrakech. Since coming here 14 years ago, I fell in love with this place. The noise, smell, ambience, liveliness, list is endless. We have had great food here, stall hopping ! But no alcohol served .

Safe and supremely constantly chaotic touristic activity. No matter what you think you need or want to buy, loose yourself in the souks and indulge in local tradition of haggling. Even if you don't buy, you'll spend many happy hours having fun on doing this. You can strike many good deals on products (such as leather ones) that would cost 10 times the price in Occident. Very rarely shop keepers get upset but it ca happen. One has sworn at my daughter, another one was rude and lost our business (he ran after us for 200 yards trying to apologise but my wallet was by then fully sealed). The medina is amazing, every nook and cranny occupied by a shop of some sort. In the high heat of the afternoon many of them give up and decide to lie in a corner of the shop or on top of their merchandise and have an extensive nap. Walking in the medina also enables you to meet many locals and some are happy to have great conversations even if they know they won't have your business. However, do not underestimate the means employed to lure you into a transaction. You might be invited in the special almost ceremonious room at the back where a Touareg-looking guy will serve you tea and invite you to seat as a choice guest. You are no longer a man off the street but a highly respected and noble person. Before you a table, on this table products shown to you with expertise, in a secret ceremony-like atmosphere. Hard to say no. I did but enjoyed various ways these guys have developed to access your treasury and make you let go of some of your money. Be aware, but play the game of the medina which is an amazing experience, the best thing you will be doing in Marrakesh. Immerse yourself and enjoy.

As mad as a box of frogs. This place is crazy!If you want to feel like you're actually starring in James Bond movie, then you need to visit this place in the evening. It will blow you away. The smells, the sights and the sounds are all incredible!

Get lost in the Medina. Spend a day wandering around the Medina looking at all the amazing stores. Be prepared to be hassled, but just smile and walk on it you don't want to look. There are also some hidden gems of places if you find yourself out of the hustle and bustle near the square. We found tailors making the most beautiful jalaba's, shoe made by hand, silver workers etc. Bring an empty suitcase to Morocco, as it is so easy to fill. Also bargain with a smile.
shoppers paradise. great to wander around looking and trying your hand at bargaining. a shoppers paradise with lots of bargains to be had if you are savy enough!!

A challenge. The streets of the Medina are full of people and it is incredible to experience this culture, however it is rather scary since there are so many streets you will without a shadow of a doubt get lost. The streets are quite dirty and so full of people and motorcicles, bikes and carriages you need to walk in one of the sides of street. Also there are a lot of people trying to get turists to follow them around as if they are guides in order to get them to some shop so they can receive a comission there and a tip from you.
Old city. Is a wonderfull and crazy place to visit, you can buy almost anything, don't forget to discuss the prices before you buy something
Be prepare to be surprised and to negotiate the price. Great place to shop but avoid anyone who 'wants' to help you saying they are not a guide. Lot's of shops that your time and look around.

Amazing tour with MarrakechDaytrips. If you stayed in El madina you can walk to everything ( Snake charmers, monkeys on chains, music, aromatic smells, restaurants, fast food- the medina has it all and more). We had a great Tour. The guide walked us through the Kasbah, Medina and Souk. We had a great lunch which was included and we saw all the important historical sites in a timely manner. I highly recommended tour if you only have a day or two to enjoy Marrakech.

Wow. If you haven't been before, be ready for the culture shock. Its busy, vibrant, bizarre range of shops, souks, modes of transport, sights sounds, everything. We found the reports of touts et al to be an exageration, yes at every stall you will be invited in to buy, but we found a polite no thankyou worked every time. We were astonished how clean it was, all things considered, and the narrowness of the streets shaded the worst of the heat. It was astonishing, exciting , just great. Some advice.1. Get your hotel or other advisor to explain how to navigate around, and especially to find your way home. then go for it. We walked everywhere, never had a problem.2. Be confident in saying no thankyou, worked for us, very few persisted beyong the first request.3. Beware of stopping and consulting your map too publicly, you could get surrounded by unwanted advisors. We probably turned away a few folk who genuinely just wanted to help, but that's the price you pay.3. Keep handfuls of (very) small change, casual tipping of acrobats, beggars, guys whose donkey you photograph...4. Be careful crossing the roads!5. There genuinely appears to be no crime, and if you do want to engage in the haggling process, remember its just a game.6. We never had any hassle in restaurants over prices or service. 7. Remember you can't get alcohol everywhere, so check before you sit down.8. in my opinion, not great for kids.A wonderful city, everyone should go.

A must-see item in your itinerary. The medina is busy from day to night. You can do some shopping and see the people's culture during the day. At dawn, you may go for a horse ride when the weather is cooler. Barbeque dinner is available at night in the square. Good to choose one with more diners as the atmosphere will be better.

Pulsing Action from Centuries of Trade. The Medina is a marvel to behold, with many souks, mosques, squares, gardens, restaurants and street food. It pulses with life. The only negativity is the constant hassles to come here, go there, buy this & buy that. Harden your resolve dive in head first, get lost, get a map, learn some arabic, smile and revel in the experience.

interesting. The Medina by night is a sight to behold , but beware of men with monkeys, dont let it jump on your shoulder. Also ladies be aware of the henna ladies, they are so fast once they have you its costs a fortune.

Magical. i never would of thought how magical marrakech square really could be, so much happening from snake charmers to monkeys running around, i have never seen another city like this around the worldthis is a must to see whilst in marrakech
Mind blowing. Amazing experience, worth the visit, go mid morning as not as busy as evening. I will be returning on my next visit for more olives and spices.

Madness.. It's very interesting to walk around but in the end the constant hassle gets to you and you need to find somewhere to get away from it. If you like shopping, especially for leather clothes, you'll probably enjoy it more than I did.

Amazing place ... From another era. The madina is like nowhere else. Miles of interlaced corridors with stalls and shops, cafes and hotels all leading to the main square. During the day the square has fruit stalls and a few attractions and at night it comes alive with food outlets, entertainers and people from all over the world.

Beautiful and very cheap things!!!. Very interesting place!!! Big market, You need to be minimum 3 days to see everything there!!! Nice people at the market!!! But you have to have some patience to negotiate every product you want to buy.

What a place!. We stayed in the medina for 3 nights on the first leg of our trip and then again after the desert on our way to Fes. Starting our Moroccan adventure in Marrakech was quite an eye opener! The hustle and bustle of the place is overwhelming especially around dusk when all the night traders, food vendors and entertainers arrive. Ofcourse you can't walk 5 steps without almost stepping on a mesmerized cobra or have a part of your body henna tattooed, but it's all part of the allure of the medina. Most of the restaurants look out over the square and you can sit for hours just watching the people who make up the intricate yet vibrant tapestry of the square. The souks are excellent with a great variety of goods on sale. You must have one of the freshly squeezed juices available from ridiculously early in the morning and very reasonably priced too. The fruit and spices on sale in the souks bombard your senses not to mention the sheer height of the spice mounds. We felt very safe in the medina and there is a strong police presence to ensure everyone is safe. Definitely try the black soap made from olive. Marrakech is really not to be missed!

A great visit but take care. You must visit the medina of Marrakech at least once in your life. Hustle and bustle but take care when buying and make sure you haggle and only pay what you think you want to pay. Watch out for others who might want to fleece you

Good to see but streets get cramped. We went here on a walking tour but the heat of the day ruined it as it was very hot at 42 degrees Celsius. Plenty to see but streets are very narrow and they is also motorbikes, donkeys or horses passing by and it gets very cramped.
Fun place. Fun for some people watching and getting lost in the streets. Some great cafes for a snack and mint tea.

Hot & Sweaty But Fun. This is one place you have to visit when in Marrakech but it would probably be better visited when it is cooler. Even at 8pm at night it was still very hot in places within the Medina. We went with a guide that the hotel organised which helped us get some history on the Medina without being harassed every time we stopped to look at something. It is buzzing with life and characters. Spent some time in a great coffee shop just on the edge of the Medina people watching and they even organised a taxi for us when we needed to go back to the hotel.

Don't get ripped off,. food was great, But beware the waiters brought us food we didn't even order and tryed to charge us for the privilege, hold your ground and argue like hell till you win, better still, only use the cafe's an restaurants around the madina, alot cheaper an you pay wot it says on the menu,

Noisy, crazy, a little scary but great fun!. I was with my daughter for a grown up girly week and we were both a little apprehensive about going to the Medina but we braved it and had a fab time. We went once during the day and once at night to experience the whole thing. A must see!

A new experience. I enjoyed my first time walking around the old town- the market place, it was a new experience full of good and bad. First the walk from the resort was lovely, although very hot, we enjoyed the walk and viewing the sites of Marrakech. I would suggest walking around the outsides of the market so where the fresh orange juice is made (try this, its delicious!!). We went during the day and weren't bugged too much by being asked to come in the shop or buy anything which was good. We did buy some little things like flip flops. However, on our way out of the market we started to walk through the middle where a lady tried to force henna on my arm and a man tried to force a monkey onto my boyfriend's shoulder for money. So during the day, I would suggest not walking through the centre of the market! Also ladies, I would suggest covering up as much as possible, I was wearing a maxi skirt and long sleeved top and still got stared at etc. I think due to my fair hair so maybe wear a hat. I also noticed some locals taking pictures of female English tourists that were wearing shorts and a top, so be considerate and respectable around the outsides of the resorts. Other then that, I really enjoyed the experience and would recommend it as an eye-opening one!

Not for me!! . The souks is unbelievable. It is so populated by night that you literally get carried down the narrow streets by the crowds of people. You are constantly watching your step due to the poor condition of the streets (broken tiles, missing tiles, empty bottles, pot holes) the motorbikes fly past and you and you find yourself trying your best to dodge them at the same time. The market sellers mostly sell the same produce and items. The sellers are very pushy and at times drag you by the arm from the crowds to pull you into their stalls. If you have young children it is very difficult to keep hold of them to keep them close especially when they are so distracted by the hustle and bustle. It is a labyrinth of stalls and it is very easy to get lost which can be quite daunting. The food items for sale are usually covered in millions of flies which is quite revolting. At the top end of the square there are shops and stalls with fixed prices which makes shopping less stressful and more enjoyable as you don't find yourself in an awkward position of haggling with demanding, pushy and at times quite aggressive stall owners. You will find many Muslim women will approach you, take your hand and start drawing on your skin with henna no matter how many times you say no and try to pull away and then will cause a scene shouting and chasing you for money claiming that you agreed to it. There are armed police who keep guard in the main square.
Lively City. It was exotic experience. However, please be careful to bargen with local. I still do not know what is the real price.

A must-try cultural experience!. Visited Marrakech for two nights in July. Having heard about the souks and markets here we spent a day roaming the city around the stalls and little alleys that are Marrakech Medina. Everything is in walking distance within the walls. I'd read about the hassle of walking through the markets but we had not one problem. There are hundreds of stalls and they all want you to buy in their shop but maintain your confidence and walk through at your own pace, be friendly but don't look interested if your not! The locals are friendly but wild! Watch out for scooters and bikes flying down the tiny alleys. You will be beeped at but even the locals are beeped at. You will find the younger men may make remarks at western females regarding the way we dress but don't even bat an eye lid and they will leave you alone. It's totally safe.
