We carried cameras and phones and cash and had not a problem! Don't give in to anyone trying to give you directions as they will ask for money. Simply "NO" and walk away, be stern and say thanks! You would spend days looking at the medina and all the attractions in it! Pack plenty of sunscreen and comfortable shoes. Highly recommend to anyone looking for a culture shock!

Marrakech street market . The Medina is not only the ancient part of the city, but also one of the biggest street markets in Morocco.It's small streets hide multiple stores in which you can buy any kind of artisan crafts, Berber antiques and general Moroccan souvenirs. It is better to go with a guide, since he will tell you which stores sell quality items and which sell Chinese copies and low quality items.It is also recommendable to be aware of everything you have and everyone in your group, since it is easy to get lost.If you are looking to buy something be prepared to haggle because the prices are way to high for the real value of items and they are prepared to lower it even to a third (or more, depending on your skills) of the original price.Have fun in the medina, it is surely a place to visit.

Wonderful assault on your senses.. The Medina is the old walled part of Marrakesh that includes the Souks and the famous square Jemaa el Fna. Lots to explore and experience. Take your lime to just wander through and come across different areas. Lots of cafes stalls and restaurants and residential areas to enjoy.
Amazing. Be careful of theafs and cheaters. Try to find the best deal and just get lost. Forget your orientation sense. On the ither hand, that is kind of a part of the game... ;)

Wow mad crazy. Me and my wife only spent 2 hours here but can i say it is a experience and halfLoads of stalls where you can get a bargain or get ripped offBe prepared to hakle they will always give u a price over double the actual price.But if you go to marrekech go to the medina i promise you will of not experienced anything like it. Sooooooo busy after 6 pm . if you dont like crowds n crowds n crowds of people and do not like being hassled stay away or try during the day

Wonderful Cultural Experience. The Medina in Marrakech is an exciting an immersive taste of Morrocan culture. There are a wide variety of goods for sale and some very interesting shows in the main square, snake charming being one of them.If you want to do some shopping, which I highly recommend, be sure to haggle. At most of the stalls you can generally get items for as low as twenty percent of the asking price, and do not be afraid to walk away, this is a useful haggling tactic, and the chances are that another stand will have the exact same item. Just be patient and keep a good head on your shoulders, and you will save a lot of money.The area is fairly safe, but being a heavily crowded area, be careful of your valuables.Marrakech is definitely somewhere you should visit if you are traveling to Morocco. Also, they have some really cool tours available like the Ouzoud Falls, don't forget good walking shoes for that one!

so beautiful that it make you crazy. i was in my first time in morocco, and i was just a little bit scared, new places, different people etc...but when i saw the medina everything desappeared in a second! colourful, safety and full of life! BEAUTIFUL

Great Shopping Area. I love this area! it is so alive and you can get good souvenirs and Moroccan items. I would advise all those that visit Marrakesh for the first time to stay in a Riad in the Medina as you get the ultimate Moroccan experience.

Daytime: Dead, Night: Vibrant. - Massive- Lots of food options- Pushy localsIn the day the square is incredibly sparse and doubly as hot, seeing as nothing is there you're better off venturing into the enormous covered market just off the main square. At night however the place is packed with tourists and locals alike, with EVERYBODY desperately trying to sell you something. The food stalls offer authentic tegine-cooked food and are great if you love sitting in and amongst the crowd and bustly atmosphere, if not there are several restaurants upon which you can sit on the terrace with a high-up view of the action. Among the stalls are many orange juice sellers, this is highly recommended as a fresh, cold, and tasty hydrant, and at only 4DH (approx 31p) a glass it's outrageously cheap!

Haggle everything. Great, fun place to shop with a wide variety of goods. Haggle on every purchase because the starting price is always much higher than the actual price. Also don't be afraid to look around at other stalls first because many sell the same thing varying in price and quality.

Magical, but smelly :D. Walking around the square at daytime is not so special. Just some people selling stuff and overall pretty empty. But at night is when the square comes to life! The smell of all the strange food, the people and the stuff the do and say is just magical. Be sure to visit it at night is my advise!

Interesting but beware of pick pockets, con artists and motorcycles!. "Non merci" is your best phrase in Marrakech as everyone wants your money!Most people are friendly and will accept a polite "No", others are more persistent and require a more forceful "NO!" to get them to leave you alone.My girlfriend caught a young man with his hand in her bag as we walked down a busy street. Keep your wits about you at all times and leave your valuables at your accommodation. He didn't get anything except a sore hand!Beware anyone giving you free information on what's going on, I got tricked by a "student studying English" giving me interesting info on what I was watching in the main square. Before I knew it I was sitting at a fortune teller with the student translating and then they wanted €20.Needless to say they didn't get it but I did give them around €3 and I left with a lesson as I should have seen it coming earlier!There are motor cycles everywhere and within the Medina it's a free for all with everyone and no-one having right of way. Walk on the right, look behind you before changing direction and keep a firm hold of kids hands.I'd avoid taking kids under 10 to Marrakech and be prepared to have your heart in your mouth every time a moped comes at them.With these warnings said, it is a wonderful place to see and take in the sights, sounds, tastes and smells. Snake charmers, musicians, dancers, spice stalls, orange juice sellers, crafts men, pastries from street sellers for 1 Dirham ( around €0.10) and exploring the narrow streets with something new round every corner.Spring time has been recommended to us for a return visit, the heat in July is a little intense.Top tip from me is to spend no longer than two nights in Marrakech. Head to Essaouira, on the coast. The Medina there is quieter, friendlier, cooler and much safer to give kids or indeed novice travellers a taste of Morocco without the risks of Marrakech.
Marrakesh by night . An experience you can't miss, just go with a decent travel guide, ours was recommended by our hotel rep and he was very good

Steeped in history, activity and fabulous accommodation.. We recently spent 8 days based in Marrakech. We stayed at Riad Aloes inside the Medina and really had a fabulous time. The old Medina is fascinating with all the advertised activities, but mostly as there is so much to explore and discover. Get lost away from the main square and enjoy the diversity of Moroccan culture, it's fabulous food and friendly people. The main square is an experience in itself - be prepared to be haggled, but it is all in good humour. Can highly recommend a visit.
Diverse and interesting place. A lot of beautiful little stalls and restaurants. This place is a maze! Make sure to be aware of your surroundings at all times for pickpockets.

The Best in Morocco. This Medina is Probably the biggest and best in Morocco. It will be easy to get lost in the labyrinth of alleys but that only adds to the fun. Bargain hard and you might get a bargain. But it is not all about shopping - check out the interesting architecture but look out for speeding motorbikes which are illegal. Also take care of your purse/wallet.

Very special Authentic place - bit of a tourist trap . My wife visited Medina 30 years ago and always talked about the biblical experience and great magicians and shows in the main square , well time has move on a bit and it's still unique and a must visit location , just be prepared for hard selling locals trying to get your every last $ cent Dress down and plain to attract less attention and get a pre booked guide from the hotel so you can go deeper into Madian ( without getting lost !) and see truly local merchandise I would go back but not in Ramadan !
nice place by night. very busy by day and night but worth the hassle as you have to go too see it ,,take a horse drawn carridge ride lovely by night no hassle no walking lovely

Madness. At night time at around 2130 the medina becomes a maelstrom of people. Care is needed to protect belongings as men and boys crowd around you if you stop to look at something and the place is rife with dippers. It is a sight to experience though as safety seems adequate.

Amazing medieval city. The old city of Marrakech, known as "Medina" (which in arabic means city) is one of the best of Morocco.Medina is everything located inside the walls of Marrakech: many neighborhoods, each one with its mosque, shops, ... and, of course, the "souks", local markets specialized in leather, clothes, food, ...Walking the Medina of Marrakech is a full experience, rich in senses, souds, touches, tastes and colors. It's a joy to discover the singular urbanism of ancient islamic civilisation, its architectural aspects and also the change that happened to it. Truth is Medina riads - traditionnal houses - has been sold to many european investors who turned them into nice riads/hotels that actually are preferred by travelers to modern hotels. Yet I think the Medina continue to seduce - at least with what remains if its authenticity.
Amazing, colourful market!. Spent many hours searching for bargains and experiencing the culture of Marrakech.We sampled many tasty tagines and the best orange juice!

Marrakech Must See!. Haggle or pay the price you're willing to pay. We visited twice, during the day (morning when it was cooler) and in the evening. The place is best in the evening, as the place comes alive. During our first visit, we agreed to a guide (20 DH) to show us around. He was informative and spoke English. In hindsight, he did take us to shops he probably has an affiliation with. We tried one juice bar and I definitely recommend this particular stall (as my photo). It was the most refreshing juice (sweetest orange juice, mix of orange/lime, orange/peach).

Arset el Bill square ..... Wow. We went there the first time the night Ramadan ended. There weren't many people there so the aggression to pull you into one of 100 choices for tagine on the square was pretty agressive, including people touching you or physically standing in your way. When we returned during the day it was more relaxed. We never felt unsafe but the intimidation to pay big numbers for street performers was a bit much. Strolling deeper into the medina was much more enjoyable.
Authentic. We loved diving into this wondrous world of culture. The moroccan culture is lovely and everyone is very welcoming.

Interesting and worth a visit. The old city encompasses three main areas: largely living accommodation in the northern third and then souks and shops in the middle and lower thirds. The gateways to the medina form interesting structures and the wall certainly dominates the city. Most people visit for the souks but it is worth just generally wandering around looking at the structure and architecture. We actually hired a couple of pushbikes (and a guide!) and cycled around (and through parts of) it

Walk into the Medina for an amazing experience. As you walk into the Medina you are looking in all directions as there is so much to see. From the hawkers, snake charmers,men with donkeys,carts selling mini tanginess, the Medina is an experience you wouldn't want to miss. Don't be scared as it can be a little daunting at first, just get in there and give it a go. The sellers won't bother you once you say you are not interested, you just have to be firm and stick to what you say. If you do want to buy something you have to have an idea of how much you want to pay for the item. They are happy to barter and actually expect you to beat them down, it's all part of the game they play. So never buy straight away, make sure you play the game.

A fantastic place but very different. I have been a couple of times in Marrakech and I am always stunned when I enter in to the Medina. It´s so much people, new sounds and smells and I always get lost in the narrow alleys. If you never been to Marrakech you must go there.

Amazing Antiques and Luxury items. Everybody knows about the stalls full of crafts and local items, but our guide took us to larger shops that ship beautiful pieces crafted in Morocco. We plan on returning when the time is right to decorate a house because we could find the most original, fine crafts at reasonable prices including shipping. If this is something you are interested in, a professional guide can take you to these places to have a look around.

Day and night are such different experiences. Definitely worth checking out on any visit to Marrakech! I'd go both during the day to try haggle some good deals and also at night to see the array of colours on show! Two completely different atmospheres!
Need good quality GPS device. Be prepared for lot of street vendors and unfocial guides.It's very easy to lost in this city without quality GPS device.

Wow. I'll never forget the first night I saw the place at night. I had seen it during the day and it was relatively busy but at night it was amazing. Plenty of food l, entertainers with their snakes and other animals. People everywhere. A complete delight I loved it:) a must if you are in Marrakech
Wow !!!!. This is the place to shop, so many people, so much choice, loved it, not for the faint hearted or anyone who doesn't like crowds !

disgusting. well this place smells of sewage and with raw meat hanging from stalls. You get harassed by shop keepers throughout the place and there are people that recognise you are a tourist and get you off the beaten track to a point that you are then lost. They then want money to get you back. New city is by far the best area

Amazing Culture. Having just visited Marrakech for 3 days I must say the hustle and bustle of the medina is somewhat crazy although interesting. Having stayed in a Riad which made it easy to explore it also provided a great bolt hole allowing you to get refreshed and out the blistering sun before heading out again. if you have children watch out for the 100's of mopeds and bikes!

Wow what a place - save some time a must see. You must allow time to just wonder through this wonderland of old. Stay close by and enjoy the true authentic life style of the locals. Just have a look. I could go back for a week and just enjoy the vibrant streets and local culture. The locals are so friendly, and its cheap.

Stay in the Medina. I highly recommend staying at a riad in the Medina. You can walk to everything, and there are plenty of riads that fit low and high budgets. I can't imagine staying anywhere else in Marrakech.

An absolute must--both day and night!. The medina is bustling by day and hopping even more at night. It is filled with snake charmers, monkeys, and all sorts of exotic restaurants and other delights. Started off in the morning just wandering around with our guide taking in the sights and smells of the medina and being somewhat overwhelmed by the vastness of it. We toured other areas and then came back in the evening for even more adventure. The snake charmers were gone replaced by belly dancers (male) and every kind of food vendor imaginable. We did not eat there but many people did and it was fascinating to see the amount of food being cooked and served. It's a unique experience. Of course, it's a big city and the vendors are out to sell so be prepared to say No a lot! And be careful with your belongings.

Different! . Snake charmers, monkeys on chains, music, aromatic smells, restaurants, fast food- the medina has it all and more. This is a must do experience both in the day and in the evening. At night- you can watch the sunset from one of the many bars and restaurants or eat food from the markets stalls. From day- you can shop and buy anything you are looking for. Be prepared to be pestered non stop!!! But just say no. Don't take photos of snakes or monkeys unless you want to pay!

A Real Experience. I have no idea why some people here are talking about people in the Medina being aggressive. I've been lucky enough to visit lots of countries in my time and I found Moroccans to be completely friendly and lovely. I had expected for them to be pushy like other North African countries' folk (Egypt, I'm looking at you), but I found that if you politely said no, they left you be and were lovely to talk to when engaged in conversation. The medina is a great experience. Is it busy? Yes. Is it hard to navigate? Not as much as some would have you believe. Should you go? Definitely.
Con. Too many people trying to rip you off. Pickpocket is rife from youngsters as young as 7 who will use a blade to cut bags camera straps etc

True Morocco! What I came here for!. I should admit that having no idea of where you are heading to, with your useless map, is worth of the visit. Go there a couple times more and you will get confortable with the situation and you will get used to those streets. Started feeling like if I lived there, helping other tourists to find their way. Great places (but a couple of young people trying aggressively to get money from pretending to help you, just say you are gonna call the police and everything ok).

Matter of taste. We went here to have a look it was not really for us to busy saying no constantly.Trying to stop people taking money off you any way they can. And really confusing looking for what you want.However for a bit of theatre it is a good place lots going onI really think that is a matter of taste some people will love it and others will see it as too much.But remember you can always leave when you have had too much. Just look for a landmark to head back for.

Amazing Place . Don't be frightened by reviews!Go Enjoy and Experience the real Morocco! Feels totally safe. Be friendly and they are friendly back! Don't ignore them!We felt totally safe with a blonde teenager and she enjoyed it too.Don't be put off from reviews.

Wont get lost.. Its fun. In the befinning after visitting Fes we are not keen to visit marakkech medina anymore becoz of those scams and tourist trap we got. But this is totally different. Inlike it, tourist friendly and remember bargain 25% from offered price.

An awful experience. We visited the medina during the day, I had read reviews and thought I was ready for what I was going to experience. I was wrong! They are all connected and out for one thing, your money and if they don't get it they try to bully you into it. I have had to deal with many sorts of people in my time and never have I been so intimidated as a man. I was there with my husband and we were lead different paths after getting lost, by people claiming not to be guides. there are so many small roads and alleyways around this place it is easy to lose your bearings. We were eventually brought to a leather making production area (which we did not ask to go to) the smell was horrific, they gave us sage to put under our nose and then gave us a tour of the place (we really had no choice at this stage) before being brought to the shop bearing the finished produce. before we knew it we were sitting drinking mint tea (which is delicious I have to say)The main guy told us if we didn't buy anything at the end we would all still be friends. he had his assistant start throwing out the rugs for us to view explaining they could be delivered by DHL, by the end of it he got annoyed because I don't haggle and I don't pay €500 for a rug, we eventually got out after I calmly told him that getting irritated would not cause me to buy something. When we were outside the premises the guy who brought us there told us he wanted paying, I refused and told him I hadn't asked him to bring me here, 3 more men approached shouting at me to pay the man, I ended up using a few choice words I didn't really want to use but..... I couldn't wait to get out of there and due to this we didn't see any more of it, we kept our heads down and got out as quick as possible which was a shame because I would have liked to have had a proper look around without the hassle. Keep in mind if you do visit, keep to the right or else you will be knocked down by one of the many scooters/bikes. Although it is their culture to hound etc, I would feel more comfortable buying things without constantly being tormented, if they left me alone I would most certainly browse their stall. Needless to say we will not be returning anytime soon. I wouldn't recommend women to visit this place alone, actually I wouldn't recommend anyone to visit this place alone.

Fantastically interesting. Like other reviewers here, I have travelled around Morocco (Fes, Rabat, Casablanca,Todra) but still find Marrakech an amazing and vibrant place. I have visited five time over the past few years (both with family and as a couple) and always go back to the Medina - but I don't necessarily stay there (areas slightly outside in the Palmerie or Hivernage are quieter). It is made up of shops, mosques, cafes, restaurants, hotels (roads), and much much more. This might sound too obvious to state, but get a map of the souks and study it a bit before you go. Also, if you are definitely going shopping, decide what you might want and concentrate on those areas - and most importantly, allow yourself time. It really can be an enjoyable experience just chatting to stallholders - you don't HAVE to buy! They can be aggressive in trying for a sale, in which case just walk away. Especially in the hot months, it is good to just wander with breaks at one of the many cafes. Also it is a more comfortable experience if you dress conservatively with covered arms and legs - this is city, not a beach. I have also seen many 'groups' being marched quickly around the area, many looking frightened. Yes, it is very different, but I've never found it dangerous - just watch out for the motorbikes and donkey carts.

Like a "movie set". When you visit the medina it almost feels as if you have stepped into an old movie set. The snake charmers and men with the monkeys make it feel surreal. Shopping is great around the medina if you feel comfortable bargaining with the vendors.

Rude sellers!. We didn't enjoy coming here. People were very rude especially if you don't go in their shops. They've got tricks to lure you in like free stuff. I turned my back one second and my hubby was eating a free bun. I told him nothing is free. The guy tried to get money from him but we insisted we have no money. There was nothing special about this place. Never again!

A lot of nice shops but also a lot of aggresive fake guides.. During this week we visited a lot of nice shops, met a lot of nice people. We also met a BIG lot of aggresive fake guides that try to guide you to the market place or something you don't want and demand money in aggresive way. Of course people want to earn their money in the Medina and try to ask a little more for their goods. That's no problem but please be aware for these aggresive guides that shout a lot: "That road is closed". If you don't know where to go, they walk along a few Streets and ask for money because they "guided" you.

Beautiful, but we didn't like the people.. This place is really beautiful and a must visit! Though people here are willing to go extremely far for money. I've been called a lot of inappropriate things for not wanting to eat at people's restaurants. Don't walk with anyone who offers to show you the way if you are lost, they will charge you bigtime. Also be careful with henna ladies. They put henna on your hand without even giving them permission and it is black henna which could cause allergic reactions. They will also make you pay a lot so don't give them your hand.

Eating in the Medina. As with the shopping in the Souk,dont be afraid.There are lots of different stalls cooking all manner of local dishes.The sights,the sounds and the smells are mesmerising.The best thing to do,we found,was to start at one end and wind your way through all the stalls[which are numbered] making a note of the stalls that interest you,and when you reach the other end,stop and make your choice.All the stalls have people telling you they are best, but You decide which you prefer.You will typically be sat on a wooden bench,order your dish,then sit back and wait for it to appear.We used to go from stall to stall,so we might have a starter in one stall and our main meal in another.In all we tried Snails which are served in a spicy broth which you drink afterwards[very good]excellent,a mixed tagine with meat and veg[very tasty],local spicey sausages[excellent] and the one that puts most people off,Half a sheeps head[,which is not as gorey as it sounds] as the meat is taken off the bone and presented to you on a plate[surprisingly easy to eat].There are many other dishes on offer so be brave and try something Morroccan.And in case you were wondering,neither of us suffered any 'undue' reactions!!!

Get lost in a magical world.. If you are going to Marrakech you would be a total wuss if you didn't stay in the medina. It is a given that on your first day you will get lost but the locals are unbelievably friendly , in general. The trick is to get involved, and enjoy the adventure but be alert , as in any city there are some sharks out there but they are a small irritant on a stunning beast.

Not for the faint hearted. I have travelled extensively in India and the bargaining here confuses me. They are not hungry for sales and there seems to be a lot of pride about having the last price. I have walked away from many sales because of this. They start with a crazy price then get insulted when you say what the item is worth. It can become nasty, I clearly haven't learnt the "rules". Perhaps I will get better at it with time!!
Amazing. Just to stand here and experience all around you, the sights, sounds, snake charmers story tellers food sellers, have never seen anything like it.
great for photography and meeting people. the medina is great to hng out and meet locl young people so friendly and cool we felt so welcome in a short space of time

Mysterious, fascinating place. Marrakesh has a mysterious, fascinating medina with souks selling anything you could possibly want or think of. Bright colors adorn the paths along with objects shining in the light. Smells of spices fill the air. Carpets hang on display along with beautiful clothing. Well worth visiting.

Amazing feel of Morocco. Initially apprehensive of scammers and hard sellers at the souks of the medina, when we got there, there was a rather calm atmosphere. There were, of course, market sellers attracting your attention to their goods, but they did not seem offended by your saying no. As long as you keep your wits about you, and walk away when you don't want to purchase anything, it is a pleasurable experience to visit the medina.
Worth the cost . These guys are great, as the medina is s complex maze, which you can become easily lost. So this tour is great to keep you on the straight and narrow .
A must for any visitor. Fantastic at night a must for any visitor the atmosphere is fantastic. It gets very busy. But just keep your wits about you and you will be fine.
An absolute delight. Visting the Medina in Marrakech is an absolute must, the old town is beautifull, always busy. Beautifull gardens and the famous Souk

Be very careful. Went to see the famous Medina Market after we had a hamman massage in our last day. We were group of 8 and we got very assertive when we were in the market. It was Ramadan when we visited so the market was not open till 6pm onwards. On the way to market we walked through the cobblestone alleyway and some local shops. The motorbike riders were atrocious. I thought was going to be hit by one or few of them. They were the bad drivers I had ever seen. The market itself was massive. They sold loads of local stuffs but very pricey so you have to negotiate to get the item that you need for a cheap price. You could always shop around as shops sold same items but that was if you would be able to get out of the shop as they would try to keep you in until you gave up and buy off an item. Yes they were very pushy to the point that you would feel very uncomfortable and annoyed. I was expecting to see stalls of spices in the market but was disappointed not to seen one. There were loads of food stalls where you could eat local foods like tagines, pastilles, and skewers and you wont be able to miss them as they would chase you until you sat down to have a meal in their stall. Especially if you would be going in a massive group like us they would never stop asking repetitively and annoyingly. Foods were okey and rather cheap compare to a proper restaurant but the amount of torture you got from them before even having a meal was horrifying. Please note that the round chewy bread was not for free. Everything that would be served on the table had it's price so be mindful of what you eat and order. It was nice to visit just once but definitely not recommend this if you would be travelling on your own. Safety first.

Don't miss the residential ares of the Medina. In addition to the souks , katoubia and the Ben yourself Madrassa, there are areas that are upper scale residential areas that are found in branches of up to 60 homes. These homes are all inward facing versus outward, and have beautiful doors facing into the alleyway. get a certified guide to take you through and there are some homes that have been turned into an art gallery that are just beautiful. Admission is by donation.It is worth a tour/visit.

Overwhelming and amazing. The Medina is an overwhelming experience. Turbulent and beautiful, spectacular and dramatic. And not without danger: I was robbed of cash and passport afterbeing nearly run over by a motorcycle driven by a pickpocket's accomplice. The Marrakesh police are not your friends and will not be helpful. Quite the contrary. I was moderately negligent: be extremely careful, hide your cash and valuable papers. this was a most unpleasant, expensive, time-consuming experience although i was not injured. the vast number of moroccan citizens are kind and generous. this robbery could have happened in any big city throughout the world.

Wow. Huge, everything, snake charmers, pushy vendors, amazing rugs, exquisite leather. Makeup and argan oil vendors were a little annoying and pushy. Some vendors had a hard time letting you go. Stores with moroccan flag out front tenant has better price and service.
Authentic. We loved the Marrakech Medina and do recommend to visit this city with a guide to avoid missing any of its beauty.

A maze of interesting sights and smells. The medina encompasses the old town and consists of many streets and alleys filled with amazing sights and sounds (and smells!) Well worth just wandering round without a plan to take it all in.

WHAT CAN I SAY ?. An are where everything happens and certainly not to be missed !You can experience all the true Moroccan influences here in every way and enjoy the bustle of all that goes on around you.Very lively at night time, especially with the food stalls !
Exotic!. The Medina of Marrakesch is really exiting. wonderful place to wonder around and see people and lots of activities. Sometimes you have the feeling you go 100 years back in time.
Mazing. You can definitely get lost in the Medina very easily if you don't know your way around. And be prepared to haggle when shopping. You can come out with some many scarfs!!
Excited. Good to see all different type of food and big stall. Only thing is that you have to haggle. Lots to item that you feel like to buy

Day Trip. Had a morning being shown by our guide Abdul who was very knowledgeable who showed us the sights and sounds. We were in a party of 4 for a 4 hour tour.
Loved the Medina and felt very at ease and found the people very friendly. Just ignore the pedlars and keep to the right in the alleyways.

Where east meets west. Definitely the central hive of activity of Marrakech. Full of Snake Charmer and Monkies, Street food and juice carts, you will definately have a lot of fun. just dont stop if your are not buying as you will be bothered by street vendors etc.
Interesting and fascinating. Really fascinating experience. Be careful though, do not give too much attention to the locals trying to sell you pictures with monkeys and snakes
Amazing. The medina of Marrakech is highly complex but amazing to get lost in to, you can spend hours just going around and taking in the moroccan way of life

THE MEDINA!. Such a fun place to go! stayed in a hostel right in the medina, spent lots of time walking around the souks and getting lost but fun to explore. Street food in the main square of an evening is a must, you will get asked by 10 different people to come eat at their stand, just pick one, all the food is the same. Everyone is friendly just be friendly back!

The Medina lovely, and found some really good bargains, but had to haggle like crazy. met some really nice people,. Loved the Medina , stayed 7 nights felt really safe, ,goes on forever, had some lovely fresh juices from a little bar, somewhere near the center. It can be a bit overwhelming and annoying , as everyone wants to sell you something, but be nice , and haggle, I gave out sweets when i said no, which went down well.

Lots of fun, but be vigillent. As I was travelling alone, being female, the square was;t as bad as expected. You have to be vigillent with your belongings, but aside from that I had a lot of fun. I kept some change in my pocket for tips so i did't have to keep getting my purse out. Secondly I recommend keeping some sunglasses or ear phones on to help avoid being hassled, it helps somewhat! The bellydancers and snake charmers were fun, and we had a traditional street barbecue sitting down in the main square! The medina gets quite dark and quiet in the streets, so be careful walking back if you are going through it!

The medina. things to do :Circle the Koutoubia MosqueSpend your dirhams at the souksLearn about Islamic scriptures and lawGet into garden living ( La Mamounia) A visit to the ancient Saadian TombsA stroll down the souksExplore its museums ( Madrast bin Yousef)Step into a Sultan’s palace (Baddi Palace) Enjoy Moroccan culinary highsShop in a handicrafts department store (Barggen always! for best offer)Grab a cocktail on a roof terrace, enjoy the viewrelax… at a hammam

Take it in your stride. The Medina is a crazy place; you will say NO a lot. But, take it easy...these are just people trying to make a living. Be polite... No thank you. Immerse yourself in it! There is so much to see. Watch for the henna women though...some of them will just grab your hand if you are stopped and start drawing, say you can pay what you want, then ask for a fortune when you finally get away :/ ... Get a seat on a rooftop restaurant though... you could people watch forever and never see the same thing twice!

Enjoy!. I removed all the jewellery and wore very simple t-shirt + long pants and ventured the medina. Thoroughly enjoyed the late night there - eating like a local, drinking mint tea like a local, haggling in half baked French and Arabic... It is a lot of fun to let the hair down and enjoy life.

A different type of crazy. This is hard to review as each to their own. But I will try my best to say a few points.In the day this is far less crazy but be careful with the snake charmers because as soon as you show any interest you will have a snake on you and pictures taken, of course this is not free.Also you will see monkeys on chains performing and pose for pictures, I am not a fan of animal cruelty so wasn't to my liking.In the evening this is where you will eat some of the best food and see and hear some of the best things in Morocco.Make sure you visit if you are here, you do not want to this is crazy place!

Good experience . Good experience to visit the souks and the market stalls both during the day time and the night time. The food stalls start live outdoor cooking at about 7.30pm into the night. Not much difference in price whether you eat out on the street or in a restaurant in the square. Nice experience but beware of too many pushy locals trying to sell you stuff and following you if you don't pay attention!

Amazing experience. I have visited the Medina during the day and in the evening and its defo a place to visit. Plenty of Moroccan bits and bobs to take home and in the evening the entertainment is awesome. Plenty of bargains to be found. Haggle haggle haggle

Aggressive tourist traps makes this disappointing . Having been to similar markets around the world (Asia, South America, Eastern Africa), my husband and I are both used to the tourist traps and pushy vendors. However, we found some of the people in the medina particularly aggressive and not respectful - intentionally trying to lead tourists down the wrong paths and then demanding payment and henna women grabbing arms and drawing on them without permission and then demanding payment. There is no problem in making a living but it doesn't have to be done this way. When politely declining or sometimes having to ignore repeated requests, some people started to get angry and used racial slurs at us which never has a place. Really too bad given I love markets and the experience of bargaining and soaking in the sights and sounds, and was very much looking forward to this. If you go, I recommend going during the day (not during sundown as some souks close), and to not stop and talk to anyone even if you feel impolite.

Excellent place . Good place and bargaining is fun if you are patient. They would sell for 20 where initial quote was 200. Of course exceptions exist. Moving away from main shops and in narrow streets is where you will find real bargains.

Amazing Place. This place is facenating. We walked for hours and still didn't see it all, and every night, it transformed to a sea of lights, and performers, and street food. We ate at number 81 (2nd row from the back on the left hand side if your back is to the temple). Very good food!We sat in a few roof top bars and just watched everything happen... It really is an amazing place.

Haggling Paradise . The medina of Marrakech with all its "Souks" (markets) is definitely worth a visit. All kinds of things can be found here - spices, carpets, lanterns, blankets, cloths, olives, and much much more! The scenery is incredible and will let you immerse in a totally different reality. When coming here our goal was to experience something completely 180 degree different than you could find in Europe - and the medina was the perfect place to be!A small tip: if you are (just like us) not the person to enjoy so much haggling about prices and so much pressure from the salesmen, go to the "Ensemble Artisanal". It is a building with several shops inside that mostly offer the same goods you can find in the souks but for fixed prices. In a super relaxed atmosphere with helpful but not pushy sellers you will find everything you need. Prices there are usually lower than for what you will get it in the souks (even with hours of haggling and charming the seller).

The real Morocco. We stayed in the medina for 6 nights, at 2 different Riads. I highly recommend stayingin the medina to get the full flavor of Marrakech. We were actually there long enoughto be able to find our way through the maze (well, mostly) Also google maps worked for us as well as helpful Moroccans. Yes they want a tip but it's part of the ambience. A truly very colorful megastore!

No Words!. This place is a lovely mix of people, food, trinkets, mosques, leather and goods. Our riad, riad joy was in the heart of the Medina. There is no other place to stay then in the medina for a true beautiful experience.

exotic and unusual place. this is an experience not to be missed. Dont believe most of the sellers, when bargining offer 20% of what they ask for increase your offer price slowly. Always be prepared to walk away, if they wont go any lower and you walk away you will know that should be the right price and dont forget that item you wanted wil be for sale from 20 or more other sellers who will have the same minimum price.

Loud, chaotic, but INTERESTING and MUST-SEE!. Wall to wall of shops and merchants asking you to buy things. Most streets are narrow, loud, and crowded, but definitely the best place to explore the city of Marrakech. It is the most chaotic and lively place, but an incredible place to get lost in. The food is amazing and cheap, and don't forget about the rooftop restaurants-- they are fantastic for enjoying a good meal with a great view!
Very Good. Busy place. As long as you are careful of the cars you will have a good time and find everything you need.

Incredible explosion of the senses!. WOW! Sights, smells, sounds - this place has it all - prepare to be astounded. We visited the medina in both daytime and night time and both were incredible within their own right. Day time - Haggling in the souks, seeing the people at work and exploring the beautiful city. Prepare to get lost, as no matter how good your map is - you're never going to locate yourself in this maze. The roads are crazy, from mopeds, donkeys, cows, cars, taxi, - you never know what is coming next. I actually had someone drive into me on their moped in the souks - so please be careful. We really enjoyed haggling in the souks, always go at least 50% of what they are asking - you can get some great bargains - and we almost needed to add extra kg on our luggage allowance. Night time - We ate in a café overlooking the square at night which was incredible. There was live music, performing acts and thousands of people. It was such a fascinating experience and definitely something not to be missed. We had been advised to not go into the medina travelling as two young girls (aged 21 and 22) but we were fine. We never felt unsafe and the people of Marrakech are lovely, friendly and welcoming. Of course, you get the normal comments - just as you would in England...but do not let this put you off. It is an incredible experience, not one to be missed!
A gem. The medina is very romantic in my opinion, I can only suggest travelers to book a hotel close by for practical reasons

Exciting and Crazy. Pretty incredible place. The medina (walled city) is like a labyrinth so prepare to be lost. Don't listen to anything anyone tells you because they either want money or to sell you something, but they are also pretty nice most of the time. I would not recommend the medina for small children or elderly as the scooters are pretty dangerous.

Lunch and Shopping at the Medina. Lunch on the main street a few metres from the Medina was a bit of a hustle a few hours after landing in Marrakech. There were a lot of people both children and adults approaching our group asking for money or food whilst we were eating. The experience was a bit overwhelming. Recommendation avoid dinning alfresco in the Medina. The shopping was great, great products, don't do your shopping on the first day learn how to haggle first and then go back 2 days later :-)
Very Animated. Loved walking around the old city but the pavements are uneven and the traffic is crazy - taxis, cars, horses, mopeds, motorbikes and mayhem!

It's easy to get lost!. The medina can be overwhelming with all the people, motorcycles, and animals in the streets. Make sure to have your riad give you a map and even draw you one as well. Once you start making you way through the streets it all starts to look the same. People are very eager to assist you back to your riad, but remember..Nothing is free in Marrakech... Well except looking at the souvenirs.

In a different world. Great experience, but be prepared to get 'swamped' by many who want to sell their serives or goods. Awesome food for a few euro's. Look for the places where the locals eat. Visiting the nearby Souk is a great experience as well, but very busy and the quality of the products they sell is average.

Step into the "red city". Palaces, souks, city walls and gates,mosques, tombs of the Seven Saints, the old Jewish quarter, museums and restaurants. The Jemma el-Fnaa - one of the best-known squares in Africa and a centre of Medina.

To much to take in. Went at night and was overcome with the sound and colours and smells of the place. We got lost in a souk and was helped by local how to get back to square the place is great back in day light latter

Step back in time 900 years. We always stay in a Riad in the Medina. It takes some getting used to as they are no real street maps. Try and find a reliable taxi driver or guide to show you the first few times. Everyone is a guide in the Medina so be prepared to hand over some change to find your way.

Crazy, different and adventurous !!!. Once in Marrakech you need to go there and visit !!! Only seeing it yourself will give you a feel of this place!!! Full of people, animals, spices, restaurants!!!

Everything Marrakech has to offer. A stay or visit to the Medina has everything that Marrakech has to offer. It is a vibrant, noisy, busy place with charm and a multitude of activities. Within the Medina, you can shop, eat, drink and learn all about the culture and history of this amazing City.

A Smorgasboard to Overload the Snses. This lane-ways, arches, open markets, dark lanes, people and more people one could only marvel at the sights and smells. Eating on a rooftop overlooking the main market provided a simultaneous visual feast.Stay the day and walk then walk some more, there is something to excite around most corners. While the locals are not too keen on being photographed, you can still capture the essence of what this Medina has to offer.

Need to experience it yourself . This place literally is the best example to see and feel Marrakech. Be prepared to get assaults on your five senses, feel the chaos, drama, energy, noise, sights, smells. If you're the type of tourists that don't dare to try and go local then you probably won't like it here. Might be indeed not pleasant getting lost, overcharged for everything, being led to the wrong street etc, but see and experience it yourself because this is the real Marrakech scene.
very buzzy place indeed!. Great place to get the atmosphere of marrakesh! Great places to eat - open until the early hour os the morning
Nice to See. The old town called Medina is highly recommended to visit in the morning or midle day not too much tourist and calm everywhere

5 days in marracech. Bonkers! food great, assult on the senses, not to be missed! Trust the lonely planet guide its good for everything. cafes with the best views dont serve the greatest food, go local!

The Medina and square are well worth a visit - souks galore!!. The Medina is alive!!! There is always something to see or do no matter what time of the day or night - A maze of color and smells loved every minute of it!!
Very Caotic. The best place to be in Marrakech, best food, drinks and of course the usual dramas , this place makes Marrakech to be what it is.

An overload to the senses. I love the medina simply because it's unlike anything you can find back home in the UK. Although I wonder about the welfare of the snakes and monkeys that you see everywhere, the snake charmers are still a must see spectacle. Have your wits about you though and don't be afraid to firmly say no to the various people that will try and sell you goods. My father is Egyptian, so I understand the Arab culture. Many Brits are too polite to tell people to leave them alone and can end up getting scammed etc. Politely say la'aa shuckrun (no thank you) to anyone that pesters you and enjoy the unique sights, smells and sounds that the Medina has to offer!

This is Morocco!. My wife and I spent every night we had in Marrakech here. There is great food at stall 100 at night. Plenty of restaurants and entertainment. You can not pass up this site if you are in Marrakech.

Be careful of the markets . If you go into Marrakech, without a group, just be careful as the markets do feel quite unsafe. You have to haggle otherwise you'll be ripped off. Also, I made the mistake of not having enough small change. Haggled down to 120mad for a bag, gave the man 200mad and he refused to give me back my money. It's creepy and there's nothing you can do. In future I will have smaller change to prevent this from happening.
Guided tour. We took a guided tour to the Medina which I would recommend doing. With 18000 shops its difficult to get round if you don't know where you are going!

An experience. This is very interesting place, it's smelly, loud, busy, colour and quite amazing. We visited during the afternoon but were told it is worth a visit on the evening too. I do love a bit of hustle but this was too much...if businesses harassed tourists a bit less probably it would be more pleasant!!
the highlight of Marrakech . it's a huge labyrinth. actually like one big bazar. it's good to have a gps if you don't want to spend the whole time in the touristic part.

amazing tranbsition in the late afternoon. This is a huge medina, with the usual snake charmers, monkey men and merchants. In the late afternoon, it transforms into restaurant row and carts with snails. There are several observation places, restaurants with open upper floors that are great vantage points to watch the transformation. One place had a gellateria on the ground floor and the pizza was reasonable at 60dms ( about $6.00 USD).A food purchase gave you great seats and unlimited time.

Stay on A Main Street to Lose Your Senses, Not Your Self. Marrakech's city center provides easy access to the souk, most major attractions, and the main square. After staying at two riads, I recommend trying to book on a main street or getting back before 7PM at night unless you are travelling with one male.

A must see when in Marrakesh. Atmospheric, enchanting, and full of surprises. But keep your wits about you.... The Medina is in the old town in Marrakesh, and the guide books will tell you all about the sights, hotels and restaurants. It would be missing out to Marrakesh and not have a good wander around the Medina and experience this atmospheric and at times enchanting city. The practical side is enjoy it, immerse yourself in the culture and what makes it a fantastic experience, but keep your wits about you.We visited the Medina in the evenings to go to a couple of restaurants. We visited Djemaa el-Fna square and nearly got ripped off by a particularly aggressive snake charmer. We wandered the area by the souks. We visited a couple of restaurants, and the Place des Espices (Rahba Kedima). We were not so interested in shopping in the souks, but that’s another experience worth visiting the Medina for.And as they say, when in Marrakesh... so we got completely lost while we were there. Not just a little bit off track, but lost as not having a clue where we were. It's hard to navigate even with a map as the roads are windy and street names are hard to find at times. Or the ones you do find are not on the map! But you can't wander too far in terms of distance so seeking help from a restaurant or shop worker will set you back on track.Visiting the Medina and all that comes with it is part of visiting Marrakesh, and despite it being tricky to navigate at times, I wouldn't say avoid it. In fact, quite the opposite. But in our experience there are a few things to be aware of. First of all, getting lost is probably inevitable so allow for that when traveling to and from restaurants. Getting lost is so part of the experience for tourists that a minority of shifty locals have scams in place to exploit it. But if you keep your wits about you, are aware of it you can probably avoid falling trap to the scams. Best advice, from our experience, keep your cool, and ignore them because it can feel quite stressful and at times intimidating.Things that were tried with us (that we didn't fall for). Local people shouting "that way is closed" "the square is closed for prayer" "you can't go that way", and being quite insistent, almost sounding convincing and following us, repeating their “warnings.” The trick behind that one is so you follow them, and end up somewhere you didn't intend to go (such as a shop where you feel compelled to buy something or a restaurant you weren't going to). Apparently it's common to get people to the tanneries. Also a few sinister looking characters followed us, and tried to get us to go with them for directions. So tempting when you are lost, but my advice is do what we did, and go to a reputable shop or restaurant where the staff will be only too happy to help. Also local children swarmed on us a couple of times, again to give directions we hadn't asked for.The guide books also tell you to take care about pickpockets, but that's common sense in any large city. The guide books also say the crime rate in Marrakesh is relatively low, so it’s important to keep perspective on this.Stall holders in the souks and outdoor stalls can be quite pushy and actually put us off browsing, which were potential sales lost. The intrusion with potential scammers and over zealous vendors was quite off-putting.I must also add that the majority of people you will come across will be decent and welcoming, and local people going about their daily business. There are also some great restaurants and riads to be found among the winding streets.

A true moroccan experience. As you would expect, in the medina, everyone becomes your "friend".The sights and smells are truly amazing, but beware the unwanted 'guides' and tricksters who expect payment for no service.This is a great experience but you would be wise to treat every approach with caution. The endless hassle can be quite wearing and may spoil your experience, but if you can learn to say "No" to everyone, you will have more fun. Making a living here is hard, so expect perseverance and ingenuity from the locals. There is no real danger to you, but I can't say the same for your cash!

Interesting souks. Be careful in the square as befor you know it someone will have wrapped a snake around your neck or a monkey on your shoulders in order for you to have your photo taken. THERE IS A CHARGE !! They can get quite nasty if they don't think you've paid enough !!!

Not advisable late pm during Ramadan. All you would expect from a Souk, but we went during Ramadan and you can imagine how you would feel at the end of a long day in the searing heat with no food, drink or cigarettes. Not that much patience to haggle with tourists who can clearly afford to pay. The atmosphere was a bit too intimidating for my liking.Friends went the next morning and it was completely different atmosphere.

Marrakech medina is something. Marrakech medina is full of life. Snake charmers, jugglers, fortune tellers, merchants of all kinds, locals and tourists all living in a moment of colour that is a thrill to the senses. Staying in a Riad in the medina we enjoyed a truly wonderful experience.
lots of spices. if you want a £10 rolex this is the place to go, lots of beggars,spices and some nice pottery, but very crowded.

The real deal. For me the only reason to visit Marrakesh is the Medina. I would advise you to try and find a riad there as well. It's the traditional part of the town and it travells you back in time with its narrow souks and all the amazing things you will see there!!

Shopping spree. When visiting the red city, Marrakech, one should never fail to visit the medina. It is heaven for shoppers. One visit is not enough for a shopping spree. Shoppers have to practice the skill of bargaining. Start bargaining with more than half the price given. If you are good, you can eventually agree on the half price originally given. Don't show interest right away and try to move to the next shop. They almost always try to lure you back again with better prices.

Medina of Marrakech. Marrakech Medina is truly amazing! We were stunned by colours, sounds, sights, smells of the shops, their wares and the variety of goods. Our western shopping centres are so dull in comparison. Such an exotic place to shop! Bartering essential!

Ancient city of Medina. Very interesting rural and traditional place. Most locals ride a motor bike. Beware the taxis as they don't like to use the meter so that they can over price the journey. Insist on the meter.

Beautiful souks. Its so busy in the evening not so much in the day. So much to explore but not much time. Food and orange juice stands just love it. Don't forget to bargain in the souks. Enjoy the smells of the spices. Just fantastic.
A Must See. Take a trip back in time with shops selling all manner of items, artisans crafting everything from leather goods to metal ware. And don't miss the snake charmer.

worht to spend more days for exploring. it was after 2 day that i realized, it is much bigger, and for doing shopping I might find some ery specilized shops that I was not able to discover first day. I think it is because it seems smaller than it is, I like that it has several small squares with it's specific energy.
Interesting. Did a tour around the medinat but enjoyed the souk really good fun however avoid being scammed stay smart

Fascinating. Here you will find everything from snake charmers monkey's ,dancers an array of food stalls and the souks are brilliant ,be prepared to barter it is part of the custom there is so much to see and buy you could buy all your souvenirs can be bought andit's so much cheaper than the hotels you can also get the best rate of exchange in the medina

Not much to see. We went there durning the night and day. Is better at night as you can experience busy town life, full off nice food. You must try traditional tazine and ice cream there are amaiaing.

Interesting. We are glad we went to experience the place, however you do get pestered and it can get tiresome. As long as you know this in advance, you can survive, maybe hire a guide in advance as they will take care of you.

must see. The medina during the day is one thing but at night it comes alive. There are acts of various kinds stalls selling all number of goods, thousands of lights and dozens of places to eat. Visit the medina during the day by all means but do not leave Marrakech without visiting at night truely a sight to behold, and we felt perfectly safe at all times.

Make sure to visit at day and night!. By day the Medina is full of oddities and entertainment. By night it is a bustling hub of food vendors and sideshow entertainers. Don't miss either of them!During the day, ake sure you try the freshly squeezed orange juice; it's delicious. One of our party literally called it a 'revelation', and said he'd never realised just how bad what we drink at home really was! I don't know how you pick which vendors include ice (for those worried about getting sick), but I had plenty from different vendors and had no problems.For the night, walk around the food stalls until you find someone who can convince you to eat at theirs over others. We were won over by a man who had realised we were Australian, and thus started swearing so we'd feel more at home! Classic stuff.
Disappointing at night. Having heard such great things about this place was very disappointed. Not much happening and no snake charmers or real entertainment at night. Did feel safe there however.
A good experience. If you enjoy bargaining this is the place for you as there is something for everyone. It is filled with locals and tourists and a must see.

The #1 Tourist Attraction. In my opinion you have to go to the Medina to experience the Souks. It's incredible, chaotic, and just crazy. I found it fantastic, and respected the real lifes of the Marrackech.
A must in Marrakech . If you're in Marrakech you have to come here!! The shops, restaurants, snake charmers etc it's a real buzz so much culture here

We enjoyed moving between the shops. we had a lovely sunny day in the medina where we were shopping and we had such a good experience even if it was hard to negotiate with the merchants but it was good

Wild and crazy . Fun fast pace shopping haggling friendly people good food experience of a lifetime
Be prepared to walk easy to navigate the sights and the sounds and the smell of grilled meat makes this a must go to place

Now THIS is a Medina!. Wonder till your heart is content. Go ahead a get lost, as it's not a problem. We stayed in a Riad near the square so we could always find our way back. Plenty to see. It's even enjoyable for the non shopper. Just be sure to ask first if you are taking a picture of a person. Each souk has something special to offer.

Time matters. When traveling to the medina be sure to do so when the sun is not at its high point since it is very hot and can be quite exhausting. Also beware of the times when the marketplace is set since there is not much to see when the market is gone.

Must have a look of the busy life all day round. Very exciting once when you arrive at the Square. Do not take pictures of the stalls nor the Marrakech people on the Square otherwise they would ask you to pay for them. Bargin on every small things when you buy.

A good antique architectural medina full of interesting sights. Very busy, and very modern for the most part, Marrakech is a high end tourist town- except for th medina, which still has a slaughterhouse as part of it, fabrics, flowers, bread, vegetables and fruit for sale among the more prominent tourist items for sale. But. Is the most interesting part of Marrakech.

MEDINA of Marrakesh. A huge place with everything and anything. What a sight to see. There are people everywhere but not to the point where you feel closed in. The people are some of the friendliest I've met across the world.

Sensory Overload. The Medina is not for the faint of heart, especially at night. There is food, entertainment, goods for purchase, and an all around good time to be had. The Moroccan people are very welcoming but be cognizant that, like in most tourist areas, there are pickpockets and scammers swarming the place. My only complaint is that there is very limited police presence in the area despite this being the case. Be sure to eat at one of the stalls. There is thick competition for your patronage but the food is mostly the same. Whatever you do, don't leave without some fresh squeezed orange or grapefruit juice.

Not what you came to Morocco to see. In three weeks of travel in Morocco we visited medinas for all of the major cities. Marrakech's medina isn't the biggest (Fes is simply amazing), nor particularly authentic (try Sale for a real-world example of life as it was still existing in the new century). My best characterization of the Marrakech medina/souks is the Moroccan dollar store. If you need a cheap little tagine, ok, but if you want hand-crafted goods skip it. Not to say they don't make product there - you can get off the main drag and find everything you could wish for. But my experience is that, unlike the rest of Morocco, Marrakech is tired of tourists even as they feed upon them. As we walked through the medina, at every turn they told us which way the square was. In a pushy way without being asked. "Get back in your box" was the message I heard. We were headed to some of the museums of the city and by the time we got there it wasn't worth it at all (with the exception of the photo museum which was a nice oasis). If you do go, seek out the Berber-esque sections - they are devoid of motor travel and it's quite pleasant to talk with the shop keepers.Speaking of mopeds, Marrakech is also unique in the number of mopeds in the medina and the speed at which they travel. I coined the term 'guide stride' after the second guide we hired for a history lesson showed up with a limp from being essentially run down. Word to the wise, do not attempt to take quick pictures of anything from the dates in the stalls to people without asking. It's unwelcome in the Muslim culture generally but people react violently here. If you see something you want to photograph, buy something.The square morphs throughout the day but I'll just say that, while I'm glad to have seen it, it would not be something I would recommend to anyone for a destination. The crowds are fun to see but the real entertainment are the story tellers that enthrall hundreds as they act out scenes from the past in wonderful detail. In Arabic. So as a westerner, you're relegated to being harassed by the snake charmers that show up and drape some specie on your shoulder to try to lure you in for $20 worth of pictures. You can get fresh escargo here if you're into that. It's like Bourbon street without the party atmosphere. Lots of OJ stalls so it's got that.

Feel the atmosphere. The square is really nice with all the locals try to rip off tourists with henna, photos with monkeys... There are a lot of food stands in the center of the square which I advice you to go once for the experience, but the food is pretty expensive, the portions small and the staff stressed and unfriendly. The fruit juices on the square are a must-try! They're really tasteful and cheap!
Jones family. World herritage site. Crowded. Full of energy. You can experience the shopping enjoy the music and the food.

its a must do experience.. fantastic place to visit very busy but worth a visit. lovely to see the culture and pick up a bargain the same time. watch out for the snake charmers and monkey tamers. they wil demand money after a photo on your own phone.

💗. Me and two of my friends (3 girls total) have been in a trip to Morocco for 12 days with Morocco Easy Tours as we had the perfect mixture of amazing views from beaches, atlas mountains and desert as we were able to see a little bit of everything. Mohamed was really easy to work with and respond quickly to our emails and let us know in details he was flexible in responding to all our messages .Our driver/guide was extremely knowledgeable and kind throughout the trip he let us stop any and everywhere to take photos and enjoy the awesome landscapes and meet so many Berber locals especially in desert while trekking with camels and the fun we had after having a delicious dinner in a full starry sky really unforgettable would definitely recommend it to everyone wants to have a life time trip in Morocco.

"The Medina to see and experience". Huge collection of vendors selling everything from carpets to blacksmithed iron. Great atmosphere and while some of the vendors are a bit aggressive in their approach, it is manageable if you keep a firm resolve. I even managed to purchase a SIM card for my phone there and used it for the week we spent in Morrocco.

Immersion in Moroccan Culture. Walking through the medina will give you a sense of how the locals work and live. We could have spent a lot more time exploring the place. I would recommend buying Moroccan lamps through one of the larger stores instead of the many smaller establishments as pricing and quality is not uniform throughout the medina.

Go With the Flow. We spent two days in Marrakech and this was sufficient time to wander the Medina and enjoy the color, vibrancy, and life in the medina. We made Marrakech the last stop on our 14-day journey through Morocco and it was the most touristy of the locations we visited, but a great way to end a wonderful experience that took us from coastlines to mountains to the desert and back. Many focus on the souks, but there are many interesting historic sites within the Medina such as the Stork Hospital, Medersa Ben Youssef, Saadian Tombs, and Bahia Palace. These sites offer dazzling displays of tiles, painted ceilings, ornate carved woodwork, and intricate plaster designs. We enjoyed wandering the endless lanes and labyrinth of the souks. Have fun with it! If you haven't shopped for items to take home, this is the place to do it. In fact, I recommend getting ceramics in Fes and waiting to get everything else in Marrakech. Rule of thumb, whatever is the first price, counter at 1/3 and have fun bargaining from there. You will never get lost, so just go with the flow of people. Once you have purchased from a vendor, ask them for directions to the Jemaa el Fna to re-orient yourself and enjoy!

amazing worth to see place. You should see it and even experience this feeling of being chasen by everybody to buy try everything, that's what Morocco is known from! Try to see the Jemaa el Fna from the terrace and have a mint tea.!

Watch your bag but enjoy the sights, sounds, and smells!. A truly unique place packed full of storytellers, dancers, snake charmers, and other performers. I continue to be blown away by the colours and chaos of the souks and Jemaa El Fnaa. It´s a completely different world that is so so worth the trip. Highly recommend.

Stunning. This is an amazing experience which changes if you're there during day or night. In the day it is more laid back with Snake charmers, Monkeys & Acrobats amongst the entertainment. During the night it comes fully alive and the vibrancy of the area is amazing. There's food stalls and restaurants and all sorts in the ajoining souks. Must be experienced. The are many beggars in the city, & children selling tissues etc. Just be polite and firm if you're not interested and they will leave you alone........ well most of them will. Most people were amazingly helpful but a few were worrying & i was mindful of people trying to point me in the wrong direction. So get a map before you arrive if possible. Great adventure to be had in and around the medina!

100% overrated, tourist trap.. Not much else to say that the title doesn't say. Prepare for every single person you encounter to be only concerned with taking as much money from you as possible. No matter where you turn, someone is out for your money. A friendly smile from a local usually follows with trying to take you offer you directions, only to lead you to nowhere and then demand that you pay them to take you back. The salesmen are unrelentingly aggressive and deceitful, especially in the pop-up restaurants at night. They will quote one price, then demand a higher figure at the end. The entire djemma is a facade of the real Morocco. Having spent the last month traveling the entire country I can definitively say that Marrakech was the worst place I visited; and I was there for a week. Other travelers met along the way agree. Give the city one or two days just to say you've been and then move on. You and your wallet will be glad you did.

Rather sad..... Very little "local colour" to be had. This is full of tourist tat, depressing men with sick looking monkeys and every stall selling Orange juice.All stores sell exactly the same products which makes one suspicious of the "made by berber tribes people" claim. Unless these Berbers have a factory in China.Stop to think for a second and you will be pounced on,,,,beware

You feel you are in a spiritual World, out of time.... Jemaa el Fna is a no brainer when you visit Marrakech, the most beautiful and out of time place on earth!!!Have a good Hrira(Soup) and then a mechoui (grilled meat) and then have a walk to see all kinds of handicraft, snakes dancing at the sound of weard instruments, or if you are more of a spiritual person, have some cards red to you...

Loved it. If travelling to Marrakech then the medina is a must see. It is very busy and packed full of people but so so worth a visit. Watch the small children with your pockets and bags but other than that go and enjoy. We found all the stall holders to be fine so pushy than others but hey their only trying to earn money.

Out of this world!. The medina has many attractions well better called 'sights', within its own right the town is an incredible place to visit, the roads are full of huddle and bustle, bikes, donkeys pulling carts right through to coaches, they have a certain way of keeping traffic on the move regardless what's going on, scooters with the entire family and bags of shopping on, donkeys pulling carts at your service as part your transfer to your riad, another 'see to believe' experience for sure. At night the medina is beautiful by horse and carriage, the lights, sounds and smells will stay with you forever. There are too many places of beauty and interest around the medina to mention but any guide will certainly point out the history of as many as they can.
Very busy. This area can get very croweded and busy so if you are going qith your family hold tight to eachother.

Wow!. There is so much to do and see in the Marrakech Medina. Be prepared to constantly be asked to buy things or to pay for pics... basically to hand money over to whatever local you see for providing some sort of novelty service or unusual sight, for example, snake charmers. Be prepared to negotiate in the souks for goods and be aware of the crazy and aggressive energy of the Medina.
Exotic. Very unique and exotic. It was a surprise for me to be in a very exotic country. I'm Brazilian and everybody says that's Brazil is exotic. I'd say MARROCO is exotic and unique. I'd Love

worth a visit. Not sure I enjoyed this without a guide, very easy to get lost. We ventured a short distance into the Medina but made sure we were aware of the way out. Wasn't impressed with a lot of the goods, seemed cheap and nasty. If you can find your way to the leather quarter then the goods are hand made in front of you.

Be Prepared to be Overwhelmed!. The colors, sites, sounds and smells of the Medina are overwhelming and wonderful! Walk, wander and gawk to your hearts content, get lost in the wandering lanes and if you need to be found look for signs pointing to Jemma el Fna or just ask someone.

To correct.... The Medina is not just Jamaa el Fna, the square. It is the entire walled city inside the wider city of Marrakech. It is windy alleyways that are beyond confusing. It's filled in one area with souks. Everything in the Medina (and in Morocco) is affordable. At the souks, bargain hard. It's expected. There are great deals to be had. There is one section of antiques, which is really great if you like old stuff.There are some great restaurants and even a few places that serve liquor in the Medina.Go. Get lost. Find your way back. It's part of the adventure.

Amazing adventure!. Traveled here with my wife on our honeymoon and the old medina is amazing. Easy to get lost, but locals are for the most part very helpful (just be cautious of scams, and people trying to help you to gouge you of your money). Very busy with tons of interesting stores and restaurants. One of the coolest places weve seen in a while!
An experience. This place is the old city, what an experience, you have to see it but please keep your wits about you, a real eye opener, must see.

Crowded, but really spectacular . You cannot miss this place in Marrakech. It is a big square where a lot of things are happening- from selling Moroccan herbs, nuts, fruits, to showing dancing snakes and monkeys under typical local music. In the evenings the place gets full of people, both locals and tourists; food is prepared and served there. Tip: choose one of the restaurants nearby which offer a terrace view to the market and to the beautiful sunset.
Amazing experience. Fabulous square, vibrant and so full of life. Not to everyone's taste but we love it. Always lots to watch.

Great place to spend a few days in. If you don't mind being hassled by the sellers this is a great place for lots of Moroccan goodies, not sure about eating the food here, didn't look like any sort of refrigeration in the meat stalls but it was all very colorful and the people are very friendly and open to negotiations

Don't miss it. The Medina is a must visit in Marrakech. The centre of it is the site of the largest market in Marrakech. Don't miss it. It is fantastic. Visit later in the lay as more things will be open.

Great market. This place was amazing. The majority of our 3 day trip was spent here. All the merchants were charming and fun to talk to. The views in the restaurants nearby were great and the food was cheap also. You can get tajine for anywhere from 30 to 60 DH which is 3-6 euros. Being that this is definitely the most touristy spot, that is a good price. Tons of musicians and performers. Snake charmers, street acrobats, Berber musicians, you can find it all. I loved the snail soup and it was only 10 DH!

Crazy place. Loved this place because it's so different from what I'm used to. Most of the food in the square is affordable and delicious. I don't like seeing the chained monkeys though. Recommend going to Ouzoud Waterfalls to see monkeys in their natural habitat instead. You must visit the square while in Marrakech.

Wait bombards your senses!. At night is a good time to go walk around the Medina, it is lively, there are food stands, the souk is opened, lots of people all over the place, all sorts of animals can be met on the square: monkeys, snakes... It is busy, loud with music, smells of food etc. A must see in Marrakesh, so crazy and so... Marrakesh!!!

Shopping Central. there is a medina in every city, but in marrakesh u must learn how to negotiate, keep negotiate they will drop or way away and the drop lower, in the square dont get caught takin pic cuz they will ask you for money
Wow. What a site. It's chaotic, it's big, it forms the heart and soul of Marrakech. You simply must visit!

wonderful madness. mix of everything Moroccan not recommended for those of nervous disposition beware of henna woman who will grab your hand and just start and then expect you to pay 40 euro we gave 4 to get rid of her and said we would get the police
A different world . Certainly worth a visit, I would suggest hiring a guide who will take you to all the interesting places. The main square is very active and lots of food stalls in the evening.

Unique experience of Marrakesh. I booked a tour of Medina of Marrakesh trough my hotel while in Marrakesh, It was such an amazing experience and I am so Happy I got a guide because there is so much to know, so much history and common knowledge, and I am sure we would get so lost by ourself. Finish the tour at a rooftop restaurant with a great view of the Medina
A very different medina. More like a walled city than a classic Moroccan medina but still interesting to explore. Easy to access by taxi anywhere in the medina.

easy to get lost but like taking a step back in time wonder fresh orange juice and so much to see. wonderful to experience step back intime coulors perfumes monkeys snake charmers the square has it all happening cant go without a visit
Crazy but worth a look . Haggling at its best it's a must see if you visit morroco night time was amazing so many people and sites and smells
find anything!. be prepared to barter, and make sure you can get out again once you're in! it is literally a-maze-ing.
