Vibrant and a must see. We had dinner here one night, great fun on the stalls. Avoid the snake charmers and henna ladies, don't take photos of people unless you want to pay for the privilege. Felt safe at all times. Orange juice stalls are good.

Visit during the day and the evening for a full experience. You can have two completely different experiences if you visit during the morning and then again in the evening...after some amazing shopping. Tip....ask your Riad for recommendations if you are looking for anything particular, they are likely to send someone with you, and of course be prepared to haggle.

Just in awe ! . We have just returned on the 20/05/2016 It was an eye opener and somewhere not to miss, The places are alive with vibrant colours of spices and flowers to the people who are dressed in gorgeous colours it makes you want to come again and again and never leave, There is so much on offer for all ages tranquil walks or hustling bustling shopping trips.Buying things from keyrings to rugs, bags, spices and local treasures !
Hustle and bustle. Not as intimidating as some of the stories I'd heard and read about. Just smile and say no, they just move on to the next one. Don't be afraid to haggle "it's fun."

Colorful, interesting. The Medina or old city of Marrakech is something that everyone should experience at least once. Its completely different from anything most Westerners are used to. However, after having been there, you'll either love it or hate it. Its loud, so loud. Its smelly. There are donkeys and mules and horses. And a lot of the people don't appear to use deodorant either. The food smells pretty interesting too. The tajines smell great. Some of the raw organ meats don't smell so great. There are people absolutely everywhere trying to make a dime off of you in absolutely any way they can. You'll either enjoy the game or hate being a target. Welcome to Marrakech.
Old Medina. Just go in the medina, get lost in this new world of little roads and streets. Forget the first shops at the Jemmaa el Fna and go and discover the real world of the medina.
Vibrant and must see. You cannot leave Marrakesh without visiting! A bit dead in the day time, but by night, how it is transformed. Try to get a drink at a roof top bar for the stunning sunset.
Very uncomfortable . Busy too many mopeds whizzing in streets so you really do have to keep your wits about you. Unless your a confident person I would give this one a miss.

A "must" for everyone. Our 4th visit to Marrakesh over 10 years, and as ever, the Medina, old city of Marrakesh, is the star of this fabulous city.Smells, sounds and sights compete for our attention, combining in a heady mix of ancient culture in a modern world.The twisting alleys can be daunting for the 1st-timer, but after a day or so, you get used to them and revel in "navigating" with maps and help from the locals. Getting lost is all part of the fun!We feel safer in Marrakesh than we do in most UK cities: the people of Marrakesh are the city's heartbeat...and it has a heart of gold.Every traveller should pack a large sense of humour: join in the banter, watch the food stalls in the Jemaa el Fna square joyfully cajole tourists and locals alike into eating at their traditional, bench-seated diner, and if things take a little longer than you're used to at home - smile - you're in Marrakesh! In the main square, we especially love dinner at "Simon's food stall 81, The European-style Argana coffee house, (fab pastries!), and the terrific restaurant Chez Chegrouni, where you write down what you order on a piece of paper, and give it to the waiter. Great Moroccan food here + good value too.The maze of alleys, wider lanes and roads are a constant source of fascination...take time to walk, rather than use taxis everywhere.The Medina also encompasses innumerable shops, cafes, restaurants, market stalls, a few palaces, (not on the scale of Buckingham Palace, but well worth an or two of your time, and incredibly cheap to visit), and of course the main souk, just off Jemaa el Fna square, itself, a World Heritage site.Go, go, go!

Just lots of tourist rubbish. not much variety in the good on offer, most seems to sell very similar items and alot of touristy items that you really wouldnt want to buy. It was disappointing as I was really looking forward to exploring here.If you do go, expect to haggle and to get hassled as you look around.

Overwhelming, but fascinating. You can get your shopping fix here for sure. Hundreds of shops in an area you can gleefully get totally lost in. A must see for Marrakech, and attached to the Jaffa square.

Large and colourful!. You will get lost here! The sights, the sounds, the scents are all incredible. You can find just about anything and everything here - though do take care crossing roads as pedestrian crossings don't mean much! You just have to walk out and hope traffic (a mishmash of taxis, cars, motorcycles, bikes, donkey carts, horse drawn carriages etc etc) will avoid you.If you show interest in something, sellers can be persistent but the general atmosphere is friendly.One tip - if you want to stop for a drink, go to a rooftop cafe from where you can watch all the mayhem in relative calm.
Amazing. Very Interresting and nice place...You have to go to a Kafee which has a nice view has ....Musics,Smells,Animals,etc etc

Lovely architecture . Visit here on or recent trip to Marrakech. Such beautiful architecture, such a lovely building with so much history. I felt emotionally moved when I entered the mosque. Worth a visit if you in Marrakech.

Visit . Amazing place and very hard to describe.Keep a close eye on your wallet and purses as apparently there are alot of pickpockets around not that we encountered any personally.Don't forget to haggle!!

Burst of noise, vision and smell.. This is something else, the noises, the smells, the sights. Do go both during the day and at night to see the difference.Do go to one of the cafes with an upper terrace to see the square and the market from above and fully take it in. Haggle for everything, never except the first price. Smell the spices, watch the entertainment.Soak it all in. If you have a child with you this is a really busy area, use some sort of reins so you do not loose them, the markets intertwine like a maze.

Great fun !!!. The medina and souk complex is a delight ! Snake charmers, monkey handlers, horse carriage rides, and a multitude of eating or snacking opportunities make this area one of the top attractions for tourists and locals alike. Photographers beware, however - most people in this area don't like to be photographed, and those who are willing will likely ask for money. Be sure to sample some of the many food stalls around the area.

In a different world. Medina, the city centre of Marrakech, is so live. Tons of people in the streats, having interest in you and where you come from. A lot of colours and smells everywhere. And so many people! Beware of the mule carts, bikes and scooters everywhere :)
Great break away. Great break away. Just over 3 hours flight time, sun, bargain shopping and lovely food. Make sure you have good comfy walking shoes

Real Marrakech. you have to taste the Medina.. Enter and get lost - just keep walking... taste the smells (sometimes a little rough but this is Marrakesh), avoid motorcycles, see the small shops, check the souks, ask for better price, just keep walking ... A lot of reviews are here about the "dangers" and people harassing you - just pay no attention to them and they will not bother you. Eventually you will come to the main square Djemma el Fna.. uauu so big, lots of stands with fresh juice. In case you are sick at some point of walking through Medina just go out (ask someone and they will point you). You can reach Djemma al Fnaa also by walking outside of Medina... but where's the fun then :-)
Medina Must See. We visited Marrackech for 4 days, you simply must spend one evening at the Medina it changes into an amphitheater of colours and smells during the evening.

All sences. One should stroll through that crisscross of small streets. It's the place to find what you are looking for: food, furniture, leather, small presents for the ones remaining home... Alibaba's cave. But, beware: you have to haggle.

great. visited during the day and early evening, great atmosphere. Plenty of bargains to be had. be careful when taking photos as many of the entertainers will want money from you for photos. Snake charmers, gamblin, comedy and magicians. Also Henna tattoos (beware as they will chase you with the Henna pens and mark you, then try to charge you for it)

Prepare to be surprised! A must visit.. You know that dream where you are in the middle of a bazar in the set of the film CasaBlanca? Well this is 10 times as intense and disoriented and far from a movie set, everything here is real, no director will yell cut, in fact you just might get run by a local motorcycle. That being said. Go. Adventure yourself, be brave and explore this unique side of the world. Ask for directions if you need to while never looking hopelessly lost. Be prepare to negotiate with merchants and make sure to be aware of your belongings. Authentic Atmosphere: 4Cleanliness: 3Local service: 3.5 Total: 10.5 (Anything above a 10 is worth visiting) Happy Adventure!

Take it in!!!. Visiting the Medina is unlike most places in the world. The narrow streets and the ancient buildings frame endless shops and stalls. Yes, there are some people who try to lead you around and provide unnecessary directions, but if you say your fine and don't engage they will pretty quickly leave you alone. You haven't truly visited Marrakech until you have gotten momentarily lost in the Medina.

Amazing, fascinating, WOW.. Loved this place. It had so much to see and the sights, sounds and smells just dazzled the senses. It was surprisingly clean for such a busy crowded place and the locals were very friendly.
Fantastic hanging around. Best place to take a nice traditional hotel, and just get lostMake sure you know where you stay!!! No joking. I got lost more then once

Enjoyed the Medina. This is a mini version of Istanbul's Grand Bazaar but more calm, and less harassing. There were working craftsmen e.g. iron works, dying wool, baking bread, weaving rugs, etc. We enjoyed the outdoor aspects of the Medina with the small curved streets which were fun to explore. Best to go early in the day before the tourist rush, also recommend a 1/2 day guide which helps acclimate you for any return visits.
Superb place.. Very special experience to walk around this maze of very narrow streets. The grand square is also a very special place. Walk around and taste the atmosphere.

Cobblers!. Recommend the cobblers in the Medina. Just before Cafe Za za. Re soled and heeled ( mending the heel ) a really badly worn and scuffed pair of treaasured comfy Next sandals. Did a great job. Sat there an hour but he spent time and they will now last a few more holidays. As usual...... A third off what he asks.. How he spotted the sandals with a real flat heel were scuffed and low soled I'll never know!!!

Busy but a must! . You must experience the medina, both in the day and at night. It's a completely different atmosphere depending on the time. A firm shake of the head will stop you being harassed too much, and allow you to enjoy it!

Shopping. There are a thousand shops all selling the same things and you must haggle if you want to buy anything. My advice is that you should pay between a third and a half of the asking price.
Have fun, get lost, find your way again, enjoy the sights and smells of the place.

LOVELY - sights and experiences in abundance . The whole of Marrakesh is an experience in itself .
There is such a diversity of things to see and do - the Medina is no exception - we visited 3 times during out stay as each time you go there is more to see .
great shops. Huge number of wonderful shops selling beautiful objects, interesting food items all in narrow alleys, warrens of shops. Best to have a guide since easy to get lost. Learn to say "no".

This is amazing!. This is a true celebration of life. Watch the sunset from any of the rooftop bars, survey the entertainments, then snack from the stalls or have a sit down meal. I ate in a few of the stalls over a few nights and all was good, safe, tasty, good value and fun!

GO NOW...SERIOUSLY, GO RIGHT NOW!. probably the most lively place I have every been to on this great earth. The sights, smells, sounds, and overall energy of the medina is intoxicating and captivating. Make sure to go to the square, the Jemma el Fna, both during the day and at night, it is magical.

Okey dokey. Huge market square lots of street performers. Snakes, etc. If you take pics they will ask you for money. We didn't like the monkeys being used for photos but up to you. Once again keep hand on valuables. Don't let the women try to get your ladies hands with henna tats. There's stuff in it that attacks your skin. It's an eye opening place. You will harrased all the time but it's like that all the time here. It's good just say no thanks and keep walking. There's nothing here u can't buy. We kept getting asked if we wanted hash or get high. Just refuse. It's worth a look. May take you 2 days or so to get good look about

FUNKY,SOUL MEDINA OF MAROC........... The walled Medina of Marrakesh,is the original city&in many ways still exists,as it always did,with its mazes of identical,ancient, narrow alleys(initially very easy to get lost,without a guide,as I experienced...so make sure you have your address punched into your phone)flanked each side with rows of homes, riad architecture(facing internally)only the unique wooden or metal doors,with there personal family touches,distinguishing one from another...outdoor market streets with all manner of fruits,spices,dates,veggies,flour,delicious street food&orange juice carts,cobblers,bath houses(HAMAN)just everything...its really like being in another world,all the women dressed in their gorgeous,colourful traditional Berber clothes adorned with silk tassels ,tres chic!..& the locals are so friendly,kind&welcoming...& of course,it would be remiss of me not to mention,the ubiquitous mint tea,referred as,by an octogenarian local as..."Moroccan whisky"...My experience was overwhelmingly positive ...just one word of caution,be mindful in the main square,of pickpockets&the usual tourist traps&cons,be firm(not rude!)in refusing their offers...and please don't point cameras in peoples faces....always ask..& give a small donation .....

New medina/ old medina. Every time i visited the city I had a bunch of taxi drivers waiting to harass everyone that came of the shuttle bus to drive you to the markets. They start of pretending to help by telling this is your bus stop and timetable to return. There were also teenage boys waiting at the bus stop forcing you to buy sweets of them even after you say no they don't go away. Once you are walking in the new medina the malls are fixed prices so it's not so bad. However, whilst walking around you get attended my locals trying to sell things and ladies pretending to be poor begging for money. The old medina is awful as you get harassed by several men who stop you when your looking at your phone map and general map. Even if you politely say no you don't need their help they still ask where you going and try to give the wrong direction to what's on the map and don't leave you alone. The worst is the fake tour guides in the old medina. We got approached by one called moustafa who apparently claimed his service is free because he works for the government and guided us to go to the markets but it turned out to be his family/friends shops with fake government flags. They started off going on about their culture about specialising in carpets and argan oil then trying force us to buy carpets for ridiculous prices. when we had and showed no interest they were becoming verbally aggressive and annoyed. Avoid any fake tourist who pretend to work for the government and say they will take you to the government markets/shops. In fact avoid them altogether and stick with guidance from your hotel/holiday package tour representatives and the map. The old medina in Marrakech is another version of Egypt where you get harassed by dodgy cunning people.

INDESCRIBABLE!!. This is the heart and soul of marrakesh..With spices,clothing,all u need for morrocan HAMAM .You can walk .. Buy . And eat the traditionel food of the country like " harira" a very tasty soup." tanjia" and " tajin" and lots of other foods.You will find lots of stuff to buy but be careful because you need to negotiate a lot to get a good bargain .
a crazy place. Medina is the place to stay and hang out in Marrakesh. Very unique and an oasis of colours. Try to be close to main square

Assault on the senses. The old medina is a good place to spend the whole day. The souks are a great location to get a cheap bargain on the local moroccan souvenirs. Beware of the high prices quoted at the start as they always bump up the prices in anticipation of bargaining by the tourists. Also, stay away from people who will try to show you directions or offer to take you to certain locations that you cannot find as they will always ask for money afterwards.

Way way way too many motos . Did not like Marrakech - way too dusty dirty crowded fast loud scary and traffic-laden. Everyone complains about the pushy salesmen and beggars at every corner but worse is feeling you would be run over at any moment by a motorcycle, car, bike or scooter darting EVERYwhere - on sidewalks, narrow alleys, tearing through the vegetable markets and of course packed 10 deep at any given moment in the street. No one stops for pedestrians, either, no traffic rules at all that we could see, so every outing was stressful - not fun at all, even if it was historic.
Medina of Marrakech. take a horse and cart ride around the medina probably the best way to sight see and to avoid beggars the street kids and people trying to drag you into the shops.
The heart of Marrakech. I think it is the best place in Marrakech, with its roads, inhabitants, hand carts and donkey carts, its smells, its houses. I stayed in Medina and I suggest it to all.

Medina good. People RUDE. Medina of Marrakech is all good and beautiful but the people are very rude. You cannot take pictures of meat hanging? I mean c'mon. Very rude peple. Never seen anywhere I have been to.
You'll get lost. We took a food tour so we had a guide to walk through the Medina and Souks. Ask shopowners or women (not guys on the street) how to get back to the main square if you get lost.

A journey worth. Marrakech is a journey worth. You need few day only to see what to be seen, you can walk to all points.Marrakech is safe as every other town in Europe. People here know this and ensure safety

Amazing place!. The medina and most importantly, Marrakech is amazing. This place is a serious overload on the senses. The people are very nice. The food is amazing, and prices are pretty cheap. That being said, here is a few things you need to watch out for; as I said previously that the people are very nice...so nice they will nice the money right out of your pocket. If you want to buy something it's ok to ask the price, but realize you can barter for about half (or less) than the price they give you. If you aren't interested, thank them and keep moving. Another thing is they will ask you for your "lowest offer", if you give them a offer..you just opened negotiations..realize though it's still ok to walk away, just a little harder. The best and cheapest way to buy beer or liquor is at the store in "new city". It will cost about 20 Durham and 5 minutes by taxi. If you just want an occasional beer or drink, go to hotel Tazi, they have a bar and are relatively cheap, but not store cheap. Do not hire a horse cart to take you around the medina, most of the horses are actually taken care of, the rest are not and it's sad. While we were there my wife and I saw a horse collapse out of sheer exhaustion and the driver started kicking the horse in the head to make it get up. Alot of people, including myself yelled at him to stop, and he did. But still. The food is amazing as well. The fruit vendors will mix fresh squeezed orange juice and any other fruit you can think of for 10 Durham. Very cheap, good, and healthy. Chicken Tajine is very popular and amazing. One last thing, if someone asks ti take you to the leather tannery, its not worth it, stinky, and not in a great part of town..trust me when i say to skip this..you arent missing anything . Above all, have fun and keep moving.
People everywhere. Sights sounds and smells are everywhere here, as are hundreds of people.. you just cannot take in all in on one visit, sadly we didn't get to come here again this time round.
adictive. I loved the medina with all its noise, markets, people, etc. Just get lost. Everything starts quite late and the best moment to visit for me was the afternoon.

Loved the medina, hated the roar of the scooters. Yes the medina -- and especially the souks -- is a fascinating place to visit. The Jemma al Fna is always interesting with snake charmers, fortune tellers, letter writers, etc. Of course it is full of mostly tourists, but definitely a place not to be missed in the city. We spent a day walking around and loved the energy of the place, loved the small shops, loved walking around the artisan stalls where people we actually making metal objects, rugs, wood pieces, etc. That was fascinating to watch! But over the last few years it has become ever more difficult to walk around safely because of the increasing number of motor scooters that roar through the small streets. Many of them are driven by testerone-fueled young men who seem not to realize actual human beings are using the same paths. In addition to the danger, the smell of the gas/oil is unpleasant. Add the scooters to the usual bicycles, mules, carrying carts and it is sometimes harrowing to get where you want to go. Don't know why the city doesn't ban the scooters but until they do, the medina (especially the souks with its narrower streets) is not a place we like to stroll around.

Bustling place. Lots to see and do and you have to try the fresh orange juice its just amazing , oranges with cinnamon are good too and the street venders and music brings the place alive at nighttime

A Must visit in Marrakech. Friday or Saturday nights are best crazy place with all the sights and smells of Marrakesh. Yes you will be approached by many people trying to sell you things but don't let this put you off going.
Amazing Shopping Paradise. I walked out with arms full of great treats! I loved the energy and feel of the places we visited and the wonderful beauty of the Medina....it was amazing
Quite an experience. Great experience loved staying and wondering through the medina. Such a great way to experience the culture and way of life.

Cool Place. A cool place that must be visited. But looking up got pickpockets . If you are scared for snakes, avoid the place .There is plenty of food and coffee shops around Medina. However in some restaurant and coffee shops they are charging you for toilet visit.
lovely at night. wonderful place to go sights smells and noise best to go in the day first to get a feel of the place carful at night

Excellent walking adventure with lots of visual and olfactory stimuli. Walking around the Medina during the day or the night is quite entertaining and visually exciting. Yes, you will be accosted by many street vendors but a opposite but firm "no thank you" works even for the most stubborn vendor. Watch out for traffic especially motorbikes as the rules of the road are unclear.

Crazy place. Amazing but crazy place. This maze is filled with people selling everything and anything you could possibly think of. The shop owners will try and drag you in to see their wares but stop when you say you aren't interested. As a female on my own I thought there might be trouble from being pestered but it was fine. Get ready to barter for everything, it's all part of the fun

Pushy, aggressive and sketchy . Pushy sales people everywhere. And don't even think about taking a picture of the monkey or snake charmer because they'll run up to you demanding money and will put there hands on you aggressively. I almost punched one of there lights out but I think he realized he was a second from death and backed off. Do not eat there unless you want to lose 50lbs in 24 hours due to major GI issues. And watch the pickpockets. Put your wallet in your front pocket and ladies be sure to hold your purse in front. Good luck!!!
Crazy, but Wonderful!. You must spend some time in the center of the old city. It is like going back into time! Try some food and bargain for some items about half what they starting price it!

great to meet new people. If you go to Morocco you have to experience the shopping at the Medina, and this one is a great example. Hundred of small streets to get lost, safe and great shopping opportunities: food, clothes, shoes, souvenirs, antiques...and mandatory to bargain. Just chill out and enjoy the real taste of Morocco!

Oh the colors and people!!. The Medina is Full of Beautiful colors, smells, sounds, and people!!! Sellers calling to buyers and shoppers walking by, street acts, snake charmers, actors wanting payment for a photo-all in good economic prosperous gest!! Definitely get a private guide to show you all the hidden treasures and sweet history & culture you won't get touring around on your own!! Our guide was Khalid Amor-with Marrakech Best Tours! He was amazingly knowledgeable of the city and its history, fluent in English and exceedingly intelligent! Definitely look him up!!!

Be prepared to haggle a lot. It was a bit of a scary experience. It is a lot to take it. Everyone calls you to their stalls and once your in one they start putting things on you and asking you to try everything. They then give you a really high price which you have to haggle a lot to bring down. I wasn't very patient, and just wanted to get out of there. But its def an experience to have had.

Go there if you enjoy an occasional chaos. The medina is big and there is so much history there. I can feel tales of gone days through the narrow alleys, souks, riads and the main square. There is no time for boredom there. Just be prepared to part with your physical space and privacy while you're there. With the right frame of mind, it is a memorable place.

Good for shopping. Spent a short time in Medina but managed to get a great massage at Hammam Rosa Bonheur Spa (very cheap!) and buy some gifts for my family and friends. All the shop owners are open to negotiation, go in with half! I was buying a scarf which he quoted as 200 dirhams and came to down 100 by the end. A lot of small lanes and motorbikes often speeding through so be aware of where you are walking and be careful of your belongings. It was generally very safe but I've heard there are a lot of pickpockets in this area.

Brilliant as expected. Another must to see, and another world away. Monky charmers, story tellers, teethe pullers, lots of interesting places to eat, a real threat for the sences. A hubub of madness, so good we went there 3 times, beware of the 'bargains' in the souks, as we found most were made in China, and way overpriced, but still good fun to barter with the sellers!

Medina. Very interested part of the city, with the big artisanal souk. Explore and roam through the many back alleys, souks, and open areas to truly experience the medina. All roads lead to Jemaa el Fna, so not worry! Avoid the shoping

Come to MarrKesh if you want scams, get harrased, fake silvers from China, to see animal cruelty, no peace at all !. We just came back from marrakesh, it was a horrible experienced! As soon as we went out of our riad accommodation, the little boy followed us pretending to help about directions to go to the souk but later on asked us for money 50 dirhams as a charge for directions. He even misled us to our destination. There's loads of animal cruelty going on: snakes, cobras and monkeys. Fake silver being sold in the Berber house tour which they even weight pretending it's a silver but later on we found out it's just fake. As well, fake silver being sold on the streets. We've been fooled and bought 380 dirhams of Jewerly: 1 necklace, 2bracelets but, we later found out it was fake silver! There's no peace at all eating.....vendor offer loads of stuff for us to buy every minute non-stop, expensive tourist price in the restaurant, food have no taste at all! I've been harassed as well while walking, some Moroccan men making sex remarks even my husband was beside me as well, when we went inside the shops. Some of them keep touching my shoulders while talking to buy stuffs. Bargaining experience was horrible! I hate it, they know how to cheat people. Every Moroccan wants a piece of tourist money. And there was a morrocan woman who just grab my hand and painted henna unsolicited and charging 200 dirhams then won't go away until we agreed to pay her 50 dirhams for her to go away. Kids, old people and mother carrying child begging for money. Leather bags-buy from the shop with a price tag. We later found out after bargaining hard that the same bags we bought were more cheaper in the other shop (only 1shop) have a price tag around that medina and it's hard to find and he will not even forced us to buy. It was a shame we bought the expensive bags already that we thought we got a good bargain, not at all...the morrocan people are very clever in getting tourist money. We felt that we only enjoyed the riad accommodations experiencing the Moroccan culture but no thanks to the everyday scams and scums, deceiver, cheaters, liars and harassment as soon as we stepped out of our riad accommodations. We will never come back, never again! You've been warned..... Don't trust those people trying to help, they want money in return. Morrocan people see tourist as walking money, just money trying to take a piece of money. It's a shame that people want to go to morroco to experience the rich culture and tradition but end up regretting....after experiencing a horrible deception from the morrocan people.

Easy to get lost but fun. Get a table in one of the cafe bar balconies for a view of the square and its activities. Watch out for the snake charmers and the monkeys; the owners will put one on you and charge you for the privilege. But that aside, the medina is a rabbit warren of activity and full of fascinating shops, curios and smells.
Unique. No visit to Marrakech is complete without a visit to the Medina. Set enough lots of time for wondering about aimlessly to fully capture the experience.
1 day. Thats all there is to say... 1 day here is enough. Same old tat for sale and people hassling you. Its cheap to eat and drink here but be vary of hygine levels in the surrounding restaurants.

Good place to grab food or a drink. The heart of the old medina. It is a must visit. Do be warned you will be pestered by almost all street traders trying to sell you food, products or take pictures with you for money. Don't let that put you off as it is still very exciting and really comes alive in the night time!

Forgettable experience. What a horrible place! Everyone I met during our 5 day visit was trying to rip us off. These people are not ready for tourism, beggars on every corner harassed by conmen aka stall owners. From taxi drivers to food stall owners, everyone sees you as a payday. Considering people visiting are 'guests' in their country they have a horrible approach. Nobody does anything for you without expecting money off you, leaves a bad taste when you can't trust anyone, everyone is on a hustle. Definitely a 3rd world country but still want to be paid in Euros, last time I checked Marrakesh wasn't in Europe.

Fantastic! Exercice extreme Caution!. Exercise caution of the winding alleyways that are accessible to experienced locals by moped, donkey, horse, carts, etc. Look left, right, up, down and all around when you are walking! I loved it. The Medina is the place to stay for an authentic moroccan holiday. Get lost, pick out silly landmarks to guide you home and just explore. People will try and show you the way because more often than not they can tell that you are lost. I was aware of this prior to travelling, so always said no thanks , but just took on board where they said. it's easy to get lost, but easy to find your way back again. it's an assault on the senses to quote Jamie Oliver and I loved every minute of it. Be sure and haggle and just enjoy it. It's like nowhere I have ever been!

Not more tourist tat!. I suspect the shop keepers have cashed in on the tourist market and it has lost some of its authenticity. Many shops selling the same items, so much so that it was difficult to find something original. Fez was probably a better medina for shopping. Having said that, if it is the atmosphere of a bustling market with all manner of smells and sights you will be able to experience a passing moving mass of people, donkeys motorbikes and barrows. Plenty of cheap tourist tat to say you've been there and done that!

Huge but bargins to be found. This is a dizzying place - an endless maze of narrow streets full of vendors selling a huge variety of goods. Prices vary and haggling is a must - shop around before buying. Take a break and savour an ice cream or go to one of the restaurants overlooking the main square for a coffee to escape the chaos.

Medina at night. Having blond hair was a real issue in the medina, especially at night. It was non stop harassment with was very annoying. Don't take photographs of the snake charmers or the men with monkeys as they get angry and demand money from you. Also, when someone says "I will show you where to go" if you are lost then be prepared to have to pay them for their services whether you wanted directions or not. It was a real eye opener and something I wouldn't want to do again but glad I experienced it.

amazing. roamed its streets alone being a woman. was not harrassed but i was dressed conservatively ( long sleeves and trousers ). i am blond. all the attention i received was polite requests to see what they were selling. nothing inappropriate. a " la, shukran" ( no thanks ) suffices if you dont want sth. they stop bothering you. the best stuff is deep in meding souks. outside the stuff is very common ( might even be chinese ). i was, however, unsuccessful at getting the price i wanted. merchants here are very good at bargaining and i am a woman.. both play a role. the henna ladies are not invasive. they ll ask but if you say no that s that. in morning jeema el fna is ok but at night.. it s magic!!! they are human juke boxes. you see a sight you like, you offer 10dh and they begin performing. it s better to visit it as late as possible.lots of food stalls. cafes around square. cheap tea. nice people. I did not feel uncomfortable walking alone.

Unforgetable. The rush and joy of the people are a must see...
This is the real Marrakech, everybody should have dinner at least once.
It is very safe, altough we have been warned about litle thiefs.
We allways went there by foot or by taxi, day and night and never had any problems

Take a leisurely stroll through the Marrakech Medina. One of the many highlights of a visit to Marrakech has to be a day spent exploring The Medina with its many narrow and maze-like streets. It comes as such a contrast to the wide open spaces of Jemmael fna (main square). The Medina dates from 1070 an is an UNESCO World Heritage Centre. Explore it at you leisure no need to hurry here.

Bring Empty Bags. You will get lost, you will be awed, you will shop and you will eat. Bring empty bags because even if you're not a shopper you may become one. We got lost several times however people were nice and helpful towards us and gave us proper directions. We didn't feel unsafe, harassed or annoyed. It is sensory overload but once you get a feel of the layout you'll have a truly memorable experience.

Magical experience. The evening is the time to get the feel of real Morrocco, withe dazzling array of lights, shops, bazaars, cafes, restaurants, night club, discos.in the main square the centre opens up to fire eater, side shows, monkeys, snake charmers, remember that you are in an African country and the standards and treatment of animals are not to everyone's taste. You can have a really good bargain hunt and haggle

Went Everyday... All day.. Probably the best work trip I've had. The market is crowed, busy, diverse, dusty, and every inch of the place is packed with cool and unique items. At every turn someone wants to make deal with you. I loved it. The best part was the expression of my pilots when they saw what I was taking back to the states on a private jet.(Not mine, I'm a flight attendant) I'd go back in a heart beat.KLP

There is many things to see. There is a lot more to see and experience in other areas of the Medina and some places outside. Be prepared for hassle, ignore unwanted attention, be confident and avoid hesitation. Don't be bullied into anything at the end of the day you are on holiday.

The soul of Marrakech. You are going to get lost a lot (have some change with you, in case you get tired of looking for your hotel or the square). Felt really safe walking around and enjoying the souks.Getting anything from local will probably cost you. Get transfer from your riad, as most of them are virtually impossible to find on your own (even with GoogleMaps and TripAdvisor)

Unforgettable. The Medina is unforgettable. It is huge and has everything you may or may not need. Don't be afraid or ashamed to negotiate prices, as this is the important part of the Medina's life :)
Crazy as u would expect. It a must see but the food is a real let down, something to do once but I would rather eat the the great restaurants available unless ur on a budget

Creepy aggressive men. My husband and I hated this tourist trap. It is very crowded and full of men aggressively approaching you either with snakes to drape around your neck, or to get you to eat at their food stand. When my husband didn't say no to the snake "charmer" (misnomer) I took a picture after they draped the snake on him. My hubby gave him a few bucks but he was shouting that it wasn't enough and wanted $40!!!! What? This place is to be viewed quickly if you must, then head to your nice quiet Riad or somewhere that is free of overly aggressive salesmen.

Still genuine. In spite of mass tourism invading the city, the Medina still
preserves its authenticity. Glad to be back after 20 years!

Amazing, snakes on the ground, spices s. Spices are sold in large shaped cones and you scoop them out. One is used for lipstick! Stall holders can be rude, be respectful and careful. Ask for a price and be prepared to barter, don't expect a decent price if on a private tour. Also don't expect your tour guide to actually STOP at the main stalls. He will instead take you to the most expensive stalls deep inside where he gets a cut from any sale. I got quite annoyed. Be firm and request loudly that you wish to stop or he will not! You will see how argan oil is made and taken upstairs to buy some, less expensive than home, but don't be tempted. Instead find a local grocery store in the medina and buy it for next to nothing, local priced.... They speak French here, our Hotel had no English speaking people until the next morning, I really had to stretch my school French to request a meal in the hotel, hilarious! The clothes can be sold in huge piles, someone starts yelling and a pile appears and women flock. They cannot try on clothes due to a religious need to remain covered. They hold the clothes to their bodies and buy them this way. The medina is beautiful, rich in its utter foreign feel, surrounded by sights and sounds you've never experienced before. Beware do not take photos of the snakes on the ground or you will be hastily asked for money for the privilege. Likewise the colourful water carriers. Being grabbed by the arm and having money demanded not in English, was frightening, so be aware. Don't blindly follow people with cards that say they are of the community, you are led down a very narrow alley with a dead end. We bolted. But there are wonderful experiences to be had, having a turban put on my husband for a photo, the camels placed at the cross roads, nice stall holders who didn't frighten us off. The skins of unimagininable animals hanging for sale, the slippers made from skins that I called yeti boots! The lanterns hanging altogether, amazing sights. They sell jewellery for three different skin colours, white, brown and black, to suit each skin colour. The plastic cheap things didn't add to its awe, they have even crept in here...

Hustle & bustle. To get the true Marrakeshi experience you have to stay in the Medina, the old town. A hive of busy, narrow streets filled shops selling everthing from leather goods, tea-pots, wooden boxes, candle holders, soap to butchers & fish stalls. Watch out for cyclists & mopeds as they race through these narrow streets. Truly an unforgetable experience!

A world of its own!. Quite the spot and a must visit. Should appeal to everyone - independent travellers on their own and the timid with a guide. We did both: guide = not lost; no guide = lost --> 8 locals looking at our map and pointing in 8 directions at the same time!
interesting visit to do. interesting visit - this a must because it really define Marrakech and Morocco - i would recommend to hire a guide because we can get lost easily and waste time

Great bargains. There is so much to see from food, clothing, jewelry and house hold items. It can take you all day to walk and shop. Vendors will bargain with you to the lowest price to accommodate your pocket. It's an experience for everyone who visit.

Time stood still. Even after my last visit (over 40 years ago) it seems some things never change. Still donkey carts around, bustling shops, soem people trying to show you around and stiil easy to get lost.Asking for the way back might get you invited to one more shop. But it is still a must see and take it as it comes since the atmosphere is still very friendly and it is a good way to see how traditions survie
Medina. The Medina of Marrakech has a world reputation and it's only when you experience it first hand do you realise its size and the volume of people

Have fun getting lost. Getting lost in the medina is great fun, especially if you stumble upon areas that seem made for the people of Marrakesh, rather than the tourists. We always found our way eventually, whenever we came across a tourist sight or two. I didn't feel that I was harassed by the shop-keepers that much, but the endless tourist shops do loose their appeal after a bit.

Insane sensory overload.... This was what I was most excited about! I'm not usually one for crowds but this was a a whole other level of crowd in a good way! It was amazing to be in the hubbub of all the stalls and the noise. Heck when i didnt even want to buy we just bartered with the stall holders just to get in the spirit of the Medina. During the day its harder to get them to bargain down early evening and late on thats when the real deals are to be made! Have fun with it! Banter and barter :)Keep an eye out for motorbikes squeezing through rushing by, keep your wits about otherwise you'l be soon knocked off your feet!Maps.me was amazing for me throughout my whole Marrakech trip, if you veer of the mainstalls into smaller ones use it to find your way back or markers of stalls. I would literally look for the light from the sky and walk towards that as you can easily get carried away into the depths of the Medina! Saying that it was a regular routine of mine to go in see what new thing or new route I could discover. Have a look at the workmanship of the woodcrafters have a chat you'l be surprised!Be brave, be bold, discover but stay alert and safe x

Interesting place. Medina is very interesting with lot of narrow lanes.lots of shopping areas and shops.amazing big stores with all kinds of clothes,art,souvenirs.the square in medina is the highlight,with lot of activities,snake charmers,dancers,henna stalls,various games and of course street food.you have to be careful of the pickpocketers,especially small children.taking pictures can offend people and they ask for money for any photo you take there

It's not all about the Souks.. The Souks are the heart and soul of the Medina but it is about much more. Just take a few minutes to stand back and watch the traffic at a busy junction or watch the local Moroccans going about their day to day life and you begin to appreciate what a fascinating and totally different culture this is. I was offered my fare back by a taxi driver if I could tell him why there were hole in the Medina Walls, I couldn't so happily paid! Do barter at every opportunity and try local cakes, beer and food in general. Moroccans love to be asked for their advise, sometimes you have to sift through the flannel before you decide on what to believe!!! A fantastic holiday.

Wow. Stayed a week here at riad alhambra . Just an amazing place . Very hot drink lots of water . Streets are so narrow with mopeds coming at you from every angle . Great fun and dont buy anything without a good barter .

Colors, smells, feelings!. We went through all these narrow paths and had a lot of time to watch these people work. It was fantastic. We were fascinated by all the smells and the colors. That was like visiting another world!

Assaulted........ ........... on all sides: The sights, the sounds and the smells!But I'm getting ahead of myself. Leave the map, leave the plans and simply stroll through this medievel throw-back of a rabbit warren, but allow time. Not a couple of hours but two or three days.Day one you'll walk for miles (and miles!) in circles and become, seemingly, hopelessly lost. You will arrive back at your accommodation wondering how you haven't been runover by one of the moped riding lunatics, and battered by the total assault on your senses. Day two you'll begin to get your mind around the countless souks scattered hither and yon at random. The myriad (apparent) dead-ends which aren't; the mini-souks inside the main souks; the lunatics on mopeds. By day three you should find that you can find you way around reasonably well..... but you will still constantly find things you missed. Don't worry; if you were there for a month you'd still be finding bits you'd missed! The locals will constantly try to help by pointing you in the direction of the square; this is genuine help and given freely. Oh, and never be afraid to ask for help; the locals are a pleasure to deal with and unstintingly helpful.As you wander past (and through) the countless stalls that make up the medina, don't be afraid to look. Look, touch, feel, smell - if there is the remotest possibility of a sale then the locals are helpfulness personified; should you feel like not buying, then a firm 'no' is (99% of the time) all that is needed......... but if you decide that you want to buy, then the fun starts. Haggle. Haggle, haggle and haggle again. It's expected and the locals openly admit it! What-ever the opening price is is approximately at least two to three times what they expect to recieve for the goods - so haggle and enjoy the experience........ but never forget that you can still walk away! (... and walking off can be part of the haggling process too!)So, wear sensible walking shoes (and -- importantly -- walk on the right!), trust the locals, trust yourself and enjoy the experience........ it's well worth it!

Like traveling back in time!. An absolute bargaining experience. Not only is the place hectic and authentic but the negotiating and bargaining is as real as it can get. The tourist hunters will be all around, the free tea to get you inside and, everything else you can think of as far a commercial strategies go, but this is what makes it so exciting and different. The smells, the colours and all around are what takes you back in time.

Fantastic. If you have time, then stroll with not map, no plan, no small time. Just go and go. Feel, smell, enjoy the medina. Spent 3-4 hours and just experience the good vibe. When you are tired - ask one of the local boys to take you to J em El FNA for 20 dirham. Dont give him money before you are outside Cafe France. thats a cool trip.
Underground part of the city. The real Marrakesh, busy, little corridors, alleys and crazy bike riders everywhere worthy to see and experience
Medina. Exciting place, full of so many different things to see, if your looking for a new experience try Marrakech, stay inside the walled city.

Great hectic place where everything happens. The medina and it's souks (shops) might be a little overwelming the first time you visit. Don't get intimidaties by people wanting to sell you things. Just stay fiendly and clear on your objectives. Some think this is a little intimidating, but it never gets unfriendly. Enjoy the sounds, smells and people. Dine at some roof garden restaurant and book a local Riad for a hotel (B&B).

Excellent Experience...may aggravate anxiety. I gave the medina 5 stars because 3 stars is "average" and it is anything but. What an experience! To me, walking through the medina was overwhelming. It was busy and bustling, the shopkeepers were aggressive and vocal, and it was loud and dusty from constant movement and chaos. It was a cultural experience that I am grateful to have had, but I am in no rush to go back. If you are traveling to Marrakech, you've got to experience the medina, but just be weary of aggressive salespeople, entertainers in the streets trying to pressure you into giving them money, and donkeys, carts, and mopeds flying around in every which direction. With this in mind, you can stay safe and take in the experience for what it's worth.

Wild, woolly, unforgettable!. It is all you have heard: the endless lanes of the souk selling everything under the sun; the smoking food stalls; the snake charmers, monkey owners, and other entertainers. But what I enjoyed most was our elegant dinner at a riad off the square, down a side lane: delicious tagine-prepared meat and vegetables, musicians on oud, strings, tambour, and exotic dancers. The whole experience of being in Morocco was unlike any travel adventure I had had before; I'll treasure these memories forever.

Have a guide the first time. Medina is medium sized but easier than most to get your bearings. Go the first time with a guide (or good map) and then do not hesitate to go out on your own. Small enough that you can get your bearings. Full of history that is still evident today. Safe for Westerners - many tourists are also in the Medina exploring with you.

Toufik. At a certain moment we got annoyed; all these people jumping into your comfort zone, asking 500 dh just for showing you the way to your restaurant, or bringing you to an auction you didn't ask for. But then there was Toufik, a craftsman from Sahara, selling beautiful wooden boxes for reasonable prices.
Its crazy. Just join in with the culture, you can get some fantastic bargains, don't be put off by the haggling. The medina is very medieval and has a unique charm about it.....its brilliant !
Now very touristic. Although you have to see the medina when you are staying in Marrakech, I found it to touristic with a lot of the same stuff sold by sometimes rather unfriendly sellers.

Chaos but fun. Safe and interesting. Chaotic and colourful. Do not use cafes cos they will rip you off and overcharge to leave you breathless.Went twice and that was enough. Did not buy any item, snakes asleep, watch out for horse drawn taxis, you have to go to experience it but twice was enough

No such thing as a bargain. Dont be taken in, the stalls mainly sell the same crap and they will hastle you into their shop by being very friendly,the usual thing when they know you are from Uk is to start saying "alright mate" and "lovely jubbly " but once inside you will have a hard job leaving withouth spending money,if you just make your polite excuses and walk out chances are you will be harassed for 50yds, Its just not worth the headache,people are rude and goods are tacky crap. You have been warned....

Headache from start to finish.. We had to pass through the medina every day on our way out from our riad, although we tried to stop and look in the shops we were constantly hassled the minute we set foot inside a shop and could not browse peacefully, also as these alleys are very narrow and mopeds fly up and down at speed you are at risk of being knocked over if you don't get out of their way quickly enough, it's the equivalent of a moped flying up and down aisles the width of the ones in tesco packed with people, also if you get disorientated and ask for directions you are likely to be charged around 20 dirhams by somebody who know considers the self your unofficial guide and they will follow you til you pay them, a much better place to go is the centre artisans just outside djem el fna and a taxi should cost no more than 30 dirhams. Here everything is fixed price and not much more expensive than the medina.

Bustling, vibrant and full of fun!. We had a great couple of days wandering around soaking up the vibe. The streets here are wider and less intimidating than Fes' medina. They are also used to tourists and whilst it is important to dress modestly it is not necessary to cover up completely. The sights, the smells, the streets, the vibe - it was lots of fun!
The most interesting place of Marrakech. It's the center of everything in Marrakech. If you like to be near the main atractions, you have to stay in a riad inside of the medina area.

you will be lost. so caotic but absolutely interesting for the tourists!
trust me,you will be lost every time,so remember points or details when you walk to have some references.
be carefull to the people that will you ask to guide you if you are lost at least they will ask you for money (and they are rude)

The raison d'etre of visiting Marrakech. Going to Marrakech and not going to the Medina is like buying an ice cream cone and then not eating it. If you like old cities, different cultures, new foods, middle eastern architecture, and a sometimes circus atmosphere, this is the place for you. Note that you cannot go into the many mosques in Morocco if you are not Islamic.
Crazy,crazy,crazy. Great place to visit and get out of. Beware of good Samaritans offering help they want your money. It was fun and exasperating.

Caution: Cactus fruit scam. At the east end of Jamaa el fna, in front of Hotel Art Place, you may see a cactus fruit stand. After taking some pieces the seller demand 10DH per one piece! (Normally 5DH per 4 pieces)
DO NOT take it.

Crazy city . Amazing crazy place. You can see everything there from water seller to snakes on the city square. Be ready to pay for every advice or even answer on your question. Amazing food and great tea. You have to visit that place for sure
Busy location especially at night. Lots of bars, street entertainers, watch for the monkeys and snakes. henna tattoos are popular, lots of fresh orange juice and nut sellers.

Aladin magic lamp. Marrakech old town Medina is like an aladin magic lamp when you are there gin comes out of the lampand takes you to the pastSouk is very colorful , sellers are altough pushy do not need to bother just say asselamin alleykum that magic word helps and detain your positionI strictly recommend you to visit there snd gave colorful experience

Bustling medina!. The medina in Marrakech is a medium size with all the expected wares for sale. It is perhaps more touristy than most so plan to shop elsewhere if you are traveling. It was fun to spend a morning shopping here.
Let yourself go--you can't get lost!. Explore and roam through the many back alleys, souks, and open areas to truly experience the medina. All roads lead to Jemaa el Fna, so not worry!
nice to see. a lot of people but nice , yves st laurents garden is nice to have seen. The architect made it so magic
Overwhelming at times.... Although I do love a bit of hustle, it can become a bit too much with the locals...if businesses harassed tourists a bit less probably it would be more pleasant!!

Great place to go to in the later afternoon to eat. Fun place to be ,eating , lots of juicestands and very good and cheap fresh ,no proplem to drink clean clean eatingstands and not bad prises good for a familie

Medina. The area was a total maze with less than helpful lads and men sending you in wrong directions only so a relative of theirs could pick you up and direct you to your destination by demanding money.

Like being in an Indiana Jones film!!. The sounds and smells are fantastic. People cajoling you into buying food, snake charmers, dancers, musicians, orange juice outlets everywhere, nut sellers - it's all going on at night. Daytime you trawl through the neverending streets of leather sellers, fruit, veg, spices. Amazing - don't take photos of the sellers as they don't like it. Felt safe, comfortable, loved it

Step back in time!. The old medina is like stepping into another world, busy streets selling an array of goods from fresh vegetables to purple wigs!! So much to see and visit, you have to see it all to take it in, donkeys pulling carts, mopeds whizzing through the streets, bartering with the locals, beautiful leather goods, really clever local craftsman, there is just so much to watch and do!
Very interesting to go and see. Would be a shame to go to Morocco and not visit here. We visited during the afternoon but were told it is worth a visit on the evening too.

Amazing. You have to visit this place at least once in your life. Sensory overload and an experience of a lifetime. Although you occasionally have people offering directions etc they soon move on if you refuse their assistance and gave us no cause for concern. Generally you can walk around without any hassle whatsoever.

A maze. Whether you have a map or not it makes no difference, there are so many tiny alleys it is impossible not to get lost! The medina itself is great, with many mosques, pretty archways, museums, the souks, the koutaba, Jamaa El Fna, but the constant hassling of men insisting on showing you the way and not taking no for an answer is exhausting. That's the downside of being a solo female traveller.

My visit there in February. After getting dark very busy ;watch your wallet and do not mix with the grounds ;people can do anything to get money-dancing /gampling /playing with animals and reptiles ;anything you can imagine happens there ;watch it not very safe especially after 8 pm

Busy Medina. I visit medina the first day I got to Marrakech, which to be honest left a bad impression on me ... Then I realised that it depends what are you looking for on your holidays. Definitely too busy for me, everyone wants to talk to you, they you grab your hand ... Which made me feel uncomfortable and quite sacred. A lady just grabbed my hand and started doing henna in less than a minute my hand was done ... And off course asked for money. Obviously asked for an absurd amount of money My boyfriend didn't want to take the money in front of her, because she would ask for more or someone could just come and grab it and run away with it, we could not risk it. so we told her we would come back to pay her, she followed us demanding her money and I told her why we wouldn't take the money in front of us and she then understood. It's definitely a morning destination and not afternoon or evening because it really put me off and I just wanted to leave. It's great for shopping and loads of food stalls.We went on a cafe with a rooftop for tea and off course to take some pictures of the busy square. Another thing everyone needs to be aware are the taxis and the road. When we were dropped off in was madness to cross the road, you literally have To risk and make the car or bikes stop. There is no rules. Taxis will charge you whatever they want. Same journey you will pay different tariffs. Be aware most places you shouldn't pay more than 70 dhm. We were like that found a driver who was really nice and gave us his number and charged 50dhm to everywhere and even gave us a tour to literally everywhere for 150dhm and would wait for us.
Fantastic experience. Just visit and drink in the experience. Felt quite safe, but keep eyes open and wallet in front pocket.

An experience. We got lost every time we stepped foot in here, but that's half the fun. If you really like something barter for it there and then as odds are you wont find the shop again. I'm terrible for seeing something then looking at alternatives before deciding to go back to the first one - this is a mistake. Shopping in the Medina is like TK Maxx shopping, buy it when you see it or it'll be lost forever.The mopeds wear you down after a while and the petrol fumes can get a bit much so try not to spend more than a few hours in here at a time, but its a fun place once you get used it to it and accept being lost is just a way of life.

Jamaa El Fna. It's the first thing you're going to do when you arrive to Marrackech! The square is totally crazy, full of people, life, music, colors and flavors!... Just be patient bc everybody wants money from the tourists. It's something to need to do but I don't like that you can't even see something without someone asking you money 5 sec after... To find a place to eat, well .. good look!...
Awesome. An area of Marrakesh that seems to have it's own micro-atmosphere. Snake charmers, watermen, Henna, Story tellers, acrobats.....loads more.
Arabic mix. All you may know about Arabic culture, you can see here. Unique souks, people, animals... Dont buy everything will be offered

Be careful of the henna ladies. First day in Marrakesh, went to the Medina and a lady went up to my daughter and offered to do henna for her. We told her that we had just arrived and that we would have henna later in the trip. She then offered my daughter a free 'good luck' henna, then did a scorpion on my little boys arm and while she was doing that she called another lady who grabbed my hand and started putting henna on it without me giving her permission, but I did let her continue. It was really bad, the instrument was not working and I had blotches all over my hand but didn't care as it was free and it is temporary. She then demanded 4000 dirhams, that's nearly £350!!!! I refused and said that they said it was free for good luck. They started shouting in Arabic and to avoid the stress I gave her £20, she demanded more so gave her another £10. Then she demanded more for the other lady. I gave her another £20 and walked straight back to the hotel. It was intense. The henna washed off in three days.

The magic of the Medina. What can I say.. it's smelly, loud, busy, colour and quite amazing. it's like steeping back in time. A truly amazing experience. as with any city, keep your wits about you, your purse closer and be aware of the alleys as it's so easy to get lost.

Nice Medina. Its a nice market with lotsa local shops. All shops though seem to seeling the 'same' stuff. I dont enjoy bargaining so shopping here was not really interesting for me - but can be fun way to interact with people.

Interesting flashback. A look into the history of the city! (When you go outside the walls you see what modern day life looks like) Many small streets with vendors and restaurants.A pity is the constant harassment of bikes and worse: mopeds. They criss-cross through narrow pedestrian streets as if they own the place and leave a trace of fumes. But you have to visit the many sides of the Medina.

Beautiful. Like in many other cities in this part of the world, you feel lost every time you turn a corner. the greatest reason in Marrakesh is that the houses all have the same shape and colour.A reddish, earthen colour that speaks to your senses. I advise you to walk if you can - it is not a very big medina, and if you get lost, there is always someone who is happy to help you. Except with one thing - so maybe I should click very good instead of excellent? I wanted to see the Majorelle Garden, and according to my guide book it should be open. However, we met, on our way there, two people who each of them, separately, told us it was closed today and would open tomorrow. OK, we had only half a day here - so why waste it on walking up to something closed? We changed our plans - and later in the evening found out from a government guide that Majorelle was NOT closed...But now it was too late to go there...I was NOT happy. The two people who had told us obviously lied, and for no reason at all it seems, because they were not selling anything. Nothing to gain by tricking us... The only thing it lead up to was anger, frustration and sowing distrust.To sum it up - we really had a not that good day, our first day here. Do not trust anyone, is the sad message.
Nice. The hustle, hubbub, and heat; the hassle from hopeful guides and shopkeepers eager to sell, The streets leading up to Djemaa el Fna offer excellent stalls with a good variety

A place to get lost in and enjoy.. A fantastic place. Its easy to get lost in this vast labyrinth of a huge variety of 'shops' selling locally made products of every conceivable type. We got absolutely exhausted just walking around in circles, but we loved it.
Horrible Chaos. Buy souvenirs from China here and be harassed by (male) vendors eager to take your money. Impossible to look at anything without being assaulted by vendors.

Very touristy but safe and fun. Its all aimed at the tourist and very safe , lots of police around etc. ... By day its full of monkey and snakes (photos will cost you money), tbh i found it all a bit in poor taste. Go people watch , have a wander but remember everyone you meet is looking to get money out of you. By night its about street food, go late afternoon as the places changes from day to night, see the sights smell the smells :-)

Amazing experience seeing the craftsmen & traditional baker. Back in time in the medina of Marrakech - the Dar El Bacha quarter is so clean, organised with street names & lots of great Moroccan products on sale - the art galleries are fantastic. This was only a few minutes walk from our Riad - Riad Zaid - so not far to walk with our shopping. Felt safe and secure at all times and the people are very friendly.

A must see city!. Marrakech is a definite must see city and only a 3 hour flght away. So much to see and do. A very clean, easily walkable, cultural, historical and shopping delight. Marrakech is a very safe city, particularly for women, with no hassle outside the square and souk. The people have a ready smile, are so welcoming and friendly, and Moroccan food is cheap and outstanding. Taxi and caleche ( horse and carriage) travel is very reasonably priced. Extremely hot in summer, but very pleasant in spring Autumn and winter. Excellant for a long weekend get away, or longer stays using the city as a base to visit the Sahara, Atlas Mountains and Coast .

Too touristy. We had traveled around Morocco for three weeks before coming to Marrakech. We stayed in the medina, as we had in Fes. The hawkers of the Marrakech medina have had many decades honing their skills in selling cheap (today often Chinese) wares at inflated prices to naive tourists. My children and I loved the medina in Fes, as it is much more local and meant for the locals, though, of course, many shops are geared toward the tourist.We loved Gueliz, outside the Medina. I highly recommend walking around Gueliz to see how modern day middle and upper class Moroccans live.

Amazing. Wow, what an experience this place is!!Never seen or felt anything like it.The people, the vibrancy the noise, the whole culture thing is unforgettable!There must be hundreds and hundreds of stalls to wander around, but be warned you are hassled constantly.Best time to visit, between 530-1000, much more going on before nightfall.

very special to see days and nights. Avery unique place to visit, many markets are there and different kind of food drinks to have.Shops, banks, takeaway, restaurants, even monkeys you can find in this big square, if you visit Marrackech then you'll have to see it.

busy busy busy. wow what a maze of narrow streets be careful you don't get lost!! we had a private guide who took us down very old alleys and pointed out spots if interest such as 400 year old alley way that leads to amazing doors of local peoples homes. well worth a trip

visit with a guide. visit with a guide
the medina (old city) is a vibrant spiderweb of streets end corners. easy to get lost in
Very busy place. Full of life, animals and things going on. Typical tourist goods on sale. Some OK quality but Fes medina is better.
Just enchanting!. Fascinating, with a maze of narrow street, full of palaces, stalls. Give yourself a treat and explore it first by carriage drawn by two horses. What a joy!

Incredible history and a must see!. Such an incredible experience and place to shop. Easy to get lost as well. Lots of great things to buy, make sure you leave room in your suitcase. Be careful when taking pictures as some of the locals will ask for money or be unhappy about you taking photos.

A lot of fun. If you have been to other medinas then you will recognized that this market is no different. A maze of streets that are loosely organized in to areas. One section you will see a lot of carpets and others, you will more textile. There is sort of a Main Street that ends at the open plaza. There you will find sad looking horses pulling carriages and men peddling monkeys posing for photos. There are many cafes surrounding the open plaza that you can grab a bit or tea. Back in the covered medina, you will cooler temperature and shade if it gets too hot. We found better products away from the busy main lane and were hassled slightly less. It is a fun area and if you came all the way to visit Merrakesh, then you really need to go.

Crowded. I was travelling with my daughter and when we book our Riad in the Medina we thought we would be close to everything since our time was short, but it is very crowded and did not have a good experience.

Very different. I stayed at a Riad in the Medina and the area itself was very interesting. It is so easy to get lost navigating through the narrow streets but the experience allowed me to feel like I was experiencing Marrakesh just as a local would. It felt very authentic and lowkey.

A crazy, buzzing, full-on place for discovery.. We love Jamaa El Fna for the buzziness - it is pretty full-on gone sunset. The souks sell lots of the same stuff as do the food stalls on the Square. We ate at stall number 1 (because it was packed and they didn't hassle us) you can get bored by the time you get to stall #127 of the 'friendly' banter from the guys on the store. Essentially the main difference is; most stalls sell tagines, grilled meats and meurguez sausage and if they don't do that then it is sheep brains / heads. On the outer skirts we had snail soup - not what you'd call yummy (imagine slimy snails in a muddy water that tastes surprisingly of mud). But whilst is Marrakesh!!!!

Good but not great. Having stayed at Essaouira for 6 nights beforehand we were not blown away by Marrakech medina. Much larger than Essaouira but not as enjoyable and more expensive. Our riad was in the medina and you had to be careful to find your way back especially after the gates close on the souks.We had 3 nights there which was enough. High pressure sellers and restaurants. The square is good for cheap fresh orange juice.Much warmer and less windy than Essaouira which was nice but even then it was chilly for some of the time.Would not have been sad to have omitted Marrakech on the one hand but on the other we have now seen it.
Chaotically beautiful.. Probably the best souk in the world - and something that needs to be explored. From the sumptuous Riads to shopping to food.

Medina as a single lady. I visited early evening whilst light was a good experience fun and good atmosphere, I left in the dark and I was followed by a young french guy, who absolutely wouldnt leave me alone, I remained very calm continued walking. Then at a music area I thankfully joined a young Moroccan man who was watching me and we pretended to be together, he tld the other guy where to go .... I would say over all its safe yes BUT depends on you're life experiences, you must be street wise and pre plan your leaving clearly and swiftly to a taxi.

Ok to shop and look around but if you don;t like to be hassled then this is not the place for you. We enjoyed shopping there and also eating around the area but you have to get used to people coming at you in all directions to sell you things. Just be direct and say no if you are not interested or else they will not let up. I was approached everyday by the women that do henna tattoos and the women that sell jewelry are even more pushy than everybody I came in contact with. I was told off so many times by them from not wanting to buy their jewelry that they claim is free

09:00-17:00 get lost in Jemaa el-Fnaa endless market. 20-23 be back to eat-out. I you ever traveled another Arab country Morocco is different in 2 attractive issues:The people.The landscape.One does not feel the religious activity nor the forced code of dressing in public which is an issue to non Muslim visitors in other middle-eastern Arab countries. plan to start at 09:00 or later in the famous market till 17:00go for rest in hotel till 20:00be back to eat in the food marketthe main public area changes it's landscape to food stands every afternoon end.

A real taste of Marrakech.. A word of warning, you will get lost! Thenarrow covered lanes of the Medina twist and turn and within yards you'll have lost your bearings. Take a hotal card to ask locals for directiosn, for the obligatory tip. The souk is a great place to shop, lots of handmade goods, farly touristy, but lots of locals shopping there as well.Be prepared to haggle hard, you can buy the same items from numerous places so push for a bargain.Watch out for the street traders who will try to sell fake stuff, and be prepared to be approached by touts trying to get you to buy from them or visit the restaurant they recommend. Some nice places to eat around the square, or try local from the many stalls.

The Marrakech Medina is a definiet must-see!. The old city, better known as the Medina, is a must see for anyone who travels to Marrakech! Full of amazing sightseeing places, the Souks, restaurants and cafes: the medina is where it all happens.

Extremely busy. A very vibrant place... Lots of local entertainers but be sure to dish out money of watching or taking photos. They can be very aggressive.Food is good. Lots of stalls mostly selling the same dishes.The shops selling lots of local handmade stuff and is good, you need to be a good haggler to catch a bargain.Too many beggars and they are persistent, once you give one another will be ready to bother.

Great time had by all!. While visiting Marrakech with our tour group we were taken by a carriage ride from our hotel through the Medina and to the market place. Well with a visit here and went back on our own the next day.

Art, Crafts, Colours and Joyful Craziness. The old town center in Marrakech is a maze of colorful, tiny streets. Although you can feel the sensation to get lost, try keep going on: sooner or later, you will find a small square where resting and rearranging your path.

Life's Far More Interesting in the Heart of the Old City. We stayed at a Riad within the Medina and spent the majority of our time within the old walls simply because it offered a cauldron of character and history generally lacking in the new town. Some areas were easy enough to navigate, whereas the souks were very easy to get lost in because of generally poor signage, labyrinthine layout and the lack of long sight views. There's plenty to see and do within the city walls for a few days at least and although the hassling is a great nuisance initially, one gets used to handling it after a day or two. It is worth saying that many locals will genuinely try to be helpful without ulterior motives; however, there are some who will latch onto easy prey simply to pressure sell or extract money for 'guiding'; unfortunately, this tends to make one wary of accepting any unsolicited approach. It is important to be alert mainly due to the volume of two wheel traffic that insists on traveling at speed in unsuitable narrow streets; having said that we didn't see a single accident in the five days we were there.

Entertaining... with cost!. Probably one of the safest place in Morocco due to high city walls and patrolled police everywhere, Medina was our choice for the mere convince to the ever so popular shops and restaurants. Lots to see but it will cost you... everything has a price which includes getting directions.Try negotiating to about 1/3 of asking price or go to the Berber village for much reasonable prices on any purchases.Everyone in Marrakesh is highly sales aggressive therefor avoid if you don't want to be bothered.We found most are friendly but who isn't when trying to make money?Use your discretion as this is Poor country

Beautiful Old Town. We stayed in the Medina and absolutely loved it. There is so much character. The roads are a bit of an adventure, so be careful when crossing them. I would recommend visiting Jeema El Fna Square and the souks, expecially in the evening when the atmosphere is amazing.

Great place to get a feel for the ambience of Marrakech. The winding walkways, full of honking motorcycles and cyclists as well as pedestrians give you a feeling of what old Marrakech was like - noisy, vibrant, crowded. Merchants do try to entice you into their stores but this has been vastly improved and "Non Merci" works wonders. Very very easy to get disoriented (another word for hopelessly lost) but just as for 'The Square" from a merchant (people passing by are just as likely to immediately show you to their favourite uncle's shop) and people will point and smile.

Why?. You will get lost. Someone will offer to help you. You will follow them. They will take you the wrong way. They will ask for money and what you give them won't be enough. Then you will need to take a taxi. Take a taxi in the first place and you won't be harassed by kids, men making sexist comments to any women in your party or wear your shoes out with thousands of extra steps going around in circles. Dusty and scary at times.

Bucket list . I think that this has to be one of the most beautiful and unique places in the world. You can basically do everything from eating traditional food, take pictures with snakes and monkeys, to boxe against a complete stranger or dance on gnawa music. Also you can find anything you want for shopping. The places changes colors and i suggest to go there for the sunset and stay until the beginning of the night.

Very busy.
