Was an experience never to be forgotten, very very busy, so many stalls and places to eat, I personally preferred to visit the medina during the day than at night, I found it very hectic and you get annoyed with people trying to sell you things, be firm and say no if your not interested as they don't leave you alone.If you make eye contact with anyone especially the snake charmers they don't leave you alone, so beware and only look at things your really interested in buying otherwise you will be bombarded with everything.

Amazing sight to see!. Loved the medina! During the day is great to see the colors and walk through the streets to shop. However, it comes to life at night! Music, many more locals and tourists, food stalls are open which is amazing (many will banter you to come visit, but very cheap! Had a bowl of hearty soup for USD $0.50 :) Food is amazingly cheap. ) If you do shopping, shop around and bargain your price before buying since various stalls sell the same items. But is can't be missed at night!
Sights . Very busy. Great place to try new foods and to get a feel for the local way of life. Keep an eye out for each other as with lots of people comes potential for pick pockets.

Soak it all in...here are some tips for making your way through it. Go in to the medina and realize a few things:1. This is a culture of giving which in turn encourages begging. I did not get hassled by beggars like in other cities but there are a lot of them here. 2. Don't be afraid to get lost. This is part of the charm to the medina so if you need to go somewhere by a specific time, leave extra time to get lost a little. If you do get lost, buy a small water bottle for 2dirham and then ask the shopkeeper for directions. They will gladly help you now. 3. Wear sunglasses, the shopkeepers are watching you to see what you're interested in and if they think they have a chance to convince you to buy something because you looked at it or touched it then they will engage more with you. Sunglasses make it harder to read you and therefore they are less likely to bother with you.4. Put your money in different groups and then different pockets. This way if you pull out your money you are less likely to draw attention to you because you are not showing that much cash. 5 Soak in the sounds and smells. It is easy to take in the sights but the sounds and smells are just as magical and they make it so unique. 6. Stay in a riad with a good rooftop terrace. I stayed in Dar Hannane and it was excellent. The terrace appeared to be one of the highest and nicest. I enjoyed breakfast on the rooftop every morning and the peacefulness of the riad in the morning is awesome!7. Be smart and mindful but do not be afraid. I was afraid before I arrived but after one night it felt like a home away from home. 8. Stay away from the guys with the monkeys unless you're u REALLY want to pay for a picture. I just went to the overlooking cafe rooftops and peacefully took pictures from above.

Romantic Maze of Teeming, Bustling Humanity. I found a room in Marrakech's old Medina (market area) online, and was already smiling ear-to-ear by the time I found it (with the help of a taxi driver and one of the many street-hustlers willing to lead you around for as many dollars as they can talk you out of). Wandering around this ancient market area, you'll immediately know where all the Hollywood stereotypes come from--and I mean that in the best way possible: goats, donkeys, mopeds, and hordes of humans wandering purposively through the complicated, sprawling Moroccan maze. Do yourself a favor, and just get lost. Wander, shop, eat, photograph, chat with locals (including the aggressive shopkeepers, over tea of course) and other travelers, and take it all in--keeping in mind that you are in a place which will celebrate its 1000th birthday in 2062. You are participating in a vibrant continuity of culture that was in place well before Genghis Khan was born; a place that predates the beginning of the Crusades. Let your imagination run wild and celebrate your presence in the middle of the headwaters of modern human history.Short version: Marrakech's medina is really really old, and really really cool.

It's live!!. Be careful of tricksters and haglers. If you decide to eat food there -- make sure to not order too much and if they bring things that don't look familiar, do no accept otherwise they keep bringing food and bring a huge bill at the end. Don't stop to watch any pop up shows - they are not free!! There are a lot of trickster but overall it's a live place to be. Must see once ATLEAST.

Different system. There is a different system and people are different. I found the Moroccans a lovely bunch.The medina was an interesting and colourful experience where you could easily and happily get lost taking in the sights.

Great place if you take out the beggars and cheaters. I was very much looking forward to my trip here. It is truly a wonderful place full of amazing smells and colours. The persistent beggars (the same ones every night!) really spoil this experience. I speak arabic therefore knew how to handle them but I saw some tourists reduced to tears due to the constant hassling for money. Apparently the police used to stop them if they saw them but don't anymore which is a shame.Be wary especially of the snake charmers and the men with monkeys. Unless you are prepared to pay at least five euros then do not attempt to take any photos and do not hand over your camera if they offer to take a closer picture for you as they won't give it back unless they are satisified with the amount you have given.
Great experience. It is buzzing with people, story tellers, snack charmers and food stalls.If you are going to visit this on Sunday night, it would be completely packed with local people.

You won't really be seeing Marrakech without going here. A must-do stop - not just for shopping but from activity from the snake charmers to those making fresh orange and other fruit juice to enjoy, the mules passing by, pulling carts in the midst of strolling visitors. A fun sensory experience! Having a guide is helpful. We also stayed at a riad located in the medina - a great experience and location. Be adventurous - try new things!

Magical Marrakech. What an awesome place. Each alleyway is filled with colourful stalls selling everything you could think of. Vendors seek your custom but are not intimidating. It's a maze to navigate. Know how to find your way home. You could be wondering the streets for hours if lost.Most normal people get lost at least once. Stay away from men and boys offering to guide you they only want money. We would recommend official guide 3 and half hour walk around medina. Watch though they'll want to take you to shops to buy if you don't want that tell them st the beginning.Enjoy the medina we certainly did.
Wow!. A very busy must. Be prepared for lots of noise, people, sellers, smells and sights. Some friendly people wanting to sell you anything. Keep your wits about you!
New Year Eve celelebration, every night 365 day. the Best Place of street food, and Moroccan Folklore, enjoy a glass of Orange juice Fresh, for 4 DH, you can found that any where in the world.

Unique Experience!. Hold onto your bags as a young female be fully prepared for the bottom pinchers! The crowds are huge and the souks are disorientating but the people are friendly and helpful should you get lost. The atmosphere is great especially at night just stay watchful of your surroundings and enjoy it! Would recommend dinner at a Riad overlooking the medina.

Great atmosphere. Loved visiting the heart of Marrakech. So much to see and do in the medina. Lots of bars and cafes to stop and have food or drink. Plenty of shops to barter with the locals and have great fun. Loved every minute of it.

A must in Marrakech. You can't visit Marrakech without going to the medina. But, be careful that you don't get too close to the monkeys or snakes. Have some cash on hand to tip the snake/monkey handlers so that you can get a photo; but don't feel obliged to touch those creatures. First of all, you don't want to; second of all, you don't need to. That aside, wandering around in the medina (we only went during the day; night time is supposed to be a real kick) is an experience you don't want to miss

Experience the medina!. Yes, it is loud. Yes, it can be smelly. Yes, shop owners try to sell you stuff. But it is a great experience. Get in there, buy some argan oil, colorful sandals, incense, an orange juice and a fake shirt! The Medina is a place not to be missed.

A maze full of wonders!. Be prepared to get lost and find wonderful hole in a wall shops. It felt as though I was in a scene from Indiana Jones, walking into one street to find another street full of new goods. Ensure you have a map close by as you can honestly get lost and not be aware of where you are as you are exploring the many little shops that are found on every street.You can find so many things here, scarves, robes, hats, fruit, nuts, sweets, teapots, pottery, maps, carpets etc. Just ensure that you have enough space in your luggage to take back.The girlfriend and I decided to go to the Medina a second time round as we felt we knew it after the first visit, but boy were we wrong. We got lost and found new streets that were not there on our first visit. We even managed to find an area where there were metal works going on, presumably for the metal teapots, lamps etc that are sold in the Medina! We even managed to go from one end of the Medina to Jemaa el Fna just by chance! We didn't bother asking for directions as we just got so lost in our own curiosity. The whole charm of the Medina is getting lost and managing to find your way out again, I would definitely advise anyone going here to give yourself a couple of hours of your day, (preferably not night) as it can get hard to navigate.

A don't-miss experience - come hungry!. If you're in Marrakech, this is a must-stop for an evening. It's filled with people, music and (above all) FOOD. Don't eat dinner before you come here or you will miss out on what this place is all about. By day it's just an open square but by night it transforms itself into a giant open air 'restaurant' with every kind of food you crave. It's noisy and fun! Be adventurous - just pick a place, sit down and order food. Save a little room for dessert since carts continually come around with colorful cakes and cookies.

No Place seen like this before. It was packed with a lot of people, the night life experience was really great as its open till 3am in the morning, lot to do and see, street food was really good first thought it would not be good for my stomach buy I was wrong.

Forget the hustle and bustle of a modern city and experience what it must have been like in the old town. Just walking around the Medina opens your eyes to a way of life that probably hasn't changed for centuries. Yes they are all looking to scam the tourists but it is an interesting place to visit, with lots of good eateries and many varied shops. you can easily get lost in the Medina but that is part of the charm as you suddenly find something quaint off the beaten track,
Good place . Good place to go for shopping and having lunch and dinner. Nice ancient history buildings lots of shopping for clothing handbags argan oil etc
Too much!!!. We went in the evening and quickly learned not to have pictures taken with anyone as they rip you off for money. Smells amazing and very vibrant.....

Hustle bustle and bargains galore.. It may seem overwhelming as you first enter the Medina but once you stop to observe the street vendors, market stalls, food stands and performers you will be ready to enjoy your time there. I love bargaining so this was a dream for me to buy unique fabrics, pottery and leather goods. Parts of the Medina are filled with chincy goods but other parts have the real deal and you just have to search a bit. One thing to beware of is the snake charmers. They wont give you a price but will gladly throw a snake around your neck and tell you to grab a few shots on your camera. We figured a bit of money would be expected but after 1 minute total they told us we owed them the equivalent of 30 euro!!!! We happily deleted the shots and showed them we did so but they became angry when we said we would give them some money but no where near that amount for 3 pictures. They became very aggressive and started to follow us even after deleting the photos so steer clear of getting too close or you'll be roped into this. Overalll its very fun and interesting and we had great conversation with the stall owners.
Fab Experience. Could find a bar to buy a beer ?. Busy busy bustling market, food market at night is amazing. Loved it !!

One of the best Medinas of Morocco. Marakech Medina tops that of Fez and Rabat. It is colorful and traditional without being too overcrowded, smelly and clauustrophobic like Fez. Plenty to see and buy - from shops to architecture, graves, palaces, souks and more. Allow a good day or two for old Marrakech

Holiday . Fantastic place to visit. The music the people and the shops,
It's mind boggling. beware of touts you take a picture or film stuff they demand money.
Great place biggest BBQ in one square

Similar to other Medinas but a great experience. While I found the medinas fascinating in both Marrakech and Fes, I preferred the medina of Marrakech a bit more. There are similarities, but I found Marrakech's medina to be less claustrophobic than the one in Fes. Regardless this is a must see!

A dazzling spectacle. The first time you arrive in the Medina you will be bombarded with sights, scents, sounds and it is quite an experience.But I can tell you for sure, that it is not to be missed. Despite what you might read, it is safer than most places in Europe. Sure, people try to sell you things but that is what it is all about...enjoy it. Say 'no thank' if you don;t want it, haggle if you do. Either way, it is an exhilarating experience.I recommend a trip in the day and another at night for a different atmosphere. The music is amazing and you will be transported to a different world.

Very Interesting Place. I really enjoyed walking around the medina however the main square was also great but very depressing. The shops and stalls there were interesting to walk around. Like if the grand bazaar in Istanbul was a small city. However I wasn't a huge fan of the square where they have monkeys on chain leashes. Mild animal cruelty there. Also the same with the snakes. I've taken care of snakes, they do not normally act that sedated. Probably were sedated. However, walking around the small streets and just getting lost there is amazing. Just sad about the animals in the square.

Gigantic bazaar. One of the vastest medinas in the Arab world and a bustling bazaar selling all kinds of handicrafts, it's also a place where ordinary Moroccans go to shop for staples and house supplies. The craft vendors are way too insistent for my taste but I derived real pleasure in watching people interact. It's easy to get lost but you thus end up discovering genuine un-touristy nook and crannies. Besides it's much easier to navigate than its counterpart in Fès.

Don't get intimidated. The Medina is something you never experienced before if you're from the northern parts of Europe like me. At first it intimidated me but key is stay streetwise and go with the hustle and bustle and please be aware of the respectful chaos that is pedestrian, scooter and vehicle traffic all mixed together to get wherever in tiny/ narrow streets. Smile, observe and enjoy.

Unbelievable!. The Medina of Marrakesh is exactly what you would imagine as a Moroccan fantasy! Be sure you go there at different times of day, as the scene is a little bit different in the morning, in the afternoon, and then at dusk and after dark.

The Buzzing Medina. This place is crazy busy from its snake charmers and monkeys to its juice and spiced Moroccan tea bars. In the night this place really comes alive and there is so much to choose from when it comes to eating here. The souks are really big and you can buy really nice stuff but make sure you bargain with the locals to get a good price!
Snakes and Monkeys!. Exciting, vibrant, and fun, with delicious food, music, dancing, and snake charmers! Highly recommend

Messy, colourful Medina. It's a labyrinth. Designed to confuse invaders, it also works with tourists! Feel invited to get lost! Take good walking shoes and an extra dose of patience since everybody will permanentely try to sell you something!Find your way around yourself. Asking for directions (or even following aparently offered directions) may, very likely, lead you to some shop.Jemaa El Fna, not to be missed in the evening

Being a Black tourist in Marrakech. Name calling in the sqaure and souks. Just to give you and idea i was called - Beyoncé, Serena Williams, Michelle Obama's sister, Brown skin, Black diamond and finally Rasta Rasta, just adding to the list... Rihanna, Nicki Minaj, snickers and twix..Part of this is humour and casual racism. I would think that because i was in Africa and that there are plenty of black morrocans this wouldn't be the case.Also people will charge you if you take pictures or record them playing music so be aware.
lovely and safe place to walk around. We went with 2 adults and 4 children (aged between 10-12 years) you really think you went back 100 years!

Amazing Experience. Go. Keep an open mind. Magical experience. Stay away from the monkeys! The cobras are optional, and the early evening is the best time to truly absorb a new, different world. Once in a lifetime experience.
Our visit was during the day. I think we made a mistake visiting during the day time, I understand it is something else at night - maybe next time!
Like a magic maze. Here you can walk around for days! The Medina is so different and wonderful! There is nothing that you can´t buy here!

Lots to buy.. The stall holders were lovely. Not too pushy at all once you had run the gauntlet of the carriage drivers. We haggled gently. Showing great disappointment that they would ask so much . Gradually got to about half. I'm sure they were delighted and our honour was satisfied that we had a bargain. An enjoyable morning but we could have been there longer as there was so much to see. Get a map from your hotel as it is easy to get lost in the mazes although the stall holders do help you to get out.

Another world. Something we have not experienced so far. Very exciting and interesting place. Be careful you might easily get lost. Make sure, google maps works on your smartphone. And do not shop where your tour guide takes you: it will be majorly overpriced. Take your time and shop around. Outside the Medina it is usually cheaper
old and big. Medina of Marrakesh is busy but you can find a lot of tourist there, more than other cities of Morocco ... you can buy leather there as cheap as other cities

Old town . Completely different place then a centrum of Marrakech, bazaars, you can buy there almost everything what you need like a souvenir's, eat a traditional Moroccan kitchen, and met a original not always nice people
Excitement day time and night life. Lots going on here, lots of activities and so much to see. Take your time walking around, and enjoy everything here that is offered!

Snake Charmers, Crafts Galore & Fresh OJ. Take a walk on the wild side. Watch your wallet and explore to your heart's content. Marrakech has a wide variety of sights and sounds. Plus more than enough shops to satisfy the pickiest shopaholic.My advice is find where the locals eat and go there. The first night we were overwhelmed with the number of people and chose a restaurant with a terrace that over looked the square. The food was good however we had much better meals and for a fraction of the price at other eating establishments.There is so much to see that you absolutely need a good pair of walking shoes. We started our holiday in Marrakech and ended in Fez. We found the shopping better in Marrakech but the prices better in Fez. Or maybe it was better bartering skills after spending a week in Morocco?????The fresh OJ is delicious. Watch for the dates and baked goods behind glass counters. We saw several flies and insects attracted to the sweets. There are bakeries where the goodies are behind shut glass cases and items are sold by the grams.Immerse yourself in the Medina and enjoy the experience.

The wonderous Medina of Marrakech. Now walking through the mysterious Medina of Marrakech is not for the faint hearted! Remember to wear comfortable shoes and a large hat! The shade of the hat hides your eyes eye contact with the local hawkers sellers of many wares and wonderful enticements is best avoided however you do at the same time need to be looking where you are going donkeys carts scooters and taxis do have a tendency to creep up on you and catch you unawares.Never looked lost do not hold a map in your hand and look confident at all times "I meant to take this turn I know where I am going" Do not accept help and keep calm at all times. The sense of challenge and achievement when you master the culture of the Marrakech Medina is an amazing feeling.I loved the mystery the magic and the excitement of these ancient streets.

hassle , hassle hassle..... Having been lucky enough to see the medina's of Fes , tangier and Marrakech. the reality is that marrakech is by far the worst of the three. The hassle is relentless, you cannot walk anywhere without hassle. But the whole point of a visit to marrakech is visiting the medina. But the truth is, it is a poor cousin the the medina's of tangier and Fez.
The heart of Marrakech. Ate here in the evening, great food and atmosphere! Our guide recommended number 14 for great fish and we were not disappointed. Fish and chips Moroccan style1

An awesome place!. I've been to Casablanca then took the train to Marrakech. I found that Marrakech is very attractive as a touristic place. Simply, you experience the Moroccan culture and the feeling that you are in a completely different place unlike any other.

Exhausting. In all honesty we loved Marrakech, and everything about the place so despite the cons of the souk it's a must . First , I hate snakes and there are plenty .It's at night this place looks spectacular and the scope is huge however bartering, it's essential, can be tiring at best .I'm from the north so I upset a few with my offers and it went ok with others but be warned , avoid the market food at all costs. The bill will expand and after arguing about the bill and the extras they will try and put on ,I paid what I thought was fair and grabbed Claire's hand and left .It can be intimidating for some I'm sure but to me I was exhausted and those bloody snakes ..Still you must go , just make sure to have a drink at la mamounia before / after..!

Loads of things to do and to see. The medina are actually the 'walls' around a big area of Marrakech. There is a lot to do; most of the touristic places are inside of the medina except for menara mall, theatre royal, central station and a very big garden near by menara mall. Jmaa el fna is like the centre of all things. The fist evening i did not want to go back to the square (i was shocked!!! So many people, so many things happening at the same time, you get lost in the souks, people asking for money etcetc). At the end i spent all of my evenings there because i got used to it!

Hotel was situated here. We stayed in a riad to experience the real Marrakech and it was the best experience EVER! But we knew we wouldn't be able to hack the lifestyle or culture for too long so only stayed 4 nights, hustle and bustle all day long but the riad was so calm and beautiful couldn't hear any noise, easy to get lost and beware of the boys, they will follow you and give you directions, get you lost and they stick to you like glue then ask you to pay them, say NO!
Amazing souk. That's the place to visit, all the shops with all kinds of stuff here. Don't buy things at first price, always need to negociate.

It´s the!! highlight. One can get lost in the souqs and maze of small and narrow streets, so make sure you have a good map; don´t rely on google maps it doesn´t work here. If you get lost go to the nearest road and get an "petit taxi", don´t take the Mercedes taxis they try to rip you off
It's a lively place. This place truly comes alive by night, you need to be on your toes not to have 5 dinners by just saying hello, best of fun though
If you like that sort of thing.. . It's fine. If not, you should not have come to Marrakech! Fun, noisy, hassly and hot. Eating in the square an experience but not best food..

Noisy ..bustling fun. Wow first visit didn't know what to look at first snakes music everything you would expect from a bustling market ..be warned if you take a picture they will chase you down for money and get very angry and insult you if you don't pay ..apart from that small problem it's an amazing place to visit and wouldn't miss it for the world something that everyone should see at some time in there travels .

Old city - dirty city. I always wanted to visit Marrakech and looked forward to the trip, buti found it very dirty and the merchants are annoying. I felt constantly harrassed to buy something. Some people might find it funny and see the beauty of it, but after travelling to many countries, it becomes annoying. I did not even want to start a converstaion or look at any products in the fear of being bulied into buying something. You do however get a feel of Marrakech still being stuck in time, with snake charmers and tarot readers, but it has a feel of desperaration to it - just a way of getting tourists to part with thier money.

Great fun but keep wits about you. This is like a maze. You will get lost. You can find all sorts here from snake charters to show stalls to food places to pharmacies and iPhone shops. People are normally quite pleasant but some will take you for a ride. Taxis are everywhere hoping for customers and will if not careful run you over if the numerous mopeds don't first. Dress appropriately if you do not want to attract attention. Be careful of you purses and bags as there are a lot of pick pockets. Also when given a price this is always way to much. Always haggle. Do a lot of window shopping to find right place. The further inside the stalls the cheaper it is generally. For example silk scarves will be 100 dh outside and only 10 deeper inside. Be warned of snake charmers they will desend on you and demand money for pictures. Same with the guys with monkeys. Also I do not advise anyone get henna tattoos, once these women have you they literally don't stop or let go of your arm. Best not to engage with them. The experience is somewhat different and will definitely put you out of your comfort zone.

Great fun. The medina is the old city and in my opinion the place to stay and be to experience Marrakech, we spent 5 days over the Easter break and was one of the best holidays we had. Just walk around the souks, visit the attractions, haggle with shopkeepers, buy some authentic spices to take home and taste the amazing moroccan food. Regarding safety, I visited with my boyfriend so i felt safe but if i was on my own I would not feel safe even though i would probable be safe. Men standing in the corners of alley ways starring at you as you walk can be intimidating but after the first 24hours you learn to ignore them and accept that this is how it is (i still dont know what they actually do in the places they stand all day). Be sensible, dress respectfully and you will be fine as anywhere in the world!

Never miss to walk around the souq market. It was my first time to visit this place felt like went back to Aladdin days :-) beautiful traditional houses, souqs, eat outs, people, small roads etc.....moreover they kept very clean and tourist can walk around and visit the shops for hand made stuffs, also antique pieces.Moreover we all definitely look for Argan oil which is special from morocco, so I did the same started searching along with my Moroccan friends ( Interestingly they also first time buying argan oil )Managed to meet Mr. Syed from the souq called "Herboriseric Imam Souhaili" who invited us in to show the products, first impression is best impression as saying here it proves by their old heritage look of shop, he took me upstairs and started explain about the argan oil how it distract and produced. When it comes price as usual got surprised as foreigner and local friends too, so we politely said bye and moved out, and what gentlemen happily said bye even not purchased.Moved and inquired with three other shops, but i was not quite satisfied my mind fully loaded with that shop and compare with other shops his price was not bad, plus more I like the way he presented the product to us he never ever talk about other shop or how they make it. Rest all of the guys talk about other shop product instead their product it sounds really fishy and I decided to buy from the first shop even if price higher or lesser.Again back to him, he was very happy to see us and started extract the oil from argan seed in front of us and explain each product how and whats the medicinal effects, with such wonderful 25 years experience and coming from Atlas mountain tribal background this gentleman is gem for that shop. He speak Arabic fluent,French and English.He dont need education how to sell and market product..... not even once he talked about other shop or other people. Genuinely focused of his product and showing each with clear details.We finally bought oil and other stuff also took his business card for future purchase or recommend others.One of good hearted person recently I met in this commercial world, If need any further details please write to me I will be very happy to give complete information for this place.Enjoy discovering.....Asif

A lot of fun!. Even if you don't like shopping, it is quite amazing to see all the things you can find inside the medina. There is a sense of safeness as everyone is friendly. Beautiful colours, food and lots of things to buy! I can't wait to go back there!

Spana - we visited the animal rescue charity which supports working animals. It is an easy taxi ride from the medina. A real eye opener and well worth supporting as their education program will help stop cruelty through ignorance and poverty

Women family birthday trip. We stayed in the medina and never felt frightened. We did dress conservatively out of respect for the Moroccan culture but wore slacks, jeans or leggings with longer tops and tried not to reveal a lot of skin. We found everyone to be very respectful, helpful and were continually reminded to conceal our iPhones and zip our purses for our safety. Police presence was there for protection and even cameras to make sure no one was taking advantage of the shoppers or shopkeepers. A very good experience.

busy noisey fun. A great Moroccan experience, keep lots of small change 10/20mad for the snake charmers, monkeys, watermen. If you have your photos taken with them they will expect a little in return. but very willing for you to take lots of photos

Great place to visit !. We loved it here - went for the day and just walked and walked and walked ! Just like you would imagine it ! We went during the day and it wasn't too busy, but I should imagine at night it would be a nightmare ! We didn't get a guide and felt very safe, but I think if we were two women I may have felt differently. Bought a few bits and bobs including a lovely lamp for the garden. One of the highlights of the holiday !

Loved it!. So easy to get lost, but that can sometimes be half the fun! Anyway, we were staying at a riad inside the medina and the host gave us a clear map including photographs on where to turn, etc, to walk into the main square. By following this we had no issues and found amazing stalls with their colourful vendors selling everything you know you don't need to buy but feel you still should. We then walked down some main alleyways from the square and found similar stalls. We also got some good deals on items we were interested in (at least we were happy with the prices), so be prepared to bargain and walk away if your prices are reasonable. Plenty of cafes and restaurants too, but we found some amazing street food which was really tasty and much cheaper.
Fantastic. If you want to visit a city who can reprent the traditional culture of Morroco and Berbers, Marrakech is good because you don't need to satisfy the comfortability,

Great Cultural Experience. The Medina is large and comes to life around sunset with entertainers, fortune tellers, snake charmers, colorful water vendors, and belly dancers (men dressed like women). They also have a very extensive night market with all kinds of foods, including goat heads and brains. It's an experience not to be missed.

The Medina epitomises Marrakech. Get lost in the Medina if you really want to discover Marrakech and savour the flavours of Moroccan life. See how people, live , interact, move in the heart of this ancient City
Medina is an amazing place, definitely to put on one's bucket list. The souk('s) are a market on steroids. A real experience of an Arabic market. Remeber to haggle over everything.

INTERESTING EXPERIENCE BUT HOLD ONTO YOUR BAGS/WALLETS. Had a walk to the medina in the evening with friends,it is very interesting and a lot going off. but be careful while not all people are out to rob you, while my friend joined the back of a crowd watching some activity that was going off. Someone moved in behind her and was acting very strange and it was obvious that he wasn't watching the entertainment as he was looking at her handbag, his friend then moved in so they were shoulder to shoulder right up behind her. It wasn't until he saw me looking and I managed to attract our friends attention that they quickly moved away. We also did a visit during the day which was less hustle and bustle.

Medina, exciting & busy. Well worth a visit very interesting architecture. not for children and is a long walk from the square. The square is where it all happens, busy with cars and people by day and in the afternoon they do not let taxis or other transport into the old city. In the evening it get even more busy with all the resturants and snake charmers and drummers spred all over the square. Noise and food everywhere mixture of locals with tourists. The oranges which they are famous for can be bought from stalls and squeezed into juice. They are the most delicious oranges I have every had. It all closes up at about 12pm, that is when we where there, maybe longer if in season. If one tries to take pictures they want you to pay, and get angry if you do not. When all is over the whole square is washed so it is all clean by morning. We found it to be safe and also noticed a lot of tourist females there all alone. We had a great time and would recommend a visit. If you are staying a few nights I recommend staying in the old city in a Riad to experience the vibe.. We stayed at Riad El Jihad, which was excellent. Jill de Klerk South Africa
Like a time travel. Just get rid of your map and get lost. Well, you1d get lost anyway, so take it easy. Hang around, don't buy anything at first (well, maybe some fruits). Breathe in. Feel good.

Are we still on planet Earth, or is this a planet in Star Wars?. I walked everywhere within the Medina on my own. Not necessarily the wisest thing. Best in pairs, as you could be targeted. Especially if you pull out a map, by the over friendly, over helpful, falsely sincere, con men. DO NOT allow their cousin or son or whoever, to lead you anywhere ( usually the tannery). They are very difficult to shake. Say "GO AWAY" angrily in their face two or three times early on. I DO NOT want you to help me. Normal people are not interested in helping you, if you look lost. Use GPS on your phone or even the sun to navigate ( it's in the south at Midday, adjust according to the time on your watch). A compass would be a good idea, in fact, as the Souks are covered. It would have saved me hours. Most maps are rubbish in helping you navigate ( especially in the souks). "HERE Maps" app. using GPS was recommended to me afterwards.DO NOT photograph ANY local individuals with out asking, even if they are 20 yards away. They may allow you, usually with a fee.Otherwise you will be threatened and verbally attacked until you pay them. Do not photograph anywhere near the Palaces or their guards. Otherwise it could get nasty as I found out. Someone did try to pick my pocket, so keep your money hidden and deep. There is also a scam with a crazy man that corners you, if someone offers to help, tell him also to GO AWAY. As he will offer to take you somewhere and demand £8(100 Dir or more) Follow these rules and you should be fine. Unless you are a hardened traveler and streetwise, use a recognized local guide who will ensure everything will be fine and stress free. I had a real stressful adventure on my own but it's not for everyone. The miles of shops in the Souks are mostly all the same so there is no need to over visit them. 30 mins should be enough for a tourist.

Exciting and Vibrant square. An amazing experiences, however be aware of the fact that if you take pictures of anybody they will try and charge you, we took photos from the roof top terraces lol. Avoid the guides and discover the souks for yourselves. Some great bargains to be had if you are prepared to haggle, start very low!!!! Even better at night and street food is lovely and the whole place comes alive. We will be back again!!!

For people who likes action ... I loved it... but you could hate it for sure. It is a crazy place, where locals mix with tourist, where you can buy anything and people try to sell to you everything... it is a fun place for sure, but do not go if you want peace and calm..

If you love action, adventure, mystery and more. This is your place. I can honestly say that spending 4 days in the Medina was life altering. From the sales tactics, the smells of food, the sights of poverty and the excitement of dinnertime, this was a magical and mystical place. You must spend days and nights as the Medina changes from daytime shopping to nighttime entertainment. The vendors are generally happy to see you and want to haggle but beware, start off very low as they are good.

Go with a guide. If you have been to other North African Countries this Medina is like all others. Lots of fake tat but also authentic items which when you barter go 80% lower, I started off with 900d and paid 300d, so hold your nerve!It's ok to wander around without a guide but you would get hassle at every shop and that could get tiring!They also have monkeys in chains for photos which is sad and also snake charmers.But in Marrakech you need to visit as there is t much else to see.

One for the bucketlist if you like citys. If you like citys you defenitly have to see this historic streets and the little shops. For sure don't forget to eat on the great plaza and drink some more mint tea.But take care of your pockets in the crowded streets -not to "loose" some of your property ;)

Very interesting place where life goes on regardless. Bustling busy maze of old and new unfortunately it rained during our stay converting most of the roads in to muddy paths, very safe although you may be hassled by touts and children asking for "Un Dhiram"

Take Maps with Me app or download TA map. Very atmospheric. Take a map on your smartphone that tracks you as easily get lost without sun to direct you. Download TA map or Maps with Me that does not use data only GPS.Safe to wander round although you get hassled occasionally for restaurant advice, massage or hashish (grannies excepted). Beggars, usually women with babies, abound. Not like Camden.Lots of cats, mind the pooh on the ground. No urine smelling corners encountered although the recent rains may have flushed them through. Frequent motorbikes, some dangerously fast, so take corners wide! Bicycles are silent so be aware from behind and at blind corners too!

An experience. We visited The Medina as part of an excursion but may as well have gone on our own as we had the most disinterested and careless tour guide I've ever come across! Anyway, the sights and sounds are a real experience, as is the hard sell from the souk sellers, henna ladies, watch sellers, snake charmers, etc. I'd already been warned not to let the henna ladies get hold of my hand and they got quite frustrated that I wasn't going to stupidly hold my hand out before agreeing on a price. I ended up walking away with one of them following behind me relentlessly! The sales patter in general was harmless and a quick but firm "la shukran" (no thank you) and they left you alone. I'd say that the whole experience was a physical assault on the senses with motor bikes, cats, welding, shouting, food, etc all around you but it was a memorable experience that I'm glad I got to have, and won't ever forget.

Medina of Marrakech - fascinating famous city. Medina of Marrakech - fascinating famous city
Beautiful , nice sunny weather, fascinating in their hand crafted and art design, friendly people and every traveler should see.

Great fun getting lost in the labyrinth of the souks!. Highly recommended place to while away many hours exploring and soaking up the atmosphere. Take an umbrella if it's raining, as it did every day of my five day visit this month.

Chaos. The Medina is utter madness. It was a bit of a culture shock when we first arrived. The winding streets, the wide range if sights and sounds could possibly be a bit overwhelming for the timid traveler. However, once you find your feet it is an extremely interesting and exciting place to explore. If you're a little lost pop into a shop and ask one of the the elderly ladies or gentlemen, some of the younger people will bring you the wrong way and expect you to give them money for their 'help'. It really is a must visit as you won't find anything like it anywhere else.

The place to go. It's always amazing to go to this place, there is so many people and so much to see and to prepare ourself for the Souk.I found this years to many kids and people trying to sell you something, and they become quite aggressive, you need to looks more than ever at your wallet and purse all the time and I did felt very uncomfortable for the first time. for the the rest Just go there it's a must
Amazing. Out of this world! A must-see for everyone! You need to stay inside the medina when in Marrackech to experience it

Not overly impressed. Visited because you can't not. Was as expected though...busy, compact. Streets of more modern shops similar to London, cheap shoe shops, kebab shops, phone shops etc. Main square was large and open but with threw traffic so watch your step. Not very clean. Be wary of street sellers - snakes and monkeys will be thrown at you and then you'll be charged for a picture. Also saw a lady selling Henna grab a girls hand and draw on her before she could say no - then chase her round with another lady demanding payment. Lots of cafes around the edge, none sell alcohol though. Side streets full of tented markets, DO barter - you WILL get the price down. I'm not one for that sort of thing, but our friend was saving loads of money by doing this. Do head down the Horse road (you'll see it) and turn right - keep on up this road to see some lovely gardens and eventually get to the New Town. This area is much better for shopping.
Exotic, chaotic and completely fascinating. Hawkers, carnival barkers everywhere! Snake charmers, tame monkeys, spices and trinkets of every kind. A madhouse, but friendly inmates. What a scene!!!

Make two trips. The Medina is completely different at night to what it is at day, so its well worth doing both. During the day in the square you have snake charmers, a mobile dentist sat under an umbrella. I think he is there twice a week. If you start taking pictures of snake charmers they will want paying. Ypou have to watch out for the henna ladies, who will creep up on you and start to draw on your hands. There is a little street of the square with shops for shopping and of course you have the souks. You can sit and have a coffee and watch the world go by very happily.
Aswesome!!. Utter chaos -- the noise, the sights and sounds and the aromas -- a once-in-a-lifetime experienced -- not to be missed!

Traveler attitude bollet proof !. As one of my friend said: If you survive Marrakech medina you survive everything. No really its not easy there. You may have a luck and you will be wondering why is so many people crazy about Marrakech medina in other case youll love it and hate it at the same time .....
Great experience. It can be a little overwhelming, especially if this is your first stop in Morocco. Interesting experience though and great people watching.

Very busy and plenty of shops and places to eat. We went to the Medina twice, once daytime and once in the evening. Daytime was quieter and easy to get about however I did not like the night time. Hassle, hassle, hassle.

Be aware. Was there for 10 minutes after being persuaded by a cobbler in the souk to remove my shoe(more fool me) I thought he wanted to view the design, and watch whilst he ripped and cut the sole off a perfectly healthy sandle, my cries of "No give me back my shoe, changed to OK so "How much as I do not have much money'" his response was ' No problem, no problem" was relieved when both sandals were returned and current lover took a firm stand and instead of giving more that I paid for the shoes what we would have paid in London. So onto the square, we bought some orange juice off one of the vans and ware shouted at by the other vendors for not choosing them, "liar you are liars " was the chant. Very bewildering and then if that w not enough to lady all in black grabbed my hand whilst I was walking away from her and peoceeded to daub my hand in Henna with me saying NO NO to her. She told me I had beautiful eyes and the when it was clear no money would be given she cursed my with a "F You!!! We laughed about it but just be careful as it is an interesting place to see.

Fantastic - But not for the average tourist!. The Medina is the beautiful old city of Marrakesh, surrounded by a huge wall, where all traditional trades and values still exist. Here you will find many sellers with stalls of hand crafted items such as leathers, rugs, pottery and silver. You will also find some great authentic restaurants - most with rooftop terrraces.Be warned, this is not a place for everyone - by all means everyone must visit, but not all should stay within the Medina. You may be tempted by the beutiful Riads, but if you are not experienced in the Morrocan culture or are not very confident travelers, I would recomend staying in the new part of Marrakesh, and visiting the Medina within an organised group. The roads can be very daunting, with cars, scooters, bikes, pedestrians and Donkeys all competing to get down very narrow roads! It can be quite fun! There are also many beautiful Mosques to visit - although you cannot get inside unless you are of their faith, the outsides are a work of art. Well worth a visit!

Medina of Marrakech. The market is full of people and old world Charm. Like everywhere in Morocco, people want to help to get money. Take taxi or horse carnage to visit. Spice shopping an experience that you should not miss. Again expect to pay... by the GRAM which is a lot of $$$$

Marrakech Medina geared to tourism and full of beggars and hagglers.. Watch your wallet, watch your wife and partner, keep your kids safe.The Medina in Marrakech is a volatile and edgy place to visit. Constant begging, and people trying to drag you into shops, I had more than one altercation whilst defending my partner from the Moroccan men, grabbing and being inappropriate. You can have a good time and take advantage of all the Medina has to offer being sensible and aware of your surroundings is key to enjoying a shopping experience here.The goods on offer and food are all decent enough, its unfortunate you have to be on guard throughout the experience.Despite this always remember to haggle hard.

A must see.... I stayed at a riad in the medina so ended up spending a bit of time here. It is nice on Fridays because it's a bit quieter due to it being a holy day. It's fun and interesting and probably the only place of it's kind on earth. Be prepared to be stopped and shouted at at every turn. I am a solo female traveler and took precautions to not be walking by myself at night. It can be hard to navigate and it's just not safe by yourself. The one night I was alone, trying to find a cab, I was seriously harassed by three teenage boys. It was very upsetting. The key is to say 'no, thank-you' and keep walking, being borderline rude, which can be difficult.
So much to see and do. If you enjoy people watching, New sights and sounds then this is the place. A real treat for the soul

Busy day at the sales. This truly an experience not to be missed, just the sights, smells (pleasant) and sounds of the Medina really let you see and feel the culture. Can be a bit wearing bartering for everything but it all very friendly. Just be aware there a bicycles and small motor scooter s, whizzing about down the narrow streets, not sure how but everybody manages to avoid each other, but worth the risks for the experience.

Fabulous City. Do it all- it is so interesting and safe.The souks are an experience but the Medina comes alive from 6.00pm onwards.Dancers,snake charmers,cafes, shops.A fabulous place to watch the world of Marrakech

fun way to shop. less hectic than Fes, this medina area has wider streets and a less pressured feel. Souks easy to navigate and there are lots of shops and eating places on the outskirts of the medina. you get a much better feel of the city staying here than in a more expensive hotel in the new city

it is chaos but definitely worth a visit. It is very colourful but be aware to be constantly asked if you wished to buy. we did purchase a few things and would would always be about a third of the starting price. Fake Ray Bans are about £3-4 football shirts £10 shorts £5
it is fun and a good experience but it can be exhausting
Wow!. A must to immerse yourself in the Moroccan culture ! The smells, colours and people were amazing....

Sexual Assault & Harassment Central. While some may enjoy being shouted at to buy the sellers' good, I found it off putting! I was also sexually assaulted in this market despite being with a group of people, wearing full length clothing (/ any other victim blaming excuse). Went to the Tourist Police and they said I should have dragged the Moroccan to them to be arrested which is impossible for anyone in shock after being assaulted. I would advise anyone to be careful but at the end of the day someone assaulting you is out of your control - try and call them out on it and get a picture of their face, otherwise the police don't care.
Amazing sensory overload. Amazing vibrant place. The true soul of Marrakech. Be prepared to walk, walk, haggle and have a great time.

Interesting but. a big hassle. You stop to look at anything and sellers (some quite agressive) bully you and demand you go in. Ended up buying a lot less than intended as a result, Bought souvenirs in Artisan Centrale instead, a huge shop where prices are fixed.Not for people with walking difficulties. You also need to be aware of mopeds, donkey carts and pickpockets.

Buzzing with life. Marrakesh is amazing if you have an open mind and take it as it is. If you like clean, clinical European destination then this is not the place for a visit. This city is deadly hot in the summer, dirty and doesn't smell great but that said, it's like a time capsule which is full of charm, history and bags of atmosphereAs a woman travelling alone, I felt completely safe and content walking around the city. Please remember ladies, this a very conservative country and should be treated as such. The key to a hassle free trip is modesty here.

Fascinating hustle and bustle. Visited this both day and night enjoyed both did see some snake charmers but just kept away.l Enjoyed fresh orange juice in the heat of the day and fresh tasty food by night, do eat at stall 31 also have the soup.
old center medina. Very old center with beautiful old city gates. There a lot of small alleys you can get lost . Try the eastern gates near the tannery
Relaxing. Great place to shop, eat and drink fresh ingredients, found a great massage parlour, fantastic value

Magical place!!!. Stop for a minute. Look around, smell the tagine and mint tea, see the colors, hear the sounds, see the people from all over the world passing by! An unforgettable experience! It's unbelievable, magical, addictive! I go back there every year since 2011. You will get lost in the narrow streets but you are going to take lots of great pictures of places you didn't know existed! Also I recommend you to stay in a riad inside medina for an authentic experience!The atmosphere of Jemma el Fna is incredible. Can't wait to come back in April this year!

Vibrant and exhilarating marketplace. The Medina is a great experience for food, shopping and entertainment. We enjoyed getting oriented by starting with a guided tour and using a good map, were then able to navigate to all the places we wanted to visit. There are some traps for visitors as in all cities. We had a couple of instances of kids becoming very aggressive when we did not give money. This meant we became a bit guarded when approached by strangers, many probably just offering to help. Overall though very enjoyable and safe, an experience thoroughly enjoyable.
Brilliant. Had lots of fun, great experiance. Fantastic night life in the square and the food it amazing. Glad we stayed in Medina

A total Maze. A must see place but be careful you can easily get lost A little bit in your face with locals just smile and say NODo not go to watch the hide dying just a scam with locals to get you in carpet shops But all said at night the colour and activities are wonderful
Recommend you go on an organised trip with a knowledgable tour guide. Using a tour guide will ensure you see the best things to see and how not to get lost as it is very easy in the maze of alleys!

Terrifying if you're a woman. In complete awe of the way my friend and I were harassed walking down the streets. We were completely covered up and yet had been screamed incredibly unnecessary and inappropriate sexual comments at us, been chased and followed. I have been to over 20 countries (5 continents), and never in my life have ever felt so terrified.
Too much hassling and pushy from sellers!. We just did one circle and left, not our cup of tea I'm afraid. I cannot see the attraction of it to be honest!
place to stay to see the real Marrakech. A must do when in Marrakesh to see the real city and the locals. Safe and where the action is. Walking distance to all

Dreamlike, enchanted walled maze. Make sure it doesnt become a nightmare!. I stayed in the Medina in March 2016 with my partner. As a woman I would not go alone unless in a hotel immediately on the central Jmaa el fna square. The reason is that the alleyways particularly on the northern edges of the Medina are full of touts waiting to try to ensnare/guide you for money. Do NOT allow anyone to guide you anywhere unless an official guide planned in advance. Take a map. Cover up if female. Only ask women the way. Ideally stay near square so don't get lost. Eat in the square at night? Number One food stall was great! Aroma cafe out of the square opposite the mosque was lovely for tea. Walk in the mosque gardens. If rich go to Mammonia hotel for tea (£15 two cups tea but worth it).

On my god!!. Apparently you either love or hate the Medina, I have to say I lean towards the hate!! The area is dirty, crowded and you are relentlessly approached by beggars and peddlers selling copies of watches and phones or children selling tissues. This is also combined with the constant stream of mopeds so you literally breathe in fumes throughout your entire visit.It's definitely an experience and glad I've seen it but will definitely not be repeated.

Amazing!. What a beautiful place! We took a trip from our hotel that took us by bus to some horse drawn carriages that took us into the middle of town. Be prepared to hold your breath when you get there though... All day heat and dozens of horses do not mix... We were then taken to one if the few two/three story buildings looking over the square where we were given cool drinks and given the opportunity to take pictures from above. We were then let loose in the square. There's everything you can think of...! Food, smells, animals, gifts...! Name it, it was there! All you need to do is haggle!
Incredible. An absolute delight to be amongst the traders with all the spices and leather and rugs. A really good experience
Good place to buy. Go in the Medina, and buy somethink! Its so nice here! Nice People, good Prices for all! It was nice!
Immerse yourself in culture.. You have to visit the Medina and Jemaa el Fna. You see monkeys and cobras along with being able to get henna tattoos. Watch your wallet but a fun visit.
Crowded and full of life.. It is worth having a guide so you can see all the smaller areas which used to specialise in products as well as find your way around easily - it can be confusing.
Bustling. Yes a bustling place where you get virtually anything also you must have bartering head-on a fair bit of entertainment around aswell

Get Lost in The Medina . The heart of old Marrakech had to be experienced to be believed. Wandering the souks is an experience in itself but make some purchases and test your haggling skills against the best! There is no need for a guide as although you will get lost repeatedly and a map is of little use in the souks you will always find your way back to a landmark that's on a map. And from there you can plan the next adventure back in there. Beware of people who try to lead you into shops or other souks and watch out for the mopeds, stay to the right hand side.

Throw out the map !! And walk wherever u want :)). Marakech medina is cool , even small than Fes' . I really enjoy local stuff there. Throw out the map , cant help me too much :) only google map can help . But whos care ??? :p enjoy walking around even u get loss , ask local people . They willing to help you. Dont forget to bargain prices 3 times . Ceramics , carpets , foods there are good . In the evening i recimmend u go to some coffee shop or restaurant place that have roof top . U can see top viewv. Very beautiful there .

Jewels amongst the chaos and maze.. This old city (walled city called Medina) is a must see. Hundreds of small streets linked together like a maze with full of small shops, markets, squares makes it very interesting. Just beware of guide hustlers who are looking to monetise every little opportunity without you even realizing.
Brilliant atmosphere. the market is amazing but be careful when taking pictures with snakes or monkeys as they will want you to pay them after!!!

Lovely Medina. The Medina is the heart of the old city. It's lovely just to wonder around
You will always find something of interest
The Medna is also a must see!. I loved visiting the Medina. It is another string of markets. A very wide selection of items at bartering prices.

An typical old-fashioned medina. The medina district of Marrakech is a typical warren of winding narrow streets and many shops. It is fun and interesting to walk around. The experience is seriously impacted by the constant stream of speeding motor scooters (and bicycles). If you are not constantly on the watch, they will mow you down, as we saw happen in one instance. If you live here, you can probably adapt quickly, but for casual tourists, it is a bit dangerous.

Hard bargaining required - stay alert & don't get lost!. It's a place where one can find a bargain, but it's like finding a needle in a haystack! If you like haggling, then you will love this place. Prices start at crazy high amounts, and more than often, one should pay about 20% - 30% of the original asking price! Personally, I did not purchase anything off the souks this time around, as you can often find some decent fixed price shops around the square, and no haggling needed! One should also note, don't start bargaining for a product you have no interest in - it is very difficult afterwards to say no, as the shopkeeper will take offence especially if he or she comes down to your asking price. In fact, I would take it further and not even pick up an item unless I'm very sure I will buy it. Even just looking at items is frustrating as you will not be left alone. Not all the souks are like this, but the majority are. It's best to know what you want and what you are willing to pay for it, and stick to that. Don't back down - in the end, if it is a reasonable price that you are offering, they will accept it.Also, it is very easy to get lost in the souks - you can always check up high to see some signs which direct you back to the main square (though even some of these have been vandalised). Never take the offer of someone showing you how to get somewhere unless you want to give a few euros/pounds/dirhams to those who are directing you. Of course, if you lost in a major way, best to ask some children, who will be more than happy to help for a few dirhams. I suggest everyone carry a map or if you have a tablet, download a map beforehand and use GPS to get you where you want to go - though the GPS signal is quite weak in this part of the world! I found the signs on top of the souks to be the most helpful.If this is your first visit to Marrakech, you should definitely visit the souks, but be alert and be confident. Know what you want and how much you want to pay and walk away if you don't get it. Keep it simple, and friendly and you may even enjoy some of this bargaining!
Worthwhile . This place is just amazing at night. It's full of life and sound - a must see on ever morroco trip. The souks become really alive after 6/7 pm.

Lovely, Once you get your barings. The Medina was confusing to get around at first. There are lots of little alley ways and walkways that aren't on the maps. The trick is to stay on the main roads with cars, those are the ones on the maps and will help you from getting lost. Once I figured that out, I was in great shape. I stayed in the medina at a beautiful and well run riad called Matin de Marakech. Staying in the Medina, I was able to walk to almost everywhere, including many attractions outside the Medina in the New City. If you want to immerse yourself in Marrakesh, I recommend at least a good visit to the Medina

A must on everyone's wish list. This place is amazing as sun falls grab a seat at a nearby cafe and watch the festivities begin, snake charmers, street performances, eateries and heaps of people from across the globe, just sit back and take in the festivities. Be careful of your wallets, phones etc great place for pick pockets, but keep yourself save and enjoy.

Definatley worth a visit. Great to visit on an evening they have a food market on and everyone is sitting round playing games and music. During the day there are belly dancers and big snakes about. If you are tickle stomached they do have real animal heads on show and cut animals up around here though.

Such a great experience. What a fantastic place to visit. It's so different to back home in England. The Medina Souks is all about haggling down the cost of goods. They have everything you could possibly think of! You definitely need to be confident and stand by your word otherwise you will get talked into buying all sorts! The best way is to so No Thank you in English or Arabic and to continue walking.Do not take pictures of the monkeys as the owners automatically put their hand out for money. Same goes for taking pictures of the snake charmers and snakes, everything is at a cost.Definitely worth going to the Souks to experience a different way of work and living. Be careful when going into the Souks themselves are there are a lot of alley ways which it is almost impossible to get out of and you are more than likely to get completely lost!If you are female try to go with a male for safety and security.

Get ready to haggle and get lost, worth a visit. There are many many shops here and no one is too pushy. You will get lost and if you can find your own way out. Disliked the monkeys on chains and snake charmers as I personally don't agree with it. There are beggar children and women but they also are not pushy. Try to eat off of the main square. We definitely paid too much money for poor food,

Medina Madness. We stayed in the very tourist orientated Hotel Ammsoffah, very close to the Souk Cha'aria. The hotel was easily enough to get to but you certainly needed a taxi to get you into the heart of the Medina. The Medina is an amazing place where the frenetic hustle and bustle will harangue you and you will be continually pestered by the many hawkers and traders. Browsing without paying for anything is not an option here and many traders start to get shirty with tourists who simply 'look'. In fact, the traders will harangue you incessantly, trying to sell you their various wares at exorbitant prices. The haggling is exhausting and can be extremely tiresome after the first hour within the Medina. The food and eating out is incredibly cheap and the food, as long as it is piping hot, is excellent. The restaurants are many and those geared up for tourists do sell alcohol. Even the most expensive of eateries will set you back forty quid, with two dining. Please only drink bottled water. The poverty is inescapable and the begging can be tricky to avoid though it is advisable to refrain from giving anything as a swarm of individuals will descend upon you for rich pickings. Please, please do not seek any directions from unofficial 'guides', who will take you to your destination then ask you for a ridiculous amount of money. They will not leave you alone if you refuse. One 'guide' demanded twenty Euros from us after taking us on a merry dance around in a circle. We refused and tried to disappear in a restaurant. The 'guide' waited outside until we finished and continued his demands. A heated argument in both English and Arabic resulted in the restaurant staff giving him five Euros to get rid of him on our behalf. The wares from the markets if haggled ruggedly are cheap. Close your eyes to the feral cats and dogs and try and avoid observing the treatment of ponies and donkeys. The Medina is a destination for the most intrepid of travellers.
Treasures in a chapelet . I looooooooved walking thorough the medina with Ibrahim. I had the feeling that nothing but good would happen to me. It is a blessing

Medina Madness. Wow! I only got three souks in before being talked into entering & purchasing goods, good tip....stay focused on what you want & don't get led astray which in my case is almost impossible!
I visited my friends. a wonderful view,nice peoples and especially a magnificient tea,and everything was changed in the night

Prepare to do battle. The bussle of the market demands your attention in multiple directions, simultaneously. While dodging the speedy scooters and plodding donkey carts, vendors cry for your attention to view their wares. Once you show a modicum of interest, the battle is engaged.This is not a battle for the shy or reticent, but one for the patient, polite, good humoured, and slightly stubborn. One will not win every skirmish but with fortitude will eventually come to an agreement that both combatants will accept with a smile and handshake. There are many products and crafts to view down the endless maze of alleys and tiny side streets.Into the mix are food vendors and restaurants generating exotic and sometimes enticing aromas. Though alcohol is banned from Medina, several of the nicer looking establishments on the fringes will offer a cold beer or local wine.The usual personal precautions should be taken while moving about this crowded market. Keep valuables locked down and hidden away.Shopping is not the only pursuit. Embedded in the Medina are palaces and museums. If you are able to disengage from the market battlefield, these are well worth seeking out.Good luck and have fun.

Very very busy. Due to the business and crazy traffic I had to be on guard with the children at all times. Also a bit disappointing when the locals are all offering to give you directions and start leading you down the streets of the souks which was very concerning so after the first day we learned the hard way and that was to not accept any direction off anyone and to have a map yourself so that you know exactly where your going. Sales people are very pushy so have to be very firm with them by saying NO all the time. Even the guides with passes who show you round the square etc. are all taking back handers off the shops so when they are guiding you they guide you to their shops. Everyone is geared up to get you to spend your money so be on guard and be firm but polite.
nice medina. we visited medina of marrakech, wow it was interesting place , we really enjoyed our visit into this place

it blows your mind in the madness. Donkey carts pulling sony goods? bikes, mopeds, motorbikes, hawkers what a hullabaloo, the noise is a cacophony of sound, keep your wits about you. the people are lovely but pushy. dont say your from london! fish and chips, OK mate, the banter is funny but wears thin in the end.I recommend every one experiences it at least once.

Evening trip to the Medina. Gosh, what a wonderful vibrant placeWonderful friendly localsAmazing coffee in the local coffee houses and bartering for your favourite souvenirsMade even more lovely by a trip in horse drawn carriageWonderful beautiful city

Amazing place day or night. Went here last week. Sunny afternoon just browsing the 100s of little stalls. Each one selling handmade lanterns and candle holders, leather bags, silk scarves then the traditional fashion then lots of fake bags/football shirts the normal when in markets. There are tiny streets that go off one another make sure you do. You never get harassed to buy anything and are very safe. The people are so friendly it's nice to sit and chill in a bar or cafe and watch the world go by. Just be careful of people on scooters they expect you to jump out of the way!

Old city. This is called medina . Place where the Muslim people lives and also very traditional streets and houses and shops . We stayed in the hotel where is in the medina . We were happy because everyone was very friendly and kind . Also close to all attractions

A very different holiday experience!. Souks are a treat for all the senses, open mind essential!
People are mostly genuine and very friendly. Some can be a bit pushy.

The Medina is Marrakech. The heart of the old city, the medina is a mix of tourists, hotels, traders and locals alike. Surrounded by the city walls with a number of interesting gates (babs) connecting the medina to the modern city, it comprises of a confusing network of narrow passage ways, traditional houses and shop fronts and some communal / market squares. Cars can only fit in a few places but the streets are used by masses of tourists on foot and locals on donkeys or motorbikes (the latter does detract from the experience since they are hazardous, noisy and fumey). The main areas are the souks which extend north and south from the main square(Jem El Fna) which is worth a visit at night. Plenty of fantastic quiet riads to stay in within the medina which make for a good base if you want to get a flavour of traditional Marrakech.

Amazing but be on guard. Whilst staying at the Tikida Palmeraie we used there shuttle bus to travel to the medina and boy it was an experience. It is just a maze of alleyways packed with shops and stalls and I expected to get really hassled but that was not the case they backed off after a firm no thank you. We were advised before we left if we got involved in haggling to settle for between 30% and 50% of the sellers initial offer and this seemed to work fine. Even if you do not intend to buy anything it is worth a look just for the experience. Whist walking about I was approached by someone from a barber shop as I had 3 or 4 days of stubble on my chin so I decided to let him give me a shave, AMAZING he spent about 25 minutes during which time he shaved me 3 times before trimming eyebrows, ear and nose hair before buffing my skin up with a little machine containing talcum powder, I felt so relaxed afterwards, he asked for 50 dirhams (about £3.50) and didn't even bother to try and haggle I just paid as it was well worth it.One thing to be aware of, we managed to lose our way and we were studying our map when we approached by a young male who asked me where I wanted to be, I told him by the main mosque and he said I was going in the wrong direction. I thanked him and began to walk in the right direction towards the mosque. He began to follow us and started chatting with me seemingly friendly enough but when the mosque came into view he demanded money from us when I refused he became aggressive and I ended up threatening him and saying I would call the police if he did not go away, as there was a police checkpoint about 50 yards away he left but that was the only downside of the day.
médina. the médina city is amazing , you can find there a spirit unvaluable . there are traditional markets called souks , delicious food , jewellery ...

it surely is an experience. lose the sense of personal space. Become one with the smell of difference spices, vibrant colours and making sure you get the best deal for goods.Talk with locals and discover their stories.
Such fun. Great place to see Marrakech as it's best. It is just a hive of little lanes and shops and you can so easily got lost and forget looking up where you are on google. Great experience.

The heart of Marrakech. Very busy, very touristy but this is the heart and centre of Marrakech. In the evening, locals and tourists alike come together in the main square, which us always a hub of activity. You have to visit the souks too - whether a quick trip or to spend hours of shopping and bartering

you cannot visit Marrakech without going to the Medina.. We got a taxi to the Media, about a 10 min ride for around £2.60. we arrived and went to a herboriste, where we had a massage each for £2.00 approx each and then were demonstrated on how the Moroccan oil is made, as well as other many products they sell, we bought some tea, which after googling how to make correctly i have now mastered back at home.. we went to the open square where there are many interesting sites to see, you must try the fresh squeezed orange juice, its delicious.. we walked around for but im sure we missed lots out as its a real maze of twists and turns and there is so much going on you get lost in the senses of it all (in a good way) we stopped at one of the small squares and enjoyed as nice traditional tea, (you could also use the loo free of charge then) be careful of accepting help with directions or having someone "guide you to a certain place" as they will generally want you to give them money or buy something from the stalls. but if you are a savvy shopper there is many a bargain to be had, we will need to bring an empty suitcase for our next venture as there are so many wonderful things to buy, note though do not hold all your money in the same place, if it looks like you have less money on you then it makes it easier to haggle ;-) we also treated ourselves to a horse and carriage ride back to the hotel, which i would recommend as its a great experience and also relatively cheap it cost us around £8.00 for a 15min journey.

The square is the cenrte of the medina.. The square is worth a visit at night but is a total ripp off for goods sold. The food stalls in the square at night you can haggle. You will not get anywhere near a bargin in the market stalls. if you are put under pressure ask for the Auxillary Force they are the tourest police.

visit in the day time. we went at night with a thomson trip. thought it might be safer as a group. the market was just repetative from stand to stand. most of the gear being sold was just tat. i would never eat there as the hygine was terrible. i saw no snake charmers as was told and i didnt really feel safe.1 of the people in our group was hit on the head by children and called Kojak although funny not really very nice. all in all poor

Ambush of the senses. I adore the Medina in Marrakesh. It is not for those of you that don't like busy, noisy places, filled with the smells of strong scents, foods and visual colour. A continuous array of folk wanting your attention and money......"come buy in my store, good price...asda price", "come looky looky....looky is free", "come see genuine fake, genuine". I love the banter and the bartering. The souk has a main square and then off the square are warrens where getting lost is to be expected. I have enjoyed meandering through and getting completely lost. I have also, upon occasion, paid a child to help me get back to the square. If time is no obstacle the sights through some of the tiniest alleys are incredible. watching incredible craftsmen working in cramped and filthy condition and yet producing masterpieces.It is a true Aladdin's treasure trove of experience. In the evening enjoy grabbing some food from one of the makeshift restaurants. There are hundreds to choose from, mostly selling the same sort of food. I always choose the busier ones as it meant the food had a higher turnover and so would be fresher! It worked for me!! There is no alcohol sold in these stands, so be warned.At dusk, as the evening sets, it is well worth visiting one of the bars that have a roof terrace....again, note the many don't serve alcohol and that a drink is compulsory to gain access to the rook top. The views of the main tower of the mosque, the spectacular skies, the smoke rising from the food stands, and noise of drumming, singing and people is fabulous...if that is your kind of thing!

Great place to visit. This is a main highlight and a must see when in Marrakesh. Try the fresh juices and meats. Get your picture taken with the water carriers and watch the locals entertain with snake charming and dancing. If you don't like any of that, there is TONS of items to shop for.

Have fun shopping. Noise, smells, bargains and fun is what this is about. Have a drink in a roof top bar and enjoy the sunset over the souk. Aim for 50% of the price or as I do a price that you feel is fair. Enjoy the bartering game it's all part of the experience

Life in the Medina. This can be a very interesting place to be and lots of unique stuff going on, especially in the square at night. The soukh is a rabbit warren and it's easy to get lost, so try and remember where you've been and retrace your steps. Young men will offer to guide you but they will either take you to a relatives shop or say it's just around the corner (when it isn't) expecting payment and leave you just as lost as before. As with all Arab Souks you will find it hard to get out of a shop once you pause to look at something, but that's half the fun as is haggling.Jema el Fna is best at night. But you will be pestered.
