Women beware of women grabbing your hand and offering to put a Henna pattern on it. Pull your hand away immediately, Once they get some on, they want payment and can be quite aggressive and greedy about it. No matter that you didn't ask for it or agree. We saw several caught this way as was my wife.

A must when traveling to Marrakech. Get lost, it's the best thing you can do in the Medina! There is so much to discover, from visiting the old tannery to eating delicious Maroccan food to shopping! Enjoy!

Amazing. Take a guide - its vast and very very easy to get lost as its a complete maze but full of shops and restaurants and characters! if You can find it - try Dar Chafir for lunch - food is amazing!

Must see and stay. When you go to marrakesh stay in a road in medina. A lot to see from street artists, little ships, craftsmen, nice restaurants with great terras with a great view! Yes ne careful what you buy against what price.

A Must See. You must go to the main square if you are in Marrakech. The snake charmers, monkeys, and dancing are very interesting. Be prepared to be a walking ATM for the locals, you will be constantly harassed by the vendors. Also, stay away from the food vendors in the court, as they will serve you food at high prices that you did not order and demand payment. If they do not give you a menu with prices, walk away (and ask exactly what they bring to you to be sure you ordered it) - their prices are about double to triple what the inside restaurants are and the quality and portions are terrible. My suggestion, if everyone there is a tourist, do not go. The locals know which places are a rip off. We went to a restaurant with a terrace and had a better meal for less than half the price with better food.

DUMP. Apparently the Medina used to be full of snake charmers and other interesting attractions but now it is just a hellish place where you will be harassed constantly even if you repeat 'no, thanks' politely in French, Arabic and Elvish. If you engage you could end up buying their house.My friend was assaulted there for no reason, not even theft, by a Moroccan. She was whacked over her head extremely hard as we were all left watching the attacker causally walk away as we were trying to work out what had happened and if we still had all of our belongings.This is certainly not an attraction for solo or even a group of women. Despite being appropriately dressed including head coverings, the females were at war throughout in an attempt to avoid sleazy male attention.With a wider view, Marrakesh is an experience that not many people wish to experience more than once. Our entire group agreed that we could have done without experiencing it at all, and stuck to other areas of Morocco.

Nice from above.... Sat with a drink on one of the rooftop bars while the sunset, very pleasant experience.Then ventured to the square and was continuously hassled, grabbed and swore at from people selling oranges/food/henna/magnets etc. Not a nice experience...calmer during the day.

Amazing market but the haggling will wear you down. It is honestly feels like you have stepped back in time, where open market stalls openly sell artisan wares and local crafts. As a photographer, you will get numerous amounts of opportunity to catch colorful and amazing shots. However, upon closer inspection, some of the stalls are tourist traps. There are trinkets and jewelry hailing from Berber communities or authentic craftsmanship, and it turns out to be completely fake. For instance, I spotted a Spiderman ring at an 'authentic' jewelry store. Let the buyer beware.

awful. frightening and aggressive people will grab, push and separate you from your group/ partner. it seemed the older the couples, the less trouble they got. As a young couple in our early 20's we had nothing but hassle, trouble and abuse! Id never go back

Take a step back in time. The Medina encompasses the Souk and Jemaa el Fna. It is the heart of Marrakech. If you are seeing the sights of Marrakech, you will end up in the Medina. There is a lot of traffic and noise here, but so much to see. Don't miss this area.
Fantastic. I have visited Jama el Fna it is fantastic place and touristic area. it is good to see a different culture and traditional very old history and old houses RYADS and a lot to be seen.

A must-do in Marrakech. You can't visit Marrakech and not visit the square, preferably as the sun is going down and it is coming to life. Find one of the large cafes along the edge of the square and go up to their terrace for a birds-eye view of the chaos. Although we didn't eat at one of the many stalls in the middle of the square on this visit (too cold to sit still in the February evening), we have on previous visits and found it perfectly good value (and perfectly safe). The snake charmers and monkeys aren't to my taste and I prefer to give those things a wide berth. But there is a lot of life here in the square and you have to experience it, if only just the once.

Huge area - step back in time . The Medina area is the old city surrounded by walls , it's full of history and old buildings. Small lanes and roads many of which lead to dead ends - the cross roads are manned by men waiting for tourists to go down the wrong way and guiding them back for money - not good , dosnt feel safe in the evening - not somewhere for ladies on there own - still fascinating .

Loud and busy. We would recommend coming to the medina of Marrakech if you are into having a very noisy and don't mind pushing your way through the crowds, but thoroughly recommend on having a private guide

Beneficial to get that Arab feeling . We stayed inside the medina and although it became an issue looking for cash points and taxis it made us seek the good of Marrakesh and more. Staying inside the medina or visiting it is a must to experience the hospitality and openness of the Arab world.

The real Marrakech. it's a wild ride!. What a maelstrom of colour and noise!Hold on to your hats and bags. It's a crazy, vibrant place. But to be safe I would advise using a money belt with lots of low denomination currency. And stays on small groups. Particularly ladies. Locals are friendly and enthusiastic. It's not much different that other local spots around the world. It's just about being sensible.You'll be offered absolutely everything. And locals are persistent. I'd advise not to go into stalls unless you have a genuine interest in buying. Otherwise you many end up buying things you don't want! And get involved in bartering. Whatever you pay will be way more than the locals. So have a crack and get involved.What I liked was the opportunity to get immersed in local culture. It's fast passed and frantic! There's so much on offer you'll be able to find everything you want and more. And watch out for mopeds! Locals tear around on them. And they're nippy! I absolutely loved this experience. Morocco is a raw, friendly, eclectic, energetic place. It's a blast. Take the plunge.

The Marrakech and safety. Please fly to Marrakech city. the best safest city. there are many things people can see in this amazing Medina of Morocco.it is very exotic town to explore. also possible to buy most of the things once you walked around of the Souk,in the evening you get a feel of love with the city when you choose one of the restaurant roof and get your self a drink then you watch the smoking food of the Jemaa el fna square. is it's absolutely exquisite.

Wander and enjoy. This is the real heart of Morocco. Do feel free to wonder in the heart of Marrekesh. Within limits, the medina is very safe and open to all. There really is something for everyone. The souks are full of exotic stuff to buy and you should find something for everyone.
Once is enough. Despite all the hype, the Medina has little charm. Worth seeing once but the novelty soon wears off.
very good. medina of marrakech was a good place to visit in marrakech , you will iscover the daily life of local people .

Not for animal lovers!. The main square was really upsetting - monkeys in chains and nappies for tourist photos and snakes held like a bit of rope. We also walked past one stall, as the vendor was plucking this poor chicken who was still alive!! He then tied her wings behind her back and we walked on quickly as I didn't want to see her demise.We would have like to have bought more, but you were pestered so much by the vendors, we stopped browsing in the end. One bloke even followed us to a coffee shop and pulled up a chair at our table! We paid him to go away! Food is generally quite cheap there but we were told not to purchase from the market in case of upset tummies. The restaurants and cafes were nice, but the coffees were very small. The people were mainly nice but you just got fed up of them wanting your money all the time.

The Medina. Getting around this place can be very complicated especially around the main square and souks. There are hundreds of little alleyways and at every turn there is some young lad trying his best to guide you in the wrong direction and expecting a few quid in return. Best advice is just ignore them (although this is quite difficult to do) and look up there are signs up above your head most of the way round guiding you to various tourist areas and certainly the main square - so if you get lost simply follow these and start again!

Amazing place, full of diverse food, music, people. It is great to seat at one of the top balconies cafes and just admire the crazyness of the plaza, where so many people gather around for selling their products, foods, offering their services of painting henna ... etc. In the morning, the fresh orange juice was a perfect way to start my day and I will always recommend visiting Marrakech, it is very hot, very lovely and friendly.

The best placefor Good Food, Good Entertainment & Good Shopping. The place is really unique and you can spend almost half day doing a lot without getting bored, Authentic Moroccan Dishes, nice entertainment, good orange juice and after all theses you can visit the souk

Heart of Marrakech; Wonderful Experience. Very busy!!! that is the best way to describe it. so many stalls selling different kind of things even though half of the stalls are selling the same merchandise. There are also street performers, live music, dancing and your hustlers that don't take NO for an answer. It can be overwhelming so make sure you are aware of your belongings. Be firm and strong on your feet and be prepared to say 'NO THANK YOU' as you will get over 100 offers to buy somethingyou will likely get lost so wear comfortable shoes and have a bottle of water in hand. Also do not get offended very easily as sellers will say anything to get your attention especially if you are a female. There are lots of places to eat and drink from but again choose wisely do not get dragged easily. Find a restaurant with a roof terrace overlooking the Medina to relax and enjoy and witness amazing views and buzzing atmosphere

An experience never to be forgotten!. Lively,hectic,mind blowing! So much to see- from snake charmers to night life, places to eat and people watch.Watch out for those vendors though, as so many sell the same items and via for your attention to buy. Was followed by man wishing us to purchase a bag.He was very reluctant to take 'No' for answer. Can be exhausting but, all part of Marrakech.Enjoy
Exciting exhilarating! . Simply amazing chaotic colourful and beguilingly beautiful area of Marrakech , so much to see so many turns and corners each with s hidden gem !

The Man Who Knew Too Much (with Google Maps). We spent two weeks in a Riad just north of the Medina. I, Wife, and Daughter walked through length and breadth a couple of times. There are souks for tools that have row on row of hammer heads and pick axes. We had fried fish at a local stand with a few benches. Even with our limited French, we could get really local food. Hot oil kills germs, but we didn't have any problem even though we tried the sauces. Amazingly, Google maps on my iPhone with local SIM card worked in all the covered souks. Local touts kept trying to tell us we were going the wrong way, even though we were following an entourage of local women with their children. When I wandered around alone, the touts would ask, "Where are you going?" I answered, "Home," looked at my google map directions and walked off. There is so much to see there. You can get the feeling what markets were like a thousand years ago. I only took pictures of cats as I did not feel comfortable intruding on others privacy. These provide a sense of the Median atmosphere.

Almost magical place to visit, safe and friendly. It is very much like stepping into a bygone era, wandering round the medina, going thru the various souks is just great. There is no hassle, polite friendly banter, and if you do get lost folks will help you out. A must visit location.

Loved it. Our hotel (Maison MK) was in the heart of the Medina so it get to the square was a 5 minute walk. There are loads of restaurants, cafes, ice cream parlours, and market stalls selling all kinds of food and orange juiceThere are street acts, music, singing and loads of dancing. If you can find a restaurant with a roof terrace overlooking the square you have the best seat in the house. The Medina is a must see for the hustle and bustle alone. There is lovely food to be had and a great atmosphere to enjoy. We went there every night bar one for lunch and dinner and we had a great time. Would definitely recommend.

Overwheming. Hard to find, hustlers everywhere. Almost had my phone stolen the first and only time I took it out of my bag. A man tried to steal my bag. It's many souks of the same products, which made us not want to purchase anything. It was overwhelming for a person like me who is not used to saying a firm "NO THANK YOU". Which is a saying you will use hundreds of times a day in the medina. It is colorful and the energy is great. There are many things to see, the goods, the poverty, the way of life is all very interesting and is definitely worth a trip. I am glad to have seen it all, but it was also not as expected. I expected to spend a lot on gifts but ended up buying nothing. If you are a woman, dress as modestly as possible because you WILL get much unwanted attention. Wear comfortable shoes. You will get lost and likely walk hours more than anticipated. Many restaurants serve subpar food. Don't go to those who try to pull you in. We only had one good meal in three days, and although it was more than twice the price of the others, it still ended up being $22 for two. This was outside of the old city. If you must buy alcohol, go into the new city and there are many small shops. We happened upon many on accident. It was hard to "Google" where they were. If you are not shy, go to the stands where the locals buy the freshly cooked food. This is truly a unique experience but if you're like us and only get a vacation rarely, it is NOT a relaxing place to go. You will be walking a lot. You will be fighting off people who want your money. And when you think you've won, or you met someone genuinely nice, trying to show you someplace as they go their own (opposite) way, they will suddenly reappear in your face to point you again in the "right" direction. Don't be fooled. Never follow anyone's directions. They will tell you this special place is only open today, it is a lie. I wish I had known all of this prior to my visit.

Exciting, authentic Marrakech experience. Busy, crowded on a Sunday night, but in a good way. Friendly crowd, freindly venders. Wonderful area for photography. Some great local food choices. Keep your valuables to a minimum, leave your backpack at home / hotel.
great place to visit. it was a very great idea to visit medina of marrakech , interesting place , great walk ,local attraction

Intimidating at first.. The medina at night can seem very intimidating with everyone wanting you to eat at their stall, and give you a henna tattoo they can see, pushy. Just be firm and try to relax. The orange juice is amazing and worth going just for that at lest. During the day theres many different sights and performers.
just great. well, the medina of marrakech... is just a magical and fantastic place! I spent christmas in marrakech and it was just great!

Absolutely amazing. The medina especially the square are absolutely amazing especially after sunset with the Berber music groups, the food stalls, the souks. The atmosphere is amazing. We went there every evening. Just be mindful that there will be pickpockets operating in the area and also some of the entertainers will aggressively ask for money. Other than that, it is a very enjoyable experience.

Good experience. It's was a great place to walk around ,but be carful There are thousands of vendors trying to sell you everything.dont miss the sunset on the terasse cafe look at of the square and Koutoubia mosque .

A great expereince. We stayed in a small self catering riad in the back streets of the medina. We were met at an intersection and then guided on foot to the front door which we needed the first time. However, we soon found it easy to move around our little corner of the medina and enjoyed buying olives form the local stalls and bread from the boulangerie around the corner. Everyone was very pleasant (especially if you speak French rather than English!) We felt perfectly safe with a 12 & 14 year old. We ate in small restaurants away from the centre for most of the time and whilst there was not much choice on the menu it was authentic, cheap and good to eat.There was not nearly as much hassle in the souks as I had expected although you get passed from pillar to post and are expected to tip if you end up anywhere near the Tanneries ( which is a smelly experience!). We didn't enjoy the Jemaa El Fna sqauare though. You have to go though. But it is hassle by day and night. Monkeys on chains and water bearers I think are there for tourists by day time nowadays. By night, it is busier and perhaps more authentic but noisier and crowded. We ate quite happily though at one of the market stalls without incident....but just he once.

Something for everyone. A labyrinth of fascination - products and skills across the whole spectrum to entice you in. We were surprised by the outstanding quality of many of the items that are actually made within the Souks, with distinct areas for each product - carpets, silver, gems, locksmiths, shoes, handbags - you name it! Treat bartering with humor and you'll receive humour in return - very friendly for the most part and definitely to be enjoyed. If you don't get lost, you're not trying hard enough!

All roads lead to Fna.. Impossible not to visit, for the food,Souks and street entertainment day and night with views of the Koutubia mosque, the caleches also park there didn't go on one, look like a div.
wonderful place to visit. medina of marrakech is an amazing place to visit , interesting things to discover , local people , very interesting

nice hotel not wheelchair friendly. We booked this hotel because it was suppose to be wheelchair friendly--not so the ramps are like ski jumps --they were very steep my chair was tipping backwards-and you had to use them to get to the restaurant and pool--plus the are was not lit up-we had a word with the rep and he said we would have to stay there that night-but to be at his desk early next morning -my husband and a couple of the lads help me use the ramps for evening meal and breakfast-, The Thompson manageress was fantastic she was on the phone no messing and by 11am we were heading off to another hotel.
great place to visit. Was such a eye opener an so much going on .Loved the monkeys there was so much goin on something for everyone.

Thinking of the fantasies? That's what they are.. We stayed in a Riad in the medina for a week. Going out in the daytime and being out in the evening are totally different. Even though it was January the place was packed all the time. The main road through has pedestrians, cars, motor bikes and bicycles. Then there are the trades people with their donkey carts as well. It seems every motorized vehicle is badly tuned as you could see the blue oil air as you passed through two particularly tight passages. It made me nauseous if I didn't cover my nose. This is home to thousands of locals, add in all the tourists and it is crazy. We are really staunch anti shoppers and pretty much kept away from the sellers or "guides", unwanted but still wanting to be paid is they go any small distance with you. The tanneries, at least the small animal one we visited required a payoff to the "cousin" (insert relative type here), the tannery tour guide and the retail shop person where you are led. They do get huffy if you don't buy, but we only have a backpack and carry-on and just aren't buyers. The dyers market has no visibility to the actual dying process, retail only. We were offered a scarf for 700MAD which kept dropping until we finally left. The same scarf around the corner was being offered at 50MAD. We did enjoy watching the craftsmen working their metal, wood, leather and what have you. Watching the neighborhood baker rotate breads into and out of his huge oven was almost mesmerizing. Outside the walls on Thursday (but almost every day) is a market that people bring anything and everything to trying to make a few coins on. The average local makes about $8 a day. If you eat at a restaurant ask if the waiter can have the leftovers to take home, really. The animal acts are mostly in the square, not in the heart of the medina. Schools get out at noon and you really don't want to be just walking around then. It is real to the locals, they are trying to make the best deal for themselves at your expense. If you aren't interested in buying do not go into a stall. Do not make eye contact and if someone asks "where are you from" turn around and walk away. A couple of Arabic phrases I learned are: "La Choukran" (no thank you); "Khallini" (leave me alone) and with exclamation marks in your voice "Safi!" (Enough). Speaking in their language seems to work most often. We never felt unsafe and the souks are fascinating if you follow these tips.

Manic Marrakech Madina. The sites, sounds and smells of Marrakesh smack you in the face in the Medina. There are people literally everywhere, people selling things, snake charmers, men with monkeys ad beggars. You can here people shouting (Moroccans talk loudly), drums banging, horns blowing and drums banging. The fragrant amour of spices waft across the square along with the of occasional punch of horse wee and poo.TipsTry the orange juice (4 dirham ) it is literally the best juice I have ever tasted.Take a horse ride around the city - Haggle Negotiate the price of taxi's and horse ride you can get a taxi practically anywhere in Marrakesh for under 70 Dirham. Haggle if you are buying anything offer 1/3 of the price dont pay more than 1/2 Don't go to the tannery it stinks and they will try and rip you off (they tried to charge us 200 Dirhams) they will also take you into a leather or carpet shop and try to sell you stuff. Download the trip advisor app it great when trying to find stuff, you can use GPS without mobile data.
Mental. This is one place weve seen and done, Its mental. Such noise when you walk into square, Only upsetting thing was seeing Monkies chained up to have their pictures taken. Very poor!
Beautiful. This is a must to visit! Loved walking through all of this and seeing all the people. Such a great time!
Huge Medina with a lot to see and buy. This is the second time I'm in Marrakech and to walk around in the Medina and the souks and get lost is one of my favorites. So much impressions.

An experience. This is something that everyone who visits Marrakech must experience, however it can be overwhelming. We had a large group so it was easier for us, but I would not travel into the market on my own. You will be approached continuously by people wanting to either sell you something or help give you directions (for a price). They are very pushy and you have to be persistent to get them to leave you alone. We witnessed people turning back and leaving certain areas due to harassment. Like I said it is something everyone should experience, just be careful.

I felt like in a Indiana Jones Movie!!. Amazing place. Good to pratice your trade habilites with local dealers, have a good mint tea or just watch snake charmers. Take care about your cell phones, digital cameras and money, not so much, just take care! Try to enjoy it two times in a day and in differente hours. Tell this because you will see a lot of changes in the atmosphere of the place and options to trade and eat! Take care abou things you eat and just drink water from botlle you may had bought on supermarkets.

Just so absorbing!. Be wary, but feel safe! Very crowded especially later in day when there are probably more pick pockets about. Watch and take photos from one of the roof top cafes. Do not take pics of all activities going on when in the square or you will be charged! so much to see, hear and experience, like a fair ground / festival every day. Felt safe with 2 teenage daughters, 15 and 17...
Amazing old world charm. The Medina is a beautiful architecture in Marrakech which adds to the grandeur and heritage of the city ,looks gorgeous

If You Like Busy This Is The Place. Marrakech Medina is the heart of the City and contained within the old walls. It is a deceptively large area and is made up mainly of Souks, Gardens, Mosques and Ruined Palaces. The central square Jemaa El Fna is mainly for the tourist where, Snake Charmers, Fortune Tellers and Men with Monkeys spend the day trying to convince you that you should part with some of your money!! This is the daytime adventure. After dark a multitude of food stalls appear which are cheap and, in our experience containing wholesome dishes. This place can become somewhat overpowering. Our visit was in February 2016 when it is not supposed to be at its busiest.

Marrakech, not what I remember. I first visited Marrakech in 2008 and was mesmerized by the colourful markets, labyrinth style back alleys, energetic shopkeepers and the magic of the Djemaa el-Fna where African and Arabian traders have converged for centuries. No matter how hard you tried you just could not take a bad photograph.I ventured back this year and whilst the city still held its romantic appeal, it left me with a bad taste in my mouth. It seems everyone wants a piece of you, there seems to be a glut of faux guides coaxing you to part with your money to surreptitiously get you around the Medina. And if you're a woman, good luck with the constant hassle and attention. It has got a lot dirtier and people seem to care less (I witnessed defecating by the city walls). The traffic has also greatly increased and the congestion and pollution with it. Crossing the road will add a few grey hairs. For some reason the Medina is now full of scooters who wiz past with no care for pedestrians, even my mother was clipped by one. Many taxis will rip you off and if you book a tour for 8am, don't expect to pick you up before 10am! And those photographs? Well now just be prepared to part with some cash (again) as people just appear demanding payment for you having taken their photo (even if you didn't!). Speaking to the Riad owner (now many of these Riad's are an oasis of calm and truly beautiful in design and comfort), he told me he's selling up as Marrakech is going down the plughole since the recession and there is an air of desperation around the city. Then there's always the terrorist threat at the back of your mind (Egypt and Tunisia still fresh in the memory). Yet many visitors tend to forget that the main square In Marrakech itself was attacked as recently as 2011 with many of these restaurants today having airport style security measures to get in. The Djemaa el-Fna is still amazing but be prepared to see chained monkeys, snakes and other forms of animal cruelty. As for souvenirs are you seriously going to use a tagine back home or for that matter wear yellow leather babouches around the house? For good food many of the Western restaurants are over priced and the local cuisine, whilst a pleasant change at first gets a bit samey. As for getting alcohol in the old city, this was an Indiana Jones style quest in itself. For the foreigner there's an unsettling air in the city, gone is the exotic Marrakech of wonder, intoxication and sensory overload. Sure it's an emerging country, but I have been to plenty in my travels and ones as diverse as Colombia, Brazil, India, Vietnam, Nicaragua, Belarus and more. I get the appreciation of different cultures and am all for new enlightened experiences. So what was the difference between these countries and Morocco? Simple; politeness, friendliness, respect and safety.

Disgusting. If you like being harassed constantly by hawkers, having to argue every single price, being abused because your offer is nearer the real price, being sneered at because you don't buy something at an inflated price, having your GF leered at, drinking diluted orange juice, watch unfortunate animals being mistreated, your path blocked by restaurant staff at night being told to pay for taking any photos anywhere near a snake charmer....then this is for you.The crush of people. The noise, the drumming, the horrible sound of the flute like instrument which does become invasive after a couple of hours and it goes on all afternoon and night. How many "charmers" (what a misnomer for these guys) are there....for sure tens of them. I saw an unfortunate monkey being used as a football by a thug who had it on a lead. Yes. He literally constantly kicked it up into the air because the monkey was slow. The squeals from this poor animal would wrench your heart. The downtrodden donkeys, heads bowed and with terrible bleeding cuts to their forelocks and backs from far too heavy loads. The numerous snakes in a totally unnatural environment.Very nice? No we found it disgusting and would never go back. It has lost any charm it ever may have had.
Good Market. Good market. Lots to see and buy. Be careful asking directions as they will insist on showing you which will cost you.
An experience. Take a look around then find a good restaurant for a meal and watch the excitement unfold, with late afternoon the most interesting

Lot of fun shopping and haggling. There is so much energy here that you can't tell what you will see around every corner. People can be a little pushy, but as long as you are polite, you should be fine

Expect to get lost. This is not for the faint hearted we tried to make our way from the main market up to the Ben Youssef Medersa but got very lost and had to take a taxi. The markets are fascinating but expect to be constantly bothered I travelled with a girlfriend but would have less hassle with a male companion. We managed to find our way back we followed signs and the sun. It is an amazing place and yes you really do have to haggle. Best advise decide what you are willing to pay and then walk away if you don't get the price you want.

Frantic but fun. Chaotic but much less so than a few years ago with the tradespeople even more aggressive in their pursuit of sales. Hold your nerve and aim to pay no more than a third of the original asking price and check you're getting quality. There's a lot of tat.
full life. everything in this medina was amazing and so cute , we really enjoyed our time there , amazing and interesting , we really liked it

Birthday treat. Wow just amazing ! Something new every turn you take, the main square Jemaa El -Fna is an experience and must be visited again at night. Tha El Badi Palace is incredible with great views of white storks. It's worth allowing plenty of time to discover Marrakech Medina on foot to get the complete experience.
Amazing colours. Amazing colours and smells surrounding you, very easy to get lost though as all the streets look very similar

Madness!. Traffic is madness, you constantly get harassed by men that want you to buy something, and yet it's one of the planet's most vibrant places. Visit Jemaa el Fna at night time, say no to street vendors if you don't want to buy something, and immerse yourself in a world you probably don't know and will never fully get.

amazing. lost our way here so many times, got misleading directions without asking for any, found excellent deals and practiced bargaining methods, sipped refreshing juices or teas in tiny cafes, I would do this over and over again!

An incredible place with snake charmers and all!!!!. This incredible meeting place or Medina is the centre of everything in Marrakech. During the day it is filled with markets selling everything from spices, to haircuts and shaves. In the night the restaurants set up and it is quite incredible the foods they serve. We didn't eat there, but we purchased spices and some souvenirs.

The red city . Amazing medina - the first one i saw. Loud and noisy, busy and - so interesting! Buy spices or cakes, eat tagine or buy a pair of shoes - but never take the first price - better devide it with 2 or 3 before buying haha. People are used to tourists especially in the medina so you find tons of stuff. Across the path to the hotel essaouira near djemaa El Fna was a small pottery with a really humble and calm artist with reasonable prices. Can recommend this shop since he let you browse through this 3 sqm room that he calls is shop stuffed with beautiful plates and stuff. He wont even try to lur you back in when you decide to not buy anything at all. Really quite and peaceful and such a nice and humble character. Deeper in the medina/ souks be aware that these kids hanging around the corners (where you going? You know the tannerys? No? I can show you its on my way - really) get paid for bringing you to the tannerys (not directly because luckily there is a random being who can take us the rest of the way since he has to go left now - yeah right) where you get talked into a "tour" aka look-around-the-place and when finished they force you to pay way too much. One girl accompaning us was so brave and stood up against that. We got tricked into the tour which started off as a free look around and all of the sudden the guy wanted money for showing us (i mean at a certain point we knew he would want something for letting us in the tannery - but i doubt that he actually owned it or so - but he really began to act aggressivly). Money for himself and the other people who led us there (its really not that obvious in the beginning but after a while you sense there is something going on... ) So this girl just kept saying that he told us its free and even when he got kind of purpelish while arguing with her and us intensly she did not let them scare her. More men came and argued and tried to convince her and us to pay more. He looked so angry the situation became really uncomfortable and me and my sister just paid 40 dh together and just wanted to leave. You know at a certain point its just enough.. But when he turned to this other girl - we met at our hostel and who explored the city with us together - with his hand still ready to collect more money she really stood up for herself and told him that she works in the tourist industry and that his behaviour is just so bad-mannered she never experienced it before. We really felt kind of weak for paying him. She was so brave and all. So we told him that he should tell people before the tour so people know what to expect and are able to choose if they want a "guided tour" or not. In the end he just send us away, still angry but kind of - i dont know - understanding (?!), too, and so we left and we were just glad we got out of there. Akward... but the "tour" itself (us walking around the tannery) talking to some of the workers, etc. was really informative and interesting. Just be aware of that. And enjoy Marrakesh - this is just a not-so-nice but not dangerous travel story. Most people are good. Some a bit annoying ... but not bad :)

Marrakech life at its best. The medina is everything you expect of Morocco. The madness of the souk and its associated negotiations to get that knock down price as well as quiet Riad which are the oasis amongst the madness. Be wary of taking photos of people in the square as they will doubtless ask fo a fee. Some fine restaurants to be found...do some research!

Amazing. What a combination. Shop, architecture, history, snake charmers, amateur dentists.... It is all here. Go in and mix it up, see the tanneries (hold your breath), hit the souks, visit the Jmaa el Fna and hold a cobra.
Beautiful atmosphere. I could walk for hours ( which I ended up doing) such a lovely place. We wasn't accosted much during our browsing.
very hectic and not cheap. it is a place you have to see to say you have been there,but you have to be able to take a bit of hassle, it is a bit of an eye opener,best to have a guide.
nice medina ,. medina of marrakech as amazing place to see how locals people live , daily life , we really enjoyed it

Good people watching. Fun at night when all the stalls are smoking with assorted grilled meats and veggies. We ate at a stall where it looked like locals dominated but I was fairly disappointed with the food. Not much seasoning and I had to ask for salt which surprised me as Moroccan food is known for the complex spice combinations. I had sanitizer with me as I had read the plates and cutlery are only rinsed. Well, its not really hygienic but its interesting. I didn't really like the monkeys or snake charmers but its bustling and great people watching.

Not for the Faint Hearted. This place was everything I hoped it wouldn't be. From the horse kalesh's lining the approach avenue which absolutely wreaked of horse urine to the poor animals being bartered for our pleasure. Several coiled snakes on the ground, Kids begging everywhere, Barbary monkey's on leads wearing nappies? what's all that about. The whole atmosphere, all be it very different to us felt really quite intimidating with food stall holders almost fighting each other for your business. Groups of mainly men in huddles around some entertainer or other making it impossible to see anything. Full credit to the tourist police they are obviously revered, as when one approached everyone scattered back to their stalls etc. One of them told me that if they are arrested they spend 2 days in a nasty jail.The sad thing about it all is, the sounds, sights and smells of this square are mind blowing and I can imagine that several decades ago it was a wonderful experience. Unfortunately the uncertain world we live in now had the opposite effect on us. I would suggest you go with an organised trip then you wont feel as isolated.
Marrakesch. Loved Marrakesch. Most beautiful city. Felt almost like home. Enjoyed the combination of old traditional culture and modern city life.
Just my vibe. Lots of peolle to kingle with, cgat to, watch, be careful of, but all in all a fun place to be. Love the atmosphere and people
interesting place. we visited Medina of marrakech and it was amazing and interesting palce , we enjoyed walking through it
Busy Bazar. Lots to see and do here. Lots of food stalls and cafes. If you get a chance get a seat in Cafe France and watch the sunset behind the mosque.

The famous areas of Marrakesh.. This was my favorite park of Marrakesh. You are in the middle of it, you can walk for hours. I honestly felt safe the whole time, but I did always keep an eye on my things and had everything close to me and closed. Just be smart and you will be fine. You will get to see all kinds of things to be sold here. If you are interested in anything, ask the price... they will always give you a crazy high one. You say no. They they will drop it or say how much do you want to pay. Say honestly what you are willing to pay, and then they will say no. When that happens say oh well, no thank you and start walking away. You will see the price drop like crazy until you hear the price you want. Best of luck.
Tourist Trap. Too many tourists. Better go to the medina in Fes of Essaouira. Marrakech is too much of a hype nowadays
Beware. The place is very crowded. Loads of places to eat. Just be aware of the seller. Don't fall into their tactics easily.

Hussle, hussle, hussle. You can buy anything and everything here but expect everyone to try and rip you off. Be VERY careful about anyone approaching you and telling you that they saw you in the hotel restaurant (they work there---right!) and are so very nice to show you around the Medina. They then bring you to their friends place where they get a commission. They are illegal guides and they are dishonest. Walk away if you are approached.

Cheap but be careful. Nice place, traditional! Not impressed about people which they not only trying to steal from you pocket but also on prices just because you are comming from abroad! We went there twice , first time on evening time which to be honest scared me a lot . That place everywhere you looking people sorrounding you to try to steal your bag , walet or phone. Day time is not that scary ( only the people with snakes which they comming to put them on you just to pay for a photo) but still be careful and watch out your pockets. Overwall to many stuff to negociate for them, more cheap then in other shops from central city.Thanks

such a rip off!. it is so difficult to avoid being ripped off, the Moroccans are so persistent that no matter how much we were warned we sometimes ended up buying things to get away from them. We enjoyed sitting in the rooftop terrace cafes looking down on jemaa el fna and eating at the stalls in the evening, but would have enjoyed wandering about the souks so much more if we could have done it with less hassle. The main thing to warn other people about is bag snatching - a man on a motorbike slashed my bag strap and drove off with my bag and its entire contents - this was nearly 9pm in the evening, on one of the roads near the medina wall not far from our riad, so always be on the look out. never drop your guard, and now I would never carry my valuables around in a handbag, I will always keep everything well hidden under my clothes.

Crazy and wonderful!. Prepare to be eaten up and spat out by the greatest theatre show on earth. Character everywhere, everyone trying to swizzle and lure you into their world. Best orange juice (and still cheap), watch out for unbelievably good salesmen and women - you will walk away with stuff you didn't even want they are so persistent and charming. Only a few aggressive snake charmers and musicians who seem to think looking requires payment. But I guess this is how they make their living....Marrakech, you are marvellous.

A colourful labyrinth. The narrow streets lined with colourful shops selling , spices scarves , leather and beautiful Moroccan lamps / jewlers / teapots etc and stalls selling fruit / dates / nuts etc nestle amongst butchers shops and bakeries dotted with little cafés and restaurants - scooters and bicycles and the odd mule and cart share these narrow spaces - so beware and look behind you - out of the hot sun it's fabulous to wander around but do take note of shop signs street names and landmarks so you don't get lost - my tip is to stay where it's colourful and busy and if you get list ask a shop keeper - a random will walk fast as you follow and then charge you - for the pleasure :) 158 moussaine chez Fatima is a tiny little shop where I had a beautiful bag made for me as I didn't want leather - gave her all the measurements and it's going to last me for years - tell her Helen the English woman she made the bag for sent you !! Enjoy it's crazy but amazing

SEE THIS IN YOUR LIFETIME. We travel. A LOT. And of all the places we've experienced, this may well be at the top. Colors. Flavors. Kindness. Richness. Aromas. Beauty. Culture. Surreal surrounds. Movie-setting-like at every turn. I am SO thankful we had a chance to see this place, and hope we get to visit again soon!

A must to visit, both day and night. By day the square is filled with orange juice stalls, date, nuts and dried fruit stalls, snake charmers, monkeys, henna tattooists. The orange juice is delicious. But by night the atmosphere is notched up big time. The square becomes one big outdoor restaurant. The atmosphere is alive with cooking, eating, sweet trolleys, people....barbecued meats, couscous, eggs, snails, mutton, all cooked for you....quite delicious.

Great Trip in past but to annoying sometimes..... once in life of course is nice to visit such a place but at some point if you stay over 3 days there it will become annoying ... at least my personal experience is not always great. if you are chill out person I wont recommend more than 2 nights such a shaky atmosphere. but if you are instead you will love it... until you will reach your limit of tolerance of not barging anymore for products and prices :))

Lovely place to meander. It's a great place to walk around for hours. Ignore the persons trying to sell you everything and all will be good. If you look at anything for more than 3 minutes you'll have to bargain and buy :)
nice medina. we had visited this medina and we explored the culture of morocco , so you can see and share life with local people

Fascinating, lively, SO much hustle and bustle!. The Medina of Marrakech is basically a huge open-air carnival of people, scents, sounds and the most interesting shopping you can imagine. There must be thousands of vendors hawking everything from carpets to shoes, to handicrafts to spices. You must enjoy and be good at bargaining. Whatever price you are given by a vendor for a particular item, pay no more than one-third of it. Be willing to walk away if you don,t get the price you want as there are many, many vendors selling the same thing.

An interesting experience . A great place to wander and shop but try to look and act confident. If you don't you will have people telling you places are closed and sending you around in circles or to their families shops or charging very high prices! All part of the experience ao don't let it get to you! !
Marrakech Medina. It was exciting full of life food and fun! Could have stayed another 2 days if our money did not run out!! Most places do not take credit cards!

If you don't have balls, stay away :)!. This was some experience for us. As a couple, they want to sell you anything and it was very stresfull. On other hand, this was one time experience that I liked because you need to be strong to resiste to not punch someone in this small streets. If you don't have a good map or very good gps, stay only in Jamaa El Fnaa. I loved this place, but my wife I think will never return in a place like this :)!

A Bit Overwhelming. The medina was great, but after having visited Rabat and Fez and their medinas, Marrakesh was more of the same. We were harassed by young men trying to provide a tour, which we repeatedly refused, but they kept following us. Also, while the medina was quite large, it was the same stuff over and over...
the best in morocco. i think that marrakech is the best city in morocco because it has good weather and typique monuments to visite .
An experience. You have to give it a go.. It's busy and bustling with lots of different people...haggle and you may get yourself a bargain
magic place ,. medina of marrakech was full magic and so amazing especially in the night , we have a great moments there , it was so nice
Wonderful Place to Sightsee. Touring all the sights, buildings, souks and alleys in the old medina is an unforgettable experience. A must see for everyone to explore

Three nights inside the Medina. We spent three nights inside the Medina, visiting several cafes, restaurants, but mostly just experiencing people:)
It was just the chaos of sounds, visual impressions and smell I expected:)

Can be overwhelming. Some part of the Medina are better (western) the eastern side, less travelled by tourists can become overwhelming. Not suitable for big group of young family. Can be dangerous with the reckless locals motorbikes riding. Polution from bikes is intense. Maze of medieval street, showing life as it is in Marrakesh. Piece of Advise, politely ignore the constant solication from Morrocan people, get a good GPS app on your phone, don't ask for help of direction, avoid streets that seem a great idea for a shortcut, stay on the main street with shop opened
A Smorgasbord of life!. Marrakech is an amazing vibrant and thriving city, which when asked to describe it by friends I can only use one word, "Bonkers"!. One place I will never ever forget!

Exciting Square in Marrakech. Fantastic medina great place to visit, exiting atmosphere, great street food, soft drinks, gift carts and shops, music, cafés and restaurants. Visited in January was quite busy during the day and very busy at night. Horse cart rides nearby, be sure to check the price, the journey - new town/old town etc,., half hour or hour with the driver as well as the person standing near the horses, otherwise this can change once you are in the cart. Enjoy the bartering and get the best price you can. Be very aware of pick pockets especially when watching the music or dancing and looking at stalls, just the same as you would in any City. Always check whether prices quoted are sterling, dirhams or euros or other currency, as there is a big difference between them. Sit at at terrace of cafe a enjoy the buzz going on around the medina, while you relax.
nice red city. My first time in Marrakesh ,i was surprised to discover this old Moroccan city, the Medina was really nice with the red color.

Great experience. Everyone needs to experience life in Medina. For beginners please watch out for snakes and monkeys "owners" after you touch the animals they shout prices in thousands - don't get fooled
A warren of winding alleys. So much fun to wander the alleys and streets, a surprise around every corner, great cafes and a sozen little squares

Great place for shopping, sight seeing & staying. The Medina of Marrakech is a UNESCO Worl Heritage Site, one can easily spend a whole day here and still come back for more. Find below our day spend at Medina - We had stayed over at Riad Andalla in the Medina, right next to the Jemaa el Fna - the central square and the epicenter of the madness. There are many tourist attractions to visit, the major one beings - Ben Youssef Madrasa, Museum of Marrakesh & Maison de la Photographie at one end meaning within 3 minutes of each other. 15 to 20 minutes away on the other side is the Bahia Palace, El Badi Palace, Saadian Tombs & the Kasbah Mosque. All these sites can be covered under four hours. Had our lunch in one of the road side cafes at Jemaa el Fna, with dessert from one of the pastries shops. Some how we never enjoyed the Moroccan dishes in these cafes, what we did enjoy was the shawarmas & doner kebabs. Next we explored the Medina with the agenda of shopping, there are great bargains to be had here. The prices differ drastically from shops to shops, the deeper you go into the Medina the cheaper the goods will become. For best prices, try to buy goods from the shops targeting the locals, most are away from the main square. I bought earrings for 10 MAD, medium size knifes for 200 to 300 MAD, medium size metal worked ceramic plates at 100 Mad. After dropping our goodies at the Riad, we went for a superb Hammam/Message at Isis Spa. The Hammam was a first time unique experience, the message among the best i have ever had. By now it was evening and we hit Jemaa el Fna to experience the atmosphere of the place. The Medina besides being a tourist attraction is actually meant for the locals. Those living nearby come here to shop & for other services like medicine (saw this awesome Berber medicine shop, refer my pic). In the evenings Jemaa el Fna is the entertainment destination for the locals,the performances are in Moroccan language and the local drink it all up. Everyone who comes to Marrakech will land up in Medina, my suggestion is stay in the Medina if you are in town for just a day or two but if you plan a longer stay look at Gueliz for bigger & better rooms at lower prizes.
Magical. Medina at night is the most magical place I've been....book a table at a restaurant on the medina and watch the hustle and bustle of Marrakech....loved it

An experience. You have to go to the Medina after sunset to see the pure level of activity and vibe of the place. There are so many things going on that you can easily spend a couple of hours looking at the different stalls and market traders. Do not take photographs unless you want to pay for the privilege (they are eagle eyed and quite aggressive with getting some money from you). They also try to put things in your hands saying 'no money' but then they ask for money. I tried to avoid the henna ladies it is really difficult and had a really bad 'drawing' on my hand because she was so insistent - and I am allergic to the henna! Apparently some of the snakes are stuffed but you only find out when you have paid to take a photo. It is really worth going to have a look but know that you will probably need to take lots of small coins with you and keep your hands in your pockets.

Strength in numbers!. I visited the medina with my friend and friends that we met at the hotel, which I was glad for. The sheer number of people dancing and taking part were enormous! Do not get caught taking photos of the goings on unless you are willing to donate a fee for the photo. Worth the experience, but I would not have gone to medina alone

Wow.. Recently spent a week visiting this place. So glad we did. So much to see and do. A perfect assault on your senses. The people who live and work here amaze me. So keen to find a way to make a living. Remember to always be polite and they will be polite back. Manners cost nothing and build bridges. Had a fabulous time.

busy and chaotic, but fun. The Medina is like no other. It has a lot of energy and the vendors can be quite aggressive, especially in the open air food courts. The men hassle you the whole time to eat at their place. The other shopping vendors can be insulting if you don't buy from them. It gets annoying after awhile but if you have thick skin you will be fine. i went a handful of times and it got easier as i knew how to deal with them. and i also knew exactly where i wanted to go. I would go back now that i know my way around.

If you travelled to Marrakech.... This is what you came for. It will be what you expected, a sensory overload, both day and night. You can see more during the day, doesn't come to life until late morning though. At night the square comes to life so go through the souks in the afternoon, snacking as you wish get to the square early evening, while the snakes are still visible and get your bearings. Once dark enjoy the music and dancing.You obviously have to be careful. Do not make your first visit at night! The local maps and signs are next to useless. Consider a proper guide if you are not used to this type of thing. I am well travelled and the Medina streets are confusing with no view to get bearings on anything. You cannot travel in straight lines and all streets look the same.Most locals are friendly and helpful, though still trying to make money. However away from the square there is organised crime where young boys and teenagers are used to catch your attention, distract you, offer to show you somewhere and take you nowhere and then charge you. You will pick up the tell tale signs and words. They will have an elder 'minder' somewhere around who will appear when you tell him to get lost, often on a small motorbike.

The Madness of Marrakech. Everyone heading to Marrakech will end up in the Medina at some point and it often feels as though they are all there at the same time. This organised chaos takes a bit of getting used to but that's part of the appeal of the place. It's different from anything else I've ever seen or experienced and was thoroughly enjoyable despite the constant pressure to buy from the traders.
wow what a fab buzzing place. words cannot do this place justiceits a collaboration of sites smells and colorsWhat a magical placeonly down side is the constant haggling for anything

Very rich in culture. The medina of marrakesh has done very well to preserve its original culture and way of life which can be seen when you enter the old city or medina as it is known as, a very interesting area with old architecture, markets and also great places to eat
Exciting. Make sure you haggle do not be intimitated.So much to see and buy. Shop keepers are mostly friendly but only haggle if you mean to buy.

HUGE! Watch out for bikes........ You could easily be run over if you're not watching your back at all times for motos. Always stay to the side! The medina is very large and can be confusing to navigate.... so pay careful attention which way you came! Very colorful, lots of photo opportunities!!! Wear comfortable walking shoes and don't ask people for directions or they will charge you. Also be sneaky when taking pictures/videos..... you may be demanded to give a few dollars if you're caught.
Busy,...noisy. Fantastic place, busy, fun, noisy,....so much to see,...friendly too.Some nice places to eat too, and not expensive at all.

A huge space full of shops and restaurants. I went to this madina twice and managed to return to my hostel in spite of the maze like area. It is full of shops selling clothes, dry fruits and other items. I enjoyed window shopping and picking up a few trinkets. Well worth a visit.

An experience not to be missed//No matter how careful you might get short changed. The medina has loads of souks, amazing colours and smells and sounds. Scooters and bikes whisking about. Watch out for plastic sandals masquerading as cow leather. Don't walk into a shop/stall unless you plan to buy and don't start haggling unless you are interested in buying.Know how much your notes are worth. Halfing something that is overpriced and poor quality, might not be a bargain. You are a tourist they see you as fair game and a laugh. They are traders some with very little money. Be respectful but firm, La shukran..........no thanks if you do not want to buy. Or just walk straight ahead and do not respond when asked where you are from and other quips. Give yourself time before buying and say you will look around. Or do like one lady we bumped into, know how much you think is fair to pay and say this is your final offer.............dm. Watch aragan oil, might be cut with olive oil but who knows. Enjoy your shopping and don't be worried about getting done ...........you will. We bought one stamp from stall outside Post office in square (as post office closed) 20 dm. Went back to get stamps from Post office next day, same stamp 9 dm!! Not everyone is trying to do you but be cautious.
A little nice place . It was nice but there are not much to do, just normal, just make a visit of 1 hour or less. Then go to discover another new place
Eating out. The atmosphere at the Medina was amazing. Music playing snakes dancing (but i did not look) and monkeys and donkeys and tut tuts all around and people selling their bits and pieces

A crazy old place!. A must do if your visiting Marrakesh! A whirlwind away from what we in the UK are used to... Nothing has price tags so get your game face on and get bartering! Be prepared to be firm with some locals as they can be persistant. Amazing smells, souks and preformers with every turn of the head. If it all gets too much, get yourself in one of the many cafe's for a lovely refreshing mint tea and a yummy tagine! Must of had six in three days! soooooo good!

Very Mixed Feelings it's a Facinating Place but felt very Intimidating. The medina is the very heart of Marrakech and one that I was looking forward to exploring. I visited the Medina twice and had two very different experiences. On the first trip I was shown around by a registered tour guide and I loved it and found it utterly fascinating. One minute there was sensory overload with the sights and the sounds and the next we were exploring quiet alleyways and side streets. The second time I went on my own and found the entire experience intimidating. The crowds and shop keepers banter I could cope with. However as a single female traveller in her mid 40s who dressed very modestly so only my hands and head were uncovered and wearing sun glasses to avoid eye contact, I didn't expect the level of male attention I received. When I was in the Kasbah I got lost looking for El Badi Palace and ended up in a quiet residential street, a man shouted out to me that the road ahead was closed. I ignored me and continued and he followed me for 3 - 4 minutes until I realised that the street was a cul de sac. When I turned back I realise me was waiting for me. I don't know he wanted, I assumed money to show me the way back to the main street, but I found the thought of being followed down an empty street very frightening and intimidating. I tried to kept my wits about me although I felt scared and then I saw a door opening and a woman and her child coming out. So I started to shout at the man to stop following me and to leave me alone and he left. From that experience I realise that I needed to stay on the main streets where other people were about.I eventually found my way out and then made my way to the souks. As I walked around I ignored the shop keepers banter but as I continued walking I arrived at a busy area filled with local people. As I walked along although the street was crowded disrespectful, sexist comments were shouted at me by young men. This went on until I managed to get myself back to the main tourist area by this time I'd had enough. I felt worn out with the verbal battering and I decided I wouldn't visit the medina again.

Mad. Never have i seen a place this hectic before
So much to see and so much is happening
5 star place to see

Very crowded but an Experience. The medina was definitely an experience!
Watch out for pickpocketers and expect the local to pester you to buy things.
We did enjoy our time there but found it quite overwhelming especially at night time.

Lively city where local craftsmen make the goods that they sell.. Lively city where local craftsmen make the goods that they sell. Leather, wood and metal crafts are on display among food markets selling fruit, veggies, meat and bread.
evening. It was a beautiful sight with very clean buildings, the streets were kept clean odertlich. Weather ar also very nice.

Madness!. A total assault on the senses! Briliant, but really hassley with people trying to get you to buy. If you are not a fan of performing animals, then give the snake charmers & monkey handlers a miss, but keep your eye open for a water seller, they look amazing!
nice place. this place was a good place , and we had some great time there ,even there is a lot of noise , it's worth a visit
Lots of Souks. Many Souks each specialized on its own product. A lot o people and salesmen all together. A unique life within the Medina. One must and should go there.

Lost for 4 hours..... Our guide offered us a tour we could get your bearings in and out of the metropolitan Kasbah and Medina. We chose to find our own way as I've never got lost before in any cities which include, Delhi, Mumbai, Moscow, Paris, Madrid and Rome. My magnetic compass memory would suffice, so I thought! My wife Allyson laughing at my ego! Well on our final day, I got cocky; we decided to just go for a walk into the centre of the Kasbah and Medina, my confidence was high! Four hours later and a few Dirhams lighter, we eventually found our bearings to get back on track! Luckily enough we got taken to The Tazir Hotel, which thankfully is the only bar in the old town that sells beer ;-) at a cost of 35 Dirhams for a small bottle of Heineken, but who cares? After the ordeal of me getting us well and truly lost on a road to nowhere the beer was worth the price! Mo sells wine back at the Riad El Farah, which for about £10 per bottle is reasonable, rather than the stress of bartering in the Zouks. Alcohol is banned in the Old Town due to respect for the Arab religion.

Lively Entertaining Square. A must see in Marrakesh is the central square, It will keep you amused seeing all the Hawkers and shops competing for your custom.It's certainly a noisey real experience with massive crowds on Friday and Sunday evening.If you like street food the square has about 60 kitchens which only open in the evening.
Explore.. A maze of very old building and souks. Well worth searching out the main places to visit. Beware of the monkey handlers and the snake charmers.....all photos cost.
great Place. Medina of marrakech is one of the most beautiful places in morocco , we had a great time in this place , we really enjoyed it

Hectic Medina of Marrakech. This is the old part of the city, so as you walk through the streets you feel transported back in time. However although the history of it is beautiful for me, the frenzied activity of it all was a little too much, however in the day time it was much different to the night time.

fab medina. large, and lots of fun. A great place to pick up a bargain too (best place we found in the country), if you know how to barter (my wife cuts their profits to the bone). We both felt very safe here, but many say to beware of pickpockets!

Sights and smells straight from ancient history. It's great for one to experience places like this in a lifetime but do be prepared for things that you'll only see in a James Bond movie.Baskets, snake charmers, monkeys on chains and hundreds and hundreds of vendors trying to persuade you that their collection of homemade bric-a-brac is better than the next row along.It's exciting and at the same time a little bit scary in places. If you don't like tight space you can stick to the main square right in the centre of the old town but if you go down through the maze of streets you'll see things for sale straight from fairy tales. Oh and things for sale that you think.... why? for example the guy selling an array of dentures and real teeth, yep... a teeth guy.The vendors are just doing their job by pestering you to come and look at their stuff so go in with an open mind. If you don't like pushy sales people, simply don't go, you'll hate it.Be VERY CAREFUL of motorcycles. They speed through the streets in narrow lanes so you need to be constantly alert and move out of their way quite quickly. I don;t mean just a couple in a day, I mean at least two or three every minute will pass you in narrow streets. Again, if you have little or no tolerance to dangerous driving, don't go.Haggling is part of the fun here but there's no hard and fast rules to getting a good price, just be courteous but not too dumb looking, don't be rude and do shop around. That's easier said than done when you want to move on, the vendor will do anything to keep you there so that's your time to get his lowest price.If you look rich and have big gold rings and a 2000 dollar camera around your neck, you can bet you'll pay double the price of the next guy so play the game and have fun..... just think of the Life Of Brian movie ..... "You're supposed to haggle...."You will get lost and people will try and help you find your way around but just politely and repeatedly say something like "I'm not buying anything, I'm just looking around"Also remember you're under no obligation to give money to anyone for anything you don't want so have fun looking if that's what you want to do.
Never again . Dirty, unsafe and intimidating. Pestered to death and they don't like it when you say no. We got called names and was sworn at. Mopeds and cars are a real nuisance.

Have Fun exploring. Get your bargaining hat on and just have fun. Ignore any first price and cut it in half, you still might be paying too much so check out other dealers. Most everything is available at multiple locations. You will have trouble leaving without some shoes!

Holiday in Marrakech.. Exciting exhilarating but too many motorbikes carrering through the narrow streets . Craftsmen demonstrating their trade are everywhere . So much to see. The aroma of the various spices is intoxicating. Be aware that many people will want to take you elsewhere in the Medina at a price?!!!

Don't be intimidated - it can be fun!. Visited Marrakech twice now, trip to the medina the first time was anything but a pleasant experience. Constant badgering by 'guides', feeling that you daren't stop and look at anything as you were immediately pounced on by someone determined to sell you something.Second visit went with a totally different attitude - don't be the obvious tourist, put the camera away, be prepared to lie - 'no we don't need ??????, this is our 5th or 6th trip' (this works when negotiating taxi prices as well) - don't ignore people, come back with a bit of banter (patting my larger than average waistline, 'do I look like I need something to eat? Maybe later) Try to look confident and don't be afraid of insulting a trader by offering far to little - it doesn't bother them asking an astronomical first price!In the evening investigate the story tellers and groups of musicians - even without the language you can spot the 'game' that the entertainers use to increase the amount of money they are given by the audience before they commence their show. Take part with a few small coins and before you know it you are being ushered to the front and you wife given a seat (that someone not willing to play has been ejected from).

Love It. I love the hussle and bustle of the Medina. I visited for a day back in October 2015 and vowed I would return just to savour the experience. I was not disappointed. The place comes alive at night and the street food market is a must do experience.

Incredible place with such craftmanship, an memorable experience. We have a local guide who took us around the medina, conquer all the alley weavers, embroidery workshop, tanneries- bags shoes etc , craft menship of cedar wood work, copper tooling, pottery...we spend a day here just browsing. So much to see. Please do ask permission if you plan to take photo. Hire a guide don't venture your own, it does not cost much as you able to see more and have help to language barrier. Keep your belonging to your self as too many people and even they very friendly.

An amazing but mad place.. We went to Marrakech sort of expecting a busy city butbnothing prepares you for the sights and smells of this place. The souks are amazing but overfun with smelly two stroke mopeds so beware.The wost thing though is the people! We like engaging with locals when we travel, but here you must avoid any eye contact otherwise they are on to you in an agressive persistent way to buy theire goods or to take you somewhwere to sell you something.You must be on your gaurd at all times.It is very wearing saying no and go away all the time.It is a dry place so dont expect to find a relaxing beervanywhere either.Therecare some pleasant places in the Medina but its hell getting tomthem.I reccomend the City Walks app for your mobile. It uses gps and is the only way you will find your waynout of the narrow souks.
Scary and fun, but can be too much!. Don't take husbands who don't like shopping. I wasn't bothered by the sellers, just ignored them and picked what I wanted to haggle over.

An experience but Very annoying . It is worth experiencing, but it is very annoying to be told that the way you going is closed and get redirected to spice shops or the restaurants. I couldn't go yards been told that I'm going the wrong way. I knew exactly where I was going and the constant scamming made it on enjoyable

Adrenalin rush!. Don't worry if you heart rate jumps up to 200 beats per minute in the Medina. You'll be busy hurdle running between donkey carts, men pushing/pulling overloaded hand carts, tractors, scooters, mopeds, bicycles and masses of people rushing from A to B - while being shouted at and spoke to from shop keepers left and right either asking you where you are from in different languages, or trying to strike up some sort of conversation getting you into their shops. The smells, sounds, fumes, sights are overwhelming at first - but... you get used to it! If you speak French you are at a clear advantage. I've never seen so many things to buy in so little space with the Souks being the main shopping labyrinth. Be prepared to be constantly badgered, approached, asked for money, taken to a 'friend's shop', promised not to be asked for money but then their friend does. The shops in the Medina are more expensive than the shops directly in the Souks. If you want to brush up your haggling skills or send if your sales team needs to improve their negotiation skills, send them to Marrakech. I certainly learnt a lot!! Lots to see and do. Relax into it and go with the flow. Learn to laugh any approaches off and you'll have fun. Just enjoy!!

Amazing. This medina is just like you would imagine from the stories of Arabian nights. Lot of different noices and smells and sights. You can see story tellers, monkey tamers, kobra enchanters and lots of food stalls.
January holiday. Prepare for haggling, big markets, amazing food, great vibes and mint tea. If you like to experience culture, this is a good place to be
Music shows food and great orange juice. Just make sure you have a Business card from your hotel or riad .the chances of getting lost are great .i asked shop owners to help me get back home .
A cacophony of sounds, smells and sights. Sometimes overwhelming, always marvellous. However I still have trouble sleeping due to animal welfare issues which we witnessed.

Great experience. At the centre of this is the market square which is a real experience. The sights, sounds, smells and experience of shooting down everyone vying for your attention is not to be missed

Amazing. Great fun getting the right price. Very busy loved it day & night. Lots of Monkeys & snakes in the square. Always felf safe and security surround the square. You can really grab a few bargains.

If you like chaos you will love the Medina. The Mediana is an amazing experience if you like hustle and bustle. There are great restaurants, places to drink, coffee shops there are buskers, donkeys, mopeds, people wanting to sell you everything from oranges to watches! It is condensed chaos!The history of the Medina goes back a long way; it was built in 1052 making it 964 years old. The character and energy are amazing, a must see if your are in Marrakech.

Amazing place!. I never tire of visiting this area, so much excitement, the street food is wonderful, the stalls around the edge have so much to offer, bargains galore! The Restaurants are lovely with great service, and the wonderful aroma that fills the air will always draw you back.
A Must!. Just awsome, day and night!Have an Ice cream mis afternoon and watch they all prep for evening, something else!

spectacular, colourful. I would love to be able to stop, to look around at all the colourful wares though a lot of them are the same from stall to stall, but the constant hassle prevents it. I know from past experience that it is difficult to get away even if you do not want anything.To those who know the souk, it is in layers of different types of goods. What I particularly enjoy is watching people practise traditional skills; there is more of this towards the back of the souk where prices also seem to be lower. Souk Cherifia though small, has an interesting 'take' on the usual goods and is also much calmer.
Full on North African experience. I prefer the Marrakesh medina to other medinas in Morocco for one simple reason: you feel more of the different African influences, especially at the main square.

Christmas Eve visit. An interesting experience! Went on a Thomson's trip, so perhaps didn't get as much hassle as we would have done without a guide! I think we would have been totally disorientated if we had gone alone, it's an absolute maze and quite polluted. Motor scooters are allowed in there and ride through at speed. If only the vendors would allow people to look at their wares, without the pressure I'm sure they would sell so much more, but I know it's not their custom.

Crazy. Have to visit if you go to Marrakech.lots of snakes and monkeys running around, try to go up to a rooftop cafe to overlook the square around sunset time as the sun comes around the main mosque from the left.

Brilliant fun. Well all I can sy is that it's an experience to go out here. Don't bother with a tour operator tour of the Medina. Go on your own to experience it and be prepared to Haggle! We were a little intimidated the first time but the following day we had a great time shopping and buying some gifts to bring home.

Easy to get lost. Takes a while to orientate yourself given all the tiny winding roads, but it's worth exploring for the colourful sites and sounds. The architecture is interesting and whilst it is old, it is still beautiful. Be prepared for vendors to constantly call out and invite you in, as well as random people offering to 'show you the way' to wherever you're going... A polite 'no thank you' is generally enough to dissuade them.

If in Morocco you have to visit!!. Great place to see, street sellers can be a pain in the neck !! Be prepared for a lot of walking, but necessary to visit!!! Lots of things to see and do especially at night!!

Large market. This market is large. But manageable. Much better than Fes in my opinion
You can find your way here with a little effort and awareness. Be sure to bargain
Amazing Medina. Being in Marrakech for only 3 days, I got a Hotel in the heart of Medina. It is really an experience to get lost all the time in narrow streets and a true Arabic environment.

Hectic, stressful and loud. I did not like the Medina at all. People are shouting at you so you buy things, they really try to get you into their shops, restaurants or whatever. Women just grab your hand and put Henna on it and if you take a picture and people notice you took one in their direction (even though they're not in it), they want money for it. When you go and sit outside for a snack or lunch, people approach you and try to sell you Phones, clocks and other stuff.

Fantastic Hurly Burly of Life in Working City.. This is truly an amazing place and in my experience is only outdone by the Medina in Fez. The Medina is an ancient working city full of characters of all possible descriptions. Watch out for agressive begging, agressive selling, people directing you in the wrong direction, people harassing you, telling you that where you are going is closed or there are women there and you can't go, likewise there is a Mosque and you can't go.Once you have got over all the negatives there are so many positives that thet whole place is breath taking. I would advise you to check out the main square early in the day prior to making an evening visit. The evenings can get very very crowded. look out for pickpockets at the end of the main square towards the shops and banks.Brilliant place, lots of lovely eating places and a good place to see a working city in the raw.

Ten useful tips for travellers in Morocco.
