I have been to Morocco three times now, and I feel I’ve seen enough of it to share a few useful tips for first time travellers to this country.Despite my previous post, where I talked about how annoying it can sometimes be to be pestered by the locals, I would like to stress that I actually love this country, and I will keep coming back. But it does help to keep these little tips in mind!1. Bargain over everythingYes, it’s OK to bargain over the price of a taxi. Or the amount you paid for your street breakfast. It is positively expected that you will have a lengthy ‘discussion’ over the price you are paying for anything you buy in a stall or shop, and it is just as much of a given that you will walk away having paid two or three times more than the locals.On our latest trip to Morocco, my friends and I met an retired American man who spent six months every year in Morocco, and the other six in America. “I can get a bread for half a dirham, a tomato for another half a dirham, and I’ve got myself a tomato sandwich for a dirham,” he told us, as we were paying 100 dirham (somehow??!) for our own breakfast, which wasn’t even that lavish. One dirham is around 7p to you and me…the same taxi that we paid 50 dirham for that morning cost him 11 dirham, he added. You just have to know how to push.The only exception, it seems, is when the price is written down. “Fixed price”, they call it. I have never been to a Moroccan supermarket, but I imagine there isn’t much bargaining to be done there. Neither can you really bargain in expensive restaurants and the like. Everywhere else, it seems to be fair game!2. Never agree to follow men on the street for directions,even if you are mega-lostWhen you first arrive in Marrakesh, prepare to be majorly overwhelmed. The place is a maze that doesn’t even make sense to the locals, and no matter how detailed the directions you are given by your hostel or riad, if you are staying inside the old city there is no chance you will find where you are staying within the first hour.And guess what looks like easy money to young Moroccan men who can speak a smidgen of English? Tired and lost-looking tourists! Unless you are in a very central area with millions of other tourists around, the local boys will descend upon you like vultures. Don’t even think of following one of them for directions! They will lead you around in circles for ages and then demand money when you finally get there.Instead, try to ask women or old men, even if it means communicating with hand gestures. If you can speak French – use it! If you don’t, maybe brush up on your travel phrases before going. Some shop owners can be quite helpful as well, but try to avoid the young males. Consider ordering a good map before heading to Marrakesh, and also keep the phone number of the hostel handy. We have had to be rescued by the hostel owners once when we simply couldn’t find our way, and were being harassed left, right and centre by local boys trying to offer ‘help’.3. Don’t buy sweets from a cart in the main squareThey don’t taste as good as they look! At all. In the evening, you will see men rushing around with these carts filled with local sweets, offering boxes of 12 for 50 dirham (just over £3). But they tend to be a bit stale and stodgy, and are probably best used as a table decoration than food (although we ate all the ones we bought on the first night there anyway).Instead, find some chebakiya if you want some proper Moroccan sweets. They are the cheapest ones by far, and the tastiest! A big box, even in the most touristy area, shouldn’t cost you more than 30 dirham. You can find it being sold inside the main markets (souks) by dedicated merchants, or in smaller portions with tea in the main square in the evening. It’s essentially a pasty rolled up in the shape of a rose, deep fried until golden and covered in a syrup made from honey and rose water. It is divine! Although also very sickly, and definitely not at all good for you.4. Bring some ImodiumThe food in Morocco varies, but it is certainly not for everyone’s stomachs, and although it is nothing as bad as I would imagine India to be, you are quite likely to get a case of the traveller’s tummy at some point during your trip. You can buy Imodium in Morocco if you forget to bring it – all pharmacies should sell it, it has the same name and it isn’t particularly expensive.Some tips I found useful to try and avoid having to resort to drugs include asking for no ice in your drinks, watching that anything with eggs is really well cooked, even if you prefer them runny, and same goes for meat. Also, probably best to stay away from the orange juice stands in the main square. But to be honest, if you eat street food (or ever end up in a Moroccan or Berber kitchen, for that matter), you will be exposed to a much larger variety of dirt and grime than you are at home. That’s simply a fact you will have to live with, unless you would rather splash out on a five star hotel with a five star restaurant for your whole stay. But that’s not my style!5. Brush up on your FrenchPeople do speak English in Morocco, and many of them speak far more languages than you and I are used to in our insulated UK-based lives (probably not the case for those readers based outside the UK…) When we were climbing in Todra Gorge, many Berbers surprised us by being proficient in Spanish, and some Italian, on top of French, Arabic and English. But you will be better off if you remember some basic phrases, so you can ask for directions, and not confuse your right with your left when you are given them. Or make sure the waiter knows you definitely want your umpteenth cup of tea sans sucre!I swear I spoke more different languages (that I didn’t even know I could speak!) during my week in Morocco in December than over the course of the whole year prior to that. And that’s considering the fact that last year saw me trying to hold a conversation with my climbing partner’s Italian grandma in Italian. Which I have never learnt.6. Don’t be afraid of staying in hostelsBut maybe bring a sleeping bag liner. You can get them mega-cheap from Sports Direct and they really give that extra sense of comfort when you are not quite sure if the sheets have been washed.Now, I have never stayed anywhere particularly posh in Morocco, as I’m the type of traveller who actually quite likes slumming it a little, plus the more money I save on accommodation, the more I can spend on other (probably unnecessary) things. But I firmly believe you will have a nicer experience staying in a hostel-style riad in the old city (the Medina), rather than a posh hotel in the new city. If you are not the hostel type, you can still find riads for a very cheap price. I wouldn’t pay more than £15/pp per night at most, but the hostels are easily a third of that price.Just read the reviews on hostelworld.com and you should be able to pick something suitable. They usually have lots of private rooms for a low price, too. We stayed at Hostel Riad Marrakech Rouge and I thought it was really good value for money, and even included breakfast. It’s also very centrally located and easy to find from the main square, Jemaa El-Fnaa.7. Have extra space in your luggage……because you will want to buy stuff! A lot of stuff. Stuff you don’t really need, or rather, never realised you needed desperately right until this moment. On my last trip, myself and my friend Valentina somehow managed to walk up to a lady selling beanie hats, just to look, and walked away with eight. Eight hats!! Three of them she just gave to us for free, because we clearly failed to haggle as hard as we should have done. (My beanie has come in useful lately though, after London plunged into subarctic conditions.)“But hats don’t take up that much space in your luggage,” you laugh…Well, I also felt compelled to buy a framed painting for my flat, and something I can only describe as a Jedi cloak as a present for a friend. Which he loved, to be fair. Last time I went I came back with a Moroccan teapot and six tea glasses, following some epic haggling where I told the vendor I was a poor Bulgarian student. I even put on an accent, and all!8. Travel outside MarrakeshThere is so much to explore! I have been to Morocco three times, and each time I discovered new adventures. The first time I went with two friends to try out surfing near Agadir, and then visited Marrakesh for the first time. I actually covered this in a different blog (a loooong time ago), so if you want to give this a read here is the link.The second time a group of us went to conquer Mount Toubkal – the highest peak in North Africa at 4,167m. We succeeded, but we were comically unprepared for the adventure, having only brought a printed version of someone else’s blog to guide us up the mountain. No guides. No map. No compass. And only a couple functioning head torches between nine of us, which came in rather useful when we got lost in the dark on the trek back down, having completely mistimed the whole descent!9. And at the end of it all…have a hammam!But I would splash out on a private one, rather than going to a public one. I’ve never actually been to a public one, but the private ones I’ve had are sooooo good! Especially after days of climbing or trekking up and down the Atlas Mountains. Last time we actually had two in one trip!You are best off booking one of these in advance though, especially if you are going during quite a busy season, because we struggled to find one last minute in Marrakesh on our second night. In the end we managed, and I highly recommend the one we went to: Les Bains d’Azahara. It’s very reasonably priced, and though it is a little bit away from the main touristy areas, it is easy to find. The most basic hammam costs 150 dirham (under £11), while a package with an hour-long massage is 400 dirham. It’s super relaxing and really worth it!The only thing I would warn you of, is that however careful you are to ask for the men and women in your group to be be placed in separate rooms, that is very unlikely to happen. Every time I’ve had a hammam in Morocco I’ve ended up in the same room as at least one of my male friends, which means that you are probably going to see a number of your friends sporting very skimpy disposable pants. You could always make a fuss about it, but I chose to just enjoy the hilarity of it. If anything, it will bring you and your friends closer. Or at least give you some good blackmail material!10. Lastly, when you head home, print your Ryanair ticket…don’t rely on your phone!Moroccan airports are some of the few globally where you still cannot simply show a bar code on your phone instead of printing off your ticket. They don’t have the technology yet, I think. Don’t worry if you aren’t able to print the return ticket before you get to Morocco though, as there are internet cafes in most places.So on the penultimate day of our latest trip to Morocco, over the New Year’s holiday, we went to an internet cafe to print out our tickets. Imagine our shock when the check-in page told us the flight had already flown?! We looked at the date on the desktop, and with horror realised it said 5 January, not 4 January, as we believed it to be. For a few horrible seconds we genuinely thought we had somehow missed a day?!…..then it turned out the Medieval computer system had the wrong date setting, and the lady manning the store didn’t know how to change it. The check-in page was taking the date from the desktop (for whatever reason), so it wouldn’t let us check in! Eventually though, we managed to print off our tickets using her computer, which didn’t seem to be plagued with this problem.I hope these little pointers help you on your next trip to Morocco. What else would you like me to write about? What destinations are you planning to check out this year? I would love to hear from you!
Great place. La Medina is an spectacular place but I must recommend for tourist to hire an official tour guide since the medina is huge and its like a maze.

Love it. People say you love or hate the old medina. I loved it. As soon as you get used to the mopeds (get used to single file with kids) it is a joy to look around all the corners and see unique sights. And if in Marrakech you must stay in a medina riad, our was stunning and cheap in price. Unforgettable.

Very exotic old town. Numerous narrow streets, shops and many thousands of people who just disagree with many shopping carts and mopeds. And throughout this labyrinth hidden multitude of charming the hotels Riyadh. Hard to navigate without a local guide if you are looking for any of them.

Bit dissapointing. Maybe I'm just not made for crowded places, is what I said to my girlfriend after one day in the Medina. But after the second one, I discovered that isn't the problem. So here are the two things I don't like about Marrakesh' Medina:First, all the people trying to make money from you. Blocking the way, trying to get you in their store, putting things in your hands and expecting you to buy it, boys giving you wrong directions only to ask money for giving you the good one and all the other scams people are trying to pull. I was constantly looking out for all of this, so that didn't allow me to really enjoy the old city. But, I read about this before I went so you could say I could have known. Secondly, and I hated this probably the most, my girlfriend just wasn't able to walk though the Medina without being harrassed. She was wearing jeans, a sweater and a jacket (we went in January) but that didn't stop Maroccan men from looking at her like she was naked, constantly asking her to come with them, calling her a lot of names (including 'putain', you look it up) right in her face and behind her back and trying to touch and grab her behind, luckily not with a lot of succes. Me walking next to her seems to make no differece, but I'm glad she didn't went on her own or with her friends. I don't know why men in the Medina are behaving like cavemen who have never seen a women before, especially because west of the Medina, in the new city, there wasn't any of this behaviour. Some positives to end:Try visiting the Madrassa, Maison de Photographie, the two palaces and the burial place next to those palaces. It are very nice places. Last tip: When looking for directions, ask a police agent or ask in a shop. They'll direct you in the right way.

Tight roads and a lot of culture. It is like you see in the films. Tight roads with hundreds of little shops. Haggling with the owners is actually quite fun. Go in knowing how much you want to pay for the item before you start haggling. rejecting a price and walking away usually gets you a lower price.

The dizzying madness of the Medina. The Medina of Marrakesh is the old Islamic capital, which originated in the 11th century. The Medina has a range of historic and ancient architectural wonders including the Saadian Tombs and the Koutoubia Mosques.It is encircled by 16 kilometres of walls and gates, much of it still, in the original pinky, salmon colour.Very quiet in the early mornings but becomes very busy as the day progresses and be especially aware of pick pockets.By late afternoon, the hustle and bustle is extraordinary.There are literally hundreds, if not thousands of people including; musicians, street performers, snake charmers, water bearers, donkeys, horses, monkeys, street stalls, food, spices, sights, smells and sounds.The list goes on....

Transported back in time. The Medina is a magical place. It's huge and without someone to show you around, you will likely get lost. There are so, so many places to experience realistic life in the Medina. The most amazing places to get the freshest fruit you've every had (just try one of those mandarin oranges = like candy) and an opportunity for a truly amazing experience. The food is wonderful, whether it's real street food or from one of the many many restaurants within the medina. The tagine and couscous are great and I've never had a better piece of lamb anywhere in my life. Perfectly cooked wherever you go. The medina is full of shops and housing with non descript doors some basic and some rather artistic, everywhere you turn. Two days in the medina was more than enough for me. Be careful of the guides (even the professional ones) as they make a TON of money by shuffling you into the various shops where they have existing relationships with the shop owners and make a very healthy commission from them to the tune of between 35% and 50%. They act like they are showing you how things are made, but then you get a hard sell from the shop owner. I suggest shopping on your own so that the stores don't hike the prices way up so that they can pay the hefty commission to the guides. You've been warned and have a wonderful time.

What's the fuss?. Having read trip-advisor reviews ("the madness of Marrakech") extensively, we really were looking forward to this experience. But we were hugely unimpressed. We found the sellers (mainly men) to be obtrusive, rude and clearly had no empathy for the manner in which most people enjoy to shop. As a result, we bought absolutely nothing. Thankfully, we had previously spent 3 days in Essaouira where one could shop without any hassle whatsoever. In addition, we were able to chose items that were locally sourced rather than mass-produced in China.The narrow passageways would have been intriguing to explore had it not been for the constant flow of motorbikes whizzing past. Not only did we feel fearful at times, the noise was an assault to the ears and fumes an offence to the lungs. Having visited similar busy market areas throughout the world without any of the aforementioned negativities, particularly in the Far East, this was not a worthwhile experience.
Super!. Absolutely a wonderful place to visit. Its like being in 1001 night. Eat at the main square, visit the bazar and many other things.

Worth a visit. This medina is not as charming as that in Fes but is still worth a walk through. Be prepared to bargain---if you pay more than 1/3 of asking, you are overpaying. Most of the shop keepers are aggressive but back down pretty quickly when you say you are not interested in buying anything. There is a full range of items here from housewares to food too jewelery to leather goods.
Amazing. Big madina, huge range of goods. Bargain till u drop. They can smell your tourist blood from a mile away

A warren of cobbled streets with a new aspect at every turn.. The Medina - the old town, is surrounded by walls, with gates at frequent intervals. The tourist map lists the main landmarks but the little 'streets' form a myriad of homes, businesses, shops, street markets and cafe/bars. It is very easy to lose one's sense of direction. There is always a ready smiling 'guide' to take you to the 'carpet factory' or other sales outlet for a small fee. Many streets are narrow and cobbled. Strong walking boots are a must to avoid sore feet or strained ankles. There are carts pulled by donkeys, who in the main are well cared for. The horses and carriages operate only on the fringe of the Medina and to the 'town' and tourist attractions. They display a tariff, but bargain before hiring!

An experince. If you go to Marrakech you cannot leave without visiting the Medina. Tips: Always haggle and expect to pay a third of what is originally asked. The people are very friendly but remember that you are in a foreign country were the average weekly income is under £20 per week. Most of the local,tradesman see you only.as a source of income and will try all sorts of tricks to get you to go to their shop. Offer to guide you, tell you that the shops in a certain area are closed when they are not. However don't let it spoil a unique experince

"Day tour with Abdoul". Me and my husband had a day trip outside Marrakech on 15th January 2016. We visited Berber villages to know a bit of their mountain life & witnessed the rural Morrocan culture. Our tour was fantastic as we have a brilliant guide who's name is Abdoul. He gave us plenty of information & been very helpful in everything we need. I cannot find any fault and he's been fantastic in any way. The highlight of the tour was the traditional food served for our lunch (vegetable soup, chicken tajine & Morrocan couscous dish, fresh oranges + mint tea) while surrounded of the breathtaking view. Seeing the highest peak of the High Atlas Mountains (tallest mountain in North Africa) was a big bonus on our tour. A very unique experience for me & my husband.
Fascinating place. We both visited throughout the medina and we stayed at a lovely riad inside the medina. It was a fascinating place and definitely worth exploring for several days.

A very beautiful yet intimidating place. I do love Marrakech (as much as I hate it), I have visited 3 times in the space of 6 years. The Medina is a stunning place, with the old buildings, call for prayers 5 times a day heard in the distance, the smells, the sunshine. Then there are the hords or young men, totally intimidating and disrespectful. They spoil the whole experience to such extent, on my 3rd visit to the city, I was too scared to go to the medina, even in male company. They will shout at you, approach you in a very disrespectful manner, call you names. Marrakech could be such an amazing place, without those men.I have stayed in a riad, right in the heart of the Medina, really amazing and tranquill place, but was so intimidated to leave the place, and every time I had to leave I just felt so unease. You can't drive during the day in the Medina, so you will be dropped off somewhere, nearish your riad, as far as the car can go, and then there will be the people trying to show you the way, get money off you, and just be a nuisance. If you are a woman, this will 100% be a disgusting experience.IF you can look past that, there are such amazing places to be seen in the medina: hidden amazing restaurants, magical riads, rooftop bars, gardens, nice shops.Bus for as long as people of Marrakech believe that tourists are idiots, walking cach machines that you can throw abuse at, the city will be attracting less and less people, and those who do come will not come back. The greediness will not pay back.Medina could be so beautiful, but that would require a differend mindset of the locals towards tourists.

You Must Not Miss It... Or Can't !!. There really is no where else quite like it, and it might make you mad, get you lost completely, have you hassled from time to time, maybe lose some money you promised yourself you never would..and have you in awe of the architecture, texture and colour,, but it is LIFE and it is REAL.

Charming chaos. A lot of people at the same time trying to catch your attention and get money from you. Still a lot to see, and much interesting! Some things are sad, like the baby monkey slaves that some keep, but there is also nice rhytms, traditional music, dance and clothing, and great entusiasm among locals in the marketplace.

A different way of life. The Medina is surreal and will take you to another way of life. Expect a lot of people to approach you and try and convince you to buy from their stalls, however do not let this deter you from a different experience of life.
Huge. Buzzing, alive and exciting- be prepared to be hounded to make a purchase...worth looking around first to grab a bargain!

Snake charmerd etc. Crowded Medina, interesting place with a few snake charmers, 4DH orange juice (5 DH if they give you a takeaway plastic cup), story tellers, young flexible boy lying face down & bending his feet over his head & holding a fork with his toes to eat fruits, etc. One doesn't see all these in our home countries.

Amazing, full of history. The Medina, the old walled city, is our favorite part of Marrakech. It is a warren of exotic surprises. The most beautiful interiors of fine old buildings quietly hide themselves down obscure passage ways, the markets are treasure troves of all sorts of goods and life, there are large pungent tanneries, old palaces, 'delicious' restaurants, beautiful squares, fascinating museums and so much more ... . Loaded donkeys, mopeds, bikes and people thread through each-other down tiny alleys. Watch-out! We liked the people enormously. They will expect 'a tip' if they help you, and us westerners can sometimes feel grieved that it appeared to be offered free in the first place. Its a different culture from ours and after all in their place, with their economy, we might do the same.
Wonderful Medina. Spent a lot of my trip in Marrakech within the Medina. its a wonderful place to be and take in all the culture. This area by night comes alive with street food and performers

Spellbinding. A total maze...no Street names..Red walls everywhere, people cooking, donkeys, bikes,crazy mayhem in the evening but we always felt safe. It may be a tourist trap but still extremely exotic and atmospheric. My tip would be orientate yourself using either graffiti, unusual shop signs, and any numbered houses. Definitely stay in the medina not outside it.
Just Awesome. It is like going back in time. We enjoyed exploring the Medina. Just make sure you read up on what goes there. It is indeed a world Heritage Site.

What's the fuss?. I have been there twice not sure what's all this fuss about. It's an average souk. Same sort of stuff on all shops within 100 meter. Not much variety. Quite few shops selling fake/copy clothes, shoes, bags, belts & sunglasses if you are interested in. It's not that complicated to navigate your route through this. If you have a map in your hands then trust me you cannot get lost and no need to ask anyone which way to go.

DONT GO!! air pollution at its maximum!!. Never had experienced in my long travellers life like this: dusty poisonous scouters follow chace you mercyless into the tinyest and of corse the bigger alleys streets places, in the shouks where fumes cant escape: even though perhibitted- no one is asking to fine them ! and scouters arent the latest models like in vietnam: no- they are bluedusty old from the 60 ies This was the poorest experience I ever had:Dont go there with kids: i became sick there. asthma- which i never had bevorDONT GO bevore you read that the authorities have done something! its redicule!!! fraiment!

Just Incredible. Ive been all over the world and have never seen anything quite like this. Its like stepping back intothe 17th century. Fantastic place would say to everyone, make sure you go there once

Food stalls interesting. During the day not so interesting. Buzzling square with lot of sellers.During the night interesting with all the foodstalls. They work hard and good food at reasonable prices.

Heaving. Very busy square whether you want to shop, eat and drink, be entertained or just soak in the atmosphere this is the place to do it.We went during the day, just as it was winding down at days-end but it was still heaving with all sorts of characters, entertainers, sellers, snake-charmers, you name it you'll find it and they are all after the same thing... YOUR MONEY ...Definitely an experience not to be missed and a great day out.Apparently night-time is much busier but in experiencing it I can only go by what everyone says.As my wife said, Marrakech is probably more for the younger ones (both in our sixties and disabled) but it is also somewhere you must experience in your lifetime.

Full of lively energy, sort of New York square. Carry a bottle of water,you will need it as you will get tired of walking, walking, walking. Do buy but don't bargain harsh as they depend on business for livelihood. Beware of guides, you don't need any guides, if you know french and if you have roamed around quiet a bit and familiarize yourself with the surrounding.

Very stimulating. An awesome warren of courtyards and beautiful tiles. Not a huge place and it could do with some more places to just sit and take it in.The finishing is not on a par with similar Moorish buildings in Andalucia, but beautiful nonetheless.

Assault on the Senses. There are some interesting points to the medina. The people, the animals, the atmosphere. However, the crowds, the hawkers, the air pollution, the scooters wear on you. We found one day in the city (medina, square) more than enough.

The best place in Morocco. I travelled there with my family and my kids were intrigued by the Medina. During the day it was a place for vendors, but as the evening comes all the exotic vendors start moving in like the snake charmers, acrobats, astrologers etc. There is a lot to see and eat at this medina. plan to spend at 2 evenings here.

This is Marrakech. We stayed within the walls of Medina for 2 nights. Could not recommend it highly enough. It was 2 days and nights of excitement, buzz, and culture. Medina and the square are bucket list places.

Amazing and Overwhelming. Everything about it is extreme but for tourists it can be...difficult. You really can't walk around in the Medina; you have to be single file because of the mopeds and traffic. If there is an area where you can stroll through the streets you are followed by locals begging you to buy buy buy. The locals harassing the tourists is a bit over the top. We were followed by a man saying, "Are you scared of me American?" They really have a diamond in the rough here; it would be a tourist mecca if there were signs telling you were to go and the locals toned it down and made the tourists feel safer.

Amazing place to visit. Maze of shops and stalls to feast your eyes on, smells of the spices is incredible, only thing is to watch out for the pick pockets at night time mostly, but well worth the visit

The fun of barginning. I left and purchased soMuch stuff it was ridiculous. I was into the fact of bargaining. Next offer the price that they ask for. Whatever they ask for cut it in half and stay firm. If they don't budge walk away. All the stores have the same thing so what one owner won't let you have another store owner will. I also found that owners were more likely to bargain in fes and the smaller cities within Morocco. So if you are visiting fes or any of the smaller cities do your shopping there and pick up a couple of things from Marrakech Also make sure to have some mint tea on the top of one of the medina rooftops. Overpriced -25dirhams but worth the view

A must do whilst in Marrakech!!. We took the hotel shuttle bus to the medina. Such a fantastic experience, vendors do not hassle you if you are not interested say no thanks and they leave you alone.An experience you will not forget or see anywhere else.!!

It was better than the guide books said it would be.... There was far less hassle to the Medina than the guide books said there would be. Be careful when selecting restaurants that serve beer and cocktails... they are more often than not non-alcoholic. Also, when the tanners are in town, a whole host of people will try to direct you there... a nice young man on his way to school will drop you off for free. The guy he drops you off with will show you the tannery and ask you for $20 per person at the end of the "tour." We didn't pay him nearly that much.

Could be 100% better. The Medina here could be a really great experience for foreigners, if only the local government would spend some money on proper signage and make the places easier to find. The bargaining etc is all fun and no problem. The real problem that there could be so much more to be done if the signage were in the right places and easy to read. maybe there should be free wifi everywhere??

Busy Market Square and look out for the hawkers. A large and bustling Market Square with heaps of food and clothing shops. Watch out for the hawkers who will harass you to pay for photos with Monkey's. snakes and horses. Worth a visit but not as good as the Fez Medina. Look out for the restaiurants around the square for a decent meal.

You have to do the Medina. a maze ... do go but with a guide to bring you around as impossible to find your way .. be ready to bargain hard with them .. but better quality goods especially leather to be found in stores.

Overwhelming if you're not prepared for it. Marrakech is just so unreal. From the kids who grab your leg to get coins, any kind of person trying to take you somewhere and sell you anything, utmost poverty mixed with celebrities, 50.000 "shops" selling god knows what, snakes, monkeys and wild cats, guys racing on bikes and scooters dragging horses through tiny streets, hidden palaces... BUT I know a ton of ppl, esp women, who can't stand the constant harrassment from locals. You need to ignore and be extremely rude and authoritative to locals to be quiet - that's a shame.

Fun but so easy to get lost!. This medina is very interesting with larger streets and many smaller, maze-like, alleyways. It is very easy to get lost so make sure you always know where the main square is. The energy is fantastic in the medina and the shops and locals are very friendly and happy to help. It can be a bit dodgy at night so make sure you have a solid plan as to where you are going.

Noisy, smelly everything you imagine. Busy,noisy and in the medina very narrow, everything you want this to be, not disappointed , some sights and smells not so pleasant, but loved the horse and cart ride back to the hotel in the evening. Some lovely cafes and bars around very reasonable prices, be careful when bartering, found it to be very aggressive.
Blend of old and new. Beautiful blend of old and new aspects of Moroccan culture. Old buildings juxtaposed against new glamorous buildings

OMG . Medina sucks.
People are really anoying and begging all the time - bikes almost hit us! It is still a must see place ! Crowded, noisy and dirty - its hard to make a good bargain, watch out for fixed prices!
A fantastic experience. Spent an evening here with some friends wandered around the stalls and viewed all the food sellers. Picked a fish bar and we weren't disappointed.

Must visit and browse!. Exploring the thousands of shops and eateries in the Souks and the whole Medina is very fascinating. Was fun bargaining while shopping. Actual prices are generally one third of the shopkeeper's quoted price. Was later told that even the food prices are negotiable at most places!

The Medina. Well worth a look daytime and best in the evening.
Some good restaurants are well hidden above the ground floor cafes so do try to find them.
Zah zags as el arabe worth a visit.

Terrible street food. I sincerely hoped that there are more 'truthful' reviews out there (later realized that there are plenty floating in the forum but too late). Whilst it could be an interesting experience to many, I wonder if one would still find it amusing if they have to endure days or weeks of diarrhea and vomit? The staffs at our hotel told us almost everyone who came back from the night market have the same problem. Once you chose the place to sit down, they don't care anymore. They will serve you things you didn't order and tell you they're just salad. Extremely small portions (4 euros for a salad in a saucer plate!) and because they want customers to stay to make it look like it is a popular place, you have to be really persistent in getting the bill. Be prepared for surprises when you do get the bill and check it carefully. They roughly added 50 dirhams and pretend it was a mathematical mistake. And the food is not tasty at all! It is much advised to go to a proper restaurant, even with tips it could be cheaper than in the medina where there are people constantly harassing you while you eat. Dirty, expensive, dangerous. Couldn't be worse.
Magic!. A maze, a labyrinth of colours, smells, noises, people, a fascinating place to get lost in - and then ask a friendly young fellow to take you where you want to go :-)

Mad !!!!!!. Be prepared for the noise of this place, the constant beating of drums and noise of the crowds can be a bit overwhelming. This market is vast and has everything from snake charmers to Monkeys in football tops, but you REALLY need your wits about you as you can very easily be conned out of your money, DO NOT take photos as you are wandering around the square as you could very well have some angry and irate sellers after you for money, it is considered good manners to ask first and then be prepared to pay for the privilege, between 20 and 50 dirnham is considered a good tip.The best place to watch everything and take photos freely is from the upstairs terraces in the cafes or restaurants surrounding the square it is much more pleasant and you don't get the constant barrage from the beggars and sellers.But it is a must place to visit.

It is what it is so don't be surprised . We visited in the horse drawn carriage early in the evening just as darkness fell and all the lights came on.Hectic. Noisy. Unique. We will go back and stay in a riad to get the full experience next time we visit Marrakech. Yes we will be going back.If you expect morrocco to be like Florida... it is not... it is delightfully different. Cultural. Friendly. I say this as we met two couples who were disappointed as it was not like Florida!!! We suggested they should have gone there then... not the lovely marrakech.

A Maze of Markets, Eateries and Guest Houses. A walk through the Medina is not for the faint hearted! From the minute we left our guest house we were thrown into a large maze full of houses, market and food stalls. You will be greeted with many sights and smells, not always pleasant! We found the shop/stall owner very demanding and it became very tiresome trying to politely say that you were just looking. In the end we found ourselves just walking past everything, which was such a shame as I would have loved to have looked more. The downside to this (and its the same in the Market) is that the tourists and shop owners are left disappointed!
Festive!. You ought to try the food cooked right in the middle of the square in those mini restaurants .. very authentic.. very delicious
Loved the Medina. I cant wait to go back to Marrakech! There is so much to do there. Shops, food, hookah, cafes and entertainment. Morocco is an amazing country.
Medina. Amazingly good fun, bustling and very busy, must go and see it, you will get lost, be prepared to banter for a price but it is an experience

It's Carpets, It's Madness... It's Carpets Madness.... I didn't really know what to expect when first entering this maze of market goodness. I certainly wasn't disappointed that's for sure.It is indeed a maze. A big, bright maze that will tip you drag you into sensory overload within a matter of minutes. Your nose is excited by exotic and tantalising aromas one second and assaulted by some not so nice the next. Your eyes struggle to take in all the colour and movement and your ears are overwhelmed by the sounds of hustle and bustle, people going about their everyday lives and motorcycle drivers screaming at you to get out of the way.There is definitely a lot to see in the markets of the Medina. Be careful though, what at first seems to be local helpfulness is quite possibly going to be someone looking to make a quick buck. Beware of guides! They will offer to guide you to where you are going and tell you they do not want any money for it. When you get to your destination, however, suddenly you are in the midst of a bartering session for how much he should get. We were expecting this and, after reading the Lonely Planet guide, were under the impression that only 10-20DHM would be changing hands. Not the exorbitant 200DHM!!! I wonder what the arabic word for 'fleeced' is? These guides can become a little aggressive if not placated. Try and get your bearings quickly and walk with direction and confidence. You will need to be firm but polite with your 'NO THANK YOU' and do not believe them when they say something is closed. They have many tricks to make you doubt yourself.The stalls in the market are stocked with everything from silver jewellery, spices, shoes and bags to homewares, art and clothing. My suggestion is, if you are wishing to buy things stay away from the stalls close to the square as they seem to be filled mostly with mass produced and touristy items. Venture further into the markets and let yourself get lost. Shops selling similar items are mostly grouped together which makes it easier to compare items. Be prepared to haggle!!! I could write a lot more about the Medina but I think it is a place that is best experienced!

Bustling. The market in the Medina is bustling with visitors and is over crowded. However it shows much of the Moroccan culture. It is ok for a walk but for buying one has to exercise some bargaining skills.

Shoppers paradise.. Excellent for shopping and sitting with a drink people watching. Masses to see! Folk stories, cobra snakes, monkeys, henna tattoos, fortune tellers, good cheap food. Just brilliant.
We had so much fun. Really good fun at night also loads to see during the day make sure you don't tread on the snakes and don't be suppressed if you get a monkey on you shoulder
History in every corner.. Walking around in Medina is like walking in old time. You just don`t know what you will get at the next corner.

BEST PLACE TO BE RUN OVER BY A MOTO. Most tourists in the Medina worry about getting lost. But the real danger is the drivers. Drivers across Morocco are crazy — and in Marrakech's Medina they drive fast through narrow and crowded alleys. Watch your purses for snatchers and your feet to make sure they're not run over. The drivers are not paying attention, are speeding and often texting. There's no sidewalks, of course, it's very crowded and when the motorcycles and mopeds come at you there can be nowhere safe to step.
Wonderfull. One of the Most exciting places ive been to so far, just loveley. We both really enjoyed haggling etc :)

I loved this place!. At night is the best! Amazing food everywhere and happy crazy people pushing you to eat in a great way! I eat so much and in a good price! Try the sweets from No 1!!! You will understand when you see them running around with the sweets! seriously I bought from the No 4 guy and I regret it!! No 1!! IS THE BEST! ;) delicious!!
Interesting place. Go to one of the roof top cafes at around 4.30 and watch the sunset go down over the market place. Dont take pictures of the snakes!

Simply Amazing. The market is amazing but prepare to get for the Bargain!!!! Its madness to shop in the market however fun and enjoy the great fresh squeeze orange juice. Great to have a fun with KALASH "Horse Riding" - overall its great experience in the Marrakesh Madina.

Crowded, frenetic, visually surprising, chaotic, intense.. Our first day in the medina we had a guide and I would highly recommend all visitors do the same. It is easy to get lost and hard to trust people to guide you to a place you recognize. Our guide even helped us negotiate prices. We were very happy to have him along. The second day we were on our own and and wanted to return to see an older man who carved stucco pieces and none of us ever found him again. The sellers are quite aggressive and it can be overwhelming. They are willing to negotiate but be careful as they will try to convince you to buy multiples. Be strong with your choices and move on. Once you get the hang of bartering you can have a lot of fun. The medina is beautiful and you will see so much that you love if you let yourself. Go with an open mind and enjoy the experience.

Be prepared for a frenetic buzz. It's a safe place to wander and get lost. Forget about keeping track of your route. You'll eventually find your way back. Wear comfortable shoes as you might walk further than anticipated.
Different Old Medina. Wanted to check the old place out.It was just too busy and motorbikes just passing through.Cheap but you need to negotiate.

Madness of Marrakech. Amazing cultural experience but hang onto your hat! Scooters, donkeys, cars everywhere but worth it to see the sights & sounds of the souks. Definitely need to be willing to barter and sometimes need to knock a "0" off or at least 50%. Fabulous items to buy from slippers & shoes, bags, cushions and much more all beautiful made with vibrant colours. Wasn't brave enough to try the food but settled for a coffee on the rooftop at Cafe France to watch the sun go down!

Amazing. Definitely can't miss this sight when you are in Marrakech, who would. Amazing night sight, great fresh squeezed orange juice, lots streets artists, great place to work around and shop(not alone though), and experience the culture. I have been to many night markets, but this one is just way too amazing.

Fun but be prepared to get lost . Tons of things to look at but be aware that some of the 'trinkets' and 'treasures' may be plastic and/or fakes. Had a great time getting lost (which was inevitable) and bartering for things. A lot of options for eating and buying gifts. We went on a day it rained quite heavily but as some is undercover we only got slightly drenched. Definitely worth a day visit!

Unique?. I had an open mind - having never visited before. You do feel that you are at the start of an adventure, the sounds, smell, atmosphere, general chaos is completely new. I am glad we came as a couple & didn't come with children. You need to be on your guard all the time as you get approached constantly. It is awful to admit that I tried not to look at anyone just to avoid being pestered.

The heart of the city!. The famous Medina is the heart of the city - popular in hollywood films, books, it is full of life night and day! From musicians, buskers, snake charmers, shops, restaurants, cafes, shops, story tellers, horse riding, this place is a must visit! A personal favourite is the fresh orange juices and to have a cous cous and salad at a restaraunt with a view of the entire medina.
Good to visit. Something different. . Good place to visit. Exactly as we see on the TV. just don't forget to bargain. "Samarin" is the place to go exactly inside the market.

A maze of little treasures. If you do anything in Marrakech make sure you get lost in the souks! And be sure to haggle haggle haggle. Also stop in one of the little food/drink stalls down towards Ben Youssef and have a mint tea, watch the world go by!

If you're looking for color, noise, smells, and tastes, this is the place. Of all the medinas we visited in Morocco, this was the most crowded, commercialized and noisy. Expect to be taken advantage of if you're not careful (the henna is almost all fake and washes off in days; bargain HARD for everything; DON'T buy from the street hustlers), but enjoy the sights and sounds of the main square, the tastes of the juices, the cafes, and the international melange of visitors. You will DEFINITELY not be alone!!!

Mixed Experiences. Gone are the days where you could find amazing treasures in the Bazaar of the Medina. They are far and few between now. What you will find are mass produced products that make you feel they were made in China. Stalls packed with t-shirts, slippers, and tourist junk. If you have a good guide, then you can be lead to some of the great artisans that still source out amazing gems. Do remember that most guides get a kick back from any purchases made, so they will be bias in who they bring you.In the main square of the Medina you will find food stalls, snake charmers and various activities that cater to the tourist. At night it becomes a social place where you have locals gathering to share stories, news events and music. The evening is usually cooler a great way to experience the Medina with the locals.

Interesting to walk around and get lost. It was a fun Medina although the motorized scooters made it somewhat harrowing with children. We enjoyed walking around and seeing what was around. I would recommend a thick skin though since there are a lot of people asking you to come into their shops. Usually they were understanding if you said no but sometimes they could be pushy.
Adventure . Crowded and noisy vendors friendly and easy to deal with even tough if can be intimidating at first. Go with an open mind and enjoy
Getting Lost. You are going to get lost within the Old Medina so be prepared. Try to remember certain signs etc as biscuit crumbs to assist. Look behind you at regular intervals.
Medina at Night. Great Time to visit the square is at night. It comes alive. Food courts in the middle +the souks around the sides. Street food prices. But worth the experience.

Touristic place you have to see. It's worth seeing once in a lifetime, but don't mind if you can't make it. It's very touristic but nice to experience. You should have in mind, that the people there don't have real jobs and they need to be like that to make money for living. It's not comparable to the western culture. I would recommend staying for 2 days, otherwise it will be a little bit boring. If you want relaxing holidays, stay near the desert or at the seaside.

such a good experience. The shopping here is amazing, they love to barter and its all part of the experience so don't feel bad, we bought a few handbags, some bowls, placemats etc.. all worked out very cheap! Its very clean and there are a lot of places to eat around the local area. The further you head into the souks the cheaper it becomes, youll also notice that people leave you alone a bit more which was nice, we got lost and had to try and make our way back, beware of people saying they will help you.. they expect paying for this! One of our friends got tricked into paying for henna as they told her it was free then they wanted 100 MD Really good day out, I would definitely recommend this. We felt really safe and and enjoyed the day.
Very interesting place. As expected a very nice place and a must do upon any visit to Marrakech. Especially lively at nice. Recommend.

Prepare to get lost. The Medina of Marrakesh is very large and it is lovely to wander around, and take in the special atmosphere in the narrow Streets, with so many shops and people. There are many places where you can shop. Prepare to bargain. Also lots of options for food. You will get lost for sure, but there are always people willing to show you the way for a small fee, or oven walk you back to the main square (for a bigger fee).

Interesting. Interesting place to visit, very busy lots of things to look at and buy. Be aware people are friendly and want to guide you around but be careful you end up being caught out and it cost you money. Once you realise this you just tell them politely I'm good thanks they will leave you alone. Defiantly worth a visit

Clean and friendly. Nice CLEAN old market. If you have been to old city markets like chandni chowk in old delhi - its not as busy, more tourist oriented but friendly call outs from locals, no hard sell, very easy going place... Did I mention clean ...

The Medina is a crazy vibrant place - get lost and enjoy!. The Medina is a bizarre bazaar! The central square is full of entertainers - snakes, monkeys, acrobats, dancers and musicians all making a vibrant racket. It's good to see in both the daytime and at night. At night, eat or drink at one of the bars/restaurants around the square and just watch and enjoy! The absolute rabbit warrens of shops around the medina are incredible and it appears most travellers are advised they will get lost! Some ladies staying at our Riad spent about 6 hours within the alley-ways not being able to find their way out! Be aware if anyone helps you they will want paying - agree a price before they take you to where you want to get to.
Justas expected. A fascinating place, endless shops down very narrow alleyways. Very easy to be picked up by a 'guide' but a place.not to be missed

Contolled madness.. At night ...this is a must see....I go to listen to the Story Tellers and the Musicians....Despite the Manicness of the place....You are absolutely safe.....in the daytime there are street sellers ....some musicians and of course the men with the monkey's on chains....Just walk around....take it all in....there is no where else like it.

Take care.. The medina is a amazing place and many will have to pass through regularly, particularly if you are staying in one of the riads.The small narrow dark streets are at first a bit indimidating, however everyone is very friendly and you soon feel safer than you would in england. The only thing to be aware of is looking lost. If you look lost you will be approached my many people giving you directions before then asking for money, the best way to avoid this is to just walk confidently and say you have no money.

Great day out. We spent the day inside the medina, exploring the museums and walking through the Souks. We have two small daughters and it was definitely a highlight when we rented a horse and cart to drive us around. It sounds lame, but locals also use this method of transport! And it was a great way to see more when our legs got tired towards the end of the day.

Hectic market. This is the one place you must visit when in Marrakech,it is so busy and so much to see.There is every thing there juglurs snake charmers accrobats,and much more.All round the square there are plenty of stalls to shop at.

Unforgetable Experience!. Go with an open mind ready for many varieties of colors, smells (good and bad), sights and sounds. Be prepared to get totally lost, but ask for help and people will provide it. You see cobras, other animals, fantastical carpets, all manner of spices, interesting people, lovely jewelry and scarves in every shade of the rainbow. I cannot imagine taking part in this experience and not feeling more alive because of it.Dress conservatively--pants and no low cut shirts, just so you don't stand out too much.We felt safe and just enjoyed. May you do the same.
Relaxing . Great place BargainsFunEntertainment with snakes monkeys and water sellers You can go all the time. Taxi hoarse carriages on demand

Very Hectic but interesting. My hotel was in the middle of the Medina. This is a very busy area full of tourist. During the day you can find fresh fruit carts and street performers. Do not take any pictures of animals or performers with out paying them. They become very hostile and its a little scary. They don't tell you a price but they will be upset if its not enough. At night, there will be all food carts for dinner and of course perfomers. We went back to the same cart every night. The food was soooo fresh. It really had me questioning the food we eat in America. Fun place but the street performers are aggressive .

Read up on Marrakech first. There are some things travelers need to know before going to the Medina or anywhere in Marrakech. First negotiate price before getting into a taxi. Same with anything there, price up front. Next, people here are not like other cities full of tourists. If they offer you directions, they expect you to pay for them. They will also send you to the wrong place and lie saying an attraction is closed. Snake charmers get 20 dirham no more if you take a picture with them. Don't give them your camera. You need to prepare your self mentally. I enjoyed the experience, but found it stressful when people were constantly grabbing at yelling. Get a tourist map, but don't look at it in the open or you will be bombarded by those "helpful" bystanders waiting for money. One of our group was threatened when he didn't give enough. By our third time we were pros, knew where we were going and were able to brush it off. It is exciting, stimulating and a bit scary. Be sure to go at night to see all the entertainment.

Don't trust the locals. We were constantly harassed going down the streets by men telling us certain attractions were closed (they weren't ), trying to charge us for directions, and just trying to get us into their shops.Do not listen to the people on the street, we found a cheap map at one of the local tourist shops that really helped. If necessary go into a local restaurant and order food and ask your waiter for directions. We found that people were most honest and helpful if we had already paid them for another service.
Amazing experience . Unlike any other market/ souk I've visited (included markets in India). Get to see the traditional part of morroco. Heaven for shoppers.

One of a Kind- Great Experience. Amazing, one of a kind attarction. Fire breathers, snake charmers, musicians, magicians, monkeys and all kinds of street performers. I have never seen anything like it. Must see.

Definitely worth seeing, but go to the hidden parts of Medina. Narrow lanes, the main ones overcrowded by strolling locals, sellers, buyers and motorcyclists, the side ones empty. Different smells and perceptions, various goods and alley cats. This is the Medina I liked, where I was the only tourist far and wide and got lost at least five times.There is the other Medina, too. Djemaa el Fna, souks, mosques and so on, all those places are worth visiting, but somehow you feel the fuss is more for you as a tourist. As one taxi driver told me, Marrakech without tourists would die.

Guide helped out alot. We visited the souks in the daytime and got a guide from our hotel who showed us round the different souks and provided us with a bit of history. We could have gotten lost without this and ended up wandering a lot. We didn't get hassled at all and we had a great time. It was like something out of a Terry Pratchett novel!
Safety beware. Be very careful walking round motor bikes zooming in and out everywhere, bit smelly and beware they want to show you round taking you into places you don't want to go.

Decent fakes to buy if you can resist the hassle. Please beware as soon as you get to the medina you will get be swamped by many people including children begging, people offering to show you around for a fee,monkey owners wanting pictures for money. Just ignore and move on.Shop from the indoor markets rather than outdoor as they are much cheaper while selling the same stuff. Only pay 70% of asking price. My wife bought her many fake handbags from the medina. Dont pay more than 100 dirams which is approximately £6.70 for a handbag. I cant comment on the food stalls as we didn't eat from the medina. Overal it was a good experience and in the end I got used to the haggling

Good to see; good atmoshphere. It a must see; to see the atmosphere. I went 3-4 times; but it did get too much. Do recommend the horse and cart tour. Good to explore the souk. Some great stuff but then it gets repetitive. Haggle 30% of the asking price. You feel you got a good deal but only to go to the next shop to find you over paid. Worst part about the medina.

Interesting place but cultural shock. Marrakech was our first stop in Morocco, thus a great cultural shock! The motorcycle, the dust, the cats... are everywhere. It is easy to get lost and taxi driver always offers you an incredible price. It's better to negotiate or you can call "Taxi Vert", which the taxi use the meters, but you need to pay 10 dirhams for the reservation. But all the attractions in medina are very clean and quiet, totally different from outside.

Terrible place for a solo female traveller. I travelled through Morocco for 2.5 months, and the medina in Marrakech and Fez was the places I disliked the most walking around alone. It can be nice to explore (a lot to look and take pictures of) but as a solo blonde female traveller I felt extremely exposed and uncomfortable by all people (read men) trying everything to get contact with me on the streets/shops and comments about my looks.One huge advice. DON'T BUY ANY SOUVENIRS IN MARRAKECH! The prices they try ripping tourists of with are crazy high. If you don't have much time in Morocco I recommend you to at least do a day trip to the beautful tourist costal town of Essaouira where shop keepers overal are much friendlier and have better prices (but you still have to haggle the price down).For example in Essaouira I bought a skin wallet (the ones they sell everywhere at touristy places in Morocco) for 35DH, and I'm sure I could have got it even cheaper if I bought more of them. When I asked about the price in Marrakech many shops started with the price 400DH(!!) for the same wallet. I went to 20-30 shops and it was almost impossible to get it cheaper than 100DH. Very exhausting experience. And I would also be very careful buying argan oil in Marrakech, first of all it's expensive and you can't be sure you get the real deal.

Interesting, but be careful. If you are in Marrakech you must visit here. Markets, food, just a true feeling of Morrocon culture. Amazing! One thing I would say though is be very careful whilst you're here as it can be dangerous. There are many locals who are waiting around for tourists, pretend to be helping them out with directions or recomendations to a place but are actually tring to trick you to more isolated areas like dark alleys to mug you. This is very common. Dont let it put you off just be very careful.

You always buy too much, and you'll most surely get lost...but good luck! It's still cheap, and you'll end up happy!. Here, you'll most cetrainly get lost, bút sometimes it´a good idea to get lost - The Marrakesh Medina is one of those places,,,

This is THE Medina. Get lost! It's so easy to do and the little roads wind endlessly around. All the shopkeepers are waiting for you to buy their wares. They are very polite and very persistent. It's all a game so enjoy yourself. There are various parts that seem to specialise is products. The spice part is amazing. Loved it. The colours are beautiful. You will find a bargain whatever you want. It's just a case of whether your baggage allowance is big enough! Good idea to take a tour first to get an overall idea. Don't get run over by the bikes and carts that push their way through. It's fascinating.

Love it or hate it. Many westerners clearly love the Medina, it is certainly vibrant, lively, full of generally friendly people and like stepping back into history but...I am so glad most of the world has moved on. It is also dusty, noisy, exceptionally polluted and also plagued by by beggars and persistently annoying people who want to be guide. The air quality in the cramped streets from the many mopeds is probably the worst I have ever experienced, worse that Beijing, worse even than Delhi. We got lost as so many people do, shopkeepers were helpful but there were also people loitering around that deliberately send you in the wrong direction so persistent and annoying young men can try to guide you and exhort money from you.If you do not like noise, extremely dirty air and large numbers of unpleasant people but still want a feel for the place put on the DVD of the "Life of Brian", your lungs will thank you for it.

A colourful experience. Winter is a great time to visit the city. The weather is still very warm without the oppressive heat of the summer months. We stayed in the Medina because it is easy to get to all the main attractions from here but if you are staying elsewhere the Medina itself is worth a visit. There are a number of colourful shops, those selling the usual tourist wares as well as the 'everyday' shops such as the butchers, barbers and grocers. There is a real buzz about the place ... Stroll around, stop for a coffee or if you are hungry get kebabs from the excellent street cafes (if you want a good view try the top floor of the Kasbah cafe). I prefer shopping here to the souks... There isn't the huge variety but you can take your time browsing and there are still bargains to be had.

You have to see it for a day. A busy mixture of smells, spices, people and souks. There are a few historic buildings to visit and the Yves St Laurent Garden. We stayed in the Amangena. Too far out. The Mamounia looks the best. Modern part of Marrakesh is very European and great night clubs. Marrakech is clean interesting with very friendly people and feels very safe.

Vibrant and full of movement. Visiting the Medina is an absolutely must if you're in Marrakech. This is where the main market areas are, the snake charmers and many restaurants that serve delicious and authentic Moroccan food. You can't miss it!
Memorable Trip. Love the vibes, the culture, the people, the souk, and overall the sensational medina that I truly admire. Will be back.

Spend a day, or several, there is more history in this one place than most states in USA. The Medina is huge. Full of shops. But this is also where thousands of people live. You have a Jewish quarter, and universities and shops for local goods as well as giant spice markets. And more places to eat than you can count.If you don't have a guide you will get lost. But it is really very safe. The biggest risk you have is deciding you have to buy something to take home and a local merchant will out-negotiate you. But you will have something to forever remember Marrakech.We hired a guide and actually bought all the light fixtures for a house we were building, as well as several rugs from a wholesale merchant. All is either from inventory or made to order and being shipped to us in the USA. If you like Moroccan design you'll never have a better opportunity to buy than here.For food there are restaurants, but there is also a large plaza where the open air shops serve everything from snails to lamb brains -- so if you are really an adventurous eater this place cannot be beat. But, of course there are far more normal foods to be had as well.The spices here cannot be beat. The spice market stretches an area larger than most supermarkets. Again, decide before buying if you are looking for fun or really want to spend money. You can buy real Moroccan saffron for 1/10th the price of anywhere else, or all kinds of the very best spices. Again, if unsure hire a guide because like anything the best stuff costs more but you have to find merchants that cater to the market (and the really good stuff you don't negotiate on the street, but rather in their back shops - and actually if you are reputable and they are reputable the prices are not negotiated on the best spices. But they are far cheaper and better than anything in the USA.)You will be shocked at the size, variety and shear learning opportunities in the Medina. To miss it is to miss Marrakech.

Vibrant and bustling. The Medina is incredibly easy to lose your way around! But take your map and you'll be fine. We stayed inside the Medina in a beautiful Riad, and we got used to the maze of streets surprisingly quickly. It really is a labyrinth of narrow cobbled roads, high walls and buildings. You'll find all the beautiful wares, spices, carpets, cafes, galleries, history, architecture, snake charmers, everything you can imagine in the Medina. Such a feast for the senses!

Get lost!. There are few places in the world where I go to to get lost and this is one of them. Narrow alleyways with shops and sellers of all kinds, wonderful doorways with interesting houses beyond and a constant string of donkey carts, mopeds and people on foot. Always safe and interesting. Go explore!

Bustling Medina. We were lucky enough to stay at a Riad inside the Medina. It really is bustling,colourful , noisy and fascinating place. It can be a bit full on however you soon get used to it. Don't worry if you get lost everybody does. We enjoyed t so much we're going back this January.

Memorable experience but watch out. Its a must experience day and night. Such vibrance and activity so much to soak up. Noteworthy that if you will be pestered and my best advice is ignore them politely. Smile and walk on and do not be offended by sniggering remarks beggars or market traders might say. A lot of traders like to be friendly and expect you to pay them.
great experience. try the food markets at night, cheap and tasty with all the experience that europe just cant offer 5 stars for morrocan people

wonderful maze of streets. so much to buy - so little time
if they ask 600d offer 100d. be firm and having said no they will run after you begging you to buy at your price
Emazing. Medina is amazing! No wonder it is on a list of UNESCO heritage. There you can find literally everything. It made us breathless and amazed. I recommend it strongly.

A huge place with all inside. Marrakesh is if not the biggest , one of the most big cities in Marocco .The old town called Medina represents always the heart of the city , where every time during the day you can see ,admire and enjoy everything , a traditional nice meal , a very good Maroccian drink , some Berber songs and dances , monkeys and Maroccian culture.Everything in one , Medina show around.

Loved my stay. I stayed in a wonderful riad in the Medina, and loved our stay. This is not for package tourists but those that want experiences. I would recommend everyone spend some time in the Medina of Marrakech to soak in this ancient place.

Disappointed. Was advised to visit this attraction both during the day and in the evening as would be very different. We decided to try evening firstwe could hear the music and see all the different light as we approached and it looked magical. However, this was slightly tainted by the smell from the horse & carts. People were very friendly, but if stopped to watcht he musicians for even a few seconds they automatically came to the tourisst looking for money.During the day we had the opportunity to explore more of the side alleys in the market, but be careful as they try and draw you further into the alleyways. Would definitely recommend having a look if close by your hotel, but for me did not match up to the hype. would cetainly not pay £20 or so for a tour.

Don't stay anywhere else!. We highly recommend staying in the medinas a traditional riad if you wNt a true Moroccan experience. The hustle and bustle is not to be missed. We only stayed 3 days but quickly got to know several shop keepers around our riad. It's a glimpse into the past as traditional folks go about their daily business. You need to be alert to the bicycles and motorbikes which rip around but it only adds to the overall experience. A must do!

To many pushy sellers. The medina is a must go for Tourist, but for me it was too stressful.Especially at Jeema el Fna the people try to sell very agressively/ try to convince you to make pictures with snails or monkeys. Sometimes you almost start running when people approch you
Colourfull and busy. People, colourfull, exotic odeurs and a lot of mopeds. Noises, a lot of food and clothes. Tourists and locals. Overwhelming.

Fantastic. What an interesting place to visit, i love walking through all the small alley ways,lots of shops and good food. There is so much to buy and see, the only problem is there is so much you want to take home. I found so many thing that would go really well in my house, but a rug was all i could carry. but the souk is very interesting, and the people are usually quite freindly and helpful.
hastle.. Too many people trying to get you in there premises, watch out being overcharged for henna. Cafes and restaurants very cheap and food tasty, plenty of choice.
Cannot be somewhere more interesting. interesting busy place to be the whole medina is the busiest part. you have to be there to believe it
So cute. I really have a nice time in this Place , I liked it and we had fun , dancing , walking , discovering the souks , its magical

Be ready to lost!. Lovely shops and food stalls but be ready to be lost. If you ask the local guys they might ask you for money before helping. So just follow tourist walking along. Go out of the Medina and if you want super cheap items.

Don't bother going to Marrakech if you don't visit the medina. A fantastic, ancient, vibrant, labyrinth of streets, alley, houses, tumbledown buildings and shops and stalls. Dive into the souks and soak up the atmosphere, but keep heading back to the Jemaa el Fna so you don't get lost in the miles of dark streets and passages. Watch out for the mopeds zipping through the narrow pedestrian streets of the souk at high speed.

Atmospheric and full of interest. From the busy souks to the narrow dark alleys the medina is a wonderful, but confusing place to visit. Wonderful because of the sights and smells and sounds. Confusing because you are bound to get lost.But just go with the flow. Enjoy its exoticism.
I just love it.. I just love the hustle and bustle of the Medina. From all the different souks to restaurants and shops and vendors, it's just great!

So much fun!. I personally loved the medina! It comes alive in the evening and night up until 11pm with a variety of entertainers from snake charmers to locals playing drums and dancing! There are endless food stalls serving street food and the souks are a fun place to be aswell. I know a lot of people do not like the square as it is too busy and you will get approached by lots of locals (it can get a bit annoying for some) but we thought it was a great way of getting a feel of the moroccon culture and meeting the locals! The people in the square are 'over-friendly' but they're very nice. We joined in wight he street entertainers playing drums and also had a go at trying to get the tourists to come to the food stalls!

A 'must' visit in marrakesh !. Don't worry about visiting, just be savvy. Having a chance to hold snakes will cost you a bit unless you are an aggressive haggler , the monkeys are heartbreaking to see (if you care about animals DONT have a photo taken with them please), the henna tattooists are not to be trusted (and one or two will forcibly grab you if they can) but it's wonderful despite these things and we were drawn there every evening. Keep your bag safe, enjoy the mostly friendly people, soak up the sounds and scents.. Amazing place!!!

Exciting, exotic , busy and fun!!. Loved The Medina of Marrakech ! So much to see within those Ancient Ramparts! The Beautiful La Mamounia Hotel & Gardens are a must to see & The Souks are colorful, noisy, and fun! Just beware of pickpockets & people offering you assistance - as some will point you deep into the Medina Labyrinth & once you are lost , will offer to lead you back to the Square - but for a price! So be careful!!

The great market of Marrakech . Be prepared to get swamped by little people and lots of entertainment. A huge variety of food stalls and some really good restaurants all in this area. The market stalls all drive a hard bargain so make sure you banter with them. Most of them will tell you double the price. Overall nice friendly atmosphere just don't get too carried away with the spending
Great spices. The souks in medina are great good for spices. Just be careful as there's a lot of beggers on the street.

Do not go if you do not like harassment. Is a landmark to see yes but if you do not like to bargain and the harassment go to other towns like Essaouira. You will find the same cheaper and without the violence. People can get upset if you look at them, if you try or in my case not to photograph them still they will come asking for money and pretending you photograph them, they speak all languages possible so do not think speaking other than -english for example will do the trick- Be careful at night can be dangerous as it is poorly lighted at night.

Crazy place!. You just have to visit the Medina to get a proper feel for Marrakech and do some people/animal watching. All a little bit crazy so be sensible with valuables (as in any other place full of people), but felt very safe

Attractive. Very interesting and historical city/town that was once an Islamic capital dating back to the 11th century. Narrow alleys are typical in a walled surrounding. Very picturesque and Jardín Majorelle is a few minutes away.

How amazing is. This is one of the most beautiful medina in Morocco, take a rest in Le cafe des epics or just walk around... snakes, monkey and local food will let u feel as a oriental prince or princess.just be careful about illegal guide that try to pick your money for a illegal visit... Drink a orange juice in place jamelnfa and let a woman make a henna tattoo....

an experience at night. Think of your biggest food court - and this is .... much bigger. This is a place where locals and tourists mix together for a social evening.During the day full of hawkers, boys with monkeys and men with snakes, along with the standard stalls

Be carefull. Great experience whatever the price is at least half it and haggle haggle haggle, great fun and very cheap. If you take photo of any snake charmers etc expect to be asked for cash but just say no very firmly and you will be fine enjoy and good luck.
Something different. We had a trip to Marrakesh. With guide.We spending the day in the Medina. Great shopping and nice restaurants. Colorful and authentic .

Beautiful at night. Visited the Medina on my visit to Marrakech this year briefly during the day.As well as last year September during the night. Could see it from a restaurant we visited last year during the evening, and it was beautiful and busy because of the lights. Typical Marrakech with the markets being busy and people calling you in, but wasn't a big deal for me as I was used to this.Will visit over and over on my returns to the city.

The smells, the crowds, the vendors. A trip to Marrakesh would not be complete with spending the day and night in the Medina. The pace is frenetic, the people fascinating, and the Orange Juice is the best I've ever had. Walking around just taking it all in was illuminating and weaving our aye through the Souks was an education. The vendors were friendly and a little pushy but never to the point of being annoying, and everyone was helpful when we got lost. Make time to stop at a cafe to justcwatch the world go by. And don't forget to go to the Medina and watch the beautiful sunset, and see the square become rows and rows of food vendors,BTW at the end of the evening, all the unsold food is given to the poor.

A not-to-be-missed sight. This is, basically, the reason why I chose to go to Marrakech. It is amazing. A lot has been said about the Medina. I did my research before going to Morocco, I read a lot but, to be honest, it wasn't as scary as people described it. Yes, the vendors are kind of aggressive, but they're not THAT bad. Some of the souks are quite OK, the sellers ignored us and let us have a good look at the products before actually buying something. We didn't use the navigator because we simply did not get lost. The Medina is spider-web-shaped, so whichever street you go to, you will at some point end up in the main square. As long as you mind your own business, avoid eye contact and just enjoy the view, you will be ignored. If you feel adventurous and want to interact with the snake charmers or with the other entertainers, negotiate the price BEFORE, not after taking pictures. They're quite sensitive about taking pictures, so respect their privacy and play by their rules. Friendly advice: avoid the place where they park the carriages. The horse smell in day heat is unbearable. Other than that, enjoy the experience, you'll never forget it. I'll definitely won't. PS: I traveled with my husband, no guide, just the two of us. Never felt unsafe. But watch out for the mopeds!
shopping. lovely cheap deals in souks in medina comes to life in evening with the sbake charmers and street dancing

People trying to make a quick buck!. What a beautiful place! Sadly, the sellers/hustlers in the medina make this experience very unpleasant. I went once before in 2007, but I guess I was too young to remember how horrible it was. I was so excited to be there, walking through town, enjoying the great colours and products and I was keen to take pictures of the locals and their products. It's a different reality though.
