As soon as you set foot there, be prepared to be harassed by hustlers. They just cannot let you pass without annoying you with their products. Be very careful when taking pictures, as they would expect you to pay them! People are very keen to offer 'help', but nothing is free - once they see you are a tourist and trying to find your way, they will immediately come and offer 'help', and they expect a lot of money in the end. Also, be careful of young boys who lie to tell you that 'the road is closed', and they will take you round a longer way and then ask for a lot of money in return! You are less likely to get harassed in town though, as most of the hustlers agglomerate around the souk and Jema el Fna area. Be careful of mopeds and bicycles in the tiny alleys as well, as they don't care about pedestrians and are unapologetic as they whizz around. There are some tiny gems if you walk around, especially restaurants tucked away in little corners. This has been a general experience in Marrakech.
Love It. Great shopping , beautiful, great restaurants. Colorful and authentic. Not to be missed with or without guide .Easy to walk through

Something else!. I've seen marketplaces and stalls before, but this was something I'd never experienced. The medina in Marrakech is hectic and busy yet charming and unique, and it's easy to get lost in the catacombes of stalls. Getting hassled to buy things is part of the experience, so expect this!

It transforms at night! . Amazing during the day with lots of alleyways and stalls, but it's at night that you really want to go! The place transforms! The street food and stalls are amazing, definitely eat there. If not, just enjoy the atmosphere! A must see!

crazy. amazing, hire a guide or set a navigater app on you`re phone, sit in one of the café`s around the edge and just watch it all happen,we went in during the afternoon and stayed until early evening,

Very Unique Experience. This place can be madness. The main plaza has a mixture of food stalls, cheap trinkets and snake charmers (always negotiate a price fire photos FIRST). At night it is even more alive. The snake charmers are gone but are replaced with street theatre, events and gaming. It is loud and exciting. The medina is one of the easiest to get around and even though we were warned about issues at night - did not find any issues. A must do...it is Marrakech.

You can do it solo, but a guide is help. We spent an afternoon shopping with a very good guide who brought us to shops I dont think we would have found on our own. Bought some nice art, carved plaster, scarfs and jewelry, plus had an enjoyable lunch on the square. Great place, very fun and as far as we were concerned, safe top. The green canvas kiosks in the open square are the ones with the snake charmers. Eh.
Crazy Place. Good and Crazy place, you can find everthing, but you have to Negotiate, they give to you a expensive price is like 200 hundred and you can get for 40, I like there.

Mad but great experience. We stayed in a riad rafaele in the medina so everywhere we went outside the riad was mad. Small lanes that all look the same so you get lost very easily but we never felt threatened ( 2 women in our 50s) There are so many small shops wanting you to buy from them but we found a firm no always worked. The main square is great ,snake charmers ,monkeys , food stands, cafes, restaurants and always drums of some description so noisy but so interesting and such a laugh!

Exotic, funny and very entertaining.. No meaning try to avoid being sheeted. You will be. Thats part of the deal. Its a market for entertainers, showman, and its happening a lot. All the time. Finding the hand craft souks was a surprise. Amazing what people can do with their hands. Street food was great!!

A must when visiting Marrakesh!. It is just incredibly chaotic, but very entertaining. Food was also pretty good and cheap. Also, in the souks there is always opportunities to find a "gem". But, don't forget to NEGOTIATE price. They are expecting it and you will be surprise how much price can go lower. :)

another world. During the day you can have a very good fresh orange juice and play music with people and snakes, get lost in the small street and find a great typical restaurant and in the night the square turns into a giant restaurant !! great place

What you can imagine ... AND MORE. This median is exactly what you would expect from a median: lots of narrow streets, filled with souks, with thousands of small shops that sell everything you can imagine ... but this one is special.The ambiance is almost of a Ali Baba Cave where all the treasures are hidden ... in this case, ready for you to take them home with you!The only bad thing is the signaletic that is so poor that you will almost surely loose yourself. Don't worry it's not dangerous .. it's just annoying sometimes ... once if you are on a time schedule ... do take care of what you are going ... because if you loose yourself ... you can take some time to go somewhere you know. This is why I only gave the 4* and not 5*
A labarinth. This is a maze of epic proportions, easy to get lost. Lots of surprises - courtyards, shops, cafes, dusty cobble stone streets/lanes/alleys, some manificent interiors.

Busy, busy, busy. Marrakech is worth to spend a day but I wouldn't stay longer. Unless you enjoy tourists around and overpriced food and drinks. It's crowded, especially in the evenings around Djemaa - the main market. Nice experience but there are better places in Morocco.
Main Square. Here you can see what is the real life in Marrakech. Live music and shows going on during the evening. Lots of shopping.

A must, and you will get lost.. Really, the media is a must for all visitors to Marrakech. But honestly, without a guide you will get lost. It is part of the fun, but really if you need to find your way back to your hotel or riad, be prepared to tip a helpful local. It is a fabulous place to wander, but unless you can read Arabic, street signs are of no help, very few are in French. We found ourselves lost on several occasions, and I usually have a very good sense of direction. In order to see more in a shoe=rter period of time, it may be wise to hire a guide.
Stunning overload for the senses! Go!. Staying in the medina is a great experience as you can walk to so many shops and restaurants within minutes. Non stop shopping!

Good vibes but ensure you haggle. Was staying at a guest house in the Medina. There were a lot of shops but you have to ensure you haggle since the prices they quote can be double the price it should be at times. I was fortunate to have a local guide at the guest house to ask what the price of things should be and he also went around with us at times and that made the trip more pleasant. Best to ignore the person selling if you don't intend to buy something.

Great experience. Be careful of the prices. Start negotiating at least 50% off original price. Some areas people pester a lot - just don't respond. Be careful with snake charmers, etc. they will ask for money.
Lovely Atmosphere. Ensure that when travelling to Marrakech you spend some time inside the Medina to explore the little narrow streets and souk. Also do not miss out the lively Jemaa El Fna square

Interesting, but polluted air. Interesting place on Earth. Everybody wants to sell you something, or just get money for giving directions. Do not pay so much attention to them. Good prices if you can bargain hard.Air is polluted by old cars and scooters. A smoker can save many cigaretts by just breathing the air after a scooter has past. Unfotunately smoking is also allowed in many bars, so it gets pretty stinky during the evening. Friendly people and safe.
A bustling city full of hidden treasures. A bustling city full of hidden treasures. Everything from mint tea to snake charmers can be found in the Medina. Worth a visit!!
Nice weekend visit! . Nice to go and stay for the weekend. Just hand luggage needed . Visit a couple of palaces and gardens.
Great places to eat and great vibe. So much energy and atmosphere here it's amazing. You can't viset marrakech and not viset here at least once.

Authentic atmosphere. Go at night and sit in a rooftop cafe to truly appreciate the amazing view and to get a full sensory experience. None of the ubiquitous fast food places to be seen, just local food and crafts and the Moroccan people making their own entertainment families dancing in a traditional way, fez hats being sent swirling or snake charmers on offer. I don't think you can say you've been to Marrakech unless you come here.

Fun and frantic place to shop. We had a guide navigate us through the medina, otherwise we surely would have gotten lost. It is fun, but can be confusing. Also, you should know how much you want to pay for something because prices can be all over the place.

Touristy place but worth the visit. It has become very touristy, and the shop keeps in the souks constantly keep harassing you to buy stuff. Other than that, the Medina is a fun place to explore.The prices for the food stalls are outrageous when compared to other local eateries..

Worth seeing. You can't leave Marrakech without spending a good chunk of time here. I loved it in the end (spent 3 days in a riad Sidi Ayoub in the medina), but was a little overwhelmed at the beginning. It was just the experience and culture shock i was looking for. Felt safe at all times, even while walking around late at night, and found the people watching some of the best ive ever enjoyed. A true delight (and sometimes challenge) for the senses.

Over rated. Better in the evening when all of the food stalls come out to try local dishes and to try snails. big French culture hence the snails!I don't like seeing monkeys chained up for public attraction getting beaten when disobeying owner and snake charmers the people don't care they just want your money.You will be ripped off, some vendors are not interested in haggling just want to rip you off! real shame!

Very expensive trip to the medina. went there with a guide and was taken to the supposedly cooperative argan oil traditional pharmacy. We had an in depth demonstration of all their products and a forced massage we were asked to pay for . The idea of taking a guide was not so wise after all as he took us to all the shops he has an agreement with and of course a commission.

Diferent world. Until you visit this place you can't imagine what you can find there. It's the most wonderful, interesting and pulsing place which I saw. During day quiet normal arabic market full of nice goods and artists, in the dark it changes into big food market. With a such delicious food.

Go your own direction. This was a wonderful, exciting end to our two week trip through the country. Maybe that is why I felt so very comfortable here. It's safe and fun. Great to grab a table and mint tea and just watch the stories unfold. All souks lead to the plaza so as confusing as it looks, it's really not--- not like Fes which is a warren of small alleys and shoulder width streets. Just don't take advice and be lead anywhere. If you ask for help you will have to pay for the assistance. I stayed in a wonderful Riad in the Medina and was comfortable walking back and forth by myself day or night.

amazing. a must see for everyone just be careful how far you go into souks trust your own judgement beware of mopeds that are constent in both directions very narrow if your brave enough venture in it is worth it you will have some try it on just say no thank you they will leave you alone

So much to see. I wondered around in the side streets for hours setting all the different shops, stalls and people.This is the Marrakesh experience people go for. Remember everyone is after your money do be ready to haggle. Even 50% off can still leave you out of pocket. Do the math in your head and think if, would you actually pay that for the same item at home if so go for it.I saw many poor souls getting ripped off but at the very least you'll have a story to tell.I stumbled across a stall with Hawks, turtles, snakes and animal heads for sale. Very bizarre be careful were you wonder.

interesting. Be prepared, you will get hassled, by everyone. It is full on but it is the way it is done I guess. If you take a photo of the square during the day try and do it from a distance, and don't feel pressured to pay if you are not enjoying any of the entertainment. By night there is a lot of choice for food, take usual precautions, however most is freshly prepared.

Haggle Haggle and Haggle some more. Great place to see all sorts of things. Dont try and take pictures without paying. Go in the shops with a price in mind and if you dont get the price you want to pay, leave. Most times the guy will come after you and give you your price, or if not, there are loads of other shops that will.

Fun place to walk around. Had such a great time here wandering around and getting lost! So much is going on and there are so many things to buy/look at/eat! People often want money for helping you out.

A colourful maze of market stalls. It felt like you could wander for ever here and still find more streets of stalls leading from one to another. Easy to get lost if you try to do too much at once. Best to retrace your steps from time to time and get your bearings as it is not good to look lost or unsure. If you do, you will be plagued by people trying to charge for directions or lead you to their choice of shops. Loads to see, with everything from beautiful craft work to mundane household goods and dodgy fake stuff. Quite high pressure selling and can be some rudeness when you are not interested. Prices vastly over inflated for tourists but if you are happy to haggle reductions are achievable. The hoped for experience of a relaxing wander through stalls is constantly interupted by the bizarre experience of motor bikes racing through in both directions in a tiny space. You have to be constantly ready to jump out of the way which takes a bit of getting used to. Some parts have signs prohibiting bikes but this is ignored. Still an interesting experience and recommended. Would have given a 'good' rating if available but for some reason trip advisor jump from average to very good, and motorbike danger makes v good impossible.
Dodgy and crowded. Prices are tripled, food stalls are not hygiene enough and the food not worth it. People with snakes are the worst. Most people are trying to rip you off.

The busiest square in Africa indeed. The medina is beautiful, especially the old part of the city. The square is amazing during the day and night. The diversity of shops, sellers and street entertainers makes every look in any direction exciting. This is my second time there.
the old part of the city. fascinating and atmospheric. unique smell of charcoal smoke and two stroke petrol engines. souks like a maze. take a guide

A complete assault of the sense (in a good way)!. One of the most intriguing, bizarre places I have ever visited. A mix of old and new, however be careful as everyone is after your 'tourist' pennies and nothing is free.Go and explore during the day, get 'lost' just keep walking and eventually you'll find somewhere that looks familiar. Don't stop, always look ahead and plan where you are going - as soon as you stop some helpful soul will try and offer you directions etc. but want some money for their 'help'.Go and find all of the wonderful trinkets, herbs and spices - want to buy something? Be prepared to barter.This place will be an assault on every sense - your sight, hearing, smell, touch and taste. Just make sure you sample everything and be daring - you won't regret it.

Be careful. This market and tourist area has great potential... Keep ur bags, wallets ext at the front of ur body, hold them tight so no motorbikes can do a snatch n grab... Women do not show ur shoulders, thighs, or any revealing body , the men r perverts, I brought a head scarf and a full length dress, wow, nobody bothered me at all.. whatever the price is always offer them half, .... There is a lot of beautiful places here to visit, just watch out for con men... Don't let anyone guide u to places at all...

1920 alleys....but who's counting!. Yes, you can get totally lost, but set up way markers and have fun wandering. Just be sure you have the address where you are staying, and someone will help you find your way out of this fascinating maze.

A sight to be experienced. We stayed in the heart of the Medina in a traditional Riad and this has got to be the best way to experience the magic of Marrakech. It really is an assault on your senses and you are whisked back to Arabian nights. If you don't like crowds and pushy sales people, then it may not be for you, but still has to be experienced. Adjust to the culture, engage with the locals and enjoy the Medina. A word of caution thought, as in any city, safeguard your personal possessions. Moroccans are not all rich and wealthy and crime does exist...someone attempted to pinch my husband's gold chain which was underneath his t-shirt in broad daylight whilst we were with a guide. We were in a quieter part of the Medina and it was opportunistic but nevertheless left us shocked...My OH is 6'2 and stocky so not your average target. The Police were there immediately and the guide proceeded to take us to get his chain fixed and could't have been more apologetic. As I said though, it's a city and these things can unfortunately happen. Just be safe-savvy and you'll be fine.

The amazing colours and smells were spoilt for me... I definitely did not like the animals that were chained in the market square - they looked so unhappy.The amazing colours of and sights were spoilt for me by this, also the people trying to hassle for money.
Great shopping. Everything you can imagine and a few things you didn't know existed. But very aggressive sales people.
medina. palace to see the colours or Marraakesh at night, it get really crowded towards the night and it is awesome
What a experience. What can i say about the markets ,,, good and fun experience, but you will get conned to go to the tenniers, DONT GO ITS A AWFUL PLACE AND VERY SMELLY.. Stay in the Markets

AMAZING Not to be missed. This is an amazing area filled with shops, people, children, animals and who knows what else. The streets are narrow and then wider and then narrow again and they wind hither and yon. I think you could actually manage to get yourself around if you have time because most of the windy narrow roads pour into something bigger, but recommend a guide (a legit one you can find as you enter the Medina). There is actually everything to see. Carpet shops, pottery shops, food of every kind shops, pharmacy's where Argon Oil is processed and probably all other native plants as well, ticky tacky of all kinds for sale, lots of traditional robes and leather shoes. Just beware your pocketbook and decide what you are willing to pay ahead of time. Check the Lonely Planet out or actually this web site for fair prices. Don't be taken in by shysters and then enjoy. Have a cup of sweet mint tea at the top of one of the buildings overlooking the square (probably don't eat) and take in it all. enjoy.

Watch out for the motor scooters!. If you can manage to keep clear of the speeding motor scooters in both directions this is a wonderful place. I bought jewellery, a carpet, some clothes and a handbag. You really do need to be brave bargaining as I have been able to get items for less than half price.

Wow!! You have to go- best at night!. Marakesh is essentially the Medina. Its alive with people sounds sights smells and a wonderful full on bustling experience! With Orange juice stalls street food local produce, souvenirs- you name it they have it. But haggle!!

very busy. I went out to the medina with my kids at night! it was very busy! I eally didn't like it because there were lots of hustlers around. but my kids enjoyed seeing the snake charmers and monkey dressers. we had some fresh orange juice too!

Hustle and Bustle. A great spectacle. Needs to be seen both during the day and night as there are different things happening.During the day it is calmer but still busy. No food stalls.mduring the night, it is full of locals and tourists. I found the food areas a bit overwhelming. Restaurants try and force you into their restaurant. If you want to experience the food go ahead but you can't relax as it is noisy. If you happen to be sitting where you are facing passing crowds you will get people trying to sell you stuff.The one stall where we tried food (117) had very average food. I would imagine they are all the same but didn't try any others so cannot confirm.I would recommend going to one of the surrounding restaurants for a more tranquil experience.I also found walking round the food stalls a bit annoying after a while. Somehow the restaurant workers clocked on we were British and made all sorts of comments in 'British' accents. 'See you later Alligator', 'cheaper than morrisons', etc. I would have preferred to be left alone and see the great food stalls, but people try and pull you in all directions.Still one to see when in Marrakesh.
Beautiful place . We really enjoyed it. Just beware of the horse riders and their prices. I enjoyed the night life trying the meat and socialising with the locals.I highly recommend it.
It's a Labarynth. Be careful of drifting off in the Medina, some locals want money off you to give you directions, and sometimes send you the wrong way

The main market. After reading allot of review on the madina of Marrakech I got abit scared of all the horror stories..I went with my family and found the madina very lively.. Vibrant.. Full of life and music and people from all corners of the globe.. 99.9% off local came across very friendly.. We where offered various things like horse rides. Food's. Kids toys. Clothes by sellers. A very a simple no thanks (la shukran) worked fine... Had a wonderful time.

Worth Visiting. Recommend that you arrive in late afternoon and spend about two hours within the shops so you can leave by no later than 7 pm for safety reasons, as it's easy to get lost and then find your way out to the main square. Then enter the main square for the nighttime activities, which is a very different experience than the main square activities of the daytime. Well worth the visit to have this unique cultural experience.
hectic place. Nice to see all the people at night. The Moroccans like to be there.There are a lot of activities and a lot of food stalls.

great bargins. the souks are a must place to visit during your time within Marrakech. there is over 16,000 shops to visit, with items ranging from handbags to trainers, to leather, to rugs, to metal work. over all a must thing to do on your list

Hustle&Bustle. Marrakech Medina was a disappointment for us. You are constantly harassed by sellers trying to get you into their shops. Motorbikes ruled the narrow streets and you had to be very careful. General speaking an uncomfortable experience, I would say. We are not inexperienced travellers but Marrakech has left us putting a line through further visits to Arab countries.
Good fun. All narrow streets (more like alleyways) with lots of people and mopeds being driven up and down. Haggling essential. Didn't bother with a guide, didn't need one.

A must see.. I went to marakech with my mum on a day trip as we stayed in agadir. It was a long trip from agadir 3 hours. We arrived in marakech it was one of the most craziest places I've ever been but a must see experience. Markets everywhere in the main square and up the side street, you can watch them at work making leather shoes, bags, jackets, wood carvings, silk scarf. Some beautiful things. The side streets around the souks are very tiny and motorbikes go through so be careful when waking round. The main square has lots of food stalls and shopping. You can really haggle down we got people from 600 dinah to 100 so think what u want to pay and stick to it. There are lots of people with monkeys, snakes music and dancing but be careful taking pictures they will expect a tip. We watch the sunset set across the square itv was beautiful. There is a bar that has a roof terrace well worth a visit as you get the best view. Brilliant place a tick in the box.

So much history in one place. I love how the Medina changes from day to night, it's amazing. It is probably an unique place with all those narrow streets with shops. For me it was a great experience to see how untouched life remains in Marrakech

Loved all the hustle & bustle. It was very nice to go and see, fun to haggle and the only place I know where fresh orange juice is cheaper than water! The food is also cheap here and the leather bags and shoes :) A shoppers delight! The only let down was that there was a lot of hassle so best to go with family or partner- definitely not for girls alone. Would not recommend girls going alone at night! Somebody tried to steal something out of my friends bag!

Should visit but with caution. Read online and advised by hotel staff to visit here at night after 7pm and it was lively but, for me, not in a buzzing kind of way. People were shoving menus in our faces and blocking our paths to get us in the stores - which was off-putting.We went there again in the following morning and it was less crowded but also less stores (but that could be because that was a Sunday). No offence intended, but I felt it was easier to build a rapport with the older merchants and negotiate in a friendly manner, with the younger ones I felt like their flirtatious approach and cornering you was not cool and made me less likely to buy from them (they didn't like to negotiate too but that could be because they are not the store owners...who knows...)The horse carriages look cool but it did not smell nice - holding our breaths waiting for the cab.Having said that, I think the square and the souks are the heart of Marrakech and would recommend to visit. Better with a large group for safety and to help haggle.

Travel back in time to narrow streets of Medina. Google has not yet managed to map Medina accuratly hence do not try to drive a car in Medina. Feel free to hire a bike and you will have access to the whole Medina.You will get lost in medina and locals will try to help you by guiding you on there bikes. But beware everything in medina will cost you money. Nothing is free in medina.You try to park you car in free parking and someone will come asking for money saying we kept an eye on your car to keep it safe while you were away so pay us!!!!Fake parking attendents with high vis jackets specially near shops and restaurants in new town. i.e. Guilez

Full of scams. Be aware of endless scams there! From the moment you get off flight and taxi, scams follow you. i was standing far away from some guys watching them showing off their snakes, then out of nowhere some guy put a snake around my neck and asked for money!  The airport is bad as well. I lost my luggage there and when I went to pick up my luggage the next day, I had to wait for almost an hour for the staff to come back to office. Overall very bad experience to Marrakech. Will not recommend no one to go
Charm & stress. Too many motorbikes and street sellers, but worth 1 visit. Keep your belongings close and don't stop. They don't accept no for an answer everytime...

Vibrant. We were staying out of town and paid an afternoon visit. By day, there's a bit of a bustle (not to be confused with the Souk per se, which is off the Medina Square) but once the late afternoon early evening sets in, the square becomes alive. I've never seen so many snake charmers in one place and the drummers set the beat. Fresh orange juice from a myriad of sellers is a welcome thirst quencher and allows one to stand and just watch the crowds. A fun place which we can't wait to return to ...

Interesting to say the least...loved Morocco!. Busy Busy Busy...but very cool experience. Be careful with eating the food their as my friends and I got sick from the water. Stomach pain and bathroom runs like no other. But if you're looking to bargain, this is the place. You have friendly guys and OVERLY friendly guys. Safe place needless to say. The kids are cute that come and beg for money...very smart and friendly, but they won't leave you until you give them at least 1 dirham.

Be careful snatchers on motorbikes. Snatcher on motorbike just at entrance to walled city! We were walking going back to hotel when 2 young lads on motorbike passed through and grabbed my bag. Luckily, I was holding my bag itself tight that he was only able to grab the strap which got ripped off from my bag. My bag broke but lucky enough that I got my stuffs. Staff in hotel said its common especially after 6pm. Puts me off going to the walled city.

Busy but a true traveller experience. It can get busy with moped drivers whizzing past and it is not sanitised for tourists, but I enjoyed staying in the medina and finding little shops and cafes to visit. Well worth staying in the medina as I did in a beautiful riad (Dar Nour El Houda, I reviewed separately). Overall, I highly recommend the medina area. You can spend days exploring the alleyways and finding new things. Great for taking amazing photographs too.

Interesting busy crazy place. The medina is an amazing place full off everything you can think off. It is a maze and you will get lost but that's part of the experience. You must stay in the medina for a real experience ...
Fantastic. A fantastic place to visit and to stay. Bustling all day and really comes alive at night. Great holiday

Visit in the afternoon. Visit in the afternoon so you can stay out and see the square in the evening. The souks start to close from 6pm.If you want to buy something really bring the price down. You cant buy anything as cheap as you thought an they always start with a ridiculous price ie 1200dhs for a scarf is a STUPID price no matter what they tell you it is not the real deal!! A freind managed to get a scarf down to 20dhs!! There are lots of back streets which I recommend looking down as often there's something unexpected down there.If your're friendly with your taxi driver or a local, try and get them to recommend places (even if it is a friend of theirs) as they are usually the best places. The sellers are pushy and can get a bit angry if you want something for a lot less than they want. If this is the case then just walk away.

Medina of Marrakech. Amazing fresh orange for 4 dirham and lots of people watching! Lots of things to buy and people are all very friendly. It gets very busy on a Friday and Saturday night but it`s a very interesting place.

Wonderful Medina of Marrakech. The long winding lanes of the Medina offer hours of fun and shopping at the souks and shops is a great experience. One can always stop for a bite and refreshing mint tea ! The food at the city center at night is awesome !
Reason for coming to Marrakech. All types of humanity can be seen and heard ! Great for people watching.Something special. Packed with history.
Busy Medina. Very busy place to visit and probably easy to get lost in but a must in Marrakesh. The smells of the spices and herbs, the colours of fabrics and leathers are a must to see.
Where every sense awakens. Taste the orange juice, smell the kebaps cooking, see the snakes being (un)charmed, hear the call to prayer, and feel Marrakech.

Great for people watching/crowds, but leave your valuables and bags in your hotel. It's fun to come here both during the daytime (for sightseeing and shopping) and also at night for watching people and maybe eating at one of the stalls.Just be aware the snake, monkey, and henna artists can be aggressive and demand payment just for looking or watching others get taken.If you come at night leave your bags in your hotel room and use common sense. It's a carnival atmosphere and quite crowded.You can get dinner at one of the many (safe to eat at) food stalls, but be aware you'll likely be presented some breads and olives you think are free but they'll charge you if you eat them. Know what you want and how much you'll pay for it. If your offer isn't accepted, walk away.You can take the public bus here (very easy and cheap) or hire or horse carriage for a ride around Marrakech.
crazy shopping. went to the medina by day and eve .more shops in daytime.lots of bartering but fun to do .you have not been to marrakesh if you not experienced the medina

Not a nice chaos.... It was ok. Would have been much, much better if we were just left alone to enjoy the chaos...been to Hong Kong, Shanghai and Istanbul e.g.: so I know chaos, or at least thought to know it...Marrakech therefore was a dissapointment! Too bad!

Shop till you drop. You have to be up for it, but we absolutely loved the busy little streets of the medina with all the little shops. In a little while you become a hassling expert and the game with the shopowners is on. I loved the shops with the leather bags, especially the really big ones were the most beautiful I've seen in Morocco

Too many mopeds.. Lovely old cobbled alleyways, wall to wall shops all completely spoilt by mopeds. The fumes were so bad we couldn't wait to get out. Much prefer the Medina in Agadir.The square however was amazing, so much too see made up for the traffic in the Medina.Don't look at the snake charmer for too long or try to take a sneaky picture as you will end up with a snake wrapped round your neck.

A market with everything one could ask for .. the market area was fun to walk around in and select those beautiful take home items which just might overload your luggage. Fun, good shopping, great artists of all kiinds, safe, and local food areas.
Colourful and busy. Have fun bartering but only if you def want to buy! Know what sort of price you are willing to pay! Don't buy in first stall, look around

Amazing. Different to view between day and night, night comes alive with sounds, smells and culture, day time more quiet but visit still worth it. Snake charmers around in daytime (not night), beware though of people charging you for dancing, henna and monkeys, including taking any photos as nothing is free. Great café on edge of Medina behind food stall 15, great food at great prices!

Great for the atmosphere. Great for a spot of shopping, food & general atmosphere of Marrakech. I just didn't like all the very rude and aggresive henna women who would constantly try to grab your arm. The snake charmers were fascinating to watch, but not for too long as again they try to approach you, but not really aggressively like the henna women. The food market seems a good shout & there are loads of good priced restaurants with great views

Completely Bonkers! But Loved It.. Well where do you start with this Place! A really amazing place. The square is a must place to visit, entertainment by day and when the sun goes down a foodies paradise erupts. I can not say enough about it a very enjoyable experience. The sights the palace, mosque, smells and noise something you will never forget. Shopkeepers speak english good enough and barter your way to anything. Not for the faint hearted but even a beginner will have no issues. Abundance of items for sale lots of testaurants and cafes. Many nationalities walking around. The usual things to be aware of pickpockets and ladies carry a bag over your shoulder. Just think keep bag against you and men make sure it's in a pocket buttons are better but then it's the same in any city. Really is a place you don't want to miss.

Enjoyable Visit. This place is amazing and busy. It is crowed but there are great bargains to be had. However, there are some shady people and pick pocketers are thrive. Then again, what part of the world isn't there pick pocketeers?There is a restaurant nearby with a balcony where you could take great photos of the entire market area. If you want to explore and experience Marrakesh to its fullest, then this is a place you cannot afford to miss.

Snake Charming. Something that everyone should probably see and experience - once. Not just a couple, but lots of snakes - some poisonous (cobras) and something that looked like rattlesnakes with the rattlers cut-off. Others I guess are non-poisonous since they are wrapped around the handlers’ necks. Sometimes they want to give you the opportunity to have it draped and wrapped around your neck. I’m not necessarily afraid of snakes but not excited about getting too close or especially having it draped around my neck. The problem is as the crowd grows everyone starts pushing forward to get a better view. Either you end-up too far away and can’t see or you end up way too close. Workers (men roaming the crowd) can also get very aggressive trying to get you to pay for taking photos.

Great Experience. I love Marrakesh, I love the colors, the noise, the people just walking around. My only problem is that some vendors they do not leave you alone and follow you annoying you. The other thing I did not like was the Henna ladies, which just grabbed your hand and started designing on your skin and would not let my hand go until I paid her. Lesson learned, always have your hands carrying something or in your pocket.

Busy market. I don't like busy crowded places so this was not my number one choice. But, I'll try and be impartial. We visited in both the day and the evening and the evening is by far the most interesting time to go. All the food stalls open up and the vendors try and charm or cajole or gently force you to eat at their stall. Their English is amazing (as is their Spanish, Italian and of course French) and one guy even had a cockney accent! They are real charmers and you'd have to be made of stone to not want to at least talk with them, even if you don't want to eat there.The place fills with local people at night and the smells and sounds are mesmerising. The stall we ate at (Chez Simo) served nice hot food at a reasonable price and apparently Rick Stein had eaten there and loved the food; they had photos to prove it! :)There's a couple of disturbing things going on like monkeys on collars and leads being paraded about and then being kept in teeny tiny cages, but we just stayed away. In the day it's less engaging, it's just full of people trying to sell you stuff. As you'd expect I suppose. But you have to develop the ability to politely and firmly say no and most traders are pretty good about it. Spend some taking to the traders though and you won't regret it. They're mostly very charming and interested in actually talking to you as well trying to sell you something. You'll learn a lot more about marrakech that way. All in all I'd say it's worth a visit in both the day time and the night time as you get to see both sides of life; during the day - the echoes of the call to prayer and the tang of freshly squeezed orange juice; during the night - the smells of grilled lamb and vegetables, the shouts of the food stall holders and the impromptu drummers and musicians.

So many things to see and absorb. I so loved this place. Every few feet has something new to experience. People, architecture, history, quirks.The art styles, the carvings, I could rave forever.There seems no logic to the passages and streets but now I know it was done to defy and confuse invaders it makes sense.A fantastic place.
Great atmosphere. Great evening eating out in the square. Wonderful atmosphere and the souk was amazing. Everyone was so friendly

Jardin Majorelle - THE BLUE HOUSE. Most wonderful visit, calm & enchanting, berber museum, gardens, coffee shop, loos, shop selling silver jewellery, scarves and leather goods (not souk prices), book shop. Definately have your camera, underfoot is fine so any shoewear is great

Amazing market. the medina is great for shopping and food, don't be afraid to barter to get the best possible price. Sometimes its even best to just start walking away. I found a lot of the shopkeepers understood a bit of english, so you can get by without needing to know french or arabic. Can be a bit overwhelming at first as people will say whatever to try to get you into their shops and may seem pushy but my advise is just to tell them no and keep walking if you are not interested.

Interesting, but there are better.. All old cities of Morocco have a Medina area (the center of the old city usually with in the city wall). Most median have streets designed several hundred years ago to walk or if you were rich, ride a donkey through. As such, they have narrow winding streets (alleyways really) that invite you to discover what is around the next corner. In Marrakesh, the streets are a bit wider than other Moroccan city Medians which has encouraged the local population to ride motorbikes in the Medina at top speed. As such what is generally around the next corner is a motorbike ready to run you over. Also, with Marrakesh a very popular tourist destination, the shops are numerous. In general they sale mostly Moroccan made products, but be prepared to bargain hard. The Medina in Fez and Meknes were much more enjoyable, slower paced, and all the shopping, local color and history you could want. They do not have, however the central plaza with it's snake charmers and Orange Juice stands that Marrakesh has.

Jemma el Fna is an exciting experience but take care. This square is exciting and fun but pickpockets are a threat. My trouser side pocket was unzipped, but fortunately thats as far as he got before I realised what was going on. Needless to say he was off in a flash but it wasnt a good experience.Most people in the square are there for fun and there are lots of tourists about. My advice would be to arrive just after dark when things get going and leave around 9.00
Great visit. Amazing sights and sounds in the medina. Lovely place where you can do great shopping. Highly recommended to visit when in Marrakech.

Walking in the Medina. The Medina contains but is more than the souks. I liked heading south and to the east (not as far as the infamous Tanneries) where the relentless pestering to buy look, stop etc eased off, In one part I passed a number of workshops where they appeared to be making some of the metal, wood and artefacts they sell in the shops, Ok you still needed to look confident even when you were lost but occasional directions did not come with a request for a tip but were given freely and pleasantly. There was one little place where an old guy appeared to have his 'studio' and his paintings were from the naive school of art but he gave me directions from his hovel and I wish I had tipped him. There were lots of alleyways and deadends with garages being used by busy work people and donkey carts, a lot of work took place on the street etc. I went down one particularly busy road of garages only to find it was actually a dead end - walked back with purpose. There were a few cafes etc as you wandered around but nothing much that I saw. However it made a nice change from the frenzy and hassle of the souk area and it was nice to see local people in their milieu. I would recommend it if you don't mind walking and getting a bit lost for a while.
Must do. Despite it being so busy it is well worth it. A unique experience . Lots to see and buy. Lovely mosques.

A Crazy, Romantic Adventure. Traveling as two Americans, we were a bit weary of traveling to Marrakech and staying in the medina. After arriving, I am so happy we chose to stay there. What a magical, crazy experience that I can't wait to repeat. We felt very safe and welcomed, albeit we did have to keep an eye out for mules, moped, carts and cars but I would have been devastated if we had traveled so far and not experienced the hectic walled city. If you are travelign to marrakech and you want the true experience, make sure to spend some time there or even better, stay there!

Good bibe. It's where all the hustle and bustle begins in the evenings. Just keep your wits about you and your belongings safe. Do t feel too offended by the guys trying to entice you in to their shops or foods stalls, if you are not interested just say that you've eaten. Don't be afraid to bargain but be realistic - it's all part of the fun. Note you will be asked for no et if you take pictures with any of the entertainers I the square be it animas or human.
A must!!. You can't go to Marrakech without going to the Medina! Buzzing, atmospheric and a visit at nighttime is a must!!

Crazy, character-filled, and hectic. Enter the Medina with brave ambitions, then get thoroughly lost-it's all part of the Morocco experience! Don't be too afraid of getting lost- there's always a petit taxi to rescue you if required.
love it. loved every thing about this, haggling different sounds and smells, bargains galore. only one snag is you do get hassled but say la which means NO. You will get lost maps duh !!!.

This is what you come to expierence in Marrakesh.. You have to experience the medina. I was on a tour and pretty much marched through the streets and passageways. I couldn't possibly retrace my steps. I'm not a shopper and I already have enough junk. You would have to spend a lot of time here to find any quality products but it is fascinating to see all the junk.

Buzzing.. Packed full of atmosphere and charm.
The place is manic, chaotic and a lot of fun!
A must visit in Marrakech.

Forget your map. Forget your map and get lost in the Medina! You will always find your way home - as long as you know where home is! A taxi around the Medina back to your Riad (or the parking place nearby) should cost between 30-50 Dirhams - check the rate before you get in the taxi
Amazing. What an amazing place but nearly impossible to find again something you wanted to return to!! Lots of bargaining to be done.

This place is crazy!. We stayed right in the Medina for a week and overall loved the experience. Never have we seen a place so vibrant 24/7! However, it can be overwhelming so if you are staying nearby, it is important to take breaks from the craziness either from a rooftop cafe or even in your room. Definitely watch your wallet as my husband was nearly pick pocketed in the evening while we watched the numerous side shows that go on at Place Jemaa-el-Fna-square. A few tips: Do NOT under any circumstances, let anyone "guide" you to where you need to go. Nothing is free in Marrakech and "helpful" people will expect a payout of $5-$10 or they can get nasty. Don't ever ask for directions. Take your map(s) and figure it out or you will have to pay someone who offers "help".Wait at least 2-3 days before you buy anything. I promise, you will see the blouse you love at 5 other places for 5 different prices and you have to give yourself a day or two to learn how to bargain. Start by cutting the price at least by half.Prepare yourself to be hounded every two steps for good or services. There were days I wanted to scream.Take time away from the craziness. Spent a few extra minute sitting in a garden or having a coffee away from the crowds. It will help your sanity. Finally - Enjoy - It is truly an amazing experience!
Trendy at some places. and rough at others. Some nice Boulevards with expencive chic areas only to be offset by very poor and impoverished downtown neighborhoods.

Lose yourself. No, seriously, you'll get lost.. What an adventure. You can buy nearly anything. And the merchants will tell you to come in to their shops "just to look" and you will be stuck because of the salesmanship and genuinely welcoming attitude. You may be offered tea. It will really be hard to refuse, so prepare yourselves. The Medina is a sensory bomb. Every alley smells different, some wonderful with spices, some barfy with leather tanning. Lots of colors and sounds and people. People walking. People on bikes. People on mopeds. A lot of people on mopeds. Somehow the chaos works. The Medina is laid out in perfect square blocks, all bright and streets well marked. I'm kidding; it's an labyrinthine and nearly anonymous system. You will get lost. Accept it. It's just part of the experience. Folks are very helpful and you'll eventually find your way out, theoretically. There are many restaurants and "bars" scattered about. It's fun to take a seat and watch the crowd. I put bars in quotes because, as far as I could tell, no one actually serves alcohol, though they all advertise mixed drinks. Also, don't take a picture of people unless you ask permission. We learned this the hard way after being pelted by small rocks thrown from the hands of several 8-10 year olds. If somebody does come up to you, perhaps dressed in traditional Berber clothing or holding a snake, and you take a picture with them or of them? You will have to pay them. It's fun. Lots of people. Generally very safe (watch for pickpockets), and a hoot.Now, go get lost.

Great. The Medina is the central district of Marrakech. It's easy to walk around to see many of the main sights and although you may get harassed by people trying to sell you stuff, for the most part I felt perfectly safe. Some parts of the Medina are beautifully tended to and look really lovely, other parts look really run down and abandoned. It's a great way to get a feel of the city though

great people. been here no have dinner, in one of the little diners right on the entrance of the medina..the best tanginess of my life! be were the locals are, pay the local price and be overwhelmed with this friendly and heart full people of morocco

The "real" Marrakesh. A must do if you are in town. The narrow streets, full of donkey carts and mopeds are a bustling noisy scene. How they miss each other and the pedestrians is a miracle! I was a bit suspicious of the providence of some of the designer goods on sale.

Wonderful atmosphere. Very different experience from other holidays, although we were constantly hassled to buy we did not at any time feel intimidated or threatened, well worth taking tea in an upstairs cafe to watch the sun go down.

It is very good, but not so good as in Fes. Medina of Marrakech not so big and crowded as Fes, however, you make a picture with a snake or monkey, buy tagine, drink fresh prepared juice. Better buy argan oil from farmacy - less chance to buy fake one. Near medina walls located fleamarket, where people try to sell very old and broken staff, we got there accidentally, when we left rented car near of one unnamed medina enters, and cannot find it even with GPS. So, we were going around half of medina, checking each entrance, until we found our car. It was tiresome, but looks inevitable, every guide book tells you, that you will lose your way inside one of medinas

Must to go!!. Madina is great. Must to go if you are visiting Marrakech, Best to go in evening to avoid sun. We went there for food, shopping, KFC, just walk around, fresh orange juice and mint tea.Spent most of our time at madina and loved it!!

Interesting North African city. Visiting from Britain we had a slight culture shock on arriving at the Medina. Some parts are beautiful but others are run down and desolate. It's very busy, which is interesting but be careful not to overdo it as it can become stressful after a while. Locals will pester continuously although not usually in a threatening way. As a fairly reserved English couple we were often taken aback.

Get lost in the Souks. Wow is all i can say......Marrakech is an amazing not to be missed experience. Just get out into the souk and do get lost....cost you will...its only by getting list you see the real Marrakech. We stumbled on the leather tanning area, the tin market...check out the food for locals there....lift the lids on the food and smell those spices. Watch out for the low flying storks nesting in the chimneys in one area we found near the city gates. Go for a carriage ride....inexpensive and well worth the tour all round the city and into the expensive Palmeira area. Ask the guide to visit the "trout pool"...it will be a great surprise. Enjoy it......a holiday to remember!

One of the most exotic places in Northern Africa; but a outrageous negligence of Marrocan people preserving the city. This is an historical place, a true patrimony of Mankind and of world culture. You can see and participate in the living History that is made everyday in the Medina. But is really criminal the negligence in preserving the Medina. The pollution is almost unbearable; the traffic is cahotic; and specially the monuments are left without care. The Badi Palace has been abandoned for decades; probably now it is too late to restore it. This is a crime against world culture and should be punished.

Charming. Watch out for the snake charmers they take your camera, sunglasses to extract more money. They agree a price but take more photos and want more money. Everyone who stopped had a problem with the agreed price. Appart from that most people are OK with a polite no thankyou in any language. Its an amazing place day and night

Busy, historic, not for the faint hearted. If you like crowds of people, monkeys on leads, snakes being charmed and people begging, then the medina is for you. The medina is full of shops selling a variety of goods from spices to handbags to turtles. Although it's quite safe, I'd definitely advise to walk around in a pair. The place smells, the horses pulling the carts look poorly and it's not a place I'll be visiting again!
Amazing. This visit is full of history and culture. It takes a couple of hours At least but it is worthy to walk through the tino streets and different neighborhoods inside the medina.

an explosion of colours!!. all your senses will enjoy the old medina in Marrakech. the smell of the square and the labyrinth of alleys with colourful items they are selling, may it be leather goods, tea pots, spices, home decors etc etc. its simply amazing. ones does need to learn to haggle. never pay the full price of item.

Not a place for a single blond female. On my trip to Morocco we visited quite a few Medinas before we made it to Marakesh. Having such a wonderful experience in Chefchaouen, Fes , Essaouira etc, I was not prepared to be harassed like this and almost run away from that place. I did have a map of this place on me and with its help I was hoping to find the Museum Of Marakesh and the house of photography. Almost the minute I left the central souk, some guy started following me and trying to tell me where I shoul go. I toke him thank you but I don't need your help. He kept following me, trying yo talk. I felt I had to stay polite but I kept on telling him I do not need his help. Twice I went inside the stores just to lose him but each time he would be waiting for me tight by the store. Once i got to a place with no tourist in sight, he told me he wants money, and when I told him that his expiation is not going to be a success, he started swearing and yelling at me. I had to almost run away from there just to get another young kid following me again.... And then again... I felt like crying and I left this place not seeing anything or buying anything...

The heart of Marrakech. The medina is a beautiful hub buzzing with culture and traditions. You will find an array of souks selling spices, olives, traditional clothing, footwear and lots of specially hand crafted goods. The street vendors have food stalls which are a real hive of activity at night. You can pick any of them for a similar dining experience. They will all reach out to you as you walk past and whilst they may come across pushy.. it's all good fun.. just smile and keep walking if you're not looking to eat. The medina gets packed at night with tourists. As usual. Just be mindful of your belongs and you will be fine. It is a safe place to go and is frequented by families. Always barter with the shop keepers.. it's the done thing. Morrocons are nice people in all.. just be friendly and upbeat and play the game. Don't feel like you're being conned. They're competing for income like anywhere else. The snake charmers will approach you if you look too hard or take pictures.. of course if you want to see the show.. stick around. As is also the case with monkey handlers.. just be politely adamant and say no with a smile and keep walking by. Again.. if you want to have the monkey on your shoulder.. stick around. The name of the main square is jemaa el efna. Any taxi will know how to get there.. but make sure you agree the fare before getting into the cab. It is a good idea to ask your hotel staff what a reasonable fare is. 30-40 dirhams on average. The orange juice is freshly squeezed and for 4 dirhams it's silly not to try it. Stick to bottled mineral water. As for food, the foodstalls have a huge variety from grilled meat to seafood and tajine. To be honest, they're all the same taste wise and price and from my experience.. fairly safe to eat from. In summary, the medina is a vibrant and colourful place which really comes alive at night. Just show due care and be alert and you will have a special time in a very special place. I highly recommend going. (I normally hate crowded places)

Amazing day and night. You will get lost but it's worth it! Shop after shop, souk after souk... it's incredible and you still won't see it all. Every time we went, we found a new area and new shops. From the people to the spices to the food to the ceramics or the brass/copper and the jewelery or the scarves.. whatever you need! Don't forget to eat at Chez Lamine while you are there, if you can find it! Ask for the mechoui!

Atmospheric, historic and very genuine. Inside the old city or Medina, of Marrakech is a wealth of history. It encompasses so much including the Mellah which is the jewish quarter and other various districts. Dozens of mosques, the souks and winding alleyways crammed with shops and artisan workshops. Cafes, riads and inns. The center of old Marrakech. You can't miss this!

A medley of sights and sounds. The Medina is a cacophony of sights and sounds.A fascinating place which is alive with people going about their daily business on a bike or moped, tourists wandering around with maps completely lost. We loved every minute of it. There is so much to see and do, wonderful sites to visit and excellent places to eat.
An eclectic mix of cultures where old meets new. Experience the market place in both daylight and darkness as they are so different. Be firm but courteous to the traders as it is their livelihood

EYE POPPING. Everything you could ever wish to buy in the souks. Cheap, cheap, cheap.Haggling is expected but start at about one third of price quoted and enjoy. Dont be too mean as really things are much cheaper than at home.

An amazing experience. The Medina of Marrakech is the most amazing labyrinth made easier if you have a copy of Souk Facil', and while this doesn't guarantee you will find your way around it does help in locating specific sights. The stallholders touting for business can be irritating if you let them, however by just accepting that's how it is can make the experience easier. There are signs and eventually you will find your way to the Jemaa el Fna regardless of how lost you seem.
Busy day and night. No matter when you go here always something to see or at night eat. Local food. Lovely freshly squeezed orange juice

Getting lost in the Medina is an adventure everyone must experience!. You'll be rewarded with delicious food and mint tea wherever you may sit and rest or shop. Study the maps to get the most out of your medina shopping.

Over-rated experience. The Medina of Marrakech was one of those experiences that I have wanted to have for several years, especially after hearing so many interesting things about it! However, I was disappointed. I imaged 25-30 years ago, this place would have been an amazing experience, but there are other places in the world where you can eat street food, get hassled to buy poor goods and be entertained (and ripped off) by dancing monkeys and snake charmers. I decided to visit the Medina twice during my stay, just in case, I had got it wrong the first time, but sadly, I was right. Over-rated, predictable, and a real let down. Sadly, the power of money, and not one of promoting their wonderful culture, food and history is the real driver these days.
Eye Opener. Inspiring look at how a large population culture can live and survive in the desert. Everything needed for life is available in one place. Living as a minimalist and surviving.

Awful. But a muss see. . This is the most awful place. The people are rude. It's dirty. It's noisy. You can get killed by the motorbikes, have your pockets picked, be scammed into buying stuff you don't want, be lied to. But you have to go. It's amazing. The rules:-try to look as little like a tourist as possible. No maps. Keep your camera hidden. You're less likely to be jumped on. - develop a "come near and I'll kill you" look. - look like you know where you're going. - know you'll get lost. Just go with the flow. You'll pop out somewhere soon. Don't EVER ask for directions. You'll be lead to a shop who will pressurise you to buy. - keep walking. - don't follow anyone's instructions - ignore the people who try to get your attention- don't take your phone or wallet. Keep your cash hidden. Then you won't worry about being pick pocketed. - drink the orange juice and try the snail soup- know you'll probably get the squits afterwards but don't worry. It'll go- stay well clear of anyone with a snake, monkey or playing an Instrument- enjoy!!!
Lively and busy. Lots of things happening throughout the day. There are lots of food stalls and fruit bars. Haggling is the norm.

Many corridors. Medina in Marrakech is a phenomenal place with many corridors featuring specialty souks.it is a real show especially at night. Night market is noisy, colorful and a real experience. But watch out for pick pockets. Photos of people is not acceptable. Some people will ask for money for a photo. Can be a mass of humanity. Do not miss it!
Crazy fun shopping. You can buy anything at the Marrakech Medina. They will start really high on the prices, use the walk away technique to get your price.

Wonderful atmosphere. This really is a must see, I would suggest either going down early enough to eat and really take in the atmosphere or go down and sit on one of the roof terraces and sip mint tea watching it all go off. It really is quite something to wander around and see the crowds of locals as well as tourists, listening and watching, playing games and generally enjoying themselves.

Great experience not for
The faint hearted. We all love a bargain and as long as you are willing to haggle that's what you will get in this world of fabulous and entertaining shoppingAdvisable to keep money and expensive cameras etc well hidden from the public Always pay at least one third of the original asking price And don't take any free items that young kids may offer you as you will end up paying for them All in all its a experience you won't want to miss

Fantastic Mahem. Inside the old city walls is the medina. There are hotels, shops, narrow streets and a large square. It is what you go to Marrakech for. You may get lost, you may be persuaded to go somewhere you didn't want to go to, but it is all part of the experience. The large square at night is total madness - sellers, and food stalls - but it is wonderful. Just a word of warning - watch out for the moped in the pedestrian streets.

Strolling around the Medina was like a step back in time, quite magical. The medina is like nothing you have ever experienced. It is a true assault on the senses. We walked the Medina without a guide and felt safe. It is easy to get lost but we always found are way home

A manic but amazing experience. We were staying on the outskirts of the Medina so visited it every day. What an experience! From the motorcycles, bikes and donkey carts trying to squeeze their way down the narrow packed alleyways to the hustle and bustle of the Souks and the main El Fna Square, the Medina is a fusion of sounds, smells and colours. At night the square comes alive with the many food stalls all vying for your business. We found that by rubbing our bellies and saying "Already eaten" & they would say "you come back tomorrow?"We found the souks a lot of fun and were persistently pursued by shopkeepers trying to haggle to make the sale. Again, we felt it worked by having some Dirham in your pocket & saying that this was our last day and that this was all we had left. One did try to barter for my watch and my phone, but when he realised I was not budging, reluctantly agreed to sell a pair of leather Baboosh slippers for 100 Dirham (originally 600 Dirham).You can get a little disoriented wandering the Medina and either a map or Google Maps on your phone is a great help. You will be bombarded by people trying to "help you, no money, no money" but we smiled & walked on and eventually they got the message.Personally, I found the Medina a safe place and enjoyed the hustle and bustle and would recommend it to anyone visiting Marrakech for the experience

A once in a lifetime experience !!. A worthwhile experience - look beyond the hustle and bustle and the feeling of vulnerability that I guess most feel at some point .It's their culture after all - snake charmers and monkeys a,,And handbags and spices and more handbags !!
Loved it!. Loved the craziness of it all. Very busy, and you really don't know where to look first! A really fun place that will leave you in awe.
Fascinating place!. We visited the Medina both by day and night. On a Saturday night, the place was hopping. Music and all kinds of great food.

Great Atmosphere and very lively. Enjoy the food, sights and smells on an evening. Do not get offended with the constant pestering by the stall holders, try to have a laugh with them as they are just trying to attract your attention to come and eat at there stalls. Deffinatly try the herbal Tea's from the stalls on the outskirts of the food stalls - Great on an cold evening to take the chill away.

An explosion of culture & a great place to shop. This is one of the most interesting places that I have ever been too. It definitely provides stimulation to all of the senses and there are great bargains to be had. When walking into the medina people will try and engaging you... keep walking and touch nothing. Touching means that you are engaging and engaging can mean parting with money! When you go dress appropriately, you will be respected as a woman for covering your head and not wearing short shorts! Cover your arms and legs. This is bargaining heaven, never accept the first price I would always offer 25% - 33% of what was offered and work from there knowing that I was aiming for at a maximum half of the price offered. Also don't be afraid to walk away there are so many people selling here. Its a great place to get leather goods and you can really get a bargain. Also be careful of people who want to guide you through the souk, they will expect payment and will take you to store holders that they get a kick back from. Also be aware of where you are walking and take note, this is a place where you can easily get lost because there are so many nooks and crannies. Watch out because in Marrakech anything and everything in on the road and going through the souke. We experienced motorbikes, bicycles and donkeys through the narrow walk ways. If you are going to Marrakech definitely go here it is a great experience.
Noisy but worth seeing. Entering the medina is like entering a fairy tale. Its beautiful buildings and its rich culture, together with its colourful people makes it unique?

MADNESS BUT FUN. This is a mad place but is a Must See for any traveller. You'll either love it or hate it. I've been before so knew all the old tricks with everyone telling you everything is closed. It isn't closed & is an ulterior motive to alleviate you of your tourist money. Everything is 25% of the cost that the Souk sellers start out & most of it is pure Tat but it's fun all the same. Go see yourself & make your own mind up

great fun. Wow how different day and night. Snake charmers,monkey's. Loved it only thing I will say is a lot of the shops sell same stuff which was a shame and often wanted more than the government price set shopping. Centre
worth the visit. lots of hassle and bustle good street food good shopping.enjoyed the jamma el fana lots of clothes shopping and lots of handbags

A lot going on!. Very busy, lively place. Street dancers and music to watch while eating at a bordering restaurant. You can buy most things from the souks, food stalls and enjoy the experience of such a vibrant centre.

very busy lots to see and do, but must be carefull. lots to do, see, eat and drink here, but tourist must be careful as there a lot of people who are just looking to rip you off either by forcing you to purchase something or by 'trying to tell your future'
booked Mahamid . late 60 full long gown . felt safe going to market. take a guide they can take you to the shops that you wont find. not hassled as had a guide . he even got discounts for us

No pressure, I give you good price. Absolutely loved the hustle & bustle of Medina.The stench of horse manure as you enter the market from the horse & carts that carry you down Boulevard Mohammed V is immense, but it's the beginning of beautiful coloured ceramics, bracelets, clothing & Babouches!!!As you walk down small alleyways where you get food, jewellery & all of the above, you are in competition with mopeds & cycles!Look out for Upcycle!!!!! OMG!!! Amazing belts, neckpieces, handbags etc made from recycled tyre. Stunning black pieces that will make you love the gothic/ baroque look!Barter, yes but smile & saying "Shukran" makes it easy.Loved it...... It's a way of Moroccan life xx

A very interesting walk. We found this place to be quite interesting. We visited with an elderly couple and lucily for us they knew the way. Although it was clearly sign posted, we unfortunately do not read arabic therefore spent 3 hours wandering around looking for a way out. The children loved the adventurous nature of it. I however was absolutely worn out!
awesome. so much happening & so much to do in the square and bargains to have and try the street food and the people are awesome

"An Experience". The Medina is an experience like no other !The intricate web of narrow streets with everything for sale including meat, vegetables, iron works, clothing, wedding decorations, etc. You need to share the alleyways with racing motorcycles, an occasional donkey, small delivery trucks and cars. Watch out for nice young English speaking man who offered to help us find our way... nothing is free !

Cool and cultural but be wary of pickpockets. Great atmosphere during this period of the old city of Marrakech - if you're in Marrakech it's a must visit! We were shown round by a friend of mine who is a local. Sat in one of the local bars and had a pot of the famous mint tea! Great place however my friend warned us to be wary of scamsters and pickpockets. Don't have your picture taken with any somersaulting monkeys as they are trained to thieve.

If is exists in Marrakesh it's here. Simply put, the shopping area in Marrakesh. From cheap souvenirs, to exensive decorative pieces for your home, you'll find it here, at no fixed price. It is very touristic, so vendors will charge you ridiculous prices for everthing they sell and hope for the best price they can get from you. Be aware that along side you, there will be moroccans living their own life and trying to get to places using bikes, motorbikes, donkeys and other means of transportation to get throgh the little alleys on the medina, so try and avoid taking the whole street to yourself and avoid walking from one side to the other without looking where you're going. these people do take notice of you but may not be able to stop their vehicles in time. It may seem a bit overcrowded but if you circulate with caution, there's room for everybody.

Watch out for the motorcycles. This is probably the busiest medina in Morocco. The intricate web of narrow streets with everything for sale including meat, vegetables, iron works, clothing, wedding decorations, etc. You need to share the alleyways with racing motorcycles, an occasional donkey, small delivery trucks and cars. Watch out for nice young English speaking man who offered to help us find our way out of the medina. (It's easy to do) He will take you into many places you did not want to go - rug shops, fabric dye stores, food markets - when you finally convince him to show you the way out he wants to be paid for his guided tour. We were far more annoyed than afraid. He didn't protest too much when we said "no".

Great to visit - but I wouldn't want to live there... . The Medina is bustling at all times of day, busiest around the Jemee el Fna square and the Souks that radiate off of this. The square is full of stalls, snake charmers, monkey handlers, fresh orange juice carts, horse carriages and people wandering around selling cigarettes, watches, wood carvings. It can feel a little intimidating at first but you just need to be friendly and firm with everyone who wants to be your friend and maintain a healthy scepticism about motives! Bartering is aggressive and with some persistence and a little 'walking away' and indifference the prices can drop up to 70% from the original. It's part of the fun but remember to leave stallholders with some profit & pride. The mopeds buzzing through the streets can be dangerous so keep eyes open and ears alert. There are also no street names so keep the square, which is signposted, as a point of reference, if you ask directions be prepared to be shown your way and then asked for money.

Chaotic and wonderful. Be ready to be amazed. A true labyrinth of small roads, filled with shops, scents and colours. You need to bargain at least 80% down the original price, which is rather exhausting. Watch our for a few rip offs: 1. Maison du Kaftan - avoid! They are more expensive than the shops they supply to on the 5th avenue and Harrods. 2. Dont buy Argan oil in the street shops, the chances of it being blended with palm or olive oil are rather huge.

The bustling lif eof the town. Over 1 million people live in Marrakech and this where they often come to shop, pray and work. It reminds you of what UK cities might have been like 300 years ago. Its large ,bustling, full of life with amazing variety. shops, workshops, eating places, musicians, animal shows (snakes, monkeys etc.) The 'market' is here with thousands (yes thousands) of stalls selling everything they make or import. Its easy to get lost as there is not a sensible road layout and no street names. Beware bikes and scooters, they don't stop, just swerve around you even in narrow alleys. You have to barter for everything (unless it is price marked but little is) and you need to pay about half what they ask for) if you want clothes or leather goods they adjust them to fit you while you wait. Its exciting and really comes to life after the sun has gone down (its cooler). Get local currency before you go, best exchange is in your hotel that has an official ATM which takes all cards.
madness. ok by day but crazy by night. Most suitable with a male partner with you. You may see some site that upset you if you are a animal lover.

The place to stay. The medina is amazing, a hive of small winding alleys, buzzing souks and teeming humanity. We stayed in a lovely riad in the medina which was surprisingly quiet and calm. I felt that we had the best of both worlds by staying in the old town, which is so much more colourful than the new town.

Amazing. Impossible to describe so as to reach all readers as it really is a place you have to visit to make up your own mind. We loved it. Its wild, fast yet slow. Always something happening day or night
WOW!!!. An out of this world experience. Has to be seen to be believed. Such a great atmosphere and def worth a visit at night!!!

Amazing. This was such an amazing experience, the sounds, the smells of the spices, the colours of some of the amazing things for sale. Sit in a rooftop cafe and just watch all the action of the medina from this vantage point.

Fantastic crazy chaos!. I really think it would be pointless to visit Marrakech without spending a good portion of the time in the Medina. I would even take this further that in order to get a feel for the city, staying in a riad in the Medina is a necessity. It is a bustling, crazy, chaotic environment, full of motor bikes, donkey, horses and carriages, the occasional car, all competing in narrow cobbled streets. It is the old world with the taste of diesel! It is a fascinating experience. Prepare yourself for a bit of a shock when you arrive - it takes a few hours to get used to the bedlam, but the shock subsides and then the fun sets in!
Very busy and a good experience. Just be careful you don't get taken off somewhere you don't want to go, just stick on your own or whoever your with . Otherwise a good but hot experience.
COMPLETELY MAD PLACE. dont ask anyone for directions; dont get your map out. Walk into a shop and ask the staff who can't lead you off on a wild goose chase!
Night time. This is a good place to go in the evening, although we didn't eat at any of the small pop up restaurants it was fun to look around.Good way to get the atmosphere of this city.

Great Shopping Be Ready to Bargain. A local told me not to buy on the first day or the last day. Good advice. So many beautiful crafts and objects. Save some room in your suitcase to bring things back.

amazing experience you won't soon forget. what a super cool way to get a real sense of marakkech -- the shopping is amazing (row after row of slippers, caftans, lanterns and more) and everything you see and hear is colorful. as everyone says be mindful of your bags and money as there are lots of beggars, especially around the food stalls. its best to go as a guide, as if you have a good one, they will take you to the more reputable places that are not a rip off.
magical. the medina is big and diverse with lots of nice places to visit. great restaurants to eat and amazing riads to stay

Recommended. Interesting but difficult to find the right price for the right quality...bargaining. Check the quality outside of the usually dark shop as you can see better what you exactly buy in the daylight ;o)
Must visit. To experience the real Morocco you must visit the souks it can be a bit overwhelming as there is a maze of alleyways but it's an adventure!!

The genuine Marrakech. It would be rather odd to come to Marrakech without spending a lot of time in the Medina - the place is so vibrant and alive. It is pretty clean and totally unthreatening compared with many cities across the world. Yes, people want to sell you their wares (or act as your guide - for a fee of course), but they are generally not too pushy.You could alternatively choose to stay within the 'Ville Nouvelle' - and miss out on so many amazing sights and experiences ...

A little bit crazy. Spent 2 days getting lost in the medina, solo female. I felt the vendors were a little bit more persistent in trying to get me to look in their shops than other groupings but didn't feel threatened just a bit irritated on occasion. They say shop around for the bargains but the Souks are so confusing its best to buy what you like when you see it, chances are you won't be able to find the same place twice by deliberate intention.
