Haggling is expected. Get a good map some of the 'helpful' people expect to be paid a lot for helping you find your way even short distances and some sent me the wrong pay when I wouldn't play

Hey, it's Marrakech !. Very interesting, very vibrant, everything imagined in my childhood. Fantastical.Watch out for pickpockets !Never felt in any physical danger, but I was bumped unnecessarily a number of times (they want you to reach for your valuables). Definitely best to go with a guide for at least the first time. A little too crowded. A bit too easy to get lost.

Wow!. A visit to Marrakech wouldn't be complete without going to the madina and the souks, there are 100's of different stalls/shops selling everything you can think of. It can be a bit overwhelming and intimidating but the shop keepers are not pushy. There is a fantastic app called 'hip Marrakech' which is map of the medina but one that tells where you are while your walking so you don't get lost! Well worth downloading and it's free!
You can see a lot in one day. The best way to do this is on foot and it is amazing how many fantastic sight you can see in one day.

Absolutely stunning..... As soon as you enter the marina it's like you've entered another world. The sights and smells are over whelming. It is beautiful hearing the sound of the pipes of the snake charmers and the smells of lamb, onion and seafood filling the square. It is impressive in both daytime and nighttime but they are completely different experiences so you need to see it in both! Lots of places to eat and drink, at varying prices, so it's worth hunting around before you settle down to dine. Friendly locals but very persistent, stand your ground and try not to get roped in to every stall!! Amazing place!

A 'must' life experience. A truly sensory experience! The wealth of opportunities and experiences could be overwhelming at times, but should not be missed. However, although it could be hectic, it always felt safe and welcoming. There are fixed price shops if you cant face negotiating!

Carpets, spices, slippers, robes, scarves, tea services!. If you've come to Marrakesh more than likely you will end up here. I loved our day shopping where the carpet vendors put on a show while serving us mint tea, we enjoyed antique shops, shopping for pointed slippers, etc. Be prepared to bargain and if they say shipping included - buy it! See if they'll ship your other purchases too. FYI ask before you take a pic or be prepared to pay. We enjoyed our escargot for $1.00 YUMMO!

Stunning. Especially by night, this place is fantastic. Lively, hustle and bustle. Great experience. If you want traditional hand made gifts, this is the place, unfortunately a lot are too big to take home, but some beautiful things that would be difficult and expensive to get in the UK. Bit scary at first, but once you settle and get used to the people and the place, it becomes exciting and fun.

Interesting.... I had a private guided tour of the Medina of Marrakech on a Sunday afternoon. It wasn't very crowded but I think the crowds probably came out a little later. It is quite large area so be ready to do a lot of walking. The area is divided up into different zones where the artisans and food sellers work. There is an area for food - dead and alive, leather goods, woolen goods, carvings, clothing, jewelry, household items, etc. I have to say that the store owners are certainly not as obnoxious and pushy as the ones in the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul. When I politely said no, they basically left me alone. There are lots of interesting things to buy, however, I have downsized so I don't need anything.

Sensory Overload. Very busy place with lots to see, hear, taste and touch. The paths and allies are slightly bigger overall then the Fes Medina which was also amazing but the square in Marrakech's medina was amazing. 7 days a week, all day and into the late hours of the night, this place had it all. All the shopping you could ever want in a medina and all sorts of food options, especially at night...stall 55 was where we ate dinner. Certainly a not to miss stop in your trip.

If you don't love the Medina then you won't enjoy Marrakech. We were staying in the heart of Marrakech minutes from the Medina.It is everything you imagine. Vibrant, exciting and very noisy. I loved getting my large glass of freshly squeezed orange juice every morning for 4 dirhams which is about 13p sweet as sweet can be. Then watching the world of the Medina unfold before me. Snake charmers, men with monkeys(which is one of the things I didn't agree with or partake of a photo but they are part of the life there on the square. Men playing music and the call to prayers all mingled in to the wonderful sounds which is Marrakech.Sit in one of the cafes overlooking the square and a whole new world opens up before you.

Hectic but not to be missed. Of course you have to explore the Medina fully and the best way to do this first time around is with a guide - that way they can help you go and see the leather being auctioned, enjoy a traditional Moroccan soup with bread in a small cafe, see the artisans making the brass lamps, see the guys heating the water for the Hammam's

Crazy, hectic, and overwhelming - but a must see!. Not for the feint-hearted, but (based on reviews before our visit) sometimes a little over-exaggerated. People will try and lure you into their shops, but a firm and polite no is usually enough to do the job.Beware the smell & pick-pockets.As an animal lover, the poor animal welfare here was hard to see.

Get lost here....it's fun!. The Medina here seems to go on forever and you will easily get lost - always, and keep going round in circles - often! Don't worry....just ask one of the locals and they will point you in the right direction. We stayed in the Medina for a week and right up to the last day, kept finding areas that we hadn't discovered before.

You have not visited Morocco without a trip to the Medina of Marrakech. What a treat for all the senses! We ventured there just before sunset and felt the transition from loud and busy daytime market to an even louder and busier evening extravaganza. The narrow streets through the Medina are lined with many merchants, most of them friendly enough as long as you understand it is their job to try to sell you their stuff. Haggle if you wish, only buy what you want, and a polite no thank you will suffice most times if you don't want to buy. The wide open plaza is great for people watching. As it gets closer to sunset, there are snake charmers and the mesmerizing sound of the oboe like instruments. There are also monkeys doing tricks. There are also story tellers surrounded by crowds listening in and laughing. I don't know Arabic, so had no Idea what the stories were, but judging by the size of the crowds, they must have been good.If you stop to look at monkeys, snakes or story tellers, you will be pressured to pay, but so what. This is how they make a living. Our guides helped us know what a fair tip was, so we carried small Dirhams for that purpose. The food booths that set up later in the afternoon are dazzling. Many open fires and lots of smoke. We weren't hungry and had dinner planned with our group, but all of the food was inviting, and the smells were both bad (the smoke) and terrific (the spicy food).Let yourself loose, take the ordinary precautions, know what a fair tip is, then venture forth.

Not just a market. What is most commonly associated with the Medina, is the big market in the center. But the Medina is so much more, the market is just part of it. Go anywhere, but if the Medina is what you're in Marrakech for, stay inside the 20 kilometer long walls surrounding it - you will notice at once when leaving the Medina.Try to experience it both day and night - walk anywhere at daytime, but save the market visit for after dark. The Medina has everything you may look for, as long as you watch your wallet.
Morroco. Great country to visit!! Amazing culture and food. Great tour guide that speaks Arab, French, Spanish and English.
Get lost in the streets. Was great to walk around. be careful of the streets and getting lost but well worth the visit. We enjoyed it with the kids.

Go by night.... I went there both night and day. Better at night, crowded, but peaceful. Plenty of food sellers. Try a cheap orange juice, at least... Story tellers, dancers, street games, music players, you can find anything to amuse you...

Good fun. Lots of fun haggling for prices. Theme fins was cleaner than I was expecting and most of the store keepers were ok when you didn't want to buy from them. We also felt quite safe there. A definite when visiting Marrakech

Open your mind and you'll have a great time!. Such an amazing place! Exciting, vibrant and, I am sure, unique! Before we went, we were told not to speak unless you wanted to buy something, wear sunglasses, look straight ahead! What rubbish! Open your mind, forget your preconceptions and engage with the people! You don't need a guide; you may get lost in the Souks but that's part of the fun and you'll find your way out eventually! Haggle for everything. Aim for half of the asking price or lower. Don't be scared to walk away - they'll chase you down the street if they want to sell! If you aren't interested a polite "no thank you" is good enough. The main square has a life of its own! Find a café with a balcony to people watch! You'll see snake charmers and monkeys on chains (neither of which I approved of!) and if you stop the men will try to get money off you. At the end of the day, you watching is their livelihood, so if you don't want to pay, don't look! Other than that, there are numerous market stalls selling everything from old dentures to argon oil! Haggle away, and make sure you have a refreshing fresh orange juice from one of the many stalls. As evening approaches the square takes on a different feel as the food stalls open up and the entertainment changes. The food stalls are a must to walk through, even if you've eaten! The owners all speak to you in out of place English phrases to get you to look at what they have! Interact with these people, it's great fun! Have a wonderful time ... we did and can't wait to go back!

WOW - BEST AT NIGHT. We were a family of 3 with a 14yr old daughter who were a little nervous at visiting the Medina and souks after hearing about other peoples experiences BUT don't listen to other peoples negative experiences as we had a fab time. We got a taxi from our complex arriving at 1730 and watched the Medina change from a market to an area with a fantastic evening atmosphere with music, acts and the smells were amazing. You need to barter with the sellers and pay what you are prepared to pay and not getting as cheap as you can as these people need to make a living. Mopeds are a nightmare especially around the souks where they are small alley ways with hundreds of people and all of a sudden you will have 2 mopeds hammering down them hooting their horns getting you to move so keep hold of your kids ( this is the only negative) You can't go to Marrakech without visiting the Medina square and Souks.
Terrific bargains for all. This is one of the best souks in the world. From vipers to Viagra and from car parts to carpets, you can get them all here. The sounds, colours and smells are fantastic.

Step back in history. The Medina of Marrakech, the walled ancient city, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and comprises Place Jemma-el-Fna, one of the busiest plazas in all of Africa, the Souks, the stalls and markets originated by the Berbers, and the Ben Youssef Madrassa.
It's a market + some crazy!!. It's deco a must see in Morocco for sure never take the the first second or third price for anything!! Loads of goodies to be had tho.

Marrakech . Medina is mad the drivers crazy the markets r a wonderful world away from our own but barter d jesus out of em if they want 500md offer 100 then ull most likely hit ur price n he still makes money from u the wife didnt like d smell of horses up d square but then she is a city girlThen when u return in d evening for the food stalls d 1st yhing u notice is d smell of food heaven all good is on display for u to see and when u taste it brilliant

Senses working overtime!!. If you want to be bombarded with colours, sounds and smells, then the Marrakech Medina (old town) is for you. There are snake charmers, "dentists", endless street food, old palaces and, of course, the phenomenal souk. It's amazing. I never knew Morocco had so much culture and colour to offer. Fill your boots!

A vibrant exciting place to explore. The Medina in Marrakech is large and winding and full of shops, restaurants, roads and much more. Give yourself time to get lost in this amazing place. You can't get lost for too long and shopkeepers or other tourists are always willing to help with directions.

A 'bucket list' visit!. Certainly a must do semi-unique experience. So different from the normal 'Paris, NY, London' and even Kinshasa, Lagos Nairobi trips, its worth it!If you stay away from the super-luxury hotels, can be done at a decent budget so you have plenty of money for shopping!Oh, but do be careful, like any crowded tourist destination and despite the Moroccans' best efforts, petty thievery/pick-pocketing occurs. We didn't let a stolen/'lost' cellphone spoil our trip, but could have done without it!
Busy and hectic. was really busy worth the experience but you do get hassled all the time that's what lets it down would advise evening rather than the day :)

Great experience for a weekend trip!. The medina is the walled area surrounding the old town. Its a busy area with lots of locals more than happy to show you the way to various places, don't do it!!! If you can download an app on your tablet that uses GPS not internet, this is all you need to navigate the alleyways and to find Trip Advisor suggestions for places to see! That's what we did and it was invaluable and we avoided be badgered by locals!

Amazing. Fantastic place day and night. Use your common sense here, keep your valuables close and safe, just in case, don't go near the men with monkeys a it's cruel and b they will be put on you and you will have to pay to get them off. Great for people watching from a cafe on the edge of the square, you pay about a £1 for a coffee or mint tea or coke, very reasonable.

A Busy, bussle, aromatic place.. A must go to place! It's very busy so stay together! A really eye opener place too! So many stalls to browse & buy.The smells of the teas & spices are exquisite. A great experience. See it in the day and watch it come 'alive' at night. It's two different experiences at the same place.
Amazing.. A truly unforgettable and amazing experience. Wow !!!! The colours, the music, the smells, the food, the sights, the entertainment, the people. A must do. Truly memorable.

the souk. the souk of medina is like the cave of Alladin.The futher one goes in the more things one gets to see. Be careful to keep tract of your lane as you are sure and certain to get loss. You have to bargain a lot which I don,t like to do.The best way to do is they tell you a price and you guess the value you want to pay. If they don,t agree just walk out and they will most of the time call you back but keep maintaining your price n they usually give in.By the way bring a good pair of walking shoes.Taxi around the Medina area is about 20 to 30 dirham. Agree on the fare before getting in. We used to eat all the different Morocan cuisine around the Medina. Lots cheaper than the hotels and plenty of varieties to enjoy.

Where the magic happens.... Orange stalls, food stalls, amazing pottery for 10d, crazy Henna ladies/monkey men, snake charmers and beautiful stalls all around all in all made it one of my favourite places to walk around in. The people themselves are lovely, even the guys selling cigarettes/handing out leaflets. I'll never forge this place and how I felt walking through it.

visit to medina market. oh very nice , market we was see all dry fruits , morrocan food .i like oranges juices . stall is every where.it's only night time you can enjoy and animal displayed, ooh what nice.i like that place.
Breathtaking. A once on a life time experience, be prepared to be constantly hassled , but is worth it for the overall sights, and you must barter with confidence. Hang on to your daughters.
Excellent memories. A beautiful medina to explore and understand the history and culture of this fascinating country. You must see this beautiful place and try the spice souk
amazing experience. the Medina in marrakech is amazing, full on! busy,exciting, but can be nerve wreaking if you haven't experienced an area like this before. awesome at night!

Sights. It was beautiful to visit this area in the evening with all the lights and various different activities going on. There were plenty of food stalls, vibrant market stalls and dancers, snakecharmers. The atmosphere was buzzing and exciting. A good experience overall.

fabulous but watch out for the naughty boys. Amazing space, full of wonders, tour groups and con-men. Do not fall for the world's oldest scam as i did when trying to get back to my hotel and let a youth help you. It's misdirect a tourist time....they also try to pass you on from one to another and you reach a point when you think you'll never see your hotel again. You will because people rae kind and helpful, it's just a matter of finding them.
crazy hectic and fun. Every item imaginable can be purchased here - have fun haggling but be aware that you may spend an hour haggling over as little as 1 euros difference.

A must see by foot. A huge area of the city around the wall is a historic wonderland. Many small alleyways and lots of souks, restaurants are at your disposal, not to forget the numerous guesthouses known as Riads.

Interesting and Crazy. During the night is the most crazy time...it's more crowded. At the square you'll see people doing a lot of things to gather money. Save time for a Moroccan massagem in one of the spa's.

Visiting the Souk.... What a fantastic experience. I went with some trepidation as I had read mixed reviews on what to expect in terms of any risk. Completely unfounded, the people were very friendly and yes they wanted to sell their products but a "no thank you" was the end of any unwanted approach. On the other hand if you want to buy! be prepared to haggle "it's good fun and expected" if your careful there are some great bargains.Be aware that it's common practice to ride scooters through crowded passages but it all adds to the experience. We went late afternoon in the daylight and stayed until around 8pm "dark" the whole place transforms. There are hundreds of people, the atmosphere is electric, especially with the snake charmers and monkeys. All of which provide entertainment "at a cost" Getting lost: be aware it's a labyrinth of passages, should you get lost avoid the volunteer guide it will likely cost money...We took a few precautions before going, keeping monies and other items secure. No point in becoming a victim.The whole visit was like stepping back in time but a superb experience and one i would highly recommend
Very interesting. Marrakech is a great place to get lost in and spend hours just wandering around haggling for goods and soaking up the atmosphere.
Interesting. Crazy, loud, crowded, interesting - always something going on, something to see or do. Great to experience street food

Have Fun and Be Watchful. We enjoyed walking around and seeing the sites. People watching was a lot of fun.Ate at a couple of the restraunts around the market and they were very good.Ate at one of the market stalls. The food was ok. They tried to charge us double the price because of all the extras they gave us. We only ordered 2 dishes and were unpleasant about this.Enjoy yourself, just becareful.

Great experience.. You can get whatever you want here. Traders are friendly - don't believe any stories of aggressive behaviour. Don't say you're interested when you are not and just keep smiling. A bit of French is all you need to buy or just say non, merci. Don't believe any locals who try to tell you somewhere is closed unless it is after 6pm or before 9am.Take a small cheap compass for the souks area - it helps to know which way you are travelling.
loud fun and a delight to see. Loved the Medina the sights and sounds are wonderful from cobras to monkeys there are lots of things to do see and buy

Motorscooters are a scourge. Overall we like the medina of Marrakech but the worst part is the running of motorscooters through the narrowest of passages upsetting the experience of pedestrians. Can understand that some residents find motorscooters a convenience and perhaps a necessity, but that is no excuse for them to intimidate pedestrians and speed through narrow passages. Some of the scooter drivers are more patient but too many are impatient and disturb pedestrians and speed. Perhaps motorscooter drivers should be made to walk their scooters through passages at the same speed as pedestrians and only ride them in designated wide passages and streets. We found that taxis in Fes and Meknes always used their meters but found the use of meters spotty in Casablanca and had worst experience in Marrakech. That might reflect on the local officials. Do not expect to see much of real craftsmen at work in their shops. You will see more of that in the medinas of Fes and Meknes. Would rate Marrakech medina higher if it were not for the scooter problem.
Not to missed. This is the "old town", Morocco as it was years ago. Just walk round and breathe it all in. Although there are many places to "visit", wandering the streets is all you really need.

The reason to go to Marrakech. You wouldn't go to Marrakech without visiting the Medina. Outside the walls it's a modern city. Inside the winding streets are humming with activity. Be careful walking around. Cars, scooters, mopeds, donkey carts, bicycles and people all compete for the road, sometimes with no seeming rhyme or reason. But surprisingly, we never saw one crash, although we constantly expected to. Walk the streets away from the Jemaa. The areas where people live are fascinating. Long, narrow roads lined with high walls and fanciful doors, which open to courtyards that in turn open to the sky. Because of the heat there are very few windows to the outside. But many places have rooftop gardens. The Medina covers a large area and each section has a different character. Worth checking out the southern quadrant, which holds the Jewish Quarter, and the palaces, and the north end, which has a totally different feel.
Crazy Place. Go here to shop, eat and drink (no alcohol).Be careful of mopeds, they come at you from all angles!

A must see - Amazing. Best to visit late afternoon/late evening, it is a huge market place full of various things to buy. A labyrinth of ally's to wander down and barter with the locals for excellent leather products and local produce.
amazing maze. Easy and safe to get around. Traditional and modern shops to explore. Look out for the disability cooperative and buy something to support them. Be cautious of motorbikes and bikes....
A must visit. This place is a must visit place as Marrakech is known for the medina with old and new town close to each other,you can see spices,and also a must see is the souks amazing loved it

Just Buzzing. An interesting place, cobbled narrow streets filled with market stalls selling all sorts of goods. Just be prepared to haggle and no price is rediculous (apart from the vendors starting price)!! Plenty of places to eat, shop and do not forget to visit the Jemaa el fanaa square which is different in the day to the night.It is easy to get lost and be aware of unofficial tour guides, but most find their way back to the main square.All in all a buzzing experience for any newcomers!

Marrakech Medina. An awakening for the senses! Be prepared to haggle as is customary! You have to experience the medina on a visit to Marrakech!! At first it's looks like a maze be you soon get accustomed to the alleyways and negotiate your way around the narrow alleyways. Do not miss this experience!

Living, shopping and eating in the Medina is a great experience. Loved our stay in the medina. Walking to restaurants, markets, shops and experiencing the buzz. The draw back..... the 5am callers all over the city. It would significantly help if you are an early riser.We also stayed out of the Medina and this gave us a totally different view of the city. Outside was still vibrant but a bit slower and rather lovely and the "caller" was a lot quieter. A walk into the medina was easy.We found walking through the Medina to visit sights and the markets (souks) was easy and very safe. Even walking around at night seemed safe (subject to normal worldwide personal security measures).We even found that taxi drivers were very fair and had set prices for driving around the medina. All very pleasant.

Just keep walking. An experience. Busy and bustling, yes you do have to watch the henna ladies just keep walking and don't engage, likewise with photos around the snake charmers. BUT this is Marrakesh and bartering, monkey, snake charmers are all part of its character. It's a colourful and lively place, you have to experience it.

My Bucket list "must do". I have long wanted to visit the Madina of Marrakech. It did not disappoint, it was busy, buzzy and exciting, shame I only had a cabin bag so was limited in my purchases. Motorcycles and bikes annoying in the narrow alleyways but it was easier in the souk. Surely you would know in advance there would be some hussling by the sellers. Get ready to negotiate downwards and go for a coffee in one of the 3 storey cafes if you need a break.

Fascinating place!. This is like stepping into a completely different world! It's hectic, noisy, kind of smelly, and very stressful dodging the mopeds/bikes/donkey carts and cars! But it is vibrant, colourful, exciting and very interesting. Haggling in the Souks is exhausting but fun, being pounced on by "guides" as soon as you pull out a map is annoying but funny-you just have to make sure they actually take you there before you pay them rather than just give you directions! You inevitably get lost in the maze of little streets but this is the best way to experience the place! Great fun if a little exhausting!

Unmissable. A maze of bright, tempting stalls selling everything you can think of; leather goods, spices, soaps, tea pots, slippers, rugs, mirrors, lanterns. We just loved it. Some friendly bartering went on, I tend to work on the premise that the shop sellers have to make a living so I work out what I'm happy to pay, rather than try to beat them down to the last farthing, it just becomes disrespectful. Everyone will try and coax you to buy but if we weren't interested a smile and ' non merci ' and we got a smile back. I'm a great believer in ' people give back what you put in, a smile and respect for others goes a long way.' We bought some beautiful things, also found some great cafes. You can't go to Marrakech and not come here.

Much too busy, not to my taste. I know this is what most tourists rave about but I actually didn't enjoy visiting the Medina at all. Constantly harassed by pushy sellers, 'guides' and restaurants. I started out with a happy banter back but this constant barrage soon wore me down and couldn't get out of there fast enough. I'm sure some people wanted to be helpful but it just got too much. Last drop was a gang of early twenty-something guys handing around shouting lewd suggestions at passing women.

Shopping. You couldn't stop and look at anything without some women trying to stab at you with her henna pen or someone trying to put a snake or monkey on you and wanting money and if you said no they said but you've touched it never again
Happening spot!. Busy, like any city center. Watch out for motorbikes and bicycles. Side roads are very charming. Definitely, a must do if in Marrakech.
Architecture to die for. If it's not too hot it's worth walking along the walls and to the archways... sometimes it is a complete contrast.

A nice window into the culture of Marrakech.. Although walking through the many jewelry, shoe, bag, leather, and spice souks was a bit intimidating, they really are authentically Moroccan and the people sell great quality goods. We visited a large rug store during which we were welcomed and served tea and saw some beautiful creations, we had a look at many jewelery souks, and were taken by our guide to a pharmacy selling argan oil, and various Moroccan products which smelt amazing.We also saw a few souks selling stunningly hand-carved wooden pieces which I would've LOVED to have been able to take home, but don't know how I'd get them on the plane... I recommend at least a visit here as you're sure to find something you'll want, just go with a man, ignore the comments from the male sellers, and remember that their first price is never their final.

Well worth wandering around but be carful of guides. I spent time wandering around the Medina. It is amazing that the narrow alleys have pedestrians, bikes, donkeys, motorbikes and sometimes even cars all sharing the same narrow street. You will get hassled to buy things but you can smile and move on if not interested. Be careful of "guides" trying to direct you. I had a total of 4 the other day all trying to help me find a place and all wanting payment. In the end I gave up and found the place myself. If you do accept someones assistance, insist on how much they want upfront and make them take you to the actual entrance of the place you are looking for. Don't let them say it's just "around the corner". Colour, smells and sounds are all unique and it's well worth a visit.
Morning tour.. Very informative tour of old & new Marrakech from both inside & outside the ancient walls!Traffic is manic with mopeds a living hell, lol!

lovely old area. We found the Medina to be much better than the New town... stay here to get a cultural experience. It is the essence of Marrakesh and should be the reason why you visit such a rich cultural city. Feel free to walk around freely , the people are friendly and always willing to assist. I did not feel harassed or unsafe at all.
interesting but take care not to get lost as we did. again been here twice lots to see bargains to haggle for good atmosphere but take care how far you go in the winding alleys are endless.
An oasis of tranquillity. My most favourite venue in Marrakesh. Not the most extensive collection for a museum but we spent 2hrs just staring at the exquisite decoration.
Awful. Unsafe due to lack of police presence Hagglers continually grabbing your arms for business If you like a deal... This is for you alternately avoid at all costs
Worth a visit. Really enjoyed my time here. It is hard to take it all in but worth every bit of it. Don't bother driving, it is just a bit crazy, but you can get about better with cabs.

Interesting but needs a clean up. It is an interesting historic area but could do with a good clean up and improvements to the sewage system. Using a recommended official guide helps to find your way around on a first visit.

Not to be missed. The medina in Marrakech is huge and seems at first to be just overwhelming. The souks are really only a small part. Depending on the area, you can explore historical sites, shop, see the local color and get a feel for Morocco. Certainly a must see when you visit.

Shops. We hired a driver who took us to the shops and other landmarks too many to list. With the driver, we felt very comfortable. We loved bargaining. Few people spoke English and it was fun trying to communicate

Ask the front desk for a guide.. You need a local guide to navigate the Marrakesh medina. Period. Ask the front desk at your Hotel. We stayed at La Maison Arabe and they gave us a wonderful guy who spoke soft British English. I think his name was Asiz. Took us everywhere worth going to. Bring money with you. It doesn't matter if you don't want to buy anything, Moroccans will sell you things. I bought awesome scarves, and a Berber welcome mat. Place Jemaa el Fna is the place to get your selfie with a monkey and a Cobra. Bring small change and a down-for-whatever attitude.
Busy medina but fun. It was very busy but fun if you're in the mode to hustle bustle. Best go mid morning or late afternoon, the middle of the day too hot and hectic.

The less authentic Medina visited in Morocco. I travelled and lived many years in Africa, so I imagine places like this do not look as exotic as for many tourists. Sadly enough, it was the worst experience had touring Morocco. The medina is little preserved compared to Fez or Meknes; motorbikes are speeding few centimeters from you even in the smallest streets; continuos harrassment from shop owners trying to sell you product made elsewhere in the country at unbelievably high prices. Signs for orientation are deliberatly manipulated or covered to lead you to shops in places away from the main paths, where you would have no interest to end up. Plenty of locals offering their services to "show you the way", which actually means long detours you to bring you to their friends shop. Tanneries are very small compared to Fez and even there you are aggressively approached by "guides" pushing you to take tours, to eventually bring you to some shop. If Marrakesch is not the only place you will visit in Morocco, its Medina is a location which could be skipped without loosing anything intersting. Have a look at J'maa el Fna square during night time and head somewhere tourists are not seen as an ATM to get money.

Great shopping!. The Medina has some of the best shopping for tourists that I've ever experienced. You can buy the usual cheap stuff from hundreds of local shops and stalls but you can also find luxury items unique to Morocco like furniture, faux antique guns, exotic glasses, hand made carpets galore, large antique vases, unique and interesting chandeliers, etc. The food has a French influence and is generally very affordable, tasty and interesting. The place is safe and taxis are a max of five US dollars anywhere.
Excellence in the sun. Very enjoyable experience in the sun, worth while visit to Marrakech and visit to Medina and the souks.

Maddening and facinating. The medina is non stop hustle and bustle. People, donkeys, bicycles, scooters, carts all vying for space in the narrow twists and turns of the ancient streets. The shopping experience is second to none, in my experience, with some good products available at good prices if you can haggle well enough with the experts. Even if you don't try your hand at haggling the Medina is fascinating, just sit in one of the many cafes and watch the world go by, visit one of the many excellent restaurants, Take a refreshing "bath" at a Hamman, watch the craftsmen creating some of the beautiful products or take in one of the other attractions in the medina.

Bonkers. The Medina ia all a little bit crazy lots of street artists and all a bit smelly whether you want to go or not if you are in Marrakesh you will undoubtedly end up here at some time so just go with the flow
Excellent shopping. Loved the markets - lots of bargains to be had if you haggle. A spare suitcase is advisable for trip home.
fun and uinteresting. no toure of Marrakesh is complete without a walk through of the medina. I enjoyed the medina in fes better but this is a worthwhile tour

Dirty, smelly, intimidating, essential!. Don't be scared, don't talk to strangers, if people talk to you, become I grossed in your partners comments. Make them feel rude for interrupting. Walk purposefully, plan your route, check maps discreetly.
Crazy but fun. The Medina is a crazy arena packed with performers and sellers. Not for the feint hearted but a world experience.
Mad and crazy but you have to do it. Be prepared to get lost! Just what you expect, loads of narrow alley ways and lots of shops and bustle. A great experience but you must have your witts about you.

Charasmatic. The medina of Marraketch is an exciting vibrant place. There are snake charmers, dancers, acrobats, water sellers All sorts of the iinteresting and unusual. The souks are amazing i think something like ten thousand traders and you can buy such wonderful things and if you go right inside you can see the traditions at work. Here you can browse the goods or just sit at one of the cafes around the square and watch the world go by!
Sensory Experience. Go in the nighttime..stunning! Food stalls, transexual belly dancers..need I say any more than that???

The Souks are at times overwhelming, but there is so much more. Walking through the old town of Marrakesh, the Medina, it is fantastic to experience all the facets of the Medina. The Souks are loud, busy, crazy and at times overwhelming. But there are so many more exceptional facets of the little streets and paths in the Medina with the old koran schools, still running ovens where even today the bread is baked, the hammams, in the dead-end alleys with all the clear structure. - And one hint: you want to kerb dealing, ensure you have a good "feel" when you have done your deal.
Friendly and fascinating. A wonderfully exciting place that is best deceived as a living museum! The shopping is fun the history is fascinating and the people are wonderfully friendly!

My favourite building in Marrakech. This is the number 1 attraction in Marrakech and having been so beautifully restored to a most beautiful Madrasa with some exquisite examples of Islamic architecture and design, it is a must to see in this city. Also visit the nearby Kouba.

Mediaeval City. You visit Marrakech to be inside the Medina. It is what makes Marrakech be Marrakech. The new part of the city looks like any other with a little Moroccan flavor. The Medina includes many different parts of old Marrakech.

Crazy bug great vibe where old meets new. Stayed in the Medina and enjoyed the hustle and bustle of the Medina. Would recommend a guide to show you around and point out the communal bakeries, old caravan trading houses, mosques and Hammaman walk on the right with confidence and you will survive the onslaught of donkey carts, mopeds,bikes and other pedestrians.

History Brought to Life. Experience authentic Morocco as its been for centuries before. You'll find Berbers and Arabs, true artisans selling their creations. Highly recommend visiting the Medina with a local guide that speaks your native language. Our guide was able to navigate through the many alleys to get us to the best hidden places. As an ethic art collector, our guide knew the artisans and helped us get the best prices on rugs and ceramics. Negotiating is a sport for Moroccans, so don't be afraid to get in on the fun! They've practice the fine art of negotiating for centuries. It you choose to take pictures of the locals or vendors, I would recommend that you ask first and be willing to pay a few coins or euros for their trouble.Our guide got us into an authentic Moroccan restaurant down an alley called Riad Dar Timtam. This was no tourist trap. The meal was outstanding and the other patrons were all Moroccan.The alleys are all very narrow and occupied by pediatrics, vendors, and motor scooters, so be alert and careful of moving vehicles.Morocco depends heavily on tourism, so the people are all very welcoming.

Jump right in there. It does seem intimidating at first--the chaos, the motorbikes, all the haggling over prices. But the people are wonderful, and getting momentarily lost is part of the experience. It's not hard to get back on track. We always felt safe, and everyone we asked was generous with directions and help.

Real life of morrocans. The medina house's the old part of the city. It is full of souks shops houses and riads. Its loud, dirty, smokey, congested and busy. However in this lies its charm. It is niceto walk through and see how people live the buildings etc, but in small doses. Better to go out in the evening when cooler.There are 19 gates amd yhe calach drivers offer a ride around the madina There are several places to visit and the best restaurants are located here.

One doesn't go to Marrakech and do not stay or visit in the Medina. Get through the port to enter the Medina and you find yourself 200-300 years back in this vibrant and exciting historic part of the city. If a 5-star resort is your thing, you probably will not appreciate the (organized) mess in the Medina, but you have not seen Marrakech if you did not visit or stayed in the Medina. We stayed in the Medina (The excellent Riad Miski) and were thrilled by the experience. Too much to describe, but immerse yourself and enjoy the ride. Start with a mint tea at a terrace and observe. Start exploring little by little, and first get to know your way back to your place from the big square. It is easy to always find your way back to the square and from there back "home". Don't forget to visit the square in the evening hours, as it completely transforms from the busy daily hassle into a lovely local environment. I could go on, but ask me for more specific questions. We loved to be there.

Wow. This is a must experience place to visit , terrifyingly fantastic , you really needs your wits about you all the time , but keep a smile on your face and learn to be as clever as the locals , learn NO in every language, try not to be offended by anything and have a great time .

Mind Boggling!. It doesn't take long to get lost in the maze of alleys and corridors of the medina. BUT who cares as this is an entertaining experience in a culture foreign to most of us. The shops and vendors go on and on and the fun looms around every corner!! Carpe Diem---seze the day and enjoy.

Jump right in and enjoy it!!. There are many reviews on here for the medina and they go both ways! For me, if you have travelled a lot and have experienced similar places, the game of haggling is fun and you can pick up some nice stuff. If this is completely new to you, it could well feel intimidating and even dangerous.. HOWEVER! It really isn't either of these. Plan to get lost! You will, and when you do, it wont worry you. It is an absolute maze however let it draw you in and just follow your senses! My advice would be if you are unsure of where you are but you buy something, that vendor will be more likely to help you out. Avoid just asking anyone as who knows where you'll end up! We found just being friendly and when you're not interested just say - they will respect that. The Medina is an amazing experience so treat it as just that!

Maze of small streets. Do not panic, sooner or later you come out to something you recognize. DON'T pay some random (kid or young man) to show you the way. Go to a cafe relax over a mint tea and ask someone who works there. Google map works very well in the Medina and could be cheaper to use insted of paying one who will tell you he's a Guide.

FASINATING. Be prepared to get lost in this HUGE bazar. This Medina has silversmiths , carpet sellers , blacksmiths ,shoe shops , handbag shop , shops with the usual holiday souvenirs......... the list is endless and of course spice shops .The smell and colours from the spice shops are fantastic, but I loved watching the silversmith and blacksmiths at work best of all. They don't just sell at this medina they actual work here as well , fascinating to watch. Food is also sold in the medina , I didn't try any but the smell was mouth watering. Look out for the intricate doors and architeciure as you pass through . Watch out for bikes and men pushing carts through the narrow streets of the medina.

Medina - the heart of Marrakech. The heart & soul of the true Marrakech- you haven't been to Marrakech if you don't visit the medina. I would recommend staying in Medina if you travel to Marrakech it is colourful & exciting especially at dusk & beyond. We stayed in Medina area for a week and everyone was so friendly & respectful. Shops & food are very inexpensive but of high quality. The hustle & bustle is entertaining & fun.

Huge Medina. Rather hectic compared to Meknes and Fes, but the main reason for travelling to Marrakech. Had an unpleasant experience with young local men showing us the way to our Riad. If you want to ask directions, ask a woman or an older male.
Too much animal abuse for me. These people are just outright cruel to the snakes and monkeys. It was deeply unpleasant and won't be going back.

An excellent Bazar. I visited the Medina 20 years ago and the core of it's feel hasn't changed, but it cleaner and bigger than ever. (there were never any ATMs or banks inside before, but there are now!)
A must for Marrakech!

Busy not for faint hearted, but in middle of real culture. For the adventurous .. Stayed in Ryad in Medina very busy at times moped and other cart vehicles also use these narrow lanes pedestrians and locals have to be careful particularly at corners. Two accidents seen during our 1 week stay. See Ryad Amiran review for further info.However if you wish to live with the locals this is the area to experience the culture. Varied re cleanliness. Quality of Ryads also variable Hotels there equivalent of guest houses. Beware of star rating, ours was not as high as advertised.

Overrated and disappointing. Was really looking forward to our 5 day trip to Marrakesh but the Medina was rather disappointing. Far less history to see then I expected as it turns out that each dynasty tended to destroy whatever their predecessors built. It's great to take in the hectic souks and main square but you can do that in 1 day.The new town is even worse with absolutely nothing interesting at all.
Live poultry market inside.. Same stuff as elsewhere just more of it. Area around the live poultry market is really smelly. Did not see any really exceptional goods.

Must go when in Marrakech. The alleyways and ryads provide an insight into how life used to be. The use of a guide is recommended - the equivalent of £4 for an hour tour of the Berber Market. We visited a Arga Oil Workshop and a carpet equivalent which were both interesting. Apart from looking at the production, one had a chance to look at the inside of a ryad and the way in which the interior spaces were used as workshops and retail area..

CAUTION ! Dirty, Agressive, Crowded, and Dangerous. Thank you recent London contributor for finally telling the truth about the Marrakech Madina. This place is NOT GOOD. You risk your life from constant (every 40 seconds) motor cycle attackers coming to within an inch (or closer) of your legs and head. Not my idea of a good time. I am currently staying at a not nice riad deep inside the Madina (have been here for 8 days) and dread going out each day. The Madina is huge and almost impossible to not get lost regularly - no signs, just vague landmarks to follow. The souks are super crowded and don't even think of stopping to shop - you will be immediately be beset upon and urged, no, demanded that you buy something. Many young men will sense that you are confused or lost and offer to help you out only to intentionally misdirect you, then suggest that you hire them to fix your problem. There are dead and dying animals everywhere (dogs, cats, donkeys, horses) and unfortunately, equally distressed homeless people on every corner (real homeless and starving people - not Western style semi-homeless) who will be begging for anything. This is a truly awful place and be aware that I am sure that many, and even most of the "positive" reviews found here are from people on 2 and 3 day closely controlled "tours" (probably staying at the Four Seasons) and totally sheltered from the real Madina. If you go on your own, expect the worst. YOU HAVE NOW BEEN WARNED !

Marrakesh vs essouira . So after spending 3 perfect days on the sleepy coastal town off essouira we headed off to the mystic land(or so it seemed) of Marrakesh, supratours coach was amazing really great service and cool air con, after spending 3 hours in the baking sun on our coach we arrived to the bus terminal just outside the centre of Marrakesh, I was really excited as since a small boy I've wanted to visit this place and try some amazing food and see monkeys and snakes ect..Hop forward a 15 minute taxi ride to the medina where we were dropped in the middle of no where and our driver just jestired forwards and walked away, we gradually walked into the medina and it was very clear we were gonna be hassled, we both couldn't seem to find this concealed riad and as soon as I turned to ask for directions we were set about on by different guys harassing us and offering to take us to the riad, long story but short version a reasonably decent looking guy approached us and must of overheard us mention the riads name and said follow me I'll show you, we followed him and soon after realised we were going in circles and then lead down a dead end alley way where his friend was waiting, it was actually our riad but the guy didn't work there, he even asked my booking number and I just gave my name, he then suggested giving the other guy 200 dirham for taking us and I knew we were being worked and started to walk out of the alley way, swearing and shouting followed and we knew that the guys couldn't get physical as both me and my partner are 6 foot plus eventually we went into another hotel and called our riad asking if somebody would collect us and informing them of what happened, they sent a guy who walked us back to the alley where we were just hustled and it turns out it was our riad.Marrakesh has a distinct feel to it and I'm happy to say it's not for me, I feel years ago it would have been charming and a bit cheeky and people trying to scam a bit of cash but now it seems it's really hell bent on draining tourists, I have been charged extra for things that are priced and when questioned had change thrown at me, I've had taxi drivers almost come to blows with each other and children literally grab at my arms and demand money, it might come off as I'm naive or should have my guard up but my idea of Marrakesh has been slightly tarnished down to my bad experience, essouira was a total contrast and I will now visit there to relax and have amazing fish and swim in the sea, sorry Marrakesh but I won't be returning!

An amazing experience and different than other Medinas. The Medina is worth seeing, experience buying like a local and haggle over the prices for the best bargain. The people are completely amazing, kind and very welcoming. The medina will completely turn you around and you can get lost for hour - I really mean hours. It's best to do a tour initial - even if briefly. Your hotel can set you up with a local guide which will take you around. Be very specific with the guide on what you are interested in as they will normally take you around but to their friends shops first and foremost. Not a bad thing but if you share your interest they are more than happy to give you great input and detail. If you like to do the Medina on your own make sure you have plenty of time, sunscreen and plenty of time. Don't be afraid to ask the locals for directions. And don't forget to haggle haggle haggle.

Mixed feelings at the beginning with a wonderful ending. When we flew into Marrakech, we were taken to our hotel, a small riad near the central square. We went for a walk to see the city. We were immediately bombarded with offers to come and see a shop, go for an excursion, buy some hash and many more. If we showed any interest in anything, we were not allowed to walk away empty handed. This was all down to our attitude and confidence. They could sense that we were out of our depth and comfort zone. We then spent several days touring the country and when we returned to Marrakech for our final 3 days, we had experienced so much in other cities that it became much easier and therefore much more fun to interact with the locals. Bartering for different things became second nature and highly enjoyable. Be prepared to walk away if you don't get the price that you want and don't be afraid to say no. I managed to barter a price from 180Euro down to 25 which goes to show how much they raise the price for foreigners. Tell them their shop is beautiful but you're not interested in buying anything. They loved this and I was able to browse and not feel any pressure to buy a single thing inside. They were just proud that I had complimented their shop and its contents. Give them something (a compliment) and they feel like they owe you something (the chance to walk around their shop, hassle free). It's amazing how we changed our attitude to Marrakech in a matter of 10 days. Marrakech is a fantastic place to visit if you have the right outlook but a nightmare if you're not prepared for it. I love this city and we are already planning a second visit.

Trap. It sa nice a vibrant spot, we were very annoyed by two young men who lost us for 30min in small lanes to get us to a spot we were close to in the 1st place. They then became very aggressive and rude asking for money. Don t go unless you can stand those kind of tricky people

Different culture . Great opportunity to see and explore a completely different life! If you're willing to see a totally different world and if you come from Europe, it's a must-see for you! Make sure your plans include this place, you won't regret. Just better look out for your friends or your partner, as it's not so hard to get lost in the crowd.

Combine Culture with Shopping. The old city still maintains the magic of medieval ages, with a lot of old attractions to see, mainly Islamic mosaic and decoration typical in Morocco. Just go through the labyrinths, experience the way of living in almost all Middle eastern old cities, and try to orient yourself and not get lost, else wise, seek local help at a cost. While walking shop around a buy leather goods, fabrics, and souvenirs at bargain prices if you master the art. It is simply a different way of living.

Dramatic Medinas. The Medina in Marrakesh is in fact a collection of different medinas such as the silversmiths, the carpet sellers, the lantern and light makers, the lock makes the blacksmiths, the species and of course pigment makers and clothes, shoes and all the normal souvenirs. The colours and the smells of the spices are absolutely stunning, but I found the most fascinating to be the blacksmiths and metal workers. Unlike some medinas and souks, there is a lot of actual work going on here, they don't just sell, they make things from scratch in front of your eyes. Working conditions will give and H&S officers a heart attack, but the results are stunning. We didn't buy much here as we were going on to Essaouria, which we were told would be cheaper with less bargaining. This was true but they did not have all the sames things as Marrakesh so we missed out a bit there.

Be prepared to get lost. The Medina was great and a short walk to the market which will challenge the best map user. Loved all the local arts and crafts. The aromas of soaps and spices and cooking of breads and kebabs. All wonderful. Be prepared to haggle as the starting price is rediculous so go in at rediculous low price and meet half way. That's the plan anyway. Sometimes you loose sometimes you win, but you must also enjoy the haggle. They do. We stayed at Riad Helen in the Medina which was fabulous. Would go back there tomorrow if I could. Mario and Maxime were the best. Providing all the info you will need to explore the local area

Beautiful and intriguing. I loved strolling around the Medina in Marrakech because the old buildings, and the craftsmen I encountered, were really special. Previously I had purchased a small book with illustrations of old trades in Marrakech and I was delighted to find some of them there. The knife sharpener and a wonderful weaver were my favorites. I also liked some of the graffiti on the houses and the intricate, gorgeous doors. The Medina was my favorite place in Marrakech!

Appalling treatment to animals . Really upsetting. Horses forced to stand about and pull carts about 20 hours a day have not seen one get food or water in 3 day's. Thwy have nowhere to rest and are tied up so thwy can't lie down ever. awful. Makes me want to go home now.

World Heritage Site. Go and ramble, get a little lost, find what you came looking for and what you did not know existed. Enjoy the fine details of the architect and the grandiose market and pubic areas of Marrakech. Sights, sounds and smells abound.

Plan A Few Days Here To See All Of The Masterpieces of Both Architecture and Art.. The Medina of Marrakesh is a designated World Heritage Site. Just to give you some cultural context for this area, Marrakesh was, for a long time, a major political, economic and cultural centre of the western Muslim world, reigning in North Africa and Andalusia. Among the most notable monument from that time was the Koutoubia Mosque, with it's incredible 77 meters tall minaret. This mosque is the quintessentail monument of Muslim architecture and continues to be one of the landmarks of the current urban landscape today. Some might even call it the Symbol of The City. There is so much to see here in the Medina: the Kasbah, the ramparts, the incredible monumental gates and gardens. You should plan a few days here to see all of the masterpieces of both architecture and art.
crazy cool place. Here is where all tourists coming. Medina of Marrakech is magic place with Jamma el fna square. Often overpriced souveniers, but worth to visit and take amazing pictrues

Get a little lost and just enjoy. I liked the rambling nature of the medina and the way one partly stumbled into what you were looking for, and at the same time, discovered accidentally many other enjoyable nooks and views.

Medina. Visited the Medina with a guide on last day of treking trip to the atlas mountains while waiting for late night flight, well worth the visit, a guide is worth the money as you see lots of places etc and get all the history explained glad we went.

Magic Medina. This is a must when in Marrakech .You can buy anything Morrocan and the smells of the spices are exquisite. You may get lost but you will always find your way out. Try the biscuits and cakes excellent. If you don't visit the Medina you have not been to Marrakech

a NICE CITY TO VISIT ONCE IN A LIFE TIME. you will diffidently enjoy 3 days in this city but not more and be careful of eating in public or anywhere.
be prepared to pay a lot of tips and to be asked for money if you stopped to watch any activity in the street.
A place to be visited once in a life time ..

1001 night. This is really like 1001 night - the fact that you are behind the 19 km long wall which incresses the Medina are special. The Medina with an historic from 1070 is just an great experience - here you can do all your shopping in the souk, buy rugs, herbs, bags, shoes or whatever tempt you.A good walk around just looking at the people are just the best.
Real Marrakech. Stayed in a Riad in the Medina. Back street are where the locals live. Watch out for the bikes whizzing through the narrow streets
Excellent , one more time !. Excellent , well-planned for French quarters of the city . Also you can be pedestrian. In each time of the day/night , you may walk. Enjoy your time!

Maze. You can not come to marrakech and not visit the Medina, it was a once in a lifetime experience as after getting lost and going round in circles you probably don't want to do it again.The shops were great, locals friendly and some amazing architecture. Great views and lots of different smells and sights!

Get lost!. Try to get lost there. Or don't, medina will do the job for you :)In medina you can obtain and procure practically everything. I mean, really, everything. The greatest outdoor shopping mall ever.My greatest experience was hammam (the old public bath) somewhere in the middle where only locals go.

Great Bargains. Be prepared to haggle , it's great fun , can be intimidating , be nice and playful there are some real bargains to be had , I bought wto lovely wicker shopping baskets, the starting price was 600dh, I paid 100dh for the two in the end , don't be frighted to start real low as the expectation is you only go upwards

the marvelous but difficult Medina of Marrakesh. Basically Marrakesh is two cities. The mostly 15th century Medina and the mostly 1950's nouveau ville (new city). They are about a kilometer apart and it is easy to walk or take a taxi from or to them.As flavorless as the new city is the Medina abounds with flavor, charm and color. But these values do not come without a price and the hussle-bussel of the Medina 'streets' crowded with people, motorcycles, bicycles, carts laden with goods and the lack of sidewalks plus the occasional car and taxi make getting around in the Medina a challenge to say the least.But for those who are intrepid or young enough to go hiking or trekking these should be of no concern. For the elderly or infirmed it is not a good idea to venture far into the medina without a strong and capable helper.Registered guides are readily available to act as liason and navigators and for those who are not really fearless it is a good idea to enlist their services.The souk(s) are located in the Medina, as is the Jamaa el fna, the main square.I highly recommend at least spending a couple hours in the Medina where some outstanding Mosques and small museums can be found, as well as just taking in the architecture and watching the daily life of the residents who call the Medina home.

Great shopping and deals to be had. A lot of fun to walk through. Be prepared with your bargaining skills and poker face because everyone will want to negotiate with you. Also be aware of the many many many people and children who will try to lead you astray from your path to take you where you want to go 'for free" and then ask you for money once they have got you somewhere you did not want to be. Better to get lost on your own then to pay someone to get you lost.

Amazing. We visited day and night. night was an eye opener a lot of music drums and dancing. a lot of food stalls day and night. whatever they ask for prices when you buy things we bartered to a third of what they were asking.. snake charmers monkeys and watch out for the ladies trying to put henna tattoos on you. we also went for a ride in a horse drawn carriage which was worth it 200 dinhams.

A Must See. It's been said before, but you really can't go to Marrekech without visiting the Medina. At the centre of this is the market square which is a real experience. The sights, sounds, smells and experience of shooting down everyone vying for your attention is not to be missed. General advice:- Stay away from the Henna ladies - don't even engage them.- Drink as much delicious freshly squeezed orange juice as you can stomach. - Grab a bowl of snails - cheap and actually quite tasty.- Try get a seat at Chez Hassan for a sausage sandwich. - Get lost in, and haggle in the Souks - but know how to 1st. Brilliant experience all round!
Medina at night. Loved it. The hustle and bustle, the aroma, the overall ambiance. Best viewed at night, but be prepared to handle the crowds.

Confusing. I have mixed feelings about the Medina. It can be very fascinating and very repulsive at the same time. The problem is that people are so annoying there that you cannot fully enjoy what you are seeing. You are surrounded by people trying to sell you every sort of thing, trying to let you take picture with every sort of thing etc etc. Very very very very annoying! Moreover,as my boyfriend speaks arabic, he understood every thing the boys where saying to me, extremely rude!
Fakes Galore. Altogether good experience. Lots and lots of fake items for sale. I think the prices were a bit high on certain items and haggling doesn't seem to work with all the vendors

Must see. The Medina is the old city which now has been transformed into entirely shops, restaurants and hotels. It is a crazy maze and you can easily get lost. It is bustling and exactly what Westerners think of when we think of a Moroccan market.

Our trip to the market. On our trip to Marrakech we had to pay a trip to the local square which a must for anyone. Visiting Marrakech its so busy and full of characters it must not be missed from snake charmers to belly dancers and stalls selling everything you must go.

Hussain Rassai . Medina is like a good market place in Marrakesh. It's an old historical area with a dynamic vibs and crowded It's very unusual and unique for western tourist It's pretty common in countries in the eastMarrakesh has awesome weather from Oct to may

Wonderful experience. Through the Riad Les Trois Mages within the Medina, we had organised a half day guided tour of the Medina. Our guide was Eder who was English speaking,Eder met us at the Riad from where we started our tour. Eder explained the history of Marrakech going back to the 11th century. The main buildings were shown to us. Visited the Medersa Ben Youssef then into the Souks to see the various workshop are then to various parts of the Souks. Visited the Palais La Bahia and finished in the Jemaa-el-Fna which is the main square.We had a fantastic insight about te Medina and Eder was brilliant.It is really worth the time.Highly recommended.

This is a MUST in Marrakesh. This is a MUST in Marrakesh. You'll find a lot of typical stuff to buy. They hace narrow streets. Lots of sellers trying to make their business and where the prices must have to be negociated ALWAYS.

Beautiful Medina. I visited ths Medina this month.It is a big and beautifull Medina, as there are many in Morocco. As usual there are plenty of different things being sold.Lots of sellers trying to make their business and where the prices must have to be negociated.

Beyond enjoyable!. We're lucky. We've been to the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul and Khan El Khahili in Cairo, we've haggled in Chiang Mai and Bangkok and Beijing and Hong Kong. I note this to emphasise there is something special about Marrakech and its Medina. For those overwhelmed easily or claustrophobic then honestly Im not sure it will be the place for you. For those who have a terrible sense of direction stay somewhere like Riad Nashira where a staff member will take you for a free guided walk of the Medina to get your bearings and to show you how to remember how to get home. So what is so special about the Medina - firstly a lot of the craftsmen and women are actually in the medina. Wander the back alleys and you will see them at work. That is pretty rare and really not something you see in the places mentioned above where most of the works are brought in. Also there is so much variety and colour in the Medina. Really the more you explore the more you will find. Get off the main streets and head down some of the side alleys you will find amazing leather and wood products. Dont forget to start the bargaining at at least half the price. You will work out quickly by wandering around (and eaves dropping on other people haggling) whereabouts the price should be. Our advice would be wander - take in the atmosphere, do a mental list of some of the things you may like, speak to your Riad and find out what is genuine and if unsure get a walking guide. However, dont be too timid or scared you will bring back wonderful things. We met a couple who were in Marrakech sourcing products for their shop in Australia and were truly stunned at the prices they could onsell some of the products for. I note this only to say - buy it with the locals in Marrakech dont go home and look to buy something like it.
totally 100% must visit. Medina of Marrakech is must visit place for everyone. I can just say I love to get lost there. Its a maze of narrow streets u will never forget.

Insanely noisy after sunset. Medina of Marrakech is a contradictory place - I have never been tried to be "legally" robbed (e.g. by selling products for 5x - 10x higher price above real value, young guys sophisticatedly creating situations that you feel lost and need help - for exorbitant price of course - beware especially of phrases like "this way is closed", "this day is is the last day when...") so many times like in Marrakech. But if you stay patient, watchful and a bit arrogant, the medina is a really interesting place for aimless roaming and soaking the special atmosphere. Despite the tiresome marketeers, the medina appeared as a pretty safe place, so do not worry, take your courage (and map of course) and immerse yourself into the chaos :-)

Mayhem at night but a must. You can't go to marrakech and not visit the medina and souks. As two women travelling alone we were a bit wary at first, but the people are friendly. You do get pressured to buy their goods and a lot of the time we just ignored. One thing I noticed, if you really like something, do the haggling but then go to walk away then watch the price drop massively!The tattoo ladies can be a bit forcefull, we stayed well away, but one girl had one done and had a bad experience where they tried to charge much more then originally agreed, threatened her and her boyfriend to go and get her man if they didn't pay up, which they did.Oh and mind the bikes, stay right! Overall a great experience and an attack on the senses.

Nice old city. Medina is the old center of Marachesh nice full of history and of poverty as well.i love the fact that you can find a huge market in there and also that the orange juice is so cheep is 4/5 dirham and ujually 13dirham is 1£ so you can drink like 3 glases of oj.

Good ceilings. Good ceilings, but not much else. Gardens really nothing more than the entrance walkway, with a few plants and trees.Building rather run down, no information at all in the place, not even a title for each 'room'. So, unless you can understand someone else's guide, it's pure guess work.Nothing on the floor to help, best bits can be seen by looking straight upwards.Some amazing ceilings, elaborate decoration, wood work and inscriptions of the Koran.Only a few rooms, but after a while ceilings become a little less interesting.Only 10Dh entrance each, but really not worth any more. Not disabled friendly, my friend (with one leg) sat on a chair but before long a rather solemn looking attendant came and stood beside her. She felt obliged to stand up and he immediately sat in 'his chair'!On the strike of closing time it was clear the staff wanted us to leave. The mops came out, doors began to close etc.Still, at least we visited.

The Medina IS Marrakesh. One of the reasons why thousands of visitors come to Marrakesh: The Medina, where the Orient, as we envision it, is still present, with its century old buildings, alleys, places, gardens and palaces.

Great place. Make sure you don't give asking price, bargain with the merchants because you get the price down. You don't need a tour guide just go in the morning and wonder around till noon by then you will have covered the whole place

Animated madness. Go to the Medina and be prepared to have your senses assaulted and your credulity challengedIf your buying goods be ready to barter and to enjoy the experience Remember you DON'T have to buyYou will be hustled by "friendly" locals who will offer to show you the way if you get lost and be expected to be paid to show youIt's a great experience but try not to be intimidated by a culture light years away from what you are used to Immerse yourself to get the most out of it

Lovely. You should not go to Morocco and confine yourself in places like Casablanca that does not portray the best of this amazing country. Marrakesh has a totally different flare and atmosphere, also offering history and sights well worth visiting.

Less daunting with technology . I arrived in Morocco resigned to the fact that I'd be forking out some cash now and then to get me 'un-lost' in the labyrinth medinas of Marrakech and Fes. On arrival, however, I was told that the maps.me app was really accurate and you can use it offline. I've used it in both cities and although I ignore it in general for the pure joy of exploring, it has bailed me out 100% of the time! So jump in, take every winding lane you dare, and enjoy the mystery of the medina!

If you are looking for chaos, culture and character.... We were told to be sure to visit the Marrakech medina and our hotel was booked right in the heart of it which made being part of the daily chaos undeniable! Be sure to arrive before dark if you have accommodation inside the walls, as making your way through the alley ways can be a challenge once you are through the walls. During the day there are plenty of children actively looking to help you for a fee to find your way around.The market is a great experience with alley way upon alley way of craft, vegetable and food stalls and locals selling their wares, restaurants, shops and historic homes and hotels.
:). Colorful, busy medina with a net of small street and thousands of small local shops. It is pleasant to get lost here:)

Complete chaos!. This place is right out of an old movie...snake charmers, monkeys on leashes, animal heads hanging from hooks, baubles, bangles, beads, pottery....junk everywhere! It is definitely a must-see, but you should only attempt to visit with a guide, as the place is a series of maze-like streets. If you are visiting Marrakech, this place is a definite MUST SEE....take pictures, but be prepared to 'pay' for the posed photos with snake charmers, etc (e.g., unless you have a zoom lens with big aperture and can capture the chaos from a distance).Food is available, but I wouldn't recommend eating in this place...unless you want to experience Montezuma's Revenge!!

The old city . The median is beautiful however the shops are pricey and they do play on tourists when it comes to extortionate prices. They will always ask for over the odds so always be careful and understand the currency otherwise its a great place to go and see the culture of Morocco

Place of interest.......... The Medina is a fascinating place there is so much going on, very lively atmosphere & always something different to see each time you go, we wandered down there most days just to soak up the feel of the place.

Not for everyone.. If you're planning on visiting Marrakech, you're going to the Medina. But if you don't like crowds, noise, sweat, smells, and such, then reconsider.My wife and I are used to this. We've lived in similar environments, and visited others. I'd say the Medina is somewhat similar to parts of Istanbul, but not as clean or charming. I didn't find the architecture to be particularly inspiring, and the narrow windings streets were often not narrow enough to prevent legions of buzzing motorcyclists almost taking your arm off. It is definitely an experience, and often a very good one, but it can get mentally tiring having your spatial awareness turned up to max all the time. Which is why so many Riads get such good reviews in this city: look for how many reviews describe them as 'an Oasis' or similar. It's because the Medina is so mentally tiring, that anywhere that offers an escape from that automatically becomes welcome.If you're thinking about a trip to Marrakech, think carefully about what you personally like and dislike, and see if it matches up. We enjoyed it overall, but 4 nights was enough.
Mad busy and a bit overwhelming. Very busy, a bit overwhelming at first, so many people and motorbikes and donkeys! A real authentic experience

Bartering for a bargain. We visited the old town Medina in Marrakech which was very busy. We would advise to go as a group of 6+ or with a hotel guide as there are lots of tiny back streets and alley ways you would definitely get lost. So If you enjoy bartering this is the place to go for a bargain.
Lovely place . I like the medina because of its exotic charm and architecture. I dislike the the lying guides and pushy sellers. I recommend marakesh for short stay

Just amazing. Labyrinth of beautiful little streets. Be aware of asking people for direction usually they will ask you for some money even if they will not guild you to your destination. Safer option is to knock on any of the riads doors and ask people there. If you are ever hungry at night you should try some of street vendors sandwichs....especially one with beef kefta! Just delicious
A fun place to visit early before the crowds arrive.. There are not many things one would want to buy in the Medina, but the atmosphere is fun if you get there early.

Medina Marrakech. We visited the medina during the day when it was quite hot,as soon as we arrived we were pestered by guys selling stuff. When you enter the square beware of the very pungent smell from the horses pulling the carriages. As you enter the main part you are surrounded by groups of men either playing card games like ' chase the lady' of snake charmers who will put a snake on you and demand a photo in exchange for payment.Going around the souk is like running the gauntlet if you are not used to it, so be prepared to be hassled to ' just look inside 'at ' Adsa Price ' goods.We were told by a very polite man thar the Berbers were visiting for one day to show their wares and told us which direction, minutes after setting off he appeared and said if we were having trouble finding it his friend who just happened to be passing would show us, this turned into a ploy to show us the tannery then into a shop where we were expected to buy something, we politely gave him a small tip and left, so be on your guard. The evenings are better very colourful and very noisy, a good view can be had from one of the roof top terraces for the price of a drink ' compulsory ' at the tup of the stairs, in all am experience, but one I personally would not need to repeat.

Hmm, medina, right. Medina is actually hidden under market, and is not such interesting itself .... actually most tourists go here to see market and buy / eat something, not to search for hidden architecture etc.
Superior Metalwork. Step closer to the glistening brass entryway and look down at your feet. Yes, those are lemon seeds! The brasswork is rubbed daily with fresh lemons.

Perfect for browsing and walking. There's so much to see and buy in the area. Don't be afraid to get lost in the alley ways and tiny streets, someone will always help you find your way (for a tiny fee) I could have spent hours and hours just wandering around, taking in the atmosphere and the culture. Definitely go back!

Get lost, find treasures.... Maze of beautiful alleys, hidden treasures, great sights around every corner. Very relaxed wandering, almost no hassling by shopkeepers or touts, amazing (hope the Egyptians are reading this too...)

a journey into the past. Visiting the Medina of Marrakech is always a good trip to the past and throughout a different culture. take your time to see the details and to find out that everything is unique.
simply stunning. history at it best what a magnificent place hard to describe what a stunning place the MEDINA is but must not be missed

Well worth a vosit. Open 9am to 10pm daily you will see goods being handmade and sold - some amazing skills and workmanship to be seen.It gets very hot in these tight streets due to the volume of people so wear light clothing. The ground is uneven and dirty therefore closed toed shoes would be better.Many items available for purchase from furniture to carpets to jewellery and lanterns! Amazing to see how these people make a living day in day out
