Shopping Secrets of the medina Marrakech Morocco. Urban Adventures Shopping Secrets of the medina.Another excellent tour. This tour takes you to shops away from the tourist traps. Good guide and a great place to buy. The shops we visited were a leather shop, great shoes and handbags, jewellery shop, rug shop, pottery shop. Good way to see the shops that the locals go to. A good way to learn about the history of the medina.Another great Urban Adventure. I do not work for Urban Adventures.

Great Experience. You really can't go to Marrakech without visiting the main Souk/Medina. My husband did an initial visit on our second day with our oldest son (10) to get his bearings, know where the shuttle stopped etc. a couple of days later, I joined them with our younger son (7). We went around 6 o'clock so it would be a little cooler (once inside the main medina (walled area) within the main square, it is covered so much cooler. It can be quite daunting for younger children because it's busy, noisy with lots going on. There are snake charmers, holy men, monkeys wearing nappies and footy kits. Be careful not to take pictures as the handlers will badger you for money. There are also lots of ladies offering henna tattoos. I declined but one lady grabbed my hand as I walked passed and started drawing on my hand. The children were fascinated so I let her carry on and had to pay her what I thought it was worth (10 dirhams my not impressed husband had to hand over as he had nothing smaller!). As nice as the tattoo was, not a good idea if you have to hold on to a child's hand. That said, it takes 10 minutes to dry but it lasted approximately 2 minutes before being smudged by my son so i had to buy some wipes to rub it off (and from my sons hand) as well as the annoying glitter they also sprinkle on!!! there are hundreds of shops and stalls. The vendors try to get you to come in but a polite no thank you is all you need if you're not interested. I certainly didn't feel hassled and despite my reservations, enjoyed the experience of watching my husband barter for 'genuine fakes!' as the vendors called them. When we came out of the medina (8.30pm) all I could say was 'wow!'. The square was packed, lots of people everywhere, loud morrocan music, wonderful smells coming from the food stalls-it really came alive. The smell of horse poop when you walk passed the horse and carriages (for rides around the town), was quite overwhelming so hold your breath. There are elderly people and mothers with newborns begging for money which can be upsetting but as long as you keep you children held tight, you should enjoy this experience. We ended up going 4 times in total (my husband is a shopaholic!) so it can't be that bad!!

Fascinating market. Interesting old city with merchants selling Moroccan food and goods. Be careful in the medina - there are motorbikes and other vehicles whizzing around the narrow lanes.It is very easy to get lost, so if you are not used to navigating by where the sun is, take a compass with you before you leave the UK, or download an app for your phone.
A Must-Do!. If you want to see old town...this is the place to be. Get mixed in with the locals and try foods and the locally made garments. Worth it! I promise

shops and maze. It's a good thing we got a tour guide. Otherwise, it is easy to get lost and miss the right shops to buy good stuffs. There are many interesting shops and places to see inside the medina. It brings us back to cultural heritage of Morocco in the midst of modern Marrakech city.

Interesting but exhausting !. Nice streets, nice shops, a beautiful place you must see if you're visiting Marrakech, it is very hard to find your way in these streets however and the people in the medina will never leave you alone, be prepared !
Good to explore but watch the motor bikes,. This medina is worth exploring. Don't be afraid of getting lost. Be guided back to the main square by the tower of the mosque.
Come to buy see or haggle. A great place to get lost in, loads to see loads to buy and loads to smell. A real cultural departure from modern marrakech
wonderful attack on the senses. 60000 stall and 400 alleyways. Be prepared to haggle. We got some great bargains. Also go at night as well as in day it's fantastic .
Only interesting. Not being the key to see in Morocco is a mandatory, should be more carefuly maintened. History is there but the inhabitant pass over it and devalues it, not being with trash

Emperors new clothes. Marrakech is not a boho hippy dippy existence. Bianca Jagger is not lounging in arabian bars listening to enthralling tales of arabian daring do.Marrakech is not for western tourists. If you like getting robbed, treated like crap and any females in your party getting leered and jeered at by mysognistic men with no teeth, then its the place for you.The behaviour of all men, from hotel staff to the biblical scenes outside in the Medina are appalling.Marrakech thirty years ago is not the Marrakech now. It is not liberal and free.I do not understand the gushing reviews of this place, yes it is colourful but a few vibrant looking market stalls (souks, lets make it sound exotic), do not excuse the constant ripping off and heckling. If you get eye contact with anyone they are on you.I have sailed around the world many times in the Merchant Navy and been to some very dangerous places, nowhere has the local people been soo , well, appalling.Spend your tourist money elsewhere, where it is appreciated.

Souks to be You!. An absolute labyrinth of stalls and dead ends. I wandered around for hours seeking our Riad which was just behind Ben Youssef Mosque. For the first couple of strolls it is enchanting and full of smells and interesting things to buy. However, if you are staying nearby it can become a pain trying to get home as you will be asked for money over and over until you lose your rag.

Hassle-laden and very confusing. Having gone with a companion and found it interesting there was a marked contrast once there alone. Women alone - and I mean travelling completely alone, like I did- may find it quite lonely. You can't really stroll around as being a Westerner you are immediately visible, and that can be very intrusive. Every male will offer themselves as a guide for a price, but equally, every stall holder will also shout after you to come in. It gets really tedious negotiating your way around the Medina, it's impossible to ask for directions as everyone wants to be paid, and the piles of tat start to look very tawdry after a while. It's pretty depressing. I'm quite used to being alone but I won't be coming back,here alone again. It's actually quite boring unless you're on a mission to bargain for Moroccan souvenirs all day. And it's all quite rubbishy really.

Disappointing. The Medina is a labyrinth and few signs to help navigation, it is important you keep your bearings as the local people will not help, I found the place indifferent to visitors, certainly not friendly as you would expect from a tourist location. It is certainly picturesque but note that people don't like having their pictures taken (in case you didn't know). We struggled with finding good restaurants and did not like leaving the hotel at night because of the problems getting around. We had a bad experience getting followed after being sent into some narrow passages and were about to get conned - the hotel warned us about the scam. Be careful in the medina.

Good enjoyable place to visit and shop. The best thing about Medina of Marrakech is that unlike Fes, it is very closely located to the new city. The new Marrakech is way cleaner and modern. The Medina has more shops than Fes and the shopkeepers dont push you or insist you to buy. Most of them speak English very well and if you know French wholla. You need to be very good at negotiation and you will be a winner with things. The best thing is to go as deep as far inside the Sammarine - the long street on the left side behind Jama al Fnaa square and when youve reached like half way through, start going in the small allies and you will find treasures on very good prices. Have a good orange juice at the square but be very selective of what you eat as the restaurants around here are not so good and value for money.

Interesting and crazy. I love this place, but I do have to say it is not for everybody.Dark little streets and alleyway, motorcycles, people, vendors, shops. food! All kinds of stuff. I felt safe though. Just be street smart and have fun!

Vibrant, noisey and so much to see. Didn't go in the day time, but heard it was good to go at night. It was alive with people, circus acts, drama, animals, snake charmers.........Keep you wits about you.Didn't eat, but plenty of place to eat, ask for advice which number stall to eat at.
Kevin ritchie. Great time had went several times to eat at the medina was everything I had expected loads to do and see will be back

Comes alive at night . Amazing place that comes alive at night.Everything happening great restaurants over looking the medina.Great place for bargains always hammer them down half and little more then start your bartering with them.Must see and do experience of a life time.Just don't take own photos of monkeys or snake charmers or you will pay.Very safe lots of police and military also in plain clothes very assuring.

Worth a careful stroll. Lots of incredible sights to behold in the Medina. The maze-like alleyways are closed to vehicular traffic, but that does not stop scooters and motorbikes from whizzing down the lanes as though there are no pedestrians in sight. The alleyways of the Medina are a sensory overload. Raw, non-refrigerated butcher stalls and everyday refuse do not do much to delight the senses, but there are also an insurmountable number of stalls selling every imaginable Moroccan knickknack one could think of. Plus, people tend to be very friendly (oftentimes overly aggressive salespeople), especially in Jemaa el F'naa.
Go for the night food markets. Found the medina in Fes a lot more interesting and a lot busier. The night food markets are great and really good fun

Definitely worth a visit - like a different world!. If you're in Marrakech, make an effort to visit the Medina and have a wander around... yes, it can be hectic (expect to routinely be almost run over by motorbikes, donkeys and bicycles in the alleys between souks!) yes, some of the stall holders can be pushy and almost every single one will try to get you into their shop and yes, it is hot and sweaty and dusty.... but it is truly worth it!The sights and smells are like nothing you will have ever expected before and we genuinely found everyone to be pleasant and accomodating. Smile at people, be friendly and if you aren't interested, we found a firm no and a smile did the trick and we really didn't get any hassle. Be prepared to haggle - many store holders will not give you an outright price and expect you to offer them what you're willing to pay! Others will give you a price but it will be vastly inflated and its your perogative to get them down to what you're looking to part with! Good luck!

Exotic and Exciting. The Medina is a fascinating warren of narrow streets lined with tiny shops offering all manner of goods. It is very easy to get lost and it changes quite dramatically after dark and on fridays when many the shops are closed so finding recognisable landmarks is difficlult. There is signage to follow but it is sometimes contradictory but the trick is not to panic, download a compass app on your phone and set it to the direction of 'La Grande Place' - Jemaa al Fna.

Step back in time. Been here twice different times of the year Amazing at New year and Amazing in the summer, We stayed in a traditional Riad which was calm and beautiful, once you step out the door its like going back to biblical times, so much to see and really friendly people.

A trip back in time. Like walking back in the past...I felt I was in the Middle Ages and in a very exotic place. The smell of roses, mint and orange flowers in intoxicating. I love the colours of Marrakech. Careful to the people.

Travel back in the years.... Make sure you get a hotel close to the centre( between the red wall). You can travel by bus Or by taxi. I stayed there during the ramadan , life start after the sun gets down.

Exciting. I stayed for three nights within the Medina of Marrakech and did a day tour which was wonderful! There were so many fantastic sights and smells - the people were so friendly and at no stage did I feel unsafe - even at night! I wandered around by myself for a couple of hours and did not feel threatened in any way! You must visit the herbarists and discover the ancient exquisite smells of the potions and creams and remedies that have been passed down through time! And of course sample the divine sweets that can only be found in Morocco!

See it once and avoid it. The atmosphere is good its is buzzing at night and flamboyant but you are pestered by touts who sell anything and even when sat in cafes you can't escape.The tourist police, for which Marrakech are allegedly famous are non existent.The medina is renowned for of its ambiance, its food market and the proximity to the souks, what has happened is that it has become a tourist hell, where you feel prayed upon which ultimately detracts from what should be a wonderful experience.I concede that you should see it, ideally very early in the morning to watch it wake and my previous visits would have given it 4 possibly 5 stars but my last visit showed it for what it has unfortunately become - a tourist trap!

A must see!. By day it is a beautiful place to visit and right next to Khoutobia Mosque. By night it is the life and soul of Marrakech. Your able to enjoy the snake Charmers, belly dancers, all manner of foods and shop to your hearts content.

go go go. this place is so cool. i had never been to morocco and had no idea what to expect. the medina is teeming with vendors, selling everything from food to jewelry to lighting fixtures to juices to herbs and tinctures. i held an iguana named lady gaga and bought baby shoes for friends at home and drank freshly squeezed juice and was perfectly delighted with all of it. if you are a woman, be prepared for stares from men - but that's a little bit the story of life for women everywhere.

Great experience... with some hints and tips. Visiting the Medina was a great experience. The noise, smells, the completely different way of life, the food, street performers, and just sitting in a cafe watching the world go by.This is a definite 'To Do' visiting Marrakech. It's not going to be for everyone as it can be intimidating and some people might be put off by the hustle and bustle, but we spent pretty much half a day there, avoiding any of the 'mishaps' mentioned in other reviews. There are official guides available, but I have no idea where they came from or how much they cost. We just went for it on our own...First off, when arriving in the main square, I'd advise you find a reference point. Somewhere you recognise, and remember which side to exit from again. There are so many different ways in and out it's very easy to exit the wrong way and wonder where exactly in Marrakech you are. For a reference point, choose one of the buildings, and maybe take a picture of it. Choosing one of the street stalls isn't a great idea, as after a few hours they all start to look very similar.... also, they move around, leave, switch spots etc. Secondly, when wandering around the alleys and soukhs, expect to get lost. It'll happen so don't pretend it won't. Don't panic, and as long as you're wandering around the same areas as every other tourist, you'll inevitibly wander back round to somwehere you notice.Everyone there is trying to make money. It's not unknown for a local 'guide' to start walking in front of you, engage in conversation and then pretend to have led you to where you were going anyway. Usually they ask for something for their service, a few loose coins usually keeps them happy and costs virtually nothing. It's actually quite handy as well if, as mentioned before, you do find yourself lost and aren't sure where you're off to...for the sake of 20DH, or less, you can be back on your merry way.BE CAREFUL of any guide who offers to take you to 'leather auction', or a visit/tour or the 'tannery'. I'd read about this in previous reviews, and it almost happened to us. My girlfriend was going around different stalls/shops looking for a leather bag, so the offer of a leather auction made sense. It wasn't until the 'guide' mentioned a tour of the tannery that the penny dropped where we were going. I stopped immediately, thanked the guide, and told him we'd not be going. He knew straight away I'd realised. As previous reviews describe, this 'tannery' is a decent walk away from the main square and soukhs, is off the beaten track, and is a con. You find yourself in an area out of sight of other tourists and when you try to leave you are apparently blocked until you pay something... almost sounded like a calm robbery. I read and, thought it sounded far fetched, then realise how easily I almost walked straight into it myself.SMILE, and a firm but polite 'No thanks' goes a long way. We spent 4 hours in and out of stalls and markets. We only bought from 4 or 5 of them. Every stall owner will try and engage you. They're salesmen and they want a sale, the same the world over. If you don't want something simply thanking them for their 'help', politely declining and walking away usually led to an amicable end to the encounter. We weren't 'abused', or called any names the full day we were there. Of course, some sellers are pushier than other, you simply need to be firmer, just remember to keep smiling, ha ha.If you DO decide to buy something then you're going to need to haggle or be conned. If they offer a price first it'll be WAY over what it's worth. As a rough guide, we never went more than a third or a half of what they asked for to begin with and after totting everything up at the end of the day we'd done well. Be prepared to walk away... if they won't come down, and you think it's too much, just thank them and leave... usually they drop their prices again. They want what's best for them, you want what's best for you. Another trick to try is one I use... I know what I'll pay, so wear a money belt under your t-shirt (makes sense too when you consider pick-pocketting) and only put in your pocket the maximum you're willing to pay. That way when you start bartering you can show your empty pockets and that you have 'no more'. Stops them asking for silly figures too. Henna Ladies in the main square. Be careful not to let them start putting any henna tattoo's on you. Once they start they demand payment, create a scene and can cause some discomfort.... possibly forcing you into paying something. One will approach you showing a book of designs while the other approaches from the other end, trying to take your hand to start drawing. Be careful. The usual 'No thanks', smile and walk away worked fine for us.Musicians/Snake Charmers - When you see these guys, you're probably going to want to take a picture, guess what? Yep... there's someone there asking for money when you've taken a picture of their 'production'.Relax in the cafe's. Down the alley ways and side streets there are plenty of cafe's and restaurants to choose from, usually via a stairway leading you above the alleyways and stalls. I can't comment on any of those as we were too busy shopping and haggling but on return to the main square we were knackered, dehydrated and wanted a seat and a cold drink. We went into the French Cafe (I think it was), and before we knew it had spent around an hour just relaxing in the shade having some water, Coca Cola, and some coffee's, all for about 100DH, while watching the bustling market place.At the end of this it was time to go and meet our transport back to our hotel. I'm definitely glad we did this, and would thoroughly recommend other travellers give it a go as well.

Not the best medina - too westernised. We visited the Marrakech Medina at the end of a two week tripo around Morocco.If we had visited only Marrakech I have no doubt we would have been blown away by the comings and goings here.However, we had been to a number of other Medinas/Souks on our trips and so Marrakech did not compete that well eg especially compared to Fes.There was far too much 'western' goods on sale. There was a lack of small workshops showing people producing goods and services. Instead of just people and mules travelling through there were mopeds and motorised carts / buggies.If you can only see the one then MArrakech is OK. But there are better

A place like no other.. This is an astonishing place, there's nothing like it. Here life seems more real somehow, everything is played out on the streets here, everything is all mixed in; beautiful doorways with beggars sleeping against them, scooters, donkeys, spices, the souks, the battering, the hassle from stall holders. After the first day i wondered what on earth I'd done booking a week here and thought I would have \miserable time, then i settled in and very soon became intoxicated with the atmosphere, the sounds, sights and smells, none of which can be conveyed either with words or pictures. I loved getting lost on the souks then after a while realising i actually knew my way round much of them. This doesn't feel like a tourist town, even though of course, much of it is, because daily life mingles with everything else, everything blends in, the locals and the tourists . i would love to go back in the spring or winter too to see how the atmosphere is then as well.Perhaps not for the faint of heart. if you after a relaxing time this is not your place!It was like being in a living theatre, the streets themselves were enough entertainment. Sitting with stall holders, drinking mint tea, discussing family and lives, that was the essence of this place for me.I can't wait to go back!

Amazing!!!!. Lots of hustle and bustle but it's the real Marrakech, locals gathering in the evening and lots of stall holders selling food, best time to visit is in the evening when the Medina comes alive, take time to walk around and take everything in, well worth a visit.

Everyone wants a piece of you. Avoid!. The lack of hospitality was astonishing! I consider myself as a positive person, always trying to grab the good things and forget the bad ones, but in this place, as much as I wanted, I can't.You will be approached a number of times, with a lot of rudeness. You will be insulted, even if you answer politely. You will see bad treated animals ( cats, donkeys, horses ). Everyone ( or almost ) will try to fool you, just to get some of your money.I truly love tourism and what it can do to some places, but here is definitely a case where people turn bad and greedy due to that. I wanted to like it, but, ended up just hating it.

Feel like you're in another place, another world - amazing experience. The Medina is the old city, which is walled and has very small alleyways and streets. This is why you come to Marrakesh, otherwise in the more modern areas you're just experiencing what you do in every city in the modern world.Open your eyes, see the way people live here, their homes, their lifestyle and take part. The Medina is all about the culture of Morocco, it holds the history, the traditions and the way of life within its walls. Sure you'll get lost, it's ok, before you know it you'll see signs that tell you this way to the market (Jamaa El Fna) or that way to other areas. Lots of teenagers and children ask if you're lost and want to be led to particular areas for a small fee. You don't have to partake or use their services, but remember these people are not living a comfortable Western life so they want a fee because this is how they survive. Life is pretty hard but despite this people smile, they welcome you and are proud to share their lifestyle with you. Negotiate the fee before you agree to have someone show you the way - oh they will try to renegotiate once you arrive but just give them the agreed fee, thank them and be on your way.I suggest you stay in a Riad which is a traditional type of accommodation in the Medina. They will provide you with a map to help you navigate your way.

Does Not Live Up To Its Billing. Prior to our arrival in Marrakech, the name conjured up images of an exotic and somewhat mystical place.Unfortunately, what we experienced was somewhat less magical.In an old historic medina you do expect dirt, a degree of squalor and hassle from the vendors / hawkers, therefore this came as no surprise.However, what was deeply disappointing was the constant attempt from the youth in the streets and alleyways to actively mis-inform you in order to send you in the opposite direction to where you wanted to go in order to get you into their associated stores / shops. When you expressed no interest in their goods their attitude quickly changes to a somewhat aggressive posture which is highly annoying.The other major disappointment was the presence of seemingly thousand of scooters, motorbikes, mopeds and the like who were constantly racing through the narrow alleyways with no regard to the pedestrian traffic. This is not only dangerous, it adds to the already high levels of air pollution in these confined spaces and does not enable the visitor to in any way relax when you are in constant fear of being run over or run into.I do not know why the authorities do not try and control or restrict this activity.

Interesting and different . Loved the city , because of its exotic charm, architecture and a bit of chaos. It's different and fascinating but aware of the bad sites of the city (see the negative reviews). I disliked lying "guides", pushy sellers and expectations from everyone that tourist=money. After all, we had an amazing time there and I would recommend Marrakech for a short stay. If you plan to spend more time in Morocco there is much more to see then the big cities only!

Medina in Marrakech December 2013. I think these 3 photos speak for themselves of the utter beauty and adventure of the Medina in Marrakech. During the day or at night every turn in the street/path/alleyway opens to a brand new world and this world is well worth visiting.

Fantastic. The main reason for coming here and to get in amongst the local culture. Be aware you need to go with an open mind as there are many traditions that you would not see in the western world with regards to animal welfare

What an experience. . We were here in October 2012 , we visited at least four times within a week. It was vibrant and exciting. We started in the main square and always ended up within the indoor markets , lots to see and smell as the spices on display give a pleasant oroma and are also very colourful. Good prices too.As usual with markets you are cajoled to enter and then you can barter for the best deals.Top tip.. as with any busy places be careful and vigilant with your wallets and bags.... and enjoy this wonderful place.

Don't miss this experience. This has to be one of the main life experiences, do not miss. Use a guided tour to orientate yourself, this souk is huge. If you don't, you WILL miss some of the sights. Ironwork, camel skins, pottery, spices, it is all here. I have travelled a bit, but never seen Cobras with their charmers.

The old city. If you leave Marrakech without venturing inside the Medina walls, then, sorry, but you can't claim you've been to Marrakech.The sights and smells will assault your senses. And, be forewarned, the aggressive vendors and locals may assault your sensibilities. You have to keep everything in stride - just embrace the good and bad, for what it is.I highly recommend staying in a Riad inside the medina walls. Get out of your five-star hotels and experience the real Morocco.
What an experience . Stayed here for a week and it is culturally amazing. You have to come in and embrace the whole culture. Then it is amazing.
Great. A unique place with so much to see. A must do to stay in the medina when visiting Marrakech. Like taking a step back in time. A truly amazing experience. Not to be missed.

A True Cultural Experience. This is the Old portion of Marrakesh and is a true cultural experience. I think it would be a travesty to visit Marrakesh without visiting the Medina. I do however advise you NOT to drive!, Take a taxi into the area or better yet get a guide to take you through the area including the souk.

Be very careful. We are seasoned travelers and have visited many busy bazaars all over the world. The Medina in Marrakech, where we stayed in a lovely riad, was nonetheless a hostile and frightening place. We encountered aggressive and dishonest people who tried to steer us in the wrong direction, tried to make us pay for things we had not asked for, and mocked and ridiculed us mercilessly--despite our efforts to be friendly and respectful. At one point we were mugged as two young men tried to steal my purse and held my husband at knifepoint. Morocco was #1 on our bucket list, but after our experience we cannot recommend it as a tourist-friendly place. If you must go, we recommend steering clear of the big cities and heading to the coast, the mountains, or the desert, where the people were much more hospitable and kind. Disappointed.

Horrible! Horrible! Horrible!. Horrible! Absolutely terrible! Every tourist I saw looked as stressed, miserable and harassed as I was so I can't understand the positive reviews at all!First of all, the place stinks like an open sewer, every building is a sickly shade of pink and there isn't a hint of vegetation anywhere. Just rows and rows of aggressive locals selling cheap tat to tourists at over inflated prices along narrow streets where you have to also dodge donkeys, motorcycles, cars, vans and push-bikes, none of which have any respect for pedestrians. As another reviewer has said, it is obvious that the sellers are all working together in deceive and relieve you of your hard earned cash. They will constantly tell you that the places you are heading to are 'closed' and divert you to other dubious places such as the 'tanneries' where you'll be shown some rancid dead animal skins and then asked to fork out 100 dirhams to the 'guide' for his 5 minute unintelligible efforts!! I just refused to pay and walked off to shouts of 'you're no good!' - something I became quite used to hearing. Ironic coming from a bunch of nasty, thieving 'no good' conmen. Absolutely horrible place. Even people who pretend to help you have their own agenda. If you take a picture of the snake charmers, they want money. If you take a picture of the street performers, they want money. If you take a picture of someone's shop, they want money. If you are lost and someone offers to point you in the right direction, he'll want money. Do not trust anyone! Then there is the animal cruelty - poor monkeys with chains around their necks, wearing gold outfits and soiled nappies, snakes, donkeys, stray mangey looking cats everywhere. Awful!Then there is the street food. Bland, tasteless and - awful. Just avoid it altogether. They tried to charge us 4 times the amount on the menu for food that was too disgusting to eat and gave us such bad vomiting and diarrhoea, we had to cancel our planned excursion the following day. After that, we only ate at the restaurants and went upstairs where we could eat in peace without being hassled by people trying to sell us knock off mobile phones, watches and.... tissues!And what is it with the tissues? Everyone from kids as young as 4yrs old to grown women trying to sell you packets of handy andies. It's really annoying!My advice is not to go, unless you are some sort of masochist who likes being ripped off and abused on an almost constant basis. I find it hard to believe that the same Brits who hate charity street fundraisers, apparently find this place 'magical'. It's a horrible place full of horrible people so only go if you want a horrible experience.

Don't miss it!. A fantastic place to get a feel of Moroccan culture and life, and to do a bit of shopping and eating! You can find almost any item you want being sold in some part of the market, although the handicrafts were the highlight for us. There are many stalls selling Moroccan sweets, olives and dried fruit and nuts. Going with a local guide will greatly enhance your experience as you can avoid the tourist traps and also take a tour through the history in the market.
Can't come and not. You've gotta see it to say you've been but 2-3 days is enough with 1 day in the Medina. It's eorth a visit but it can get hot and annoying with the locals.

Funky Old Medina. The Medina is such a strange place, it is like going back in time. Be prepared to share narrow, closed in corridors with mopeds, motorbikes, hundreds of tourists, and people pulling donkeys, pulling carts. Magnificent!

Medina of Marrakesh- the Square. Old city. The square in the old city is like no place I have ever been before. It is exotic filled with snake charmers, monkey handlers, and the list goes on. When taking pictures, watch out, they will aggressively accost you for money. During the day, the square is fairly quiet, at night is another scene filled with thousands of people.

Historic district. I visited the Medina of Marrakech 3 times, it was constructed in 1070 to 1072 there are so many historical sites to visit here , it was also once the imperial capital of morocco, now it is a UNESCO world heritage center.Beautiful place and it is still an important economic center of morocco.

Amazing experience!. Amazing experience!! My boyfriend and I had a fantastic time in Morocco. We would recommend the roof top restaurants for dinner, get there in time to watch the sunset though! Be careful of people showing you places around the medina as everyone just wants your money!! We found a simple no thank you was the best to get people to leave you alone!

Medina. A lovely vibrant colourful, shopping experience.Being in Marrakech. You would expect the products to be from that country. But they are Imported from china omg, they no longer haggle they have fixed prices. Which to me just takes the edge of the whole experience

We stayed in medina. For 5days at the Chacha lala riad, the market is amazing but they are very pushy to get you in their shops and to try and do henna, so long as you are firm and confident at saying no to them they will back off, I had an incident whilst I was out there with a women doing henna I said no to henna and that I had no money and she continued to put the henna on me and when I tried to walk away she was quite aggressive and grabbed my arm in the end I managed to get my partner and he got a local chap to come over and cool the situation but by this point I was very shaken and up set but it was all fine in the end i stayed away from all women selling henna but I had this awful stain on my arm for a week :( their is loads of amazing restaurants to eat and drink, not many places which serve alcohol.

Kai Wiggins. Absolutely amazing for around 10-15 minutes! Then the constant "hello friend" "come into my store" "free to look" with you repeating "no merci" more times than a Frenchman does in his life becomes very wearing! It is a constant hassle and you will almost guaranteed get lost! I did find it very interesting to see everything and it is much more vibrant in the square at night!Somewhere worth visiting definitely but if you have time go to Fes as it is more relaxed and you are not run over by crazy locals driving bikes down tiny alleyways the whole time!Still somewhere I would suggest visiting but be careful as it is not for the faint hearted! Also some meat related stalls that you may want to avoid looking at!

What can you say.......fasinating on so many levels.. The Medina is a kaleidoscope of noise, color, smell and a general attack on your senses that is hard to describe. All the stall holders, traders, street hawkers and merchants KNOW who the tourists are, and they do pester and try and sell everything to you. They have picked up some key English phases to assist in there endeavors, but don't be fouled. All the prices are inflated and you need to haggle. Always start with half there asking price, and be prepared to walk away. If pestered too much a firm and strong NO works well. Be careful of the old women in the main square who stop you and ask for your help in identifying a strange bank note whilst her assistant applies henna to your hand, even when you tell them to stop, they keep applying. When you argue they make a big noise, forcing you to give them some money to shut them up. A con is still a con. As with any place crowded and overflowing with people, just exercise some caution and common sense.

taste the real marrakech. Keep your eyes and ears open for an amazing experience and journey back through time. Exciting but not for the faint-hearted or weak-stomached. Female travellers need to dress conservatively to avoid jeers from the locals. Good restaurants.

Impossible to rate.. How can you rate a piece of history like this? Still, it's a place that requires more caution than I would have expected, in spite of lots of warnings in this forum. We have always been happy and comfortable to tour independently. The locals will make this very difficult. Constant harassment and commonly you are misinformed as to where to go to exit. Did not mind the smells, donkeys, garbage or motorbikes but the constant harassment for guiding us was bothersome. Worse were the responses when we would say that we required no assistance. Also had my iPad stolen right from my hand my two guys on a motorbike. You have to decide if you are comfortable telling people you don't want help, don't want to buy etc and for negative reaction. If not, you should probably hire a guide or travel in a group of 4 or more.

Amazing experience. The Medina in Marrakech is amazing, The different smells of spices etc is incredible. The whole area is an experience in itself, There are traders pestering you to buy their wares but you just have to be firm with them and they will go away. You also have to be very careful not to let your children go wandering off

Brilliant !. You really feel like you are travelling when you visit the Medina !Everything from snake charmers to cool food stalls. Music everywhere and guys trying to sell you everything from watches to " antiques"Its a sensory overload for sure but one that is bot to be missed.Go to one of the rooftop cafes as sunset - it is amazing !

Overpowering. Wandering around the Medina is quite an experience and should not be missed. BUT, prepare yourself for the following:- noise and more noise, of all sorts, from everywhere- motorbikes zapping their way through the crowds- insalubrious cafes and restaurants with average food and limited choice- being hassled by locals who appear helpful but have their own agenda to guide you to their shops- being called "raciste" if you decline help politelyIt is a real shame that such a stunning historical site is marred by poor behavior and disrespectful treatment of its visitors.

sensory overload. This area is amazing. What a culture shock! Once you get used to being assertive with vendors you really can immerse yourself in the culture here. Make sure you go into the old souks and not just the main market streets on the way to the main square. Try to get out of using the map as soon as possible as you are fair game for people "helping" you when they see you looking lost. They always want a tip which is ok but they very often dont take you where you want to go. We were two females and I honestly felt safe. Dont let your imagination run away with you. People are just trying to make a living and they are generally nice if you are firm but polite. Ask at your hotel for advice on average prices etc.

An Experience! But not one I'd recommend.. We were staying by the bus station and entered the Medina by the gates down there. The Medina in this area is dirty, smelling of urine and is dangerous to cross the roads with motorbikes flying around. On entering the Medina it doesn't really improve, we saw dead rats, dead cats etc. Motorbikes ruled the narrow streets and you had to be very careful. You are constantly harassed by sellers trying to get you into their shops. We are used to going into shops around Europe and having a look at what is on offer, this is not possible here as you will be harassed by aggressive sellers who become rude when you don't buy from them. So for the few days we spent in around the Medina, we didn't buy anything, which is a pity as we ended up buying our presents elsewhere. On every corner there are people telling you this street is closed, or that the main square is closed etc. They try to get you lost and then reappear to help you. They will look for money. They give you the classic line, do not worry I am not a guide, do not believe them they either want money to show you where to go or they want to bring you to certain shops where they will get commission. They again get rude if you refuse their help. As you get closer to the main square, you get harassed and shouted at more and more by the sellers. It is best to ignore them and pretend that you do not speak their language. The main square is more harassment. Again, everyone is looking for money from you. There are no police around and the whole experience can be unnerving. Its certainly an experience, but not one that I think I'd repeat. One day in Marrakech is plenty, get out of there and see Morocco properly. If going into the Medina, download the map on Google Maps to your phone beforehand, then using the gps on your function (which doesn't cost money), use that to navigate around the Medina. Otherwise you will be easy prey for those looking to exploit you. Do not trust the shopkeepers who also talk about trying to help you and speaking from the heart, these will soon have you in their shops trying to get you to buy stuff and again they get aggressive if you do not buy. Everyone seems to be working together and working as a team to try to exploit you. Be very careful.

Medina Magic. We traveled during Ramadan so we got to see the extremes. Not much during the day, but at night WOW they Medina comes to life with food vendors, snake charmers and stalls.We felt safe as we wound our way through the streets and alleys. Be careful of the ladies who grab your hand tightly and paint henna on your arm before demanding money, but other than that it is a wonderful place to spend time the store owners are not too 'in your face' and leave you alone if you say no, smile and move on.

Indescribable . You can't visit Marrakech without visiting the medina. The place is like nothing I have ever seen before. Busy, bustling and hot, the medina can be a daunting place. Make sure you have your wits about you when visiting here as robberies aren't uncommon. If you're looking for some great, cheap lunch, make sure to try roti d'or.

Explore with caution. It's always nice to experience new culture. Look for the spices and herbs shops, skip the tanneries. Careful with your belongings, it's always good not to tempt others so keep it out of sight. Good luck dodging the carts, donkeys, motorcycles and vendors! When buying, HAGGLE first at least half of the price. Marrakesh is nice to visit but seriously the haggling business everywhere drains your enthusiasm and energy so keep that in mind. If you are a woman try to dress a bit more appropriate to their culture, even if some will say they are okay with shorts or sleeveless shirts if you can avoid do it. I was with my husband and I was wearing pants and short sleeves shirt but I still get catcalled. If you wanna eat like a local, try the open stalls at the edge of the zouk in the Djemaa el-Fnaa.

Great craftspeople, don't go without guide. This wasn't my first time in a medina, but it was my first time in Marrakesh's Medina. It was pretty intense- had we not had a guide with us, we would not have been able to enjoy strolling through the souks unmolested. We went to Dar Mejbar, and spent a couple of hours with Azziz, drinking mint tea and getting a great show of the gorgeous carpets from tribes all over Morocco. We ended up buying quite a few and we are not sorry in the least- no buyers remorse! We also went to a lamp shop (don't remember the name, our guide took us) AND to the fabulous Maison de Caftan- awesome embroidered clothing, déjà llamas, caftans and velvet jackets. All in all, I like the experience of the Medina in Tangier much better, but Tangier doesn't have the craftspeople that Marrakesh has. Take my advice- get a guide! And enjoy haggling- it's expected- and enjoy the people. They are wonderful when they are not trying to get you to buy their wares. Truly warm and lovely people!

A unique and exiting place seeped in mystery. A magical place that is totally unique. Great shopping for leather goods, clothes (some knockoffs), perfumes and other items. Try to avoid Ramadam time in July as it is obviously a religious time and most places and supermarkets may not serve alcohol. Do travel on the pony traps and carts as it is not very expensive and definitely an experience.

Yes I want to go back. If you love experiences different cultures and street food and love watching local talent this is the place for you. Don't be scared hire a private guide to give you tours of the Medina and dive right into the culture. This is absolutely one of my favorite places I have traveled and I have been in 50+ countries. Love it!

The True Marrakech. Yes this is a busy busy place and it's not everyone's cup of tea but you do get a good flavour of what Marrakech and Morrocco are all about. You have to visit at least once in your life.

True Marrakech in every sense. We stayed in a Riad within the Medina and spent a lot of our time there as a result. The great mix of old/new, European/African culture and style makes it fascinating. Don't pay attention to those who say it is too touristic, once you are away from the souk, it is very authentically Moroccan. You will however get treated like an ignorant Western tourist if you act like one, so be prepared to watch out for traffic, joke with locals and barter without shame or prejudice!

Beautiful old city centre. Marrakech is worth visiting, even when you are staying in one of the Agadir beach resorts. A tourist bus with a qualified guide and driver will bring you from early morning till late in the evening for a one day trip to Marrakech. It is really worth the energy and the one day energy needed. The Medina, the old city of Marrakech is beautiful. Avoid going in the bazar or souk on your own. Better is to take a local professional guide, which is provided by the tour operator. You will walk with him in the souk without any problem nor any harassment by the merchandisers. Be aware and keep away of the individuals that come to advertise you about arghan oil. It is all fake. Stay with the guide and he will bring you to a trustworthy company if you want to buy this special oil.

Noisy and touristic. I was disappointed by our trips to the Medina. We were constantly pushed aside by noisy, smelly scooters and the stalls themselves seemed filled with identical wares probably off the boat from China. To avoid.

Fun place to walk around. Just be careful.. This is a fun place to walk around and get lost but be careful. It is very confusing so use google maps. A sim card is very cheap or you can just use offline maps. People will come up to you and want to show you around. Tell them no firmly and keep repeating it. If they follow you anyway and want you to pay, do not do it. If you want to take pictures of the monkeys or snake tamers, expect to pay them. Do not let anyone put a snake around your neck unless you are prepared to pay them to remove it. There are lots of beggars and pick pockets to watch out for as well.Finally, for the vendors, it is there job to get you to pay as much as they can. Some might see this as trying to rip you off, but it is really just a cultural difference. Do your homework though.look up what you should be prepared to pay online. Negotiate everything. Never but something from the first vendor. They will try to act like your friend but negotiate a price , then go to one of the other vendors selling the same thing and use the first price as a point of legitimacy to negotiate a fairer price . The census will legitimately charge you 10 times more than something is worth because westerners are not used to negotiating. Most of what they are selling is not valuable and there are lots of vendors selling the exact same things. Good luck and enjoy it.

An insight view into a "different word". When you get to the medina and start discovering the narrow crooked streets with all the stands and shops offering anything you can imagine, you can easily get lost. But that is the point! It kind of feels like travelling in time. Spend some time just walking around, negotiate with the shop assistants and buy yourself some tasty treat. Be careful though during night it is not a very safe place, especially for women.
medina. Exciting place to visit. Snake charmers fortune tellers. Musicians. Everything. And pick up bargains

Τhousands & one night..( χίλιες&μία νύχτες). Whatever you have in your mind when you think of the East, you will find in Marrakech. The red city, the jewel of the South, as they used to say to Morocco, with its bazaars, outdoor markets full of flavours & smells, gardens, palaces and colors, Arabian horses, walls, palm trees, luxury hotels will spel on you.Central to the city around which everything moves is the amazing Mosque El Fna square (Djemaa El Fna), which will literally take you to another time .For many people is a destination of magic... Pay attention the dates of visiting because its too hot in summer time...!

An experience but not one to repeat i dont think. We had a free shuttle service from our hotel which was great. We went out at 2.30pm and returned on the 4,30pm bus. That was MORE than enough! Firstly we were accosted by multiple "guides" wanting to take us to the stalls of his choosing for a small amount of money per person, they are really insistent but as long as you remain firm and say NO they do eventually leave you alone. Be careful to take note of where you are as the place is like a maze and you can very easily get lost. Watch your wallets, bags etc too as we were followed by a very suspicious looking young man who retreated when i made it obvious i knew he was following me. (I had a bag with suncream and water in but he obviously thought i had money etc). It was unbelievably hot (49 degrees!) so it would have perhaps been wiser to go later in the evening. The stalls are all very welcoming but they dont want you to leave unless you've bought something. Aim to pay around a third to maximum of half of whatever price they first ask for and dont be afraid to walk away, they come after you and sell for the lower price 99% of the time. They seem to think its acceptable to grab you to put items and even animals on you for photographs so they can ask to be paid afterwards and some get rather insulted when you say NO but dont let that put you off. The horse and carts are all lined up along the side of the road but the horses are without water in unbearable heat ALL DAY so on principle we would not use them. The horses in some cases even had their front and back legs chained together to restrict their movement, it was horrible to see. There were men with Monkeys chained to them and they would attempt to place these on you for a photograph, again, we refused as we considered this cruel and unnecessary. The Main Square has to be seen to be believed! cars, mopeds, bikes, trucks, horse and carts as well as people everywhere, all going in different directions, all at the same time, you really have to be careful. You cannot go to Marrakech and not go to the Medina but dont wander too far away from the main square, try and stay polite when saying no thank-you and put plenty of suncream on if you go in the daytime. Its absolutely boiling! Much warmer than at the hotel somehow. Having said all the negatives, there are some lovely things to buy as souvenirs or even home decoration and the genuine imitations are a plenty. Just keep your wits about you and be careful not to be killed by a moped.

Very Good However..... I loved the Medina.. there are loads of lovely deals here. I bought hand made pottery, scarfs and a canvas painting!However... do NOT let the ladies with Henna put anything on you without agreeing a price first! One lady was very forceful and grabbed my hand despite me trying to pull away from her.. She proceeded to draw on me and then demanded 800dhs. I told her I was not going to pay her as I did not ask for anything. She became very angry and shouted at me..telling me I should not disrespect her work. I told her I did not have the money to pay her (I didn't). She told me to go to the bank! In the end my friend paid her 100dhs. I've never felt so intimidated while on holiday. The lady seemed very harmless and friendly at first!It put me off of going back there.

Interesting ancient Arab area.. The ancient Arab quarters has many stores along the interesting narrow streets, if you can think of anything they probably sell it, shoes old and new, clothing, pots and pans.

Yet another Medina. Medina, old city, or simply a translation of city. Is a similar experience across many North African Destination.Some bargains to be had and some traditional souvenirs to be bought. Monkeys with their trainers and performers who seek little tips to entertain you

Dreadful cesspit of desperation and degradation. The Medina of Marrakech has a couple of jewels buried deep within it. The problem is twofold: finding them and then making your way over to them unmolested. One of these jewels is the Museum of Marrakech, which contains fascinating exhibits and artwork that has been loaned on occasion to international institutions such as SOAS, and which contains most pleasing architecture and features, with friendly and helpful staff. Here is my story of what happened on the way there. First I was accosted by a young man who appeared insistent on giving me directions despite my protestations I didn't need his help. He then tried to sell me Argan oil (a local snake oil type of cure-all) which I refused. I ignored him, then he tried to close a road to me, saying there was a mosque down that road, that it was time for prayers and that I couldn't head that way because I was a tourist! When I asked him if he was a policeman or guard to close a public right of way, he became furious and violent. A passer-by intervened, and that passer-by then tried to sell me hash. All of this is par for the course in this rotten sewer of a "tourist destination". The people in the Medina are seething with greed, dissatisfaction and suppressed jealousy and rage at tourists, while conveniently ignoring that their king has effectively walled off half of the city for his own private use (he has at least 2 palaces in every city). To the locals of the Medina, every tourist, even a student or a backpacker, is fair game to be defrauded or robbed, a fat-cat millionaire who has no right but to be redirected through the souks whenever he or she is on the way to an actual tourist destination of merit, such as a museum or the Jewish graveyard. I have lived in a third world country before, and I recognise well the symptoms of a place run by a mafia. I also recognise well the symptoms of stress, anxiety and bemusement on the faces of tourists. Make the best of it, but you will be accosted and harassed here. If you go to a 'nice' part, for example the kasbah, you will be aggressively redirected to the souks, usually on false pretences, by some random person. This is the work of mafia gangs.Regarding shopping, you should avoid any kind of tourist tat. All the gemstones are plain, worthless quartzes dyed with some chemicals then baked in the oven. That's why their colour is so glaring, and why it doesn't penetrate through the entire geode, and why the exterior of the geode is as black as coal. When you've been through the Medina a few times, you will see that there are one or two shops selling things at fixed prices. Look at these carefully and make a mental note of a guide price before going out to haggle for anything anywhere. For example, one shop sold all leather jackets for a flat rate of 600 dirhams. Anything someone wants to sell or offer to you will be some kind of fraud, so don't go in there trying to buy anything you haven't already researched thoroughly on the internet. Leather goods in the Medina are actually inferior and more expensive, and the sellers far more aggressive and dishonest, than in the markets in Gueliz. Likewise for anything you see in the Medina you might want to buy. Just don't. Go to Gueliz.Unfortunately the Medina looks amazing in photos but is nothing but stress and aggravation when experienced in real life. There is much talk of an invisible tourist police taking control, but absolutely no evidence of this unprovable and unlikely state of affairs. If there was an undercover police force, the locals would know their faces from the first moment they made an arrest. There are no nice people here except maybe the occasional Tuareg. You've been warned. The unpleasantness of the Medina is compounded by the presence of animal cruelty (not just monkey and snake displays but also the slaughter of livestock and chickens), flies, cockroaches and bugs buzzing over foodstuffs such as sweets, and the occasional local relieving himself in full daylight in the corner. It's a pretty foul place. I can imagine it would have been a fantastic place to visit in the 1960s and 1970s, but the world has moved on and now it's just a cesspit of desperation and degradation.

People and more people. Medina is really nice, but full of tourists, and Moroccans trying to sell you something, or even kids trying to take you to some place. But you can find quiet place if you get out from the main streets. The main square is amazing specially during the night.

Don't be afraid and take in the eclectic feel of the deeper parts of the market. Luckily I had a local friend who showed me around but I was surprised at what I found when we walked deeper in the markets. I was a little scared when I first went there on my own but really I have had no bad experience with anyone, people are so nice if you treat them with respect, and haggling is part of the fun, not necessarily about the money alone. I highly enjoyed it.

Don't touch black henna. The marina is crazy be prepared bKids are grabbing money from your hands and don't give you a minute. These kids have money but want more. The guy with monkey will grab you take pictures then ask you for 200 dhams. Please be careful with henna. It is beautiful but it's got black hair dye in it which will soon break you out into a horrible itchy mess. Mine was done 3 weeks ago and I have scarring still so does my daughter. I wish someone had put on here before I went. There are genuine very poor people here so I gave a lot to them. Taxi drivers are crooks lol. Always get price before and tell them you don't want a tour etc as they will try take you different places then charge double. In all its a very poor country and not much to see so make sure you have good hotel with everything you need. Also cover up at the madina souk etc or you will get constant hassle from men

You have to visit once!. It's like marmite you'll either hate it or love it! We travelled as a couple and to be fair we wouldn't normally be drawn to such hustle and bustle but this is a world heritage site with the walls of the medina having been built in 1126-27 we had to visit it. We didn't feel too comfortable here, not a bad thing - it's good to be taken out of your comfort zone occasionally. Visit it and be your own judge.

Beware the motor cycles. Having already visited Fes and the wonderful medina there I was disappointed in the Marrakech equivalent. You have to jump out of the way of motor bikes zooming up and down the laneways- and it is very dirty. Also, we found the stall-holders (and the 'performers' in the square) much more aggressive than their equivalents in Fes- and prepared to cheat customers over change etc. Didn't enjoy this one nearly as much as Fes.

Marrakech Medina :). Visited Marrakech for the first time last week. I was a little put off by the stories of the Medina, but it really wasn’t that bad. If you don’t want to buy something just say no and walk off. Be stern and not a push over. The constant ‘look at this, look at that, good price’ does get a little tiring but that is the culture! My advise would be women please be respectful and cover up – shoulders especially. Really enjoyed my experience. Allow yourself to get lost, but not too lost!

Awful place. Spent 3 nights in Marrakech Medina last week and hated the place. Absolutely every single trader bar none sees western people as walking money trees. I found the place interesting and enjoyed seeing the souks but the relentless harassment just ruined my time there. It was a relief to retreat back to the secluded roof terrace of our riad and get out of it all. If you are a person that enjoys their own personal space and the chance to visit places at your own mellow pace, don't bother going to Marrakech.
Guide.. Don't bother with a guide, he will bore you to death, an visit all his mates, better on your own, felt quite safe.

A must do, another world. Such a different world with small alleyways, workers making leather and metal goods, shops, museums, galleries, stalls, fruit markets etc etc I actually stayed in the Medina of Marrakech at a riad called Dar Nour El Houda, a lovely place. Ate at some lovely restaurants there such as Dar Tazi. All so very well priced for a bargain break.It is a must to spend a few days living in the Medina if you come to Marrakech.

Not worth a visit. On our trip in Marrakech Medina was on our list to do. as soon as we come out from the hotel we were approached by ,,tour guide,, who offered us to take around Medina, which we thought would be good idea as it was our first day in Marakech. He toke us only to the stands which were paying him commissions and literally pushed us inside the stores to buy something so he can get some money. Sales people were nice once we walked in to the shops but they changed to very arrogant and aggressive when they noticed we wont buy anything . Then we just decided to leave as it was becoming scary.

Keep your wits about you! . The Medina is a huge assault on the senses! At night particularly there is so much going on everywhere and a whole array of sights to take in. But you need to be very careful and keep your wits about you as money really talks and just taking a picture could cost you! There are snake charmers around that will charge you if you stop to watch or take a picture. There are people with monkeys who try to put the monkey on you for pictures. It's impossible to agree a price first because the monkey is on your shoulder straight away and as soon as it is off the request for money starts! Try to have change or small notes in your pocket as it is difficult to get money out unexpectedly with the men looking into your bag demanding big sums. Give them the small amount in your pocket and tell them it's all you have and walk away. Or keep your distance in the first place! The henna women are also very forceful. I had one grab my hand and start putting henna on me despite my protestations. Be firm, keep walking, avoid eye contact as once they have you their grip is very strong. My friend had to pretty much karate chop the lady off me!! If you want their service, always agree a price first!!! If you eat in a restaurant you will find most are very well priced and you can have a lovely meal for about 50 Dirhams. I would advise you to sit upstairs as not only do you get a fantastic view but if you sit downstairs you are constantly hassled by locals trying to sell you everything from watches and phones to children selling packets of tissues. People also come around playing instruments and doing acrobatics before asking for money. Avoid eye contact. I saw one old man with an instrument spit at an eating couple because they did not give him money!!! Also avoid giving change to the children, encouraging them to approach strangers can only end badly. Be prepared for the many beggars, it's heartbreaking. If you like to haggle the souks are great, like Aladdin's cave. But the first price they give you will be unreasonably high!!! Aim to pay a third of that at an absolute maximum. You can normally haggle a lot lower by walking away. If they let you go you know you have reached the limit of what they will accept! It is better to go when there are more tourists around so the sellers' attention is divided. We went when it was quiet during Ramadan so we received a lot of unwanted attention, especially being two women. Everybody wants Money for something and some of the men are very full on!! Don't be ripped off by taxis either. They should never cost more than 10-20 dirhams for short distance rides during the day. You have to be savvy in the Medina but once you've got the hang of it there truly is a lot to see and it has a strange charm about it that can't be easily described.

Vibrant & Active - lovely to watch from terraces. A very different cultural experience which I enjoyed immensely! The medina is a very busy & noisy place but also very vibrant and colourful. Need to watch out for scooters and taxis which seem to drive in any direction. A great idea is to see the Medina from one of the restaurant/cafe roof terraces. Great view of the Medina & also excellent for taking photos.

Like no other. It felt like I was in Aladdin. The streets are winding and sometimes narrow. There are many sights and smells. Everything is new. I would recommend finding a great tour. I'm afraid the one I went on was complete rubbish. That did not detract from a truly amazing space.

Really authentic - could wander for hours!. This is a hard one to rate as I can understand all the negative points people make - but personally I loved it and think it is one of those things you can only decide for yourself... I would definitely say go as its free to look and if you don't like it, leave or seek refuge in one of the many fantastic restaurants/bars/cafes that are in and surrounding the medina.
Scary but worth a visit. It was a little scary at times you have to visit but will not visit again on future visits to MARRAKECH

Beware when shopping here. Be very careful when purchasing items from the stalls in the market - especially stalls that sell herbs / saffron/ musk / argan oil etc.We visited one of these with a Dutch lady that lives in Marrakech and the owner of the stall explained that they have 2 different types of product - one they sell to the locals and the other to tourists. For example the tourist saffron is made out of the dry stringy bits from the corn cob and dyed red - and they sell it for double the price of the real saffron that they sell to the locals. so you can imagine that all the other 'tourist products' they sell are fakes as well. Buy your Argan oil from a supermarket (like Carrefour) instead - it is cheaper and 100% argan.

Enchanting but chaotic! . Some people are friendly, the colours and architecture is amazing! Avoid the henna women as they are aggressive, my skin is very sensitive so I did not want henna but she grabbed me and tried to put it on my hand, I pushed her away but she grabbed me from behind luckily my boyfriend was there and shouted at her to leave me alone! It is quite a scary place but definitely a must see! Some locals are friendly but others heckle you.Like every place it has bad points and good however it did not live up to its expectations.I wouldn't go back for a week but definitely a long weekend.Be prepared to haggle and have fun with the sellers they are trying to make a living but are friendly when it comes to haggling a price.Do not follow anyone for directions they will either try and charge you and you always end up in a different place to where you want to be!You can't trust many people they are always trying to get money or just screw you over in general.One occasion a man demanded us for money after we said we wouldn't pay him for taking us somewhere. We were in the wrong place and he wanted 500 dirhams we argued and argued and he become verbally and physically aggressive towards me trying to grab me if my boyfriend hadn't been there Im not sure what I would have done!It is a scary place for a female traveller and wouldn't recommend going on your own if you are female. The streets are scary at night but the comfort of a riad is always welcoming!

Like stepping into another world. A stunning place to wander but keep your wits about you, your money hidden and your camera in your bag - also speak French if you can rather than English. Always ask before taking someones photo and haggle for everything! Buy spices, leatherware and take in the amazing smells and sights

Best one we visited. We stayed in the Medina in Marrakech, Casablanca, Rabat, and Fez and this was by far the best of the four. It has a great selection of products, it is the easiest to get around (assuming you are good with directions). Don't be afraid to get lost... it is one of the best way to find interesting shops and areas. Find some land marks and remember what is around them and if you are lost and stumble across a landmark you can reorient yourself. We did a cooking class at Souk Cuisine on the first day which meant we walked around the Medina with someone that knew what they were doing and we never got lost after that. Not having to worry about where you are allows you to better enjoy where you are now.Lots of good little restaurants and TONS of shops. The only Medina that came close was in Fez.
EXOTIC. every step ask for money. Visit markets in night and drink oragne juice, it good. souvenirs in the city cheaper.

Hazardous Bikes. The medina itself has the charm but it is completely destroyed by all the motorised vehicles who are constantly on the move and one can forget a nice calm walk in there as you are constantly on the watch trying to avoid this for your personal safety. You can hardly walk without someone or the other trying to sell you something,offering to be your guide and the worst was a Henna woman who grabbed my wifes hand and started drooling all over her hand and would not let go and then demanded payment. The shops are all the same with a few exceptions.The food square was fine even though there is almost the same food and drinks all over. A nice experience though marred by all the unfortunate tourist snares.
Brilliant atmosphere. This is a beautiful place in the city. The people are very friendly. There is lots to see, all of which is very interesting.
Medina souks are fun. I stayed in the Medina and spent quite a bit of time in the souks there. It's like a maze but plenty to see and shop. Close to the square and Koutoubia Mosque.

In chanting. We couldn't get enough of this place so interesting and colourful so much to see and learn not to mention shopping.
Great to go for 4 or 5 days
Enthralling. Truly an enthralling and exciting place. Would return in a heartbeat! Some of the usual tourist traps that are anywhere in the world but overall a very safe feeling.
old traditon marrakech.. charming again it is my fave place Marrakech are amazing and old tradition aparts from the roads are dangerous, watch out. it was date from 2007 of the year.

Top attraction. One of Marrakech's top attractions and rightly so. You can spent hours just walking the Medina and watching people. People are friendly, respectful and smiling. This made shoping a lot easier and more pleasant than expected. Dressing appropiately would be recommended as a sign of respect, though. To us it seemed like some locals did indeed disapprove of people in hotpants and tank-tops, which is not surprising in a country like Morocco. Normal skirts, dresses or shirts seemed to be absolutely fine.

shopping at its best!. yes its hotyes they are pushyyes you will get heckled if you are female and alonethose are the bad pointsbut.... you must remember where you are, where you have travelled to and im sure you would have read some reviews before you left ,so you should know what youre letting yourself in for.on the plus side however...bargains at every turndelightful tucked away shopscolouful stallsfriendly people...if you give them a chance and are not rude to them...they are just trying to make a living after allabove allBRILLIANT FUN!!!!Go, enjoy yourself and put everything down to experience, but above all, remember its THEIR home, be respectful.

Safe, friendly and welcoming place.. The beautiful Medina is a feast for the senses. The people we encountered were friendly and welcoming, generally not just because they wanted you to buy the products in the souk, but also because they want you to enjoy your visit to the souks and Marrakech. We enjoyed our time visiting the old souks walking the historic alleys and eating in the market. We felt safe and quickly noted as long as you acknowledged the souk owners they were absolutely fine, an ignorant dismissal of them is nothing but rude and I saw plenty of people being like this. Marrakech is friendly and welcoming to everyone and this is how they the locals want you to feel. It's a must do visit, don't hesitate!

Why you come to Marrakech. This is the whole reason to come to Marrakech. I would highly advise you stay in a raid in the medina itself instead of just visiting it. You will feel perfectly safe walking during the day or night and you will really understand and enjoy Morocco more. The souks (which are only a small part of the medina) are much less aggressive and more spacious then in Fes. It's a more relaxing way to shop.The other non shopping activites, such as the visiting the historic buildings, restaurants, and mosques are wonderful. The locals are very welcoming - you can play video games or go to the public hamam with them. Some don't like their picture taken, so just ask first. Not sure how you could got to Marrakech and skip this.

Good experience but very annoying. We spent 4 days in the medina as our raid was here. It was a great experience to see it but it gets very frustrating being asked for money on everything that you do. You can't look, take pictures, ask for help or even go to the toilet without losing some cash. It's a little scary at night too if you don't know your way. I felt my enjoyment was cancelled out with the constant thought of getting harassed or pickpocketed.
Historical and full of life. Definitely worth a wander around seeing how the locals trade and lead their life's. You will definitely get lost but that's half the fun!

So scary- a horrible place. I went to the Medina with a fellow female friend one evening. The first thing I noticed was the overwhelming stench of urine everywhere. Beggars, dirt everywhere, men making sex noises in our faces, women touching us, men shouting at my friend that she had a fat behind. We saw 2 black girls frightened- men were spitting at their feet and telling them they are disgusting. Hundreds of men shouting at us to come into their shops- so scary. We went into one shop that looked safe enough with a quiet old man inside but after we both made purchases he grabbed our arms and tried to kiss us. I had to struggle free and just run. A lady offered me henna on my hand and I politely declined( in future don't answer, just ignore and walk on) and she grabbed my hand and started painting it on my hand anyway saying "just a little flower no money" then she asked my name and I kept saying no I didn't want the hen but she covered my hand. She then asked for money and I said no I didn't want it but she wouldn't let go. I managed to get away and another woman chased me screaming for money. I told her no and that I did not want it and she shouted "take it off" and grabbed my hand and scraped it off with sharp plastic. My hand was red raw with henna smudged all over it. The people here are desperate and it is scary. There is no mystical charm- it is terrifying, mysogynistic and seedy. Avoid at all costs. If you do go do not let the monkeys on chains near you- the trainers put them on your shoulder and take photos then demand a lot of money. The monkeys are also trained to dip into your bags and take your purse. The men everywhere are so vile-'taxi drivers, airport staff, everyone. Western women are dirt on their shoe.

Wonderful market stalls. The Medina of Marrakech, being one of the oldest parts of the city, is one of the atmospheric parts of bustling Marrakech. The wonderful market stalls sell so many things, but be prepared to haggle if you want the best deals.

very busy and full of life... I love this place especially at night. the city comes alive, lots sof things to do and food to try.beware of the street vendors. they can be very rutless i tried to take a picture of the snake charmer from far with the intention of tiping. he got so upset i took pictures of him and almost chased me down for a tip. which i refused to.

Uncomfortable Marrakech. As someone who has traveled extensively throughout the world, including many areas of the Middle East and Africa, I was surprised at the attitudes I encountered in Marrakech. It was quite obvious from the onset of our visit, that we were welcome in Marrakech only as long as we spent money. Otherwise, they simply did not want us there, and frankly, we soon did not want to be there either.
Amazing colors and smells. The sights, the foods, the smells, all are overwhelming and delicious. Make sure you allow enough time to roam, get lost, and resurface in a new area.

I love Marrakech. Somewhere which should be on everyone's list . An incredible place. My daughter and I stayed in a RIAD and it was just fabulous.. Went for trip to the mountains . Certainly to be recommended. Great food and service everywhere we went.
Great place to visit. So full of culture. Great trip, definitely need a guide though. Can get very crowded so the earlier the better, I would definitely visit again.

A little taste of everything. At first my husband and I were intimidated by the medina. It is such a large area with such a large number of people. However, once we decided to brave it, we were so glad we did. The medina holds everything from souvenirs to food vendors to street acts. Although it is wise to be aware of your surroundings we did not feel unsafe. The people were friendly and we ended up coming home with a few treasures. My advice to fellow travelers would be: be polite, stand your ground, and haggle to the best of your ability!

Best place to get lost!. Fantastic fun getting lost in the Medina in Marrakesh. We discovered some great sights and sounds by wandering off the beaten track. Approaching the Medina from the back, by the city walls we found Chickens grazing in the street outside the butcher's door ! Artisans sitting in doorways making jewellery, too much to mention. Felt safe to explore.

a market place as old as time.
