It is really busy, hot , dusty, crowded, smelly, noisy and there is an assault on every sense...get past this and you will enjoy and see and participate in an aspect of what makes this place a UNESCO world heritage site.Be careful to haggle but be balanced. the pretty crystal geodes that are pink and blue are all dyed...ask for a bucket of water if they say they aren't! I always take money for beggars..not too many but giving alms in one of the Pillars of Islam so you will be blessed...as tourists we have sooooo much more than these poor wretches on the street in a country with no national health scheme.I found people so helpful..learn the Arabic for No, thank you...Lah! Shukran..it is usually enough to be graciously excused from a purchase. If you look interested in an item it is inferred that you do want to buy. Use the masses of advice that is on the internet for behaviour that is appropriate.

Not for the faint-hearted or naive, but fun all the same.. Be. Prepared. To haggle. Absolute mayhem. I would advise not buying anything if you haven't seen it somewhere else first just to get an idea of price. Usually you can halve the initial price they give you, so be persistent! Also unless you want to be pestered constantly move with a bit of pace and don't look or smile at anyone. Obviously you'll still be pestered a bit but I found that helped. Avoid pharmacies, we were unwitting and got ripped off on massive proportions. Look out for the colour of argan oil, it should be fairly dark and not really more than 30DHs. Definitely worth the visit though, has to be seen.

Great to see but didn't want to stay long. It was nice to visit the medina but I was happy to leave to stay in our hotel just out of the old town! The people are very persistent and won't leave you alone! Being a blonde white female I felt very targeted for everything, the women doing henna were so aggressive she told me it was free and then tried to charge 1500 dirhams (it was terrible too) when I refused she grabbed my hand and smudged it before I could get away I was circled by women shouting at me! I got away but was very shaken as it was my first night and was a horrible experience! My advice for anyone especially women is to say no and be very stern about it, I hear there is a henna cafe and I wish I had gone there instead and actually had a pleasant experience and something to show for it! I also got a photo with a snake, he tried to charge 600 dirhams and his friend also ran over with his had trying to get money but luckily we got away with only 100 dirhams! The grande balcone cafe was great and gives you a great view of the square and the koutoubia mosque, they are sneaky too tho they said we could buy ice cream from them down stairs and take it up but when we got the the top made us buy a drink before we could get onto the balcony for 25 dirhams each, when we went to walk away they then let us go through without paying! I was called all sorts of names in the square... Lady gaga, skinny, and all sorts! Funny but quite uncomfortable! Men run after you with monkeys demanding you get a photo only so they can charge you and become extremely aggressive! AVOID HENNA SNAKE AND MONKEY PEOPLE!!! There are about 50 of the same orange juice stalls selling the same thing for the same price my advice is to go to the first one and buy it if you're going to as they are exactly the same only they won't pester you if they see you already have one! I felt after getting a henna as soon as I showed them and said no they left me alone! It's great to experience don't get me wrong but you need to make sure you are strong and say no, I didn't and I almost didn't go back to the medina after the first day! The street food is all the same and all swarmed in flies they do what ever it takes to get you in their stall to eat but we avoided it! They recognised us and every night pestered us and it becomes so annoying (117 takes you to heaven, 118 118) things like thatDefinitely experience the medina but try and be stern about it, many kids came up trying to sell tissues and begging for a sip of my drink I felt incredibly harsh but I always said no, there was one boy that asked for my drink and it was almost finished so i just gave him it but there's girls were standing as I was paying for the orange asking for it!

Hi-jacked by a bogs security guard. My friend and I caught a hotel shuttle bus to the Medina but it did not drop us off outside and we had to find our own way there. A local man, dressed in European dress, approached us and said he would show us the way. He claimed to be one of the security guards at our hotel. He said there was a special rug auction and he would take us to that on the way.Once in there we felt like flies trapped in a spider's web and ended up buying rugs when we had no intention to do so. It was a very hard sell and I did manage to negotiate mine down from £900 to £120 and I like it - so no regrets. My friend was not so fortunate - she ended up paying £300 for her rug (it was a little bigger than mine) but they diddled her on the exchange rate and on the final bill. We emailed them to ask for it to be sorted but no response. So PLEASE AVOID going to PALAIS VIZIR. One of their staff then took us to a shop which was selling overpriced oils and spices - they were 75% more expensive than in the Medina. So AVOID being lured in to expensive shops by local men in European dress who pretend they are from your hotel - this man was not. On my return home I found that my neighbours experienced a virtually identical scenario and we think it was the same man!!On the positive side the Medina itself was very interesting - clean, good value and no hard sell.So to the traders at Palais Vizir and the man that lured us in there if you happen to read this review - you have given your country a bad reputation and you spoilt our holiday by ripping my friend off - shame on you.
Chaos :). If you like it busy, bustling ever so slightly insane this is the place for you. Its non stop, to tip say no with a smile
A must see. Please visit the medina - it's a fascinating place which will stimulate all your senses. It's rich and vibrant.
beautiful. nice intricate art work.typical Moroccan beauty. Needs a guide to fully understand the different sides.

A labyrinth of markets and sights. Really enjoyed going for long walks in the medina. Not for the faint hearted but for the adventurers out there. Really cool things to buy too. Loved it. Has to be done at least once.

An excellent experience. We visited the medina in the morning and spent a couple of hours visiting different shops. There is a spice shop where they give talks on the different spices and medicinal herbs. Well worth a visit. Don't be in a hurry to buy as there are dozens of shops selling the same goods. Prices are good but the quality can be variable.We came back in the evening to visit the square. The place comes to life then with snake charmers, dancers etc. This is the best time to visit if you only have a short time to visit

An interesting experience - upsides and downsides. A really interesting place and really worth a visit. The locals do see you as gullible and rich so whatever price they offer you for something it is normally worth about 1/4 of that. I struggled with the treatment of animals though so do be warned! Be careful of anyone putting anything on you - hats, monkeys etc they will expect money for a photo. It is worth staying for the evening and seeing the change in the market to a food market. As a female I would be careful about going along without any men with you. This is even more important during the night time and I would suggest not going to stand in within the crowds watching the music / dancing etc as the men we were with had their pockets gone through and the young women were all groped - not a pleasant experience.
Superb gifts good prices.. Of course you have to go, you have to buy souvenirs and you have to see the beautiful entrance. Worth the visit.

Mesmerizing sensory overload...but watch those motorbikes!. It is a visual feast to stroll through the Marrakesh medina, much more colorful than refined Fes. Rugs, slippers, headscarves, even sweets are displayed in shop fronts right on the street in myriad colors. Enjoy wandering and looking. To see some local textile action, go to the rug auction at about 5 PM daily except Friday [after prayers] in the rug market next to Rabha Kedima, an open place full of women making baskets and crocheted hats. You can't bid on the rugs yourself, but a dealer can and will get a 10% markup, much less than you would usually pay. My favorite to deal with is Mehdi at shop #48, just inside the entrance to the rug souk and on the left. Though you may not see anything you like at the auction, he can find you any style or size you ask for, borrowing from other shops besides his tiny one if need be. There are also a couple of cafes [with bathrooms] on this square, and a cash machine. But as I said in the title, watch out for those motorbikes while strolling the medina streets. I'm torn between wishing they would be banned and understanding that people living in the medina need them to get to work. Anyone with a creative solution, write to the Tourism Office in Marrakesh!

A singular experience. . Having read some of the reviews it can be a bit daunting, however we found it wonderful. Being able to say hello, please, yes, no, and thank you in Arabic will certainly make your visit here more friendly. Being firm without rudeness to sellers will help you deal with them. We wandered far and wide amongst the back alleys and never once felt uncomfortable.

Stinking hole. Do not visit this place, locals are a nightmare ! Rude , aggressive , greedy , dead flesh including goats heads hanging at every corner , nauseating smells , food that will make you ill , cruelty to their animals . All of the locals look at you like a cash cow !!! STAY AWAY!!

An experience.... The Medina is one of those places you have to visit to see for yourself exactly how busy/crazy but beautiful it actually is!My friend and I visited the Medina as part of a tour we had booked, without the tour I think we would have gotten lost right away through all of the narrow streets and the herds of people! We stopped off in a café that had an upstairs seating area with a pretty amazing view of the main square (I cannot remember the name of this café/bar but if you manage to come across it, go upstairs and see the view!!) In the main square there are snake charmers and people with monkeys, these people can be very 'pushy' so PLEASE agree on an amount in which you will pay them for a picture with the snakes or monkey. I made the mistake of letting the snake charmer guy free with my camera and he ended up charging me 200 Dirhams, but in all fairness, he took some great photos of the snakes up close! To hold the monkey and to have my picture taken, I gave the guy 50 Dirhams and walked away (I would have given him less but I didn't have any change or anything smaller than a 50) he seemed happy enough.Walking through all the indoor markets can be a little frustrating as you will need to watch where you're stepping due to the paths being a little uneven and then you have shop keepers trying to get you into the shops and stop you but if you say no, they usually just accept that.If you're buying anything, make sure you barter as they usually try to sell you things that are twice as much as they are worth, if you barter right - you can get some pretty good deals! The Medina is definitely worth a visit!!
Medina. Buzzing! Huge area - the streets around it have plenty to see. easy to get lost in Marrakech........

Its a must. I am surprised that this is not the number one attraction and its certainly not to be missed, the magnitude of the place is frightening and its so easy to get lost in the numerous souks that surround the main square Jemma el Fna. You will get lost , but keep walking and sooner or later you will find yourself back in the square, and if all else fails , ask a shopkeeper in my experience they are all very helpful despite trying to sell you their wares at the same time. Do go during the day and in the evening as the contrast is amazing, during the day you can get a much clearer idea of how the medina operates, at night its just bedlam.

Media of Marrakech. if you do go to Marrakech you have to go to the Medina just to see the sheer size of the place,I have never seen anything like it. It's definitely not for the timid natured people of the world. Heres a few tips and things you should know before you step inside them walls which will hopefully help you enjoy your Medina experience and also give you more time to do it at your own pace and ul get to see more: "U Should "1).Know the exchange rate/money value2). Not buy anything at there first price if you divide it by 3 then haggle,3).be on your guard for pick pockets it might not be a fashion statement but bumbags worn to the front safest way.4).stand your ground and if you dnt want to buy what ther truing to sell just raise your voice when you say N0, theyr are plenty of police inside the Medina and It is against the law to hassle you.NOTE: There products are there only means of living so they will try anything they can to sell them as nobody gets any kind ov help from government.A hard working labourer earns 40p an hr, so dnt be put off with beggars either plz5).keep an eye out for the ladys painting Henna on women tourists they just grab ur arm and start painting you which will cost you big money,if you do want it done do it with brown because black Henna is not real and bad for skin.6) pick out some landmarks if u go inside market it's like a maze and the more you get lost the more hassle ul get to buy things.My first time at Medina was a nightmare, I went again few days later an had the best time ever as i showed i was no push over we were actually having fun haggling with eachother. I hope tips above help you and you's have as good a time I had on 2nd visit.Ther are many places to eat all over the Medina with something for everyone food wise many Thanx Pat.Greene

crazy but great. you enter through the medina walls to be taken back in timethere are souks and more souks narrow alleys and you are almost sure to get lost but there are plenty of takers that will help you for 10 dinars about a euro eventually you will come to the main square which is the place to be as darkness falls the noise and the hubbub have to be experienced snake charmers, boxing matches, dancers, and above all many food stalls abound eat here for a fiver and be amazed don't miss it!!!
Get Lost in the Medina. The medina is one of those places where you have to get lost in.Just wonder the streets and you will learn so much about this rustic city.

Nothing special and no variety. Fes is better!. All the stalls sell more or less the same low quality and fake things... You have illusion of choice but it is not real... The streets are hectic and dangerous with constant motorbikes and scooters passing by... The constant irritation of guys coming and asking where you are going and that you need a guide is quite frustrating... Our worst experience was in the north part of medina where teen aged guys that were high on drugs would tell us f*** off because we refused to tell them our riad name and did not agree to have them as our guides... Seriously the charm of ancient market place, history and authenticity is long long gone. Everyone tries to cheat and con you.. Would have been nice place 20-30 years ago before mass tourism... If you want a little more authentic experience go to Fes medina... Plus people in there leave you alone after first no and are generally more nicer and helpful... Also we stopped in total over 15 taxies at different times and locations in Marrakech, not even one agreed to drive with the meter... In Fes this was never a problem!

THE IRRESISTIBLE CHARM OF A MANIC SHOPPING MALL. I've lost count of the number of times I have entered the treasure trove but I still love it. The selection of items on sale is just mind blowing and I have to fight the desire to buy everything! There are the tourist trodden routes through this labyrinth of narrow passageways but away from these you can find amazing craftsmanship and wonderful items that you never realised you couldn't live without. Yes, you do get called to see what each store owner has to offer but it's not intrusive. The bonus is getting down to some serious haggling. Don't be shy, these people thrive on it. Beware of donkey carts, motorbikes and wheelbarrows using these narrow cobbled roads too. One word of advice - remember you will have to get whatever you buy back home with you.

Getting lost with a map. Even if you have a map of the Medina, it won't help much, especially at night, where you just cannot see the next turn due to too much stuff for sale hanging from the ceilings and piling up in the streets. And that's the beauty about the Medina. Go there without a map and just walk around until you have no idea where you are.

Magic of the Medina. Amazing array of everything you could ever think of and wonderful aroma of herbs and spices. Very hot inside so would advise a night visit. Be prepared to haggle .. the locals expect it

Return over and over - every day and every night is new experience. Marrakech Medina spins with colour and vibrancy - enjoy it if you get lost in its winding interior quarters. Best not let a guide strut you into the boutiques of all his friends for a kick back. Not dangerous, not threatening unless you take photos without permission and run into some grouch. They don't seem to want the free publicity your pictures can give them. Some traders even get abusive very quickly as if you would know beforehand how touchy they are!

Marrakech is the Medina. The historic town or Medina is the reason to visit Marrakech. Containing the Jemaa el Fna, the Souk and palaces you'll likely stay here in a Riad and spend most of your time here shopping, eating, wandering,

Hustle and Bustle. A mad place but a must see in the evening. Everyone is out to make a living, so be prepared for hassle. Not happy to see monkeys on leads for photo opportunities and certainly would not be giving them any money or the snake charmers for that matter. Having dealt with the madness of Indian markets, I found this a walk in the park but hassle all the same. Most of the restaurants do not sell alcohol, but you can not walk 50 yards without being offered hash/cannabis.

berber market. the so called official guide wanted no money so we listened to his spiel as he led us into this addmittedlly much cleaner labyrinth. Inevitably we were introduced to a business man selling carpets for astronomical prices and imagined them mistaking me for cruise or de caprio. as my paltry 700 wasnt good enough from a tourist on a budget. they actually got me to walk back to my riad to pay their dogsbody a 50 dirham tip. how do they sleep at nighy with that constant badgering heckle.
Chaotic charm of the Marrakech old town. Loud sounds, a myriad assault on your senses, windy impossible streets where you get lost, the Medina of Marrakech is charming.

Beautiful.... I visited the Medina in May of 2014 and it's beautiful...it's what you'd expect to see when you visit Marrakesh. If you've been to any of the open markets around the world then you know what to expect. Lots of good food being sold and other small souvenirs. I was traveling on my own so I walked around solo the first time but after getting to know some of the other people staying at the hostel a group of 12 of us it drew the attention of the food vendors. Overall it was an enjoyable visit. My only gripe would be I could do without some of the trash talk from some of the guys working at the stores to get your attention.

ALWAYS ALWAYS COMPARE PRICES!. I covered up my shoulders on the first day and decided not to on the following days because of the heat, I received no abuse, just some men complimenting me, nothing majorly uncomfortable, the locals in the medina are so so nice BUT there are several things tourists have to be aware of while shopping in the medina. Try using a side bag with a zip and wear it in front of you, best way to stay safe and not having anything stolen. Argon Oil - We got told a trick (on our last day which was annoying) and if you shake the argon oil bottle you can tell if its mixed or not if it bubbles up quite a bit it means that its mixed, if not then it should be fine.Henna Ladies - OUR BIGGEST PROBLEM! If you don't want henna, don't feel rude but just don't stop, when they're talking to you, they will grab your hand, start drawing the henna and force you to pay. Its very cheap but thats not the point if you're not wanting henna in the first place and watch your children around them because they may force them. All other products - Try not to buy from the first shop you're looking in, ask for their price, and look around at least 2 other shops, I got ripped off big time! Don't be pressured when they "last price now now now" You will find the same product in another little hut. Try not to pick anything up that you don't want because again - they will pressure you. Amazing part of the city, very fun :)

An assault on the senses and emotions.. Overall we had a great time in Marrakesh. we enjoyed the souks, the food, architecture and many of the people. The Medina is something else though. The relentless waves of sights, sounds, smells and people can be intoxicating or overwhelming. There is clearly a large proportion of the population who are desperately poor. We saw heart rending scenes of women begging on the street draped in exhausted tiny children; animals on the brink of starvation riddled with disease. Horrific glimpses into butchers shops and the smell of decay everywhere. Add to that some of the locals who seem determined to rinse every tourist and it can get a bit much. We were enticed down side streets by apparently friendly locals offering guidance through the labyrinth of lanes only to find them demanding money with menaces once they got us really lost. We had never been anywhere like it. It is a big culture shock so be prepared and hold onto your wallet. Hard to rate so went middle of the road.

Amazing. Stayed in a Riad whilst in Morocco, so much to see inside and easy to get lost, remember where the exit points are. The best way to experience Marrakech and most of the main sites in this city are located within these walls

Isn't this what you come to Marrakech for?. It is good to have a day or two in Marrakech before you tackle the medina, it is very stressful after a while and becomes a bit repetitive. We visited Essaouira after Marrakech and it was much more chilled out! Don't pick anything up unless your interested in it as you will get pestered. Take it all in your stride and have fun with it, it is after all a totally different culture.
Fun. Interesting culturally and architecturally. Just watch your valuables, and enjoy. I felt more comfortable in a mixed group, not sure how I would feel as a solo female tourist.

Busy, locals are VERY aggressive. The medina was obviously a "must-see," however be warned. The locals are very very aggressive trying to sell you things. They will be in your face and argumentative with you. The biggest annoyance is they will tell you the streets are closed, or that you aren't allowed to go that way, which is entirely dishonest. When you go down a different street, you will find yourself lost, and they will magically appear to get you back to where you want to be for a hefty fee.

Interesting but stressful!. Visited with my family in March. The colors were beautiful and the stalls so interesting especially being from England the difference was clear. It was however very crowded and busy at times and we were consistently offered to be shown round for 'free' by the locals who after would demand money ! One time we were called racists because apparently didn't pay the man enough to be forced round. As a woman (modestly dressed in trousers and long sleeved tops) I still received many remarks such as 'hey sexy' or 'hey beautiful' while at the same time being forced to have henna. Making the experience rather stressful. I wouldn't take young children there unless you can keep a close eye on them and expect to receive comments if you are a woman !

Medina of Marrakech. Compared to other Medinas (old towns) in Morocco it's very big and nice and you find a variety of things to by. From souvenir to spices, carpet, and even currency exchange. Almost the whole market is covered and it protects you from sun while you go long distances. The visit will be pleasant but sometimes the insisting sellers make it a bit difficult to concentrate and enjoy your walk/shopping because as soon as you stop to watch something or you show yourself interested you're trapped and the sellers try to sell you something at any cost.

Overwhelming!. By staying in a riad in the medina you are able to step out of the calm and then into the chaos of the Medina itself!! In one minute you may be in a quiet corner... the next in a throng of people,bikes,oxcarts, and motorcycles..all passing within an inch of you!! Exhilarating!!

Marrakech - great experience. Just back from a few nights in Marrakech (late May 2015) - As a couple staying at Riad Flam in the Medina area. Riad is beautiful, very calming and a peaceful joy to stay in. Very difficult to find until you're used to the wee route out to the roadside. We had read lots on here about Taxi from Airport issues so we booked an online transfer which I paid before we left (by Paypal) cost 9 Euros. Great move as we would NEVER have found the Riad first time. (A member of the Riad staff was waiting at the roadend to lead us! This wasn't part of our transfer - so very good service). I thought that the Taxi back to airport at the end of our trip would be a big Haggle - it wasn't. I asked a Petit Taxi man how much - he said how much you pay - I said 80dh - (just over £5) he said OK - sorted!As you expect here - this place is hussle and bussle and just buzzing with people/mopeds/bikes/cars/donkey carts - thousands of wee souk shops and hidden moments everywhere. You'll get lost but that's the fun of it! We did not get any hassle at all but everyone will be trying to sell you something or get you into their shop/attraction/restaurant it's pretty intense but all part of the great experience.One thing that we couldn't pick up much info on before coming was - alcohol. If you like a beer, wine, spirit then it can be a task. You can not get any alcohol on the main square. You can in restaurants and bars outwith there but its not cheap. I can only go by what we found - but just off the square (down the Rue des Banques - the street down the side of Cafe de France) - is a 3 level bar restaurant called Le Salama where from 16:30 till late they have drinks at 2 for 1 and a bottle of beer is then about £2.Would be nice to see more on here of what other places like that people have found in their expolrations.We had booked a Camel Ride online - great morning out a few miles out of town - 2 hrs on the camels with Mint T and Crepes half way - good fun young guide guys - £24. Loved it.

A Great way to experience Marrakech. We were lucky enough to stay in a riad in the Medina. The Medina is a myriad of small alleyways where the locals live and work. I would definitely recommend staying there despite missing a few luxuries, as there is no better way to immerse yourself in such a different culture.

well worth a visit. Along with the main market square, this is the other must-do. It's mostly or is pedestrian-friendly, with lots of historic sites, little street cafes and is far less daunting and demanding than the Jmaa el fna.So if you want to spend half a day just wandering in a safe, historic but buzzing place, the Medina should suffice.There are several small markets too, all worth a visit. The shops easier to navigate too. In the little bakeries that carry those home made sweetmeats, do look out for the hoardes of wasps that find their way into the display cabinets. Bring a camera, for the doorways and entrances alone are well worth a pic or two.

Lovely old town with hidden delights. We stayed in a riad in the medina which was full of character. Shops sit side by side with wonderful museums hidden behind quite plain doors.
We felt the medina of Fez ( and it's souk) had slightly more character, but Marrakesh is a vibrant and exciting place to visit.

Stayed in riad in medina. Enclosed area in Marrakech (old bit) lots of walking on uneven pavements & roads. Some amazing ornate doorways hidden away in little allyways. Lots of feral cats - all seemed to be fed by locals and some liked being stroked. Easy to get lost and very few people able to give directions in English (French maybe) but loads willing to walk with you to wherever you need to be.

A lovely hang-out. Superb food. Cheap Shopping. The Medina is the heart of Marrakech. It is a beautiful place to hang out, relax - a kind of similar yet very different experience from the beautiful plazas in European cities.At the centre of Medina is the Jemma-el-Fanna or the square, replete with food stalls serving yummy kebabs and seafood fries. The square also houses several shops where you can buy anything from home decor items to prayer mats - all that pretty cheap. Lamb skewers and batter-fried squids top the list of lovely food, spiced up with bread and aubergine paste.Like any traditional Muslim shopping & food district (Jumma Masjid and Chandni Chowk in Delhi), this square also comes to life only from late afternoon - definitely after 5 pm. The food stalls actually buzz with people post 630 or 7...If you don't fancy typical street food, there are a number of nice cafes encircling the Jemma-el-Fanna, with Cafe de France topping the list with lovely continental and authentic Moroccan food. You can simply relax at these cafes and watch the Medina's sea of colour, humanity and activity and have endless cups of Moroccan Mint tea. Emanating from the square, which you can think of as a hub, are several streets which house thousands of small shops straddling together selling anything from ceramic pottery to clothes to spice and olives. The place is a maze and it is easy to get lost in the narrow but very colourful bylanes.In and around the Medina are several historical places too - the Koutobiya Mosque and the Bahia palace being the best of the lot. There is an art gallery and Madrasah too within hopping distance from the Medina.A lovely place to hang out, enjoy, shop and eat - a mix of traditional and modern.

A great change from Fes. In contrast to Fes, the medina of Marrakech has relatively wide streets so it is relaxing to stroll through and look at the many shops. Also in contrast to Fes, there are not many animals nor their droppings, so one can look around rather than at the ground. We enjoyed several strolls through the medina.

A must do.. The sounds, the smells, the bustle of the people, dodging bikes, watching cats. Haggling, haggling, haggling. It's a wonderful market one of the best I've ever visited. The people are all friendly and don't be afraid of saying "no thanks" they accept it and move on. But be ready to haggle - never accept a price!

Don't Make Eye Contact. Very nice, but don't make eye contact or the shop owners will jump on it and insist you buy or come look at their products. I liked the square a little more than the medina as the square had so many food options and different things to look at. The shops sort of blend together after a while.

Endless supply of merchandise. I have been to a few markets but this is classic. Although the merchandise is average the hidden streets and rooftop restaurants are priceless. A guide we didn't book took us to a nice restaurant for lunch and we were able to see the endless market. Lunch was good tagine and couscous. Don't miss the souk it is worth the bartering.

An eye-opening experience.. The diversity of goods and services available within the area were truly staggering. The various crafts practised, silk weaving and dying, metal and leather work etc., were a joy to behold. It was fascinating to see all the food stuffs which were available to buy. As well as a walk around both day and night we took a leisurely horse and carriage ride one evening, which was delghtful. The crowds can be a little intimidating on foot and I was not keen on the snakes etc used by the traders.

The heart of Marrakech. You cannot go to Marrakech and not go to the medina as it's the heart and soul of the city. The medina is the whole area within the walls of the old city. The souks, the old square, the tallest mosque, the snake charmers, most of the riads .... Basically everything you must do/see whilst visiting this vibrant city. The souks are definitely the most interesting part but it's so easy to get lost within the hundreds of inter-twinning lanes. We usually like to explore on our own when in a new city but our Riad organised a guide which was great as he led us on a tour of the medina, inc the souks, and told us the interesting history of the city. I had a few bits and pieces I wanted to buy within the souks, so having a guide who knew what areas of the souks would be best, was a massive help. I would definitely recommend a guide for the medina and souks.

Spectacular Cultural Experience and Amazing Foods. Jamaa Al Fanaa is a must and unlike anything I have ever seen elsewhere. The Madinah was great, the street performers were amazing and the Moroccan people are one of the best and friendliest in the world. The ancient Mosques and Palaces were great to visit. The Atlas Mountains and the outlying villages were great. Use the local buses and small taxis; they are cheaper than the tourist taxis, and just as good. Learn to haggle and you'll be fine.

Beyond the souks. Though it seems that many people venture into the medina in Marrakech for the open market and the souks, we decided to stay at a Riad within the old city walls rather than a modern hotel. It was a luxurious experience at the facility, but once you wander out it is nearly impossible to find your way through the labyrinth unless you have a guide or some effective phone app, neither of which we had. You should also be prepared to be hustled by young men telling you "that street is closed" and willing to show you the way for a price. The disparate nature of the touristic Riads and the abject poverty and crumbling infrastructure around them is difficult to see, but it's well worth it for a more comprehensive understanding of Marrakech - and if you have the time, an excursion I. To the Atlas Mountains is well worth the price.

Complete filthy dump, stinks everywhere. Best avoid the old town, nothing of use, it's absolutely filthy and the smell of sewage is horrific. No sign of any street cleaning probably in years. Just grim. People try to sell you things all the time which is off-putting and extremely rude, you get the feel someone will mug you at any minute. Avoid the food if you don't want to be ill. Taxi drivers are a night,are and harass you constantly.
Not that authentic. Lots of stuff to see, do and buy but it's so touristy that it doesn't seem authentic. I didn't like the caged animals.

obtrusive sellers and youngsters. obtrusive sellers and youngsters infest the atmosphere and you do not trust anybody when you are walking through the souk and medina in marrakech as a woman. Which is a pity because there are so many nice places and hidden gems. So STOP guys, being so pushy!!!

Start negotiating à 1/3 of the price! :). It's a great experience but everyone is trying to rip you off. They broke it to a science! The networks, the nice guys "helping you to find your way", the ones pretending to be sent by your hotel (one within the network sees you walking out of a cab or out of your hotel and "subtly" follows you until one of his friends pretends to work for the hotel and wants to walk you back to your hotel... etc). PS: Hotel staff almost always wears a uniform, even in Riyads. Enjoy the craziness and chaos!

Fun place like in some movies scene very colorful.. There are endless rows of shops,trying hard to catch up with some of my group in order not to get lost.If you find something you really like spare sometime for bargaining as these take time and some skill.There are many kind of shops here ie;herb,fabric,silver,leather you can easily spend 2-3hours here.

Great fun. The medina is fantastic, it feels like real Marrakech. Just be prepared to be hassled by shop and restaraunt owners! You should also be prepared to haggle for just about everything. Never the less, if you embrace it all, its truely a remarkable place to experience. Visit the cafe France for some great views of the market.

Real Marrakech. This is both amazing (as you can see the real heart of Marrakech) and annoying (as you are offered to buy something ALL THE TIME). Anyway this is great place to visit and to get lost in. Just a little tip: if someone offers you anything at all (even to show the way to soaks or something) be sure that if you accept it, you`ll have to pay them!

Shopping for fabrics and beads. There are several shops selling brocade fabrics for decoration on Avenue Houmaine el Fatouaki leading from Hotel Tazi to Place des Ferblantiers. The better qualities are mixed cotton, viscose, polyester, the cheaper only polyester, prices range from 10-50 euros per meter. The area of the Souk Epices, also selling fabrics, spices and jewellery is under heavy construction and unfortunately the renovation means higher prices in the new shops. If you go down a small alley by restaurant Tanjia you will still find three shops full of beads and jewellery with lower prices. The street vendors come here to shop as this is mainly wholesale. Beads are sold by weight and there are intersting finds to be made if you have the time and patience. There is the large shop of Style Berber Produceurs near Bab Fteuh left from Jemaa el Fna which has an overwhelming stock both in jewellery and beads with higher prices. You can also watch the local women making the traditional jewellery.
Timeless!. By walking through the medina of Marrakech you will feel like you have stepped back in time! Our second visit to this enchanted area says it all!

Don't go on a Sunday !. Everybody is coming for the Medina. And you should. Beautiful mixture of oriental and african style.
DO not go on Sunday. 60 % is closed.

exciting. the medina of marrakesh is full of small shops that for sure will catch your attention,you will find leather goods that are very cheap such as shoes, bags, slippers, etc.also you have to visit the silver shops, they offer good products with good prices,in the medina you will find really kind merchants that speak french and Arabic (a few speak English and Spanish)you will also find many places that sell orange juice (very refreshing on a hot day)as well as traditional clothing (the jellaba & koftan)the colors are amazing and the movement (definitely bring your camera)
Great food. Good to explore eat loads of meat and getting lost in the allies but most of all its very safe. Good for people who don't drink.

What we learnt. The medina has some beautiful architecture and some must see places such as the palaces and tombs. Food in Marrakech isn't brilliant. We found that the best places to eat were an Italian called I Limoni and the Jemma El Fenna Market (which was also cheap!) 45d between two people. The market is also a must see experience at night. The streets of the medina are a rat run. Make sure you load Google maps on your phone or at least have a map with you, although this may not help you very much as most of the streets are under cover and due to the high buildings you may not be able to locate yourself on the maps too well. You will be inundated with people who will come up to you if you look lost or get your phone out pretending to be 'your friend' or to guide you to a destination. These people will want paying and when you do pay them will always want more. Stand your ground and do not give in. Be firm if you do not want their help. We often had 'guides' waiting on the corner for us even when we had said no and walked off in a random direction to try and shake them off. Be careful when walking the streets as mopeds and scooters as well as cars use the narrow alley ways and don't often stop. The bus to Jemma El Fenna is number 2 and from Jemma El Fenna to the new main part of town is number 1. The airport bus from Jemma El Fenna is number 19.

JUST AMAZING...A REAL ALADINS CAVE. Like a film set. Surreal and an experience not to be missed. Good idea if exploring round blind alleys it can be a maze, take gps and put pedestrian in. Make start point your fav, so you can really explore and still get back!

What we came for. We came to Morocco to stay at a Riad in the medina and experience it all first hand. It is what it is and certainly not for everybody. It is true that con men (guides) abound and will steer you here and there and then demand exorbitant payment. Just say no to ALL approaches and walk with purpose... although this is difficult while strolling and eyeing the booths. If you would like a guide, hire one through your hotel at an agreed on price. This guide will be your shield for the day against eager volunteer "guides" but will likely have some "cousins" with shops, etc, etc. It is what it is. One tip I gained (though out in the desert, not in Marrakech) on larger purchases like rugs, leather jackets, etc is always bargain in the local currency (MAD) and make any merchant that quotes you a credit card price in Euros or US Dollars give you a price in MAD. They are looking to add 10% or more in the "conversion" if you settle on a Euro or dollar price.
Busy Busy Busy. Loved the atmosphere and the retail - You must haggle- It's expected - Wasn't fond of the snake charmers and the constant harassment from henna "artists"

Not bad, but when will they ever learn?. This was my second time in Morocco, first time in Marrakech. All fine so far. Friendly people, only saw one pickpocket, decent offers, nice old city center worth seeing. BUT why are the vendors still bothering their customers that much? Probably because it works, I guess, but this doesn't make it better. Strolling, casual relaxed watching is almost impossible. Also guys, do you think that people coming from the US or Europe are all looking for CHEAP things first? Why don't you offer quality first? Just my two cents, I might be wrong and not represent the majority of visitors. However, I rather visit Istanbul again...

Motorbike Heaven, Hell for Pedestrians. The very early morning is the time to really enjoy life in this vibrant medina, filled with wonderful sights and smells...all that we travelers were looking for in Marrakech. But enjoy it while you can before the onslaught of motorbikes which encounter your every turn, even in the remotest alleyways, blasting through impossible crowds and destroying the experience. Sorry but it's true, so don't expect a traipsey in exotica. Marrakech is all tourist, all the time.

great country very hot and great sites to see. i have stayed in the palm plaza and spa marrakech , i can say with out a dought that its features and stunning pool and bar and staff were outstanding ,they could not do enough for me and the pool staff were great i had a problem with my fridge and went to the front desk and it was sorted with in 20 minutes ,we went to the old city its worth a trip ,and to the snow cap mountains ,so to all those who are going here this hotel will cover all,and just for news i met the owner who gave us some of his birthday cake ,a gentle man ,thanks to all staff palm plaza marrakech ,

Interesting place. This medina and its souks is a shoppers paradise, as long as you are prepared to do business with rude, aggressive shopkeepers. There are lots of places you can escape to if you are prepared to walk and lose yourself in the narrow lanes. Take a good map. It's well worth exploring the quiet more residential lanes.

It's a Marmite experience!. The Medina is easy to reach by free transfers by major hotels or a short taxi ride. The main entrance is lined with horse drawn carriages with an overpowering horsey smell. If you want to hire a carriage, agree the price and the length of the ride before you get in. The main square is crowded with snake charmers, henna ladies, watermen and dancing moneys. These poor animals are not treated at all well. I saw them being fed with dry, dirty bread. You can buy dates, spices and nuts at reasonable prices. There are many restaurants around the square where you can go upstairs and enjoy a cold drink while "people watching". Through the Medina square you can enter the Souk with row upon row of small shops selling everything from hand made leather sandals, leather coats, carved wooden boxes, carpets and beautiful tagines.......so leave plenty of space in your luggage for your shopping. The shops owners are friendly and expect you to barter in a friendly manner. We made three visits to the Medina and Souk and only met good, friendly local people, willing to give directions when you get lost. You are quite safe, so go and enjoy some "different" retail therapy, but if you want a sanitised day out, it will not be for you, but don't complain, stay at home and shop in M & S!

A busy maze of streets . The medina truly is the heart of Marrakech. It's impossible not to get lost but you'll always find your way in the end and discover some interesting sights on the way.The streets are constantly bustling with people, donkeys and motor bikes some of which whizz through the smallest spaces! After dark it gets busier still as locals tend to shop when it's cooler so be prepared for a bit of jostling by the crowds but it's no worse than commuting on London Underground! Lots of people offers directions to "big square" we were advised to ignore them which we did, and we were always going to the right way anyway so suspect it's a ruse to get you into their shops! It's busy, noisy and a bit smelly but if you're street savvy you'll enjoy the experience as is truly is like no where else.
very different-very much worth seeing. maze-like streets and absolutely worth seeing,looks like 1001 nights.be aware: ppl will try to rob u!

Embraced by Marrakech.... an experience to remember and repeat!. Experienced the Medina and the Souks in Marrakech for the first time recently. WOW! A culture shock but a very positive one. A total immersion and experience for the senses. Sights! Smells! Sounds! Activity! Buzz! Atmosphere! Confusing at first but my experience was that everyone looked out for everyone else. Lost ? Just ask a vendor and they will point you in the right direction. Want to buy something ? Yes ? Be prepared to negotiate. It's the done thing and 99.9% of the time is good fun and done with good humour coming to a win win situation for both parties. Spices, oils, coffee, leather, jewellery, fruits, juices, artisan goods painstakingly made by hand in derbs or lttle alleyways ...local men (usually) hammering out a living. Co-operatives supporting local people the order of the day and therefore one doesn't mind paying a bit over the odds to support the people and economy here. The variety is exceptional. Carts, bicycles, donkeys, people, scooters, cars, small and big taxis....full on but all the more enjoyable for that. By the way small taxis are cheaper and again before you agree to use them you have to haggle on price. Sometimes the taxi driver has to stop en route to ask the way. Interesting approach! And sometimes you are dropped near and not right at the destination and have to work out the rest of the route. You get used to this different way of life and get there in the end. If this is all too much all at once, take time out from the buzz of it all. Sit on the balcony of the Cafe Du France for example and just watch it all happening whilst having a local tagine, just a cafe du lait or preferably traditional Moroccan mint tea. And if you so wish, make a contribution in kind when you are there. Volunteering perhaps at an orphanage or using the restaurant at Amal Women's Training Centre (see separate review). Go on ....you know you want to be embraced by Marrakech and its people. An experience to remember and repeat!

Awful. The Medina is absolutely awful. If you are thinking of going don't. It is dirty and oppressive. The guides are relentless, rude and downright crooked. We were well aware of the problem with the guides but others in our group fell foul of them. They will tell you that they are part of your hotel or tour which is a lie. They will take you to some horrible tacky shops and then demand money from you with menaces.You can see all you need to from photographs, they look ok. The reality of the place is like turning over a stone - full of money grabbing low lives. Go somewhere else instead.

If you can't find a bargain...then you have your eyes shut!!. Loved it. Always something going on from snake charmers to traditional music. Take a carriage ride and toilet paper. Not many public toilets and catching a public bus at night is a nightmare. Taxis are everywhere, just remember you can negotiate a price. Beggars are everywhere, so if you feel inclined, save your coins. Enjoy :0)
Amazing experience, bustling bustling busy busy. Wow, the city that never sleeps! almost....... Its certainly pretty frantic 18 hours of the day and then maybe a little calmer :-)

Hectic...Haggling...Crazy...and more than a little stressful!. My star rating is for the experience of the Medina.Surely a stay in Marrakech is not complete without a visit to the Medina.If you get lost.....and you will.....ask for directions to 'the Square'. Jemaa El Fna.IF you do want to buy something then be prepared to haggle.Do not be afraid to say no.....you will be hassled.If you want to shop in a more relaxed environment then there is a small shopping precinct (the Artisan Complex) where the prices are fixed. Experience both.....why not? The complex will give you a steer on a reasonable price to pay.Go to the Medina whilst you are in Marrakech!

Get used to the smell and be prepared to be hassled constantly. You have to wander around the Medina, but you are constantly being harassed by over enthusiastic locals, eager to earn a local Dirham!! Just ignore them.The stalls are full of the same local stuff, spices, rugs and general tourist 'tat'. Show interest at your peril. They latch on and start with ridiculously high prices as if preparing for haggle battle. Just consider your maximum price and stay with it. They will soon come running after you if you walk away. Steer clear of the food and drink stalls however. We saw so many of their produce absolutely covered in flies and wasps, it was amazing that anybody would buy from them at all.

Nice place to spend some time. No town/city in Morocco is complete without a Medina. It's fun to wander about, browse and buy a few knick knacks.
People will pursue you. Smile at them and say no nicely

So much worse than Fez!!!!!. If you are looking for an amazing historic medina with photos at every turn, cool streets, non agressive people and no fear of getting run over from a motorbike, go to Fez. Definitely will skip Marrakesh next time, Fez is sooooo much better!

Not that a-maze-ing. You will inevitably and inadvertently wander the medina if you have to a) find your riad, or b) go from point A to point B in what you might think is the shortest path to where you need to go. After an hour or so, everything will start to blend in and look the same. Initially you will stumble upon cool shops or places to eat or interesting sites. But the touts who are in your face constantly start wearing on you. You only need to be walking for a few seconds before a tout will identify you as a tourist, and do his best to latch onto you. He'll either you offer you directions or assume you're looking for "the square" and try to help. But it's not free. You will surely be hit up for money if you accept directions in any way. Some might even point you the wrong way. The best thing is to use Google maps on your phone to find your way around and retrace your steps using landmarks you passed. I didn't need to have a data connection and Google maps, at least, indicated where I was. With regards to picture taking, be careful who you snap a pic of. I watched tourists get hit up with money or even have their camera looked at and requested deletion of pictures. Not really a fun place to be, in my opinion.

Fun afternoon. Busy,dirty,lots of smells and hundreds of stalls. Buying a carpet was an experience from fun with pleasant dealers to down right rude and one just wouldn't stop. The dying section was interesting with much of the same to buy. A long walk home after going in circles for a while.
Learn to say NO. Beautiful and interesting place.A bit smelly and dirty in places.Too many touts hassling you to buy things.Learn to say NO to everything.

Pleasant experience. Marrakesh was the highlight of my visit to Morocco and the Medina is the most interesting attraction in this beautiful city. Luckily my hotel was a few steps away from the hustle and bustle of the exciting Square and the souks. The weather could not have been any better and the people are very courteous and friendly.

Crazy place!. Amazing, fun, and interesting to walk thru the medina and haggle with the shop keepers. Went to see the tanneries on the outskirts and a fair walk from the centre of the square - not for the faint-hearted it's tricky to walk through the actual area they use. You will be given a bunch of fresh mint to hold at your nose - make sure you take this!

Sensory overload. We love the medina, it is so much fun just walking around, the alleyways, the scents and getting lost in a controlled way. We have been here a few days now and have the way home down pat. We were here two years ago and I must say there are less donkeys and pestering sellers and children wanting to take you to the square for a fee. That said the smells of food and things we would prefer not to know is intoxicating in a good way. It is so refreshing to see items in shops and stalls that are not made in China - we could fill a container or a TARDIS, if we had the chance. Make sure you have a fresh OJ in the big square - 40 eurocents / 4 DH.

A maze but something at every turn. We entered the Medina though one of many gates. The doesn't appear to be many straight lanes with corners abounding.The lanes are full of shops or stands and there were plenty of offers to sell products to us.I loved how you can get lost, in this world so different from home, the different items and the colour of the rugs or food.The share is large and there were plenty of places to have lunch, the more expensive ones have terraces and roof tops to look over the square.I didn't like the monies with leads or the snake charmers wanting you to have photos taken with the snake.But all in all there was colour and movement, and a maze of ways to go

Interesting and Complicated place!!!!. This is a very interesting place, have not seen other like it in my many trips, it's a city withing the city of Marrakech. The pace is caotic here inside, lots of people, lots of small stores, lots of people from the area trying to make a living out of the tourists. The center or hart of this jungle, and is a very hot jungle, is the Djamaa el Fna Square, here where most of things happen during the day and specially at night with a lot of attractions of all types. Also has restaurants inside and in all the buildings surrounding the square, some good and some not so much. Beside a city jungle this is also a maze as you can get lost just by taking the wrong turn and believe me, this does happen you wanted or not. If you do speak French, English or Spanish you may find help and in the worst case scenario, have always handy a map of the medina and just point where you want to go. As I said, there are all kind of people making their living out ot tourists so they will, for a very small fee, take you any and every where withing this maze. By the way, make yourself a favor and before you travel here, see here in TripAdvisor what is the best travel agency to make the 2 day/1 night trip to the Sahara Desert or any other trip. What is the best place to get a Sauna and Massage or any other thing you may want. Planning in advance will make your trip and experience more worth wile and time efficient. Good luck

Do not miss. Wow this was amazing at night as I wrote on my review of the Souk BUT during the day it was so different and interesting , we used a wonderful local guide Abdoul who had lived in the Medina all his life so his knowledge was invaluable. Its almost like a trade centre we saw shoe makers , the tanning process of the leather , metal workers , spices being weighed and displayed such an eye opener not to be missed.

Bustling, dirty and crowded. The Medina of Marrakech is full of people, cars, bicycles, scooters, donkeys, people carrying carts etc. It's incredibly busy, packed and filthy (no one cleans up after their donkeys). If you want to enjoy a Medina with shops, go to the pedestrian friendly one in Fez.

Marrakech for solo female travellers. Throw a book in any direction in the old pink walled city of Marrakech in Morocco and it will land on a beautiful Riad. You can go out on a tour of the spice markets or surrounding Atlas Mountains, visit the locations of films like Babel, Gladiator, Romancing the Stone, Game of Thrones, and see signs pointing south to Timbuktu ( I thought this was an imaginary city but it’s real! ) Visit the women’s co-ops to buy real Argan oil hair and skin products direct from the ladies who make them to fund their daughters education and their own independence. When you are done seeing great locations and laughing Berber ladies wearing their original version of the hijab casually like a Nepalese headscarf, with metal coins on if they are going to town, head back behind the high walls of your Riad to be spoiled like a princess in the cool courtyard. I can really recommend Riad Enija midweek as they are block booked out at weekends by corporates, so firstly it is often empty during the week and secondly 5* for 2 * US/ European prices at that time. You will have the ice cool marble Roman swimming pool and wonderful staff, trees, private terraces and even nightingales all to yourself. Bring TE Lawrence ( Lawrence of Arabia’s ) the Seven pillars of Wisdom or Edward Dulac’s Picture book for the French Red Cross.

Going back in time.. Although Marrakech is constantly changing and growing more modern the Madina, the 900 year old heart of the city is tough and adapts to accomodate new visitors - now many from Rabat and Casablanca.Having first visited in 1971 I can thoroughly recommend it. Get out there and get lost.

Must do!. No matter the time of day, you must stop here!We found more people with monkeys and snakes during the day.Be aware, everyone expects to be paid for a photo.At night, the food vendors, music, et al were spectacular.Recommend taking photos to find your way back, lots of alleys: But that's all the fun!!!
Vibrant. A vibrant colourful part of Marrakech is a must to visit so much going on . The souk is fascinating with so many stalls, you would need a two day visit to get round them all,

an experience not to be missed. fantastic,bustling,busy,colourful and with the tantalising aroma of spices,the place to be in marrakech.Small enough to find your way around with an amazing array of wares for sale from hundreds of stalls and shops.love it!

Love this place. This is everything you would expect and more! Had been before with my husband and loved the whole experience. Was a little worried that two blonde girls on their own might get hassled loads but was pleasantly surprised, don't get me wrong you will get hassled but not too bad and a polite but firm no works, So much to see and buy and much is good quality. But the Medina is not just the souks, there are many restaurant and Riads that you can visit and standard of street food is really good and quite safe to eat. In general the people were respectful to two blondes though the younger boys hanging around would pounce if they saw you consult a map!! we ended up not bothering with the map as when in the souks there are few signs and none that seemed to corelate to what was on the map! You will get lost - many times but it all adds to the experience and you will discover so much but if you see anything you want to buy get it there and then as it's very unlikely you will ever find it again!!! we stayed in Riad in the Medina off Rue El Bacha by the palace and felt supremely safe. At night they have security to make sure you get back safely to your Riad - our guy, Omar, was a godsend. you haven't been to Marrakech until you've visited the Medina its wonderful.

Amazing. We went to the medina in Marrakech in September and it was an amazing place. Full of colours, the smell of spices and friendly locals. Lots to see, eat and gifts to buy. 100% recommend a day and evening visit!

Quite an experience.. Really cannot miss strolling around the Medina and souks. You do get quite hassled by the traders but a firm No usually sends them on their way. Such amazing sights and things to buy you just cannot resist but Haggle hard and settle for about a third of their original asking price otherwise walk away. If you feel uncomfortable haggling go to ET Bouchaib which is the Government run artisan complex, indoors and fixed very reasonable prices and they sell just about everything you could desire. The Herbalists around this area may worry you a little but I am told they are licenced if you do not want to take the chance again you can buy if the ET. The Berber Co-op is also very good but here the haggling reaches its heights so be strong.

Not as scary as you think..... This medina is bustling, people and things going on everywhere. But the square isn't that big or scary as other tourist Id met beforehand made out it was. Some of my friends were actually scared of going there and avoided it altogether based on its reputation alone - ridiculous! I didn't get harassed at all in the five days I was here. In the square, don't take photos of people or things unless you want to pay a tip for it. DONT be afraid to eat at the "local" looking places around the square - AMAZING food!! The locals here are used to tourists, and don't feel the need to be overly friendly- but they aren't too bad. Generally if you're friendly and respectful, they will be too. Other than that - its all good. In saying that, medinas in other cities were a little friendlier and more interesting to be honest. Well worth a visit, but don't forget the rest of Morocco. Fes medina was more authentic (and MUCH bigger!).

Monkeys and Cobras and Snakes OH MY !!. A bit overwhelming at first.We pulled in to the big square and had a quick hour tour of the aera before being set loose for an hour or so on our own.An hour isn't even close to enough time to get deep into the Medina.There are booths all thru the alleys with clothes,leather,meat and veggies.Its an ancient farmers market.The entertainment is out in the main square.We saw monkeys all dressed up ,snake charmers that you can get your picture taken with and even a guy who makes dentures right there on the street.Do beware of the sales guys,not in a bad way its gust they are so damn good.You will walk away wondering why you bought what you did but you are happy you did.These guys are the salesmen of all salesmen.There is so much going on its all a blur,if you can go back for a secon visit and take it all in.As for prices ,if your tour is going to Fes,hold off the prices are better there the only thing is if you are looking for t shirts as gifts or for yourself get them here for some reason there are none in Fes,just soccer jerseys,just remember to barter hard its s sport there.

Too many tourists. I've seen many medinas and the one in Marakesh seems to be the worst one. Of course, it has a lot of trade and cultural charm, but it's way too touristy. It's stinky and dirty. It's overpriced as sellers know that all-inclusive European will pay even hundred euro for something that usually costs ten. In my opinion, like many popular places, it lost its' original charm because of mass tourism. If you look for the magic medina - go to Chefchaouen.

It's a circus medina. There is nothing to adequately describe this place. Noise, chaos, history, culture, beauty, mazes of streets. Madness with motorbikes, fumes, bicycles, cabs, storks nesting peacefully atop of buildings. A myriad of colors, smells, spices, leathercrafts, lampmaking...to trinkets, snake charmers, street,performers and millions of curiousity seekers and explorers all coming together in this melting pot. A guide is really helpful for the historical aspects of this multi faceted place. A must see one in your life.

Fascinating Labyrinth. A warren of alleys filled with souks, market squares, well-hidden riads. Haggling is the order of business in the souks, start well below the stated price. It is very easy to get lost in the medina. Seemingly helpful individuals will give directions, often walking with you to your stated destination (oftentimes Jemaa el Fna). They expect payment for this service, and can be quite aggressive. If you must ask for directions, ask the shopkeepers. Moroccan sweets and orange juice, available throughout the medina, are a must try. When walking around, keep to the right, as motorbikes whiz by at breakneck speeds.
bustling. vibrant and bursting with morocan gifts, maybe a bit too pushy for you to buy, just be polite but firm.

Utter Madness worth the visit. I went to the Medina around 7pm in the evening to get a good seat at the Café France to sit over the Medina to watch the sun go down and the Medina come to life. The sights and sounds can be overwhelming. Seems like another world to have snake charmers & monkeys trainers in the Medina. Be careful, as the snake charmers will try to place the snakes around your head then try to extort monies from you. For that matter everyone is trying to extort monies from you. Everything is bartered. Basically what ever price is given to you stand firm at about 1/3 of the price. It is exhausting to barter all the time and the culture will sell their family to get more coin. Always a story to try to make you buy, pay or spend more. Sunset at the café was stunning! Worth the trip

An experience you won't forget.... I have just returned from Marrakesh, I didn't know what to expect and was a little nervous visiting the medina and souks. Yes it is busy, hectic and you will get lost! But it's great. (If you need directions ask shop keepers they normally will help and they can't take you on a dead end tour as they wont leave their shops). As in any other country be aware of your belongings and be respectful of their culture in the way you dress. Haggling is part of the way of life here so if you don't like pushy sales people this is not the place for you. You have to be firm and say No Thank You and carry on your way. Yes a lot of the stuff in the souks is tat and imported from China but it is easy to spot this from the traditional Moroccan items. The experience in the day and in the night are totally different and both I would recommend.

The Moroccan red City / historical & Cultural. Marrakech is a very old city gives its visitors a special tourism with its narrow streets and solid colors.The square and in the alleys of the Medina, it is a festival of colors. Despite the crowd rushing day and night in the old city, it feels like a village. All know, recognize. The music and the pace forever remain etched in the memories.

The First Touch of Moroccan shopping and life. Well, this place is obviously a place for tourists to see different things. You will get to see Moroccan products - ceramics, pottery, Moroccan lambs, Arabic dresses, herbs and spices, leathers and etc..However, one of the feature I liked is the contrast feeling it gave during day time and night time. In a day time, you would see snakes show, shops and if you could find the right place, there was a small path in which locals people enjoy their cuisine and it was really cheap. In the night time, you would see Henna-Painting ladies, music buskers and lots of food vendors. The price for this food vendor is cheap compared to a proper restaurant.It is also linked with different souks where the locals shop so enjoy yourself in this maze.

A Must. Its hard to believe when you are standing in the middle of the madness that is the Medina you are only 3 hours away from the UKThe atmosphere is an electric mix of noise, smells , sights that amaze.There are snake charmers, story tellers ,henna artists , music makers (so loud !) dancers, horse and carriages , bikes and the wonderful orange juice sellers, to name but a tiny part of what is happening.Walking around the Souks with 2 blond teenage girls we felt neither frightened or threatened.In fact I nearly accepted 1,500 camels for one of them.Goods on sale were extraordinary, we have been to many souks in many countries but this was the biggest and best The array of goods is mind boggling and the bartering is done with fun, if we did not want to look in the shop we were thanked and followed with 'cheap as chips ' or 'lovely jubbly ' !!A great experience and we will definitely return

what you expect from Marrakech and more. Please visit the centre of this charming city, but don't pay what's asked of you from the market stalls! The locals here have the trading mentality in their DNA, so dont be shocked!

Madness in the medina. Hectic, bustling, busy, what more can you expect. Haggle, bargain and hold your nerve in the souks. It's a great atmosphere and won't disapooint. Sure there are odd smells from the tanneries on the east side etc, but top class food and all very reasonable. Some great palaces and museums too.
Mesmerizing. No place like it. Heard and read about it. No matter how much I read, nothing feels like the real experience. AMAZING!

Cacophony. The medina of Marrakech is very noisy with drums, people shouting, music: it is chaos but great fun! The food markets in the evening are brilliant and number 1 stall is the one we found to be best.

Crowded place where traditional life takes place. The Medina or also known The Souks, offer so many things to see, smell and shop. If you are looking for typical Berber carpets, traditional lamps and cushions, this is the best place for you! Don't forget to deal for a good price. Go in the morning or afternoon, as by night, it gets too crowdy and to complicated to find the way back ;)

Just wander. Go any place, dive into the atmosphere, get lost, ask someone if got lost. Helpful people, but beware of false guides. Make the impression as if you know what you do and where you are. Then you will see edges, that are non-touristic, chaotic, true.

Impressive. Medina is so nice place in Marrakech. Certainly one of the most interesting place to visit in the city. There a re lots of culture there, with traditional food, local people selling the most variety of things and some exibitions os snakes and songs. Nice place.
Get lost in the past. Spend a day and get lost on your way to the museum and Jardin, then go to the Jemaa el Fna Square at night

Medina of Marakech. Marrakech is an exotic old city that retains a fusion of French, Arabic, and Berber cultures. It offers temperate weather with views of the snow capped Atlas mountains. Magnificent minarets, the call of Islam, and friendly merchants create a nice vibe. Where else does one find snake charmers tempting cobras, fresh sqeezed orange juice venders, delightful Moroccan tagine dinners, and ancient souks selling spices, leather, jewelry, and of course Argan oil products. A trip to the medina from the airport should cost about 100 dirhams. A nice cous cous or Tagine meal about 30 dirhams ($3). Fresh orange juice 4 dirhams. Watch out, if you watch the snakes or play game to their enticings expect to pay; one demaded 400 dirham. Its easy to get lost, figuratively, in the souks, but with thought you can find your way back to the plaza without trouble. Tourists with luggage draw attention from unhelpful guides who hope to earn some money. The best money exchange rates where at the Ali Hotel near the plaza but lots of options are nearby. Consider staying in a Riad for a cozy and more typical experience. If you are shopping for Argan oil, prices vary considerably and may depend on your haggling skills. If prefered, go to a store that sells foods, and they often sell the oil at a fixed rate: 90 dirham for 250 mL or 170 dirham for 500 mL. Leather products also vary in price but consider paying about half the original price: 550 dh for a carry-on sized nice cow leather bag, rather than the 800 to 900 dh they ask. Enjoy!! Morocco is one if the safest Islamic countries and it offer tremendous delights.

This is Marrakech. The old walled city of Marrakech is the reason for most people to visit this fascinating place. Don't get lost walking around the narrow streets, but someone will always help you find your way around!

Great place. Markets were great, people were very nice! Thoroughly enjoyed our shopping spree at the markets....we visited some shops more than once and the shop keepers recignised us...bartling experience was awsome

"Historic and cultural". This place is a mixture of goods and bads. A place full of morrocon goods, food and many more. When u there u must keep this in mind that you not in eurpe. There is a concern of hygien sometimes smelly sometimes no very clean but still stunning. Amazing experience, A different world, different cultre,full of locals it's great. Not only visiting this place is good but staying in a riad in the medina is a must to have real morrocon experience. This will mak your trip unforgetable.

Children loved it. My 5 yr old and 7 yr old boys loved it. Enjoyed the madness, has a sort of music festival vibe to it. Good food. Didn't like seeing poorly treated monkeys though. Don't get much hassle really. Friendly people. The henna tattoo ladies are a bit annoying - ie doing henna on kids without asking and then demanding huge payment - but they settled for 15 dirham and kids liked their scorpion tattoos.

2 Days is more than enough!. It was great to visit the Medina, though we wished we had planned a shorter stay. 2 days was more than enough and having made my way to the coast post staying in the Medina of Marrakech, I have to say that I appreciate the tranquility. Marrakech was much too aggressive!
Colour and Spice. Fantastic sensory experience of colour, smells, taste and culture an allround amazing day out that we will never forget.

Got to experience it. Amazing hustle and bustle - like going back to Biblical times - traders, dealing, haggling, street entertainers, spices, sweet pastries, mint tea, snake charmers and people watching.Go there with an open mind, respect a different culture and be alert...... no different to any city in the world !

Must See but..... The medina is an amazing place, it's a completely different world to what most Europeans or "western" people are used. It is a vibrant bustling area filled with souks and alleyways. It may seem intimidating at first but you soon relax.Tip#1 you will get lost, don't panic and you will be fine. Tip#2 you will be constant chatter from locals trying to sell you something, just smile and ignore them.

A key experience in Marrakech - Much safer than you think. We were situated in a riad within the medina and wandering around (with our tripadvisor map to hand) was some of the greatest experiences that we had and taste of Marrakech during our time on holiday.For all the hustle and bustle, at no time did we feel unsafe, yes people are trying to haggle and get you to buy things but I did not feel any danger of pickpockets more than in central london.KEY ADVICE!!!If you go to the squares or come across any henna artists or people who want to give you something for 'free' be sure to say NO firmly unless you intend to purchase. They can be very insistent to say the least.Must visit though and take a wander around and see all the areas which make these near-slums exist. A wonderful circus of activity but it can get a bit much/a bit boring after your third time there but definitely worth one meal in one of the overlooking restaurants to watch the action unfold.

would not do again. you need a guide in the souk so easy to get lost, we went with our tour guide really not worth it we spent 1/2 in chemist being told about oils and creams, walking loads but seeing nothing. medina square was good. you can get official tour guides to take you into souk, barter price.

Great market for day and night. you can start the morning by frash orange juice for less then 1 $.continue by great breakfast, shopping and smelling the real market life, eating for lunch lamb shops , 1 kg for 20 $.afternoon great marocain tea, walking between the local jugglers, you can spend hours to see all , and to be ready for the big show in the evening: the food market. WOW

Amazing. Endless tiny stalls selling Moroccan lamps, leather goods, spices, pottery, carpets, fabric, clothes, etc. really amazing to see the crafts are kept alive and to be able to see the artists at work. Beware of the snakes and monkeys.

Too much ado about nothing. As we had a top in Casablanca with our cruise, we decided to do a very expensive shore excursion to Marrakech. Granted, our tour guide eas really terrible, but I fail to see the excitement about the Medina. Filth, smells, people bumping into you trying to snatch something from you and all other miseries, these are all things that I do not enjoy. I expected someting like Istanbul, but was hugy disappointed.

An open-air theatre,Jemaa el-Fnaa-Marracesh. The fourth largest city in the country after Casablanca, Rabat & Fes known also as the "Red City" or "Ochre City" because of the coloure of the houses.Τhe largest traditional souk( small alleys) and the busiest square in all of Marocco , the Jemaa el-Fnaa is an open theatre full of acrobats , storytellers , watery , snake charmers , dancers & musicians , spices, fresh fruits & juices, handmade things . A market place full of colors , smells , flavors and spectacle where you can find almost everything you can imagine . As darkness falls, the square fills with dozens of food-stalls with traditional food . Get lost in the alleys without fear , drink pure orange juice & buy arabic peanuts , admire the carpets & silver-plated , ask for better price always and insist.

lovely place full of activites. its like the entire tourist crowd of the city assembles here around evenings. lovely place to be. lots of locals, good food, great cafes, but sometimes they push you to much to eat at their stalls

Culture shock and culture fun. I stayed in a riad in the medina, and then adventured in the souks everyday. It was a loud crowd all of the time, and even crazier at night. A definite must-see to complete any visit to Marrakech

A maze of hustling interspersed with many oasis . The city wall is 19km around its perimeter. Entrance gates lead you inside from the busy wide streets into a maze of small alleyways and roads and of course into the heart of the Souks.
