Take a wrong turn down an alleyway and you may happen upon an oasis of calm in a rooftop riad or restaurant. Suggest saving a Google map for use offline and favouriting your riad or hotel. Then use GPS offline to guide you back. Getting lost is so easy. The Souks at first apart intimidating but persevere you'll long for a still through then on your return to normal life.

busy. very busy place!! with plenty to see. Watch out for the cunning shop keepers!! who will lure you into their shops and be very persistent!!! They will also try to direct you if you look lost where they want you too go!The evening market is a must!! wonderful sights, music and smells. Stop off at a rooftop café to take it all in.

Cleaner & safer than expected. I expected to be terrified entering the Medina alone but was pleasantly surprised at how easy it was to wander about by myself. It's loosely divided into sections, metal workers, carpet sellers, herb sellers, etc. People will invite you into their shops but not in a hard core way. As you meander about keep your eyes open for cafes tha are located upstairs. It's a break from the hustle bustle and there is typically a shaded patio and views of the city. There are some wonderful cafes with really good food at affordable prices. There were only 2 negatives for me: first was the speed of the motorcycles in the narrow alleys and second was the young men who try to get you to go to the tanneries for spices or whatever. Do not engage them unless you are willing to pay them a fee. Most people will be kind enough to point you in the right direction if you are lost. Almost everyone (except shopkeepers) will not want you to take photos of them. They may get quite angry if you do.

Lots to See and Do. The main square is the focal point at night and a good spot to start your exploration of the Souks. During the day it has lots of things to entertain the tourists. Those entertaining you are not there for their art they are there to make money so please be prepared to tip if you stop to enjoy what it is they have for you to see. Around the square are lots of low cost decent food eateries. Wandering the alleyways was not that difficult. There are some signs that will help guide you but you can find your way back out of the Souks area if you need to so feel free to wander. I suggest going to what was called the spice market/area. There were several interesting Souks in this area selling more non-touristy artistic stuff. Expect to barter kindly. At night the main square is the attraction. Yeah the carriage area smells like horse pee etc... but that is because there are lots of horses waiting for tourists. Expect to be "courted" for your business as you wander the square, as there will be alot of people trying to sell you things but that is just part of the experience. One night in the square is all we needed and did not have desire to return to the square at night but two days wandering the Souks might have been better than the one day we had. Overall I found the Medina to be quite touristy and less authentic than the other medinas in other Moroccan cities.

Lots to see. The medina is worth a visit in the day and another at night. By day the square is quieter with henna ladies, monkey's for photos and snake charmers. The souks are interesting but it's easy to get lost if you take the small alleys. Stick to the main routes and there are signs hanging from the roof to point you in the direction of the square. We found bartering a bit tedious but the shop keepers were courteous and enjoy it.By night the smell of horse piss from the horse drawn carriages lined up at the entrance to the square was quite overwhelming! The square was packed but you felt safe. There were food stalls and entertainers with lots of sounds and smells of food!

Don't Buy seafood on the street.. Medina of Marrkech is a amazing place, you can find everithing you want, but do not buy seafood on the street. I saw horrible things in the back of the restaurant of the Medina.

Sensory overload... A very neat experience with an abundance of sights, sounds, smells and so many people. Be assertive and confident while shopping in the souks and follow the crowds in order to not find yourself in an unsafe area. Very cultural and face paced.
Exciting. Just love being there, the atmosphere at night is a lot better than during the day.Always very busy. I just love being around the Moroccan people!You must visit.

Mixed experience. The medina is a place with lows and highs. the positive: the energy, hustle and bustle, the beautiful riads and restaurants hidden behind gates and terrasses on the roof, beautiful stores and friendly people in the storesthe negative: the noise and fumes of motorcycles which drive at incredible speed through the small streets, the difficulty to find your way around and the hastle by people (especially beware of young teenagers hanging around corners in the medina) trying to send you in the wrong direction or showing you the way and then ask money, the dirt and trash in the streets.In short, some people fall in love with it, others hate it
Vibrant. Loved the medina, it does get very busy in the evenings, and with that also comes many beggars. Have to haggle hard, we only got the hang of it when we were leaving.
Lots to see and culturally very interesting with lots to do and see.. Be aware if you take photographs or being grabbed by people wanting to thrust snake at you it will cost you money.

Don't encourage kids with money. Expect to get lost and research your way around before you go. You'll initially receive a lot of unwanted attention offering to show you round - don't accept and refuse politely but firmly. Payment will be expected for this assistance and it won't necessarily be for a small amount.

Old Town. We stayed in a Riad in Medina so felt like we were right in the middle of all the action - a great experience. The Riad itself was very peaceful and was easy to forget that you are right in the middle of it. As soon as you step out the door you are in another world altogether!Medina is home for the famous Souks and Jeema El Fna Square. It is very busy and definitely not for everyone...but a must see. Its easy to wonder around the tiny roads and alleyways and watch life go by for hours. You'll often see people walking, cycling, on motorbikes/scooters and donkeys trying to pass down the same alleyway at the same time! There are many places to eat...all with varying standards!People are friendly and always like a good banter. Take everything with a pinch of salt and always smile and you'll never get any troubles! if buying anything from the Souks remember to haggle your heart out...they will spot a tourist a mile off and immanently bump the prices up!Overall great experience!

Worth a wander. The medina is an interesting place, with little restaurants and shops in narrow streets that are terrorized by locals on scooters and bicycles. The absolute diametric opposite of any mall you've been in, and all the better for that!

Endless alleys with wonderful sights. We were able to walks the alleys of both this medina and the one in Fes and if I had to give my vote, I would vote for this one. I found that there is much more variety here. You do have to learn to navigate it though. There are mainly three streets / alleys that run from the Jemma-el-fna Square north: Rue Mouassine, Rue Semarine and Rue Rahba Kdima. The middle ally (Rue Semarine) is the widest and most transited one. While there is plenty to see there, we preferred the side alleys. It seemed to us the quality was higher there. Another general rule of thumb is that the further yo go from the square, the higher the quality. Another tip: always haggle. No matter if you think the first price they gave you was okay, haggle it down. The owners normally do not expect that you will take the first price. Be aware though that if you do begin to haggle it is expected that you will buy the item. That does not mean that if the merchant does not give you a price you feel comfortable with you have to buy it, but rather that if you offer a price and the merchant accepts, it would be rude not to honor it. Last tip I would offer is to dress discretely. While in general the souks are safe, dressing discretely will help keep away unwanted attention to yourself (or as in my case, my wife) during your wanderings around the souks.

Very good, and quite awfull as well!. Just an amazing experience for someone from northern Europe. A real warren of passageways and alleys, which, after a couple of days we began to find our way around. Hetic pace of life, with large numbers of mopeds wizzing about the place, plus all the locals, the tourists, the shopkeepers, the beggars, The mopeds were a definate downside; many of them were clearly in need of some serious engine servicing. Still a tremendous experience.

COULDN'T FIND UR WAY OUT. We found the Medina twisted different ways so much, it was Impossible to find your way out.The locals would say it was this way to the Square, but you would land up being taken to their or their sister stall, or no where at all. My daughter eventually bought some shoes, and the seller there did show us the way out, we would never have got out otherwise.Anyone going to the Medina, really must take great care, if you have a good memory that's great, otherwise write down on paper which way you have turned at every point.We found nearly all the shops there all sold the same stuff, so after a while we got bored with it. BE VERY VIGILANT AS YOU MAY LOSE YOUR PURSE AS WELL!

Absolutely beautiful. You feel like you have walked into a movie set. Narrow alleyways, small stores with handmade goods for sale, pink buildings, wide sky, surrounded by snow-capped mountains. It is a fantastic place to wander through and get lost in. I found people to be really friendly and I didn't feel hassled. Yes, they ask you to come in their stores but they are not insistent. It is absolutely fantastic.

whatever you buy, take it with you or you will never see it again. I paid A$500 at an antique shop for three items. This amount included postage. Nine months later I still had not received the goods. Luckily, when I bought the items, I asked for a receipt. I finally emailed the receipt to a resident shopping tour guide who speaks Arabic. After three attempts, the shop owner gave her the goods and they have now been posted. Do not trust the shop owners. Take your goods with you or you will never see them again.
A must in Marrakech. Love the buzz and the people in the area, did enjoy much the occasional helpers that want money for showing you the right direction!

Vibrant, colorful, exotic Medina that can also be taxing after a few days. We were exhausted after the third day visiting the Medina, but we kept coming back. Be it for the sight of snails and scorpions as a common snack, watching with awe the skillful tea pourers fill a cup with a long projection of mint tea, or the women clad from head to toe in black burqas - everything was new, different and exciting. It is a treat for the eye and for the keen photographer. We traveled as a small group of girls and were ceaselessly stopped on the streets by vendors and random men; if possible, traveling with a male companion or two may have made this easier. Also, haggle like never before. We were surprised that prices came down 50-80% from the initial prices. Although, be weary of vendors who sometimes don't take haggling well - they may shoo you out the door or aggressively yell at you. Maybe because we were all girls. It is a male centric place - we didn't see many women apart from tourists.

Flavours, Scents, colors, ... A Day in the Medina of Marrakech, go through it, open your eyes, your ears and your nose, a must see ...Kind tip : if you can afford it, pay yourself a local guide, plan the visit with him and stay firm in the negotiation if you want to buy something

Take a guide. The medina is an endless labyrinth filled with everything you can imagine... heads of sheep, Moroccan wedding furniture, live chickens, designer knockoffs. It is like stepping back in time. I have read that it is a mistake to take a guide because you cannot get the best bargain. I cannot imagine going without a guide, and the guide will save you time and money. We were 8 people, and we had 2 guides... and were REALLY happy to have them both.

Mixed feelings. On the one hand, you are in Marrakech - an exotic local with certainly a lot to take in. On the other hand, you are in Marrakech - a tourist destination which has adapted accordingly. Yeah, of course it is fascinating, but it is also a little obvious that most of the goods for sale are not great quality, and you get the sense the locals expect you to just throw money at them because you are there and in their presence. Don't get me wrong - we spent over a week here and I enjoyed every minute of it - but whatever magic this place had before has been diminished.This is not a place to go with kids unless they are nearing their teens. The roads throughout the medina are multi-use - lots of speeding mopeds and donkey carts. Also, there aren't a lot of green areas to escape to. It is really a place better enjoyed as a couple or solo.

Vibrant old market in the heart of the city. Fabulous Riads tucked away down tiny alleys, the very old metal, dying, leatherwork and other artisan markets still using age old crafts to make goods, the bustling square at night with snake charmers and exotic stalls. the transport by horse and cart and donkeys and mules and human pwered luggage carts.

Magical. We were only there for a long weekend & I feel that if I had stayed a month I would not have done the Medina justice! There was so much to see so many little diversions such couloir & so many unusual wares I was quite dizzy by the end of the day. At times I felt like I was on a Indiana Jones film set. Great fun & great bargains.
A sensory experience not to be missed.. Fantastic sensory overload. Fruits, spices, donkeys and diesel. Mint tea, orange juice, snakes and snails.No litter - no mess – no problems.

Good but lacked atmosphere in the daytime. If I had been there longer I would have gone to the markets at night when there would have been more people and a better atmosphere. I like the history of it though.

Chaotic. It is an absolute madhouse! You risk life and limb in this place and is not for the faint hearted, that said, it is a necessary experience if you are here, you could not miss out this.As said before, there is danger all around, mainly from dare devils on bikes that have no regard for the well being of the tourist, we are just a major inconvenience to them and an easy target to be ripped off!Still, take it for what it is and try and have fun along the way, just be careful. There are bargains to be had, just make sure you pay no more than what you think it is worth.

Glorious madness!. The hustle and bustle of the market squares, the shopkeepers trying to sell you anything they can, the smells of the aromatic spices, the sounds of drums and snake-charming pipes, the myriad of lanes and paths, dodging bicycles, mopeds and donkey carts, the colours of the fruit vegetables on sale, the ornate tiles, the palaces, the view of the snow-capped peaks of the High Atlas mountains, super-sweet mint tea, wonderful shopportunities, haggling, delicious street food, the call to prayer, the intoxicating scent of orange blossom, nesting storks, the tranquility of the Riad.
Enjoy the bartering. We are not naturally shoppers but I would challenge anyone not to buy a few items from the souks. We bought so much we had to check in another case!

Medina by night. After visiting the Fes and Meknes old medina and souks, visiting the Marrakesh medina during the day was somehow a repetition. However, visiting the Jamaa El-Fna plaza at night was a totally different experience. During the day the locals and even the internal tourists from other Moroccan cities (enjoying the summer school vacation) hide from the extreme August heat, but when night falls they take over the plaza full of food stalls. It is a feast with an unbelievable amount of people. It is safe to walk around and taste so many different types of Moroccan food, or just buy some nuts, olives or dry fruits like figs and dades in very organized and colourful stalls. Outsiders usually enjoy the show from the Cafe Glacier terrace (worthy compulsory minimum consumption of one soft drink).
Amazing. One of the most fascinating places in the world. Get lost and soak up the atmosphere. Don't forget to try some of the orange juice - it is incredible.
Fascinating. Wander about, get lost, drink mint tea, have lunch, browse the souks, barter with the locals. It's great!

Fantastic & frightening. I loved walking around the medina but it is very easy to get lost, bikes and mopeds think they have right of way and many Marrakech teenagers get a buzz out of sending you in the wrong direction!

Chaotic and incredible place. There's a bit for everybody within the medina: you have the riads (the nice and the ugly ones), you have the square with it's food stalls, musicians, henna painters and slaved animals, you have the palaces, the museums, the tanneries, the souks. You can spend several days trying to see it all.If you are an organized person, enjoy walking and wake up early in the day it should be enough with 3 days to cover all the major sites.I recommend not having food at the big square as the prices are much higher than in the restaurants a bit further away. We had some excellent sandwiches on food stalls we found in the souk. Also had some lovely stuffed bread (with eggs and olive paste) cooked in a tagine. Would not recommend the fried fish that is sold in the souk as the fish if mostly bones with almost no meet.If you are using a taxi beware of the prices. Ask at your hotel/riad about how much you shold be paying. We paid 30 dirham from the square to the train/bus station (we were asked from 200 to 100 but stay firm as say that you will only pay 30 which is almost double the real price they charge locals). To the airport we paid 100 dirham from the square.

Different World. I loved it, amazing the feeling of colours, noises, smells... I felt that I travelled to the Middle Age, so different to Europe and they are not that far from us...I have many picture of the medina on my bloghttp://latravelera.blogspot.com

What is the Medina?. The Medina is the old part of Marrakech and surrounded by high stone walls and sometimes way to narrow passageways. There are extremely few straight roads and driving here is not recommened for the faint of heart. Finding your way around in the Mellah (Jewish district around the synagogues) is extremely tricky at first but soon you realize that only very few alleys actually lead somewhere useful. Also dont trust local boys/men who tells you that 'this way closed'. They want to lead you to their cousins spice shop and to get paid for it as well.

Marrakesh just didn't do it for me. Visited Marrkesh for 3-4 days in Sept 203. I left feeling discouraged about the people and the way they treated animals. So so SO many horse carriages with the most malnourished, tattered and torn horses. They all carried their heads low, which anyone who knows horses know they shouldn't do that. They line them up, dozens and dozens of harnessed horses along the streets in the blazing sun. Never once did I see them give the horses water. Many of them had blistered and bloody ankles. It was just too much for me. Please do not solicit these carriages! Also, the cats in the town were no better. Many with busted faces, only one eye, if they could even open their eyes from the crust that had built over them. Kittens everywhere. I am an animal lover of course, so this was difficult. It was hard to see passed the animal cruelty to enjoy the actual city. I saw a cage with about 40 Box turtles stacked up inside, I guess for sale? Not sure. Just odd. Marrakesh didn't do it for me. Oh, and the people are not pleasant to be around. I'm not going to elaborate anymore on that to avoid insulting anyone from there, but they were not welcoming or fun to be around.

A pandoras box of experiences. A must see place to visit and experience the multifacetted city where you will see abject poverty and opulence.The souks must be visited to experience the shopping of such a diverse place
Fascinating !. It was like being transported back a hundred years. Watch out for mopeds swerving around walkers with little regard.

If you care about animals forget visiting Marrakech. “Tortured monkeys, beaten donkeys, pestering locals, filth”I have just returned from a four day break....I will not return....the most upsetting for me was the animal treatment...I googled donkeys in Marrakech and the below came up from 2012 and three years on I agree with everything thus review said so I have copied and pasted below... If I had stayed in my Riad and not ventured out it would have been a really nice break.Copy below......We spent a lot of money coming to Marrakech based on the Tripadvisor top ten 2012 traveller choice cities, which placed Marrakech a spot ahead of Istanbul... but it pales in comparison! The jetset are gone and if there ever was any real glamour so has that! The poverty here is staggering, people harassing, sorry i should say begging you for money constantly... everywhere... it is quite sad... if you are able to look past that then you are confronted with filthy neighbourhood after another, rancid smells, piled up rubbish and an unkept environment all around. Prices are on par with other major cities and if i got what other top cities had to offer then i would not mind paying but i didn't... the locals that do not feel the need to harass you are rather nice, gentle and smiley and easy to comunicate with in various languages.The main square J el and is described in many poetic ways in literature but my take on it is that it could be fun if only the locals allowed you to take it in, but vendors clammer over one another to try to get your attention and if they don't get it it turns ugly, they start insulting you and can turn aggressive, even against one another... lots of brawls... The overwhelming number of motorbikes are dangerour and willing to run you over. The souks could be fun too but should you even dare to glance at any item, again vendors will swoop on you and not let it go... and i do not mean like in Istanbul where they will in fact get the hint and back off, these people do not take no for an answer... Perhaps the saddest part are the animals, monkeys that have had their teeth removed and are viciously reprimanded and choked should they not comply with the onslaught of petting and torture... i am a primatologist and it was evident that they were highly disturbed, but you need not be an expert to notice this... you will see starved donkeys being beaten with thick wooden and metal rods... the ones that could not physically go on got the brunt of the abuse... the horses are generally well fed but again nowhere close to being treated well... the snakes do not have it any better either... sheep seemed to be the healthiest of the animals i came across... the dogs and countless cats all look sick and near death... riddled with parasites... it made my heart sink really! :( Most attractions leave a lot to be desired... poorly maintained and overly hyped up. No real entertainment in terms of theatre or spectacle.It is possible to have a good time, just be ready to spend a lot of money, stick to the top 5*L hotels and spas, sip cocktails, ignore the bills, hire luxury cars to take you past the city walls to Majorelle gardens, Ourika valley, the spectacular Ouzud falls and Richard Branson's gem of a hotel well outside of town and tucked away in the mountains (for €170 they will send a range rover to whisk you away). But then do you really want to spend that much and get so little? This is the most negative review i have ever written and i am sorry for that but i think it is important that you know this so you can be aware of what to expect; a relic of good days gone by but with some potential still there
Weeks, not days, needed to explore this amazing place. Don't miss the Artisan's sector - and don't stint on spending there! If nothing else, you will gain enormous respect for the final articles.

Fast moving and eclectic town square. Extremely colorful, lively town square that it really lights up at night. Careful of the women trying to draw with henna on your hands, I was grabbed and drawn as i was trying to politely say no thank you. They then asked for $20 USD. Also watch out when taking pictures of the snake handlers as they will ask for money if they see you. The harrira soup in the medina is very delicious and sustaining and just for a few dirham.
Mind blowing. Exhilarating experience need to be prepared to be hassled a lot. Use of animals e.g monkeys snakes etc exploitative. Little children selling stuff upsetting.

Medina and Souk. Fantastic for walk around and colourful pictures, there are few roof terrace resturants great to have lunch and view from the top afte a long walk. Did feel any harassment being a tourist, very safe and pleasant.
A journey within the journey. A incredible maze of little streets, millions of stands selling everything, colors, scents, music. The real experience.

A vibrant exotic place.. In the Marrakech Medina you see a lot of life, people go about their every day life as they have done for many years. Apart from the motor scooters their is no motorised traffic but plenty of donkey carts and hand carts making deliveries to the myriad of tiny shops selling every imaginable thing. In the main square there are snake charmers, performing monkeys and people doing dodgy card tricks and conjuring! It would have been nice to browse at leisure in any of the many shops but you only have to look half interested in something and they think you want to buy and then you have all sorts of things thrust at you that you do not want.

Walking in the Neighborhoods. We spent hours walking in the medina & different neighborhoods, getting lost, finding spice market, souks, speaking with the people. It's very safe & interesting to see that people really live here in the heart of Marrakech.
Aamazing. A simple must to do ....fantastic breathtaking architecture,magical place of great splendour ...one to be definitely visited

Has to be one for the bucket shop. Anything I say in this review would be hopelessly underplaying the experience. All I would say is go there twice - once during the day and another at night as there is such a change. Also I'd recommend taking a guide into the souks to show the various goods being traded. Just be aware that there will be a hard sell in at least 2 of the areas you visit. Just go there.

one of the world's most bussiest and thrilled market. wow!!!! this is the first world which would come out of your mouth when you reach at Medina.Medina is full with people ,people from all over world. especially in evening its wonderful ... music .... dance... shows.... jugglers .... all .the aroma of food street at night makes the place more attractive. The food and the way its served would certainly thrilled you.best place to buy the leather goods .The quality of leather is very fine .do bargain.

Vibrant, colourful, amazing!. Busy, vibrant, colourful and full of life! An experience not to be missed. A place like no other place Ive been to before. Smells, sights and sounds that will stay with you for ever.
Must See. It's the place of all the bargains. It can be intimidating at first. but if you keep things good natured don't be afraid to haggle.

AWESOME. Brilliant, mad, chaos of Marrakech. Busy and watch out for horses, cars and bikes! Stalls selling drinks, pots, clothes and the henna ladies. Restaurants around the outside brilliant for food and people watching. A must visit.

Go for it!. Although it can be so packed that you have no choice but to let the crowds take you away, there is nothing like it! Just let go and plunge in. You will always find your way back and the trip through the souks is not to be missed!

Ignore helpful passers-by!!!!. As stated previously the locals have a knack of acting as though there are just passing you and being friendly, asking where you are from and trying to lead you to the tanneries. Unfortunately you cannot believe what they say, a lot of the time they will point you in the wrong direction, Just do your own thing and firm that you don't need help. Worth seeing, lively, atmospheric

Has to be experienced!. Visit day and night to see the difference. I loved the hustle and bustle at night time with all the pop up restaurants touting for business. It was all good fun and we never felt pressurised by anyone. Excellent experience eating out in the Medina.

Sensory overload!. I loved getting lost here. As a woman traveling alone, I was not at all anxious being in an area that is full of people, donkey carts, motorbikes, and the like. The vendors were varied, and I enjoyed looking - I was not pressured to buy - requested, but not pressured.

Marrakech Medina. That is why you go there is the first place. Its easier to navigate then the medina in fez. Lots of people speak english so you can get directions. But don't engage freelance "Guides" who may lead you on a wild goose chase and then ask for 1000 Dinar.

The Square that's Everywhere!. This is the square that you see in every travel book and magazine advertising Marrakech and now I see why. It's breathtaking, overwhelming and quite hard to describe. The snake charmers, smells and sights are more than you can possibly prepare for. The highlight of every trip to Morocco. Go! Don't miss it!

A completely crazy mad sensory overload!. The old part of Marrakech (the Medina) is so full of character, and real characters too! There are people everywhere, rushing about through tiny crowded streets on scooters, donkeys, on foot, carrying huge loads, shouting and calling... There are colours and smells and amazing sights everywhere you look. It simply blew our minds for the first couple of days. Having said that, we got used to it remarkably quickly and generally felt very safe, though we were cautious and didn't carry rucksacks, expensive cameras etc. and always kept our hands on our phones and wallets. You need to be a bit canny and streetwise, and it certainly isn't for the faint hearted. You will undoubtedly get lost, and even the best map won't necessarily help you as road signs are few and far between, and you certainly don't want to get your map out in open view, or you will be assaulted by offers of "help" (payment always required). But if you get lost, keep going, look at the suns shadow, and you will eventually come to somewhere you recognise. My advice is; be firm and strong in resisting any offers, keep walking, accept you will be hassled if you stop and look around, accept that you are viewed as a walking cashpoint by all the traders and locals, be prepared to haggle hard, don't be intimidated, and definitely don't go on the back of anyone's scooter who might offer you a lift somewhere .... Sorry to be cynical but it's not genuine, they will ask for money. It's vibrant and thrilling, but after a few days, the constant hassle became quite wearing.... A long weekend will be enough! I'm still glad I went though :-)

Overload your senses with once in lifetime experience. Prepared to be overloaded with strange sights, sounds , and smells. For the less experienced traveler it can come across as a bit of a culture shock.The most important thing I can tell you is that you MUST wits about you around here. If you a woman you can expect to receive a lot of unwanted attention from men. I would not advise a woman to visit here alone. Try and stick to the main areas and try not to get lost in the maze of markets. And when inside the markets, brace yourself for aggressive sales techniques.When it comes to haggling, start from 25 % of the price they initially state and work your way up.

mind blowing. it mixes so well old and new, small narrow streets with beautiful houses turned into riads and wonderful patios, sellers of all types, gorgeous food, in general nice friendly people. The phrase was "democratic price".

Manic but amazing!. We loved walking round the medina - we didn't have a map, but we soon got the hang of it and we loved all the banter and bartering with the stall holders. Sometimes it felt a bit overwhelming and a bit too much, but then you can just walk away, no-one can force you to buy stuff! Our riad (Riad Africa) was very close to some busy alley ways with lots of shops and traders, and most of the time it was all very friendly and jovial, if you are friendly to them, they give the same back to you and also a better price on what you buy, if you are polite and friendly! They're just trying to make a living, after all! We did get some lovely souvenirs and bargains.

It is nice, but the vendors are very pushy. I think the Medina in Fes is much more friendly and comfortable and then one in Marrakech is much more touristy and the vendors are very aggressive in approaching you and demanding you visit their shops. It may not be comfortable for some people.

Nothing like it!. Fantastic experience. On the whole people are friendly and everyone is extremely helpful, directing you to the Big Square whether you want to go there or not :-) Make sure you barter, like seriously barter. You need to drop the price to a third and walk away. They will pretty much always shout after you, if not there will be another shop selling the same next door. Great fun and ideal for a weekend away.

Organized chaos!. Sounds, smells, sights, colors, jostling for space with pedestrians, bicycles, motor scooters. Watch out for the bikes; they come upon you without warning, dodging through the crowds at high speed, irrespective of how packed the alley might be.

An assault on the senses!. So much to see and do if you take the time to explore. We carried a map and walked for hours, stopping for only for food, drink and photo opportunities. The souks are incredible and easy to get lost in. The palaces and tombs quite something too. Be prepared to be expected to pay for directions though, we tended to work it out ourselves and calmly and politely refused offers of help. Most people were genuinely trying to help but we did find others didn't let go easily. We did find the constant sales pitches a bit tiring (though not so bad as we found Turkey a few years ago) but as long as you are polite they were too. We ate at one of the food stalls in the evening (a busy fish stall), calamari, chips and aubergine - very very cheap and delicious ! Please don't encourage the monkey and snake entertainment - a sorry sight to us these days, also the henna ladies can be very pushy. Having said all that we had some good days wandering round the medina.

The real Marrakech. The Medina is a mix of the old and the remodelled bustling new. The old part is traditional convenience shops, food places the locals frequents in narrow, winding streets, Some of it is not accessible by anything with more than 2 wheels.The new is everything you would expect of in terms of hotels, restaurants etc.
Souk visit. Could be interesting but hassel everywhere, not a place to go unguided"...........".................."......." Beware of the square at night..................
Other Worldly!. Only Three and 1/2 hours from the UK, visiting the Medina of Marrakech is a surreal experience and one not to be missed.
shopping. good fake stuff but whatever you do barter with the stall holder asnext dooris more likely the same and get it cheaper from him and be careful of the scooters coming up and down the lanes

So old and beautiful. A good place to stay and just walk about. Lots to see and everything is so old and genuine. The people are friendly but if someone comes up to you to help you with directions or be a guide, expect them to want to be paid handsomely!

good. Visited the souk and medina. All these places are the same. Sellers trying to sell you stuff. They say 50 you say 5 and you eventually agree to pay10. What I like is the funny comments they make about us english. Worth a visit. We didn't have a guide. But still found our way round

an endless labyrinth. an endless labyrinth of small ,very small and unbelievable small streets of the old city. a lot of shops , small factories, carpenters ,restaurants and everything that can be produces or sale . take a day to get lost there , do not afraid, the people very friendly and polite

Let yourself be in the moment... I simply enjoyed wander and soak up the smells and colors of this magical place.
Just let go and let yourself be in the moment...

great history and culture to see. walking in Medina is interesting but will be better with a tour guide. there are hundreds of old shops for antiques and food and there are cultural activities and dance in the evening time. there are plenty of beggars and it gets very crowded sometimes so better not to carry any valuable things. still a must see despite all.

the reason to go.... we stayed in the Madina area, the souks are great, but look for quality items and don't forget to barter, they love it. Always entertainment in the Square, day and night, not something to miss out on.

Full on and amazing! Not to be missed.. Incredible experience. The haggling is wearing but it can be avoided by using one of the Prix Fixe souks and, frankly, still amazingly cheap and a much more pleasant shopping experience!

Wonderful experience. If you want the most authentic experience, go on a weekend- it is packed and you get a real sense of the atmosphere. If big crowds aren't your thing go during the week. Don't be afraid to haggle for things!

Shopping. Best place to shop. Fabric, lanterns, carpets, leather goods, jewelry, you name it it's there. Bargain, bargain, bargain. Very interesting place. I could spend a whole day there. Easy to get lost though, so best to have a guide with you.

Colourful. Prepere ypu self for a fairytale moment! Charmig, noisy, extremet colourful, LOTs of pots and carpet for sale, for bargain prices, friendly salespersons and old arketecture. I took about 100 pictures of old Doors, one more nicer, the another! Wear comfortanles shoes, and, if you are a woken, cover your body, with long sleeves. Shorts is no no! If you are allergic to animals, be prepered, in the medina, it is a lot of them, horses, goats, donkeys, chocken, dogs, cats everywhere. Use cash, and shop a lot! The merchandise is so lovely, cheap, and you will regnet that you didn't buy more, when you are back from your trip.

BIG letdown!!!. I visited the Medina with my Husband and Granddaughter in Nov. 2014. It was reasonably quiet at the time we were there, so I was thankful of that. My Husband certainly enjoyed the snake charmers, but unfortunately my Granddaughter and I couldn't wait to leave. I felt it was just one big dirty square with very little of interest. We did go inside and bought a few niknaks, but this was made very uncomfortable with the Moroccans trying to get your custom. I completely understand they have to make a living, but I felt uneasy with the whole process.
Must take time.. People, animals, street life. Traditions. Take time and let it all seep in. Keep your valuables safe and let yourself hang out.

A great experience and adventure... for the first couple days. It is one of the most interesting places I have been yet. A completely new World than what I am used to. Then you get comfortable with it. And finally, you get frustrated with it and want to stay in your Riad. Then you get to a point where you want to go out just to spite people and start to walk with a swagger like you are part of the Medina. At that point you seem to like the place again.It is very tricky to get around. It will really test your navigational abilities. But getting lost will allow you to see something new and interesting. You will be constantly harassed to buy or eat things. Most things to see are in the Medina so you can't avoid going in. Be ready to negotiate or spend way too much on things. It can be fun. Don't take things personally when they sometimes say offensive things during negotiation. It is a game and if you get offended, you will lose. If you don't like bargaining, think of it as a game. Take your feelings out of it. Just a suggestion.After a few days staying in a Riad within the Medina, you start to despise the Medina and certain people inside it. After being told 'This road is closed, it is a dead end, where are you going? I can help you' a hundred times from punk kids knowing very well it is not a dead end and that your Riad is just a couple blocks down that road, you start to despise the young adults of the Medina. Despise them for trying to scam you into going to the tanneries or offering 'help' and then demand 200 dh (about 20 Euros). Despise them for driving obnoxiously fast down narrow roads almost striking old ladies in their stinky, loud, and environmentally very unfriendly motorcycles. Despise them for swearing at you for not following them into their shop or to the tanneries. You will easily despise the young ones, but find a lot of respect for the older generations.So go there, for sure, but limit the time there if you are introverted.

The heart of old Marrakech. There is much to see so it's well worth planning your visit in advance. The Eye Witness Top 10 guide book is highly recommended. Prepare to do a lot of walking and, don't worry, getting lost initially is inevitable but you soon get used to finding your way around!

marvellous medina. The mediana was everything I expected and more. You have to expect to be constantly approached but courtesy doesn't cost a penny. I loved the vibrancy and excitement. I visited the artisan centre first so that I would know how much to offer in the shocks.

Mayhem!. It was just as we expected it.Noisy,dusty and charming in its own way.The sellers had all the patter off such as "English?Fish and Chips"and Asda price.We saw snake charmers but could only take photos if we paid them. Fair enough I suppose. Also Old Ladies trying to Henna tattoo us...

The adventure awaits. The medina of Marrakesh is full of adventure, wonders, magic, culture, people, lifestyle. It is full of things that can change your perspective of the world, of your culture and lifestyle and maybe even how you think of things. It is a place of warm, generous people, and raw scenes of societies poor. It is a place where people live and work, it is a place where tourists explore, it is a place where the disenfranchised go to do what they have to to survive. I love the medina. I love the adventure. I visit to experience a different lifestyle and culture. I totarate the uncomfortable and celebrate the beautiful, the exotic, the magical. I give the medina a top rating for the level of adventure and emotional feelings it will elicit.

A nightmare. The best recommendation we were given before our visit to Marrakech was to employ a guide to show you around the Medina, and we ignored it. Don't!!It is a rabbit warren as one souk merges into the next, and it is easy to become disorientated. Plenty of folk will tell you which way to go, but their main objective is to lead you to an outlet where they hope to earn some commission and then demand a payment from you for doing so.Signage exists, and is pretty accurate you just have to recognise it as it is usually placed well above your eye-line.Stallholders will pester you if you merely stop to browse. This does not happen if you are with a guide.A great experience, but it can get a little wearing.

Pure Magic!. It's the old part of the city and takes you into another world of bazars and tradition! We definitely enjoyed the day in this part and experienced a lot of different things in terms of the Morrocan culture and their origins. We had a great time!

Frenetic, interesting but not for everyone. Found it a little disappointing and surrounding areas a little 'tired'. I know it is part of the 'vibe' when visiting Marrakech but wouldn't rush back to that spot.....

Bonkers!!. This place is amazing!! The snake charmers, the blacksmiths quarter, the silk merchants quarter, the tanneries, the mad people zooming through the narrow streets on mopeds. It's a constant stream of things to see.Have a good haggle & bag some great bargains. Be firm but fair & be sure to visit the spice merchants square for some fresh ginseng tea, which will hit you like a dozen Red Bull!!!Don't worry if you get lost, as we did many times, for a pound or two any local will guide you back to the main square. Then you can dive down another side street & get lost all over again.
A must of the world stood still. The scents, the sounds, the feeling of walking through the Medina or just sitting down and people watching is a very fulfilling experience.

A day in Marrakech..... With only a few days in Morocco, viator certainly took the stress away of seeking out the Medina's secrets. The full 9 hour discovery tour took us through the historical maze of culture, stunning architecture and fabulous smells of fresh bread, argon and jasmine - not to mention the tanneries, metal works and fast paced moped gangs racing through the narrow alleys keeping us on the edge at times. The 3 course meal included in the price, gave us 2 hours calm away from the bustle on a secluded roof-top restaurant. The final talk at the berber pharmacy gave us a chance to buy products of guaranteed quality and finished with drinks overlooking the main square at dusk. Thanks to Jamal and Aziz for their fantastic knowledge and insight which made this tour one of the highlights.

Scary at first!. We rented a small road in the Bab Doukkal district of the Medina, and were worried about getting lost in the labyrinthine streets. But once we got our bearings and memorised the route back, we loved it. The people are friendly, and say good morning once they've seen you a couple of times. A fantastic place to stay!
Wonderful Medina (my fave in Morocco). It is confusing, just like a Medina should be. It has hustlers just like all Medinas do. There is negotiation, just like a Medina should have.

Vibrant, cultural....amazing. We visited Marrakech with trepidation after reading various reviews, however all our concerns were alleviated after we arrived. We were transported to our Riad (Le Rihani) via prior arrangement, which all ran smoothly.When we first went out and about and visited the main square and the souks it was all quite manic with people everywhere. There were pushbikes, mopeds, donkeys, carts and even cars coming at you from all angles down very narrow walkways and in the square for which needed to have our wits about us, however we very quickly got used to this. The locals would constantly ask you to look in their shops but we did not find them aggressive and they generally left you alone if you politely said no. You definitely need to barter over prices. The main square changes throughout the day. The mornings were calm, with the locals setting up their stalls. It got busier throughout the day then in the evening the atmosphere became electric and very busy. The food stalls would be set up with seating and many types of cuisine was available.During the daytime you will see the snake charmers, monkeys and performers. If you don’t approach them they will leave you alone, however be careful when taking photographs as they will ask you for money. Keep at a distance and use your zoom!!We also walked around the Jewish Quarter and the Kasbah, which was also very busy and interesting, so there is more than just the main square to see.Be careful when walking around the souks if you are approached and asked to visit the Tannery. We know of friends who have then been and were aggressively asked afterwards for money for being guided to the venue.There are plenty of trips out of Marrakech and I would recommend ‘Dunes and Deserts Exploration’ as a company. We pre-booked a day out on quad bikes and it was awesome.Marrakech is perfect for a short trip where you will experience the culture and vibrant way of life. We loved it.

Chaotic exciting madness. A different world from western culture, but very "buzzy" and authentic. The locals are polite and friendly going about their business and you don't feel threatened.Some locals try and help with directions out of sheer niceness and others are looking for a tip.Beware your map which makes navigating look simple, what look like major roads can be just that but are often tiny covered and uncovered alleyways.

An original place full of colors. The medina od Marrakesh is very interesting place, full of shops, people, colors. At the beginning it can seem a little bit overwhelming, but as soon as you get used to it, you love it. And you can have a great time haggling for everything. A great experience!

Just go for the experience. There is nowhere like it in the world to experience the madness and all the comings and goings . people trying to make a living !!! It must be very difficult . We didnt have any problems . Its dirty, dusty and with bikes, motorbikes, donkey carts etc but this is North Africa . Just take in the sights and sounds and enjoy. Avoid the spice shops as you can end up spending a lot on things you dont need which of course i did this time !!!
A great buzz. Not for the feint hearted. Be prepared to part with your money unless you are good at haggling. They are the pros and the tourists are the amateurs !!!
A revelation. So clean and so buzzy, so much to see and do in such a small area, with amazing gardens, architecture eating and shopping it caters for everyone

amazing shops everywhere. The medina is full of life. Shops of all sorts and bargaining is a must. People are extremely helpful and there is a lot of knock off products of very good quality. They get offended if you ask them if it is made in China. Highly recommend it

Like a war zone filled with hustlers. We had absolutely no expectations going in, and were still disappointed in the Medina experience. It's filthy, hectic, filled with aggressive shop-keepers hawking cheap tourist trinkets, lunatics on mopeds, run-down houses, human feces, and amateur "guides" insisting on showing you the tourist "attractions" for a tip.After a while we stopped making eye-contact, and for the rest of our vacation we skirted around the Medina rather than walking through it. See Jemaa el Fnaa in the evening, but avoid the rest like the plague.

Ok experience. I am not a shopper, and I really get annoyed with people pressuring me to buy stuff. So it was interesting just to walk thru and see everything. One thing that was a big turn off was that everyone charges for you to take a photo. So bring plenty of coins if you want to take pictures. Also be prepared to bargain. Everything is marked up 75-80%, so start out crazy low and work your way up to the 75% off the original price. An interesting experience for anyone, but hardcore shoppers will probably love it.

Swimming with Sharks. The greatest single reason for not enjoying our holiday. The constant pestering. The stream of offers to lead you in the wrong direction or the longest way so that they can demand more payment. The constant insistence that you are going in the wrong direction or that the way is closed one one reason or another. Their welcome and politeness goes out of the window when you fail to buy their services of buy from them. The more polite you try to be the more insistent they are.

Bring lots of Duham to buy from the artisans~!. This is a shoppers paradise for leather, pottery, silver, wood, fabric...you name it. Easier to get around due to the lack of donkeys in the ailes but look out for the scooters. Walk to the right and keep an ear open for motorized scooters who buz by you at a good clip. There is a few really fun resturants and Riads to visit within the Mediana and I highly recommend a checking them out...

A day in Marrakech. Booked break through Audley Travel. Their local agents were Travel Link who provided the driver and guide for a day trip to historical sites and the souks.Visiting the carpet factory seriously dents your wallet!We walked almost everywhere but the guide's knowledge made the day effortless.

Shop and bargin. Love this medina, always have. Be prepared to bargin hard, walk off all that stuff. Go in get lost and ignore the offers of a guide, you don't need one! Came away with some gorgeous stuff, but I had a plan, which might be wise

Dreaming town. One of the most exclusive place, it' s an open window full of colours, fragrances, unique place to visit! Even if you feel a little bit uncomfortable because people try to sell you whatever, there s a magic feeling really smelling the culture of Marrakech. It s really chic!!!!!
A total must. Amazing experience not to be hurried shop a little and then stop for a rest and a drink in the spice market and just watch the world go by!

felt intimidated. The Medina was dirty with snake charmers, henna artists and other attractions. We felt intimidated as quite often stopped and pestered. My husband took a photograph of the horse and carriages one of the touts became quite nasty.

Starwars writ large !!!!!!!. This was my first visit to the medina - and phew - it will blow your corporate socks off. Where does one begin - it is not in the western urban psyche at all - at one level it is chaos - deprivation extreme poverty - medieval living - star wars !!!!!! - at another level it just challenges all our concepts of order, economy, structure and society - You have to experience it and answer your own questions - but it works - how it works - i don't know !!!!!! and its relatively hassle free, you will get asked but if you are firm they back off really quickly - one of life's great tapestry experiences!!!!!!!!!!
Awesome!. Unbelievably terrific, you must get to experience this once in your lifetime. So much fun, enjoyment - the sights, the smells, the people.mabsolutely remarkable!
medina. inside the walls alsorts of people could make anything you could imagine by hand the craftsmanship was a treat to watch

Lively, vibrant, oriental Atmosphere. The stroll through the Medina of Marrakech is an exorbitant experience, inlike anything else. Once you got in be prepaired that EVERYONE - actually almost every person you meet try to sell or at least show you something......You better prepare for it and do not hestitate to say NO ! Unless you want to buy something, then really hard negotiate is announced. It´s fun, people love it and compete with you.

Chaotic and exciting. So much to see - our preference was to take a guide rather than miss anything or get lost and waste time. Be ready for the bartering - offer a fifth and come up to a third was some advice we were offered.

Chaos With A Character, Madness Of Marrakech Medina. You may be one of the few who may fall into the trap of thinking that the Medina of Marrakech is a bit hyped. After all it's a very crowded market place with a lot of noise, people selling all sorts of things under the sun. Think before you commit to this assumption by asking yourself that how many of such chaos you would have seen in the world which come with a character? Having travelled extensively all over India and being raised in crowded countries like Bangladesh, I am no stranger to crowd and chaos. What is unique and appealing about the Medina of Marrakech was the fact that it is chaos with a character where even the cacophony had a certain charm, not found or experienced by me anywhere else in the world. Protected by the old city walls, the Medina of Marrakech was declared a UNESCO heritage site. When we drove near the Medina to look for a parking space, the frantic commotions of the parking attendants and volunteers set the tone very well of what to expect later. Haggling was the first hint, starting with the cost of parking per hour. We made our way walking slowly along with the stream of people who were happily taking part in the joyful buzz of the surroundings. We were warmed up by curious onlookers, beggars, bemused tourists and locals when we arrived at the famous Jemaa al Fena, the coveted main square of the Medina where it all happens. You will see a handful of orange juice stalls and it is certainly a good idea to fill your tank with some fresh Moroccan orange juice before you set off to negotiate with the teeming crowd everywhere. The first rule of exploring the Medina is to make sure you have the main square in your mind map. The second rule is that you need to be comfortable with the fact that you will get lost and it is perfectly fine. So have plenty of time in your hand. The final rule is that you have to return to main square before sunset and place yourself at one of the many restaurants with a view to enjoy the sunset while you sip some mint tea. That is it; mind these three rules and you will be mad about the Medina. While we wandered around the serpentine narrow alleys of the Medina (Souks as they call it) we saw items and artefacts of Moroccan tradition ranging from shoes, clothes, lights, spices, olives to stuffed and even live animals for sale. Here is a good activity you can engage yourself into if you really want to keep yourself busy. Start taking count of the unique items and objects you will encounter during your stroll through the Medina from one Souk to another. When you are back at your riad or hotel, count the numbers. This is exactly what will give you an idea of what is available in Morocco and what is traded. What is traded is what gets consumed and what gets consumed makes the customers - the Moroccans who live in this enthralling country making the very fabric of the society and tradition they keep alive. It is taken for granted that you will end up in the Jemaa al Fena square at some point of your discovery of the souks. We can recommend securing a good seat on the second floor of the Cafe France restaurant just before sunset. Order yourself some mint tea and settle yourself while the sun will set behind the proud minarets of the Koutoubia Mosque, splashing a ravishing tone of orange in the western sky. While you enjoy the beautiful silhouette of the minaret against the sleeping sun, you will get to hear the increasing bustle from the Medina beneath you. Makeshift restaurants will install themselves cooking Moroccan delicacies on the spot, the aroma of which will be too hard to deny even for the staunch hardliners who avoid street food due to hygiene. You will want to mingle with the amazing characters who bring to life and loudness the whole place every day, year after year. Snake charmers, monkey players, henna artists, musicians, magicians: to name a few all in one place. Is this an amusement park? Is this a circus? You may ask yourself. This is the Medina madness with the chaos with a character is what you will realise only when you will retreat to the tranquillity of your Riad, when the gentle sound of flowing water from the fountain will pacify your mind, once the anti-climax of the loud chaos will be offset with the calm of the night, you will enlighten yourself only at that moment why is it so vibrant and full of sound, color and smell in the Medina. The reason is that the Medina of Marrakech is the lifeline of this city which narrates the story of the city every day to tourists and locals alike. It is the story teller with a character. Other places in the world may only have chaos, but no story to tell, thus no character. Only Marrakech, only Medina. More of our experience can be found at www.onetimefashionista.com
Senses Overload. A fantastic place full of life wonderful people, interesting architecture, shops and workshops. Be prepared to haggle, it is expected and part of the fun.

Safe and easy to navigate. We wandered around without ever feeling that an alley or passageway was unsafe. the market traders were friendly and not at all aggresive, (unlike some of the other Nother Africa souks that I jave visited)).
This is why you go to Marrakech. Frenetic and colorful, you will be in sensory overload in the souks. Lots of bartering, but undoubtedly great buys to be had.

not a friendly place. Compared to other medinas we visited this past month Marrakesh has the most pushy and aggressive shopkeepers. It also has the least friendly and welcoming people. Many men got nasty and angry when we tried to take pictures of the medina area - even if they were not the object of the image! I to sick of being called Ali Baba by just about every shopkeeper, tout and wannabe guide around. If you like pollution and pushy people have at it...

Eye catching. Never a dull moment in this sea of human prosperity. The shop owners have selling down to a T, they are friendly and use to be ihonored without insult. I found a few life time moments I won't ever forget here and took no pictures for Facebook, it's all in my mind only lol
Sean T

Nowhere else on earth....... The Medina is a must experience with all its chaos, smoke, dust, petrol fumes, motor bikes, donkeys and haggling. Put on a sturdy pair of shoes and be prepared to duck and dive as people try to get you into their shop or stall, take you to the tannery or a market stall. It is an interesting juxtaposition of opulence and poverty. Don't listen when someone tells you that a road is closed and try and direct you somewhere else. Also be wary of people coming up to you and asking if you remember them from the Riad. Try and plan your route and don't look too lost. The banter on the whole is friendly and harmless and the atmosphere is unique

What an experience. What a fantastic mix of sights, sounds snd smells.There is probably something here for all tastes. Some parts are like stepping back in time: barber shops where you can get a shave, the typing service complete with carbon paper, little shops that sell everything. The vibrant colours, the friendly faces and amazing smells make this a must visit place. However, go with an open mind and a willingness to engage in a culture that is different from your own. Tgen you'll have the time of yout life.

NEVER pay full price. You can get lost in this place for days!. I think my BF and I finally felt like we saw all of it after 3 days of wandering. It also helps to stay in a riad within the medina (I highly recommend Riad Nashira!!) so that getting there is easy. Plus the riads will always have very clear directions for to and from their location and at Riad Nashira, they had someone walk us to the medina. Once there, it can be stimulation overload. If you see animals (turtles, chameleons, etc) they are props to get you closer to the store so you will buy something. I didn't mind it since at one of the stores, I got to play with a chameleon for over 10 minutes. The trade off was that I had to buy something but since I was already in the market for some spices, it was a win win for me. They packaged up by lavender, saffron, tea and rose oil while I enjoyed the company of my little friend. So advise: don't play with the animals unless you are interested in buying something. If its just some guy walking around with an animal, be prepared to give him money for a photo or to pet it. Also never pay full price for anything. You will find 100 stall selling the same exact things. You should go in to every purchase with an amount you are willing to part with for the item you want. Tell them your price and then walk away. >90% of the time, they will chase you down (walk slowly away) with the item you wanted packaged, agreeing to your price. They will always ask you for a price that is also fair for them but keep in mind, their price is not in any way fair for us. I have noted the price they give locals and the price they give us. Even my lowest offers were more than what the locals paid so just keep that in mind. This Medina though is one of the most memorable places you will ever visit. Take your time and really enjoy it. Eat the street meat like the locals. Drink tea out of the glass cups like the locals. You won't regret it

Explore Marrakech. We had a guided tour of the historical quarter, the souks, and the main square. We then did some bargaining in the souk and found the shopkeepers very friendly and not at all pushy. However in the main square, Jemaa el Fna, the Senegalise touts where very persistant, and difficult to get rid off. Still a worthwile experience.
You can't miss this area. This will soon disappear with modern shopping centers, bigger airport and more westerners.Very chaotic and energetic atmosphere. Fun shopping and bargaining.
Shopping.. We went there in day,all ok,some beggars.We brought all we wanted.Had a lovely lunch on a roof terrace.Very reasonable.

Buyer beware!. We have just returned from a long visit to Morocco. While we found a certain amount of insistent selling everywhere nothing equaled Marrakesh for dishonest practices. As has been said taxis were notoriously dishonest. Our hotel told us that they would not turn the meter on for foreigners, they offered to negotiate fares for us. They were still far more than they should have been. We learned the hard way to give them the money before we started to avoid the argument at the end. We were accosted regularly outside our hotel by guides claiming to be from the hotel. " you don't remember me? I work at----"! Finally my husband whipped out his iPhone to take a picture. The guides evaporated. It was too bad to resort to unpleasant measures but la shukaran did not usually work. I ended up doing some shopping at the Ville Nouvelle boutiques after finding the souks too difficult as one could not stop and look or discuss anything without hassle. Moroccan acquaintances said it was difficult for them as well, but as sympathetic as they were, it did not leave me with a very positive memory of my Marrakesh experience. Fes is equally interesting and calmer!

Amazing sights!. We went to the medina a couple of times during our stay in Marrakech in February.It is amazing,breathtaking & mad-all at the same time!!There is a lot to see-many places to eat & it has a very vibrant atmosphere!Be warned though-you will be pestered to buy should you stop to look in the souks-but the banter is very inoffensive! Bartering is expected and fun-but can be exhausting! Stick to your price if you want something-but be fair and respectful-after all they are only trying to make a living!The scarves are beautiful in many sizes and shades & there is some very good value leather goods on sale, along with some colourful & unusual items of jewellery.There are acrobats, snake charmers and Henna tatooists in the main square and also many stalls selling soft drinks, snacks and refreshments.Be warned if you eat in one of the restaurants overlooking the medina you will be charged a lot more to eat there-simply for the view,but you can get the real feel by sitting on one of the benches in the centre & eating with the locals-having the food prepared in front of you for a real Moroccan experience-this is what we thought was the better experience.A great experience we will be repeating in the future!

Lose yourself along the Medina. The best recommendation I can give is to get lost along the alleys of the Medina, it is definetly the best way to do tourism in Morocco. People are normally pretty nice and always willing to help, just keep in mind that if the walk you to the place they will ask for a tip (sometimes if worthy).

Hectic, chaotic, noisy & unforgettable.. The constant noise level, contrasting smells and general hustle & bustle is a shock to the system, even for a Londoner, but an experience not to be missed. Be polite & respectful when refusing offers of help/guidance (even on the 99th occasion that day!), walk around the souks (where you will almost certainly get lost), and do try to eat at least once at the open air food stalls in the main square in the evening - it's fresh and cheap!

Hectic. Interesting,we had a few walks around,prepare to get lost,don't bother asking for directions,they all try to send you to the Tannery,and if you decide to go a different way,that road,they'll say,is closed.Ignore them all and just wander around till you've had enough.Ask a shop keeper for directions when you want to head back to the square.Watch out for the,donkeys and carts,bikes and worst of all the mopeds.

Just brilliant. The medina lived up to all our expectations. The shop keepers will try to get you into their shops. It's only natural they are trying to sell things. Don't take their pushiness as harmful a smile and a maybe later does the trick then just move on It's all part of the experience.

Just like the movie Aladin. We used a great app to navigate the Medina. The app does not need wifi or data plan which was great. I wish I could tell you what app it was, but my phone got stolen right out of my hand while looking at the map. The thief jump into the back of a motorcycle and away he went into the little streets. Hope who ever has it is enjoying it. Be aware of your surroundings and enjoy the Medina. The monkeys, the snakes, the funny shoes and specially the mint tea.
Souk. Grand for a walkabout and haggling with traders - some good value but don't engage if you're not interested in buying.
must stay in the medina. yiu must stay in the medina if you wish to experience real life not the western hotels outside the walls

BEWARE THE TANNERY. We found the tannery and it stinks which is fine but as soon as you enter a man gives you some mint to sniff and says follow me and I will take your pictures of you all, then he leads you through you actually do not need to be lead through, and then into the one shop that sells leather goods, we were four adults and the other couple bought a pair of mens slippers he paid three times the value (350) and we said no thank you the man was shouting in my face saying why you not buy, you buy they are good slippers, BE WARNED he was aggressive and we felt threatened as there is only a few men standing around and not many people about. My advice would be DO NOT GO INTO THE SHOP:

Hustle and bustle. we stayed in the centre of the Medina and thought we would never find our way , but it only took a day to get to know it . We loved it and the people who are so very gentle and friendly.

Amazing Bazaars. Advise - tour guides take you to certain areas to buy goods I guess this is how they make more money. Worth looking around the different Souks, but be prepared to haggle - personally not very good at it!

Crazy but great handbags. This is crazy with mopeds whizzing past, donkeys pulling carts and people begging. However, there are some axing goods. Haggle hard and walk away for a good deal. I got 5 beautiful leather bags for 54 pound.
Vibrant. Enjoyed the medina and all the alleys and bazaars.Loved the haggling over prices.I just had a price in mind and would walk away and they would call back and sell.Great bargains

fantasic day out. if you go to the medina get ready to haggle its good fun and expected but you should only ever pay a third of the starting price ,the cafes and resteraunts serve fantastic foods in the square at both day and night ane its very cheap as well

A wonderful place which we were told "was closed". We were staying in a Riad in the north of the medina away from the centre and the souks. We explored as many streets and alley ways to take in the true life of the Medina, other than the souks and the main square. A strange experience, on a regular basis, was that we were told that it was closed as we headed in certain directions. This is clearly a ploy to get tourists heading into the souks and towards the main square. We did venture into the area of the tanneries which was a real treat, although I would advise doing this with a guide or be willing to pay a small amount to a local who will say he is not a guide but will look for payment after taking you into the works. But it is a true experience for a number of the senses, not least smell. Apart from the misdirections we never felt threaten or uncomfortable. Part of the enjoy,net of the Medina is getting lost on more than one occasions. A truly wonderful time.
Easy to get lost. Easy to get lost with all the alleyways. If you ask anyone for directions....prepare to pay. They won't help you for free.

Winding lanes filled with many treasures.. Spend hours wandering the old souks. Stop and chat with the vendors who are very friendly when you take the time to give them the time of day. Yes, some sellers may be a bit aggressive but they are just trying to make a living, and bargaining is a game, so play along and you will have a wonderful time and go home with some beautiful Morrocan products.
Was interesting. We walked all around the Medina, even the very poor parts where people live... Embrace the culture.. So interesting.. We think we work hard for low pay.. ,!,

Hustle and Bustle!!. The medina in Marrakech is a really interesting place! With so many different things to see and some amazing architecture, colours, smells, people - and donkeys!! We went as two females (me being 23 and blonde) and didn't use a guide, the best tip we got was only use left or rights when navigating your way round the souks, that way you can easily find your way back.  Most of the time we felt safe, although we quickly learnt to not listen to some locals (unless you ask a shop keeper and spend time looking in their shops). Numerous times people will approach you and try to Direct you (often the wrong way if you refuse the help). We also learnt not to tell people where you are heading if they ask, we got told things were closed when they weren't, in exchange for 'showing us a way back' - this guy later on got chased by the police and we were told he was not helping us and directed correctly by the police (to the museum which was open). There is little red or green squares high up I the side of buildings telling you the directions. - USE THESE! They may take you a long way round but you get to see plenty!Another tip of mine would be use an app such as mapmywalk - it's amazing to see how far you walk and although it can get confused with all the little alleys- it can help you get your barrings slightly! The lovely thing about the place is there is still locals everywhere and they are living their daily lives. Also, if you are not confident in haggling the 'ensemble artisanal' is a great little centre with lots of shops with fixed prices. It's also a good way to guide you before your haggling! Relax- but not too trusting and you'll have a wonderful time!

Always love a good medina. What;s not to like? TThere are actually signs in the medina now so you can always find your way back to the main square. Remember to bargain for everything and start with a quarter of the price!

Busy, cosy, smelly, intimate. Visiting the Medina is an attack on all your senses. Spices, meat, leather, fish, people and lots of motors. It's nice to get lost, especially in the parts that are not so touristic. Just wander around, ask for a price now and then and be patiënt on bargaining.
Full on experience. 1001 Nights meets Ali Baba and the forty thieves. This is a full on sensory experience - not to be missed!
Huge. The Medina is the old town surrounded by 80km of wall, and is beautiful in history, sights, smells, bargains, and people.

Too much for me. Nice places. You have to be aware because shop owners will do anything to sell you sth 10x the price.
Do not buy anything unless you are alone without a guide

Side roads and alleyways. Several visits here and we still can't get enough of the place. A little daunting to start for some but not so big that you won't eventually find yourself standing somewhere familiar and worse case scenario is that someone will lead you to where you want to go for a small fee.Most of the major Marrakech tourist attractions can be found within the medina walls along with numerous restaurants and small hotels. Guides (both official and not so) are available at all attractions, again for a fee. They will also try to take you round the souks but if you go with a guide be prepared for long visits to local pharmacies and workers co-operatives. We did this on our first visit but now prefer to wander round on our own; we enjoy the banter with the shop owners and just say no and walk away when we're not interested. Marrakech has a wide range of multiple starred hotels but we would always opt for a small Riad in the medina.

It's all about the money. Our lovely Riad was right in the Medina, close to a vegetable and spice market. Thus we saw a lot of the medina wherever we wanted to go.One could perhaps say it's amazing to see and experience it, and I'd probably say it's worth to experience this at least one time in your life.The medina consists of many small streets: Where the buildings end, the streets begin immediately and this space is shared by whatever shopkeepers put out in front of their shops, by motorbikes, by bicycles, by pedestrians, by carts pulled/pushed by donkeys, motorbikes or people. We never felt comfortable walking hand in hand, in stead we filed behind each other just watching out for the traffic. We only saw one motorbike crash into a bicycle in the 4 days we were there! Along with the pollution, it wasn't all that pleasant to walk around there.Even if you just look ahead of you, shopkeepers still try to grab your attention. If you show even the slightest interest some of the many crafty goods that are sold, a hassle about the price begins. If you really do want to buy something, you can get the price down a bit and to really get it lower just walk away, at which time a price might be shouted after you. Sometimes we were offered this "democratic" price - still don't know what this term is supposed to mean! However, all this non-stop hassling is rather tiring and it's impossible to just admire the goods on display. Perhaps if they didn't try so hard, we would buy more and at least have enjoyed it more.We were pursuaded into going with a guide to see some of the tanneries. He didn't tell us that he'll charge us 200dh for it, so I gave him 50dh afterwards, which made him show his sad face, as many of them do. We were also taken to a shop and sat down with a cup of tea and being displayed carpets to buy: The one we liked started at 6800dh and we bought it for 1650dh. Watch out for unstable dyes in the carpets - we effectively ruined ours when we got home by getting it wet. I'm not really sure the prices are that good and it seems really easy to get ripped off completely.There are some cash machine in the main square but not really anywhere else we could find.Several times, someone would point us in the opposite direction where we wanted to go, simply shouting that the square is the other way, or that it's closed this way. Don't listen to this dishonest advise. Rather, cache the maps on your smartphone and use your GPS to navigate yourself to where you want to go, or get lost for a while and then navigate yourself back.Our desire to go back to the medina is rather little, but I reckon we're glad we had the experience.

crazy shopping. full of hustle and bustle but be ready to haggle, and many a bargain will be gained. but dont be taken in by the first place you see, look around the more into the medina the more haggling power .
