Utter chaos - and delightfully so. A challenge for the control freak as EVERYONE gets lost here. That is precisely the charm. Would that the young boys trying to earn a bob or two as guides out of the maze were a little more up front about doing so. They are spoiling their own market.

Amazing but confusing. This is an amazing place with wonderful shops and work places so you can see how some of the products are made. It's very confusing and somewhat dangerous with motorcycles and carts coming through the very narrow streets - I would recommend taking a reputable guide, someone who can help you shop if you want to do that as pricing is very flexible from one end to another.
Medina. Another world, felt quite safe once we got our bearings. Did not like being pestered by unofficial guides but once we got used to that it was ok. A real eye opener.

Weekend away. Fabulous, eclectic, manic weekend, would recommend to anyone, not sure about the sanitation and probably would not recommend for young children, but wonderful place, great food, such a great experience
Nice people and beutiful handmanscraft. Take a guide so you ca get to the foundouks to visit the little factorys and beautiful pieces they make.
Large medina. It's a very large open spaced medina, but you walk around it in a easy way. Very hot in the summer and very busy especially at night.

Worth a visit, but be prepared to be lost!. It is really entertaining to walk round and not know what to expect next. It is really well lit at night and feels very safe. You will just be walking around and suddenly see unexpected architectural styles e.g. doors etc. But even with a map, you WILL get lost!

Crazy. It's ally busy, packed full of everything you could ever want to buy, full of men trying to get your attention to buy, great smells, noises etc. it's a real experience and if you go with the flow and stick to your guns spending wise, you'll have a good time.

fascinating. wherever you go, there are charming corners, even in the less touristic areas, so many important monuments but also just simply looking at the architecture of houses and their colors, checking the little artisans shops, etc ...
The Medina. You must get a tour guide when going around the Medina. Watch your bags. Very interesting culture. Try and experience the medina at day and night as it changes quite a lot.

All you need you can get here - this place is a MUST. This is a must if you are visiting Marrakesh. There will be a lot of hassle from people wanting to sell something to you. Do not buy any Argan oil at a cheap price - you may end up with normal olive oil. The Argan cosmetics will be ok and quite cheap too. I am always purchasing all kinds of spices. You have real good value for your money. If you like olives they are only 25% of the prices in Germany and the quality is much better. Be careful to take any picture from people - you might be asked to pay for it.

1001 Nights!. Colours, fragrance, exotic ambience, like wandering from one page of the 1001 Nights Fairy Tales to another page. The chaos, to some disturbing while to me fascinating and captivating. The sellers are always trying, yet in a gracious and respectful way compared to many other Countries I have been. Extremely friendly and helpful people. Dare to take the first step forward, relax and open up ....... a whole new exotic and beautiful world awaits you in the medina. I love Marrakech, Moroccon People and the Berber Culture that many prowdly retain. Moroccon People are extremely friendly and kind. But this does not mean that you should leave your antenas and brains behind.I would not recommend you to take out Money from the ATM vending Machines at Djema el Fna. Your card might end up being copied or fished.

An exciting place. We were unsure what to expect but loved the atmosphere and even managed to dodge all the photo opportunities that you have to pay for and also the henna tattooists - just walk away.

Must see. The markets place souks and medina are a must see. Visiting marakech and not going would be a shame. Be prepared though. We found night time a lot more exciting amf got less hassle from people trying to sell things. Watch out for the hennah ladies who just grab your hand and then demand payment. Learning local language to show appreciation goes a long way as does the app...hipmarakech..this ap works of gps so is free and a downloaded map. We got it from hennah cafe on last day and wish we had it before..

Avoid the snakes and monkeys. A remarkable contrast of noise and smell as the old town market offers up its 'tourist tat' to travellers. It is exactly what you expect and is entertaining with a number of busy Souks straight of of the square. Don't be tempted to take pictures of any particular stall or the snake and monkey men, they will immediately harass you for money.

Daunting !!. The medina can be very overwhelming as so many traders are trying to get your attention and are very persuasive, we had 2 handbags by the time we left!!, altough the people are very friendly and willing to help. We did not go out in this area at night as my wife found it quite scary, but it really is well worth a visit.

Plenty of Pap. A huge place but shops selling more or less the same things - Food is a no no as the flies have first pick as nothing seems to be covered and whilst the Bread items look nice the flies have first dibs on them and the locals seem oblivious to them unlike us Northern Europeans with higher hygene standards - also the cakes and sweet items too have the wasps on them in their droves ,The livestock too is kept in deplorable conditions with chickens herded in small pens which are overcrowded and even see them sitting outside with their wings broken and legs tied together and as for eggs which are sold in the thousands are left in the sun to cook away prior to being bought .Also you are offered a guide for cash to get you out as due to the size of it you can easily get lost as the locals take away the signs put in by the Tourist board and invite you to go down this lane or that one but unless you know where they are taking you to do not go with them as they have been known to set you up for a mugging - never felt safe when in the Medina and used the Police we saw there to get us out safely .Nothing worth buying in my opinion as its all barter and there is only one winner and its not you

Visiting Medina. Loved to Hussle & Bussle , lots of things to see and people watch, the weather was not on our side but did not stop us from walking around, looking at snake charmers, shopping and bartering for my new briefcase. I feel i got a real bargain, Cost £40.00 back home would have cost £100.00, great quality and good leather

Jemaa el Fnaa! Organize chaos. Walking around the souk is an adventure! One has to be there to truly understand what it is like to be in an organized chaos. In the day - at least before 5pm, the Jemaa is like any open market, but at night it becomes a show. There are hundreds of food hawkers. There are magic shows, acrobats, and arcades- just to name a few of the activities. Food is great and cheap!
African market. Beware of "guides". Always ask the price in advance.Everything I imagined about a market place in Africa

Embrace the hustle and bustle! . When you come to Marrakech it is only right that you visit the infamous Medina! This will give you a true taste of Morrocan life and how amazing the culture is. From authentic food to souks upon souks to buy beautiful antiques and clothes. Get lost! Always head back to the square if you lose your way. A must see experience when visiting Marrakech
Fascinating. Enjoyed the working are of the souk, the wool dyers, metal workers making lamps etc.Loved watching craftsmen at work.
Good for shopping for gifts. We visited many Medinas in Morocco and there were more sections in the one in Marrakech which offered a broad range of shops for gifts and souvenirs
Prepare to haggle. We found the souk a little intimidating with the aggressive but friendly stance of the stall holders and not as cheap as it seems

easy to get lost but enjoyed it. we wandered about different parts of the Medina and never felt threatened once. You did get a bit of chat from the locals to try and get you into their shops but if you just said no thanks and kept walking most were fine. Just try and retrace your steps as it can be easy to get lost as most of it looks similar but its a must to go and see if you go to Marrakech,

Medina on steroids. We went to several medinas around Morocco. Marrakesh was unique in the aggressiveness of the vendors and the extent of the souks. On the plus side, you can buy anything. On the minus side, you will over pay for it, since you will generally have no basis for what anything actually costs, and the starting price is literally 4-6x the final price (if you have the skill).But if you're not shopping and just walking, there is much to see there. Unfortunately you cannot stop without being accosted by the merchants. If you want real shopping I suggest you go to the Taroudant or Essaouira Medinas. Friendlier merchants, and starting and ending prices. Outside the Souks, there is a lot to explore in the twisting and winding streets. All the little museums and buildings are worth seeing. The price of $3-6 buys you entrance to most, where you'll spend 30 minutes to an hour of enjoyable time.Marrakesh is a great city to go to view and see. The Djemaa El Fna is a free stage play all day and well into the night. I ate the snails there and survived fine.

Medina Madness. The medina is busy and loud and you have to have your wits about you. I felt safe, but found spending too long there a little exhausting. I love to shop and browse but that is tricky here as they are so keen for a sale - I'd have bought more if they had left me to it! There is lots to see and atmosphere to soak up. I didn't enjoy the monkeys dressed up as it is cruel and whilst the snakes look lethargic I was nervous a man might try and drape one over me, although my screams might have woken the poor creature up! Every hour or so we had to escape to the cafe with a roof terrace and enjoy a mint tea and take a breather. I am glad I came and enjoyed the experience but I couldn't do it too often :-)

Busy lively atmosphere day and night. Guess its a must see when you are here.I was a little disappointed on what was for sale in the actual square but some of the stalls sold original items.Its busy 24 hrs a day and has a great atmosphere

Loved it!. Arrival here in the evening by taxi on my own was so exciting! Not like anywhere I had ever been before! Mules, motorbikes and people teeming everywhere - not at all touristy yet...and so atmospheric! Just like you imagine!

OMG - Where do you start!!!!. Amazing!!!! I have to say I loved the Medina and old market. 1st impressions are you have been transported back 1000 years - until you see all the mopeds and satellite dishes. Yes it's busy, dirty, smelly, people pestering you for money and you see all sorts of animal cruelty - but this is Marrakech not London so don't judge it by Western standards. Just keep a good sense of humour, be aware of where you are and go with the flow. I can truly say I had the time of my life!! Yes you will get lost in all the twists and turns, just enjoy it and you will come out eventually. local men/boys will try to be 'helpful' but just say no firmly and keep walking and they will leave you alone. Sales people will be pushy. Don't be all polite and intimidated - if you want something then haggle if not just walk on. The square really comes alive by night and you can't go wrong eating at 1 of the market stalls. Very cheap and tasty. Just keep an open mind and remember you're not in England and you'll have a fantastic time. Ps - watch out for the snakes !!!

Be careful when taking photos. It is worthwhile having a guided tour of the Souk to see all the places in this labyrinth of alleyways that the faint hearted would miss. Also be careful when taking photos as everyone seems to want money for smiling (or not) at your camera - also even their pets!

Best shopping experience in all of Morocco!. The medina at Marrakech was a wonderful shopping experience! An incredible selection of everything you can imagine. It was great fun haggling with the store owners too. We never felt intimidated there even with a lot of people clamoring to get us into their shops and to "give you the best price my friend". We wandered around for hours but never had much problem finding our way out into the main square. It was a great experience and one that everyone should have during a visit to Marrakech! Don't miss it! Great photo ops too!!! But some are for a price.

Great experience if you don't mind being pestered. My wife and I went to the souks at Jamma El FNA square and the Bab El Khemis - both very different The Jamma El FNA square souk is what one might see as a 'traditional' souk, similar to that found in p[laces like Turkey - 100's of stalls all selling local products that one might purchase as gifts or souvenirs OR new products such as lampshades, tiles or leather goods. The Bab El Khemis souk is very different and sells a great deal of 2nd hand stuff (clothing especially), plus mattresses, furniture, vintage Moroccan artifacts and small enterprise manufacturing - if you want a window frame or a table or a bed frame made, this is where to find the craftsmen Fascinating area and both worth visiting Tip - Take a compass with you !
confusing. The medina was great for shopping but so easy to get lost. You are constantly harrassed by men. Dont be afraid to barter .. there are some good bargains to be found.

Complete Madness!. A must visit! Both at day and at night. The place is a complete hustle and bustle and chaos, but it is a must. You have to try the street food! One of the best Tangines we had, although not the most comfortable environments, seated over an open drain. We enjoyed the spiced tea and fudgy cake every evening after dinner. The stall holders are always willing to give explanations about the tea and other herbs etc. We tried eucalypts in ours, very "refreshing". Be careful about taking photos as money will be demanded if you have been thought to capture an individual. The cafes are expensive around the square and not the best but you pay for the atmosphere! It is a tourist attraction as well as a local attraction. Always better buys the further away you go but that's the same for everywhere similar that you go in the world. The souks were amazing, particularly in the production rather than selling area. Be prepared to wander!

Lively, colourful, shop til you drop.. Initially a bit intimidating due to amount of hassle from stall holders if you stop to look at something in the soul stalls, you soon realise they are a friendly bunch and a ' no, merci' is generally accepted with a following 'maybe later' from them to which you say yes. Haggling not too difficult, and in any event all pretty reasonable prices for smaller stuff- did not attempt the carpet haggling!

Nothing special. It could be good if you can negotiate but you cannot do it for all shops in this area. They don't care about you the only thing that counts most is money. They offer services and help you never asked and they pretend to be paid. All of them sale more or less the same stuff and all of them sale the best stuff (whatever). The streets are really nice but a walk in this place would be much more comfortable without someone selling you stuff at every corner.

Medina Madness. Loved the Medina, sights and sounds and smells. Not for the faint hearted. Maps are not much use - could not have managed without my GPS, would probably still be wandering around in circles. Pay no attention to the helpful "it's shut" or "la place is this way" etc. More often than not it's misleading information.
busy busy busy!!!!. so many people, so many laces to look, animals, magicians, and monkeys- OH MY! A must to get a feel for the city and its inhabitants. Just be sure to watch you bag!!!
interesting and authentic. interesting, touristic, but full of flavours and colours, it is not the Grand Bazaar but it is more authentic

an awesome experience. To Watch and Experience the biggest street food spectacle is by itself amazing. The range of activities, the varieties of food and drinks, the coming together of so many culture and traditions is a treat for the eyes and a delight for the stomach.

Superb. I spent almost three full days wondering the streets if the medina and it was an amazing experience. The sights, sounds and smells of the various food venders is incredible and you feel as if you've entered another world. Haggle for everything and offer a third of what the seller says, it's common knowledge that's what they expect to get so stick your ground.I found using a small bit of Arabic was greatly appreciated by most and it was easier to get rid of overbearing street sellers.Avoid asking people on the street for directions, the police and some shop owners are generally happy to give you some sort of direction.

Has to be experienced. Well, it's a total buzz from start to finish, and mostly in a good way. It's a real hubbub and is a must-see for anyone whose idea of a busy shopping area is Oxford Street. The main square is full of people trying to sell their wares, performers hoping for contributions and all manner of snake-charmers, monkey owners and henna artists. Be careful - they will offer to let you touch a snake,take your photo with a monkey, or paint a pattern on your hand - tell them you have no money and they say it's free, then they harrass you for cash. One even tried to march me to a cashpoint! My tip - stay clear and watch from a distnace, and avoid any conversation.The souks are where the real pleasure can be found. Tiny shops selling everything from handmade jewellery to soaps to spices to linen to designer clothes... or at least very good copies. Again, be wary of peole who offer to help you when you're lost or simply need to ask where something is - they all want paying! But the good side is that you can haggle for some great bargains. Don't ever pay full price; don't even pay half. We knocked one shop down from 1,200 dirhams to 200 dirhams for a necklace, and then bought a top for 200 dirhams which was first priced at 650 dirhams.At night the medina turns into a mini food festival, and the atmosphere is quite incredible. All manner of food is available, but check prices first and also watch for cleanliness - my own glass was drained and taken away from me, then given to someone else to use without washing it!All in all, a fun and interesting experience, but pretty exhausting.

Fascinating Old Town. You can easily spend a few days wandering around the alleyways of the old town, especially in the extensive souk. Would have given it 5 starts but for the annoying unofficial tour guides who pester you constantly.

a fantastic experience. just unforgettable - narrow winding streets, beautyful doors and windows, glimpses of riads' inner courts and gardens, street vendors selling all kinds of amazing things, old ladies dangerously driving on scooters, donkey carts taking produce to the souks... impossible not to get lost at least once, cause the medina (old city) is quite big, and there're no accurate maps of it. don't panic, just look for the signs for Jemaa el Fna or other famous landmarks. there would be lots of people offering to show you the way to "the big square", but don't bother - they will walk you in circles and demand money, you'll be better off on your own.
Medina.. What a fantastic experience. In the day it was busy but at night it came alive, the smells of the food. The food I ate was very good. Would recommend a night time trip to the medina.
A must see place. As recommended by everyone. Quite a place to visit and we were not disappointed in any way. Unusually it lived up to all the hype.

amazing. medieval life mixes with modern life- its so hard to explain how crazy interesting this place is. You will see the people selling vegetables like they did 300 years ago and at the same time talking with their cell phone. its an incredible place! the Suqs the lights the smells the windy tiny roads filled with people and their donkey pulled carriages is something that will bring you back in time. Stay in the medina and just look around in awe at some stuff that hasnt changed in hundred of years.

very busy. take a seat just before sunset at on of the roof top cafes (there is one on the first corner where all you have to do is buy a drink and you can go up) and you watch the whole square start to come alive

a maze of fun. Loved the atmosphere, the many stores and colors. It is nice to walk among the locals, eat at their little stands and shop like they do. The soukhs are a big maze, fun to wonder around in.
Great experience. Liked the people, completely changed my opinion of Marrakech, bargains galore! Disliked feeling a little bit intimidated at night.

Great experience. An amazing place full of contrasts. Great food, sights and smells. Lots of hidden gems so do your research. First visit? get a guide so you can relax more and enjoy. Can't wait to go back.

Everyone wants you money. No exceptions. Rich in history and beautiful from afar, this place is somewhere you have to go when visiting Marrakech. However the people are pushy, they follow you around trying to sell you stuff and I even had one girl grab my hand and start henna-ing me before I realised what was happening, and I am no pushover! I got some good deals, saw some sights and enjoyed my day, but be under no illusions, no matter how friendly or however the exchange begins, it is always leading to your money and how they can part you from it. You are walking cash signs to them and nothing more. Learn to say no thank you in arabic, and however much you feel yourself wanting to be polite, fight the urge and ignore them completely. The minute you make eye contact, you are already half way towards giving them your cash. Not even a photo is free. If you point your camera towards a landmark and a local is in the general direction of the camera, they'll expect cash.

Authentic atmosphere. Wandering around in the medina is very exiting there is a lot to see. Even if you visit several times. In some parts you can still feel and see the authentic way of life. You have to be alert while walking around but we (2 women) never felt unsafe.

Took a full day walking around. This is in Jamaa-El-Fna square where moroccan people like to sell many cheap stuffs or you want to take picture of the vemon snake and monkey. I had good walking around and it was soooo hard choose and buy lots of stuff and also, I did enjoyed bargain for much cheaper price. Try it for yourself to bargain it and don't be scare cos they are desperate to sell anyway whatever price you wish to offer. Also, there have a very nice restaurants and the food was good and nice view of the medina of Marrakech.

Authentic. Locals and tourist all end up in the main square Jamma De Fna, as night falls, creating a heady environment of thousands of people, traditional music, smells of unusual food cooking and some very strange sights! Snake charmers, street dentists, acrobats and tarot card readers, to name but a few.
Recommended for 1-2 days. As all the other travellers said, stay in Marrakech for one or two nights its enough, the city has lots of things to do and visit but people aren't that good .
Living History. It is older than time and very unchanged. It's busy and hot. Lots of bargains if you negotiate right.

lots and lots of stuff. meandering along the narrow alleyways of the Marrakech Medina is a feast for the senses...there is a lot of cheap stuff to be found and also some gems...the dates are fantastic and one of the most famous tailors of the city is here...don't try and negotiate his prices, he might throw you out of his shop, negotiate everywhere else, be if for fresh nana mint or candles or oils. ENJOY

smaller medina than others we had seen, but nice. did a lot of shopping here to,. there were many stores with good prices and lots of products to pic from had some wonderfully fresh squeezed orang juice, yum yum.
.. Great. Loved the excitement especially the night time. It was busy and full of things to see and do.

Amazing, safe, fun and everything else. We loved walking through the tight and dimly lit ally ways late at night. We never felt unwelcome or unsafe and we always greeted with the word marhaba - welcome.
beautiful place full of hidden gems great food and culture. there was nothing that you couldnt handle with a polite no thankyou or stern NO : ) had an amazing experience cant wait to do it again

Marrakech overrated and expensive. I have just returned from Marrakech and it's the first time I have returned from holiday and can honestly say I am happy to be home. I would like to consider myself fairly well travelled. I have previously been to other countries in North Africa, North America, Asia and Europe and would not return to Marrakech.The Medina itself is dirty and dangerous. In large areas of the town there are no pavements and motor vehicles, motor cycles, bicycles and pedestrians are all on the road. The cars and motor bikes drive on the roads haphazardly just missing other road users. The pollution is extremely high.The places of interest have no real interest at all and are extremely overrated. The people of Marrakech treat tourists with disdain and only want to see how much money they can obtain from them. If you ask for directions they expect payment. There are various scams like pretending they want to help you find where you are going only to try to take you to a shop to buy some spices or oil In the Souks for which they charge an extortionate amount.To eat out in decent restaurants is as expensive or more expensive than London and the taxis are constantly trying to rip you off. In my opinion Marrakech is totally overrated.
At first daunting but it gets better. A compass is a good idea then at least you have an idea of the direction you are heading as few of the lanes have signs!
See the city! . What an amazing visit. The people, the shopping, the food, the vendors. So much fun and what an experience. And the history of everything around you makes everything that much cooler
Old town with old fashioned charm. This is one of the few more or less genuine souqs/medinas left. No wonder it is on the Unesco World Heritage list. Well worth a visit.

well worth a visit. be carefull when you hit the market you dont get lost allways backtrack
if someone wants you to go to leather market go other way as not to be trusted

A Confusion of Alleys!. A real market place exists in this medina. All sorts of items can be bought here but bargaining is tough! Be careful of your orientation as it is so asy to get lost. And beware of pickpockets.

Old town is so unique. You can find the best street food here, usually at night. Also, the best shopping of your life. You will definitely have to barter with the locals to get a good deal, but that's half of the fun! Be careful for pick pockets and watch out for the snake charmers and monkeys...they target tourists for money if you take their picture.

Just enjoy. Just loose yourself in the streets. Open your eyes, nose and senses. People will be friendly if you are, if you need help you will find, if you don't, just let them know in a friendly way. We felt very save, there was not one moment we did not enjoy. Watch out a bit for the bikes and bicycles and eat where your nose leads to and "take a risk" to eat in small non tourist places. You won't regret

Lively medieval city.. This place has probably changed little in centuries. The best things: the amazing architecture, the artisan craftsmen with workshops spilling onto the street, the colours and smells (spices, bread, orange blossom, kebabs), the feeling of history (donkeys pulling wagonloads of firewood).The worst things: feeling that people are trying to hustle you (they want a tip just to give you directions), motorcyclists on narrow streets brushing past you, no prices on display, the crazy drivers.You certainly feel more in control if you can speak some French as alll the locals do.
Nice Garden. Peaceful, relaxing & quiet place to visit. It can get busy and its not very big. Worth a visit, but there are better gardens in Marrakech which are free to enter.

Coolest place on the planet. Medina means old walled city. It takes days to explore the edges of this sultry and ancient place. The Souks are fascinating. Remember that to NOT bargain is an insult, it is one big game. However, do not fall prey to any pick pocketing or scams. A favorite is a guy will say to you, "hey, I met you at the Riad." Then he will proceed to take you to his" friends or cousins or brother's" rug emporium. You should never feel obligated to buy anything, so don't be bullied into doing so. Just say " la shukran", which is Arabic for NO THANKYOU, and bow and be on your way with a smile.

Medina advice. Just wander around, get lost and let the sights and sounds of the medina wash over you. Try to relax and look at the artisans at work. Have a few Dirham in change to pay for viewing or taking photographs if you are not going to buy. Most maps are useless. If you think you know or do know where you are walk with purpose otherwise you will get bothered by young men who want to direct you into the souks to see the artisans and then expect you to buy.

So Much to Experience - Tomorrow We're Getting Lost. There is just so much to do in Marrakech and the place is wonderfully vibrant with life, crazy scooter drivers and over burdened donkey carts. We arranged for two day tours as we thought it was a little too difficult to navigate on our own at first. We used Morocco Private Experience and Authentic Tours Marrakech. Both tours were excellent, and though they did overlap slightly, each was unique. The guides enthusiastically shared their knowledge while showing us their favorite craftsmen and other hidden points of interest. We especially enjoyed seeing the hamman fire maker, stoking the flames to keep the spa water the correct temperature and also heat local families' tagines atop his furnace.

Indiana Jones. Snake Charmers, monkeys, water sellers and other stall keepers selling everything under the sun. Always something to look at. Brilliant. Only sorry I didn't get to see it at night-time. Next time..
visitasguiadasenmarrakech.com. Great place to visit, well preserved and Fati from visitasguiadasenmarrakech was excelent showing us around.

Very atmospheric. I stayed at a Riad in the Medina as I really wanted to soak up the atmosphere. I certainly think I achieved that.I read somewhere that the wall around the Medina is 17km which means that (if circular) the old city is about 6km across. That feels about right -- I spent three days walking the narrow streets and there were certainly places I didn't see, but I have a very good overall impression. Here are some bullet points that might help you:1. Everyone is very friendly and the Medina (and indeed the whole of Marrakech.. probably Morocco entirely) is very safe. You will never feel threatened or at risk. 2. On every street corner there will be at least one young man. As you walk past, he will say one of the following:-a. "That was is closed" (it isn't);b. "Only today Berber people are in Marrakech" (they aren't);c. "Square is that way" (it may or may not be).It isn't that they are in any way bad... they are just trying to drum up business by diverting you towards "their" shop or whatever. If you stand still and look lost, you risk hiring a guide -- who may or may not lead you to your destination by a route which may (or may not) be direct. And will then want a tip (probably he will ask for 200 Dh, but you can laugh at this and give him zero, 50 or 100 depending how generous you are feeling, how far he took you and whether he actually took you to the right place). You can of course start the journey by telling them that you will not be paying them a tip.... which may (or may not) work. 3. If you want to buy stuff in the souk, I strongly recommend that you hold off, ideally for a day but at least for a couple of hours while you get the hang of negotiating and prices. You could see the same "silk" scarf for Db 1000, 100 or 10 at three different stalls. Likewise rugs and anything else. If you walk into a stall, you will need to be quite firm to get out again without purchasing something. I had one guy chasing me down the street, reducing prices all the way, just because I expressed an interest in a penknife. It is all quite good-natured but some people might find it rather wearing after a while.4. The Medina is a total maze of tiny streets -- most no more than 1.5m-2m wide but with people, hand-carts, donkey-carts, motorbikes and occasionally vehicles all competing for space... along with vendors offering their wares on mats. No road runs straight and you will feel like you have been turned around a million times and have no sense of direction. Sometimes there are signs that appear mutually exclusive (e.g. Jemaa el Fna both Left and Right). Just go with the flow and treat every getting lost as an exploration. Eventually you will get yourselves back to familiar territory (normally Baab Mellah, Jemaa el Fna or Baab Debagh).5. Be respectful. Moroccans are friendly and easy-going but some do not like to have their picture taken.Enjoy!

Walk from Bab Ailen to the square was exciting. Staying near the Medina gates of Bab Ailen, the walk towards Djemma El Fna was always exciting. While in Djemma El Fna, you definitely have to be on your guard, but little away from it we could relax. On this stretch, until the last 100 meters or so before the square, people were very friendly to us. Invariably the topic of much loved Bollywood films would be opened, and people would tell us about their favourite memories of Bollowood heros and heroines. The fifty plus would talk about Dev Anand while the thirty minus wouldl talk about Shahrookh Khan. the language of communication was a problem, but you can manage. But nobody really tried to fleece us on this stretch except the occasional banter.And the views and mood would be different at different times of the day. Early morning -everywhere, you have the vegetable, fruit and meat sellers; the bakeries making different breads - the lubia and baseera seller (we used to join in and eat and sample everything); later all other kinds of establishment would open. Very crowded between 10am nad 2pm and again from 5pm to 10pm. But night time beyond 10pm was also very pleasant as we would peep into the bakeries (attached to the hammams) trying to line up the tangia pots in the cinders. You can get lost, but getting lost is fun here if you keep your humour.

loca flavours. after going to many places, we found the shopping best at the Medina. its good to spend an afternoon there and the continue watching all the dance, music, acrobats in the evening. one may think it to be touristy and expensive but actually its not!! I didnt like the local food--tajin too much but pizzas and Morocco mint tea were refreshing.

Square of madness (in a good way). The square bustles with tourists and traders and it works!There are the snake charmers and monkey performers which drew my eye for a few moments but the star of the show are the market stalls and Souks leading of the square. fresh OJ or grapefruit juice are a must and the food stalls are awesome, I ate 2 evenings and the lamb chops are a most, go for a evening and just enjoy the atmosphere and banter

So alive!. The Medina of Marrakech is amazing. There are so many things going on in here, so many colours, light, people... Very friendly and helpful people. Downside with eating here is the children begging for money and food...
Medina. We paid on average a quarter of the asking price. Some hard selling but always pleasant and helpful.

A maze of sensory delight. While one can make their way through the medina, I would recommend a local help guide you through. It is fascinating, noisy, and a fun experience to just wander. You haven't been to Marrakesh if you haven't wandered through the medina.

Fascinating. Walked all around the Medina and marvelled at the warren of houses, baths, riads and sellers. Would have loved to have seen inside the houses as hard to imagine what they are like. Scooters and bikes manage to travel at speed so watch yourself.Bought bags from a coop and had great fun in the haggling process. No idea if we paid more than we should but you don't get that experience in England.

Not for the faint-hearted. The medina is a madhouse of narrow alleys and lanes, thronged with people and stalls - both touristy and for the local people. You will see all sorts of meat, veg, bread etc. displayed, as well as what they think tourists will be tempted by. It's fascinating and very easy to get lost. Beware of the friendly young men who offer to show you the way as they will want paying when you arrive at your destination. One thing to be really careful of is the manic moped riders who whizz down the lanes with little regard for pedestrians. Always walk to the right to avoid being hit by them.

Defining the word "chaos". If you want a real life definition of the word chaos, this is the place. There's scooters, going through these streets at high speeds, screaming shop keepers who are constantly trying to get your attention, several fat cats running around, and garbage dumps everywhere.The so-called souks, have people who try to come up and be your friend when you have not even asked them for help or directions. They sense that your foreign - and approach you to make quick money - beware of the same.The maps of the medina are not accurate, at least the ones handed out at the riads etc they show streets that are not present, it would be difficult to make a map for such a place!Live outside the medina, and just spend an hour or so here to get a flavor, no more than that.

The Mad Medina. If you're looking for the Heart of Marrakech look no further than the Medina. Hustle/Bustle and an eclectic mix of everything you desire! From the Tanneries (leather quarter) to the Palaces/Souks/Tombs and Mosques you will get lost in this labyrinth of a Moroccan bygone era!! Essential visit.....bring your Dirhams and Barter HARD!!!!!

The Medina. We were in the Medina part of Marrakech and I loved it. The old town has character and the narrow streets were something else. Never felt hassled when walking through the souk. A compass is a good thing to have though as we got a bit disorientated once or twice.Lovely people

NO COMMISSION !!!. When visiting Marrakech, be prepared when being addressed as 'Friend'. It means they have watched you approaching from afar and see you are ripe for harvest.If taking a taxi to medina, you may find the taxi going out of the way to collect a friend who knows your language. Immediately, say NO COMMISSION! These guys will leach onto you to get you to tip them... often. If they take you to souks and you buy... they expect COMMISSION from you as well as the shop keeper.Be assertive. When they hear you say NO COMMISSION it shows them you are on to their scam!We were in a horse carriage and had men jump in to help. NO COMMISSION. I say I pay driver and not you.You will be able to handle it. But those 2 words will help out more than you know.

The main square. The usual hustle and bustle, market stalls, and traders all vying for one's attention and money! A large area with lots to see, we visited at all times of day, but late afternoon or early evening is best!

Best for shopping. When on a tour one does not have much time to shop. While tour guides are usually good with their advice, they usually take you to shops where they get a fee(I have seen the passing of money).Our guide told us to hold off our impulse buying and to wait until we got to ....Something told me to do otherwise and during our free afternoon (vs. going to the botanical gardens or cooking class) we went to the Medina in Marrakech and shopped at our own pace. And did we bargain!!! Without pressure and the ability to look, and compare. As it turned out, it rained the day our guide was going to take us shopping and the Medina in Casablanca (our last stop when many people planned to do their shopping) was very small compared to Marrakech and consequently did not have half the selection(and the shopkeepers were not as eager to bargain)..

The energy of Marrakech. Moving through the Medina was exciting. It it filled with fabulous shops for tourists and locals as well was excellent restaurants. The transition of the square from vendors to cafes is a beauty to behold.

stunning. Very stunning but be aware of rogue tour guides they can be very intimidating if you do want a beer there is a place down the side road from Cafe France which is buy one get from free, but still £6.00 a pint

Average. Excited to be in Marrakesh and staying in the medina area. The large market area though is underwhelming. It reminded me of the flea markets back home. It was interesting to tell friends that I had been there but it definitely was not the highlight of my trip to Marrakesh.

Full of Flavours and Colours. Medina is very lively, extreemly colourful and busy place. Be prepered to be hassled, watch out for motorbikes and thieves. If you can overlook that - you will have an amazing time discovering the place
Medina souks. It was very crowded, need to keep your wits about you, although having said that a very good experience

Dreadful. The medina was ok if you like that sort of thing, be prepared for it being very dirty and very smelly, hygiene is a major issue here so be very careful and make sure you take tissues and hand sanitizer. The first sight we got when walking up the median was a horse and trap driver urinating in the street and wasn’t bothered about exposing his genitals to whoever was passing. The snake charmers were trying to get the snakes to dance even though it is winter and they want to hibernate, so they smack and taunt them to wake them up, making monkeys dance when they don’t want to, Yes I know that this is their way of life and I understand that some people will love this kind of thing, I’m just saying I didn’t and found it to be very upsetting. THE TOMBS - we went to the tombs - PLEASE DONT GET A TOUR GUIDE it will take you all of 5 minutes to go round them, But you will love the architecture inside its stunning, not much else to see and very difficult to find, across from the palace and located past the souks and shops on a back alley that is not signposted at all, I think they want you to ask them so that they can get paid to point you in the right direction, nothing is free here.FANTASIA- If you can book the fantasia night it is one heck of a funny experience, one you will never replicate and we found it wonderful, it was very traditional, authentic and they gave a wonderful service, be careful of the food though, this is a set menu and you really are unsure of what you are eating , we had lamb but we had the WHOLE animal in 1 pot including everything that comes with an animal, very interesting, it cost 450 dirhams per person and this was for the transport, entertainment and food (DRINKS and SERVICE ARE NOT INCLUDED) if you are a cautious eater like me I ate an apple so it was a very expensive meal for 2 of our party as we both only ate an apple.Our taxi driver was absolutely wonderful and was very helpful. Just be aware that the show they put on after the meal is about 1 hour long in the summer but they cut it back to approx 10 minutes in the winter and still charge you the full amount so this was very disappointing and you feel a little cheated.THE ANIMALS - be careful around the feral dogs and cats, I say be aware, you can’t miss them as they are everywhere and I found it very upsetting when I saw dogs being hit with bricks and rocks, I am a dog owner myself and found it very upsetting, There cats are the everywhere and they are extremely matted with scabs and blinded with tics and with so many of them that you can’t help and just have to walk by. Anyway I’m done now, to summarise, I found Marrakech different, not as cultural as I expected and certainly an eye opening and is a place that I would not wish to return to, my husband compared this to the slums in Slum Dog Millionaire and he isn’t far off in that description but make your own mind up about it as everyone has a difference perspective on it.

Hustle and Bustle. as regards the Medina, being well travelled, it was dark dingy, and quite intimidating, for people who dont like this sort of thing. We all know the vendors are only after one thing, your money. You have got to be strong and say no and mean it.

Life in action. The medina is a picturesque and active place. Almost everything can be purchased. Hotels and riads abound. Watch out for autos, motor bikes, bicycles, running children, and teens on rollerblades. Thieves do exist and the sellers will make a good deal - for them.

The pink town within the city. If you do nothing else in the Medina just walk around, you will find it enchanting. As if you have been transported into an other dimension. I have visited Morocco and Marrakesh few times before but the Medina never stops to amaze me. You can clear your mind while walking and listen to the walls.
Lively and fun mixed with the expected rip off and hassle.. Bargain and don't give in too easily! Prices are better in the winter with less tourists. Enjoy the lively atmosphere!

A warren of intrigue. A tourist must. Contains the Souks which is colourful network of small shops and stalls offering a wide range of goods from leather and wooden items to numerous food and clothing stalls including spices. Its so easy to get lost but there is no shortage of willing people to guide you back to the main square with its snake charmers and ladies doing henna.
Lovely. I went with a private guide and it is well worth it was there is so much to learn. The highlight of my stay in Marrakesh.
Go on a Saturday!. The berbers come into town on Saturday to the tanneries. A must see! Such a unique experience and a way to gain cultural knowledge.

splendid experience. The smells of spices, cooking, candles, and flowers. The colours are bright and varied, the local people are friendly, helpful and most speak English. The evening is the best time, the square fills with locals enjoying a meal in the stalls cooking local specialitiesThe mint tea is very sweet so if you don't take sugar ask for it with no sugar, give the sugar cubes to the horses on the carriages, they love it!!!!

An Experience. Use common sense, keep a good eye on your belongings and be aware of vehicles driving down tiny narrow, packed streets. Unless you have a map or a guide, you're very likely to get lost in here. You have two options in this case. Look up at the ceiling for signs for the square, or pay a little kid to show you the way back. We decided to wander and risk getting lost, and we walked for hours down tiny lanes and alley ways and saw the back of the medina. This can be daunting if you are a single woman so I'd suggest being on your guard. However, as a couple we didn't experience any danger or hostility.It is dirty, crowded and smelly, but it's worth doing. You could easily spend hours in here just wandering around all the different shops. There are lots of smaller bazaars too with some interesting things to see. My tip is to do some reading up about bargaining with shopkeepers so you can see how it's done and get yourself a good deal.

Dissapointed. I visited a few of the shops during the afternoon, most of the shopkeepers were too busy , not bothered talking to us. Some of them quoted ridiculous price , it looks they had no intention of selling.

Where all your senses will work overtime!. Let me first start by stating I was a female traveling solo.The souks were amazing - I wanted to buy everything!Be prepared to get lost - it will happen. There aren't any "road" signs - just signs pointing in the direction to the main square - Jamaa el Fna or to other attractions such as the Museum of Marrakech or the Ben Youssef Mosque.Be prepared to get haggled while checking any items out at the stalls. ALWAYS negotiate pricing if you're interested in purchasing an item.Also, locals really do not like tourist taking pictures of them or the stalls so politely ask for permission.DO NOT give children or men money if they say they are a guide when you do get lost; politely smile and say no thank you.I found that speaking Spanish to the locals helped me out far more than my English - so if you can speak French or Spanish the locals will be able to assist you better.And lastly, even though I got lost countless amount of times, I never felt like I was in harm's way.I felt pretty safe. There are few bathroom facilities where you have to pay a fee to get in but if you can hold it I suggest heading to a restaurant/cafe in the square or heading back to your hotel/riad.I can't wait to go back and visit again!
Sounds, Smells and Colour. An amazing place bustling with people of all nations; snake charmers, henna tattoos, horse and carriages, monkeys, food stalls etc. etc. etc. Also not at all threatening.
Loved it. Wonderful shopping, great food and lovely people what more can you ask for.I felt very safe no problems at all.

Guide in Marrakech. We had a great experience with Mustapha in Marrakech! He was helpful, kind, and extremely informative. He didn't even charge us anything!!! Highly recommend! email him at marrakechtourguide yahoo.com 00212661077650

Hits every one of your senses. Get ready when you go into the medina - it is exciting, mad, energetic and exhausting but you will love it I am sure.Watch out for the motorbikes weaving in and out of the pedestrians and dont take any photos or ask for directions unless you want to pay.
so many little stalls. I loved walking around the Medina and finding bargains. So many peolpe with very interesting looking faces.
An amazing place. This is a very exciting place, with a real buzz. Don't attempt to drive and if you are uncertain then take a guided tour. Well worth a visit!

Hated it. The first thing that hit me was the smell. I have sensitive smelling anyway but it stank. Human and animal waste, and two stroke fuel. Then there was the animals they looked so sad in pain, with no quality if life. We got lost, as they have no street names. So many people and transport modes. You just walk across the road the cars stop for you if you are brave enough. I was so out of my comfort zone. I would go back now I know what to expect. Such a poor country.

Fascinating!. Visiting the medina and the square (both by day and night) is a must do. The small alleyways seem absolutely endless with so many goods to look at. In the square there is an array of entertainment and in the food markets there is so much to look at.( although we were advised not to eat there). It really is a sensory overload. However the constant harrassment by the shopkeepers is very overwhelming and constant which i think spoils the entire experience. I also found the many sick and injured cats wandering around and the treatment of the performing monkeys hard to bear. Overall though, this is a must see!

Whatever it is, a total experience !. It was my first trip to the city: amazing, exotic, beautiful, chaotic, dirty. Now that I have been there, I am sure I can enjoy it better but as a first time it has shocked me. At least, thou feel that is different to Western Europe. A great, thrilling experience.

Go at sunset. What can I say about the median of Marrakech other than "wow"!The smells, the sounds, the sights.....all combine to give an amazing experience whether you are simply walking round or seeking great bargains.While there be sure to visit one of the terrace cafés (just look up, you'll see them everywhere), as you will get a wonderful view.For me the highlight was being there around sunset when the main square comes alive with food stalls, street performers, snake charmers, vendors.....an experience I will not forget in a long time.

Find your way. IT is easy to find your way in the medina. It is the heart of Marrakesh. IT is Not easy to access the medina by car so take comfortable shoes with you, you will walk a lot. Everything you need is for sale but no Supermarkets here. You have to buy everything in small shops, on the streets or little market. A lot of atm machines are available. IT is adviced to have cash with you. Most of the shops do only paiments in cash.

Be prepared. The trick to enjoying the Medina is to enter it with the right attitude, calm, unhurried and slightly aloof, polite but firm NO'S to the multiple attempts to sell anything to you and you should be fine.

A Sensual Roller Coaster. It is difficult to describe the excitement of the Medina. You really have to lose yourself both physically and emotionally and open yourself to its many charms. It is easy to get lost but we quickly learned that all roads lead to the square...eventually. The Medina wall is good if you are lost as a taxi will take you where you want to go. The locals are friendly and amusing and will help. Every corner is another photo opportunity. It is unique and magical.

A must see. Why else would you come to Marrakesh if not to see the Medina, but get good advice from your hotelier, a good map and hold on tight to your common sense. At times not for the faint hearted, the number of times we were told we were going the wrong way to something was unbelievable but don't believe them keep walking and look overhead for the signs that point you in the right direction, failing that go in a shop and ask. Do not be led by anyone no matter how friendly their approach, you will be took the long way round the Medina, and charged for it. Amazing place

medina. Amazing .... sights, sounds, smell, colour. Loved it. Was afraid before we went that the traders would be too pushy and we would be over hassled, but this is not the case. If you say no they will mostly not push you any further.
Pice of art. If you want to see history then this is the place to go. Nice old bazar and shops. This will take you In history. I am so please to see these kind of places.

Quaint old town. Unusual old town, made up of narrow alleyways bounded by little shops and very plain buildings no higher than about three storeys, which hide fantastic interiors, such as the Riad where I stayed, a House with four or five guest rooms on two floors facing inwards to a beautiful courtyard with pool, open to the sky, with a roof terrace and views to the Atlas Mountains and the tall minarets of the Koutoubia and the Ben Youssef Mosque. Very quiet away from the bustle of the main square Jemaa-el-Fna and its adjacent Souks.
shopping. very busy. but good fun bartering for all manner of goods lamps, pots, rugs, spices, be prepared to be asked if you want to buy anything

a little overwhelming but an experience !. Hassled big time by the shop keepers and people wanting to show you the way somewhere. Did not like the animal exploitation in the square ..monkeys dressed up for photos
Nice but nothing special. It`s quite clean but quite ordinary place. Souks is not a maze, every path is leads to Jemma El Fna. Very touristic atmosphere.
"lots to explore". But hard work being bothered all the time by stall holders. You need to be able to walk without getting too tired.

Like Marmite. I really really really wanted to like the Medina. I had thought it would be one of the highlights of our trip. Unfortunately, had a few bad experiences (like getting yelled at for no particular reason - got called a skinhead, im simply bald!! or having my girlfriend continually harassed, and she was dressed in very conservative clothing) After a couple days it simply got too much. Monkeys on chains, kids begging in streets (have a look at pics). Motorcycles within inches of hitting you and constant harassment for money in some way, shape or form. A few times people tried to scam us like bringing us to restaurants that were actually closed!!!I understand that Morocco is a developing country and that the people there are simply trying to make out a living, but I think its probably gone a bit too far with regards to looking at westerners as a cash point. I had wanted to see and experience the Moroccan culture. We simply weren't able to experience it in Marrakesh and the Medina in particular. I loved the rest of our trip to Morocco (Imlil and Essaouria) as they seemed more genuine and authentic. I would imagine that others would love the craziness - maybe it just wasnt for us :)

Inspiring African medina between snow and desert.. Experiencing Marrakech was one of the most thrilling experiences. Shopping, noises, pushy market traders, good food, friendly smiles and night life at the Jamal Efna. Hidden corridors of Medina will not leave anyone indifferent.
Overwhelming at first, then a real hoot!. At first it's a bit intimidating, but you quickly acclimate and if you enjoy bargaining, you will enjoy waling through the markets of the Medina.
Bonkers!. Amazing, loud, assault on all your senses at once, complete cultural experience, a place to never forget.

Great experience - you will never forget. Great experience that you will never forget... Snakes, monkeys is just an example that you can find in this place... the culture in Marroco is something magic, specially for you that have been visiting big cities like me. Visit the Medina with a tour guide, this will avoid you to be bored by local people that will want to guide you.
Exciting. Just an amazing place to wander around - each day even though we took the same route we saw something different and interesting.

Teeming with life. Wonderful array of products, leather goods, spices, tassels and fresh produce. Masses of motorbikes, tricycles and milling throngs. Smells of food and spices. Good cafes in alleys and squares. Bartering essential.

Madness. The Jemaa El Fna square and maze of souks make Marrakesh a must visit destination. Be prepared to be approached to buy things from street vendors and stall holders or be offered a tour of a Berber tannery though while interesting inevitably ends at a shop selling carpets and leather goods with the initial tour guide awaiting your 'contribution' for his services outside. You also end up some way of the beaten track. Bartering is expected in the souks, don't pay the first price given.

Main attraction. No visit to Marrakesh would be complete without visiting the sprawling medina. It's great for people watching, the noise and the smalls will stay with you forever. The snakes and monkeys were not to my taste but hey. Try and visit the tanneries, guides will expect a tip obviously but it's worth it. They give you a bunch of mint as a gas mask (it stinks) don't wear your best shoes! You will end up in some leather shops but I didn't buy anything and they were cool with that. If you like haggling for a bargain this is the place. If not go to the artisan centre, they give a discount for multiple purchases but no haggling

Don't go to Marrakwch. Rather than go to this horrible place, spend your money on supporting the welfare of the tortured animals in Marrakech. The obvious plight of the thirsty and overworked donkeys and horses and the poor moneys in chains being dragged around for the enjoyment of tourists is awful to see. The plight of the poor, begging people isn't much better. There's no pleasure to be found here.

Feast for the Senses. The medina is something you MUST see, feel, smell, taste and hear!!! The vibrant colors and aromas of the spices, beautiful rugs , lanterns and fabrics, . The exotic foods to taste, and fabulous music are a once in a lifetime experience! Do it!

Exotic. Loved the colorful sights, the olive market, even liked the snake charmers. The place is huge and we walked for hours visiting many of the stalls and even bought a beautiful berber carpet. The only thing I did not care for was the huge screen showing movies. While they are very proud of this modern festival it does not fit with the historic Medina in my opinion.

entertaining. i greatly enjoyed strolling around the medina. the shopkeepers were no where near as aggressive as i had been led to believe and several were very informative about the local area, their products and other interesting informational tidbits.

The Medina is the Heart of Marrakech. No travel will be complete in Marrakech if you don't visit this exotic place. A guide is recommended specially if you want to go dept there. Is a big tourist trap with lost of merchants and artifacts. They ask you very high prices so you need to negociate hard with them for a fair price.

..madness on wheels. We stayed at a Riad in the heart of the Medina. If you like to experience madness, smells beyond description and sights to boggle the imagination, you will love it here. Every day was an adventure and we looked forward to it. It is like going into biblical times but with scooters and mopeds thrown in!! Don't be frightened and don't ask for help unless you are prepared to pay for it. Even to be pointed in the right direction will cost you and then they will offer to show you and accompany you and want 400dirhams. We were prepared to wander around, get lost, begin again and found more sights to see that way. We saw all the usual tourist attractions but a lot more besides. We are in the square at the stalls and also in Roads and Day's. From the sublime to the ridiculous this place has it all.
Crazy Medina. We love the buzz and the craziness of the medina! You need a peaceful retreat to stay in once you're out, but it is a must in Marrakech!
Attraction. Interesting to visit and people watch both day and night. Watch out for the snake charmers they only want your money.

Great Experience. Always a fun time to see the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh here at the Medina. We had dinner in the square where there are plenty of options. Super cheap and good food if you pick the right stall. Just be ready to get hassled by every food vendor there. They all want you to eat at their place! Be sure to stop and get Harira -- the Traditional Moroccan soup. It's sooo good. The merzouga is also delicious. It's a Moroccan sausage that is tasty.We also did a little shopping inside the Medina but didn't venture very far the first night. It's like a labyrinth and it was getting late. Enjoy!

too confusing, but must see. we spent a morning walking at a newyork pace, and even if we didn't stop anywhere, as many places and things don't worth a stop, we managed to get out of there after 3/4 hours!!! Must see, but nothing of real value inside. nothing happened to us, even at late night. pay someone to guide you at the exit you need to reach

Why pay to sit in a chemist and be pitched to on holiday?. This trip was disappointing. The bus was late to start with. We were rushed through the souks and medinas. Whilst I appreciate this is not a shopping trip, it would have been pleasant to see the hand crafted products. The tour guides weren't up for any form on conversation, which put a dampener on the trip. We arrived at a chemist where we sat for an hour on uncomfortable seats and were covered in various lotions and potions. When it came to buying the products it was a free for all. We went on this trip with the view to going back another day to look for ourselves, but left and chose only to go back to pick up a few gifts to take home with us. A free drink was provided at the end of the trip though.
Truly fascinating. Nothing can prepare you for what you are about to experience. Immerse yourself to maximise the experience, no regrets here
Fascinating. Secret is to keep in mind a few landmarks, you will never get lost!Amazing restaurants, caffes and hammans...all to explore

What an adventure!. What a sight, lanes and lanes of stalls selling everything from football tops to rugs. Be prepared to get hassled to have a look and subsequently purchase anything you lay eyes on. That aspect of the souqs in the medina isn't particularly enjoyable, however you get used to saying just looking and moving on.It is possible that you will get lost and my tip would be just to keep walking and eventually you will come to a main type street. Be cautious of locals giving you directions then wanting a tip for you only to become more lost and repeat the process. This didn't happen to us as we also were using google maps but I saw it in operation.Don't be alarmed though most if not all moroccans are nice people just going about their daily lives making a dollar.Enjoy

an experience. we went to the medina a few times...the first with a guide...he showed us around and took us to some great shops...then, on our own...the snake charmers wrapped his snake around my head!

Interesting experience! . We decided to stay in the medina in one of the riad, it was lovely to walk around, although first time i thought i was going to be lost! It was a bit like a maze! But after paying a lot of attention walking around we got by pretty easy. Plenty of things to see like shops. It was quite interesting to see how people live here. Beware of the " hard sale" that will make you feel rather uncomfortable! And beware of the "official guide" that will take you to the small alleys and straight to a carpet shop! We got caught once!

History is everywhere including the pushy salespeople. Walking around the medina and visiting the markets is certainly an interesting experience and in some ways cannot be avoided if one intends to visit the historical places of interest. The pushy sales part get old after a few hours.

Great Culture Shock 3 hours from London. The Medina is great for a fantastic long weekend away. You get a real culture shock only 3 hours away from London. The Medina is bustling with all kinds of traders. You must negotiate hard, and prices start high but it is all in the fun and games of Marrakech. Go and enjoy !!!

Hell broken loose. If you are the kind who likes to walk narrow lanes and alleys with no signposts with shopkeepers on either side who make rude comments, teenagers imposing themselves upon you as guides and pointing deliberately in the wrong direction, dodging two wheelers, a peculiar smell that pervades and finally emerging onto a large square where there is no order or character, go here

Alive. This place allows you to glimpse into the lives of normal Moroccans. As they whiz past on bikes scooters and bigger, and you walk past the butchers, bakers, fishmongers, chicken sellers you get the most wonderful sense of being given a window into the lives of others. I recommend staying here but at least you should wander around by yourself and get a little lost. If you have a phone with google maps cached then you will never be truly lost and will be able to see the parts that most tourists seldom tread.

Just get lost. Despite reading some feedback, we found the Medina great and friendly. People more than happy to point you in the right direction if you look like you're a bit lost. The main square is ok, really touristy and we preferred the other areas of the Medina for getting lost for a few hours.

Bustling. We toured the medina with a guide, Moulay, from Ya'lla tours and he helped us navigate the windy alleys as well as learn to bargain in the Moroccan fashion. This was extremely helpful, though we did return on our own. While the alleys are confusing we did not find ourselves lost but enjoyed visiting all the small shops. Most of our time was spent in the area where they sold clothing and home goods ( bags, shawls, shoes, wooden carved items, etc) but we did venture into the area with the animals - primarily chickens. It is a fascinating adventure and one that shouldn't be missed. The plaza outside the medina is alive with all sorts of activities including snake charmers - which our daughter loved! For a few coins you can hold the snakes and let them wrap around your neck …if you want. Definitely include this on your itinerary.

Colourful Souk. Great Souk but if you're going to Essaoiura save your money and shop there instead as prices more expensive in Marrakech. Make sure you bargain well as they will go as low as a third of the original asking price in some cases.

Wonderful medina. Fantastic experience, the sights and sounds are amazing and there are so many hidden treasures behind the Medina walls. We enjoyed our week here immensely and are so glad we stayed inside the Medina instead of in a fancy hotel in the new town.

Craziness. While it was a fascinating place to see, there is a wild quality about the Medina in Marrakech. We had been to the Medina in Fes which was absolutely amazing. We never felt threatened or in danger. I can't say the same about the Medina in Marrakech. When we first arrived, a vendor got a carton of cigarettes swiped by a passing motorbike. That really opened our eyes. There are motorbikes driving way too fast in such a small space. I would not recommend bringing children through the Medina at night. There is just too much going on and it is quite frenetic. That being said, it is a memorable place and definitely something to see while in Marrakech. Just be careful!

Enjoyable place to get lost in. I found the souks fascinating. Dodging mopeds, men crafting their work, literally under your feet, people watching, soaking it all up. Spend a few hours over a few days & yes, it is mostly aimed at tourists, haggling can be fun to watch & participate in. I never felt under pressure to buy, despite finding myself being dressed up in kaftans several times.

Milling around the Medina. Excellent, well worth a visit. As a Star Wars fan, I couldn't help but feel, I'd stepped onto Tataouine, with the street performances, the Berber-style music, the bizarre and wonderful architecture... The souks were an experience in themselves, but in saying that, so was the sampling of snails and sheep's head. The medina has more than enough to keep you occupied and enthralled for a short stay in Marrakech. You must see it for yourself!

Definitely memorable!. We lived there in a very nice riad, and if you only visit Marrakech for a couple of days you definitely should live in Medina, as this is the most authentic, noisy and colourful place. But as for me, after 2-3 days I got a little tired of all this noise and of frauds trying to cheat the tourists. We always had to be attentive and couldn't relax for a moment, because someone either tried to cheat us or to insult when they failed. Of course Moroccan people are not at all like that, which you will find out away from Medina and in other towns, but Medina attracts both tourists and frauds.

Haggle Haggle Haggle!. Loved exploring the buzzy Medina, and experiencing the souks. The Moroccans have to be the best (if not the pushiest) salesmen in the world! But great to experience and enjoy the sights and sample everything Marrakesh has to offer.

Unlike anything you've ever seen. Many people flock to see silly shows with monkeys, snakes, etc. There are many "souks" that mixed products made in Morocco and other come from China. You will probably pay for everything from a smile to a photo.

Great for shopping, but not the best medina in Morocco. Liked: obviously this is a great medina for shopping. Shop around and ask at least 3-4 vendors to get a good idea of what you should pay. I found them wildly different!Disliked: obviously it's geared for tourist shopping only. It lacks a bit of the authenticity that other Moroccan medinas have.

Love this place. The medina is amazing - have never been anywhere like it - the hustle and bustle is great and you can buy everything there from sinks to souvenirs, beds to bling. We got lost each time we went - despite having a map. Had a couple of hairy moments but on the whole felt safe and the locals are very helpful.

A travel back in time. With its narrow, winding streets and loads of street vendors, walking through the Medina feels like stepping back in time. This is the place to really get a sense of what life in Morocco was (and is) like, and walking around always feels like an adventure. Be prepared to get lost but that is all part of the experience.
thrilling. just stroll, don't try too hard to get to a specific place, try to enjoy what is on your way, keep your eyes, ears and nose open.

An interesting experience.. There are many interesting sites to visit in the Medina including the Salidin tombs and the Royal Place. The Souks are interesting but be aware that much of what they sell is strictly for tourists and you need to haggle.if you want more classy stuff you need to ask advice. The cafes are mostly very average and again y ou need to use your guide book and ask advise are there are some wonderful hidden gems.

Busy, busy, busy but fascinating. It was easy to get lost on the first day but one soon becomes familiar with the surroundings and from then on it's easy to get around - just mind the motorbikes and donkey carts!

Marrakech Medina. It was my third visit to Marrakech, and I just love the souks. There is so much of interest in the medina, if you like people watching and observing this is the place for you - go into a cafe with a terrace, order a mint tea, and enjoy!

Feels like in a different age. If you had just one day in Marrakech, you should simply wander around. It feels like being in a diff er ent age, with people on donkeys, in their djellabas, producing handcraft, selling herbs and spices, baking bread, chatting, relaxing. No need to go to the hectic Souk or the feverish Place if you just want to experience something different.

Great shopping!. The medina of Marrakech is lots of fun and is a feast for the senses! Be prepared to haggle!! When you make a counter offer, make it much lower than you want to end up paying so that you'll have room to raise your offer. It's a game you'll play over and over. You can come home with great stuff if you're patient and take your time looking around.

Labyrinth in Marrakech. Walking through the medina is like walking through a labyrinth. There are always things to see, to bargain for, and places to drink mint tea. Watch out for the motorcycles as they tend to race through the narrow streets. There are many picturesque corners and places. In general alcohol is expensive and hard to find except in some of the nicer hotels or discretely at a few places around the Jemaa el Fna.

Interesting. The street food stalls were yummy and cheap. The orange juice was really fresh and good. We tried to go back to the same stall everyday. It is interesting to see the Medina lights up during dusk to night.

Mental!. So we had downloaded the marrakech riad travel plus app which is AMAZING!!! Written b an english coupl who own a few Riads in town. It has advice on EVERYTHING including haggling techniques! GPS map with all the sites marked with photos and info and a little blob to follow so no need for teenage boys or werid men to help you! Get it - it was a life saver - we never got lost and went to all the reccomended cafes etc and they were all great!
Cool. The medina is cramped, crowded, almost impossible to navigate, but neverendingly fascinating. The narrow alleys are wonderfully cool. How else would the people survive the summers?

Medina madness. You can't visit Marrakech without visiting the Medina - it's a feast for the senses. The vibrant colours of the souks, the carpets, scarves, lamps, a shopaholics dream. The smells and sound of Jemaa el fna - crazy during the day even crazier at night!

Amazing place. Our hotel was in the medina and there is always something going on with many street traders and fruit sellers Personally I have never been anywhere like it before and I found it fascinating.

Colourful ... But learn to haggle ;). It is an absolute delight walking around the medina. There are beautiful shops and some amazing craft. The prices are always upped for tourists hence you should be ready to haggle. You can get the prices really low depending on how good you are. Don't be rude, just smile and offer them what you think is the best price. If they say no just walk away, they will come after you and sell for the price you asked for... trust me! ... Be aware of men/kids lingering around trying to find lost tourists (its easy to get lost in those alleys). They will try to offer you directions and to walk with you but at the end will ask you for money. Even if you are lost, don't have a puzzled or lost expression on your as that attracts more of them. Be confident and just tell them you know where you going. Ask shops for directions instead. Overall it is very safe and you can walk around freely in the after hours. Also beware of the little bikes zooming around. But the biggest thing to remember if shopping - haggle haggle haggle ;)
Medina. Vibrant excellent shopping with lots of bargains and even if you couldn't walk one step without being lured into the shops an extremely friendly atmosphere and zillions of nice things to buy.
Take care!. Take care before looking or talking to locals in the Medina area. They all seem to expect a "tip". A Camera they" love"
Crowds, shopping, picturesque. Well if you dont see the medina in marrakesh its not worth the visit. However be carefull with your belongings, lots of pickpockets around.

a different world in djema'l fena square in the city. "Aykutlar Yolda" visited Marrakech in december 2013.The city is divided into two sections; one is the new part which is built by French people and the second is the oldcity. Most of the touristic attractions as djema'l fena square, bahia palace, koutoubia mosque are located in oldcity. Being in djema'l fena square is totally a different experience for all travellers.See Marrakesh pictures from the link below: https://www.facebook.com/24118791156/photos/a.10151167953361157.437643.24118791156/10151168139321157/?type=3&theater

An absolute delight!. We spent a total of 5 days in Marrakech and we stayed in a Riyad near Jamaa al fena as we found spending time in the medina an absolute delight for many reasons.From our very first morning we decided to brave our way through the alleyways of the souks armed with a map. From that point onwards we spent a lot of time roaming the streets of the souks where we started off shyly bargaining but then learned the power of walking away!!! 9 times out of 10 the merchants agreed to our chosen price so make sure you bargain for EVERYTHING!!Food wise we enjoyed eating from the stalls in Jamaa al fena as there was quite a lot on offer. However, this was only available in the evenings so I strongly recommend going for a Riyad/hotel with breakfast included as then you will only have lunch to worry about.We also visited the palaces and the synagogue which, although architecturally interesting, we completed in a couple of hours as there wasn't much to see.All in all it was a magical experience which I would say is a MUST if you are planning a trip to Morocco :)

Nice but!. The medina has practically everything that Fes has, but just doesn't have the character and atmosphere. An irritant is the small motor cycles buzzing around like mosquitos with the attendant fumes

Hive of activity.. The Medina is a wonderful place to visit with loads of atmosphere, places to eat, activities to watch and stalls to spend your money in. There is always something going on and loads to do. Well worth a visit.

Medina of Marrakech provides a look back into the past.
