Small shops selling all kinds of wares, sweets, lamps, locks, keys, spices, clothes, wooden artifacts, household items, I mean the list just goes on. A guide is helpful here because many of them really know the history of the place. You really feel like you have stepped back in time.

An eye opener!. Well worth a visit - We've been a few times so were prepared for the smell, the hustle and bustle, and we've learned not get eye contact unless you want to buy and how to say no thank you with a smile!

Filled with Life. So much to see in this medina and a very lively market. You will get hassled, but that's typical in these parts...but overall, plenty of things to look at and try to get outside of the central areas to see more of the local souks etc.

Excellent. We liked the incredible crafts for sale....and the array of
Morroccan carpets, especially. This was made real by the
earlier visit to Majorelle and the Musee Berber.

Trip into time. Getting into Medina is like taking time capsule into the past. No need to buy anything just look around and choose early morning when it is still not busy. Bust avoid eye contacts and do not ask about price if not planning to buy.

Not my cup of tea. Marrakesh first impressions: museums, palaces, mosques, quite pretty. The rest of the Medina: not so pretty. Busy, ditrty, old, ugly buildings and streets. We are staying out of the touristic centre in very, very modest street, slum-like neighbourhood. The Riad's room is charming, the patio nicely covered, the terrace not inviting. And everyone is trying to get money out of you: no one gives information, they sell it. You can't look once (let alone twice) at a product, and they almost jump at you to get you inside the shops. And in the enormous soufs, it is a lot of the same articles on and on: same leather bags, same lamps, same woodcraft, same pashimnas, lot's of fakes too (Nike, Victor Hugo, etc). The Medina, in general, is very poor, but you'll also find many miserable old people and single women begging or selling very simple things on the streets.

This Medina is along with other great medina's / souks in the arab world .. It has been in operation for hundreds if not thousands of years . Full of wonderful artisans trying to lure you into their tiny shops. You can find good slippers here t shirts , bags and all manner of old wares as well. Of course this is where you can get the famous Moroccan Tajines to bake in from as well. Its a labyrinth of small alleys you can easily get lost in and enjoy doing so. Some of the vendors or hawkers can be a tad aggressive so patience is required to deal with them.

Ancient, crazy, traditional and fun. A must see!. Nice to venture yourself solo, without guides, the Marrakesh's medina it's not so big and have good signalisation what makes it easy to go by.A lot of traditional shops, mixed with some not so traditional (lot's of Barcelona's and real Madrid's shirts for sale!).You don't have to take a day just to visit it, unless you're planning to shop a lot. There are a few attractions located inside the medina so you can just take your time wile going from one to another, making some detours in the way to discovery some hidden and small traditional shops (sailing spices, scarfs, tapestries and others).And yes, getting lost is part of the package. Actually I would say it´s part of the FUN and you can´t really say you made a complete visit if you don´t get lost at least for once! Also fun to interact with the salesman at shops doorsteps. They tend to be very nice and funny, always making jokes and usually spoken in lots of languages. Try not to enter the shop thou, or you will find yourself "forced" to buy something. They don't seam to have that "just looking" western costume.PS: also be alert of some strange folks sitting or standing leaning in the walls or corners offering haxixe. Although there seam to be no big trouble there. They usually don't follow the tourists and the simple act of ignoring then proves to be very effective.

Sainsbury's will never seem the same again!. We stayed in the medina for six nights and although we hate shopping with a vengeance, we never tired of walking round it. Everything is so vibrant and although, yes, there are the tourist stalls, there are also all the stalls where the locals buy their household goods. Wonderful bakers, fish counters, vegetable and meat stalls, all beautifully kept. There are still many donkeys laden with goods, as cars cannot readily pass through all the narrow streets, but the motor bikes were a bit annoying, as the seemed to pass at an alarming rate. We loved the atmosphere.

Simply Awesome!. Simply awesome, it's like stepping back in time. Many places to eat and the souq is so much fun. Don't settle for the first price, I hate bargaining, so I prefer to get a few quotes and get an idea of what I should pay for things.
Eye opener. A few to many people around for us. We didn't get to see all what we wanted but enjoyed the overall experience.
Atmospheric. people generally friendly and mostly leave you along if that's what you want. I always felt safe and prices can be very cheap especially if you haggle a bit.

The heart of Marrakesh.. Marrakesh contains an impressive number of masterpieces of architecture and art specially in the Medina.
Be careful that is so easy to lost your way in the Medina. Dont ask for information, the best way is going with a guide if you are not secure to go by yourself.
Souks. Brilliant shopping but you got to be very careful, haggle for your goods and also have a good look around before you buy.

It's a medina. Nothing out of the ordinary if you have had the chance to visit other Arabic cities.
Well worth a look though if you are in Marrakech.
The reason to come to Marocco. The whole medina is full of history. There is so much architecture, city walls, gates, mosques and palaces. And the souks for shoppers!

eating in the square. A lot of the stalls in the square sell the same food,kebabs ect but some sell real local dishes like sheeps head and tongue.We found the best places to eat was to go to the stalls with lots of locals dining,if they eat there it must be ok.Try the orange juice from the street vendors

Must see in Marrakech. The Medina is a must see in Marrakech. It feels confusing at first but is quite easy to navigate. Wander around taking in the colours and noise. Lots of touristy tat with some excellent things to buy. Stray away from the main routes for the good quality shops. Frequent mint tea stops in rooftop cafés help to keep your bearings.

Crowded, noisy but nice!. We stayed in a Riad in the Medina to have the opportunity to walk the old city, the souks and all the main attractions. It was a little bit overwhelming at first, but we got accustomed to it. I loved the architecture of the mosques and some houses, and was impressed by the variety of things sold in the souks. They really overprice everything, so always bargain, we got 70% off the original price on almost everything we bought.My recommendations: Try to walk on one side of the street, as there are bikes, motor bikes, carts, and even cars running all over. Also, wear comfortable but closed shoes, as the streets are cobbled and dirty. Use maps and gps on your phone (we used the Here app) to go around the Medina; even if you get lost, you will easily go back on track, and will prevent you from asking for directions and then being asked for money in return (this did not happen to us, but a lady we met in the riad was upset by this). If you want to get rid from a vendor, offer a really really low price, and they will leave you alone. And never ever accept presents from anyone in the souks, because they will charge you for that afterwards (we also learned this from the lady at our riad). There are some little things like these that can spoil your trip and make upset and want to leave, unfortunately that was the case of the nice lady we met in our riad. Just be careful and enjoy, as we did!
just as expected. But nicer - not too busy, 90% locally produced - so not just a shop window for China.......Best at day time (though square hots up a sunset

Dirty but interesting. Bring your own water. The city is vibrant and rather dirty. Be aware that folks offering help for no money are connected to the shops and are driving business to the shop owners. They probably get a cut of the sales. Be aware that you could get charged thousands of times over the price for goods. Buyer beware.

Senses overload. Our first day experience in the Medina wasn't the greatest, despite knowing about locals wanting money for simple directions we soon got suckered into after a couple of locals pointed us in the right direction without asking for anything, the 3rd however wasn't very pleasant, we learned that looking at your map attracts the money makers. Besides that, your senses are on a trip of a lifetime. The smells are amazing(Sometimes not), the sights are remarkable, the taste of the street food is another level, they know their way around a spice rack, the sounds of the local lingo and music is refreshing, however sometimes drowned out by the scooters. Eyes in the back of your head needed to avoid the colossal amount of scooters. I did keep my hands in my pockets a lot of time on my phone and wallet, probably being over cautious but next time I will be taking a hidden bag for important stuff. Overall a wonderful, intoxicating place. May not be for some, definitely an unforgettable experience.

Disappointing. We stayed right in the medina of Marrakech for 4 days and nights. We found it disappointing compared to Fez. The vendors are much more aggressive and you certainly can not trust their prices. You really have to be firm and be prepared to walk when bargaining with them. What REALLY was disappointing was all the scooters and motorbikes in all of the alleys of the souks...something you don't encounter at all in Fez. We continually had to go the outside of the alleys as otherwise, you would be hit with the scooter or motorbike. If you have enough time to visit both Marrakech and Fez, do so as both are different and both have something to offer. However, if you only have time to go to one city, go to Fez. There are far more shops, the merchandise is of much better quality, and you won't be hassled as much. We were not impressed with the main square at night either. The vendors during the day have to take down their stalls and restaurants and other stalls go up in the evening. Then we mainly saw knock off Chinese merchandise being sold...you know, genuine Rolex watches for like $10!!!If you get off the main square and away from all the noise and action in the evening and go down some of the smaller alleys, there are very nice restaurants in the medina of Marrakech. Overall, we were very happy with our riad, very pleased with our evening meals, but disappointed in what type of activities were in the medina. Oh, be prepared to suddenly have a snake around your neck too...without your permission!!!
Beautiful. Very beautiful medina from outside, it's a shame we cannot visit the inside, but it is well conserved and the view from the Place Jemma el Fna is great

large madina. We have toured a d stayed within several madina's on our 3 week tour of Morocco and this one was the most lively and cleaner. Snake charmers and monkey venders filled the square with all the excitement of food and material venders. Experience it as do the thousands of locals, just be very aware and ready to bargain.

A bit intimidating. Go with a tour. It's hard to enjoy the Medina. You can't just browse at the markets without being hassled. Lots of people trying to scam you... one man insisted I ate a free pastry before charging me 150D (£12) for it! The mosque in the centre is beautiful, the gates are beautiful, but I went once and wouldn't return.

A walk through the Medina is a must. Marrakech proves a feast for all the senses, and walking through the bustling souks, kasbahs & myriad tiny secret alleys you will see a culture teeming with customs as bewildering as they are colourful & exciting. You can admire the local architecture & way of life as the medina's labyrinthine souks have overwhelming sounds, smells & a distinctly medieval atmosphere. I thought it was great but wouldn't want to do it in the heat!

5 star experience ... so different from anything else!. 5 star experience ... so different from anything else! So many hawkers but beware when I was there back in 2006 they could get aggressive which sometimes gets tiring ... but that is part of the unique experience ... cool bartering system as well!!!

Busy place with very strong atmosphere. Old Medina in Marrekech is busy place full of people but with unique and very strong atmosphere. Don´t be confused with lost yourself in souks. Just enjoy the place which is a characteristic view of Marrakech. You can see some of my photos of Medina here: http://hikemyworld.com/2014/12/07/osamela-cesta-marokem-cirkus-marrakes/

1001 night. In arriving the Medina in Marrakesh you go back hundreds of year. It is very ecsotic, exating and a real experience for life. Over 1000 riads( small hotelsl with 8-12 rooms) is like oases in a city full of contrast..... I really recommended too visiti local Hammams ( one of them "1001 night") and the souks and Berbermarked give you both oportunities to take somting home and never forget voloures and smells ...like spices, flowers,argan oil, urin, goat and sheep. Its sad watchinh the dancing monkeys in dresse but is a part of the citypictures in the Medina... Remeber to carry with you marrocan dirham, but euros can be used some places. The travel agency Zbar Travel gives you the tour that is made for you.Tracking in Atlasmountains is beutiful and spectacular(4200 mao)

A working medina. The medina does not cater to tourists but is actually one where artisans are working; such as blacksmiths, cobblers and variety more. The orange juice is delicious as is the price....perhaps the lowest in all of Morocco. Only thing I did not care for where shop keepers wanting to charge for taking pictures...silly.

Great experience. Medina of Marrakech is very interesting..... If you are at Marrakech you must see. There is everything, restaurants, bars and of course many street seller who sell everything. Also, there are snake charmer. Beware when you shoot, so you can not see, otherwise they will ask you for money.

very average. I was expecting fire eaters, Jugglers & more sceptical.What we sore were a few crowds of mostly Moroccan men stood round in large circles watch other Moroccan men do some odd looking dancing.Did not do a lot me.We also tried so of the local food in the centre again very disappointing, very bland but its something you may feel you have to do at least once.

Tat & Turtles. I was looking forward to seeing the Medina but upon arrival it was a similar marketplace to many in the Arab world with no distinction (I think Turkey's Grand Bazar was better). It was busy and bustling and everyone us selling the same stuff which is usual. Still, if you haven't been anywhere like this before it can be interesting. Some of the items I wasn't impressed with however, for example, the live animals squashed into very small dirty cages -small turtles piled on top of each other! It is very sad and you want to buy them just to let them go, but don't be tempted as this would just fuel the trade more.
medina. Marrakech is a city that is divided in 2 part, the most interesting part is the old town which is all surrounded by walls with its cultural and historical monuments nearby

Beware!. There's not many bargains to be had. Don't believe a word anyone tells you. Don't get lost!!!!! Prepare to be fleeced at any opportunity! Was good to experience but for 2 ladies alone it was extremely intimidating. Most of the men are lewd and disgusting and follow you around and the women are rude!

It is a different day today!. Have enough of change in your pocket and sweets for the begging kids.Be careful where you point it at an entertainer they will want 200dh. Give them 20-50 and walk away. They will probably follow you wanting more. Don't get ripped off. (Better to take one good picture and make it count)Get used to the fact you will be hassled and be polite.A polite no thank you is much better than ignoring them. (Do no be a bad tourist). / Have a mint tea and people watch.Get you shoes well polished !!

Beautiful Mayhem. We spent days wandering around the this maze of side streets, alleys and dead ends. A great way to pass some time and soak up local culture.A couple of points to note:It gets very touristy and a little chaotic closer to the main sqaure, "the Jemaa el Fna", so best to keep a little further north if you want something a little more authentic and calm. All the guide books say that you can see the Kotoubia Mosque from anywhere in the city. This is not true in the Medina and we found it much better to work off the sun. Its generally in the south around lunch time so you can gauge which direction to go off of that. The best way we found to navigate in and out of the Medina is by the gates which surround it. Each gate or "Bab" gives you access to a different side and is a very useful way to get your bearings. Also very useful for giving taxi men directions.Asking for directions can be more trouble than its worth. If you are really stuck ask shop keepers but by enlarge asking for directions will land you with an unwanted "Guide" hanging around too long and looking for something in return for his help. Best to pull out your map and have a crack at finding it yourself.
Full of life. Full of life and mystery and bargains. Liked the feeling and the many things to do. I didn't like coming home.

World Class!. An amazing place. Where else in the world can you find amazing food, Berber carpets, gold, silver, spices, and snakes all within a block or two? You are going to be hassled for money, people are not going to want you to photograph them, and you are going to encounter a hundred other obstacles that might make this an uncomfortable experience. However all of these same things are the things that you are going to remember when you get home as the reason why this place is so amazing.If I could go back, I would plan on spending a whole day here, starting at 9 am when the market is empty and staying until night when all of the shops close. It's an amazing place and you will wish that you had seen it all.
Breathtaking. The medina was absolute heaven ,you can get lost in it's amazing walls and a whole day goes by without you even noticing.Absolute must,you can't not come here when in Morocco.
Take a Taxi. No names of streets, you are allways lost. The "guides" aggressively wanting money, do not take a fotograf of a wrong door.

Unpleasant experience, feels like a tourist trap. I did not enjoy my experience. Did not like getting hassled to look at things when you show any interest by just looking when you walk past! Can no one window shop first? I loved taking in the colours and the vibrancy and the atmosphere, but felt very intimidated, as I only wanted to window shop first! And wary of taking photos, as feel you have to ask permission, or have to pay to do so! Hated being approached all the time by "guides" offering to show you where to go, asking for payment, and giving bad advice, perhaps a miscommunication or language issue. Do not be conned into being told it is a last day of an auction for leather goods, and then taken through a maze of streets for 20 minutes, to get to a tannery, which was revolting and sickening, and then to a shop selling leather goods, who's staff were unfriendly, rude and got aggressive when you bargained and did not buy. Then the person at the tannery had the cheek to ask for payment for taking you there and then snatching the money from your hands, when my friend asked how much and showed some money in her hands. If it had been a pleasant experience, I would gladly have paid, but as it was I felt very mislead and uncomfortable.
Amazing Area. An absolute must on any visit to the city. Avoid eye contact if you don't want to buy or haggle. Be prepared to get lost repeatedly.

Brilliant!. A complete bombardment to the senses!! Action EVERYWHERE!! People, motorbikes, donkey carts, vendors, souks, food, sights, smells, sounds... magical experience!! Vendors are all about selling their wares to tourists, but you are always greeted with warmth, hospitality, and generosity! Can be very intense and tiring...and you simply HAVE to negotiate EVERYTHING! It can be very exhausting but not to be missed!

Great shopping. We enjoyed the hustle and bustle of the medina, you can buy some brilliant souvenir trinkets for your home, it's even better when you get to haggle, just know your limit and what the price your paying is want you want, haggle hard with a smile and you'll get the price you want! Some lovely places to eat here too.
nice. I liked it. I felt I was in Arabia.....I loved the musicians, the snake charmers, the acrobats the storytellers, orange stands and the restaurants.

Medina. The weather spoilt it for us, we didn't really stay out too long. Don't be duped into going to see the tannery. We were taken on a very long walk, to see the tannery then taken to a leather shop quality wasn't good. There is a Goverment shop a little pricey for leather goods - you don't get hassle.

Exciting and vibrant. Go the the medina barter hard and have fun. Lovely leather goods and traditional morrocan things. Beautiful carpets. We did not encounter any problems obviously they are not going to like it if you make them show you their whole range if you are not going to buy but are happy for you to look. It can get a bit annoying when the shop keepers keep trying to make you look at things but just say no be firm but polite.
Tourist heaven?. The Medina and souks are great fun but you need to enjoy haggling. The food in the square on the stalls in the evening is not great but I guess it is part of the experience.

Medina of Marrakech Morocco. A trip to the medina in Marrakech is simply...an experience. There is so much going on, so many shops and small eateries and artisans working their trade. A visit here allows you to live the way the Moroccans have for many generations. Definitely wrth a visit.

Part of guided tour... Interesting tour, bit of hassle by the locals but this is to be expected and had friendly fun haggling with them. Clean compared with some areas of Marakech. Mopeds and scooters everywhere. This Medina was, in my view the most interesting part of the old city..

Wonderful. We had just arrived from Fez where we stayed and visited the medina there. Marrakech Medina is much easier to navigate and you don't get hassled as much. Prepare to get lost or allow someone to take you around - for a fee of course.

Dirty, busy & hard to drive in. We took a Taxi from the airport. They line up outside & call out asking if you need a taxi as you walk by. Charged us per person plus bags! But they started by telling us it was 100 dh, then when we said ok, they said 200dh because 2 of us. We thought that was ok, just a miss understanding but once we were in the car he mentioned price for bags. He wouldn't say how much. Then when we got out of the car it cost us 250dh (from airport to riad mogadar). We took a taxi from the hotel back to the airport to get our rental car the next morning, the hotel called one for us and we were only charged 100 dh total for both of us AND our bags! lol. And we noticed (when it was light out) that there are taxis just across the lane way from the main doors (just up a couple steps) and I'm sure we could have gotten them for cheaper.

Must experience. Markets are full of local trades and many bargains to be had if you can haggle! Friendly locals more than willing to give directions etc for a small fee! Not so good if you just want to look though!

Exciting place the Medina. You simply have to spend some days in the bustling bussiness of the Medina where you can either do some good bussiness or you can be taken for a ride. It is great fun haggling the prices and above all it is expected of you to do so. Find herbs, leathergoods, silverware, just about anything at marvellous prices and enjoy the atmosphere. Eat a meal in the Djemaa el-Fna market Square and buy a glas of freshly pressed orangejuice.
Shoppers paradise. no expensive stores here just thousands of market stalls in a never ending maze of winding alleys. great atmos!!
A different place. Incredible colors and wonderful atmosphere in this part of Marrakech. Different from anything seen so far. A place to lose yourself for a few hours.

Fun frenzy. Djemaa el Fna square is the best part of the Marrakech medina. The souks get a bit boring with hundreds of stalls with very similar offer. Ok for a day but one can soon get tired of saying "no thanks". The buzz is in the square and I only wish one could watch it and take it all in without being constantly hassled. The cafés on the terraces are an option, but a bit too far!
Jamaa al Fena. I suppose it is atmospheric however it is turning into a tourist trap bought dried figs from the souk much better deal that the Fena

Great shopping. The prices are great, but you need to know how to bargain, otherwise is gonna be expensive for you. The variety of prodcuts os not the best quality, but you can find many nice things for presents, or just as souvenirs.
i loved the medina. this is all Marrakech! Go here to sample the Real Morocco! Be prepared to haggle hard though. The sellers like to feel that they had a good barter with you!

Almost back in biblical times. A great place to visit , but be prepared for rather smelly whiffs from drains and dusty uneven cobbled streets. Streets are very narrow so take care of scooters cars and bikes whizzing past you. This is the real Marrakech and it should not be avoided if you want to see street life. The Medina is like going back in time. Like everywhere in the old part of Marrakech you will be hassled to come into shops , eateries etc . This is their livelihood and part of the Marrakech experience . We stayed in a Riad , lovely small palaces hidden behind big boring stone walls ....but when you are inside they can be exquisite. Choose a 5 star graded one , but remember their grading system is not the same as ours !

Market Madness. This could not be further removed from what we live with in Liverpool.Its a step back in time, and you have to experience it first hand to understand.The walled city is like something out of a film set, and the Souks contained within, as a sight to behold.

A mixture of a very nice feeling with friendly people.. The medina is like a labyrint. Small and narrow streets and easy to get lost. I believe you like or you dont. But do try. The people are in general nice and says Bonjour if you give them a smile. I liked the mixture of adults and children playing drums. Bikes, mc and wagons with donkeys. People everywhere.

Our guide around Marrakech. We had a half day tour with Mustapha from Urban Adventures. Brilliant, he really made it a special tour for us. He showed us the main attractions and gave us so much information but also made it so interesting and he was very witty as well. He gave us the confidence to just go out there and enjoy the atmosphere, the souks and the people. Wonderful thank you Mustapha.

Hagglers paradise!. It's definitely somewhere to go and see everything in one place. Snake charmers, performers, markets and guides who will show you around however you must be willing to observe and deal with sometimes intense shop keepers or women grabbing your wife's hand to paint henna without permission on her hand or children asking for change. After the first day you become a little immune to it and can take in the whole atmosphere. We will go again however only make eye contact with the stores or performers we wish to see .

Crazy!. Amazing energy is this bustling district of Marrakech. Make sure you have your bargaining hat on - managed to buy a beautiful rug from less than half of the original asked price. A little unnerving for a foreigner at night in the quieter back streets, but locals are friendly and happy to direct you if you ask!

Crazy Good!. Souks, mosques, horse-drawn carriages, snake charmers, henna masters, food stands, fresh orange juice, cafes, narrow streets, a huge square full of action, fancy hotels, small riads, and every mode of transportation you can imagine! That is the Medina. Ancient walls enclose this old part of Marrakesh.

Not what I expected.. Very glad I went as I have seen many travel shows highlighting this as an exciting destination. Please be prepared for the bad smell - the travel shows didn't mention this..... Very entertaining but be prepared to pay, all the snake charmers and monkey tamers etc all want to be paid a couple of euros. Glad I went - certainly an eye opener

Good in parts very bad in others.. If you don't want to see squalor dirt and poverty don't go anywhere near the tannery or the eastern side of the Medina. Stepping out of the beautiful Riad into the street was like stepping out of a time machine and going back 2000 years with dirt in the streets and beggars lying around and constant hassle by them and the shopkeepers and Resturant owners particularly eastern side of the square and Medina. Down by the Kasbah to the south it was much more pleasant cleaner and with less begging and hassle.
Wandering through the souks. Strolling around the square and the souks was interesting. It was surprisingly un-touristy. At least 90 percent of the people we saw were locals.

Very busy, but lots to see. The place is first and foremost a tourist trap, every Tom, Dick and Harry wants to show you something or sell you something. The snake charmers, monkey holders and water sellers are all ways of extracting money from you, as are the fortune tellers, the henna woman and the beggars..... These are the downfalls. The upside is the large number of stalls and streets, many times we were recognised and eventually starting having banter with the guys out there, not just getting hassled. We spent many days going round and round, that is because there is so much and so many places to walk that you didn't know existed. Food stalls are aplenty, as are cafes, try some snails too, go on you only live once!!
So much to see, smell and hear. This was great fun, local people living their lives, very few obvious tourists - a really fun day out.

A Very Different Experience from the Fes Medina. Our group visited Marrakech as the last town on our Moroccan tour. I had been looking for special fabric for a family member throughout the tour, and finally found lovely turquoise woven fabric at a good price and from very friendly and courteous merchants in a tiny shop. I also found beautiful braided trim in another small and crowded store, to go with the fabric, and then bought a prettily trimmed pants set elsewhere for my seven-year-old great granddaughter.The part of the Marrakech medina closest to the main square wasn't quite my cup of tea. Yes, you could find oodles of kitschy souvenirs and all sorts of totes with "Morocco" written across them, but I found the goods to be more interesting further into the medina, and away from the snake charmers and tourist snacks. I liked this medina a lot, but it didn't have the same, historical feel for me as the one in Fes. Maybe it's just me.

You're not in Kansas anymore. It's right out of an Indiana Jones movie. A huge square, with exotically dressed locals, colorful dancing groups, weird food booths sporting everything from pigs heads to mountains of snails. Snake charmers blow their instruments while their pet cobras and rattlesnakes dance to their music. But don't take their picture unless you want to part with some cash. Enforcers circle the snake charmers area looking for tourists trying to take a freebie shot of the snake act. If they catch you plan to be shook down for more than if you volunteered in the first place.It's easy to get lost in the maze of alleys that form the souks and some areas are downright creepy. Some of the areas have workshops where they make all sorts of cheap tourist items, but again don't take their pictures unless you want to make a financial donation. Most of the really high end stores and most interesting stores are deep into the souks, so don't be afraid to explore, but leave a breadcrumb trail so that you can find your way out. There are some good restaurants in the plaza, look for the ones that are busy and look at their menu and prices.... some are very reasonable. You won't find any beer or wine here so plan on tea or a soda, although I saw some vendors traveling the restaurant tables selling bottles of something that looked like beer in a recycled containers. restroom facilities are available at most of the restaurants on the square and are in decent condition.I wouldn't travel alone here at night, but that's me. We only had a couple of hours here, I could have spent a couple of days exploring. Definitely the highlight of Marrakech.

Europe abuts on Africa. There is more than Tongue can tell in this central Medinah. No disappointments at all as food and every requirement and option are around the stalls. Spices and dried fruits by the ton. Eat out in the square - an experience ++. No 1 for meat and No 14 for Fish.

Interesting !!. Very busy, especially at night, quite a spectacle. Beware of so called guides who will ambush you & pretend to show you a direction then fully expect to be paid at the end of it. Out experience cost us the equivalent of £50.
Marrakesh. Square a bit disappointing for me to be honest its all a tourist trap and a rip off. Souks and medina far better
ambiance. I love the feeling of that place! Now it's easier to go without being bothered by "guides" I have lots of memories there from my childhood

Travel in the Souks. This was a wonderful experience, remember, "everyone gets lost in the Medina". We felt perfectly safe at all times, the "barkers" are not aggressive, but fun in trying to get you into their stores to buy. Lovely merchandise. Do not forget to buy Moroccan tea (as I did forget) and a hammered teapot to take home.

Worth seeing it once. I read many reviews about the Medina and the souks before our trip so I knew what to expect. We had a guide for half a day on our first day which I would recommend as he showed us around and pointed good spots to catch taxis a bit further away from the square to avoid rip offs. As other reviewers have said here, the Medina is a bit of a crazy place, with lots of people, smells- good and bad, donkey carts, mopeds etc. so you have to be alert and keep your wits with you especially in the evening to avoid being run over or hassled too much by the sellers. We did not experience any aggressive selling or rude behavior and this could be because my partner is a big hulky guy (on a few occassions they shouted Van Damme after him in a good humored way which was quite funny and made us all laugh), or it could be that our firm ''no thank you''- s were enough to leave us alone. In any case, showing (or pretending) that you know what you are doing helps. We enjoyed haggling and bought a few nice things at a good price. One thing I would say, and I think it has been said here before, is don't start haggling for the sake of it and then leaving without buying anything. This is def not liked and I get that as no one wants their time wasted. We deliberately tried to 'get lost' in the souks but somehow always managed to end up in the main square, finding hidden little streets in the process. We just looked around and tried to memorise spots which seemed to help.The Medina is a tiring experience though, having to stay alert all the time and all. Only if they just let you be! That would make such a difference! I don't think we would return to the Medina and Marrakesh but it was worth going once to see something different.

Don't miss this. We went around with a guide so I guess we covered a lot of the medina in one full day. I read somewhere that some of cities in this part of the world was built so that attackers should get lost. This is exactly the feeling you have when you are guided around the medina, you loose the sense of location directly. I guess that if you walk on your own it is not that difficult to get back to the main square or one of the gates. And it is not big enough to get seriously lost.The medina is a wonderful experience with all the different kinds of people, shops, homes, motor bikes, donkeys and horses. The nice thing with a guide is that you may get to see some things out of the ordinary like the man tending the fire that keeps the hammam warm and the inside of a bakery. The sad thing is that you get to see other things out of the ordinary like the poultry shops with live animals in the back, slaughtered on a bench with the owners daughter sitting beside him on the bench eating her luncheon bread. I guess that these are the kinds of places where the bird flu makes its species hops.

Overwhelming experience. The overall medina is quite complex and confusing and can be overwhelming at times. The key is to stay calm, enjoy, and remember that this too is all part of the experience of Marrakech. There is lots to do in the main square and shopping wise. To me, however, site seeing was limited to either shopping or the main square. The only other activities were the Saadin tombs and then hammams. Thr central area could use a couple museums that are higher quality with art and/or history - something like the one at thr Jardin Majorelle. Don't let this put you off from going by any means - just is my thought on future improvements for the area.

What a Experience. Well worth a vist,we went on a tour by ourselves no map just of we went,dont worry about getting lost you will find your way around.Embrace your sences,the sounds,smells and the culture this will be something you will never forget that i can assure you.

Not to be missed. Stay close by in a riad for authenticity. a guide is not essential with a reasonable sense of direction. Google maps on a phone are not detailed but at least the position arrow can be useful.We found it safe for women even after dark but watch out for men seeking to become your guide.

Very very different. Incredible place. Never been anywhere quite like this before. After the first night when we got our bearings were were blown away by the culture and the different activities going on.Everything from walking down the small alleys and getting list to watching the snake charmers and the monkeys in the main square. Every corner you turn has something different to offer
Just get lost. Fun to wonder around and get lost..... would advise that you buy a decent map as the one provide by the hotel was not to scale and lacked detail.

Main reason to visit Marrakech!. You can spend days on end in the medina and find new places, streets. There are plenty of sights to see, spas/hammans to visit plus of course the souks. It almost seems like another reality!

Old Medina is way better than New. Old Medina is like a lost world. It's a big, dirty, busy maze full of culture, sights and everyday 'city-life' activities. You just have to embrace it and "swim with the current"... So to speak. Overall, be prepared to gets lost but has way more character than New Medina.

The only place to stay in Marrakech.... .... we believe, if you want to truly experience the old town of Marrakech. Experience the sights. sounds and smells of this unique place. You won't be disappointed.

A tour you will not forget. Sarting at Jamaâ El Fna Square, where everything happens, merge into the maze of narrow streets, the several "babs" = doors, the endless shops, the amazing colours, the aroma of spices and the sight of delicous sweets! The Medina is a UNESCO World Heritage we must care for.

See Life Before your very Eyes. Great place for food, entertainment & just crowd watching. Air fills with cooking smells, drums of music, singing & dancing creating celebration all around. Coupled with Cafes & Shops selling just about everything exotic.

Marrakech of the old days. dont be shy and make the effort to get lost !!!! Not that difficult in fact ! But as soon as you are, you'll find exciting areas, typical local markets, smiling locals and very little assle ! Only advice : be careful taking pictures, some local people dont like it too much !
Wow!. What an experience it is to spend time in the medina. Lots of atmosphere, excitement and people...great food at night when the restaurants come out...we ate at number 41 - fantastic.

Very Dangerous. Just don't go. There is nothing in there that you want or need. There are lots of con men and very bad people in there who will get you lost and disorientated and then demand money to get you out again. Even when you do give them money they just direct you back into the place again to be picked up by someone else. Its a massive sewer so best stay as far away from it as possible.

square. its safe but they never tell you prices before giving your hand the bag or what ever you are interested in its almost impossible to learn a price and continue shopping MUST do bargain. they start the asking price minimum 2 times more the value. Locals are good and cool people. Very beutiful and friendly girls. Very good clubs and hotels.
Medina. Roof top restaurantsThe hum drumThe atmosphereThe bargainsNot the snake charmers although part of the scene

Easier than Fes. Much easier to navigate than Fes thanks to its intelligent design. A straight walkway runs through the centre of the Medina with intersecting passages every 20 metres or so which are dead ends on either side. Impossible to get lost as you will just turn around at the end. The shopping is magnificent and be SURE that you barter!!! Don't be afraid to walk away if you don't want to pay the price, you will find another stall that sells similar items.

beware. its a wonderful Place BUT beware of the friendley boys who want to show directions...they charge uoy PLENTY and in you argue they get hostile and gather friends and make shure you pay plenty for almost nothing
Thrilling. I am a woman with long Blonde hair and I was wary of the unwanted attention. I did not have any problems and really enjoyed the culture within the square and the souks.
Very interesting. unfortnately they want Money from you everywhere. You must be prepared to pay for everything, so if you don't want that, rather don't take a photo of anything.

terrifyingly beautiful. What a beautiful sight to see- so exciting and energetic with all the sounds of drums, chanting, singing, praying, monkeys, snakes, camels, stalls with beautiful lanterns and tagines, mirrors, false teeth, spices. Then you get the 'helpful' locals taking you down quiet streets for 15 minute walks away from the exciting town square with gang signs/murals on the walls, kids running about, locals constantly staring at you shouting things. Not to mention the traffic. You really need to have your wits about you when you come here unless you stick to the hotel or tourist areas. Great place, but just be careful.
Worth a try. It was soooo busy and easy to get lost - which we did - should have hired a guide. But on the plus side a definite experience
Old Guys Rule. Amazing smells and colours of products on offer. Not hassled too much, everyone very pleasant, so an enjoyable experience.

Not for me. I imagine that people love it or hate it. I hated it. You can't stop and look at anything because 10 people pounce on you. I hated the whole experience, felt sorry for the animals I saw (monkeys on leads, donkeys and camels chained at the roadside for tourists). Don't encourage them.

Souks and stalls great fun. Engage in conversation with the locals and yes they are all after your money but why. Not its a tough life Stalls set up each evening , no dirty kitchen corners food fresh and cooked to your order ,good value

Do not miss, worth paying for a guide. The only way to see and properly appreciate this area is to have a guide. In our case this was arranged by our Riad and only cost 300 dirham for 3 hours for the two of us. By doing it this way we saw much more than we would have seen on our own and had an explanation of what we wanted. Having done it this way were happy to revisit on our own later.

Busy as always. you do not dare to look at anything with even a hint of inetrest before being hassled, but you knew that before going there..... prices are not that good. Tat everywhere....do you really need those things on display? Buildings worth looking at but boring being hassled.

Use GPS and a local SIM to get there. - read how. We liked Medina and like to share how to get there. Since navigation can be difficult. Use your GPS and Google Maps with your mobile and a local SIM.As we did some traveling in Marocco, we have been looking for details on GPS navigation in Marocco. And wanted telephone and intenet. We did not find a lot of usefull information on the internet. So let's share with you our experience. In the end it is very simple and cheap! And you defenately need help with Navigation in Marokko. There is no information, or it is written in Arab. We had a car but also needed it in cities to find places. It all went well thanks to INWI and Google Maps.TOMTOM? NO!We rented a Tomtom GPS in the Netherlands with a map of Marocco. Our experience: not usefull at all. It did not know locations, only some bigger streetnames. Worse, it did not know a lot of roads. It leaves you with very, very high level information and it is impossible to work with. Mostly you don't have a street name and the street are very confusing in Maroc.INWIThe smartest thing to do is to buy a local SIM card for your smartphone in Marocco. We bought it upon arrival at the Marrakesh airport, near the car rental desks. There is a INWI desk (Purple sign). Go there, pay 120 dirham (about €11 - $15) for the 100 dirham INWI card: ZEN CONNECT. The man behind the desk installed the simcard on our phone and made it work instandly. If you buy this card, only buy it in a place were they install it and make it work directly. We have seen more Purple INWI shops in Marocco. This gives you for 30 days:- 3 hours national phone calls- 1 GB data (mobile internet)- 1000 sms- we even used it to call to the Netherlands and it worked!Internet was not as fast as I am used to in The Netherlands, but he.... It is fast enough!GOOGLE MAPSOn our phone (with INWI) we used Google Maps. It is much more easy because you can enter nanes of restaurants, accomodations, atractions, places of interest, etc. It will find the place and take you there. You sometimes have to play a little but we did find everything we were looking for! Even restaurants in small streets in Medina Marrakech. It knows almost all little (ofroad) streets.USE IT and SHARE this informationIn our 10 days visit we were so happy we had this SIM that gave us directions, mobile internet and telephone. Whitout it we would have been lost. Or worse, victim of all the "local friends", (we call hustlers) that give you tips and directions. Not always good and always costing you money! Now it was easy to find our own way or check information and prices directly on the internet.Happy Traveling!

Amazing but intimidating. totally chaotic and full of intrigue. Loads to see, but almost afraid to look! First visit was spent trying to keep my mind on getting my bearings while avoiding eye contact with any of the stall holders! Then, as I settled down, felt more comfortable being able to haggle prices. So much to see, loads of lovely stalls. Don't be afraid to walk away if they don't give you a decent price, there is loads of choices on other stalls. Super spices, oils, olives, dates, scarves, bags, too many things to mention. All housed in tiny alleyways with passing cyclists, motorbikes, donkeys, simply wonderful chaos. I loved the experience, but always had a bit of anxiety while there!

wonderful area. The 11th century wall as we were told is stunning.. Ignor people who travel here without doing any homework. The whole point of visiting is the madness, the pestering, of which I was surprised how friendly and non aggressive their tactics were, the smells!4Its eye opening and needs embracing. I am not a normal heart of the action type of person but its fun if u know what you are doing and remember you came to experience different!

crazy. be prepared to be hassled a lot .. but you just have to be firm and say no not interested .. and dont let them lead you anywhere as they start rushing you about . they told me the cash machine was just round the corner so i folloed him and it took 15 minutes fast waliking to get to it.

Busy. Glad I've seen this, but the traffic, diesel/petrol and horse urine smells took the edge of the visit. Very busy, but I think this is a standard thing, especially at night. The people were quite helpful & friendly, but not a place I personally would re-visit.

Really my gripe is with the souks... not the Medina!. The truth is I have no gripe with the Medina which I guess is the walled city other than the insane traffic and the diesel pollution and overpowering smell of horse urine on the approach to the main carriage stand. Its the Souk's as such that I found impossible to enjoy. In general I'm a compulsive shopper but found it a total pain being constantly hassled with the result that I didn't purchase anything. Which was pretty frustrating as if I'd been able to shop at leisure I would have made a lot of purchases returned home with a lot of excess baggage and done the Moroccan economy a lot of good. In saying that I had the privilege of engaging some of the shopkeepers in conversation and they would like things to be more laid back but there's so much competition for business they've no option other than hassle every potential customer they can get their hands on.

Lots of tips esp for solo female traveller . Like all medinas they are vast maze and soooo easy to get lost - Marrakech more so as it's bigger and has more cultural and culinary delights then the other medinas. Def book a guide first day it's way to get some orientation and knowledge of the area. They will also be able to take to to the souks that u are interested In. Also they can point out locations of interesting cultural sights which like everything are hard to find. If your time is limited a guide is essential, they are accredited and are always locals (part of the accreditation).I stayed for 5days at the end of a 2 weeks tour. The guide was a really great way to start - made me more comfortable exploring on my own.Ladies do be respectful esp if your your own - I wore mid to long pants, loose tops that at least covered my shoulders, at night I wore a scarf and felt safe wandering the medina on my own.You will get hassled/pressured to buy and come across some rude annoying people. It is frustrating and stressful sometimes, I don't deny it especially if you are staying in the medina. However, they are the minority and mostly the haggling and banter is good fun commerce. Don't be afraid to check out some of the riads w courtyards and/or rooftop terraces that host cafés or restaurants -often u will walk thru a carpet or other shop politely decline as they are often lead to a hidden oasis - good idea to do this during the day so hopefully you can find it a bit easier if you come back at night! For the more budget travelers - you simply must treat yourselves to a couple nights in a good riad - you get brilliant Moroccan hospitality (I found the staff in cheaper hotels in new towns throughout morocco exceptionally rude) the riad also it's a great respite from the hustle and bustle that is Marrakech. One the most memorable palaces - yes it was palatial- I have ever stayed in. Find yourself a good Hamaam again do this in daylight it's a great evening activity esp if you are on your own. I did a one on one cooking class with riad that also took me to the markets to purchase ingredients - a great local experience. (Riad Kniza)I have read reviews good and bad - I think it is what u make of it and how you behave with locals that makes the difference. After a couple of day I was waving and chatting to familiar faces in the medina, invited for countless glasses of mint tea from shopkeepers to have a chat not to buy, on my last day I was getting hugs goodbye and even got a lift on a motorcycle back to the riad I stayed in! Oops forgot Photos - Moroccans do not like their photos taken as a rule. Chat to your guide usually it's a lot easier to snap away and they will explain the I would always ask a shop keeper even if I had bought something it's usually about respect not money except at Jemaa el-Fnaa it's all about money there- it's also serves as an anchor I would always find my way back there when lost. Don't let that put you off - by day it does not look much by night it's exciting and vibrant to explore. Tipping is everything in Morocco, hard to get use to but a way of life. A lot if deeds will be expected to be rewarded with a tip Eg It's usually easy to figure out who is really giving directions and those hoping to get a few dirhams. I would address this politely early on to avoid any dramas. Always carry some small change. It's a long review but I hope it helps especially single female travelers - it also applies to all the medinas I visited. Oops last tip - can't remember what they are called but find yourself one of the fruit salad/smoothie cafés in new town the drinks/fruit salads are a meal in themselves - these places are true local hang and for good reason as they are delicious and like nothing I have seen before. (Ask you your guide)

Beautiful history. The place is crazy. The best we did was to take a guided walking tour on our first day so we understood how Marrakech works, safety, main squares and bargain techniques.I've been to Cairo and I can say I've felt safer in Marrakech (safer than little villages in Brazil - my native country).At first, this place is intimidating but slowly you learn their culture and way of life.This place is such an experience and worth a walking visit.

Book a guide.. The Medina of Marrakech is wonderful. There are so many interesting and beautiful things to buy, and probably much cheaper than back home. The reason that I awarded an average score is that it is impossible to navigate your way around and we ended up getting massively lost. Many of the locals charge for directions so we could not ask for help. Therefore I did not get a chance to properly look around and buy anything.My only regret about my trip to Marrakech is that I didn't have enough time to visit here again. I am sure if I had visited again I would have loved it. If your time in Marrakech is limited, book a guide so that you do not miss out.

Tourist trap. Although it is part of this culture felt like its been commercialised and feel like the locals want to pull wool over your eyes ! Would like to have purchased more of the genuine local crafts but left after 2 hours - found the haggling quite waring

You must experience the bazaar! But be cautious!. I loved the medina and its bazaar. A lot of sights, things to see and local culture and ambiance. You can shop and haggle for your souvenirs here. Before you go to the bazaar one suggestion: go to the local souvenir shop and price the goods there. The locals that are hocking their wares here are quick to mark up and charge more to the unsuspecting tourist! Once you know what is a fair price in the souvenir shop you have a basis to start your haggling. Offer about 1/2 of what you would pay in the souvenir shop and work your way up from there. The locals can be very aggressive and a bit scary at first, but once you stand your ground an offer a fair price they will quickly accept. I had one experience where an aggressive monkey owner put his monkey on my shoulder and let me pet him and then demanded about $20.00 for the experience! I offered him $5.00 and he kept pushing for the $20.00 at which point I started to leave and he gladly accepted the $5.00.The food is authentic and quite tasty. The people are glad to help for a $ or two. Music, snake charmers and locals make it well worth-while.The cemetery is worth seeing The medina and narrow streets can be a bit intimidating yet gives you a feel for the culture and how they live.

Interesting experience. The experience is totally different, you will find everything from food to furniture, from textiles to jewellery, but don't believe everything they tell you in fact don't believe anything. Bargaining is the rule, don't be afraid to go to quarter the price, and walk away, they will follow pretending to be hurt. That's the game, enjoy it, we did and reduced one of our purchases from 1,600 to 400 and I believe they still made a large profit. Be aware the area is very large and it is very easy to get lost, but don't be put off the experience is worth it.

Worth a visit. Be prepared to be pestered!! Its worth a visit to tick that you've been to Jemma el Fna. Nothing special other than rows of stalls selling anything and everything. Avoid eating there at night time!!

place to see. I like the place, it is very interesting, different, something what you must see when in Marrakesh
I do not like that if you need to find way, locals are not really helpful.

You can find anything you want in the Medina of Marrakech. Honestly, you can find ANYTHING here, from food to musical instruments, luggage, clothing, textiles, camel yarn, teeth, ANYTHING. And it is a great experience following the narrow pathways among the friendly vendors offering delicious mint tea, and eager to bargain for treasures... be prepared to bargain - it's expected and appreciated!

Not too late to correct. Clearly i hope i will be read by officials : merchants are becoming more and more agressive, even insulting the tourists who are not buying or buying enough. Right behaviour to ruin Marrakech reputation.

Unreal experience!. It took me a little while to actually get used to this place. Its completely foreign for me and was a massive culture shock. There are people EVERYWHERE. Singing, dancing, selling stuff, begging, people with monkeys, birds, lizards, snakes, squirrels - everything you can think of is pretty much in this place!Its also a complete shock to your system in terms of what you're going to see and smell and hear. There is just so much going on its difficult to know where to look and what to do if you're not used to it! Be brave though - this is an amazing cultural experience that you cannot miss.We went through the market on our own as my husband is a big guy and is pretty experienced with these sort of markets - but if you're a newbie, or on your own I would highly recommend that you invest in a tour guide. They are pretty inexpensive, and will help ensure that you don't get hassled or led astray by people who want you to go visit their shop/business. A couple of tips what we were given which I thought I'd pass on to you are:1) Don't eat the food, and drink bottled water - We were told by our hotel guide that they cook with water that is basically sewerage water. That being said - the Lonely planet guide tells you to try the food. If you're brave go ahead and do it (the food looks and smells amazing), but if you're like me and have a tender belly, don't do it - as tempting as it is.2) As a lady I was worried about covering my head in respect for the culture and religion. It really wasn't necessary as most people seemed pretty OK with modern women from other countries and religions. Just to be safe (and respectful) though - I wore long pants and a sleeved shirt, and carried a scarf with me just to be sure. I never had a problem and never needed the scarf.3) Be aware that you're most likely going to see things that aren't like home. I did see some things that made me sad. This is a poor country - lots of beggars and lots of very sick people on the streets without footwear etc. There was also some animals in cages that I didn't really approve of. I think if I had known that this was the case I would have mentally prepared and then wouldn't have been so upset. So I'm warning you now. This is a cultural experience and things are not like what they are at home.4) Don't trust anyone! Especially if you chose to go alone. People will come and follow you and tell you that they will be your guide, and that they work for your hotel and are here to help them. Or they might come and tell you that there is a 'Big sale!' nearby that you have to go and look at. Just be polite, and kindly tell them that you're ok. Or if they won't leave you alone just lie and tell them you've found your destination or whatever. Or tell them that you're a local and don't need a guide. 6) Know your currency, and take some small change so you can enjoy the buskers - There is so much to see! And heaps you'll want to interact with. Pretty much EVERYTHING costs though - so take some small change to pay the snake charmer for a photo - or give a tip to the ladies doing the henna. You can't watch or interact without paying something. Also make sure you know the exchange rate so you don't get ripped off while bartering. Someone tried to charge us the equivalent of $100AU for a tshirt thinking we didn't know what 700 durha was (we ended up actually getting it for about $10).Most of all enjoy your time here. Take the time to really explore and chat with the locals and pick up some awesome bargains! I would LOVE to go back again and do some more shopping. Have fun!

Medina visit. I was a little disappointed with the Medina, i did not find the traditional crafts being carried out, there was mainly shops some with impressive displays. My wife began to take a photo of one such display of fruit and was shouted at by the owner, not too friendly. Needless to say we bought nothing from him! We were taken into a pharmacy and given a talk on all the products they had. They could cure everything! At the end of the talk came the sales pitch, everything was well overpriced. One interesting feature on the doors in the Medina was that there were 2 knockers, 1 on the small door for the use of family and another one on the outer door for traders.

So Much Fun, but Hire a Private Guide. Be sure to book a guide through your hotel or agency. Those on the streets are not licensed and will lead you astray. It is a very complex web of buildings and you may not find your way all the way in or out without a guide. So much to see and most Souks give special presentations to you without pressure in their presence. You will see the best the Medina has to offer. Absolute must. It is the essence of Marrakech.

unbelvieable. my wife and myself went to the medina a little bit nervous of eat there ,but we went for it and very pleased we did .i got mixed grill my wife got chicken skewers these came with chips ,salad and with dips and bread,plus free mint tea.you sit and watch the world go by ,snake charmers, belly dancers ,fire eaters the lot all for £7 .

Crazy!. The best word to describe this place is crazy! there is so much going on all the time a definite feast for all of your senses. Watch out for the henna ladies and the pastry man they will try to rip you off
Fantastic cultural experience. Liked the whole shopping and cultural experience. The small tight alleyways and road with the hustle and bustle of everyday life.

Must see: the Souks. 300.000 people life in the Medina of Marrakech - the old part of town. Thousands of shops sell everything imaginable. Lots of people work in small cubicles producing anything from shoes, belts, metal-works, wooden pieces etc. All prices can and must be negotiated. As a rule of thumb start with one fifth of what the vendor asks...

So much fun!. Yes, it's hectic. Yes, the streets are like a maze. Yes, it's confusing. But it's so much fun! Don't take anything too seriously. Take note of stores and landmarks as you walk, so you can find your way back. Take in the sites, the sounds and the smells of this unique place...this is a cultural experience you will always remember!
Be preapred to bet lost. Exciting the first time you visit. After that, you don't find it that appealing.Besides that, you will get lost more than once. But totally worth the experience!

Hustle and bustle. Love the sounds of the souks and the opportunity to haggle with the traders although we know they always win. Just about everything is available for a price. Go down the side streets day or night without feeling afraid. The main square is very commercial and mainly comprised squeezed orange juice sellers and men with monkeys and snakes. Be prepared to pay for taking photos of the scene. No need to spend long here as it really all happens in the alleys. Thoroughly enjoyable.

The opposite of Fes. Less hectic and confusing than the medina at Fes and best done with a guide. This was where we could find the exact spices we were after to cook tagine style back home. It is a picture takers paradise with snake charmers, musicians, and of course cats everywhere. The assortment of leather goods was exceptional in the small shops and tannery.
best souks I ve ever seen. the souks and the Jemma el Fna are outstanding experiences in marrakech. Even you dont want to buy anything - it is pitoresk to visit this places.

Get a good map!. Too many annoying husslers to really enjoy the experience. Tried not to look lost but often had to double back from dead ends. Better at night - more relaxed shopping. Got better at bartering with practice.

Medina Marrakech. This is such a brilliant place the atmosphere is second to none. Just wander, look, listen and soak up all the great smells. its like a wonderland in the evening. I would describe it as a child's first trip to disneyland. I was so excited. Sit in one of the many rooftop cafes and enjoy the panoramic views.

You will need several visits to cover......... The Medina of Marrakech comprises the old city inside the city ramparts. As such it includes all of the historical sites including Jemaa El Fnaa, Kououbia Mosque, Saadian Tombs, Bahia Palace, as well as the Souks, Kasbah, and Mellah. You will need several days to experience the sights and sounds of old Marrakech, but it's well worth it. After taking in the main attractions, wander through the narrow lanes of the Souk taking time to haggle for souvenirs - unforgettable !

The place to shop. What ever you want to take home with you this is the place. Art, leather goods, clothes, jewellery, lamps, wood carving, pottery, it's all here and most of it handmade in workshops down the small alleyways. A real mixture of luxury goods and tourist tack. Haggling is a must and the 'pushiness' can be a bit much after a while.

best to do with a guide. We stayed at the medina, the only possible choice for me. However, the winding streets make it easy for you to get lost. We took a 3-hour walking tour and enjoyed every minute of it.
Get ready to walk!. 1000 year old market, just walk and get lost and enjoy! Eat everywhere, drink fresh juice, smell everything... you will never forget it!!

an interesting place to see while in Marrakesh. i recommend to hire an independent guide if you don't want to get lost in the little tangled streets and alleys. But be prepared that unless you specifically say that you don't want to - he will take you to ,his, friends shops and stalls.. to get his 10% commission on all purchases.. As a family of 10 we were just hurdled through all quickly and ,somehow, ended up in a back of the shop with little rooms created to rip one off - full of spices, herbs, potions, creams.. and the guide just gone only to appear after someones signal.. :( interesting nevertheless but very overpriced - you are better off in the main souk - deep inside to do your own biding

A very interesting place to visit. Apart from the usual tourist landmarks inside the Medina there are lots of opportunities to roam around the narrow local streets and observe how the locals live - a wonderful experience in all.
What an Experience. Excellent experience, one off the bucket list. Easy to haggle with the traders in a friendly way and a few bargains to be had

Undiscovered Treasure in the Medina. Dar Dallah, in the medina area, was a guest house but the owner converted it to a museum 6 months ago. The villa has been magnificently restored, but the highlight is the collection of unique Berber rugs arrayed in a colorful and pleasing way throughout the villa. These are small rugs made by Berber women in their spare time. Tearing old “synthetic” clothes into strips, the women tied them into artful weavings. The history of the women is reflected: a dress they wore years ago, a husband’s old shirt, a child’s blouse. The stories and process are well documented. The owner was present and shared his passion for the rugs; he talked about “the 1%”--those rug-weavers who are true artists and although they create in their own styles, often reflect Klee or Miro or Mondrain. We had refreshments on the roof terrace. The museum is a welcome retreat from the hustle of the medina just down the alley.

Get lost!. To experience this takes a willingness to get lost, and doing so is well worth the experience! There are precious few street signs, so navigation is by dead reckoning, but even then the tangle of pathways is so convoluted that the best things can only be discovered by getting lost (or using a local guide). We recommend risking getting lost, but doing that in the daytime!
A great place to wander. A lovely feast for the eyes. A super place to purchase spices and last minute gifts before heading home.

The best in morocco. We like to visit marrakech very much , it is different than other cities u can find wonderful mix between history and modernity, full of good restaurants & Many sights to visit also the touristic bus tour was great.

Very bustling, bargain seeking and fascinating. Bargain hunting and variety of goods on offer.great fun bartering, disliked the constant hassling though, would loved to browse but the shopkeepers won't leave you alone
Great atmosphere. Loved the atmosphere but do steer clear of snake charmers or monkeys unless you want to pay to get rid of them! A polite 'non merci' goes a long way!

Female Travelers Beware. My daughter and I spent a few extra days in Marrakech after our guided tour of Morocco ended. When in the medina we were verbally accosted and harassed. When we politely told vendors that wanted us to view their wares, we were cursed and verbally assaulted. Young men deliberately gave us wrong directions to purposely mislead us to get us lost then hassled us for money to give us additional directions which only lead us further astray into isolated and unsafe areas. It was a frightening experience.The way we were treated in the Marrakech Medina was vastly different than the experience we encountered any place else in Morocco. I believe we were treated this way because of our female gender and our lack of male escort.If traveling to Morocco, skip Marrakech.
A river of life inn Morocco. Take your courage and plunge in: be prepared to haggle and to get lost, but to have fun and discover some wonderful souvenirs and memorable sights

Fantastic. So amazing, if you want to get lost this is the place. It's a complete maze. Don't fall for men saying they are from your Hotel and will show you around, they will only take you to family and friends shops. The atmosphere is electric with the street acrobats. Beware you will be charged for taking photo's. Plenty of good restaurant's where you can get something to eat or just a drink. Oh and beware of the scooters in the very narrow alleys, they seem to have priority.

Stepping back in time.... Like going back in time the Medina area of Marrakech is enchanting. It stimulates all the senses - the sounds, the smells (not all good!) and the sights are rather unique. However, be prepared to throw yourself into the hustle and bustle of daily trading life, in which you are regularly offered a product, some food, directions or even just asked for money! Play along, charm them, and move on - they then tend to leave you alone. The products are disappointingly repetitive though - several stalls/shops selling the same things.The buildings (palaces, gateways, city walls) are fantastic - some of them still existing since the 1600s. An excellent opportunity for keen photographers, although try to avoid simply taking photos of people's stalls and moving on - they find this offensive (instead chat to them or buy something first, then ask for a photo).

A true cultural experience. A gathering of people like no other place. Once you chill out and get used to saying no, and learn the rules- such as photographing a person means paying . Its is good to sit and watch
back on time. Old buildings, amazing riads, lot of cats, donkeys on the street, small shops, bakeries, smell of barbecue, small streets and easy to get lost

Maze of the shops. Medina of Marrakech is huge maze, getting lost is part of thrill - there are always kind people telling you the way to main square! A lot things to turist but also a lot of everyday stuff too, many riads also are located there as well there is still recidences too. Worth of seeing. If not interested of shopping just say no thank you for salesmen. I got in one of the shops for artisan cooperative which was interesting too due the huge selection of handwork and antiques.

Group holiday. As a group of friends we had a brilliant time in the medina and the souk. We were all women and felt safe at all times. Although it was busy, people were mostly friendly and helpful. Avoid offers to take you somewhere - you'll be expected to pay!

crowded. very crowded place , not entirely safe, lots of noise , and all the shops are the same and sell the same things, lots of food (hygiene??), but very very lovely when it's getting dark. Then you can sit on a terrace and get a drink, but I wouldn't do that in the Cafe de France, the waiter stole our wallet while he was diverting our attention with the incorrect change he gave us.

Unusal. During the day is is very open and not too busy. There are people going about their business with horse or donkey carts, snake charmers, and the sort. Come sundown all that changes to a lively cacophony of sights, people and sounds. People everywhere, again snake charmers, monkey handlers, musicians, seems like hundreds of food and juice stalls. There are people selling and people buying anything that you can think you would ever need.

Exciting. Was all I imagined it to be at times a bit hectic but full of atmosphere. The Plaza de Jmaa el Fnna is a must a night as all there are all types of things going on after you have walked through go a sit on a terrace of a cafe and relax and absorb all the sounds and sights it is well worth it looking down on the people.

An Experience for the Most Seasoned Traveller. A challenge to the senses even for a seasoned traveller. To make the most of any first visit do not try to explore without a good guide. They will save time and money overall - especially in the Souk area. Despite the Medina being quite a maze, a half day guide and perseverance will pay off to understand and make the most of this unique area.

Big market place. Very unique expierence.Just be sure to haggle well, dont be afraid to walk away. Dont be pressured into any sale. And count your change.Its all part of the expereicne.Aside from that, the medina is an expansive sight of little alleyways consiting of markets, fom leather to metal. Amazing array of products, and the locals are friendly. Snake charmers, monkey tamers occupy part of the square during the day, and at night it is transformed to an area consisting of many different food stalls. Try the soup it is amazing and cheap!Rememebr nothing is for free.
Typical north African. Have you ever been to an old city og part of a arabic city, it is all the same. Living, noise, shopping, lots of people, smiles, bargain.....

Colours, smells, take your camera!. This is wonderful, whether you want to shop or not. Wander around past the small private houses, stalls, the odd hammam, and appreciate the colours and smells. There is a photo opportunity every metre! You cannot get lost, it really is easy to find your way through the narrow trails. Watch your bag, of course. If you want to buy something, bargain: but don't bargain if you don't intend to buy, that is really rude and prevents the shopkeeper making another sale. If you don't speak aby Arabic, us French or English (in that order).

Bustling and busy.. Everywhere in Medina is bustling, there are Black Africans selling watches and I phones, Hawkers, street traders, numerous beggars, restaurant touts. All life is there, at night the area becomes even busier and as you near Jemaa el Fna the activity levels increase, the place bustles with tourists and locals alike. Watch out for vehicles of all sorts everywhere. Taxis, donkey cats and motorbikes do not seem to respect any sort of restrictions as to where they go.

interesting experience. The medina is full of hustle and bustle and great for buying items such as crockery, sandals, spices. The food stalls in the middle of the main square are a great experience; stall number 1 has a good, rapid turnover, ensuring freshly cooked, hot food and if you're on a budget, you couldn't do better.

Unlike anywhere else. Small alleyways assault the senses in all ways. Donkeys and bikes zoom around the place and everywhere is so alive. The places of interest are easy to find and well worth taking the time to visit. Many places to eat and drink - all very different!!

An experience. So different from anywhere I have been, busy, fascinating, fun, a little scary at night. Beautiful buildings, interesting people, when I go back I want to take an empty holdall to fill with purchases from the market

An experience. You need to bear in mind the age of the Medina. That said, expect throngs of locals, tourists, alleyways, donkeys, mopeds, scooters, and a hive of industry, not to mention the smells and sights that go with it. You name it, it is in there. That's what it is all about, and the experience of a lifetime.
Multifarious!!. The old city has plenty to offer with food, shopping and cultural attractions. Palaces and museums are wonderful and offer many surprises.

Not for the faint hearted. This was my second visit to Marrakech, the first time being with a groups of blokes after a motor bike tour. This time it was with my wife to celebrate an anniversary. Jemaa el Fna square and the souks are a unique adventure which have to be experienced. The souks sell a huge variety of items from leather goods, china, pottery, to spices, local perfumes and oils, the senses are totally over whelmed. There is a huge selection of bars and restaurants as well, all the food we had was acceptable to excellent. We didn’t do many of the other tourist sites, we aren’t really into that, instead we had a Hamman and massage, which was great and reasonably priced.The down side is the constant hassle from traders to buy their goods, from leaving our Riad and walking 500 m I must have been asked 20 times if I wanted to buy something and some of them are really pushy, you have to be very thick skinned!! You also have to also have to navigate your way along very narrow lanes, competing for space with mopeds/scooters who whizz along, cyclists, donkey’s and carts, it is a nightmare, I am surprised there aren’t more accidents.
