The worst culprits though are the locals who ask you if you are lost and then try and insist that they show you the way somewhere. One guy just followed us after some casual conversation and then told me I had to give him some money. I am not easily intimidated and I told him where to go, but my wife was a bit shaken and it was an unpleasant experience. It’s a shame really, because there are some genuine locals who just want a chat.Would we go back, probably, it is an interesting place with almost guaranteed sunshine.

Busy, colourful and fantastic!!. Main square, felt safe hole atmosphere changes between day and night. Worth getting to a local cafe before sunset to watch all the activities. Freshly squeezed Orange juice available for about 40p a glass from all the local stalls. Street sellers can be pushy. Ladies doing the henna tattoos are very pushy and will offer a pattern for free and then try to charge huge prices to complete them whatever they try to charge barter like mad and only pay about a 1/3 of what they say. Snake charmers will try to charge you for taking photos.Getting lost in the souks is part of visiting Marrakesh and again barter like crazy, I just wish we had been left to look at stalls rather than be pestered continually until I couldn't be bothered any more and was relieved to get out of the souks!Horse and carriage rides are available, again barter like crazy, we paid about £10 for a 40 minute tour.

Quite an experience. It takes a second day visiting the souks to feel less intimidated by the souks, the endless motorcycles and motorbikes. It also takes some of us a time or two haggling to be more comfortable. It is part of the game and the sellers are downright disappointed if you don't engage in it. Do come equipped with a currency calculator on your smart phone and Google Translate.
Vibrant and fascinating!. LOVED the Medina, especially the markets. Annoying being hassled by the stall owners but I guess it is all part of the experience. They DO rip you off though!

must see but perhaps once is enough. Having traveled extensively throughout Africa and the Middle East , i knew what to expect in the square and souks that wind in and out in a crazy maze , this is for tourists and i suppose you shouldn't criticize the local salesmen for taking any advantage available to them to make a sale , that said they should not get upset when you say no thank you several times followed by an emphatic NO!! There are numerous scams , like offering to show you the way back to the square then taking you to their pals shop instead , all part of the experience, but be firm and polite otherwise you will be dazed and poorer in a matter of mins ....DON'T go to the leather tanning area , its appalling and of no appeal whatsoever , all the taxi drivers will try and take you there
An experience. Everything i liked was also the things I disliked ,some of the crafts were astonishing ,but probably better to go to the artisan centre
Thrilling. Going to purchase from the sooks was a great experience. All Moroccan people are so friendly. Just watch out for the " scams". Watch Scam City on the television
Chaotic vibrancy. It was an interesting experience! Colourful, smelly and a little scary at times. An assault on all your senses.

A Must. It was very nice to see the vibrant chaotic atmosphere with a sensory overload at the Medina. We got bit lost and a guy told us he would help us get to the square, we refused as I knew about the warnings about being approached and they want money from you as it is after all how they make their living, but he insisted that he did not want any money as it was only 2 minutes away. He led us the wrong way but then he still wanted some money so we gave him few dirhams. Eventually after 15 minutes of walking around the maze of narrow streets we saw some other tourists who pointed us in right directions. After this incident we did not get lost and we used the mosque to navigate our way for rest of the days.

Hints. Some tipsHintsBuy all ceramics and leather in Fes. Much cheaper and larger variety. Wood products more numerous and slightly cheaper in Marrakech. Carpets in Fes and Marrakech roughly the same price. Although if you walk into a larger fancy carpet shop especially those in Marrakech expect to get ripped to shreds when the bargaining starts. Rather try find a smaller carpet shop. Tanneries in Fes much more impressivePalaces and medersa much more beautiful in MarrakechGet your spice mixes in Marrakech. Cheaper and more variety as more competition. Don't buy stuff on the side of the road rather get from Marrakech or Fes as much less expensive.
little city in big city. great experience to walk around the medina. some places a bit hard to find as there are no streetname signs.

Lots to see and do - character. It's a veritablke feast for the eyes. There's Souks, traders, snake charmers and old buildings in abundance.Ok there's people pestering you but they take NO for an answer quite readily and they will barter (a bit). There are some great offers on local artisan work and also as many fake bits of tat as you like!Well worth a good walk around.

Could spend hours here!. Fantastic to wander, haggle and just take in the smells, sights and hustle and bustle. Like going back in time ! And time just disappears here. I am sure you can buy anything if you look hard and long enough!

a fairytale, a rough one.... It's noisy and stinky but so charming! Avoid to ask anyone for the way to anywhere, everyone will ask you for a lot of money at the end since they think everyone from outside is rich.
LarsB. Big, crowded and fully chaotic. It is "a must" though for those visiting Marrakech. Outside the Medina - or the Souk - is the Grand Square. Another "must" in this ineresting city.

Experience. The medina is an awesome experience . Be careful of your bags and pockets as pick pockets were about. Soak the the atmosphere enjoy the experience and haggle some so lovely Moroccan goodies

mad. Was an experience - very chaotic, you have to be quite firm and say no if not interested, beggars everywhere especially little children which can be upsetting also attitude to animals leaves a lot to be desired

A Mission. It is fun to watch from a terrace but to walk through it is like going through obstacles. Be firm and say no if you don't want someone to warp a snake around your neck or selling you things you don;t really want to buy.

Colorful and fascinating. Get lost in Marrakesh's Medina... You'll discover colours and scents and noises... and it never ends. Locals are friendly and helpful and guide you out of the maze once you had enough Just aks for "la place" - the Jamma'a el Fna and they will guide the way. Avoid the "faux guides" , the wanna-be tour guides.

Walled City. The entire Old City is surrounded by stout walls which creates the Medina. A good variety of things to see & do, even excluding the over-priced Souks (even with substantial bartering dropping prices by 1000% - yes, that's thousands not hundreds - the shoddy goods, now mainly from China, & probably got locally from a "Cash & Carry) are not too attractive. The old Jewish quarter & the Kasbah are well worth visiting, as well as the normal tourist attractions, plus the locals are friendly & less likely to hassle you than in many other N. African cities

I hate marakesh. This country is not magical! it is hot, dirty and people are very rude. Nothing is special. But if u have money, u can go jah mahal restaurant, sofitel lounge bar and hotel la mamounia, these places are very expensive but beatiful

Exhilarating and fun. A crazy place, the sights, sound and smells were amazing. I loved it but my husband wasn't so keen. The stall holders were respectful and not as pushy as I expected them to be, they would back off if told we weren't interested. Some of them we passed every day on our way out and we got to know them, they would greet us and have a chat. The motorbikes, donkeys and carts were a bit of a challenge but we soon learnt to get out of their way quickly.

the most important attraction. Try this place, day and night. Mix with the local, by some good tea, or species. Don´t be affraid to get lost, you will find the way out. Feel the spirit of Marrakesh int the fantastic place.

Very pleasant. A lot of picture moments here! It is great to have a walk around and to really experience the culture. The culture however may act as a bit of a shock for some tourists. Speaking of tourist you will find that you run into an English man here or an American there

Two different worlds. In the day there was so much to see, enough to take at least a week. The guided tour is a must. At night there is a different atmosphere with the many outdoor eating places.Good food, plenty of it and very quick service.

A must for the ambience. The Medina is of course a must for all who want the local magic and color of the souks. Absolutely everything can be found. Bargaining a must. Downside: far too many motorbikes!!!!

A whole lot of the same thing. Getting here is simple just follow the street signs to el jima fen and you will be in the medina as soon as you see those signs. The "tour guides" illegal of course stand at all the entrances and tell you this way is closed for the mosque. They are lying 100% of the time. It's a maze and designed that way on purpose. We used on of the kids and they will only take u so far in cause the police will harass them for harassing you. Beware of the shop owner offering advice then telling you his shop is all for charity. After a couple hours you will be so worn out for the constant pulling and motorcycles racing by that you will need to find the square climb to the highest roof top out of it all and have a coke and relax. Remember when leaving if you need help tell them the closest landmark not your hotel name as they will tell you it's closed now. Lol. We helped a set of British travelers get into the square they looked like they were about to lose it on a couple kids trying to take them every where but the square. $20 is enough they will complain but keep walking towards the square and they will disappear. All else fails ask a cop

Amazingly lively. Loved the hustle and bustle, hated the bullying by the traders. Everyone wants your money, and groups of locals will surround you to try and force you to pay for things you don't want. Stay firm and walk away.

Daytime Marrakech. I thought there was some beautiful craftwork to buy, but be very careful about what you are buying work out the cost. Don't think you can take photo's of anyone you will be asked for money. Visit Yves Saint Laurent beautiful garden.

A must- but be smart. Do not walk with anyone who is wanting to help give you directions unless you plan to pay them and do not take a picture of snack charmers with snakes unless you agree on a price before hand, they can get mean and confrontational. As in all of Morocco you really should dress more conservatively, we found we were treated with more respect than those that did not. This is a great place full of energy and interesting people. Parts can get very crowded. Take your time, plan on getting lost as part of the adventure.

great place to stay. I stayed in a Riad in the Medina area, it's really convenient, 15 minutes from the airport and has character. We found a Riad that was need the big square, the palaces and the tombs, i would recommend staying in this area.

Dont get lost lol. If you like haggling this is the place to go with literally hundreds of stalls. But you need to be strong or you will soon find yourself spending a lot more than you intend. Take care getting lost in here is all part of the fun but its very hot so make sure your carrying water

Magical Marrakesh. All the magic of Morocco condensed into this area.Fantastic!The Moroccan people are amongst the warmest friendliest people we have met in our travels and funny with it.We felt totally safe and relaxed in the Medina and had a great time just "mooching".The sights, sounds and wonderful smells can overwhelm the senses at times and each foray into the souks is a mini adventure.
Old world. Really, really old skool give it a shot!! If you like to feel like you are in the market scene of Gladiator, then have no doubts come here.

Fascinating. Once you get used to the heat and the crowds this is a fascinating experience. If you like to shop and haggle this is the place for you. You can get a bargain but you need to be confident and determined.

Great fun haggling. Love the souks! Don't get drawn into shopping too early in there though as the further in you get, the better the experience with the real craftsmen. Worth going to artisan centre prior to check prices. Remember also don't be silly with low prices. These guys live on less than you probably paid for your riad stay per night so haggling over 10 dh feels inappropriate. Enjoy!

This Medina. This Medina is split around the main Square, it has a tourist side and a locals side. At night the square is full of Moroccans and they are huddled around various floorshows that people put on. The shops are all open and there is music from various groups around the square.

The heart of Marrakesh. Perfect place to feel Marrakesh every day life. Don`t miss the Jamaa el Fna plaza at day AND night... Make sure you have orange juice at day and dinner at the stands and night!
Fascinating Diversion. You can get lost for hours in the literal sense and centuries in the evocative . Nice place place to wander
Fantastic experience. Everything is lively and bustling, a must to see by day and again at night, lots of good shopping and great places to eat, liked there was not too much hassle
the medina!. It was crazy but well worth the time we spent in the medina. Once we got used to the constant talking, we navigated pretty well.

Noisy and dirty. Main square alive with local performers and very noisy. Food stalls busy and the sales tout on stand number 25 was keen to confirm that he "guaranteed no diarrhoea" with his food! Inside the Medina the roads were narrow and goods on sale were the same everywhere. Nothing special to see or buy and by 1030 pm places were closing.

Marrakech Medina, lively and very busy!. It has become very very busy, this was our 5th visit to the Medina over the last 10 years. I have to say I don't need another visit any more. The prices have become really high and it is to much hassle to get the price down. You better off visiting a Medina for example in Taroudant or Essaouira. But for the first time visitor, you have to visit this place!

Senses overload. This will test your sense of direction beyond anything you have had to deal with before. The place is a warren of tiny streets with all manner of vehicles vying for their bit of space. You are competing with mopeds who speed by so fast it's impossible to jump out of their way. Bicycles that you don't hear. Donkeys pulling carts. Horse drawn caleche....... Oh and people, many many people.All that said, it's an incredible place. I have wandered around for hours being totally lost and not felt threatened or uncomfortable during the day or night. Sometimes I even manage to get to my intended destination, other times not.

a sensory adventure. The maze of narrow streets and high walls challenges your sense of direction, but the aroma of the spice markets and bustle of the souks, and colours of the sky, and buildings are exciting.

Marrakech Medina. very busy, massive and easy to get lost in so get a good street map otherwise you will be sent in all directions by locals who expect remuneration for their assistance. keep a hold on your wallet/handbag and don't flash cash

Bussssyyyyy!. fun, busy and lively!!! however lots of sellers pestering you especially at night when they want you to eat from them. i often just looked down and walked as to keep away from eye contact!!!

An ancient style souk that hasn't lost its charm. I've lived in the Middle East and know a good souk when I see one. This is the real deal - not some Vegas-style fake. That said, the Medina requires time. You cannot peel back its layers in a day, so take several to take it in, find what you might like and then to buy or not - it's more about the experience of the hunt....

take you time and get lost. take you time and get lost, discover unique places probably you will not know how to come back, do not be afraid and smell, look, enjoy the burstling activitybargain, bargain, bargain if you want to buy somethingrespect, kindness also when you refuse and keep low profile

A step into another world. Mayhem, colour, history, people, atmosphere, shops, souks and restaurant; it is all there. Beautiful restaurants in Palatial settings, Discreet streets with large imposing doors leading to secret Palatial homes and places to stay. A great city to explore.
Very origin place. The Medina is a very origin place with all the souks and traditional dealers and craftsmen. A MUST in Marrakesch !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Hectic but fun!. We loved walking around the souks and talking in the smells and sounds from the medina! There are many bargains to be found and we enjoyed trying to barter for cheap prices! You do get pestered as soon as you arrive until you leave. There are snake charmers and people selling things everywhere you turn! Only dislike was that there were Monkeys on chains for tourists to have pictures with. Overall a fun experience but no for everyone!

Very Quirky. I so enjoyed exploring the narrow walk ways of the Medina got my spices there too not expensive like the main Sqwe had a guide which we gave a tip to also we saw a mosque, a bakery (an Oven), which a local sends their bread to get bakedIt is a must to see
Must visit. This is the quintessential Morocco. you have o barter, and you'll be hustled, but you wouldn't be here if that was a problem

Simply must do. The markets of Marrakesh have spoiled me for all others. At night, it's like a carnival. During the day, it's a feast of sights and smells. I adored the different parts...leather goods, blacksmiths, textiles, spices. We even went to a pharmacy and learned about some local holistic medicines and lotions.
What Buzz. Just great for walking around and soaking up the atmosphere. There is always a bargain to be had as well but don't expect it be brilliant quality.

Chaotic but fascinating. Once inside the walls of the city you step back in time and to what seems like another world. With narrow streets and constant shouts of 'stay to the right' as bikes and mopeds whizz past you. Great place to go exploring and felt very safe during the day. A little uneasy when it got dark and the shops started to close in certain areas. In face we were warned to stay away from part of the souks after 10pm. All in all a great place to experience.

Don't be afraid. A great place to be in during the day and at night, we were not hassled too much and a simple no was sufficient to any one who wanted us to use their services, try the square at night, the sights smells and characters will last you a lifetime.
Must do. Relax, smile, engage. They are out to get your money but its all done with great wit and humour. You are very safe there.

The real Marrakech. The Medina is a real rabbit warren of narrow streets and alleys, lined with shops, small industries, cafes and of course the long winding souks. I was surprised how little pestering we got - felt safe walking even at night. Watch out for the scooters and mopeds - they fly through the streets and you just have to keep out of their way. It may look shabby (and admittedly a bit smelly in parts) but behind the closed doors you often find beautifully decorated restaurants, riads, courtyards. Just be careful around the tanneries area where there seems to be a large syndicate of men operating together - you will be expected to pay one man who introduces you to another who then takes you to a guide, who then drops you in a shop! They all expect paying - the guide wanted 100 MAD (about £7). But this was the exception - we found most people happy to help wherever we went (though of course a small tip is always gratefully received). The number of stray and emaciated cats is distressing but the SPANA hospital can help - they treat and neuter for free - it's free to visit the hospital and see the work they are involved with!

Great to stroll round. The medina is always the heart of a city and this is no different. Wander the cool narrow streets and enjoy the bustle of the souks, bargain with artisans and admire the ancient place.
great experience. We were forwarned so hired a guide for half a day, that was good value as he showed us the different areas and brought some structure and history to the maze of stalls and crafts.

Fascinating experience in the souq.. I had read the lonely planet tip of going to the artisan studios to get an idea of prices before actually buying anything and this turned out to be very good advice, as the souq owners charge the most ridiculous prices. If you arent comfortable with bargaining strongly you are better to buy at the fixed price artisans studios.
Hectic. Not for the faint hearted as very pushy sales, but certainly worth seeing, all goods were the same from stall to stall

Walk to the Right!. I truly enjoyed the hectic medina. It actually comes alive around sunset. During the daytime, it's easy to maneuver around the medina. The local people are friendly...just give them salaam and a smile, and you just might start up a good conversation. Most people in the medina speak French in addition to Arabic, but very few speak English, and even then, expect it not to be perfect. I loved making my way from the alley of our riad to the main corridor where I had to maneuver around the motor scooters, donkeys, horses, taxis, and pedestrian traffic. It was interesting. You have to be ready for that adventure, and one cannot be shy. Just remember to always walk on the right hand side and you'll be okay.

Very interesting. This medina is really easy to get lost in. I would suggest you go with a guide and then the vendors don't bother you. You have to be careful because motor scooters come down the narrow streets. It is very interesting to wander around and see all the wonderful things they are selling. There are stray cats everywhere. The only good thing is that the shop owners feed them so at least they are not starving.
WOW!. Amazing. Got lost but really helpful shopkeepers. Could spend days poking around, especially watching craftsmen.

Chaos. Loved the craziness of the place, very tight narrow streets, with the hustle and bustle of people everywhere, selling almost anything you could want.Watch out for people approaching you outside the Medina wanting to take you inside. They are on commission for taking you to specific shops within the Medina. We got caught, they consistently say no obligation to buy, but if you don't buy from the first shop, they escort you to a second shop and then a third etc....Rather than cause a row we purchased some goods from the third place we visited and were then left alone to wander around at our own pace and leisure.
awsome place. In the medina of Marrakech you can find nice souvenirs and many kind of shops, also places where you can see how they make all the nice things. Bought lots of spices!
Great vibrant bustling place.. You have not been to Morocco if you don't visit the medina. An amazing place full of vibrant colours, sounds, smells and sights. A great holiday all in all.

Un tuffo in un altro mondo. - A dive into another world.. Son sceso in un Hotel nella Medina perchè volevo viverla dall'interno, e non andarci come in visita ad un acquatio. E' davvero un mondo diverso. Qui la vita è per strada e la strada è il ganglio vitale della cultura marocchina. Qui la gente parla, si conosce, vive, commercia. Una società forse più umana della nostra, diversa. Da vedere ed apprezzare. ----------I've got an Hotel in very Medina because I wanted to experience it from the inside, and not to go there as a visit to an aquarium. It's really a different world. Here life is on the street and the street is the center nerve of the Moroccan culture. Here people talk about everything, they meet, live, trade. A life style perhaps more humane than ours, very different. Medina is something to see and appreciate, best living there for the duration of the holiday.

Best pure Argan Oil in Medina, Marrakech. After wandering the souks of the Medina and seeing plenty of Argan Oil for very reasonable prices, I felt as though it was likely to be a watered down version. I also read reviews that this is common.I was then recommended Herboristrie Firdaous. 8Without doubt this is the best cosmetic Argan Oil I have bought. On arrival, the owner was talking to a local and asked told me she would be a minute. After walking around the Medina and people trying to grab my attention this was quite refreshing! They are not desperate to make a sale as they know their products are good and sought after.I paid 180 Dirham (£12ish) for a large bottle. It is lovely and will last a long time. My frizzy hair has never been so tame!To get here- head to the post office on the square. Walk down the big busy road to the left of the post office. Turn into the shopping centre which is on the left just before the shop on the corner 'Solo'. Head upstairs and it is immediately in front of you.Locals will show you there but will charge a fee. I hope you like it as much as I did!

Download a map to use GPS offline. This is a rabbit warren of alleyways and side streets. You would do well to use GPS if you can because it's so easy to get lost.However, it's a pretty safe place, even after dark. You obviously take care of your belongings but we never felt threatened because the streets are full of people.

Confronting. This was our first medina and it was very busy and congested. In the whole of Morocco it was my least favourite medina, probably because it was sensory overload and very new (actually it was ancient, but new to us). It was very full -on.
busy and exotic. the merchandise, the oriental atmosphere, the "charisma' the place has. In the evening it is extreme busy but an unforgettable experience.

interesting. this was a interesting place to visit. it WAS NOT as one would envision, however. 'snake charmers' did not perform as expected. they were VERY pushy, demanding money for every picture taken. they would chase you through the square demanding money if you were 'caught' taking a picture. they say the place is a thousand or more years old..it sure smelled like it :( nasty, dirty, and very expensive. if your here on a cruise ship visit, save the time and go to Rabat. this is not something I would ever do again, nor would I recommend this (unless you happen to be very close by)

Magical. In the narrow shady streets donkeys, mopeds, and carts will pass by while you may bargain for anything you can imagine. Merchants are always ready to sell you even what you haven't thought of :) Or just buy a tasty piece of Moroccan flat bread, olives or grapes, and enjoy yourself. Be prepared to easily lose your sense of directions in the mazy medina. Look for special, remarkable shops, landmarks, or boards, plus use gps navigation - these will make orientation a lot easier.

Definitely not for me !. The place is polluted, smelly, dirty, motorbikes pushing pedestrians out, little carriages pulled by poor , suffering donkeys (huge cruelty to animals), people trying to give you the wrong directions, this is a big scan in Marrakech. Everything I've seen up for sale in the shops , I could order off Amazon for 1/4 of the price. If you're planning to buy anything NEVER pay the asking price. One exemple : I found a wooden tray and asked how much was , the guy said 1200 Durham(£85.00 pounds), i've said I wasn't interested, the price dropped to 600 Durham, I've said NO thanks, 400 durham, I walked away, 300 durham. Didn't buy it . Asked the guy at my Riad, and he said the tray was worth around 120 durham. DON'T TRUST ANYONE IN MARRAKECH.

manic!. We arrived on an organised tour in a horse drawn trap - bit hairy in the traffic from the hotel, but the horses looked well fed and cared for. The square at night was buzzing with sounds and smells of delicious food cooking. We were accosted immediately by people with snakes who draped them round us - luckily we didn't mind but if we had it would have been pretty scary! Obviously they want money for photos and were not happy with coins. One of the group had a monkey plonked on her shoulder and the owner was quite angry when given a coin even though she had not encouraged him. The tour guide had to step in as she became quite upset. The shopkeepers encouraged everyone to buy but were not too pushy - and the tour guide was walking quite fast so we didn't have chance to buy anything! I would have liked to spend more time looking round as we only had a snapshot of the place but I enjoyed what I saw.

bag snatching in the medina. I have visited Morocco four times over the last few years and have always had a thoroughly enjoyable stay. I consider myself to be an experienced traveller and have never felt particularly at risk in Marrakech, taking usual, sensible precautions. On this occasion I spent four days in Marrakech, as always staying at a Riad in the Medina - which provided the usual welcome Marrakech 'buzz' - it never disappoints. I thought it maybe helpful though to share my 'bag snatch' experience as I certainly learnt a lesson about becoming over confident in what had begun to feel like very familiar well trodden streets. Others have commented on the throng of traffic in the medina - pedestrians, donkeys with carts, bicycles and small motor bikes surround you. Walking down a surprisingly quiet street, it therefore did not strike me as unusual when I became aware of a scooter close behind me with a passenger on the back. I was totally unprepared for the passenger to grab my bag as they passed me and take off at speed disappearing into the melee before I even had time to register that my bag containing phone, money and bank card had been stolen. Indeed, my initial thought was that they had in error tried to pass too close to me, catching the bag strap in error and they would stop and return my bag to me. Sadly - naive in the extreme. I spent the next three hours in a police station ( having been sent from one station to another, a fifteen minute walk away) trying to report the theft which became farcical in itself - there was little interest or enthusiasm in taking the report. At one point three teenagers who had been caught stealing from another tourist were brought into the office I was waiting in, all handcuffed and wailing loudly. They were immediately surrounded by a number of officers far more interested in this drama than in taking my report - the officers began shouting at them and one officer kicked at them a number of times, forcing them to crouch on the floor and stand alternately. I was shifted around from room to room and was directed to wait for long periods of time in corridors with no explanation as to what was happening - after three hours I was told to return with my passport and that when I returned I would have to start the process again. Quite an experience and by the time I left ( with the promise I would return with my passport) I had not managed to get any officer to actually take any of the details despite being taken to various locations in the station and asked to retell the story to yet another disinterested officer barely making eye contact many times over. The only really helpful person in the station was a Moroccan lady who I initially thought worked there but later found was reporting a crime herself. It would have felt totally chaotic without her explanations, reassurances and suggestions. I didn't return to the station - I knew it would be fruitless. So all in all - the incident hasn't changed my view or love or Morocco but it has left me aware that unpredictable things can happen and the more relaxed you are the greater the risk maybe. True of any busy city in the world maybe and certainly many tourists in England experience similar situations. Don't be put off visiting Marrakech but do keep your wits about you. Make sure you have telephone numbers with you for cancellation of bank cards, sim cards etc just in case the worst happens - we had to phone a friend in England to get the relevant telephone numbers as internet access is limited in the Medina and signals poor often. Chances are it won't happen to you and you will have a thoroughly enjoyable holiday - just as I always have - I certainly will return to Marrakech certainly - a little wiser next time.
Medina. Walking and find your way to the Medina is interesting - you definitely need a good map and a sense of humour but all the same great fun...lots of weird smells (some good, some terrible!)

Dirty. Take your willies with you if you visit the medina this area is dusty, dirty and smelly couldn't wait to get out. Watch out for scams people stalking you on bikes and then stopping you to say they remember you from the hotel you work in they often work in pairs

Great place to bargain hunt. This was our first trip to Morocco, so we did not know what to expect. We stayed inside the Medina and glad we did. The Medina is where all the action is. We thought it was busy during the day, but wait, it gets busier at night. A must do if you are in Marrakesh. Everyone was friendly.

Worth getting lost. The Medina in some ways is less maze-like than the medina in Fes. Therefore there are rewards in just wandering about as you might get lost but it seemed easier to find you way back to a main throughfare to be able to reorientate. Do go off the main throughfares for closer viewing of normal life and also artisans at work.
Be Careful. Watch Out for Scams and High first Buy Prices!!!Market full of Leather bags,shoes,scarfs and etc. for as little as few euros.

Get lost in the Medina. We visited the Medina several times during our trip. As our Riad owner advised, part of the adventure is to get lost. There are many different areas, some quieter than others, almost all have vendors happy to sell you something. Know your prices, we were talked into buying some small boxes for four times the price of another shop and that was after some bargaining! Wonderful things to buy, the metal work lamps are stunning but difficult to pack. Jewelry, fabrics, spices, fun slippers, leatherwork all good bargains to be had. Don't be too serious with your haggling, try joking and laughing it's much more fun and most of the stuff is quite cheap after a bit of haggling. You will be offered lots of sweet mint tea at the carpet shops. Enjoy!
the square. Liked,full of fun at night with local song and dance in the squareDisliked the market, felt a little uncomfortable.
Historic area of city. Able to enter and leave at any of the many gates.Finding something new round every corner.Taste of local life.Tannery is disgusting.

Amazing atmosphere, pleased we went to visit. Really worth 1 visit, we visited at night and experienced a sea of people selling everything from carpets to flying toys. The street food outlets were great, entertaining locals claiming to be from "Hackney" or "Dorset" were really funny! Food was good however we should not have left it to them to choose our dishes as they delivered almost every dish they had on the menu and the cost was a bit excessive and there was no way we could have eaten it all!! It was worth the trip though.

Crazy. Don't be fooled by the "I'm employed by the hotel" guide who may greet your shuttle bus, he put the fear of god up us, took us into shops of his choice trying to get us to spend money, then demanded £20 for his service, barter hard and don't be afraid to walk away.

Half day trip. Exciting place to visit .lovely people and lots to buy if you want to.the main square is full of snake charmers and monkeys. Didn't like the constant badgering as they all want your business.

True Moroccan experience. We stayed in a genuine old riad in the Medina, and spent a couple of days wandering all around the little alleys and streets to see the numerous trade areas. The tanneries were particularly fantastic to walk around and see age-old skills being practiced. We felt this was a genuine Moroccan experience and, although the local people are desperate to sell to you, they are so friendly and pleasant and the word "welcome" is the word you hear the most. Immerse yourself in it and you will be rewarded. Just don't try taking photos of animals, dead or alive!

Walled Part of Marrakesh. This place will be culture shock to anyone arriving without knowledge.Its old, poor livedin with all sorts of smells, sounds, traffic, animals one has left behind in the middle ages.Safe but the environment will take some getting used to, book a good 4/5 star hotel to counter the outside.Maximum stay recommended would be 2/3 days.NO MORE.

Shabby square waiting to fleece you. Visited Marrakech in September for a long weekend and as part of the city tour, with a guide, went to The Medina (daytime).It wasn't very busy, but apparently this was due to the time of day.There were men, supposedly snake charming, but from where I was standing I never saw the snakes move, so they could have been stuffed?! The snakes that were being held and walked around were quite small. There were monkeys on chains that you could hold for a photo, at a price of course and the money you offer is never enough. It was expected, but always disappointing when people show their true colours with greed. We didn't stay long in a The Medina as there are only so many times you can refuse to hold a monkey or avoid being chased to hold a snake!It was interesting to experience, but seen and done it.

The Kech Bazzar. Be prepared to bargain. Offer half and then negotiate from there. Vendors can be aggressive so be firm. Stinky, dirty, visually overwhelming but oh you can't miss it. It's a unique cultural experience.
Old town charm. This central location has all you would expect from a Middle Eastern Medina.Souks,galore,restaurants,cafes and lots of hustle and bussle and wonderful orange juice about 35p a glass

its an experience ........ I wouldn;t like to repeat !! we ventured into the medina several times. The streets are very narrow (about 10 to 12 feet) and you are competing with mopeds loaded up with families/kitchen sink etc (sometimes 3 abreast), some with lights, some without, donkeys pulling carts. taxis (yes I couldn;t believe it either) - tip - keep into the right hand side when walking in the souks and walk in single file - less chance of getting run over. We did see several accidents where people had been knocked off bikes/mopeds - they do have rules of the road in Marrakech - but no-one follows them :) We went to the square in the day (quiet) and at night (beyond busy) - the stink of ammonia from the horse pee may make your eyes water which happened to us - there are loads of horses with carriages (think Blackpool prom) stood around for hours and no rain between May to Nov to wash the waste away ..... We managed to avoid the henna tatooists and others selling various bits of tat - we went to a govt run shop (Ensemble Artisan) in the kasbah area (near the Koutoubia mosque - you will know you have found it as its the only store in Marrakech with escalators) the prices are fixed and very reasonable. I have put 1 to 2 hours time to visit as I think you need time out to recuperate after that length of time

Medina visit. I know the guide books say what an adventure it is to visit without a guide - stop the madness! If this is your first Medina, take a guide and control where you visit, not just his recommendations. The people are pushy, watch out for your wallets, but the visit is facinating. Know your prices. Great rugs,
Medina. Frenetic , crazy and colorful, no alcohol really but then it is an Arab Country so why . Not happy with the monkeys on chains performing

what a great place. the culture is to be embraced it is vast.
sights, sounds smells, snake charmers, dancers, African drums,
then the Medina behind it - for miles of shopping. ENJOY.
reminded me of home. it was like being at home with shops like Zara and H&M so if you don't go here you're not really missing out. There were loads of bag shops.

A mixed bag!. Firstly, this is a very interesting area and a massive culture shock, which is what we wanted to experience. The medina itself is basically the old city of Marrakech, which is enclosed within the walls. There is a mosque, a large square, souks, museums, cafes, bars, shops and restaurants all enclosed within the medina. The first thing to hit you as you enter near the centre is the smell. There are lots of flies, horses, animal excrement and a strong smell of urine in 40 degree+ heat. Secondly, there are lots of vehicles, mopeds, trucks and bikes to keep your eye on. There are very few official street crossings and they tend to drive wherever they want. On top of this there are then street sellers constantly trying to get your attention with hats, toys and watches. So firstly, only go if you can keep your wits about you and your eye on everything going on and your wallet/bag/purse at the same time!I wouldn't recommend taking children any younger than teenagers as literally there is too much to keep your eye on already yourself let alone looking after young children (and they may not be as discreet about the smell! Oh from the mouths of babes...).My partner and I only ventured out once during the day ourselves and went twice more to the gardens and historical sights but guided. I would recommend going with guides if possible as they will tell street sellers to leave you alone and can get you through the mass of mazes without getting lost! We found it very difficult to follow roads and streets as streets are poorly laid out and signposted and often look the same. If you do go yourself, 2-3 hours max is all you need really.As a warning- women, keep your hands on your bags and another hand in a pocket or on a friend/partners arm - we were warned that women will come up to you, quickly grab your hand, draw a henna tattoo before you've realised and ask for 500dh (£50). If your hands aren't free, they wont try it.The souks were an experience, easy to get lost and you have to be alert. But the smells of the spices, the street trades, the goods for sale were all worth the visit. So different, so diverse and amazing rainbows of colour through the streets were amazing. Again only go if you're fully awake- you're battling streets with few rules - donkeys, trucks and mopeds will surprise you and come very close without warning in heavily pedestrian areas. Walk to a side to try to avoid this!We were advised to only pay 1/3 of whatever price they tried to get from you in the souks. We got bored of the aggressive nature of selling in the end and walked along to 'ensemble artisan', a shop nearby controlled by the government, with set prices and no aggressive selling. Here I got a lantern for 40dh (about £3) which is less than was being asked in the Souks and no pushy sales. Well worth a visit.I would definitely recommend adults visit the medina, but with a tour guide if possible!

Medina. Interesting people and area. A little dirty and smelly but that was expected. Great foods to try. Be sure to pay no more than half of listed price on goods...walk away if they don't except your offer. They will follow you if they really want the sell.

Loved the sights and sounds of the Medina of Merrakech!. Loved all of the sights and sounds of the Medina. We stayed in the Princess Riad and found the staff to be warm and welcoming. The food was great and the service was exceptional. The Medina of Marrakech is a sight to behold! The shopping was great and there was a constant buzz of activity.

A maze of tiny streets and shops. This has to be an experience not to be missed, A maze of tiny streets with hundreds of shops selling everything from clothes to leather goods, spices to metalwork, superb wooden items and jewellery, etc. Most made by one man artisans.You WILL get lost! Finding your way around and keeping a sense of direction is just about impossible. But that's all part of the adventure. Watch out though, for the young men who will offer to guide you to where you want to go. First they will take you to a relative's shop further into the maze, and then they will guide you a mile or more through tiny alleyways ending up 50 yards from where you started.... and then want paying. So you really do need to ignore them! BIG HINT.... get a maps app on your phone and use GPS.to pinpoint your location and see the way to where you need to go. (The locally supplied "maps" of the Mediina are useless comic representations of the place!)Doing some shopping? Nothing is priced! Be prepared for the people to start at a very high price! They EXPECT you to negotiate. The best thing to do is to ask yourself how much you would be prepared to pay for an item at home. halve it, and start your haggling there. Don't get carried away and pay more for something than you would back home! Its easy to do! Be prepared to say "no thanks" and walk away.You can pick up some interesting bargains. Make sure that you have enough room in your suitcase to take everything home :-)

Well worth the visit to the Medina...but be careful of the speedy cars!. We stayed in the Medina and it was great fun walking around. The location is terrific but you need to be careful of the cars that speed around.

Mayhem of Marrakech. Definitely something to experience as there's so much going on. It's very busy and bustling and there's a lot to see and buy but the way the people try and sell to you is very aggressive and you have to be wary and be on your guard at all times as they try to pull you in to buy their goods/ charge you to photograph things like the monkeys and snake charmers. I would suggest avoiding the square and going straight to the souks and whilst in there just ignore what everyone is shouting to you and if people offer you directions when you're walking through saying 'that way' ignore them because how do they know where you're even going? They're trying to confuse you so that you get lost and need their help to find your way back to the square and they'll want money for that service. So I resorted to scowling at them and storming away from them whilst making it clear that I was looking around of my own accord and that I didn't need them to say anything.

Lose yourself. Just wander around. Stop, take in the sights, the sounds, the smells, in fact it's a full workout for all the senses. The light streaming through and the colour and the spots of manic crowds and the quite corners. Really enjoyable at every turn.

Has to be seen at night. Went on a guided tour during the day, which was fun... Small tip only do the half day as the full day is to long. The whole place and square transforms in the evening a must see. Enjoy!

From dust til dawn. The best way to explore it as we found was just to go for it and explore it! Don't look lost and don't look at your map because before you know it you will end up at The tanneries which was not my first choice as a vegetarian!!!!

dirty smelly urine soaked poor entertainment from poverty wrecked street urchins. caleches horse drawn carriages horses allowed to urinate in djmaa el fnaa donkeys etc strong smell of urine no street cleansing you met with pungent odour of urine in the strong heat it was overpowering the jugglers werent that good ragamufin street urchins doing acrobatics also violence aggresion from monkey handlers over photographs camera snatched after monkey was without being asked placed on shoulder there is nothing to do in marakech its not suitable for any thrill seeker of family holdiay it does not fit any holiday category there is basically nothing there to do except sit in djmaa el fnaa drinking moroccan tea in a filthy square
Beautifull. We just saw the building from outside and it was a sumptuous! Always a lot of people surrounding the place!

A Great Place to get lost in!. We were forwarned so hired a guide for half a day, that was good value as he showed us the different areas and brought some structure and history to the maze of stalls and crafts. They do like to take you to their favourite palces to buy, but no-one was pushy and no one got upset when we said no.

great experience. Absolutely go at night, when the sure and the media turn into a living circus with clowns magicians and fortune tellers.crawling with people and animals great adventure.Very very well recommended.

mixed feelings on Marrakech. I found myseelf agreeing with many of the bad reviews and some of the good.If you are staying here for more than a day or two,book yourself into a riad near Jamaa El Fna (square), then you can retreat to peace and quiet.Once out of your riad you will be relentlessly pestered if you even dart a glance into the scarf shop; Bartering is good fun but start low and never pay more than 35-40per cent of asking price.The square at night is utterly manic, with dancing berbers, snake charmers and pathetic monkeys dressed for photo ops., the local cheap food stalls sell decent quality local food but avoid the pastilla unless you like bakewell pudding with strips of chicken in it...Also if you are female prepare to be goosed at least twice a night especially after midnight when the square gets a little threatening, even if you are with a partner;watch for begging children around the ice cream stall and the cash machines, they look cute but are expert dippers.If you feel strongly about animal welfare this is not the place for you, snakes monkeys and donkeys have a pretty tough time.If you can pre arrange your arrival transfer do so ,the taxis here will try and charge you £30 to drive 5 mins. from airport and then charge you extra for luggage!Finally as we left early for the airport I noticed a donkey pulling a large cart with dozens of boxes all marked "made in China".This place is not the romantic idyll it once was decades ago, just look at the5 star hotel resorts on the edge of townI would head for the coast or mountains.....you have been warned.......

Shop, shop, shop - just watch for the bikes!. Pros: A huge variety of shops with lots of interesting merchandiseCan get good deals if you haggleMostly sheltered from the sunCons:Some of the shopkeepers are clearly out to con you. The constant need to haggle to get a fair price gets tiring after a whileReal risk of injury from mopeds and cycles if you don't keep you wits about youCan get a bit lost and then risk having to pay someone to get you back on the right track.

Noisy, crazy, colourful experience.. A labyrinth of side streets and alley ways, easy to get lost yet easy to learn your way around too. Lots to see and do. Lots of interesting things to buy. We spend a few hours each days working our way through the Medina and enjoyed every moment of it.
Souks. the souks were a lot of fun. They were not in your face and willing to barter. Some even invited us in for tea.
More subdued that you'd think. I'm not so sure we saw this properly as it wasn't heaving as I'd expected. Very friendly and welcoming people though.
Wonderful place. Place full of wonderful things to see. We spent some of our time at night sat in a cafe watching all the hustle and bustle go by. It was a wonderful experience.

Look Out. There are many interesting places to visit within the medina however with the traffic that flows through there , you need to watch your step. Some shop keepers can be very persistent and you need to be very firm if you are not interested in their wares. Many also do not like you taking photos, it's a good idea to ask first.

Back in time. When you get over the cultural shock that scares you among mopes, bikes and donkey carts you start feeling back in time like you were living in the middle age, absolutely authentic and pure. Everyone has to live it :)

Very lively. A must go! We went here a few times in the evening to dine and just shop, it can become very busy so keep your daughters close!! My daughter was whistled at and called shakira a few times until my son gave the culprits 'the look'! But overall enjoyed it.

Be prepared to bargain!. Where to start? Haggling is the number one sport and passion for Moroccans! They are offended if you don't try to bargain with them.... Mind you, they are very good at it but in the end, it is a win win for all

Don't miss it!. My girlfriend and I wandered in her about half an hour after arriving at our hotel one evening in August. Yes it's busy and noisy and hot, but it is well worth a visit. We also visited it twice during the day and enjoyed it both times.Owners will try to get you stop at their shops, but a polite no usually discourages them and you can move on without any hassle. Be prepared to spend a good few hours wandering around and don't be afraid to haggle if you want to buy something. It is expected!Do be aware of slightly more annoying individuals who will try to latch on to you and act as impromptu tour guides! We actually had a good and bad experience of this. An older gentleman called Mohammed proved a great source of information and was so charming, we ended up walking round for about 3 hours in his company! He knew lots about the medina and souks, the religious background of various buildings and sections of the medina. He took us off the beaten track of which we were a little wary at first, but it was worth it. On another occasion a teen ager rode his bike along side us for about 2 minutes, directing us to the main square, even though we didn't need or ask for directions as this was our 3rd visit. He asked for money and when we refused he got a little abusive, throwing every swear word he had learned at us. But it didn't ruin our visit and wouldn't put us off visiting gain.
Overwhelming. My daughter was totally overwhelmed to the point of being scared. It was noisy, dirty and chaotic but we got some good bargains.
A fascinating city I need to further explore. It was busy but friendly and being in the medina as an older person alone I felt very safe. I would love to return to marrakesh

A little scary but very entertaining!. Loved the people and the randomness, plus the street food which you have to try. Keep your belongings safe though and be prepared to haggle if you want to buy anything! Ignore any insults too when you don't want to buy from them..

A bit too much. Honestly I had expected more out of the Medina. It was too smelly, chaotic and hot. Scooters and bikes almost killed us so many times. Maybe it's because I can see this kind of thing at any time in Lebanon (where I'm originally from). But the Medina wasn't for me.

Thriving!. I loved this place! Thriving, exciting, surprising but also shocking and unpredictable. I was amazed by the atmosphere. Monkeys, snakes, flutes, storytellers, magicians, etc. it all took me aback as you will never see it while travelling across Europe. Better to visit in the evening/at night than in the day because not much is actually happening. A must-see place for anyone visiting Morocco.

Crazy bustle,. Untidy, smelly but fascinating . Liked watching the chaos. It was extremely hot . Scooters and bikes vi with taxis for road space. Every where there are stalls of every kind selling souvenirs , clothes, rugs fruit and veg.

we watched acrobats, snake charmers, herbalists, storytellers and more. We loved the place jma el fna in the centre of Marrakech -full of activity and spectacle. A must do activity for all adventurous travellers.

« Marrakesh »The alleyways of the Medina. In Marrakesh, When you first arrive in the Medina you wonder how you will ever find your way around.The network of alleyways is somethingwei have not come across before. Some of the alleyways are a bit daunting especially at night, although wi never felt threatened at any time. Watch out for the moped rider or cyclist who appear out of nowhere with only inches between you and them.Many of the riads are situated in the alleyways and it is a challenge finding your way back especially by night !!
Mad mad mad. Loved it!!! Exciting noisy and fun!! Bargain away I suggest starting at a quarter and not paying more than a third of initial price!!! Great fun

Loose in the medina and have fun!. We have spent three days in Marrakech and it has been a fantastic experience. We have been walking around following the map provided by the riad and we ejoyed our walking around looking for the places to be seen, smelling the scents of the souq, filling our eyes with wonderful colors and images.

Lots of shopping, but annoying and stinky. Meh, the Medina is alright if you are going on a guided tour that way no one (or a very reduced number of people) bothers you. Walking around the Medina on your own is like walking through a trash dump honestly. It's very easy to get lost and people are constantly harassing you, not to mention the streets are filthy, like really disgusting. There are a few neat palaces to see and other museums and historical spots but please save yourself a TON of hassle and book a tour to see those things. It's too easy to get pick-pocketed as well.

Know what to expect. The Medina is a labyrinth of alleys and souks. It may be overwhelming to travelers. Suggest you take plenty of change (good luck on that) because if you look lost, or ask for directions, you'll quickly adopt a guide who will expect to be paid for walking you around. The souk generally has the same merchandise. Know that some areas have a concentration of clothing, fabrics, rugs, woven handbags, or other items, but kitsch is everywhere. As for buying, definitely demand half the price originally quoted you, and work up very slowly. If it's something you can't live without, know that before you walk away from a deal for good. Otherwise, most merchants will have the same items elsewhere.
poor area rubble looking area. Looked very poor outside of the hotel did not quite look as if some one was building or knocking some thing down the medina has some nice bits
crazy town. loved the busyness of the streets, having to fight your way through mopeds, donkeys with carts, masses of people. strange but fantastic experience

Bargain Hunt!. You cannot afford to miss a visit to the Medina, mix with locals,sample some street food, spend time caressing silk and woollen garments and sip on some mint tea to cool you off.Packed with the masses and buzzing with life- just keep on demanding a lower price..it's all in the eyes!

Shopping paradise!. The medina is a wonderful place to just roam around for the day and get lost. If you are good at haggling, you can score some great deals on unique items. Every corner seems to be filled with color and culture.
An epic experience. This truly is an epic experience. I would highly recommend getting a guide. Give yourself several hours.

Medina by night. Horse drawn carraige tour of the old and new parts of the city and then time in the square to take in the atmosphere do some haggling, have photo,s with Monkeys, snake or a vulture ! Or you could just stay in the restaurant have a drink and wait for coach back, a good experience
A look into history. The medina reminds you of what old cities probably looked like. It's a wonderful experience losing yourself in the many souks.
a treat. a must see and experience, a bit intense but such a different thing to your average holiday stuff, also one advise: haggle, haggle, haggle!

Watch out for scooters.. After visiting 6 Medinas in Morocco we rated Marrakech and Fez about equal. They are quite different from each other but both are a lot of fun and an adventure for a first time visitor. You have no choice but to be lost but try and not do it too late at night although the streets are well lit and surprisingly safe at all hours. I am told the Medina police do a good job of protecting the tourist trade.The huge plaza is a lot of fun and becomes an entertainment zone at night. Lots of restaurants, food carts, snake charmers and the dreaded scooter. Scooter riders drive as though the narrow streets are empty so you have to be constantly aware not to get in their way. Break you day up because we were often tired and needed a break and then ready to go back for more.

Awful experience. (We visited this place in june 2013, but I still would like to share my experience with potential travelers)I totally agree with Charlene S: who is getting paid for writing good reviews? It is an awful place to stay because of a number of reasons!First of all the way they treat animals. Horses all day in the burning sun (in the summer!) without getting any water, monkeys on ropes etc etc). If you would see those things in Nordwest Europe, you would be shocked and call somebody to rescue those poor animals.Then, the husslers. They simply WON'T LEAVE YOU ALONE. They just want your money, and nothing else. There's no such thing as walking around and enjoying your holiday. Everybody wants something and that something is MONEY! They want you in their shops and restaurants so they get their commission! Honestly, if they would have left us alone, we surely would have bought some nice souvenir. But not now, they just don't seem to understand that their approach is working against them.It really bothered us that we had no space of our own. We felt pretty intimidated. We planned to stay here for two nights but we left one day earlier for Essaouira (nice place, almost no husslers!) just because we were fed up with it! If you like to be treated like a walking ATM, the medina of Marrakech is the place to be. If you don't and want to meet genuine people and a beautiful landscape, go somewhere else (Essaouira, the rural area)!
Another Must. The Medina, Like Fna is a must see. Life, laughter, battering, bargains lots to see. Entertainment without the price tag. A wonderful experience.

Must see experience. Loved this place lots, went everyday when we were in Marrakech. Loved seeing the sites, different colours, foods and generally walking around having a laugh.Would definitely recommend and go again, maybe the best experience in Marrakech/Morocco and entertaining too.

Smelly. Nothing much to see, the maze of dirty alleyways littered with tourist tat. Moroccan men with snakes & monkeys, demanding money for the privilege of having their captive animals thrust upon you. Always check your change, waiters in cafe's putting your money in their pockets, then disappearing to look after other customers, only to give you your money back when challenged a couple of times. Very tiresome!Would not visit Morocco again, once is definitely enough, but unnecessary. Save your money and visit India, beautiful country!

Shopping fantasy. This is really the highlight of the city. It can be overwhelming so take some breaks from exploring and shopping. As a single woman I did get hassled and followed, but I was expecting this and was very direct to get rid of them. Didn't ruin the experience. I loved just wandering the medina and getting lost.
amazing experience. really enjoyed the whole haggling process for my bargins , the tip is you never go with the first, or second price always pay what you feel its worth to you and have fun with it!

The reason to come to Marrakech. Its hectic, its full of stalls, people, zooming motorbikes, donkey carts, its generally 7 feet wide at the max, to find excellent cafes jammed in and Riads (hotels) just down each litle blind alley is a sight to be seen. We stayed in such a Riad, and yes you do need to beware of the traffic and the kids who mis-direct you, but it will be a great memory of mayhem, how the Riad (hotel) can be so uttery peaceful and have this outside is a constant wonder to us. Keep an eye on any kids, they won't be kidnapped or anything but can get immediately lost and the bikes flying down the narrow alleys are a big danger to those who are unaware. Still I give the place 5 stars, its just GOT to be experienced, then you find the Souks and the alleys get narrower, although thankfully the motorbikes are banned from that part (in theory at least).
Medina adventure. Loved the culture, colours, history and diversity. Must travel to all the palaces and mosques, so historically colourful.

Sadly such a letdown.. I had great expectations. I am easily pleased. But no matter how hard I wanted to like the place, I just couldn't. Perhaps in days gone by things were different, plesant, charming, an experience to savour. Now it is simply a tourist trap, and somewhere you will have nearly every man and his dog trying to extract every last dirham out of you. Sadly the experience will leave you not being able to trust even those genuinely friendly helpful people that want to point you in the right direction. If a place can leave you feeling like you can't trust ANYONE then there is something under lyingly wrong.

The beating heart of Marrakesh. Getting lost in the Medina is the only way to experience this city. Might be frustrating at times, but you find hidden gems, and you get the real feel of what Marrakesh has to offer. Some of the best restaurants for local food are located right here. Don't miss it!

Touristic medina, which does not have the quality of the medina's of e.g. Fez. After having visited the medinas of Fez, Rabat and Meknes, the medina of Marrakesh was somewhat disappointing, for it seems to be mostly important for tourists instead of for the local people.

You can't not see it..... This is a sight to behold, and experience. Not for the feint hearted or short tempered either. Also be aware, there will always be people looking to exploit you if you look vulnerable or lost. So be confident, be firm but polite and don't be shy to turn away or say 'No!". The Medina is alive all day and every day, it is incredible to see. If you want to see the snake charmers go in the day ( I didn't), but you may get more than you bargained for. I found most people to be polite and genuine, and the tourists that were respectful to the culture were mostly left alone. So dress appropriately and be polite. There are a few good bars near the square, just look tot he roof tops. And eating in the square is also recommended. You'll be ok, you're just as likely to get an upset stomach from your hotel as you are in the square. Try stall 117 (stairway to heaven)... fun chaps...

indescribable experience. getting lost in marrakech's medina is an amazing, unique experience. i have never been to any place in the world that can compare to this.i can't even make any recommendations because it is so hard to find anything, including your way out, so schedule enough time for your visit.

Intense Morocco. I was here in July, and it was super hot. During Ramadan its apparently a lot more quiet than normal, which is probably why it was slightly less crazier for me then for some other reviewers. At night, the place really came alive for Ramadan. Try the Goats Head and Brain, it is actually not that bad

Medina not for the faint hearted. Lots of meat, fish and vegetables on display, quiet smelly and we were hassled by so called guides.
There was amaze of streets and this was a shock on our first day in Marrakesh, not for the average tourist

Get lost in the Medina. Getting lost in the Medina is so fun and all the souks and people. Just amazing!
The Medina is a must for everybody visiting Marrakech.

fine if you like being hassled and fleeced. constantly avoiding scooters avoiding starting up conversations with shop keepers as they will inevitably try and tempt you to buy something for ridiculously over-inflated prices. avoiding letting people 'show you the way'.
yep a very pleasant way to spend the day indeed. nothing particularly rewarding about being constantly badgered.
Beautiful place. So lovely to stay where the typical morracains live their everyday life, loved every minute of it, so vibrating.

excellent. I will warn you now this is not for everyone. However if you are prepared to embrace culture and respect it and keep an open mind you will have a great time. I spent 3 weeks here and i loved every minute of it .
Good variety of shopping, be prepared to barter.. Suggest that you always shop with your girlfriend/wife, do not let her go into the market alone becauseshe can be pestered by unwelcome locals!
mmmm. ok. been to more interesting & ethnic places. Maybe that was too long ago. Can see why they're building so much new stuff now

watch out for cars!. I love Marrakech but if you are in the medina and want to cross the road- watch out for cars! The hustle and bustle are part of the experience but you do want to live to tell the story. It is all part of the experience that is Marrakech.

Twists & Turns at every corner!. What can I say? If you have never been lost in a maze before then you are definitely in for a treat! There are so many different things to see at every turning - shops, Haman places, Excursion Centres, Corner shops , Cafes, Tailors etc. It is fascinating as well as you have to dodge Cyclists, Cats, Motorcycles, Bicycles, Donkeys pulling carts and people offering to show you the tourist places or being too helpful! If you are staying in a Riad within the Medina, just look for a landmark and keep the Riad's address with you at all times so that if you get lost, you can show it to a shopkeeper (Not over friendly guys offering to help you for a fee) who will direct you. Above all, feel free and explore the area. You will be suprised at what you will find!
Interesting and atmospheric. Suggest you get a guide to take you around as it is easy to get list. Embrace the local culture but be careful of being approached for money and food.

Hectic. A must see but you really need to be careful. We are experience travellers and yet still managed to be conned into following someone to the 'genuine Berber market'. You are constantly hassled and it can be quite stressful but if you are prepared, it is a great experience.
Fab shopping!. Lovely hidden restaurants and feast for the senses! Have your wits about when crossing the road, all manor of things use the road with no apparent order!!

medina. Liked: It's the real culture - very different to UK. Lots of stalls.
Disliked: Too crowded, lots of pikpockets

Hot and Busy!. A real eye opener - chaos on the roads - scooters, horse and carts, coaches, taxis and cars - there don't seem to be any rules! Incredibly busy and vibrant - an absolute must, especially in the evening.

Not for the fainthearted but worth visiting. We had a city tour as part of our holiday package and it was a walking tour of the Medina. If we hadn't been on the tour it would have been impossible to see the reality of life in the Medina because it can be daunting to venture down the narrow twists and turns. It's an amazing place - you can find virtually anything you want and get quite skilled at haggling; there are so many tempting spices, remedies, souvenirs, but then you remember the baggage limitations. It can be a little offputting seeing the flies feasting on the pastries or meat on sale, but it's all part of the experience!It's essential to wear comfortable shoes and have small change (10 dirham coins for example), to give if you pause to watch bread being made, or take a photo of a local. We had a lovely afternoon.Our tour guide was from Click Excursions, but be aware you will be taken to fairly pricey shops and a Moroccon pharmacy tour that extols the marvelous virtues of Aargan oil (without giving any prices) and before you know it, the total is a few thousand dirhams! Only on researching one of the products on return did I learn that the oil should never be kept on plastic bottles - dark bottles are better to avoid deterioration caused by sunlight. The key is to only buy what you really need and enjoy the testers and 20 dirham massage!
Hang on to Your Dihrams. Lots to see here, but be ready for the full on assault of snake charmers, henna painters, "guides" and salesmen. They will work you for every penny.

Wished I stayed outside Medina. Do not venture into the Souks area unless you know where your going as everyone tries to send you the WRONG way and then you end up lost at their "tannery". Do not follow anyone. I had someone telling me the square was down one alleyway and yet I knew for a fact it was the other direction. They even scrubbed off the directions on the signs so tourists will get lost! Everywhere you turn people are trying to get money off you. It's a very stressful place. I will not miss it when im home

What an amazing experience!. In reflecting on the journey my wife and I took through Morocco, I have concluded no Moroccan journey can be complete without exploring the different Medinas of this Kingdom. While the Medinas are similar in many ways, they all have their unique characteristics which distinguish them. The Medina of Marrakech is a vibrant place that offers all manner of goods, foods, spices and fresh juices. Once the evening arrives, the vibrancy grows as the square comes alive with food stalls, acrobats, entertainers---and the scores of people there to experience it all. However, don’t just look, try to enjoy and savor the experience. Try some delicious orange juice or lamb or just give a friendly “bon jour” or “bon soir” to one of the many friendly people you will meet.This Medina has generally wider passages which are open to the sky which lends a certain brightness to everything. However, as with all of the Medinas, the Marrakech Medina is a feast for the senses. From the spice souks, to the fresh roasted lamb, to the souks selling mint tea glasses, slippers and carpets there is a great deal to take in. You will also smell all of the fragrances from the different spices being sold throughout the medina.I recommend taking a day (or two or three. . . .) and explore the Medina during the day into to evening. The change is remarkable and somewhat unique to the Marrakech Medina. This experience will undoubtedly be a highlight of your journey through Morocco.

Just there you can understand Marrakech!. The Medina could be, at first impression, a though place. But once you understand the rhythm and the pace if the place, the behavior of the people and the kindness of everyone there, you will be thinking on travel again to here.Enjoyable architecture, meaningful all over the place.Don't be afraid, just a bit of common sense will help.

Must walk on it without fear. Get to know the artisanal products and people of Marrakech, walk around the medina even at night!
Just watch out with little beggars

This is why you come to Marrakech!. I gave it a 5 star but it could easily be a 2 or 3 star. Some will like it; some won't. It's a glimse into life centuries ago and the way it used to be in the medinas. We were with a group of about 35 and went twice to the area. First, we took a carriage ride and saw the place at night. The sights and sounds (and smells) are amazing. This is when the locals come to the medina. Lots of eating places that cater to the locals but as a tourist I would not eat anything in those places...The next day we went to see the touristy side. Complete with snake charmes and people trying to sell you everything.... They all want money to take pictures so be prepared to pay a little or snap on the sly. I would suggest you always go with a tour guide as you could easily get lost.Don't miss it!
An assault on the senses. Amazing. Full of life and character. Sights, smells, tastes and colour! People everywhere, and you need 360degree vision to take it all in!

The old twn of Marrakech - the medina. We stayed in the medina - do not be tempted to stay in the new town. Get the real feel of Marrakech by staying in the medina.It is an old walled town with very narrow streets. Many small Raid hotels (try Riad Capaldi), very friendly people, fascinating and beautiful sites, good restaurants.The medina is quite small so you can walk a lot of it but there are also taxis and horse/cart transport.
Madina. More relaxed than medina of Fes, it is a good place to wander and spend time shopping or just looking at all the colorful things. Go deeper for cheaper prices.

Not friendly and unspectacular. The square was full of street sellers invading your space and following you along, even when you told them no. It was also dirty and smelly from the various animals that were present. After walking around the (much more interesting) souks theres nothing new to see in the square either.

Depends What You Are Looking For or Expect to Find. This Medina or town is of average size much smaller than the one in Fez but larger than Casablanca's. Remember this is not going to be like your home town market, this is a very different culture, so explore and understand. It is smelly, dirty, has beggar's, lots of animals and shops. We walked from our hotel past the Mosque to the open market and then strolled through the side streets. Did some shopping, bought some lamps and shoes for decoration in our home. Had a good afternoon exploring then went back to our hotel.

Busy & chaotic. Be ready for hassle! Very bustling (as expected) but you will be approach very frequently by children, men & women asking for money; trying to sell something, or trying to tempt you. Be aware of pick-pockets!

beautiful, big and confuse. I went to Marrakesh after Fez, and I must to say that I did get a little bit scared of the medina. Much bigger, tourist and chaotic than Fez. They allow the entrance of motorbike and one must be careful not to get hit. But it is very characteristic and I think that represents very well the spirit of the city with colors, smells and flavors from Morroco.
Old Town Charm. Everthing that you want to see in an old town. Great restaurants all around the center square. Great local merchandise.

Hypnotizing. The medina is very charming. Djema el fna is COMPLETELY different when the sun is down. By day, snake charmers and women with henna will chase you down! There are two souks as well to buy souveniers and food. Many restaurants line the plaza. You must try the fresh juices - go to cart #23! You won't regret it, you'll thank me. By night, things change. Almostout of nowhere it seems, the square transforms with a bunch of pop up restaurants serving traditional morrocan food. Music is being played, dancers putting on a show. Walk through at different hours to see what I'm talking about!

Medina Experience. We visited Marrakech and decided to see for ourselves what the fuss was about. Soon as we got near the markets we had a gentleman ask us if we were looking for anything specific. Word of advice do not be rude or ignore these gentleman, best answer is to say just looking thank you. The markets are in fact very busy and you can get anything you want from beautiful Moroccan craft to fake Hollister flip flops. Always bargain up to 60% on what ever you want to purchase and keep your money safe. The Medina has some nice places to eat (not posh) from Kebabs to Pizzas to the Traditional Tajine. Overall a very good experience specially if you enjoy the hustle and bustle of the city.

Interesting and lively. Fascinating experience you will never forget from the almost medieval street markets to the beautiful mosques and the vibrant and lively souks. Be prepared to be approached constantly with offers of taxis, guides etc. don't get I to any conversation or the expectation is for some money to change hands for the exchange of information
