A place to get lost. The many nooks and crannies of the Medina are a pleasure to wander through and possibly loss one's way in the many narrow street and alleyways. You are assailed by the many smells of leather and spice that permeate the air. Keep the mood light and be pleasant to the many merchants offering their wares, a firm no should be sufficient. It can be hot and stuffy so ensure you have enough water with you until you see the light of day. It is something that should not be missed during any visit to Marrakech.
Medina. Great for browsing around stalls and getting a feel for Moroccan food and lifestyle. Worth looking down the little alleyways and exploring

Amazing by night, quiet by day. We visited the Medina twice during our stay and night visits are a must! During the day it's really quiet and there isn't much to see. Our night visit we sat on the terrace at one of the restaurants and sipped on mint tea whilst enjoying the view of the amazing lights of the Medina. Something that has to be done!!!A lot of people trying to sell things and loads of entertainment. Definitely a site to see :-)

Who is being paid to write these reviews?..... My first hand experience of the Medina was not a good one. In fact, it was so poor I am beginning to question the authenticity of the 'Excellent' and 'great' reviews written on here. I am genuinely at a point where I believe holiday makers are paid to write a good review so people visit the Medina when they go to Morocco. Here are just a few things we came across upon our visit to the Medina.  - animal cruelty is rife. Stray cats and dogs in the poorest of health roaming everywhere - The locals spit at you and give you intimidating stares if you wear shorts, show your shoulders or have your hair out - The Medina is VERY unsafe at night. Do NOT even think of going there if you visit during the month of Ramadan. (We only visited at night because it was closed during the day due to Ramadan) - Flies, bees, insects, whatever are all over the food in the market. Basically, if that was seen in England, it would be H&S and the stall would be closed down.  - Very poor hygiene in and around the Medina - The smell.... Don't even get me started on the smell. Horse poo, camels, large unemptied bins overflowing with rubbish, sewerage.. These are all the smells we smelt on a daily basis.There is nothing good about the Medina. Seriously. Think about it..... How is poor hygiene good? Or animal cruelty? Or disgusting smells? There's a very fine line between embracing culture and being subject to holiday hell. Perhaps I am just used to the finer things in life.. If this is you too -- avoid this place at all costs. You'll be thanking me in the end. I'm a very fair reviewer and would never lie about an experience. P.S - I could say so much more.... But you'll probably stop reading after a while and get bored. Those were my main issues and probably will be yours too. Just think... If you were in England and saw a kitten with a broken foot, it would make you feel sad right? Times that feeling by 100 when you visit this country (And I'm not even a cat person!!)
Must experience. I could have spent my whole vacation in the Medina. So much to see, buy, eat. There was nothing I did not like about it.

An experience.... A crazy maze. Make sure you have a guide with you if you visit the medina. Otherwise , be ready to waste your time looking for places, asking for directions, trying to pass politely everyone's offer to sell you something or to lead you somewhere and people asking for money. As we experienced, be aware about asking permission before taking photos of people & their wares. You may ask their permission to be photographed & in exchange they will ask you for about 10 dirhams (approx. €1)
THE KASBAR. This is such an interesting place to visit (the original town). It is 100% authentic and I had the privilege of staying there.
Enjoy the hustle and bustle. Loved the Medina, full of colour and character. Very safe, Go and enjoy this unique place. Plenty of little cafes to recharge your batteries in.

You will get lost!. Guaranteed, at some point you will get lost BUT you will find your way home with the help of the locals. Ask the shopkeepers rather than the boys who are hanging out in the souks. Can get some great deals if you haggle - expect to pay 30% less than they ask.

Keep your wits about you!. Fantastic place to submerge yourself in culture with smells, colours, vibrancy, sound and sights. From snake charmers, to escargots stands, to local cuisine, to souvenirs, to henna tattoos to bargains it has it all! But keep your wits about you! When you sit at the stalls for food you think you are getting a quality cheap meal, but they will keep bringing over entrees which you think is in with the meal but they charge you for it all which soon hikes up cost of meal! Women will grab you and start to put henna on you. Stand your ground and say you don't want it. When a woman did this to my friend I told her she was allergic and she wiped it straight off! You can get lost in the streets so try and spot recognisable stalls to navigate your way back out. A men claiming to be a stall holder tried to get me and my friend to follow him down back lanes but we latched onto an eldery English couple and stuck with them till we felt safe. It's not a place to wonder off alone if you are female. Don't be insulted when you don't buy as some will do, just ignore and walk away. Expect to be harrased but go for the experience! It's a fantastic place

Unique. Narrow alleys everywhere you look, full of all kinds of life and colour. Carpets, shoes, clothes, metalwork, wood carvings, herbalists etc. Nothing is tacky, it is beatifully made by people trying to scratch a living, but doing it with a smile. Learn to no thanks in Arabic and they generally leave you be!
MEDINA. Lovely place, so much to see day and night. You can spend all day just walking and see thinks, you have to try some local food and have fresh orange juice!

Manic Marrakech... Well, what can I say..just visited Marrakech and stayed within the Medina. It's a rather smelly place, ranging from bad to good. Nice spices and soaps to the opposite extreme! I am in my 40s and felt quite safe in the city, but I can easily understand why you may not. There are many dark alleys and poorly lit areas. It is the sort of place to go for an experience but I certainly wouldn't take children, elderly or disabled people . The place just isn't equipped for it. Forget it if you are in a wheel chair.We met an American family and the two children were quite distressed by the way they perceived the animals being treated. Thin donkeys, horses and cats. I guess it could come across as being unfriendly but then why wouldn't it when, to a local, every tourist he meets wants to screw him down to the last penny of profit! These people are the same as us, they want to make a living. Pay them what they ask and they might be friendlier. How would you fancy having to haggle for your wage every month?It is a place that thankfully we can visit and return from and maybe think that our own place isn't that bad after all lol.

Not relaxing but worth a visit. Visiting a Medina is not for everyone but if you like the idea of getting lost, discovering new roads, smells, colours, objects of any kind and if you are not bothered by hundreds of sellers then it's definitively a must.My experience in the Medina of Marrakesh has been quite positive mainly because I didn't have the need to buy anything therefore I could enjoy the walk almost undisturbed.Beware of scooters though!

Qite unfriendly place. The old town centre of Marrakesh worths visiting but the visitor should be prepared for a lot of dirt around most stands, people permanently offering their goods and services (of varied quality but usually at much higher than corresponding price that can be hardly decreased by negotiation to a reasonable level), not accessible mosques, and definitely aggressive pickpockets,

'The' experience of Marrakech. You have to experience a trip to and walk around the medina to fully appreciate the Marrakech culture. Lets face it, you're in Marrakech, if you want luxury and cleanliness you're visiting the wrong city.Its a real experience to wonder and navigate your way through the medina and souks, if you want it they have it, from spices like Safron to wonder ornate light fittings which you'll wonder when you've bought them, how on earth you're going to get them home ( we seen a british couple from our hotel purchase 2 hugh fittings and then scratch their heads back at the hotels as to how they were getting home ) You're going to come across some really friendly characters who you can watch making their wares outside their souks and you're going to also come across some not so friendly characters who will do their best to draw you in and make a purchase. Just be firm, but friendly and stick tot your guns.On average you should aim to offer around 1/3 of the asking price as a starter.When you're done and all shopped out, take a walk outside and find a rooftop terrace to experience the sunset.The medina does't really come to life until 9:30-10:00pmGood luck and enjoy.

Medina Marrakech. When entering this Medina you are first struck with stall after stall of wares, noise and different aromas.Yes it's busy and noisy but if you take your time and browse at your leisure it can be a great experience. Don't be rushed or hustled.There are many stalls offering the same products. If you chose to buy think of a price that you are happy to pay. Relate that price to the average prices in that country ask yourself would you pay the equivalent back home. Always keep a smile on your face and never lose your sense of humour "your on holiday". This after all is an experience that should be on your to do list whilst in Marrakech.

Intimidating horrible place. The Medina was my worst taste of Marrakech - we ventured in only twice and both times we felt very intimidated.I was travelling with my daughter and we were dressed very sensibly, however that didn't stop the endless sexual comments and the stray hands - we got lost at one point just trying to get away from an unpleasant situation and when a very kind young man tried to help us I have to say I snapped - but he was kind and he did help us find our way back. So there are some great people there, but my overreaching memory of the Medina is not good.I think had we been travelling with a man it may have been a different experience for us
Souks. Great value for money and gifts can be cheap.but it's hard work when you have to haggle all the time.

Buyer beware. We loved Marrakech as much for the contrast between the old city (medina) and the new city. However, what soured us on the Marrakech experience was that we bought an expensive tajine in what was supposed to be a reputable store in the medina. We did the usual negotiation and even managed to get a "deal" at 60% less than the original asking price. We thought we had just bought the most beautiful tajine. When we got home to Canada we really wanted to unpack our tajine to make sure it arrived safely after all the flights it had been on. Unfortunately, we were in for a big disappointment. It looks as though we were scammed. Now we know what happens when you are not paying enough attention and get caught up in the superficial beauty of a particular piece. The workers in the store were particularly keen to pack the tajine by themselves and away from our prying eyes. When we got the piece unpacked we could see that the red stones were in fact plastic and the colour had been rubbed off as the piece was moved through the various airports. It is also really apparent that the workmanship was nowhere close to the quality we had thought we were buying. How did this happen? We don't really know. We are not careless purchasers. We look carefully at what we are buying. We either missed the quality problems with this piece or the piece we thought we were buying was switched for a piece of junk. We are really disappointed, in ourselves, in the people who sold us this piece, in our guide for taking us to a place that would sell such shoddy products but mostly in ourselves. The medina is fascinating. I just wouldn't recommend paying big bucks for anything unless you can be absolutely sure of the quality.
Watch out for Henna ladies. A typical souk, hustle and bustle, haggling etc. only negative aggressive henna ladies. Worth going to see the tanneries if you have not experienced the smell before.

A New Experience. The medina is not your average American shopping experience by far. It is full of shops side by side and everyone is "pressuring" you to come in and buy. It's great for haggling but can get exhausting because the shop owners are nice but relentless. BE FIRM. There are great steals here on leather and furniture and rugs. Everything is beautiful!

Great experience. Try the medina for a bargain haggle hard and stand your ground. Beware of pick pockets in the crowds . The Souks are amazing but easy to get lost. Remember where you enter and keep your bearings. Have a coffee over looking the square at night it's a great experience.

A different way to shop. Medinas around the middle east are amazing places to shop. This is one of the bigger ones but didn't have the same feel about it as others in Morocco. You have to be very firm in what you want and how to deal with pushy staff but that is no different to other places around the world. There is the trash (as there is everywhere) but there is also some very good merchandise and finding that is the trick. Like every busy place one needs to be security conscious and be aware of your situation at all time, it is easy to become lost in these places, particularly if you are on a tight time schedules.

Out of this world. Absolutely brilliant. To think this place has not changed for over 1000 years. Great bargain to be had if you are good a haggling. You should never pay more than a 1/3 of the asking price. Come down lower and work your way up a little bit. Beautiful leather goods. Check for the quality.

Whole place like a cockroach nest. This should be renamed "shakedown square" EVERY person just wants your € $ ¥ £ ₩ etc,.,,nothing else, dont be illusionied thinking otherwise.. You will be bombarded with people selling, junk, tissues, henna, where No! Means keep asking, then once walking away, they follow you, it's a nightmare.The starving children was hard to see, as area is packed with restaurants that don't seem to feed the poor, a virtue of Islam, is to never to see their own starve... Seems to be missing from the medina.. I personally fed several starving children, from 2 years old to early teens. The restaurants would get angry to see them eating, throw stuff at them and try to kick them, which I had to always tell them to stop.Place is only concerned about your money and they don't respect the tourists... Police have a somewhat limited presence, if you don't speak French or Arabic you're wasting your time.

Tourist Trap. It sad that this Medina has sold its soul to tourism, much better medinas in Rabat, Fes & Tangier. It was my first visit to a Medina and I noticed that it was almost like a tourist attraction which is very sad. It appeared to have lost the character of what I am sure was once a place full of adventure and unique sights and had become a mecca for tourists willing to pay outrages prices for fake oils, souvenirs etc. I was also sad to see the poor condition of the horses used to pull tourists in carriages around hot cobbled streets.

A Walk in the Past. Loved staying a a riad in Marrakesh and being able to walk freely throughout the maze of narrow streets and paths. I was able to sit on a bench in the heart of a strictly local area where the residents met in the evening to chat while the children played. I even kicked back a soccer ball to the delight of the local boys. In the morning I chatted with a group of lovely schoolgirls who giggled a lot. Never at any time was I afraid. My riad was off the beaten path so I had to walk it alone many times including at night. One day on my way back to my riad I noticed a crowd around a shop and stopped to investigate. I ended up drinking the most delicious fruit drink I ever had. It was made of fresh pineapple, strawberries, bananas, and kiwi for only fifty cents (US). I did buy one for another local senior and we stood there enjoying each other and our delicious drink. Keep your eyes open for these special gems!
Medinas. I've been to the Medina in Fez,Rabat, etc. Of you have seen 1 medina, you have seen Aboutaleb all of the Medinas. But it is always Nice to do for one day.

Into another world. Walking through all the narrow walkways with shops and riads at every turn gives a wonderful sense of what it must of been like hundreds of years ago. Happy to say that on the whole the shop keepers are a lovely bunch and really don't hassle you. Only sad thing is that a few years ago it was mainly donkey's buzzing through but now there are lots of motorbikes which not only pollutes the air but is noisy and at times stressful, hopefully, they will limit this and bring back the normal day to day hustle and bustle without the noise & fumes of bikes!

The Red City Pise Walls and main Bab Gates.. Take a Caliche tour outside of the gates and around and about the red mud and straw brick walls. Pick them up from outside the Koutoubia Mosque and agree total price in advance in MAD. Bab Agnaou is the best and oldest gate, made of stone. An interesting one is Bab Doukkala as it's been separated from the walls by 20th centure bad planning! Allow 1 hours for a tour, best toured at sunset. Go inside the walls after to the night market in Jemma El Fna square....
A must see attraction. The best and the most authentic part of the marrakech and maybe of the entire morocco. Don't forget to bargain when u decide to buy souvenirs...

Visit the Medina of Marrakech. Across the ages, it has been the marketplace where is found the soul of the city. The local wares, the merchants and buyers, the back and forth of commerce. So true then it is of the Medina in Marrakech, made more impressive by the contrasts of commercial jets and luxury resorts surrounding this ancient marketplace. The history is as redolent as the smells, not all of them good as the donkeys and stalls contribute, but are quickly overwhelmed by cumin, cinnamon, jasmine, leather. The sounds, a tumultuous symphony of braying mules, vendors insisting entrance, cart wheels clattering, coins clinking, muezzins calling, fans whispering, the gut strings of sintirs thrumming, and hunter's horns blaring from the square. Two young men passed me in the tight alley. Dressed in traditional multicolored tasseled and fringed outfits with cone hats, I thought them acrobats from the circus. They were tea sellers. Men and women in colorful djellabas flowed by, working, shopping, their Darija dialect and French mellifluously blending as tourists dressed for comfort more than style portrayed an startling mix of cultures, and all descending into this twisting labyrinth that mixes spatters of sunlight with pools of darkness, colors sharp, smells pungent. Like a Berber carpet in an array of colors, so to the sights: hanging carcasses, poofs of lambskin, stacks of delft inscribed in arabesque poetry, herbs and hardware, Bedouin trade goods, African antiques, mounds of olives and unguents. Chatterers, bargainers, and beggars abound so, yes, the Medina is chaos, but controlled, comprehensible, and welcoming. My greatest find here was the sincere warmth of the folk. People make a market, and Marrakech's Medina is teeming with friendly faces. Do not be dissuaded from this place. Certainly, be aware of who you are and where you are, but do walk in history and be embraced by the Medina. You'll discover more than bargains.

You've got to go. Our group of eight negotiated with a guide to take us into the Medina. That was very important. DON'T GO IN THE MEDINA ALONE! First, you can definitely get lost because it really is that big. It is sprawling. Second, just go to experience the Medina. We didn't really have a plan for anything in particular. Our guide took us to a high-end clothing store and then to a building that seemed to contain many craft stores. We got clothing, shoes and jewelry. A highlight was going to what we would probably call a Health Food store. We got tea, natural medicines, herbs, oils and soaps. We watched a demonstration (in the store) of argan oil being processed and got a massage. Everything in one place. We never could have found the place without our guide. And, without the guide (Mr Moury), we probably wouldn't have found our way back to the van.

Once Inna Lifetime Hassle. The good: The ONLY reason to visit is the historical significance and the romanticism of saying you were there. The orange juice vendors are good peeps and you can negotiate a decent deal on a foam shave. The bad: The modern medina is so overpriced, even after haggling down to 30% of the asking price, that you might as well buy the junk on Ebay. The fabled days of getting an amazing deal are done. There, I said it. The Ugly: I arrived with cautious optimism and followed all the best practices of safe travel, while still trying to have a good time. I have been here five days, which is four too long. I am tired of being a target, a mark, a hunted tourist who can be illegally forced to pay for "guides" when I know damn well where I am going. Outside of the main square (Jemaa El Fnaa) there is no police presence, so good luck fending off the angry and aggressive males.

Entertainment and hassle. Everybody has their had out here. If you intend on taking any pictures be prpared to pay for it. The snake charmers will demand and will ask for more if you hold a snake. Negotiate first, before dealing with a snake charmer. The vendors do not take "No" for an answer. Just keep on walking and do not engage in any conversation if they bother you too much. Beware of pickpockets when it is really crowded. Plus you can get really lost in the back streets of the medina. Have fun and enjoy the experience.
culture. make sure you barter for a good price, dont be lead to pay full price, watch out for donkeys, miles, banana carts and people trying to help you... the atmosphere is amazing

Crowded Market Place. The whole place is different in its appeal and character but that necessarily does not mean that it is all good. The streets are filthy filled with its share of touts, vendors, street performers, beggars and shops that sells everything from clothes to spices. The prices are crazy unless you bring them down aimed with the best of haggling. I personally did not like it as somehow the place was quite intimidating with the pushing crowds and overly enthusiastic shop keepers and wannabe guides and helpers. Its just like any other market but then Medina is kind of famous and lies in the center of the city being connected to everything.

Crazy, chaotic, colourful must see place. Our riad was within the Medina and armed with a good map and a cellphone linking us back to our accommodation,we felt okay venturing out at night. The medina 'roads' and alleyways are amazing, shared by donkeys, mules, motor scooters, carts and pedestrians. The large square was colourful, noisy, and chaotic. A real assault on the all the senses. Watch out for the Henna ladies (very aggressive - firmly extract yourself from their 'grip' otherwise you are unwittingly buying an expensive experience), and be careful not to take photos of the snake charmers unless you are prepared to pay handsomely for it. The local men glare lecherously which is unpleasant and reflects the objectivity with which they regard females, but there is a lightness and general joviality about the food sellers (and particularly the orange juice sellers) which compensates. Our visit next day with a guide offered a very different and welcome experience. Compared to Fez, we felt safe. and enjoyed the large open square which Fez lacked.

Amazing. Great for a City Break, visited June this year. Would highly recommend and be prepared to haggle in the Markets, never accept first price. Also people will offer to be a tour guide.... For a fee! Great place for a Hamam massage!

Beyond description !. This is a total assault on the senses, a must see and experience, it was 42 degrees when we visited which made it even more insane, you will love it or hate it, no in between, good Cafe's and restaurants all round, be prepared to put up with some hassle as the local people are all trying to sell you their wares but are generally very happy and friendly, go try it !!

Controversial. Worth visiting, the step from the West is big and you have to take into account the lack of many things. Many precious things to see, a lot public. Locals are nice. Good to have the tourist police keeping the things on the safe, side, never felt odd on that viewpoint.

Heart of Marrakech. The Medina is really the heart of Marrakech. And to be honest you can't miss it even if you try. Leave the main squares and wonder the small streets. We got the tip that ca. 700 meters in from the main square is where the real bargains are.
A walk through. It was an interesting walk through, visiting the shops. However we felt we had enjoyed a similar walk through in Medina in Fes.

The city that sold its soul long ago....... What to say about Marrakech that has not been said before? This is my take- and you have a different one, more power to you: This place was, at some point in history, an easy and exotic destination for the Western Traveler who wanted the ease of a place with French as an available language, a place as different from the East and the West and yet familiar with both, with a history making it more amenable to non-Muslim outsiders. Camels, souks, sand, spices…. adventure. What is it now? To some of you who go, it’s a quick jaunt from Europe to a place that is “different” and yes – “exotic” in being that different. Good weather in winter, and beautiful hotels and riads that cater to your every need. Good food and rest and people waiting on you nonstop, your every wish their command. To others it will be the worst experience of your lifetime. This is not Egypt or Turkey. While those countries, if you try, and especially if you come from a non-Western heritage do offer the possibility of authentic experiences- there are no authentic experiences to be had in Marrakech other than being ripped off, abused and harassed. Any experience you THINK is authentic is not. It is constructed for you. It is Disneyland, it is theater, it is a good act. Just because the dirty streets of the medina, littered with trash, overrun with smells, and packed with interesting visions make you feel like you have stepped into an authentic world – rest assured, you have not. This is a city with no soul and no heart. It’s a place that has sold itself, long ago – for money, and greed, and far worse, an underlying dislike and hatred of “other.” Where good people are raised to take pride in living with one goal – survival, by any means necessary, and yes, with an excessive greed. These are not a hospitable people, much as the pretense is there. You will make many friends in Marrakech, you will laugh, and be complimented, and invited. You will drink tea and cookies and hear endless beautiful stories. Listen to the stories in every corner, drink the tea, smile, shake hands, and be fully aware, its all smoke and mirrors…. Not just when you are being conned into purchases by your close friend, your inn keeper, this person and that - but around every corner, in every action you take. The rest of the world is poor too, and the rest of the world needs to survive on tourists and outsiders but few in the middle east or east go about it as brazenly as those in this place. In my experience, a genuine soul is difficult if not impossible to find, and it is not worth the effort, even if they are there. These people are too good at acting, they are bred to put on a show for you - of humility, of honesty, of caring. The place is perhaps worth one visit, to experience the history, and yes, to experience the vile and soulless experience of the medina, its souks, and its inhabitants- most of whom hate Westerners with a passion- no matter what they say. Almost every kindness, every bit of ‘joy’ in this soulless place is constructed. It is a heartless and empty place, of poor people who need and grab, and of wealthy and greedy merchants who only want more, and more and more, with not an iota of the supposed tenets of the religion they supposedly live by.Separate from all this is also another world, of the highest population of drug addicts of most cities in this part of the planet-- family men who bring their kids out to get their hits - lost souls wandering streets ill and hungry- and much of the darkness that goes with that -- at night in the medina. The Northern Medina is especially where this takes on an ugly face.I will never forget my many experiences in this city, and I am glad to have had them. I will remember these characters for a lifetime. But you better have thick skin or blind eyes. Fortunately most who venture here never open their eyes to see the reality of the place.I will also never go back.

Better by night . Having been both during the day & at night I would recommend doing both however personally I prefer the atmosphere in the evening. It's buzzing around the square, so many people, music, food and excitement. You have to have plenty time to wander and see all there is to see it's huge! Haggling is a must. I have seen previous posts about the henna ladies and if you just say no and keep walking they were no bother. All the sellers are trying to get your attention but as long as your form and polite they take it well. Beware of people trying to talk, walk with you and show you the way it will end up costing you a lot of money. If your offered to be shown to the leather tanneries then say NO it will cost you and is a waste of money! You get much less bother with this kind of thing at night time. As I said be firm and polite and enjoy walking around and taking it a in. The smell of the spices are fab, the smell of the donkeys and chickens not so much!
Brilliant but very easy to get lost!. Fabulous walled medina, full of colour, noise and people. Many restaurants and cafes.... and the fresh orange juice stalls are not to be missed.

Be ready right when you hit the ground!!. If this is your first Medina in Moroco, it can be quite overwhelming. People everywhere. Shouting. Aggressive selling. Snake charmers. Belly dancers. Crowds. You'll see most everything in only a short time. We had visited the Fes Medina a week earlier, so the open spaces where a bit of a relief, but still, the wandering alleyways and hawking shopkeepers will make sure you are aware at all times.My partner and I never felt unsafe and really enjoyed just venturing around looking at all the sights and taking in all the sounds.Make sure you go out both during the day and at night to see the many different sights of a very unique experience!

Intriguing. If, like me, you research your travels before departing, the medina and souks won't surprise you. However, they will delight you. As I expected, they were crowded, diverse, and colorful. The historical sites in the Medina are best seen with a guide. You can wander the souks alone, but not in a hurry or impatience. There are signs on may walls that point to the square, but prepare to be lost if on your own. Be sure to stop for water or coffee in one of the cafés in Djemma el Fna. You'll need the water and watching people and activities is entertaining.

Hell. This market is like hell. You will get harrassed, man handled and dragged into shops. The henna woman will physically hold your arm and try and force their henna on you even after politely saying NO!
Crazy Place, but brilliant. Watch out for the Henna ladies, but other than that a great place to go, you have to try the foo in the stalls at night also.

Exotic place for bargaining. Very specific place for bargaining. You can find almost everything you need from Morocco. People (sellers) are totally different: very agressive and polite. The prices are dependent on the location of the store (close to Main Square prices become much higher).
Their organised chaos. Thank godness for our tour guide, or we would of been so lost, loads to see and ponder over and you can test out your haggling skills.......very friendly people

Beautiful. Incredible, it really deserves an excellent rating, but compared to the Fes medina it comes a narrow second. We bartered for a teapot (which I learned later probably wouldn't be safe to drink from), a tajine and a gorgeous brass lamp. Definitely check out the main square for all the action. The snake charming was interesting, but the monkeys reminded me that they were being treated poorly.

Pulsating with life. It is lively, exciting and walking through the Medina's busy streets, you have a sensory experience where all your senses are aroused.It could be a little cleaner, but we didn't mind.
See as much as you can. Nothing to dislike, visit at different times of the day/night to get the full effect of the area, watch out for the manic mopedists!!

The other Terracotta wonder. The Medina in Marrakech is defined by the Terracotta fort wall going all around the Medina. That in itself is pretty impressive. It covers quite a fair bit and one can easily get lost inside the maze of alleyways, shops selling trinkets, salons, cafes, tailors, Riads and the general hustle and bustle. I had the pleasure of staying in the Medina in Riad Laksiba so got to wonder around parts of the Kasbah area. There are many attractions within the Medina and it's somewhat safe. You don't get hassled as much - the streets are labeled in english so you work your way quite easily. Its full of life! So worth a visit.

Chaos. The only way to describe it. All of your senses are needed to maneuver your way through the Medina. Donkeys, carts, motorcycles and pedestrians all vie for the same narrow alley ways. It is different from any experience I have ever had. I highly recommend an outing in the Medina. Although we explored it for a day on our own, the second day we had a guide. This made us see and experience it on a much better level. ask at your Riad if they have someone they can refer you to.

A place where you cannot miss if you are in Morocco. This is a fantastic market square to visit, it get live by 6pm and goes on till late night, anything and everything is from Foods, spices, to metal to live stock and the place is very safe and it is amazing experience to all.

Overwhelming. The worst thing about Marrakech unfortunately was the locals. Men will stare lecherously, or worse, comment and the harrassment to buy/look is overwhelming. It feels like everyone is out to shake you down, and rip you off and their technique of selling feels overly aggressive and relentless

Spices galore. Great place to buy spices,you must haggle though,which I don't really like. Bought some copper light shades which are lovely,we paid less for two than his first price for one, ha,be brave but smile !

I want the donkeys back!. On a hot day the mopeds, smelly and smokey makes one wonder why this Souk allows this traffic. After visiting some other Souks (Fez!!) this one seems more for tourists then other places.
Medina. The medina is amazing and if you happen to get lost (which is highly likely), you are never more that 10 minutes away from The Place and will find your way back.
Shopping in the market at Marrakech. The hustle and bustle of the market was quite an experience but we disliked the monkeys, snakes and vulture being used for photographic purposes.
Little hassle - plenty to see. Was expecting a great deal of hassle in the Souk but very pleasantly surprised with virtually no hassle at all. A wonderful, vibrant place.
Action but not pushy. Wandering around with very few "come to my store" interruptions, lots of unusual artifats to consider
Centre of Morocco. Staying in a hotel within the ancient walls of the city is amazing. You will experience the sights, sounds and smells of one of the most amazing cities you will ever visit.

exciting and safe. The medina is a loud and lively place which at the same time is perfectly safe for travellers. We were two women and always felt secure. However, if you are lost, just ask women for direction (if you are a woman yourself). Men tend to bring you on along walk and then charge you for it (but you'll still arrive). If you know where you are going, don't listen to men who tell you that you are walking into the wrong direction or that the place you are going to is closed. It's mostly not true and they just want to lure you into a shop. But rely, this is the worst what could happen and the place is still brilliant.

difficult. Very difficult to review as we travelled a lot in morroco and visited many cities. If it is your only medina you will enjoy. Get lost in the small lanes but If you ask for help everyone will lie and divert you to a shop or the by saying your destination is closed. Be firm and raise your voice if necessary. We had arguments with one guy who demanded 300 dirham for showing us around the tanneris that we did not ask for. It anyone says, even kids they will show you the way they will want paying at least 100 Durham. Always refuse and give then 10.If you have a choice Fez is a far better experience.Remember your opening words to everyone who offers help or advise is "how much"

Great Place To Shop For Exotic Marrakech Trinkets!. If you are not used to large crowds and congested areas, this is probably not the place for you.However, if you are looking for a good place to shop and see some exotic trinkets, hand made crafts and people, visit this medina for a few hours and enjoy the medina, as there is lots to buy and see.Tip: If someone comes up to you and says that they will guide you through the medina, be careful, as they are only doing it because they want your money and there is no telling where they will actually lead you.
Medina. Much less intimidating than in Fez. Lots to see. Bargaining was great and the street entertainment was fun
Lots to buy. Great place to see M at its best and worst and but things you think you or your friends might want whether you or they really do

Don't leave go of your husband. I was a bit overwhelmed by the space and what went on in it and how on earth anyone made a living. It was also incredibly hot. Water bottle a must. And don't get lost from the group. Two guides and "a counter" - but none seemed to have a very good understanding of English. (Sorry - their English was much better than my Moroccan!)

very good. This was our first Medina visit and it was a great experience. Eventually you figure out how to navigate it. Signs are posted reasonably in the Medina. But we learned to look at some landmarks to navigate it. However, I still liked the Fez souks as we were not hassled in Fez. If someone grabs your hand to take you somewhere in Marrakech Medina, be prepared to pay money. 10 dirhams for a minute of guiding was too little and they wanted 30 dirhams. We learned and refused in the future. I also liked shopping at Fez without the pressure of hassling. But Fez medina is a lot bigger and a lot more complicate to navigate. Leather goods are also much better in Fez.

A magical experience. Having read trip advisor reviews I was a little nervous about visiting the Medina and our first visit was a bit stressful, however we returned the following day and I have to say that we thoroughly enjoyed it. The hustle and bustle of locals going about their business adds to the experience and the smell from oranges and spices is tangible. There was very little pressure from stall holders; once we said no we were left alone. The only problem is you find that you are repeating yourself, but this is purely because the place is filled to the brim with market stalls.We avoided riding on a Caleche until late in the day and I have to say that was the best part of the Medina trip, it's great value for money (250 DM) and we were taken on an extensive hour long tour of the area around the Medina and Royal Palace. (DON 'T TAKE PICTURES PALACE).All in all a great adventure and a must for anyone visiting the area.

Unlike anything in North America. The Medina is an amazing and is so different from anywhere in the Western world. I loved it but was also glad to leave after a few hours walking throught the maze of poorly marked alleys. We did not get lost but were able to find our way by speaking French with locals when we had questions. We were surprised that the street vendors were not as agressive as we expected. We understand that they make their living by selling so we were not too bothered by their tactics. Prices and quality vary so you need to look and compare before buying. Watch out for friendly men who want to show you "something special" or help you find your way. We had several approach us and declined their offers as one was trying to direct us towards the tanneries and another claimed he worked at our Riad and wanted to take us to a "very special" carpet auction. We were never afraid anywhere in Marrakech but did were careful not to trust those who offered help when they really just wanted our money.We found the Medina in Essaouira much easier to navigate as the streets are more or less set-up on a grid pattern. We liked shopping better in Essaouira and found better deals than in Marrakech. The vendors were more friendly in Essaouira and since it is much smaller than Marrakech it is easier to recall the location of a stall you like. Enjoy your trip to the Medina and just say no "thank you" and walk away if you feel you are being pressured to buy.

Just another market square. From all the hype I had expected it to be bustling, but during the day and early evening it was nothing like the guide books indicated. That being said it was great to sit in one of the rooftop bars and people watch. The souks leading off the square were equally underwhelming with more football shirts than spices, etc. for sale - but nevertheless worth the experience.

Overwhelming but wonderful. Explore Jemaa el Fna - it's lively, intriguing and authentic! Take a horse and carriage tour for about 20 minutes - just enough to see the medina. (The hour long tours take you out of the city walls, and into the more commercial district which we found less interesting.) The Koutoubia mosque is simply stunning, from all angles. The souks are fun, colourful and lively. Barter - always barter! And be prepared to walk away if the price remains too high. Sample the nuts on sale and the moroccan pastries - both delicious! Enjoy this bustling and charming place!

Annoying at best. Interesting place to visit and very nice, if only the locals would leave you in peace for more than 10 seconds without throwing a snake or a monkey on your back so they can charge for a photo. Markets are good though, bargains to be had, but all very tiresome trying to get the bargain price. Place has not changed since I last visited 30 years ago.
unforgetable place. The most caotic but amazing place I`ve been. The sounds, the crowd, the food... it can scare you at first, but will delight you for sure

Mixed Opinions. It is a fascinating place with an incredible atmosphere, just walking around hearing the music and noise of the place is a unique experience. Found it difficult to get to grips with the locals though, nobody offers to help you without asking for a tip, which makes asking for help rather awkward, taking photos gets you stern looks and more requests for money. Overall, it is a must see.

You must see it!. It is not possible to be in Marrakech and not to go to the local medina. Crazy place, a lot of colors, a lot of people, a lot of goods ... a bargain, bargain, bargain. But be careful - it is very easy to lose, especially in the evening. The side streets are narrow and dark.

Good experience but....... Mad place. Loved haggling for my friend who was quite willing to pay near the asking price!! Hated the hassle of it all for myself. Too hot and noisy, scared of being ripped off all the time and constantly watching out for the bad boys. Plus side is to relax high above it all in one of many rooftop cafe/bars watching the sunset whilst sipping fresh mint tea.
a must. You cannot go to marrakech and not stay in the medina. Here you will experience marrakech ins and outs.

Crazy Place and pushy sellers. you can't walk around and explore the place without being hassled by the numerous sellers there who are very pushy. worth a visit for an experience if you have not been to another arabic country before otherwise its pretty much the same

Crazy Place!. Great experience but a couple of days here was enough as it is very full on! Lovely places to eat, drink tea and some bargains to be had too! Be sure to eat here at night You will probably get lost within 5 mins but that is all part of the fun!

Callous cruelty and a high grime rate. Don't visit Marrakech unless you are immune to animal cruelty and have a taste for grime. Underfed horses drawing the famous carriages (there are a few which look well kept but they are in the minority - choose your ride with this in mind!), filthy snakes charmlessly curled up on the plaza floor (you can tell the conditions they are kept in by the smell), and a continuous sideshow of beaten beasts of burden standing in the merciless African sun without shelter or water. We were all disgusted by the display of contempt for non-humans and were reminded that women probably didn't fare much better behind closed doors. Grubby men with a couple of brown teeth left over from chewing disgusting things thrust themselves at you from all quarters and actually manage to put you off shopping. What you do buy is subject to an entertaining bargaining system but we would have spent more if we had been allowed to relax. Still, bearing in mind that any of your spending fuels an economy which turns a blind eye to blatant cruelty, if you have a conscience you're probably better off going somewhere completely different.

The place to stay. If you're a first timer in Marrakech, then you have to stay in the Medina, this is the real hustle and bustle of Marrakech, but beware of getting run over by a motorbike when exploring the narrow streets.

Pales in comparison to the Medina in Fez. You cannot help but wonder at the tackiness of the "goings-on" in the Jemaa El-Fna square - hawkers, gawkers, and tawdry snake charmers. I recommend you avoid and go straight to the souks which are more interesting. Unlike Fez where all you have to watch out for are donkeys and horses delivering supplies, here you have to dodge trucks and motorcyclists who zoom by at your expense. The tanneries are all but dead and aside from the Ben Youssef Medersa, there is not much to see.

A unique place. A very nice place, more open than the Fes medina but with the same ups and downs. Almost every citizen will offer themselves to guide you and use a lot of excuses to convince you. If you really need one, it's ok to pay them or if you want to be sure you don't miss anything in the medina. But other than that, avoid them. Also, negociate everything from guides, souvenirs (the cheapest we found of Marrakech, Fes and Rabat), taxis (I managed to get a taxi from the train station to the main market from 60 to 20 dirhams). Don't change money under a rate of 10.9 dirhams for 1 euro. Search the bus network because they are better. From the train station to the Jemaa El Fna take number 8 for 4 dirhams a ticket. Eat at the Toubkal in the main market (great food, a lot and for a good price). If you want desert tours, buy them from the city, not online because we met a girl who lost 25 euros this way, we lost 11. Avoid the guys with the snakes or monkeys because you loose money there. The new city is very well built, in tone with the architecture of the old city. Have fun!

Old City. Old walled city. Nice place to visit with lots of shops and plenty of bargains to be had. Expect to be hassled to buy things but a smile and a sweet no thank will stop the hassle, until you come to the next shop. Enjoy the walk in the labyrinths and just take in the atmosphere. Don't worry if you feel like you are getting lost. Just ask and you will be pointed towards the exit.

Opportunity for lovely souveniers. Hundreds of tiny shops - all vying for your attention (and purchases). Expect requests to buy, buy, buy but a smile and a polite no thank you is all you need offer if you are just looking. But... there are lots of wonderful things to buy at very reasonable prices (negotiate a price at approximately half what the stall holder starts at).

Great old city but too commercialized. Without the commercialized part, this place is wonderful. The oldness is still well preserved. Too much hassles from people try to sell you things, it's kinda bugging. Ok, don't think about the tourism-side effects - there are numerous beautiful places to visit here. Stay in riad, don't stay in hotels when you come here to experience the beauty of this place, and try looking for something where not many tourists are around. There are chances to mingle with the locals' life even within the proximity. But if you like to be tourists, it's your call, then it's easy to be one, even Moroccan will accommodate it very well. For me, it's just unfortunate that people are accommodating tourism the way they are now: asking for money for every little thing they do (even they don't do anything at all)... chasing and forcing tourists to visit their stores... little peace for me left, so I would try going through main roads where tourism-side effects do not exist as much :)For fist timers, it's fine to go with the flocks.

Chaos & Beauty. an incredible place to get lost and find back yourself. important not to get scared or overwhelmed by what is surrounding you. If you find someone that offers you to bring you to place he will bring you along in a tour of shops, workshops, kitchens in undisclosed alley, it's all fine and also pretty fun just be aware that you will have to give him a tip!

AMAZING PLACE. The Medina is an amazing place to spend time, explore, discover and experience authentic Marrakech. the Medina hosts a huge laberinth of walkways all looking identical. getting lost is all part of the joy. The main square is vibrant and a great place to explore and hand out. beware though! if you stand to watch any of the performers be expected to part with some cash. for a good holiday picture get a snake wrapped around your neck or a monkey on your head for a few D's. There were lots of horse and carriages which we decided not to ride. the hourses look exhausted and a couple of times we witnessed them loose their footing on the cobbled ground. it was very unearving.There are some resturants in the square, boastinmg exquisit views of the medina, however, you pay for the view alone in our experience the food was poor. and when we left and saw the state of the bathrom and dumb waiter we were pleased we'd left our meal. within the laberinth you will find small traditional eating houses, some with low seating, where the owners encourage you to chill out, rest and enjoy the food. others at street level are more vibrant, enjoy a tagine and watch the world go back!!in the main brilliant. I enjoyed being in the Medina and much preferred it to the more modern areas of Marrakech.

Insanity both good and bad. There were parts of the medina that I really enjoyed. Seeing what was for sale and having some great freshly squeezed orange juice. Most of the booths are selling similar items and many of the handicrafts are now made in another part of the world. At night the crowds grow and the safety level goes down. I saw some things going on there that disturbed me. It's a place you have to visit in Marrakech but be aware of what you are seeing and who is near you
Loved the Medina. Always wanted to visit Marrakech and visit the Medina. Did not disappoint. Very atmospheric, authentic, no tourist trinkets. Locals going about their everyday business.

Enjoy getting lost in the souks. The medina is a maze of tiny streets with no names - eventually you'll find you've entered the souks. Just keep walking and don't worry about getting lost - you'll find wonders along the way, and there's always someone to show you the way to your riad.

It was an experience.... Exciting for the first 5 minutes, but the constant hassle from the touts was too much for me. It seemed that everyone was out to (forcefully) get your money. It was entertaining watching motorcycles making their may down narrow crowded streets of the Medina, carrying an assortment of oversized objects. Its just a completely different world. I actually loved my Holiday in Morocco; outside of Marrakech, the Atlas mountains and Sahara desert was wonderful. However, Marrakech made me realise how much I value my personal space. Glad I experienced it, but will not be rushing back any time soon. Best place to witness it is from the safety of a balcony of an over looking restaurant drinking mint tea!

great experience. The true spirit of Marrakesh is the medina with her squares and souks and not the new town with fancy hotels and pricey restaurants. A great place, but sometimes can be tricky.. all the locals want to make you buy something..anything.. it will not be relaxing but medina will definitely seduce you.

An oasis of clam. Just beautiful...go there and escape the madness of the souk!It is quiet and surrounded by lots of gorgeous plants and trees, just what you need after a sweaty morning of bartering :)

Amazing selection of goods but less enchanting than Fes. Very easy to navigate the medina in Marrakech. Found the variety of products and goods to be intriguing and have a slightly different style than in other cities further North. Loved the abundance of Berber and regional goods from the Atlas mountains. Left with a few bags of souvenirs and felt very satisfied. My heart still remains in the spiritual medina in Fes though.

Beware of snake charmers. The Medina is the beating heart of the city. Close to the markets, the big square is filled with people who will help you part with your money. Snake charmers, monkeys on chains, horse drawn carriages, fruit juice sellers. My advice? Watch it all from the terrace of one of the many the rooftop cafes with a cup of mint tea in your hand. They don't serve alcohol here.

Crazy, chaotic and captivating. Don't think for a second that this will be a relaxing experience. You cannot browse, you cannot look at anything without being asked to enter the shop or without them thrusting products under your nose and into your hands. However, it is fun! And it's a completely different world to the western civilised ways we are so used to. I beg you, do not buy an item from here at the first price you're given - in fact 1/3 of the price they offer if where you should pitch it. If that seller won't come down - walk away - three stalls down you'll see the same thing. Be wary of cheap leathers and really inspect the bags, poofs etc before committing. If I'm honest; I'd go here for the fun of it and not to purchase as it's london prices! Also - don't tell them where you're from! If you say England - you'll get the England price tag ;-). Otherwise, enjoy!
Typical Morocco plaza and souke. Entertainment, dining and fascination both day and night with a more gentle touch than many other similar places
Very busy. A very busy area and if you don't want to be hassled too much, don't let them see you pointing and taking photo's or they will demand payment.

Another world for sure.. The medina is much easier to negotiate by yourself than the one on Fes and a greater variation in quality. Really fun. And the snake charmers in the square are awesome. Almost too neat and clean compared to other medinas.

Labyrinth Medina. Wow! It's quite an experience to walk trough the Medina without getting lost! Cause you will get lost! It's like being in a labyrinth therefore be calm patient and start early in the morning hours because it gets very hot! The Medina has many doors I will recommend writing down a point of reference the door that it's nearest to you and start from there. You will be approached by many locals giving you advise where to go? What do I recommend to make your life more easier and less stressful! Get a young kid as a guide pay him a few euros it really worth it! And it's saves you time and peace of mind. I do not recommend taking any of the the horse rides as I saw that many of the horses are not treated well, and are hurt some of them the legs were bleeding. The same goes for taking pictures with the poor monkeys in the heat it's an attraction that I just don't share. I can imagine this poor animals under the heat of 45 degrees with the asphalt melting under their legs. I wonder wether they get any rest.

Bussy bussy. Very busy and slightly intimidating but once you had your bearings then you're away. Lots of the same things on different stalls and lots of buy ine buy mine but ou just have to keep going and say no

Mayhem and Marvelous Madness. The Medina is amazing. Everywhere you look your eyes will find a million detailed things to take in. So much life going on around you…. arts and crafts, smells of delicious Moroccan spices and cooked tajines, incredible architecture - horseshoe archways and colourful mosaic tiles, leather slippers, brass lanterns creating colourful light patterns that bounce off of mysterious crevices… simply amazing… simply Marrakech!

Loved the hustle and bustle!. Awesome vibrant colors, sights and sounds. Lots of wonderful finds and discoveries if you take a quite moment and absorb all that is going on around you. We travelled with our 3 young girls and even they were taken by the Medina and all the donkeys and motorbikes weaving amongst the pedestrians. We didn't enjoy seeing the monkeys on chains with dirty diapers or the aggressive henna tattoo ladies - not sure who/ what was worse! All in all a fabulous day out though.

Facinating. A maze of tiny streets, but not too hard to find your way in and out of. Just ignore the painted signs, not all of which are telling the truth!And beware of motorcycles and mule carts - it's not dangerous really, but can be a bit surprising!
medieval. you get lost all the time, but it seems you have gone 100 years back in time, souks are sometimes rather touristic and outrageous prices, but fun the walk around

In general, a tourist trap. We have seen other medinas and once you have seen Meknes and Fes, you realize that medina of Marrakech is in general for the tourists. You can still find authentic products and quality workmanship but you need to have an expert eye to avoid being fooled into something of high price with low quality. Best advice, as all already know, go to the places where there are a lot of Moroccans. Better advice does not exist. Also compared to other medinas, it is rather a mess in the streets.

Shoppers and foodie paradise. Be brave go and explore, there are some amazing things to see. If your into cooking it is a spice paradise. Go and explore loads of places to see or sit and have a coffee/mint tea and watch the world go by.

Watch out. I have never travelled anywhere where I felt on edge so much. The crowded area, noise and unknown do not usually bother me however I did not relax in Marrakech at all. Walking around the medina one night I found a child going through my back pack whilst walking (not that there was anything romotely valuable in there) to which I had to fight off. The next day whilst walking around the streets a man started to follow and talk to us. We were making our own way around and he insisted that he had been our guide, demanded money and got very confrontational. Be warned and on your guard is my advice.

The Medina. The culture seems as if it's unchanged over centuries, which I respect so much. I wandered among Marrakech residents in western clothes, burkhas, and everything in between. The silver and leather and foods and teas and color were indescribable.

Get Lost and have fun. Firstly, you will get lost but enjoy it, you can't stay lost for long whether you use a map (Readily available from your Riad or hotel) or just wander around until you find the way out. Have a laugh with the traders and treat it as a game and you can't go wrong. A lot easier to haggle prices than either Tunisia or Egypt.

Fantastic. A brilliant experience! It is busy and noisy and exotic and great fun! We had no hassle, just good humoured banter. Polite 'no thank you' was accepted with good grace. The day time is so different to the night time. The night time was even busier and had an amazing atmosphere. Eat at the street cafés, super food great fun.

Wonderful and unique.. A truly unique experience. It is very safe with police and undercover police roaming around so do not be afraid. Walk around and visit the old palaces, visit the souks and the main place. Do keep your bag closed and close to you at all times though.

Culture shock. The Medina might be only 31/2 hours away from the UK but it's a world away from it in reality. The traffic is surreal, taxis, donkey carts, people carriers, mopeds, bikes, coaches, pick up trucks, pedestrians all crammed into streets barely wide enough for any of them. Then there's the shops/businesses, based in what we would think of as cupboards, all the goods hanging out, be it carpets or meat, and odd bodies just sitting chatting. You will be hassled, but if you're polite and good humoured saying no thank you, they will accept that. And there are some great places to stop for a refreshing mint tea or a meal. Cafe Bahia is astonishing and Cafe Badia roof terrace offers a smashing view of the storks nesting. Relax and enjoy!

Busy busy. The Medina is a warren of little streets and alleys. We found it difficult to orientate ourselves but that's part of the fun, right! Not too much hassling of three women as we were. Firm no was enough to stop most of the attention.

Antique store El Eemrani in Medina. Our wonderful trip to Morocco was marred by a very bad experience with this antique shop. We purchased a wooden window frame, called "petite fenetre" for about $800. Two months later, after returning home, when nothing arrived, we asked our bank to reimburse us the money. Shortly after, a badly wrapped package arrived. It contained a poorly made copy of our "antique" window, covered with some nasty smelling shoe-polish. We returned the package to the store. The owner did not bother to pick it up from the post office till the time to claim our money from the bank (two billing periods) has legally expired. The owner ignored our emails and a letter. At the end - no money, no merchandise for us. Stay away from the store and its owner - Mahamed El Eemrani. Looks like he knew what he was doing and pulled this trick more than once.

great place as a first experience in Morocco. We've visited a couple of cities in Morocco, but being in the Medina of Marrakech as our first stop was a great idea to have a sense of what this country is and a good first contact with the culture. Once in Morocco, try to also visit other Medinas such as Fes, Meknes and Chefchaouen. This last one was more than amazing!
Madness in medina. Crazy markets , defo easy to get lost but so much fun to haggle over some little bowls or slippers , tip ! Do not wear white

Get lost a whole day and enjoy the experience!!!. Incredible medina fulll of life and activity...Wonderful sights, smells and sounds await you.If you arent an regular traveler I would suggest to take an official guide which will help you not to get lost, as you will get lost for sure if you go alone, and will make sure u will be less harassed by people in the Medina.Nevertheless an incredible experience

Medina Adventures. The Medina is worth visiting and be prepared to barter - some of the traders were excellent and did not apply too much purchasing pressure but others followed everywhere but overall a good experience

Bustle. Wonderful sights and smells and sounds abound. Those of a more timid disposition might be better getting an official guide, for the rest explore and enjoy. You won't be bored but you may well get lost!

Historic and fun place. Great little windy streets and tall walls to get lost but always opens up to an Oasis somewhere. Finding a hidden shop or bar and even the Riads are will hidden. Would definitely return.

The Medina is like 1001 Nights. The mystical medina in Marrakesh centre is a must see. one can stroll through without beeing harrassed. So many things to see- smell- taste. Careful once taking photos since the people do not realy like to be photographed. Please ask before.

Cleaner than most other Souks. Cleaner but no real atmosphere, unlike Egypt. This souk plays on the tourists, and also the prices are high especially as they do not have any cents in their money and everything is rounded up. Quite a rip off in all. You have to see it if you are there but once seen thast it.

Busy and fascinating.. Worth the hassle, it's everything you expect, so gear yourself up for the noise and the bustle. Find a restaurant with a balcony and park yourself on it for an hour or two of people watching.
An experience to be remembered.
This is what Marrakech is all about. The old city is what it is all about. We loved wandering and getting lost in the Medina. It helps to have GPS on you phone to find your way home.

Must go. This is one of the best experiences in the world. Its like going back in time, and nothing like we have here....The REAL Labyrinth of passages and mazes in the city... Scary, and exciting at the same time... people ask you what you are looking for and then walk at a million miles an hour and take you down this way and that.... before you know if you don't know where you are.... But all is safe... Loved every bit

A must for a true Moroccan experience.. Shop or just watch in wonder how the Moroccans live. Lots to watch in the square, acrobats, snake charmers, water carriers, plenty of places to rest & get refreshments, & what seems like hundreds of souks to shop in!

Crazy but interesting. Our Riad was in the Medina , we loved staying here. Don't stay here if you don't like crowds or vendors, but then you miss the pleasure of the banter , the wonderful exotic smells and sounds. The medina is old and interesting. At very turn or corner there is something to see.

moped city. Interesting to experience but dodging the stinky mopeds and bikes made getting around a hassle compared to Fes. Found there were a lot of sharks around - even the bank that tried to short change us. Plenty of good stuff in the souks but Fes and Essaouaira so much nicer to meander around.

A World Class Shopper's Paradise. It's easy to lose yourself and blow your entire budget at any of the shops inside the Medina's Souks. The craftsmanship and artistry of anything you buy here is unparalleled. Most items are hand-made and you would pay a fortune for the equivalent back home. However, buyer beware...check the prices, your receipts, take photos of purchased items and receipts if you are having anything shipped back. Also, stay well within the areas frequented by tourists. It can be easy to get lost here since streets have no names and one alleyway likes like the other. Be wary of anyone that insists on "guiding" you back to your destination as you can fall prey to unscrupulous thugs that will attempt to extort more money from you than they deserve.

What beautiful madness.. It is everything you've read. It is chaotic. It is an overload of your senses. Bring your haggling skills, and when your pricing, expect to pay anywhere from 1/4 to 1/2 of what they originally give you as a price. I bought more leather good than I planned, and I'm so happy I did! Plan on buying a carry-on leather bag to carry back home all your new goodies.Regarding dress and walking around. I would never have walked around at night if I didn't have my boyfriend with me, even though I was very covered. The simple fact that I was a blonde westerner had me stand out. I would have hated missing the Medina at night, it truly comes alive and is such a different feel than during the day. Note, even with a guy and fully covered (I work ankle length dresses and long sleeved sweaters), you're butt will be grabbed. Note, I saw girls wearing all sorts of short outfits and bearing their arms during the day. Walking with my boyfriend during the day with my long dresses on, we still got comments, but I felt perfectly safe. And, it was a nice boost to the ego. ;-)I'm so happy that I experienced this. It is truly unique and something everyone should do at least once.
Great place to stay. Our Riad was in the medina --- great atmosphere -- excellent way to get a good feel for Marrakech, and the people there.
Interesting mad and wonderful. Everything i likedLots of nice pattisurees , coffee shops, souks great, historic jewish quater and u can get lost in the madness and exotic quater

Chaos reigns!. The streets of the Medina are crowded with everything from hand carts and pushbikes, through mopeds, scooters, donkey carts, horse carriages, tuk-tuks, small and large taxis, private cars, to buses and lorries. The sound of horns never ceases! In the alleyways the mopeds and scooters dash past you as you savour the pungent aromas of spices, cooked meats and fish, and survey the myriad vendors of everything you can imagine!The souqs are full of urgent merchants and tantalising goods to barter over, and the Place Djemaa el-Fna is a riot of snake charmers, monkeys on chains and in nappies, drumming groups, and henna 'tatooists'. However the public footways are not well-maintained, and in many places the relative poverty is only too obvious. Worth a couple of days, but find the Complexes Artisanal for gifts and souvenirs!

Why are you expecting?. It's a nut house full of crazy colourful characters. I say it is best enjoyed by joining in. Don't be rude. Don't be stand-offish. It a stage and you are an actor up there with all the other actors. Oh and drink lots of water. It's like Africa hot there.
Fabulous. Take a tour if you can! It can be confusing and busy. If you get lost ask a tour guide with a big group...

Worth visiting more than once if you can. Lots of sights and sounds and relatively clean. If you're not prepared to haggle over prices, this is probably not the place for you to shop, but even if you're just looking, it's worth wandering around and getting lost in the narrow streets and alleys.

too many people. This garden is one of the top tourist attractions. It is interesting & houses many unusual plants but is so crowded that you can't really appreciate what it has to offer. Being a private garden, you pay a high price to go in (50 dirhams) & spend much of your time avoiding other visitors. I wouldn't bother again.
like being part of Indiana Jones film set. crowds, snake charmers, great Tagines to eat, Moroccan night markets, side streets, and ramparts of Marrakech

Marrakech Medina is Amazing. It has so many things to look at from the not so good shops to the craft shops with the workers making their goods, the food, accommodation, the Jemma El Fna square. It has everything and if you have enough time you can find the best you'll be in heaven. The worst things are working out how to deal with shop owners when you don't want to buy anything and the motorbikes that nearly knock you over as they speed through the narrow laneways.

A great experience. Spent 5 days in the Medina staying at the excellent Riad Badi. On the first day it was a little hectic dodging mopeds and bicycles but got used to that quite quickly. We would spend our days wandering the souks making the odd purchase here and there (after bartering which at times was hilarious) and ate in different places every day and night. The vibe was good the people on the whole were friendly and not too overbearing or pushy - just had to be able to say no quite firmly which was respected and we always felt safe. Oh and the weather was amazing mid 30's the whole time. Would do it it again but only for a couple of days and would definitely like to explore more of Morocco.

Try and discover the behind the scenes. We had a terrific French speaking guide who gave us an alternative view of the Medina. He showed us the behind the scenes - how the Medina is organized around the Mosque, school, Hammam, artisans etc. We saw the artisans making the products, the baker making the bread for the entire community of each quartier, the worker throwing wood chips on the fire to heat the Hammams. It helped understand how the Medina is structured and how the community works and lives. Very interesting.
Mad as ever !. good fun and great bartering with the locals. Don't bother with the food at the night market as it's overpriced and very average.

Rabat medina is much better.. We visited Marrakech on the first day our trip to Morocco.We did like wandering through medina taking in the noise! sights etc . We did a bit if shopping. After a few days we visited Rabat medina and that was a pleasant surprise. No more shop keepers who would chase your for a sale and most prices were fixed and tagged. Basically hassle free shopping experience. I found the quality of goods also much better and real value for money. We had some sweets which were being freshly made and we knew they were safe as they were coming out steaming hot.

This Souck is a real Beauty!. The Medina of Marrakesh is crazy, You walk around, You get lost but You always find your way and if you really get lost then someone will be very happy to show you the way.La Place, Le Muse de Marrakech and all the shops make the visit worth to be extremely tired at the end of the day.

old city. it has a lot of hustle and bustle and scruffiness but actually there isn't a lot there. souks which are a lot of very small retail premises in shacks selling a lot of rubbish plus a few selling items/services to the locals and a few buildings of minor interest ,great to soak up atmosphere, the sellers are not actually pushy and are polite. if you state you are not interested they desist. I would recommend only a full day with arrival /departure day before/after
Small and manageable Medina. Well worth the visit. Not that different from the other medinas in Morocco, but a manageable size and full of colours and smells that live in your memory for ever.
Plenty of senses. This Medina offer everything in term of colours, sounds, smells. It seems that the time did not change for decades. It is a huge difference from Europe but only few hours away.

5 for atmosphere, 3 for food. A great experience that has to be seen but it is now quite touristy and if you decide to eat enjoy it as for what it is. It appears to have changed from where you could visit each "kitchen" which seemed to specialise in particular foods to what is now very regimented stalls with rows of seats all offering the same things. Be very careful as you can easily over order and of course in true Marrakech salesmanship you will suddenly have platefuls of salads/vegetables being brought out and when you come to pay what should have been a cheap dinner takes on a bill worthy of a reasonable restaurant!

Chaos and Madness. And you are a walking cash-cow here.. Marrakech's "tourist-fresh-meat-cash-cow" mentality was off the charts compared to the other touristy shopping bazaars around the world (e.g. chatuchak, night markets, etc). From restaurants literally grabbing you for patronage to performers demanding tips because you took a photo in their general direction to shop owners blocking the exits... it was a pretty insane and definitely an experience. To save future visitors time/bargain-fatigue, i got a cliche tourist morocco t-shirt for 40DH (started at 120DH), using the walking off method. While i'm not sure if this is the cheapest price, i guess it would be a good reference. I love picking up knick-knacks (magnets, pouches, doodads) and found the best prices (ie the store owners listed the price at a fair amount) and the best place it seemed for that was near where the Jemaa el Fna square turns into the markets. As a male, i saw it on the whole as a different cultural experience, but my three female travel companions were rather put off by it all. It is a interesting and fascinating place in its own right with some good bargains to be found (after A LOT of haggling), and no regrets having visited there. Wandering during the day was hotter, but less hectic as compared to the evening where human traffic balloons up.

The reason to go. The medina has a lot of history and culture. I say go with a guide. They can help you find items you want to purchase, but also ensure you get the most out of the visit with must see locations and history/cultural information during you visit.
Very busy. Lovely atmosphere very central location. Lots to see and a variety of foods to taste. Easy to get to and friendly people. Though it can get a little overbearing.

Hated every minute of it! . Im literally on the way home having just landed at London Stansted and felt compelled to write a review as soon as possible. I consider myself to be an open minded well travelled person and like most like to explore real places and real cultures rather than hide behind compounds and resorts who see nothing more than a sun lounger and an all inclusive buffet! In this instance however I wished I spent my money on ignorance and that is being polite! Marrakesh medina is a maze of smelly streets, , chaotic mopeds and poor unwell looking horses, donkeys and cats. The men in particular are aggressive, intimidating and show utter dismay to why you are in their country but not spending your money on tac which is made another alley way not far from the souks! There is genuinely not much to see in Marrakesh and its unwelcoming demand for money when we initial got lost in the souks made me feel vulnerable and threatened! It is hard to identify in a place when they lack such social structure!! We will not be returning to Marrakech and advise others to think carefully about what kind of experience they wish to seek before booking a trip to Marrakech!
Bonkers. There is no way I could sum this place up to give it the description it deserves. Loud, exciting, hot, dusty, busy, lively crazy...........

More Souk than Medina. The Medina of Marrakech is more like an extended souk, not nearly as hectic as say the Medinas of Tangier or Fes. The Medina is worth a visit, come prepared to haggle and bon chance!

A festival of smells, colors, prices and smiles...... Absolutely loved Marrakech....Somehow chaotic yet fascinating....Lots of people, locals and tourist alike. The many karts selling orange juices, the food stalls, the vendors all combined in one big explosion of smells, colors, prices and smiles. Local people are very friendly and understand the tourist very well, they know when to leave you alone when you say nicely the final NO. Bargaining is not my thing but I managed to buy a couple of things half the original price, so it was worth it. Our tourist guide told us to always offer less than half the price so you can go up until they finally agree for half the original price, thanks Mustapha for that tip.
