Make sure you dine in one of the many terraces overlooking the Medina, seeing the sunset while having a nice meal right in the middle of the commotion is priceless...Our kids had a great time, there were something for everyone to enjoy, the snakes for our 6 years old son, the ladies doing the henna for our daughters (11 & 15), the many games, the small stores, everything was fascinating to us. What's not to love about it....Don't be afraid, go, experience it and you'll love it....

You have to know how to bargain with the vendors. When they see you are American they see dollar signs.. Great prices but you must negotiate. The leather is of good quality, watch out for the camel leather. Poor quality, the dye will eventually rub off. Be careful of the quality of the rugs. Color will run. Spices are fresh and cheap. I got saffron, which was a couple of dollars, nut meg 8 balls for fifty cents. Cheap prices on tumeric, paprika, nutmeg. I love the medina just be car full with your bag ladies. Hold it close under your arm and make sure you change your money at a bank. It is durhams. What I do is change it here in Houston at an international bank. Morocco is beautiful, so are the beaches and the food is extraordinary. Have a safe trip and don't forget to register with the American embassy.

Still a culture shock.. You cannot dodge the core of the old city. Even if deliberately or inadvertently you find your hotel is outside the old city on one of the Western European bland hotel enclaves you have to walk into the square and from there into the souk and the shopping area. I read a bit about the general layout and the groupings of specialities but it still did not prepare me for the tight narrow bustling enormity of it. Yes we got hassled but the frustrating persistence aside you can resist the worst excesses and enjoy or entertain yourselves with the light banter. Just be on your guard for pickpockets and other cash or property thefts.

Yes it is crazy; yes you should go. Things really don't get crazy busy until later in the evening. Of course most of the food vendors and others don't roll out into the square until the cool of the evening either. Definitely wander the souk stalls a little just for the experience. If you choose to buy something realize that haggling is just part of the whole experience; never pay face value for anything. Also take the chance to enjoy tea or coffee on one of the patios surrounding the main square.

Interesting. We stayed at a Riad just about 2 minutes from one of the rear entrances to the Souk. The Souk and the Square are great places to visit. I don't see a need to be apprehensive about people misquiding or cheating if one is a bit careful. The local people are quite friendly and we enjoyed getting lost in the Souk which is really huge and shopping paradise (if your luggage limit permits). A good idea is to go in the morning to the Souk as there is less crowd and we are fresh enough to put our bargaining skills to use.. Ask more than 2 people for directions to know which is correct. Eating at the food stalls in the Square is a unique experience, make sure to check the price with the waiter when ordering the food.
Amazing. Found the medina amazing, so many different streets that you could easily get lost, visited it both day and night, the atmosphere at night was fantastic
Wander around. Wander around the souks and get lost. You will enjoy the smells and the activities. The 'game' of buying stuff is great.
Different place to see it. It is really a different place to see it. To much messed and confused, but interesting, different and amazing. Go!
Old town is lovely. Make sure you do not stray too far off the beaten track as the roads can get confusing but the old town is a lovely place to visit so make sure you visit

Bring your GPS. The Medina is a must, of course, when in Marrakesh. The small streets are so complicated that really you need to be careful. We started out to go somewhere outside the Medina and never made it. We kept going round and round, super interesting, but had to ask for help to get back to the Plaza so we could find our way to our riad. Everyone wants to sell you something and will literally haul you by your arm to get you inside. If they ask for Rh 200 you need to offer 100 and then start bargaining down from there. Dont let that deter you, though, you can get some nice souvenirs in the Medina.

Madness in the medina. Its a bit of a shock at first, narrow streets that are very busy with bikes ,cats donkeys and lots of poverty. But once you start shopping it becomes fun.The square comes alive at dusk with street food and snake charmers.We didnt eat but there are several bars with good views.Walk on the right and the bikes will avoid you but watch out when coming round a corner !
Never experienced this much excitement!. This was a fantastic experience in to be missed! A mass of people and activity, not a dull moment!............

Horrible air pollution. Last January, we stayed in Marrakech for two days. We'd found a lovely riad in the medina (the inner city). For me, it was against my better judgment: last time I was there (two years ago) I found we were not really able to walk around, since the air was polluted by all the traffic going on in those tiny streets. This time, it was much, much worse. I felt I was not able to breathe at all, and had to put a scarf to my mouth to feel a little protected. There is so much traffic inside the medina: so many cars and motorcycles, and they're not really the latest model so they're all leaving behind clouds of thick, black smog. Some streets in the medina have roofs over them, you can imagine it gets even worse in those places. Even outside the medina, the air is dirty and bad for you. For me, the magic is definitely over.

Worth the chaos. If visiting Marrakech, the Medina is a must. Enjoy the chaos, get lost in the souks, don't worry about a map - it probably won't help much - and just enjoy the experience. Learn quickly to ignore the barrage of requests to buy (something and everything) and NEVER accept a young man's (or boy) offer to lead you to your destination. Be sure to visit Jemaa El Fnna at night - or when the sun is setting - to witness the change in atmosphere. Be out of the souks before closing or face the prospects of being completely lost. Don't buy from the vendors in Jemaa El Fnnaa - as our guide told us - the dust on that fruit and nuts has been accumulating since the 11th century!

Arabic World most amazing city. We visited the historic and unesco heritage Medina of Marrakech during our trip in Morocco in April 2014. It is really beautiful. All houses are traditional and painted in red. Jemaa El Fna the central square and the souks around are spectacular. Don't miss Saadin Tombs Bahia Palace and of course Koutoubia mosque. Stroll around jews district and get lost in the narrow streets.Take a small tour at Majorette Gardins. They are small but really unique.Not only Medina (witch means city centre in Arabic) is a must but all Marrakech including the new city is a pleasant city called "The Red City" as all and i mean all houses are painted red.You can feel a sense of an Arabic City with European influences, We have been in several countries in the Arabic World and Marrakech is for sure the cleanest and most amazing. It is a unique city you don't have to miss

Get a good map. Marrakech medina's full of interesting things to see and do, but the tourist map they give out free is almost unusable. (It's very difficult to locate landmarks, and the print's hard to read.) Try to get hold of a plainer, simpler version, and it'll make your stay much less stressful.

Shopping Moroccan Style!. When we visited in April it wasn't too crowded. It leads to the souk which is like a maze and you really do benefit from hiring a guide. They will take you to places where the standard of goods is better although more expensive. Didn't like having to carry so much cash as a lot of vendors don't take cards and often even if they do their card machine doesn't work! There are ATM's but you are limited to how much you can withdraw same as in the UK. They will often take Euros and Sterling too.

Crazy! But fun. We have travelled before but the medina of Marrakech is crazy. Once you step in the square you are overwhelmed with snake charmers trying to get a picture with you, ladies doing henna and men with monkeys. I must say I didn't enjoy looking at the monkeys and didn't give them any money. However we got trapped with the snake charmers and ended up paying a lot of money for them to go away!,so be aware of that. Once your in the medina it's colourful, loud and fun! Leather slippers and sandals, handbags and lanterns galore. Be prepared to barter as a bit of fun but not everything is cheap. If you go to Marrakech you must see the medina.

Amazing. Nothing can prepare you for the medina. We went through the day and on an evening. It's like two different places. It was very daunting for us as a couple and perhaps would have been better going as part of a trip with our hotel/Thomsons. There are lots of merchants, food stalls, sights, sounds, smells, hustle and bustle. Be careful of the "dodgy" people such as the snake charmers/monkeys on chains/acrobats/henna women/pretend tour guides BUT soak it all in as part of the amazing experience and enjoy!

Two Days is More Than Enough. The medina of Marrakech is fun only for the first day or two, afterwards its getting you tired. Its exotics is monotonous and architecture is unenlivened. The constant ado out of nothing coupled with bad air and noise from scooters will give you headache. Numerous people trying to help you find a way somewhere you do not really intend going and expecting a fee in return will soon annoy you. Narrow streets & lack of light will get you claustrophobic eventually. Interesting experience, when in very limited dosage. Enjoy responisbly.

STEP BACK IN TIME. If you look at old postcards you can see this place has not changed much. It was very interesting and the food stalls in the evening are certainly worth a walk by, sheeps heads on offer....

Mind blowing !. The Medina is a labyrinth of tiny narrow passageways full of merchants, poverty, feral animals, rubbish, and dirt. But it is also a lively extravaganza of Moroccans living their daily lives. Mopeds and bicycles crossing your path, dodging merchants throwing water around their stalls, moving quickly out of the way of a donkey cart. Covering your nose as you pass by the butchers. I will admit, for the first 4 hours or so we were overwhelmed but you soon become in tune with the goings on and learn to walk on the right hand side. Being English it was easy to ignore most of the calls from stall holders , as they were in French. A real taste of Marrakesh, not to be missed.

La la, shukran! Try your hand at haggling . That market is s bit of a tourist trap for those who do not know how to barter with the local traders, but I guess they need to make an income some how! But things can work out dear if your conversion rates aren't taken into account. I suggest you go with the intention of immersion in this experience but learn a few phrases , like no no thanks!(La La shukuran!) Or French (its too expensive) C'est trip cher.And wear tinted sunglasses to avoid eye contact with those you do not want to engage, because as soon as you cast your gaze at their wears, they will pounce. They can be very persistent, so don't get angry just continue to walk!!
Must See. Try and get to see as much of this place as you can, go in and out of different entrances, by day and night, every inch is different.

Bi-polar. I really feel badly for those that rated the Medina "poor" or "terrible". It simply means they were not prepared. Yes, the Medina is a labyrinth of tiny narrow passageways full of merchants, poverty, feral animals, trash, and filth. But it is also a lively extravaganza of Moraccans living their daily lives. Mopeds and bicycles crossing your path, dodging merchants throwing water around their stalls, moving quickly out of the way of a donkey cart. Covering your nose as you pass by the butchers. I will admit, for the first 4 hours or so I was COMPLETELY overwhelmed. We had done a lot of prep before this trip to make sure we did not stand out as "dumb Americans" but I will admit, I still felt really out of place. We went back to our hotel to decompress for a while, and the next time we went out into the Medina I was ready. We spent 4 days in Marrakech -- all of which was in the Medina and I still feel like I did not uncover all her secrets. Once you get used to saying no to people, you really do become more comfortable. We unfortunately speak neither French nor Arabic, so communicating and getting around was a little tricky. Overall I have to say I completely LOVED it. The Medina was built to be a maze. You are not supposed to feel comfortable there as an outsider. By day 2 I knew my way around -- but keep in mind that we walked miles and miles learning it. You can totally get by without doing that -- we did it because we wanted to. Accounts of not taking out your map etc. are totally true. If you look like you don't know what you are doing - -a local will "help" you -- just be prepared to pay them. And no matter what you pay, be prepared for them to tell you it is not enough. Learn a couple key phrases in Arabic and French. Especially "no thank you", "how do I get here", "right" and "left". The people there are extremely friendly. As a woman, I was mostly ignored. My husband got FAR more attention than I did. Merchants -- especially in the big square -- would put their arms around him and try to lead him into their booths. No one likes their picture taken here. As a photographer, this was difficult for me. I had to really learn to be sneaky and quick. If you buy something, the merchant will let you take as many pictures as you want. Go prepped for an experience you'll not get anywhere else and you will be happy. Also, be prepared to take a break every few hours. Find a nice "Salon de The", review your map, and begin again. You will seriously love it.
A must see!. An unique experience! Beautiful during the day, lively at night. Very exotic smells, products, people...

I wasn't disappointed. Loved the medina and its derbs. Could walk around the small streets all day and soak up the atmosphere. The frequent call to prayer in the backround was almost peaceful. ON the downside, remember that the toilet facilities might not be what you're used to in some of the smaller restaurants and cafes.

fascinating. Busy, hectic, fascinating. Worth getting a good guide. We had a guide through the tour rep who took us through the medina and the souks and helped us to negotiate prices. Don't take photos of anyone without asking permission first and be prepared to pay a few dirhams formthe privilege.

Great fun. Full of interest with lots to see. Smaller that Fez and cleaner and without hassle. The square is great fun day and night with a very good atmosphere. Plenty of cafes for people watching.We did not find traders in the souks to be a nuisance. If you are polite and just say 'no thank you' (better in French) they do not pester. They are polite people and deserve the same.

Where is Indiana Jones?. This is a place to visit more than once. The first time you go, don't bring either your camera or your wallet. Just walk and gape.Let your imagination take you in a time warp. It is truly a place that will overload your senses with an overarching cacophony of stuff you will never have experienced before.

Beware of the scooters. The Medina in Marrakach is well worth a visit. The "shops" are varied and interesting and best of all, you hardly get hassled. The people are friendly and generally courteous but much more pleasant than many places we have been to around the world. You will always get people who want to sell you something, just ignore them and they are not too pushy. If you are looking for somewhere, they will sometimes offer you advice and will often say "it is closed" and offer to guide you. Do not go with them.Some "shops" do not like you taking photos of their stall. Perhaps they just want money.The worst bit is the bikes and scooters. Why do the authorities allow scooters to travel down narrow pedestrian walkways. They come up behind you and for some reason think they have priority. We saw one person get wiped out by a scooter that was going too fast.It is a really nice atmosphere in the Medina, very special but completely spoilt by the scooters in what should be a pedestrian only area.

Great experience. Having previously been to Tunisia, a few years ago now, and had pushy sellers literally grabbing you and pulling you into their shops I was not sure about how this would go, my wife was definitely worried! However we had no problems at all and really enjoyed the experience. Don't get me wrong this is definitely not for the faint hearted, you have people calling from their shops and you have to constantly dodge motorcycles and bikes, but that's part of the appeal!Although sellers called to you from their shops, it was not every shop and it was all good natured with "Asda price" being heard regularly. I never felt threatened or at risk from pick pockets, keep your money in a safe pocket and you shouldn't have to worry about that anyway.There are lots of cafes and restaurants to try, and everyone wants to sit on the roof terrace, so look for a place with empty seats before climbing all those stairs! The sight, sounds and smells of the area was quite amazing and I'd recommend a visit to everyone.

Worth the viewing. If you do not go you will never know what you have missed . Great cafes around the edges and stalls all over the place the fruit juice is so refreshing on a warm day plenty of music and noise to be had by all along with the Hawkers .
Hustle & Bustle. What an amazing place to get lost in for a day!Alleyways, souks, squares, people and smells...totally enthralling.

The sounds, smells and sights of the Medina will stay with me forever. This is the second time I have been to Marrakesh (the first was 10 years ago with a female friend). This time I went with my husband. The Medina was vibrant but I have to say there are a few cautious tales to be told. First of all, there are the official Government guides who have badges and wear striped dish-dashes (generally but not exclusively). Then, there seemed to be the alternative guides who were older men, smartly dressed, who led you to believe that they were long term residents of the Medina and just wanted to help you because they loved their city. They will then casually give you directions to a certain place (usually the Berber Centre in the Kasbah) and then they will "disappear". However, just as you are walking past the Berber Centre they will appear again and tell you that the Centre is only open for one day because the Berbers only come down from the mountain villages every so often for a festival in the town and they are heading back tomorrow. WRONG! Approximately 75% of the inhabitants in Marrakesh are in fact Berbers. I'm sure the Berber Centre was interesting but primarily you will be subjected to hard sell and your friendly local Marrakeshi gentlemen will be looking for a healthy commission or a tip. You will also find that you will be told by residents of the Medina and Kasbah that certain attractions are closed today - because they want you to go with them elsewhere for commission or a tip, or that a route or alleyway is shut off and that you will have to take an alternative route - and they will show you the way and that they don't want money until you say goodbye. Then, you will be asked for paper Dirhams or Euros. Small change is not acceptable in any currency and they will make a fuss. In my view 10 Dirhams (about 75 pence) is a very adequate tip and my husband and I would not be bullied. So, make sure you have plenty of small change in the local currency when out and about in the Medina. Whilst I appreciate that many of the residents of Marrakesh are very poor by European standards, their behaviour really can be rather wearing. I have lived and worked in the Middle East in several countries and I go to Egypt regularly on holiday and usually love the Arab bartering mentality and have loads of fun but I found that locals' behavious in Marrakesh could sometimes be quite menacing. The taxi drivers too will not have meters and so you have to agree a price before you get in the vehicle. One taxi driver wanted way too much to take us to the Marjorelle Gardens, wait and return us to our hotel. He tried to tell me that it was 40 kms away (it's actually less than 3 from the Medina). If you don't want to be ripped off, have a map and do your homework first. A clean, more luxurious taxi will charge more, which is fair enough, but many yellow taxis are not really roadworthy and have no working seatbelts but want to charge the same price. A taxi from the Medina to the airport should cost about 150 dirhams maximum, but you will probably be asked for twice that amount.Having had a good moan, the souks are amazing and fascinating. You will probably get lost but you can also buy some bargains. Beware of buying Argan Oil. Try to buy from an official Herbalist. The same applies for saffron. There are ways of telling whether you have the genuine thing or not - tips available if required. The tanneries in the eastern quarter of the Medina are interesting but very smelly. This area is one of the poorest in the Medina and you will be bothered more than in other areas. The Marrakesh Museum, Bahia Palace and Saidian Tombs are all worth a visit but in themselves are not jaw-dropping spectacles. Jab el Fnaa Square itself is different in the daytime to the night time. During the day, you have snake charmers, henna painters, fruit and spice stalls. In the evening, it transforms into a wonderful open air restaurant. The food is freshly cooked but no alcohol is available at these pop-up restaurants. There are also many groups gathered to perform evocative drumming. Only a few restaurants serve alcohol in the Medina as they have to be 80 metres from a mosque before they can get a licence - and there are a number of mosques in the Medina so it could be tricky. The Nouvelle Cite restaurants mostly serve alcohol. Non-muslims are not allowed into the Koutoubia Mosque but the surrounding gardens are lovely. The carriage rides are a good way of seeing the Medina but we didn't go on one this time and so I have no idea what the prices are. The horses are mostly in good condition. Don't try to take photos of snake charmers, water sellers or some quirky stalls unless you are prepared to pay a tip. The first time I visited Marrakesh there was a stall selling false teeth - a must for a picture - but I couldn't find it this time. There are also men with monkeys wearing nappies which they will try to put on your person. Yuk. Beware also if you don't like snakes because the snake charmers will often produce snakes from their pockets and try to hand them to you. If you want to stay in a Riad, make sure of its location. Many in the Medina/Kasbah are not accessible by vehicles and you could easily get lost in the alleyways dragging your baggage with you. My best advice would be to find one near Jab al Fnaa Square. My final suggestion is to get a good guide book - the Lonely Planet or Rough Guides are really helpful and do a bit of homework before your trip to get the maximum benefit from your stay.

Something to experience at least once in your life.. Strolling through crowded souks and haggling for better prices is not my cup of tea, but still being in the medina is a worthy experience. For me it was most interesting at dusk, especially the main square.
Dangerous shopping. Very exotic men also extremely noisy with constantly scooters,motorbikes,bicycles and animaltransport throuh the tiny souks.Very frustating.

Moroccan culture at its best. Medina is lovely, so much to see and buy, so it can get confusing. Offer the stall/ Shop keepers at least 2/3 to 1/2 of the price...really barter with them and they will give u a good price.

Overrated!!!. The Medina is supposed to be the heart and soul of Marrakech, but I didn’t like it. It was as busy as I had expected, but it wasn’t clean. I felt slightly unsafe; I thought my pockets were going to be picked at any point. I thought the stalls (before I visited it) were going to be of a better quality, but they were all very samey and sold lots of oranges. And the street entertainment I thought was going to be more talented, only there were dodgy blokes with monkeys and snake charmers, that didn’t look very charming. My preconceived ideas spoilt it and I am perplexed why travel channels sell it so much! It’s not all that! The souks on the other hand were really nice. I would love to have bought a few things; only I couldn’t take them home in the plane due to the size of items they were selling.

'Hard' walking.... ..because on allmost every meter of our walking somebody wanted to sell us something. Mostly polite merchants but some of them were quite agressive...But despite of all it was very interesting and fascinating... lot of narrow and very narrow streets, like a real labyrinth, lot of people and domestic animals beginning from dogs and cats, finishing with donkeys, monkeys, horses and camels...

Does not live up to the hype. We spent a week in Morocco, based in a riad (Villa Makassar) in the Kasbah area of the Medina. We had visited Tangier before but this was our first visit to Marrakech and I have to say that we were disappointed – it did not live up to expectations. Positives:- Although there is a lot to see, you only need about 3 days before running out of things to visit. However, there are some good trips out of town to the coast or the Atlas Mountains. We hired a car and found the driving easy, except during rush hour in Marrakech, when you could say it is “interesting”. - As long as you enjoy walking, everything within the Medina is within walking distance.- There are some great sights just outside the Medina, notably the Jardin Majorelle – a must see. - It feels safe, although if women do not want to be stared at, they need to dress modestly. - Most people speak good English and French is the second language, which most people appear to understand. - Although it is pretty grotty and by the end of each day there is trash everywhere, the locals clean up at night and the streets look relatively clean every morning. - Some of the Moorish architecture is pretty amazing and although it is not in the same league as that in the Alcazar in Seville or the Alhambra Palace in Granada. However, the entrance fees to historical sited and museums are very cheap (typically 10 – 20 DH). - To their credit, the locals appear to work incredibly long hours to earn very little money. - The locals love it if you make the effort to say “shukran” (thank you). - If you have a decent guide book and are a good map reader, you can get around easily without taking part in a tour. Otherwise, expect to be “herded like sheep” and waste time in places you would rather not bother with. We took time to browse. Negatives:- As in many third world countries, the contrasts between the “have’s” and “have not’s” are very evident. There is extreme poverty in places, with numerous beggars and people living in appalling conditions. Yet behind the facades there are some beautiful buildings and riads or people driving flashy cars. Have some coins in your pocket to give to those who obviously need them but beware of scammers. - The poor animals have an even harder life. There are decrepit looking cats everywhere (which is probably why we did not see any rats) and the locals treat their donkeys, mules and horses appallingly. Most look as though they are starving and they have horrible sores from the harnesses. And the drivers are not averse to using their whips. - We were surprised by how expensive the hotels/riads and (safe) restaurants were – approximately 50% more than in the UK or US. - There seems to be huge over-supply of goods. You will see a dozen stores next to each other all trying to sell the same stuff but very few buyers. How on earth people make a living there is a mystery. - Wherever you go you get hassled by people trying to sell you something. If you show interest in anything in the souk, expect a “hard sell”. If you are just passing through or do not want to buy anything, the advice is to look ahead, avoid eye contact and keep walking. “Non merci” is an essential part of your vocabulary. - You need to negotiate for most things, including taxis. The first line of negotiation is often, “How much do you want to pay?” Do some research on what things cost. If you really do want to buy something, I would suggest taking a trip out of town (e.g., to Essaouira) where everything is a fraction of the price and the prices are usually displayed.- Don’t try to take a picture of the snake charmers or any other short of show. Someone will swoop on you demanding money. - Beware young men who offer to show you the way. They will either be taking you to their uncle’s spice shop or will take you the long way round and expect to be paid. If you pay them, they will then argue that it’s not enough. “Non merci” again!So overall, Marrakech is probably worth a visit but you do not need more than a couple of days there.

A "must do" when visiting Marrakech. The medina is a labyrinth of souks and food stalls. It can be easy to find yourself lost so try to try to remember your way! But if you do get lost some of the locals will point you in the right direction. Beware of those trying to direct you to their shop though!
Wow!. The medina contains warrens of souks and shops and the square which comes to life at dusk, with food stalls and street entertainers aplenty.

the medina itself is niece and lot to see. I went to essouirra about 1 hour and half drive from Marrakech beautiful town on the coast and I recommend also a small village about 1 hour drive from Marrakech called ourika it's a must you can climb high to see waterfalls and you can have your lunch by the river beautiful,

Busy but an experience. It is an amazing experience. Just smile and be polite to the locals and carry on walking! They want to guide you different places such as the tanneries and the square! Be adventurous and try all the different alleyways as you will find markets everywhere.
Night time is best. To see and hear so many people enjoying themselves is a delight. One is there conflict in this world ?

Great place to get a feel for the Moroccan ambiance. The medina in Marrakech is quite big with lots of things to see, visit, and eat. I personally preferred the souks of Marrakech and the Medina of Marrakech to that of Casablanca and Fes.The atmosphere both during the night and the day is impressive and great to take in by drinking a mint tea at one of the many cafes surrounding the main square of Jemaa El Fna. As with any high-tourist attraction I would advise everyone to be wary of their valuables and to make sure their bags/purses are securely closed and preferably in front of you so as to keep an eye on them.
Very busy. I am really keen on this place, I got hit by a moped we where both trying to get out of the way of a taxi, the shops where ok didn't get hassle a polite no thanks did wonders

Great fun. Barter, Barter, Barter! . As frequent visitors to Turkey and Egypt, my partner and I are both well versed in trading and how to deal with the 'pushy' sales ideas often displayed whilst in these areas. We expected more of the same pestering and badgering and this place was almost European in feel in that regard. In Egypt or Turkey, for example, 99% of people will pester and harangue you to buy... Here, maybe 15% do the same, the remainder will try, but a simple "No, but thank you" sees the end of the matter! Bartering is simple.... If you actually want to buy something (and there is PLENTY of things to buy!), ask the price and offer 1/3 of that price. By the time you settle on a price, normally around 50% of the starting price, you should be about right. I even pushed my luck by taking out 100dr and telling a shop keeper I couldn't buy or Barter as I only had 100dr for a 600dr tagine.... Somehow, he agreed to the sale, so, as cheeky as that was, it shows there are massive bargains to be found if you are determined to be a little blunt, but polite, in dealing with traders! The place is a joy to watch. Arrive at about 4pm and just sit, relax, drink coffee (or tea ha, ha) and watch the place come alive. It's one great life experience. Food within the Medina, on the stalls, is fantastic, although, personally, I didn't risk the sea food ;-) Much cheaper than restaurant prices, just as good and, again, a life experience. Women, keep your hands in your pockets, as the women offering henna tattoos will grab a hand and just start doing one whilst you walk, then demand money. They seem to last about 24 hours, then fade. Even if you actually want one, they are a waste of time and they try to charge about 300dr for them. My partner and I ate 3 courses and had drinks for 140dr! All in all, this was the best experience of our holiday....

Like a step back in time. Lots of donkeys and carts, mopeds, people trying to sell you stuff. Snake charmers, people with monkeys etc. Just soak up the atmosphere and give a roof top bar a go to chill out.

Busy. What an experience!!! We went in both during the day and one evening. Don't go on your own as you get pestered, go with a friend or in a group. If you go during the day it's worth paying for a guide but they do take to friends shops who try to get you to buy what their shop is selling so you just have to keep saying no! It was certainly an experience and I'm glad I did it.

an eye opening experience. no chance to just browse you will get harassed and the stall owners will try and bully you into buying their goods Be strong and say no and they will soon let you move onIt was fascinating to see so many different items for sail and to be able to haggle over the price I got a few bargains and was very pleased with everything What a wonderful experience and we didn't get lost On a personal note please do not encourage the men with monkeys by having your picture taken with them - they are not treated well and the more they are encouraged the more get taken from the wild A terrific experience that I would love do again

Lost and found. First day in Marrakech, living in the heart of the Medina, we ventured first thing in the morning into the Souks.The first set of people we came across were genuinely nice and even exchanged Facebook details to keep in touch.As the afternoon approached, we realised we were lost as the intrinsic maze nature of the souks is inescapable, not a sign in sight or a person who knows how to read a map could help you, we were merely surrounded by people who wanted our money and couldn't speak English.Everything eventually became déjàvu as all the stalls sold the same items (except a select few with live animals).Eye contact with anybody resulted in persistent money begging and the excitement of taking photos turned into a threat from the locals.Great experience all in all
great. wow what a place i felt like indiana jones it is like going back 100 years the only thing missing was ali baba and the 40 thieves

Fascinating, but.... In parts it's like walking around a shopping mall with donkey carts, motocyclettes, hand-barrows, bicycles all taking ownership of the space you're in. It can get trying after a time.

bustling. Great bustling market Sadly every Moroccon seems to want a hand out and the mopeds are a bit of a hazard but great place to look round and see what there is to buy but you need to haggle IF you are buying anything
An Ancient World. step back into time and do some shopping..... make sure you pay half of the price they offer..... part of local culture to make a deal

Donkeys, scooters and bicycles!. Watch your toes and be aware of others around you as you wind down the narrow alleys that accommodate all kinds of commuters and modes of transport. It's busy all times of the day and night! Our Riad (Dar Limoun Amara) was smack in the middle of the medina, and I would recommend it to anyone. Great location.
A must see. Went with guide but it didn't stop the traders from hassling to buy every step ot the way. It is essential to visit when in Marrakech, but overall not a great experience.

the area to stay, but some little changes needed. if you travel in marrakech, do stay in the medina, the historical partnot point to travel so far without staying among local peopledo book an hotel such as a riad ( with little or big patio ) instead of a normal hotel in the new part of marrakech call Guelizok the medina is quite dirty in some part, but it parts of the charm - a new plan to refurbish the medina medina is not that unsafe as other part of marrakech, or some big towns in the world, you just need to be aware of where you are and where you gomedina includes the main spots to visit in marrakech such as monuments and museums, do not miss daytime and nightime the famous jema efna square and the soukshugh

Stay in the Medina and see how the locals live. The Medina of Marrakech is the walled city and generally vehicular free. You get a real sense of life as the locals live it, get a guide the first day to show you around take you to where they bake bread or cook the local's Tangias, the souks - but don't buy anything the first day!

Old vs new. If what you want is cramped alleys with people hassling you to buy cheap tat you don't want, then the medina is for you! The medina is the old city, within the walls. It's tourist central, but it's somewhere you have to go or why bother going to Marrakech at all?

SOUKS. The Souks is very crowded, very smelly.Dirty and generally a unpleasant experience and there was nothing that one could give favourable comment!!!! Terrible!!The market goes into a labyrinth, which is very narrow.Its very easy to get lost. It certainly is a experience.. but I didn´t liked!
Very exotic. This was really exotic for someone who lives in the west most of their lives. Not a Marks & Spencer in sight, which was really good.

A typical medina. If you have not gone to any cities in Morocco...this would be the one to go to---
Since, it is hectic, a combination of both clean and dirty, modern and ancient, modestly dressed women and modern dressed, with an overall feeling of rush rush,,,with a big overlay of dustiness...

A Must When In Marrakech. I was weary at first to enter the heart of the Medina and was sure I'd get lost, which I did, but once I had got used to being "pestered" by stall holders looking for business I began to enjoy the experience and wished I'd had more time to wander around and soak up the atmosphere. I'd recommend 2 or 3 hours of losing yourself in the Medina and not worrying about finding your way out again, you will in the end, even if you have to buy a souvenir or two and get a local to point you in the right direction.

Busy, busy place. Brilliant, the hustle and bustle of the narrow streets is like being in an Indiana jones movie. And the goods and wares from the sellers in the souks are bright and vibrant. Your eyes are everywhere taking it all in but watch out for the scooters. KEEP RIGHT!
bit like blackpool at night. Ok but prefer the souks and hidden restaurants in the alleyways. Lovely orange juice opposite cafe de France (where you can use toilet for a few dinars).
Wonderful. Not quite as good as the madrasa, but is you like Islamic décor definitely worth a visit. Nice gardens and a peaceful retreat from the hubbub outside.

Aladdin's factory. Wonderful to think that almost everything for sale in the souk was made right there. It truly is a huge handicrafts factory enterprise. It is an enormous souk, and the variety of the products on sale is utterly amazing. Prices are low as long as youy bargain. Expect to pay around a third of the asking price. We bought cactus fibre scarves (£6-8) a bedcover of cactus fibre (£12) a straw hat, handbags, slippers (start about £6 cheapest) leather cushions, a belt. We loved poking around the area with tortoises (wish I could have brought one back) chameleons, animal skins (zebra, leopard) snakes live and skins - a bird of prey. There's so much to see. The vendors are goodnatured, and don't hassle you. (much).
Very easy to get lost inside all the souks in the Medina.. One can see all how skillful all the craft man in the souks are making leather goods, morrocan tin lampshades and clothings.

Go early. My girlfriend and I went with our tour group in the afternoon when it was packed with locals and tourists. We went back the next day at 9am when things were opening; a much more pleasant experience: uncrowded, cleaner, and much less vendor aggression. Very pleasant and profitable shopping experience.

Be prepared.. You will be hassled so accept it with good grace. When haggling start at about 30% go to 50% then walk away. It usually works. Amazing sights sounds and smells but advised to avoid the Mellah quarter especially at night, told it was dangerous. When aproached by toutes "you English" reply "non Irlandaise (Irish)" they are totally confused and give up. Currency is much cheaper in marrekech so don't bother in advance there are loads of cash machines and currency exchange outlets with better rates than Gatwick. Avoid what you think is a free sample or taster as it will cost you dear.

Time to get hustled in Marocco. Big square, with snake charmers, food, etc. get ready to pay for every picture you snap! They are born hustlers and this is there territory. I didn't enjoy my experience here and wouldn't go back. I think any trip in Marrakesh wouldn't be complete without a visit here but I think it's more for braggining rights.
An assault on the senses. Sights, sounds, smells are all here and it is an amazingly different experience to anything we have experienced in the west

Hustle and Bustle. The medina is a hive of activity, lots of shops, stalls, snake charmers, entertainers, food stalls etc. I liked the atmosphere of the medina and everyone is very friendly. There is nothing to dislike but you could be irritated by constantly being called into shops to buy and haggling down prices to get a good deal but for me you have to embrace everything.

Like going back 500, 1000, or 2000 years. One of the wonders of international tourism. The medina gives perhaps the best impression still existing of what it would have been like to live in New Testament Jerusalem, or Pompeii without the Roman architecture, or even a European medieval city. Most of the city walls still there, surrounding a warren of alleys with houses, palaces, mosques, religious schools, inns with courtyards, artisan workshops for joinery (starting from the actual branches of trees), metal work from ornamental to practical, leather goods including tanneries, weavers, bake shops, bath houses, fountains, butchers cutting meat in their open-fronted shops, big displays of fresh vegetables, spices and so on. Donkey-carts, hand barrows, street-smart urchins and beggars fill the lanes.

Crazy and wonderful. Both day time and night time this place is an experience not to be missed. Great fun shopping. One evening we had a local with us and what a difference it makes to the opening prices asked… saved a ton of time and money.

Not to be missed. It's better if a local you trust walks you through the Medina: not because it's unsafe (on the contrary, I found it very safe and fun), but rather because they will be able to bring you to the best shops and sights. My guide brought me to a shop and said to the owner, 'I'm from here: give me the good dates!'. We were taken downstairs to a completely different part of the shop and sold the best dates I've ever had in my life!

Fabulous place. Horrible people. Demanding money from someone for taking a photo when they haven't doesn't make for good tourism. Doing so by grabbing their arm and refusing to let them leave is even worse. Fist fights with the locals are not for me. I was planning on going back to shop - I stayed away.

Big, impressive, noisy, dirty but the real thing. The walled in area is very big and there is much to see and much to do.I guess most people will concentrate on the souk which is really impressive. Merchants of all kinds sit here and try to sell their goods, be it woodwork, jewellery, spices, pots and pans, rugs, clothes, meat, vegetables, all that you can think of. Galleries too. You can find really high quality items here. You have to bargain on the price of everything except for food. Be realistic and accept that you will never ever get near the price a local will be offered at the end of a long bargaining process.In order to escape alive from a visit, be on guard on all the time: Small motor bikes whizz through the narrow streets at breakneck speed. They have no intention of stopping for a pedestrian.Other than that you can feel perfectly safe here: A very friendly population and you can walk everywhere without risk.

An uncomfortable experience. Somewhere that was always on my bucket list, really looked forward to the visit, but despite reading reviews that it was not a daunting experience and that they were not hassled every step of the way, our experience was exactly the opposite.We were advised "don't wear jewellery", "don't show expensive cameras", "don't carry anything that would attract a pickpockets attention". OK this might have made me even more aware of possible problems, but were were pursued by street vendors, people wanting to be our guides, all and sundry offering us help and assistance that we didn't want. We are not inexperienced travellers but Marrakech has left us putting a line through further visits to Arab countries. Pleased to leave it.

Not as daunting!. I would recommend a guide for the first day, to get your bearings & to make sure you don't miss any of the sights as you are likely to without one. I was pleasantly surprised that you are not hasselled every step of the way in the Souks as I had imagined. Morroccans appear to be very aware of the negative perceptions travellers may have & they are making great efforts to address this to make visitors more comfortable. I hate to haggle, but the market traders make it a relaxed affair & we had a laugh while doing it.
Beautiful well worth a visit. Outstanding gardens, gorgeous colours, walk around enjoy and relax in the peace an tranquility. Galary, cafe, toilets and gift shop.
Nice places. It is very nice to walk through le Medina. The people are very friendly and one can have a lot of fun. Although it is nice to eat there.

Advice from the locals. 1. Do not get a hotel inside the Medina unless you have been to Marrakech several times and you are not alone.2. Avoid the Medina after dark, particularly if you are on your own. That is when the freaks come out.3. It is perfectly OK to smile when saying No, thank you. You will be doing a lot of that.4. Do not let ANYONE guide you to anything.5. Asking directions is usually pointless and pulling out a map makes you a target.Apart from that, the Medina is fascinating, but that's what the people who actually live there said. I got around it by taking a carriage or taxi anywhere I wanted to go and peeping a lot.

You will love it or hate it!. The Medina can seem overwhelming and we met guests at our Riad who said once was enough, but if you go back and start to find your way around it becomes more familiar and less daunting. My tips would be walk everywhere, then you get your bearings, and do not accept help from kids (or adults) who offer to show you the way. Although harmless you will be taken on a circuitous route past their cousin's shop, not taken to your destination and then asked for money!

Fascinating old town. Labyrinthine, fascinating and well worth the visit, the medina (old town) is a gem. Be prepared to be hassled by locals, but politely stand your ground and you will have a great time.
OK. I found this ok but not as exciting and colorful as led to believe. I found it a little intimidating mainly because of all of the warnings I had been given by people
Aggressive. This is a tough town. Everybody wants a tip and everything is a barter. Of all the cities I visited in Morocco, this medina is the most aggressive.

1-Star and 5-Star at the same time. The Medina is what lies within the old city walls. It is quite a contrast from what lies outside the walls. This place has no traffic lights, yet it has cars, donkeys, carts, scooters, bicycles, and pedestrians going in all directions of the narrow streets and alleys that criss-cross all over. There are thousands of little shops, food stalls, repair shops, dentists, wood-workers, riads, hotels, hammans, everything. It's crazy, madness, and probably hasn't changed much in the last 100 years. It's overwhelming for most people and it takes 3 days before you even start to get use to it. You don't know what to do, who to trust, where to go….most of the time your fully concentrating on just not being run over. Sometimes it's amazing, other times it's dreadful. The longer you are there, the more you will like it. It's like nothing else I've ever experienced.

Not the B all and end all of Marrakech.. Yes the Medina is a must see when visiting Marrakech, because that is where the history is. But it definitely is all that Marrakech has to offer. The new city is far nicer.
If you want hassled constantly. Constant harassment from guides and scam artists. If you want to haggle over a couple of dollars- good luck, personally I found it not worth the grief.

so different. amazing experience - fantastic colours everywhere, amazing choice - everything from food to carpets to clothes to shoes to jewellery to live animals..... easy to get lost but people very friendly and helpful

Stepping back in time. An absolute must , it gives you a real glimse into a way of life that hasn't fundamentally changed for hundreds of year. To the main selling dentures in the square to the food sellers in the alley ways.

Fun shopping experience. While I would tend to do any serious shopping in the new part of Marrakech, the Medina is just plain fun. Go out, get lost, haggle a bit for a few cheap trinkets, ignore the vendors trying to hassle you, and enjoy your day. Sure it's dirty, crowded, small, tight, confusing, etc. but what are you expecting out of a trip to Marrakech?

all those little streets are confusing at first.... ... but you'll get used to them. Try to get a detailed map. There is no reason to feel threatened. Yes, the locals are a little pushy but all in good fun. The best thing for me were the vegetable markets. It made me want to buy fresh produce and take it home. I didn't do that but on the day of our departure I stopped and bought some freshly baked bread, the round flat kind with cracked wheat. It's in the freezer and will have its big performance when I cook my first tajine for friends ;-)
Like nowhere else!. Visited twice. Get lost in the narrow streets, explore and enjoy: loved it. Go off the beaten path to find the 'Real Marrakech.'

A Must Do Experience. The Medina is a cultural treat. You can find almost anything there and the food is great. Make sure to allocate 2 or 3 full days to see it all and don't pay a guide or use a guide to see it - they will only take you to the shops where there friends and family are selling. And be ready to barter - that's the fun part. Your legs are your best negotiating tool.

Overwhelming but fabulous. You can easily spend a whole day just wandering. Each souk has a different character and away from the more tourist orientated souks you can find local markets, watching local people going about their every day lives is amazing and a bit overwhelming. If you are looking for something that challenges all the senses you will find it here. One tip though, if you ask for directions, chances are someone will very enthusiastically lead you to where you want to go but will expect payment ! people will also try and take you to where they want you to go and charge you !

Beautiful and intimidating.... The Medina was a truly beautiful place with so much to offer! We purchased beautiful bags, spices, scarves and enjoyed haggling with the locals for our items. I however, did grow weary of being harassed. I did expect it, but not quite as much as it happened. I, on the first day wore a black jumpsuit and black cardigan, so was pretty much covered from head to toe, however I do have long blonde hair which people said may be a problem. On the first day I had my bottom grabbed about 3 times, at one point by someone on a moped who pretty much tried to take off with me. I found it quite tiring and as 3 young women together found it quite intimidating so wouldn't return unless with a boyfriends or male friends.After a few days once your used to it people shouting ''Shakira'' and ''Nice bum'' will just make you laugh.Don't let random people offer to take you on a tour to the tanneries or even just guide you places as you may think they're being friendly but they'll stand with their hands out at the end...

Fear not !. Fabulous, colourful, vibrant and friendly. Full of all sorts of markets and we found virtually hassle free. You are approached often with goods but when you show no interest you are not pursued. Lots of specialists sectors e.g metal work, lanterns, leather and pottery etc.. Lots of cafes and restaurants and fresh orange juice stalls.

Medina of Marrakech. Take a walk through the Medina of Marrakech. Start at the big Marketplace in front of the Medina, and experience the many sounds of flutes people and music, sights of snakes. Get lost in the narrow streets, Enjoy the many colours, the smells and the huge amount of things they are selling. Don´t miss the negotiatience with the shopowners. Try to taste the many delicious Things they are selling. Most of alle try one of the many cafe that serves food on roffterrases, from where you can overlook the many roff and Places of the Medina. When the day is over and you are a bit tired in foot and leg, go to the big Marketplace again. At 18 hours the Marketplace is changed to one big restaurant with lots of tents offering meals of al kinds.The Medina. The arabic way of life. Music, smells and colours. You will love it

Bright and open. This medina contrasts quite a bit with the one in Fes. We walked from the Bab Agnaou to the Bahia Palace and it felt quite open and less mysterious than in Fes. We also walked along the mall to the Jemaa El Fnaa. Although we had guides with us, their help was not as critical as having guides in Fes.

sorry did not like the medina....3 days was enough..... After 3 days in a Riad in the Medina, I canx our last 3 days and moved to a fully inclusive resort on the outskirts of Marrakech..something I swore than I would never do...but after 3 days or wandering around the medina, continually getting lost, which did not matter, as you always come back to the Square, but just seeing more and more and more of the same...it got very boring....I guess I did not like seeing something so Authentic...did not enjoy Morocco, whic is a shame as was really looking forward to it...I am a very experienced travellers, love Egypt, Jordan, Israel, etc but just could not enjoy the experience of Morocco.

Great way to immerse yourself in Moroccan way of life. This Medina was the first one we encountered on our trip to Morocco, and its safe to say we threw ourselves in the deep end in doing so. Marrakech is known to be a tourist hub therefore the shopkeepers/locals in the Medina can be quiet full on to handle with their schemes of getting money from you. but at the same time we really enjoyed our time in the medina and stayed in a hostel in the centre of it. We felt safe walking around (couple in mid 20s) and we quickly learnt that a firm NO to people following you for money sets them on their way and you just have to be firm, sounds harsh but ignoring the people coming up to you on the street is the best way to deal with them, do not be friendly or polite as they will follow you and you will not be able to shake them. Really enjoyed the street food set up on the main square each night, this place is a must!

A maze of tiny alleyways and streets.. No matter how good your map is, the main streets seem to shrink into alleyways that just about take pedestrians and motorcycles, so it is very easy to get lost. But, for the equivalent of £1 there is always someone who will guide you in the right direction.
Authentic Morocco. The maze of Marrakesh old town is the truly Moroccan soul and the place to stay if you visit the city.

hustle and bustle. traders are very persistent and want you to buy from them but you have to be firm, haggling is part of the shopping experience. the main square is very busy at night and you can't see what is going on as there are too many people. we got lost far into the souks (which is not recommended) but we saw things that you would not believe, how the locals live.

Souks and crowds. We have been before and so knew what to expect -- wonderful smells of spices, fascinating souks and crowds. But they should stop pandering to western-style fast food -- hamburgers, panninis and endless chips! Local food, if you can find it, is much better.
Eye opener. Fantastic,very traditional,go with the flow,an experience not to be missed,more for the locals than the tourist.
watch the world go by. The Medina is wonderfulEat there Drink Mint tea or fresh juice and watch the world go byNumber one stall is where we ate but they all looked good

Don't forget to haggle!!!. Loved it. The place to come if, like me, you love shopping. You can buy anything and everything here. Just don't be tempted to follow anyone to look at his family's, his friends, or his own goods. Also be aware of being told something is 'only here today'. Other than that ENJOY the unique experience.
Getting Lost. You will get lost in this amazing place...but you will find your way out...its fascinating! In some places its like going back in time for thousands of years.
Easy to navigate. Very easy to navigate. The entire medina (old city) is approx 19 km no need to take a cab even to visit Majorelle Garden.
A different world. As if you are on a James Bond movie set. Busy, hectic but also charming. Just discover it and go with the flow

Really enjoyed our time here. It's hussle and haggling but really great to see. Shopping shoulder to shoulder with the locals and we found that a polite smile and a no thank-you deterred all but the two more in your face sellers. Indeed if you were carrying bags and had clearly bought something they were called out less so buy something early on and relax! We felt completely safe here, the Moroccans are really a genuine and kind people and very hospitable. You can't come here without visiting the souks! Do beware pick pockets though and you really don't need a guide! Even if it's day 1 tell them it's day 5!! We were there 4 days and were only asked twice if we wanted a guide so.

Interesting but not returning. The concept of visiting 10,000 stores in crowded streets mentally prepared to bargain all the time has never been something I dreamed of doing. I did it once in Delhi and had to repeat it now in Marrakech to please my wife. Always accompanied by a good and knowledgeable guide indicated by the hotel we surfed the crowds looking for bargains and unique pieces. Most clothing stores claim to have exclusive hand made models that can be seen in the next stores. The glass, wooden pieces, boxes, tea pots, silver items, are all the same in most shops. We did buy some antiques but not sure about them.They always want to bargain at the end giving a global discount forcing you to buy more than one piece. Bargain each piece. You may get at least 50% of the initial price. We found most articles even after bargaining expensive but maybe because we were tired we end up buying. We went 2 days as our guide always had some need to see stores. Just the last one was worthwhile for women clothing with exclusive models. I do not want to advertise but if you look for the best in local traditional fashion clothing you have to look for the big name in Marrakech. Did see some cartons written "made in china" that to be fair could be for merchandise other than the one sold at Medina. Beggers were not a problem. Streets were considerably clean. The general mess is organized and you are able to walk freely, just keep the right end side of the street and watch for the motorcycles. Do not go without an official guide indicated by the hotel. Also enter in any store you feel like not just on the one your guide tells you to.Regardless of the above Medina is a must to see. We did not eat there just had coffee and tea at the Ryads which are worth seeing.

his place is amazing. his place is amazing. The 5 brothers who run this place treat everyone like family. The food is great and so is the nightly entertainment, but the most amazing part is the view of the dunes from the front steps. I stood there with my mouth open!

An adventure!. Be strong, stand your ground and you can enjoy the experience. Don't get taken in by 'friendly' locals offering to help you find your way around - unless you are preparing to pay for the privilege!

Medina. Median was very colourful and noisy. Some parts in the middle were more sophisticated than the side parts where you got hassled more. Walking through these parts with my 3 daughters, we had to be careful not to have eye contact with some of the men or they would not leave you alone. The shop keepers themselves were very friendly and we didn't feel intimidated, you just have to be firm.

Haggling with the hospitable Moroccans. I've traveled quite a bit, but despite my experience, haggling for anything is still one of my least favorite things to do. But I must admit, that the culture of the Moroccan people, at every market place, made it by far the best experience of my least favorite travel activity!The Moroccan people in general are a very 'hospitable' culture - they take great care in making sure that everyone is greeted with a welcoming salutation, and expect (deserve) a gracious reply in turn. This also applies in the medinas - where their job is certainly to try to entice you to buy their wares, but the experience is far better when the culture is to be polite and gracious during the traditional 'haggling' negotiations. You will find that even if you cannot come to an agreement on price, most vendors will still respectfully bid you a good day. Be advised: there are people who will offer to guide you, and expect payment for the service (even if they say they won't). I found it helpful and worth the few dollars, to get a guide to take us to exactly what we were looking for. Of course, they will take you to their friends and relatives - but you can stop along the way with them to look at whatever you want, and my experience was that they would help you to negotiate a fair price. A guide is also the quickest way out of the maze of the medina - saving you the time and stress of being lost if you are on a schedule, or frightened by the crowds.The marketplace came to life as the sunlight grew dimmer - the crowd quickly grew, the hawking of the vendors calling you to dine at their stalls grew louder, and the energy became more dynamic. There is everything at the medina - freshly squeezed citrus drinks, charming young men trying to entice you to dine in their stalls making fresh foods, vendors with all manner of things for sale, and even the exotic experience of snake charmers and monkeys to pose with to scare friends and family back at home!

The real Marrakesh. We were staying in a poorer end of the Medina but never felt in danger even when walking home late at night We were very nicely deceived in our first day or so with people claiming they recognised us from the Riad and offering to show us where the locals buy Aragon oil etc but in reality lead to where their contacts owned the shopWe ended up probably paying too much for substandard goods but it was done with theatre with cups of mint tea poured and stories told and we took it as part of the experience of our introduction to Marrakesh You must visit the souks both during the day and in the evening don't start to haggle unless you want to buy and really like what you are looking at . Walking along the roadway in the evening full of crowds of people and motor bikes weaving past and donkeys in carts with exotic smells made it a great experience
Step back in time. Great. We loved staying in the medina. It was interesting and a great experience. Watch out for the bikes!

Bad atmosphere, at least for me. Too crowded, too noisy and on every 5 meters somebody wants to "help" you. I didn't like the atmosphere at all, probably it is better with a local guide who really guides you and doesn't want to rip you off.

Unique experience. We visited as part of a tour group under two scenarios (a) Night guided tour where hundreds of thousands of people were milling, eating, being entertained by so many things. The noise, the buzz, the crowds, the sellers (of whatever you wanted or didn't want), the half terrified feeling that you'd be lost, coupled with the thrill of being with so many people moving in all different directions and in all different modes -on foot, on bike, in car, on horse. The smells and the sounds, as well as what the eyes could see,was an amazing mixture. Even the smoke rising from the cooking of the meats seemed to produce not only a wonderful aroma but further mystique. As a group, we couldn't believe that we weren't all tied together to ensure we didn't lose each other but somehow, with the local guide, we all emerged. It was exhilarating!(b) Day visit. As a group we were returned to the Medina to "look or buy" for 1.5 hours. Even though there are individual stalls, where we went I observed that they were very organised. A "runner" relayed to other stall owners what we were interested in and as additional information was gained, this was passed on so that the next stall owner could offer a bit more. Fortunately we had a reference point for price (from a shop) and used this as our top price. I hadn't bargained before - but I loved it - and of course I bought things that I don't really need! This was a great experience. Hint: be on your guard all the time; don't take photos of the locals unless you ask otherwise they will demand money; if you get a cab agree a fixed price before you get in the cab.

Not what I expected. The medina is a large square with streets radiating off on several directions. The square is where the "main event" stuff takes place, but there was little happening when I was there. There were a couple of snake charmers, a guy with a monkey, and about 43 places to buy fresh squeezed orange juice.The really wild stuff goes on after dark, I am told. And since I didn't get here after dark, I certainly cannot refute that.I did find a stall just off the square, with the help of my friendly guide, where I could get mechoui (whole roast lamb). My buddy and I ordered a sheep's head and a half kilo of the mechoui. Both the head and the shoulder meat we had was excellent and the price was quite reasonable (About $20 for the both of us for lamb, bread, olives, and beverages)
Old nice city part. In the medina are small street wehre you can buy all the little handmade things of the art. You can go by feet and there don t drive any car because of the small streets.

Take a compass and learn to tut.. This is a must see when you are in Marrakech, despite what others have written.Yes, you will be approached by shop keepers. Yes, it can be busy, dirty and smelly. Yes, you might take a wrong turning but the experience is unforgettable.These are poor people working hard to make a living but without exception we found them to be polite, helpful and honest. A few precautions; Don't hire a guide - they will steer you to a relative's shop.Don't accept offers of directions - even when they say they don't want money - they do. A favourite opening line is, "Hello, don't you recognise me? I work in the Riad - I've just changed clothes. Are you looking for spices/carpets/jewellery/ etc today? I can get you a special price."Do take a compass with you. That way you'll be able to navigate the narrow passageways without help. [TOP TIP]Do stop and look at the goods but remember souks are market places and you'd expect to be approached by a sales assistant in a city clothing store, wouldn't you?Do learn how to politely escalate your refusal. Start by making a tutting sound with your tongue as you quickly flick your head up and back. This is how the locals say No and works most of the time.If the attention persists, say La Shokran - No thanks. If that doesn't work say Khalas (the kh is pronounced like the Scottish ch sound in loch) - that means Enough! Hold up your right hand at the same time (never your left). Last resort is to shout Shouma - Shame on you! We never needed more than the tutting.Do dress modestly. Women wearing scarves on their heads get less attention.Try not to shake hands with the traders. Arab people hold hands longer than westerners during a handshake, but this is also a clever way to gently steer you towards their shop. Smile and tut instead.Do ask if you can take photographs - even if it is just the goods, not the vendor.Remember that the price of taxis goes up when it's raining but you'll still be able to cut a deal.Allow a couple of hours at least and enjoy the whole experience.

THE OLD TOWN IS VERY BUSY. LOCAL PEOPLE ARE VERY HAR-WORKERS....Quite clean, friendly people..... We always felt save, even in the evening. Locals are very helpful.Thanks marrakech people!!Dislike, but...it is there way: as soon as we look to something, someone approaches to sell....and, you just walk away. If not, you probably would buy it.....
Good to see. Not to be on top of your visit list. busy crowded area and we are not allowed in. Hotel coach drop off point is just opposite the Medina if you wanted to see it.

Hassle and stressful. We did not really enjoy the experience because of the constant hassle, I totally understand that for very poor people, tourists are wealthy and can afford to buy. However, the level of hassle meant that we only ventured out of the Riad a few times and then after a few days, decided we had had enough. The Government really need to get street signs in place so that one has a chance of following a map. Not being able to navigate because of the lack of street signs means you are a target for people who want to 'guide' you and then try to hustle you. Its a shame, because the people of Marrakech are kind and helpful and a tourist should not have to feel fearful and stressed. We would not recommend the Medina.

Great place to visit. If you want to buy anything it is the place for. But be careful about the scams, don't ask any question or that will cost you a tip. Don't go to visit the tannery for free, like they said it will cost you 10 euro, you re lost don't let people to accompany you or it will cost you money again. Be careful of the pick pocket especially in the busy places, it is happen to me. Just be aware, but it is a great place to get lost too.

Poverty on tap. So very very poor,people always trying to grab you or get money from you, make sure you don't ask for directions or look at your map as they want paying for that, we made sure we were back at Hotel before it got dark.

Too commercialized for a historical place. Medina is Marrakech is the most fleshy, touristy, and commercial out all Medina's we have seen in Morocco. As everything, it has pluses and minuses. We like Marrakesh over Fes, Rabat, Casablanca, Meknes; etc., however, some people might get tired of mirages of sales people who are everywhere. If you are OK with saying "la shukran" a few times, then it should not be a problem. If you are in Marrakech, Medina is the absolute must to see. I would avoid visiting sooks, other than taking a pick from a distance. Carriage ride is a good thing to use (2hr = $25 give or take).

Blend of textures. Been here with my family, we love the Old medina, it was a small town surrounded by an immense wall dated since 11th Century, lovely color in earthy textures, amazing crazy souks and streets and its crazy but funny people, old and young Marrakesh -knows how to play the game of luring the tourist in their magical or bad dreams. but the old city is colorful, many fascinating monuments and mosque, and you can hear those prayers all over the city. It was also not so far to the famous Mamounia palace , one of the best luxurious place I ever visited, From morning to night medina is busy, vendors and stalls, and those old taxis, and children playing in the streets. It is a wonderful experience to see this place

Excellent experience. The medina is huge, don't be scared when you are stood out at the start of one of the pathways into it from the square, it is a must do when in Merrakech. The colours, smells, and friendly folk selling their goods is something you need to experience. People say you get hassled but they are not aggressive and it is their way and you are in their country, really you can have quite a laugh and haggle with them. There are lots of pathways inside but just keep walking and don't worry, if you don't want to talk, wear shades and don't make eye contact. I used some tall building to get my bearings once in a while and got back to the square OK.It is mostly shaded and out of the sun.Just do itVisited here Feb '10Plead hit 'YES' if you found this helpful

A cultural walk with amazing shops. A place to shop in Marrakech with plenty of traditional things to buy at reasonable prices. Must but Tagine from local shops with brass or silver traditional Moroccan teapot...

Lots of shopping opportunity but mostly tat. A nice place to visit for a few hours to take in the sights and smells of the Medina, Beware of straying too far away from the main market as you may find yourself in a dark alley and unsure of your way back to the square. Most of the stalls sell the same thing, so if you dont get the price to what you'd like, keep walking you'll surely find it elsewhere. Beggars, pickpockets and motorbikes/scooters in the alleys are constant reminders to be cautious.

Very stressful .... we are quite well travelled, and Marrakesh was a must see place, the souks and Medina was an experience, but not one I want to repeat in a hurry, DO NOT TAKE CHILDREN, you can't stop and look at anything without being hassled and harassed, I would love to have walked freely and enjoyed the sights and sounds and occasionally the smells. I would have loved to have purchased a few small things but it got to the point where you just don't want to stop and look. I am the most polite person ever and it doesn't feel nice to be ripped off. I politely said no thank you and was told to "f... yourself' very loudly by a woman trying to put Henna on my hand which I didn't want, we were followed by a man who kept asking 'where you going I show you the way' he wouldn't leave us alone, we gave him a few pounds but he still didn't go away... My one tip DO NOT EAT IN THE MEDINA we were totally ripped off with prices, and the food was dreadful, it really is a very intimidating place and not for the faint hearted which I most certainly am not .... oh and don't stop to look or take a photo of a 'snake charmer' unless you're prepared to pay!

Amazing chaos. Jemaa el Fna or the main square can be described as welcoming but chaotic at the same time, I must say it is not for the faint hearted. In this bulging square you will see everything from snake tamers , monkeys, donkeys and traditional dancers to stalls selling spices ,foods and beautiful hand made crafts. Don't be put of by being approached constantly or asked to look to taste or to buy this is merely the culture of the people.So what you want to do in the square.This is truly the heartbeat of Marrakech.

Beware bogus guides. Beware of supposedly 'Official Guides' who take you through back streets to a carpet shop & then just leave you. Make sure you observe your route so that, like us, you can walk away & find your own way back! Haggle in a friendly manner for souvenirs - it's a game & great fun
Good but not as nice as Essaouira. too much chinese stuff sold there. you can get better shopping experience but not in the centre of the medina, go on the streets a little further from the centre.

Good deal[ing]s. I noticed many comments use the term 'great bargains' when talking about Marrakech's medina quarter and the souks. I would advise that the visitor should expect 'great bargaining' instead. The prices are not important, really. You have traveled for something unique, so what price can you set for the unique? And the quality of materials and the workmanship are just as unique. I would encourage every visitor to explore and visit the artisans in their shops, converse, sense; this is where a great deal is made.As for bargaining and dealing; you are in the center of the world's best sales people. One ten-yr-old boy we dealt with could converse fluently in at least the five languages of our group, shifting from one to another effortlessly. He was polite to a fault and engaging; no fear of the waters he navigated. The price you will pay might not impress your friends when you get home, but you will have dealt and lightly haggled and bargained boltly,.... and that is a story of great worth in the telling!
Fun exploring the medina. Lots of fun shops with great bargains. Great people watching! The smells of the spices were awesome.
Must see in Marrakech. This is a given for a trip to Marrakech. Its very dusty and colourful but that's the charm of Marrakech. Make sure you haggle for everything, its their culture!

An area of diverse colour, spices, and much more. On our visit to Medina, we saw an excellent variety of what Marrakech is all about. The colour of the fabrics are amazing, especially for the women. Spices are everywhere to tease your nose.  Livestock are sold live to the locals and you see many a local on foot or bike carrying the live chickens or rabbits home. We even saw a moped stocked up trays of eggs. It flew past us in a flash. You would not see anything so extraordinary here in the UK.There are plenty of stalls selling food and drinks. Mint tea is the usual drink and we had plenty of it. It was divine. As usual there were the usual pedlars of all ages plying their wares and ladies prepared to pain your hands intricately with henna.There are streets after streets full of stalls of all kinds. You could spend days just searching the mass of metal, leather, fabric, food, spice, and the like. It could suck you up so easily as there was just so much to see.Prepare to barter for your goods, don't just accept the first figure given to you. We came back with good quality items and at good prices all because my husband successfully bartered the prices down. Would we go again, yes we would as there is much we still have not seen.
Marrakech. what a stunning city.So vibrant and colourful.The Moorish architecture, especially at the Madrassa is simply stunning. wish we had longer than 3 days

AWFUL ! Avoid!!!!!. Marrakech as a whole is an awful place. Dirty and a tourist trap.
