It is virtually impossible to even buy a bottle of water without being charged 5 times as much as what you can expect in a Western country.Everyone is out to con you out of money. I am well travelled and have been all over the world, so I am quite open minded. It is the first time I have been anywhere that I felt so strongly against that I would warn people to avoid it all together.There is hardly that much to see or experience here anyway. Not worth the money or time.
Give it ago. Dont be afraid to go out and about and explore. i am so happy i did. exploring is all part of being in Marrakech, watching the sunset, listening to the mosque calling everyone to prayer.
heart of marrakech. the old town full of history ,sights ,characters all things Moroccan . must be experienced to get a real flavour of what marrakech is about
Very interesting !. Lose yourself in the old medina and souk. It is like stepping back in time. So exciting ! Great for photos and shopping. Be prepared to haggle !

very noisy place. The Medina is almost same like any Medina in Morroco. But the most irritating part is the presence of noisy and dangerous scooters in the narrow streets. The Medina is also full of animals that block the narrow streets. Many Morrocans try to hustle tourists inside the old city which is really disturbing. Unlike Medinas in Rabat and Fez which are really nicer. The only good place to visit inside the Medina is Jemaa Al Fina.

So different. The atmosphere was exciting and so different. Many of the buildings were old and beautiful.We enjoyed people wanting to talk to us and sell us their products but I did not appreciate comments made by some men about my 19 year old daughter who made the effort to dress respectively so as not to cause offensive.

Market hassles. This vibrant, noisy and often maze like souk is a place like no other. The smells and scenes are truly at the heart of Moroccan culture and its worth the adventure. However, travel in pairs and be prepared for the amount of hassle you'll get. The hustlers are not the local shopkeepers, who on the whole are great fun to haggle with, but a different type of local, who are rude and offensive young men hanging around trying to make some baksheesh.

Crazy but fun! Give yourself time to get your bearings!. The medina can be overwhelming to a newcomer! It took our group (4 adults, 5 kids) a few days to get our bearings and then we had a blast walking around but the first 3 days were a bit intimidating. If you get lost, ask shopkeepers directions! Do not take advice from the young boys on the streets trying to "help you" you will surely get more lost. The shopkeepers are very helpful.

the Median. The souks seem interesting but the sight of animal skins being sold openly especially leopard skins and other endangered species wasjust too much. On the one hand we are trying to protect animals from extinction and the other side is there is no regulations at all in Marrakech.

Great fun. Walking through Jemna el Fna and the surrounding souks is not to be missed. There are a number of great historic sites to be visited although these are not always well marked. There is a considerable amount of tourist tat to be haggled over but it is all done with great humour. The main square has little of significance during the day but comes alive at night with the cheap food stalls (I ate there three times and was not ill). You will be overwhelmed by touts but they all have a great sense of humour - talk to them and they'll make you laugh! Must be done but can get tedious after a while and the monkeys on chains, snake charmers and henna tattooist didn't amuse me at all, however traditional.

An experiance. The Medina is an experience and great if you like to haggle. At around 4pm they start setting up food stalls in the square, it is a lovely sight when it is dark and all the lights are twinkling.
Be prepared. You will be hassled and have no time to 'browse' but you soon get used to it and just have to learn to say 'no'. Great selection of stalls and entertainment.
Different world. Donkeys, motorbikes, cats, loads of people and everyone is trying to sell you something from leather good to kif.

Madness in Marrakech. The scene is set the audience await & the performance begins from afternoon till late. Food stalls performers snake charmers & the obligatory hassling.enjoy but only give correct change.

keep your nerve. lovely to just walk around but be very careful as they will charge over the odds for anything you want to buy, for just normal touristy gifts and stuff I suggest you go to a shop next to hotel Islane all the items have fixed marked price and reasonable save a lot of time in haggling
incredible. be prepared for persistant vendors. Worth a tour/guide for your first visit to the souks. The whole experiance was incredible

Wonderful. The old medina has changed liitle over the centuries (apart from the ubiquitous motorbikes!) and I would recommend vistors stay here, rather than in one of the modern hotels in the new city.
Heart of the city. It's nice just to walk along the numerous streets and to drop by market place. To stop in a small restaurant or caffe for a refreshment drink or light lunch.

the old of old. Inside the old city, and be hide "cafe de France" down the small roads you come to the Medina and there is so such to see at least 2 days with the old Jewish area and spice markets and forts and palaces, with good eating everywhere. No need to stay there as everything is quite close and getting around on foot is no problem.People are so friendly and willing to help and guild you in the right direction. A real pleasure to the senses.

Medina. Medina is nothing but a place with a main square and narrow by lanes full of street vendors or small shops selling clothes, souvenirs and spices, shoes and restaurant. The place is extremely crowded, full of filth, dirt. You will be almost lost in the crowd. It is certainly not for those who loves peace and quitetude and relaxing environment. I would not go again to this place after paying so much money. Its not a place worth wasting your money

Part of it's charm. Last visited this fortified city packed with vendors and their stalls many years ago and while locals still throng the streets, many of the souk's stalls are clearly designed for foreigners. The surrounding neighbourhoods have grown substantially and was not at all recognisable. My friend and I departed the bus at the Medina and were immediately approached by men stating they were from our hotel offering their services as guides. Although we said no, they still followed us for awhile but soon gave up. We were also approached by several women trying to grab our hands to decorate them with henna tattoos, but a firm 'no thank you' and they left us alone. There is a lot of hustle & bustle in the Medina which might not suit everybody as it can be a culture shock for some, but it's all part of it's charm. Shop around before you buy, always barter and be assertive. Still a magical city.....

An accoustic handgranade. As soon as you enter, you are taken aback by the sights and smells... but mainly the sound of the Medina. Noise comes from every direction, as do the mopeds & donkeys pulling carts. Stalls are everywhere selling everything, including the kitchen sink (I kid you not). You will seldom see a price tag, so make sure you know the cost before considering a purchase. Shop around and dont be affraid to walk away

Very Interesting. Busy and not for the faint hearted. Not hassle free shopping at all but once the art of 'tuning out' or detaching from the hassle is adopted its delightful fun to deal with some of the less aggresive sellers.

Exotic!. The Medina is exotic and extremely interesting, but also very safe - even the most chaotic part of it, the Kasbah and the jewish quarters. It is easy to get lost, but it isn´t so big as to make it difficult to find your way again.The locals are mostly helpful and not as pushy as we expected, despite their obvious desire to earn a bit of cash by lending a helpful (though largely unnecessary) hand.Be careful with the prices you get charged at shops - ask in advance what you will be charged. We got striped in a spices shop because we didn´t take this obvious precaution...
a laberinth, full of surprises. first impressions not too good, in fact horrible, but after returning the 2nd time/day, i quickly changed my mind, i got enchanted by everything it had to offer.

barell loads of rubbish. Before I begin, I go again to Marrakech Febuary 2014. Because on my last visit I found the overall ambience quite exciting, different and lively from European adventure, and also to that found in Tunisia / Turkey. But on my first trip I did stay in a Riadh, centre of the Medina / Soukh, and was one of very few Europeans seen in that area in general and even had over filled rubbish bins and a tied up donkey next to the entrance thereof. Genuine fly ridden food shops alongside the very narrow streets upon which one walked with trepidation, mopeds everywhere missing the pedestrian by centimetres. Whilst the air is filled with the aeromatica of open markets, fresh fish or meat shops, ( also fly ridden) cooking and so on, the acrid moped smoke and motor noise everywhere rather detracts from the pleasure.But the stalls/shops/bazaar? Piles of poor product, nothing less than rubbish, poor quality offerings hanging from shop frames. Just stopping to look, or even walking by attracts the vendor to you, "Francais, Deutsch, Eeengleesh, I spik, I spik - you buy you buy" and if you're really unlucky one will be grabbed by the arm with similar words with an attempt to drag one into dark recesses wherever. As to the leisurely examination of goods, forget it. " you have money, you buy, finest camel leather you look," when frankly better stuff can be bought in Leeds Market! Cheaper! As to the touristy phrases to the effect of enjoying bartering for a bargain, well, find out for yourself. Dont hold the breath unless you just enjoy the useless.Then there are the street entertainers, snake charmers and the like. Be aware of the viciously thrusted fez in front of the nose demanding money at the mere hint of a camera shot. Sat harmlessly with a coffee, amateurish acrobats often begin throwing themselves about in front of the cafe for a few minutes before the ubiquitous fez was produced and shaken " for ze accerobattes".Ignoring them was a good strategy - from behind the cafe table face stuck in the emptying cup.On trips into the wilds, when stopping in the remotest places the inevitable trader seemed to pop out from behind a sand dune or rock formation as if by arrangement. Whilst there is so much more to tell of this, keeping a clear head there is genuinely a lot to see of a different culture - but for the first timer the place is geared up to one thing, and one thing only, treating the tourist as an idiot, forcing the unwary to buy poor stuff from curiosity or fear, and charging as much as they can for utter crap.2014 I am treating myself to a fine all inclusive hotel, and intend to enjoy the country and overall culture without giving the Denizens of the Medina the pleasure of ripping me off!

Worth a look. There are things happening everywhere here - plenty of stalls, plenty of food. it is well worth a look just from a chaos perspective and getting yourself lost for a while. Amazing labyrinth.

Takes getting used to, but don't miss. You haven't experienced this place until you spend some time in the Medina. It took us a day to get used to the pushy sales and learn how to walk away. We never felt unsafe, they just have a very different way of doing business and once you figure it out...Enjoy the craziness, but have a calm place to stay at night, you'll need it.

Amazing old city with crowds. This is a must see - narrow winding streets filled with people and shops. Exotic yet down to earth. Ask for directions for where you want to go. People were friendly and helpful.

Lively and interesting, but difficult to breathe. We loved the lively atmosphere of the Medina in Marrakech, but much prefered the Medinas of Chefchaouen and of Fes because they do not allow cars and motorbikes. The air pollution in the medina of marrakech made it difficult to fully enjoy the atmosphere. It feels like a pretty unhealthy place. (dirty, polluted). People here were pushier (more desperate) than in the other Medinas we experienced in Morocco. We did like the activity and bustle of the medina and getting lost in winding old streets, but felt so overwhelmed by the air quality and dodging being run over by motorbikes, that we ended up leaving a day early to get out to rural Morocco. Jemaa El Fna is pretty amazing at night and shouldn't be missed. We also liked seeing the setup in Jemaa El Fna in the late afternoon, as food vendors started preparing for the lively evening. Our meal in Jemaa El Fna at night was delicious and choosing a restaurant was a fun experience.In terms of the souqs, we were glad we saved our shopping for Fes and Chefchaouen, as they seemed to have some more authentic products and less slightly pushy salespeople. (especially in chefchaouen). I recommend really wandering out into the less traveled areas of the medina where fewer tourists wander. Those are the areas that we enjoyed the most.
Intense. One of those must visit places in the world. Hectic, timeless, atmospheric, noisy, dusty, dirty, tiring, fantastic.

none stop hassle all the way. The old town is a lovely place with all the cobbles and people working, what spoils it alot is the hassle you get from the morrocan wanting to rip people off all the time, wanting to take you places, sell you things and as a woman i could tell that they were talking about me and starring all the time, and some of them shouting abuse. If they just left people to wander around it would be lovely.

A mass of traders selling allsorts of wares. This is a very large area of all sorts of market traders seling scarves jeweillery earthenware etc many of them selling the same things. It is;just like a huge maze with lots of nooks and crannies and you can easily get lost but ask anyone the way out to the main square and they are always eager to help you so dont worry too much about not being able to find your way out on your own. The traders are very friendly and all want to entice you on to their stall and spend some money but remember you should always Haggle with them to get a bargain. Very few of the stalls have any prices on so if you want to browse quietly without being hassled then this is probably not the best place to shop, In my opinion it is well worth a visit as there is a great atmosphere and you certainly won't be bored

Interesting. Definately well worth a visit with all the intersting things to see. From traditional singers to jugglers, people selling their wares. The only downside is that there were monkeys that were almost thrown on to people so that you had to pay to have a photo taken with them, if you don't like that sort of thing then you have to be quite assertive about saying no. Some of the horses pulling coaches around the market did not look very well looked after which was rather upsetting. Night time is the best time to visit.
Medina of Marrakech. Love it what a buzzing place by day and by night, holding a monkey by day, and all the food stalls by night
Interesting. I'm not much of a shopper but the medina and souks are worth the wander. We thought it was crazy until we went to Fez.

Fantastic souks. The souk area is very rich of experience and shopping opportunities. It's fairly easy to navigate with a good map as it is well signed. Make sure to bargain and shop around before buying. Prepare to get overwhelmed.

Keep a low profile and everything will go well. Obviously you got to be used to mopeds, crowds, and narrow winding streets. But if you take it the positive way, smile, are polite and open minded, you can have a great time and find everything you wanted ! Forget about time constraints and keep your positive attitude. What I liked also is just to get 'lost' in smaller streets leading to either a hidden riad or a lovely little shop...Not really a place for families with babies.

Back 10yrs later.... Huge disappointment. 10yrs ago I was enchanted by the medina. Mysterious alleys with all sorts of trades on display. Of course you get hassled to buy stuff, but back then it was mostly good natured banter and haggling with a smile... What a difference a decade makes... Aggressive sales everywhere, people grabbing at you to visit their store, kids intentionally pointing you in the wrong direction so that their friend can then "guide" you and demand tips. It's all very unpleasant overall. I wish I hadn't come back to ruin my memories of this place.

Square Comes Alive At Night. Yes, it is a tourist trap but you can’t come to Marrakech and not visit the medina! I went to the square both in the morning and at night. Try the morning option first if like me it is your first visit as it was much calmer and easier to negotiate your way around. I went twice in the morning around 10am. We never took a map or a guide and just went with the flow. At night, the square really comes to life. The sky is lit by the sky flier toys, the floor is adorned with the beautiful lanterns and LED windup toys. The sounds of traditional singers and story tellers fill the air alongside the hubbub of the crowds. It seriously is a world of its own!There are lots of shops selling the same thing; traditional gowns, belts, bags etc. There were also some strange and uncomfortable sights like animals skins and dead snakes the deeper we went into the souks. Plus you do get a lot of ‘traffic’ in the paths so be prepared to repeatedly move out of the way. If you don’t fancy exploring or are intimidated by the square just go for the refreshing fresh orange juice which is an absolute bargain at 4Dh! There are rows of sellers near the exit.Haggling is a strange experience. Some traders offer extortionate prices (10 times the actual amount) and others will offer a fair deal straight away so you never have any consistency. I took a currency converter so I wouldn’t get ripped off and it was the best thing I did. Think about it, why pay a ridiculous price for something in Marrakech if you would not buy it for that much in your home country? Also there is a currency exchange place near the square which offers decent rates so you can change your money there.One thing I would say it try to use the loo at your hotel before you travel ladies. They have the ‘squat’ toilets where you have the pleasure of paying a dirham to use their hole in the ground (take your own paper!).

Squalor. I have just had the most terrible holiday ever in the Medina in Marrakech. It is quite easily the most squalid, filthy, unpleasant and downright dangerous place I have ever been to. 'Attractions' to see in Marrakech are sub-standard at best - there are far better examples of Islamic culture to see elsewhere in the world without having to go this horrible place.As for 'the jewel in the crown' Jemaa el Fna, if you are interested in seeing total and utter squalor, all types of human low life, locals trying to rip off tourists on a grand scale, all different forms of animal abuse and a general smelly chaos, then this just the place for you.The only thing that makes me feel good about Marrakech is the knowledge that I will never ever go there again. Please take my advice, do not waste your hard earned money (as my wife and I unfortunately did) going to this sh**tehole of a place.

Fabulous medina. Great to just wander and get lost in. Bargain hard for,shopping, and be prepared to walk away as this often secures the sale. Shop around and get an idea of prices, or go to a fixed price shop if you don't want to bargain. It seems relatively safe, with minimum hassles (probably more if you are a young woman). We where there in Dec and then again for the Post-Christmas period which was much busier and traders were more aggressive in trying to get a sale. See the big square, but there are lots of smaller squares too.

FAN. we enjoyed so much walking in Medina,and I bought a lot of things ,I knew that I had to bargain over the price and I did it very well .we lost our way many times and we found it again and it was fanny .Be careful of the bikes and the horses in the medina ,and if you taking photos !!!!especially women ,they are getting angered easy .
An Experience. Not for the faint hearted. Need to be assertive, or look as if you know what you are doing, and where you are going.

Good fun but better deals to be had.. This place is great to go around and they have pretty much everything there but know the value of something before you decide to buy as prices are just what the vendor is feeling at the time. From my experience there were better deals to be had for most items further out from the medina. If you do want to try your hand at haggling it can be fun but make sure to know what you want to pay for the item first and don't be afraid to walk away. The other thing to point out is that it can get very tedious with vendors trying to constantly sell something to you, always asking to look at this or that and this really stops you from ever really wanting to stop moving to look at anything as they will pounce as soon as you even glance at an item.

Medina Marrakesh. If you like haggling for bargains and noisy narrow streets then this is for you! Make sure you lookout for the donkey carts and mopeds, they don't stop you have to jump out of the way! Locals are friendly but do say NO if you don't want an unofficial guide. Loads of good places to eat as well but VERY easy to get lost - we did on several occasions.

'Its One of a Kind, You Won't Find Better'. That is what we heard whenever we walked into any of the shops or stalls in the Medina. Its not true - whatever you see, there will be other places that sell exactly the same thing and you may find better elsewhere. The best advice I can give you is to say that you bought something similar the day before so you really aren't that interested and don't want to insult the shopkeeper - then you can offer them the silliest prices - bargaining is fun, but they are the masters and you cannot win at their game. I have seen things on the internet since I have come home that are cheaper than the things I am having shipped from Marrakech. I have just put it down to experience and enjoying playing the game. Having travelled to the Arab market in Jerusalem many times, the Medina was not a culture shock but I have never witnessed such terrible treatment of the animals that we walked past including monkeys on chains and half starved donkeys. It was very sad to see. Please do not encourage the people who own monkeys, snakes etc to keep them by paying to have photos with these poor animals.We took a guide with us so we didn't get lost but there were plenty of tourists around without guides who looked perfectly happy just wondering around. I thought that my teenage children, especially my daughter would get a lot of hassle but I was pleasantly surprised that everyone was very respectful and polite to us. If you look too closely into a shop or stall or point at something the shopkeeper with rush out to get you to come and look at everything in his shop. It can get quite irritating but don't be shy to say no thank you. The guide told us that we should ignore them.I will definitely go back but I will go out armed with a much better idea of how much things are worth.
Quiet in daytime. I am a boring old f**t and haven't visited at night yet! Quite fun in daytime but not world class. I preferred Essaouira.

All life is there. You can buy anything you want from photo frames made from old bike tyres through tat of all sorts mixed in with real life necessities of living: to artisan made articles. Always start your bargaining at half what you think an item is worth to you and join in the haggle it is expected and they will always start at more double. No one will bother you if you say no politely.A word of warning if tapped on the shoulder look the opposite way cos they will have their hand in that pocket. This advice cost me about £10 but like every where else most people are great kind and helpful. I had many more positive experiences.Acute observation of your rear is required at all times to avoid carts donkeys and MOPEDS but they all missed me!!
busy and fun. Lots of colour and life going on. Very different at night compared to day time but felt very safe both times.

Marrakech. Although we enjoyed the souks, we found it difficult to buy just one item. You were repeatedly badgered to buy thing you didn't want.Unfortunately, We couldn't forget the images of the poor skinny donkeys pulling carts so overloaded, they could hardly stand. Having said that, our hotel was excellent and the staff were great.

A great experience. We were actually staying in the Medina on the outskirts near one of the gates. The Medina is an amazing place but may come as a bit of a culture shock if you have not visited Africa or any other Islamic country. The souks are amazing but it is not easy to find your way around. If you are worried about getting lost (which we did a few times) then hire a guide but we didn't bother. You don't get as much hassle as some of the reviews I have read. My tips are - don't stop and look too long if you are not interested in buying, just be polite and say 'no thanks' if you are not intersted and never take pictures if you have not asked permission or are not prepared to pay for the privelidge, in particular the snake chamers and the men with silly hats. Be prepared, take a map and dress accordingly and you will enjoy the experience.

Perfect. You will probably be lost after 15 minutes, but no worries you will find your way back to the hotel! Be prepared to negotiate, but the local products are amazing and you can bring home a real nice souvenir.

The only thing to do in Marrakesh - Haggle. It's fun to get lost in the winding alleys of the souks and haggle with shopkeepers to buy overpriced things you werent even interested in. This warm fuzzy feeling last for about an hour before you realise this is on the most part all there is to do in marrakesh once you have seen the 'attractions'. The souks all sell the same things (common phrases ....Magic Box, Hand made, how much you pay and of course final price) TIP - ask the first person their price go to the next and say the first one one gave it for half that price and rince and repeat till you find a price you are comfortable paying :) As mentioned in other reviews the medina will remind you of most markets in Asia more than Africa, a mix of poverty and riches. its worth a mooch but very underwhelming to say the least.

Great place to get lost.. Impossible not to get lost, so just as well. The traders can be very insistent and it's best to know what the going price should be as it's very easy to get ripped off. However you can also get some bargains.

Nice when you get used to it. The first day's visit to the medina was horrendous. People yelling at you, yelling after you, mopeds and bicycles constantly passing you too close and salesmen who you feel are trying to deceive you. The second time I had gotten used to the rythm and culture of it and could then truly appreciate it. Give it a second chance!And, obviously: don't ask for directions and don't follow anyone.

Interesting. The Medina gives the true old world flavour of moorish life. Small alleys, busy shops selling colourful ware, old Benz taxis interspersed with horse carts and the pink buildings with some exotic riads hidden well inside, make this a truly amazing place to wander around. The food is amazing- try the tagines and the kebabs. Many riads look simple on the outside but are surprisingly well decorated once you are in. The main square was interesting but you sort of felt that the whole place is geared up as a showcase to tourists. The Souks are colourful and yes there are snake charmers in the main big square. Personally I would have given the main square a miss and spent more time in the streets around the medina or even in the Menara gardens.The streets of the medina have similar wares to shop that are available in the Souk- I bought lots of earrings. Toilets don't have loo rolls. So make sure to carry one-especially if travelling with kids. All in all a lovely experience.

chaos in the rough. the sounds and sights overwhelm you when you first enter the square. The snake charmers are quite aggressive so unless you are comfortable around the critters walk away from them. The dry fruit stalls look colorful and smells are enticing. once the evening settles in the snake charmers are gone and the square transforms into a vast arena of food stalls. they are all crowded and food in enjoyed by all comers. the souks around the square have stores that have all kinds of wares new to antiques and fakes. bargaining is the word of the day.

Amazing. Brilliant everything to buy in one place amazing street entertainers and busy place also some excellent restaurant scattered about watch the cars though they are all over the square and the horse and carriage ride is great in the main square

Medina theatre life. If you come from busy and overcrowded Tokio, it´s not so difficult to adapt into the medina of Marrakech. Still, it´s another kind of crowd. You have to be alert and all the time take care not to be overrun or hit by one of the many many vehicles, driving there criss cross around you.But if you go with the flow a bit, it´s manageable and lively.We enjoyed it for a while, and then fled in our quiet nice riad in the middle of the medina.Marrakech and its life is exciting, but only for one or two days. Sit down somewhere, and enjoy the spectacle, it´s really like a big theatre!

Bargaining is tough. I liked the variety but bargaining is a serious issue. They quote 400 and then let the item go for 130. My advice is to keep asking around and maybe buy on your last day. Don't over pay taxis, they say 50 dirhams for everything but the real rate is usually far lower (I paid 20-30 dirhams)

What an experience!. Absolutely fab! It's a must-do if you're in Marrakech! It's an assault on every sense, and so different to anything you've seen before! Prepare to haggle, it's all part of the experience.

An assault on your senses..but how could it be otherwise?. You haven't been to Marrakesh if you haven't visited the medina. We never felt unsafe, just severely pestered at times - some parts are much worse than others for this. Just give the impression that you've seen it all before, refuse politely yet firmly. Above all - smile when you do so. Avoid any 'help' you are offered - ask a shopkeeper if you need assistance.Be aware that their politeness ethos means that they will have to give you an answer - even if they know or not! Ask direct questions - 'Is the square this way or that way'? If you sense uncertainty, thank them, walk as indicated for a short while ...and ask someone else.Use your common sense and follow the normal rules, don't flash money, expensive jewellery or mobile phones, creep into a corner to consult a map. The mopeds though were real pain - take care. Unforettable and a must do.

So crazy its a must see. Wow what an experience the Medina is huge, everyone says you must have a guide, simply forget it, getting lost is all part of the experience. Some people says its overpriced, having lived in the Middle East for 7 years, haggling is part of the culture so embrace it and its expected, I can see why many films have been shot in the Marrakesh Medina, its bursting with colour, spices and ram packed with all kinds of goods, nick nacks and great bargains. Bikes and mopeds will drive you crazy and I wish they could be banned, its not like Tunisia, if you say your not interested the stall holders will leave you alone. If someone wants to show where something is just keep walking or you will end up in their uncles shop or worse a really crappy restaurant. All being said, its craziness is part of the charm

Getting lost whilst stepping back in time, guide recommended.. The ambience, the colours, the donkey carts, the people.......you are bombarded with a multitude of sensations as you walk through this vibrant, working market. On the edge of the market, where one feels they won't get lost, the stalls are geared mostly to the tourist but fabulously colourful nevertheless. If you have a guide who knows this vast area well you can explore further and see where the locals shop. Highly recommended.

The Old World. We were fortunate to stay in a riad behind the walled city of the Medina of Marrakech. It is truly a step back in time, but this part of the city makes you vibrate. Be prepared for a bit of testosterone overload. The streets are overloaded with young males in groups congregated, chatting and just being male. I can feel threatening to some women, but I felt thoroughly safe the entire while. However, the one thing that is disconcerting is that they are really serious about not having their pictures taken without permission. You may be confronted if you do so!

A must!. In my opinion you have to visit the (old) medina if you go to Marrakech, if not you could just as well go anywhere else. The new medina has many good restaurants and night clubs, but nothing you wouldn't see somewhere else. The old medina is something special about Marrakech. It's full of people, sights, wares, sounds and smells, and I've seen nothing like it. At the same time you have to consider that the place is full of pestering peddlers, people giving good advice (that they will ask paid for), scooters (in the small and crowded streets), and that it all makes a noisy and smelly cacophony...
Keep Walking..... The medina is cool, but if you don't want to be harassed and accosted at every turn, don't make direct eye contact and only linger if you are truly interested in making a purchase.

Marrakech Medina Hassles. One good impression I had was that the medina is a main buying area for Moroccans, not merely a tourist attraction. However, this ancient area is difficult to navigate due to shop owner excessive aggressiveness including night time restaurant hawkers. There is no such thing as 'just looking' or comparative price shopping you may be accustomed to back home. You are greeted you as you pass each shop in an attempt to get you to come into a stall. If you step in the owner now expects you to buy. All the high pressure antics took the leisure and pleasure out of shopping for me. The quality of the goods ranges from low to mediocre. Prices are never marked, the bartering is harrowing. After one purchase at an agreed upon price the seller was visibly annoyed, making me very uncomfortable! I disliked the whole game. I feel with most purchases I way overpaid for junk. It is impossible to establish fair market value. Guaranteed: whatever you buy you will see somewhere else for less. Frustrating. If you can tolerate all this perhaps your experience will be better than mine. Trying to discreetly take photos often raised ire, even if I just wanted a shot of a shop. I would never visibly point my camera at someone. One time I was taking a photo of a sales cart and the owner began berating me. Lucky for me a passing tour Moroccan guide intervened and smoothed the situation over but I was still left with a very bad feeling. Turns out the cart owner wanted me to ask permission and charge me for the opportunity! I feel merchants were not good ambassadors for their country. All the games and inveigling and constant badgering became tiring. My one week experience there left me very dissatisfied. My best tactics, which I recommend, were to never make eye contact with a shop owner, walk by quickly enough to see the goods, ignore all comments and stop in only when you are ready to purchase or have the fortitude to walk away impervious to the pressure. Twice locals helped negotiate a fair price for me. Local residents were always friendly and helpful.It is very difficult to know if you are buying genuine made in Morocco vs made in China. Be wary.I have traveled in many third world countries experiencing comfort, mutual respect absent of the hassles I encountered throughout my three week stay in this country.

Must see. Maze like small streets, very narrow confusing and smelly. They look all the same. Sometimes it's hard to find street signs. And it's easy to get lost. There are lots of spice and handicraft shops. Some vendors are pushy. I loved this medina experience! It's very interesting! You cannot miss it!

Something to experience.. On first impression the Medina seems confusing and a bit intimidating. But you soon get the logic of the place and it is actually quite easy to walk around. It quite fascinating in its hustle and bustle and then when you enter the Riad all is quiet and peaceful.

No just doesn't seem to work. The Medina is a must visit and to visit Marrakech and not visit both during the day and at night would be a real shame.But be prepared for a lot of attention, the minute you arrive and before you get to the Medina itself you will almost certainly be offered a dozen taxis home!Regardless where you are staying the big red tourist bus seems the easiest and hassle free way to see the sights. A two day ticket is about £12 and you can jump on and off at all the sights of Marrakech.From the bus stop wander into the Medina , past the snake charmers, be prepared if your camera comes out so does their hat for payment. The spice and fruit stalls are next and stunning.Becareful in the Souk, during the day I have never felt in danger, smart travellers sense and you will be fine, what I am meaning is if they spot you make eye contact with a product or display they are not good at taking No for an answer or even a dozen No'sI found the better quality shirts and goods in the small shops surrounding the Souk and I bought some wonderful quality cotton shirts that remind of some very expensive shirts I bought in Selfridges.Now nighttime and the Medina transforms, food stalls, pop up restaurants fill the place.....it is great.With one massive downside, the guys trying to drag you in with "just look at the menu" can get quite rude and almost aggressive not quite threatening but enough to really peeve.However we found a gem in Sim at Chez Sim, he made us laugh entertained us and we promised we would be back and he wished us on our way with our smile. After being hassled by a dozen restaurants we said he simply had to go back to Chez Sim as they had been so nice....... well worth it, tomato salsas, stunning cous cous and I had a pile of delicious Lamb Chops.....washed down with a Sprite and a Coke, the Medina is obviously dry.If you visit the Medina at night visit Chez Sim
worth a visit. It is nice to walk around the medina with its friendly neighbourhoods. careful not to be taken in by a few people who try to lead you the wrong way but it is mainly safe.

Morocco must-see. The Medina is why we travel - tourists from all over the world, locals, the exotic and the familiar, all in one place. Granted, I felt very secure and safe with my Moroccan son-in-law in tow, but I never felt threatened except by the cobras. You haven't been to Morocco unless you visit a medinah, and this one is as good as it gets.

Excellent area to wonder around. Wonder around the souks and other shops/markets and tast the Marrakesh'life. don't bother finding directions: just walk around to the next sqaure. Do not forget to get a coffee on a roof-tip terrace every few hours.

Fascinating but Mopeds Should be Banned. This is a fascinating place to visit with its Medina, history, culture and multitude of great restaurants to sample. At first sight the Medina can appear to be scruffy, at times an awful conglomeration but always full of life, colour and that real sense of what Morocco is all about.We visited in December for 10 days and warmed to the place very quickly. You have to get over the poverty and squalor that lie behind the Medina because then you can see a proud people with a history and vibrancy that is enchanting. This is a devout Muslim country and you will find there are some restaurants that do not serve alcohol. Open signs of affection are frowned upon and most of the mosques are closed to non Muslims. There are hosts of vendors in small kiosks or shops in the Medina offering their wares which range from wood carvings to ornate silver décor for the most extravagant of homes. We bought some beautiful wooden tissue boxes made from lemon tree and cedar to the most intricate design. See below.Whilst the international hotels are located in the modern (French built) area of the city outside the old city walls, there are literally thousands of small hotels or Riads in the Medina. If you want to experience the real Marrakech this is the area to stay in. There are prices to suit everyone and it can cost as little as £20 a night right up to £200 or more. A feature of most Riads and indeed many restaurants is that what looks like an innocuous door or façade, opens up to reveal a palatial interior. See my review of Le Coq Berbere.Walking through the Medina can be a bit daunting. You will be regularly stopped and encouraged into a shop or a ‘helpful’ guide will take it upon himself to explain where everything is in the Medina. This usually ends up in you being taken to a shop to buy something. They all have to make a living I suppose but it can be a bit irritating. Be polite but firm if you are approached and just say no thank you. The other point to make is that there is a constant flow of donkeys, bikes, mopeds and sometimes cars in the narrow streets of the Medina. By far the worst are the moped riders, some of whom drive way too fast in such a confined space. They come at you from all angles and expect you to get out of the way. You have to get used to the fumes as well because most of the Medina is covered and the moped fumes just hang in a blue pall, so pollution is quite bad. That’s the bad side of things but they are far outweighed by the attractions of the Medina itself.Eventually you will make your way to Place Jemma El Fna, the massive square in Marrakech where traders, storytellers and all manner of people gather to ply their trade. In daytime it is less well populated with mainly fruit sellers and juice makers plus the odd snake charmer and dancer. Beware! If you so much as point a camera in their direction, they will pester you for money and some I saw get quite irate with a tourist who didn’t want to contribute. At night there are stalls selling spices, street food, clothes, shoes, toys and all manner of tourist gifts. If you want to dine al fresco with the locals and you like fish, go to stall number 14 where you can order fish and vegetables for just a few Dirham, eat with your hands and be given a piece of kitchen roll to clean up. It’s quite an experience. There are numerous bars overlooking the square with roof top balconies that let you see the panoply of activity below. It is well worth doing. Travelling around Marrakech is best done by the Petite Taxis, small usually run down old bangers that are relatively cheap. You do need to agree a price for your destination but it is so obvious you are a tourist and I’m afraid like many tourist cities you will be charged a tourist price. We proved this by sharing a taxi with a local and the journey was only 9 dirham whereas the same journey the previous day had cost 70 dirham or about £6. It’s still cheap but not as cheap as the locals get it.Bartering in the souks and Medina shops generally is expected. If you want to buy wooden handicraft or indeed any handicrafts try asking for advice on where to go from your Riad manager. We were introduced to a carpenter who was a real find. My wife and I bought four highly decorative wooden boxes from him which originally started at around £150 but ended up at less than half that price. This was not before the owner had told us all about his shop, his sons, his wider family, his love of his work as a carpenter how he had met the king of Morocco, the various qualities of each wood he used and of course the cup of mint tea we were offered, a trademark of Moroccan hospitality. All this took around an hour and was really as much fun as the actual buying. There is an open top bus service which costs around £10 each but takes you round all the main sites of Marrakech and you can get on and off at the various stops all day long. There is commentary in 6 languages including English although the sound system on our bus was not working properly because people kept changing seats to plug into the audio system at different points. There are numerous museums and sights worth seeing in Marrakech. Well worth visiting is the Dar Si Said Museum near the Palais Bahia. It has some fascinating exhibits and beautiful designs on ceilings and walls that are worth the visit just for those alone.The Medina does take some getting used to and it is very easy to get lost. Eventually you get familiar with certain routes and if you do get lost it doesn’t take long to get back on track. You can always ask a local but see my comments above. One man we asked was a teacher and happy to guide us back on to the main street when we got lost without expecting any tip or take us to a shop. Overall, Marrakech is a fascinating experience and well worth the visit. Hopefully our experiences will help others to enjoy it as much as we did.

More than just tourism. Yes, of course, all in the Medina is about tourists, but if you take your time to walk around without prejudice you will have the chance to make amazing cultural discoveries. Avoid coming in big groups, intimacy is much better here
Everybody is there!. You can find all the typical food there, plus during the dai you can see snakes and monkeys all the traditional things in one place

Vibrant, in-your-face and amazing!. Love the atmosphere and vibe! Be open-minded and accepting of different ways of living. You will get pestered to spend money in the Soukes - despite this sometimes being a bit overbearing initially - the humour and friendliness of the shop/stall holders is great - but it's a game you must be prepared to pay when you visit. The Jemma el Fna square is fascinating and full of character whether you go during the day or after dark. However - beware - if you take pics of the 'attractions' you will be expected to pay. I have no problem with this - the majority of people there are going about their daily business and must feel like zoo animals. We took 13 year old twin girls - they attracted alot of attention from the young men, Essential too keep a close eye on young females and give strong "leave well alone" messages when necessary however the attention was only verbal and pretty much not too far outside of what is considered appropriate. Go, take care and enjoy this fabulous city!

Challenging. The Medina is something you have to brace yourself for. It is very large and much of the stalls carry the same items. Walking through you can expect every few feet for someone to ask you to visit their shop in one way or other. We were also waylaid by a youth who told us the way forward was "closed for mosque" and he would show us another way. We kept going and he yelled at us and sped off. (It was not closed).
Fun fair.. Wonderful old square with lots of shops and restaurants, though it's bit risky to eat there. Also keep away from the initially friendly fake guides monkey and snake charmers
Just for the experience. But things are not cheap and the locals don't like to be photographed. They expect money for photos taken

break in the medina. Good place to have a coffee or tea, be prepared to get hassled by friendly locals, but beware of young people trying to show you the way round the medina, they take you for a 10 minute walk, just to place you back where you stated from to justify their donation guide fee, better steer away from them.

Polarising. Girlfriend/Me:It's beautiful/it's crap, there's so much to explore/it's all exactly the same, I love it here/I can't wait to leave.I love haggling and bargaining/I feel constantly harassed and pressured, there's so much cool stuff to buy/it's mass-produced colossally overpriced pish for gullible westerners, the monkeys are cute/I just saw one bite a woman.The villa [amira] is nice/the villa is beautiful and the staff are wonderful, the street food is good/the street food IS good, it's an experience/it certainly is.I'm so glad we came/as am I, but I'm never coming back.
experience at leisure. Sit above in a cafe get a drink and watch the madness its an amazing site and worth doing either night or day
Mystical.. It's probably the most mystical place I've ever been after India. The coffee shops, old souk, little squares, the old raids and shops.Lots of history.

Make sure you get an accredited Guide to take you round!. Busy - hectic - like going back hundreds of years. The night market was a complete assault on the senses - performing monkeys, snake charmers, 'dentists' that pull teeth with pliers, even a vulture to put round your neck for a photo opportunity,if you're so inclined... Loved it all, but keep a hand on your belongings especially at night when young pickpockets work the streets and ladies, be aware that men often rub past you and 'accidentally' touch your bottom, so keep a male friend close by or wear baggy clothes.

Enough of a good thing. Well you have to do it to absorb the sights and sounds. Spices, donkeys, slippers and all. After a while it gets a bit much unless you are looking for something specific. The constant assault on all the senses - especially the motorbiles weaving in and out of the pedestrians - can be wearing. Just remember that's why you came.

Like Going Back in Time. It would be a great opportunity to wander aimlessly; but a willing and expectant guide is never far away! Directions from locals flow freely to tanneries, their brother's shop etc. And if you politely decline the offer it only defers the moment - every 100 metres a new guide will appear! But it is an amazing place and experience.

Terrible place. Nothing there some odd snake monkeys and dirty people. Beggars and food tough by every hand Go around the old city get yourself a licence guide and a proper riad and hotel Eat in good restaurants not expence

lovely. a very nice city interesting for me it was my kind of place but I could see why it not for all but it is great the way it is and has been since time,love it all there is nothing that was not pleasant people helpful a few beggar's about but they are not pushy,

get yourself a private tour guide. We had been o the medina before and promised ourselves that if we returned we would do this tour again and we did. Having our own tour guide was well worth the expense as he took us to the places we wanted to see. Throughout the tour Ali was very attentive to our needs and questions about the place. We learned a lot from Ali about the Berbers, their culture and what this medina means to the Berber people now and in days gone by. This was a wonderful way to spend an afternoon.

AMUSANTE. You have to fight for every price. Sometimes you discover that the price requested is 10 times more than what should be.Sometimes is quite honest. So it is difficult to understand.I bought a leather puff starting from 5000 DH, I offer 1000DH and finally I pay 2200DH.The day after I went in Governement artisanal complex and the price fix was 650DH!!If you are looking for Cosmetics go to Certified BIO produits. In Morocco there is NO law to protect customers, you can write anything you like on a bottle and put inside water or mais oil! Ask for taxi price before any service: petit taxi are bet 30/50DH, normal taxi are 100 DH and 200 DH the night. Wash you shoes as soon you arrive home. If you are looking for furniture ,iron job , deco items go to Souk Bab Lakhmis-Close on friday.

Its like Marmite - love it or hate it!. The Medina is a bit like Marmite and I love it. Nothing beats just wandering around, checking out all the nooks and crannies and just letting yourself get lost. Large parts are aimed at tourists (folks are just trying to earn a living like everyone else) but you wil also come across parts that are clearly for locals going about their day to day business.Just take it all in your stride, be polite, smile and just walk away if you feel you are being harrassed. And always haggle with a smile :-) Yes it can be a bit hassley and if you don't really like the hassle of haggling there is a artesian complex just a short walk away from the square where prices are fixed and you won't get any hassle and its also a good place to check out prices if you do want to nab a bargain in the medina at the going rate. Enjoy!
loved it. Just loved everything about it , the locals, the way of life , the market , the atmosphere . Wish I was back there

Very Chaotic. It interesting to visit a different culture and a city that old, but is a chaos, a lot of vehicles to be aware, noisy, dirty, and a lot of young moroccans trying to get advantage of you.

The Medina. Certainly an experience, although not always a good one. Beware being told ‘it is closed that way’ or something similar, which is used to channel you towards awaiting shop keepers. If staying in the Medina I’d suggest being on the western side if possible, so you can easily dip out of the chaos more easily. Ben Youssef Medersa is fairly limited in what it has to offer, yet well worth a visit, whereas the Marrakech Museum is less rewarding of your time.

Crazy, but so amazing!. We were very overwhelmed by the sellers trying to get money off you, but after a while you get into the flow and becoming more firm is one of our new skills!It is an experience to do, some people will not like it.. Others will love it, like did we!

Parasites. Unfortunately if you are of a western/European look you are immediately target by numerous morroc morons who with a friendly smile and sadly only one intention, to relive you of some cash..They approach and say you know me I'm from the hotel to make you feel at ease then take you to a shop to try to extract cash from you this happens within minutes of you looking for your accommodation if not shortly after, for me and my partner all it made us was unable to spend any time looking at goods as we felt like victim's rather than welcome tourist..We will never come back.

Just walk, get lost, walk more.. Cleaner than some! Atmospheric. Felt safe. You will get lost. You will find yourself again - or pay a hustler to guide you! Don't listen to the hustlers who will guide you straight into their cousin's carpet shop etc.

Full off overpriced tat. Go off the beaten track if you get lost use the satalite dishes to get back they point towards the big square. if you dont want to barter go to the artisian store south of the city where prices are fixed and 15-20% cheaper than the Medina

Shopping and People watching. An amazing mix of covered and uncovered traders selling food, jewellery, clothing, rugs, shoes - everything. There are people who will try to rip you off but if you're streetwise you can spot them a mile off. You will be expected to haggle and barter - its all part of the experience. If you don't want to buy something show NO INTEREST and don't make eye contact. You should take plenty of dirham because I guarantee you there is something for everyone.

Worth the time!. As others have said, most folks either love or hate the Medina. As a family of four with two teens, we were split. The kids were really intimidated by everyone trying to get their attention and the persistence of many of the sellers to get us to us to buy something from them. The adults loved it as there was a huge variety of things to see and people to watch. We went both during the day and in the evening and if you can only go once, I would suggest going in the evening and making night of it. There is plenty of things to see, the food is great, and the atmosphere is crazy. It can be overwhelming to the senses and if you don't have a sense of adventure it might be too much but you should at least stop by and see it for yourself.

Chaotic but fun once you get the hang of it. This place can be hectic and full of pressure but once you realize that you have the cash and you stick to your guns on a price, it can be achieved. If you are not happy with the deal, just walk away. Start low and go up a bit... The souks will try to snowball you will an outrageous price. Think to yourself would I pay this price back home? If so, you are paying too much for it... you should be able to get some deals.The market is a truly crazy place but fun! Lastly, don't accept crap from people like putting henna on your hand when you didn't ask for it and then demanding money for their poor children. This situation is crap and just get loud and tell them 'NO!'

Lost and Found. The Medina is such an amazing experience! The sights, smells, sounds around you are unbelievable! We never thought we'd find our way back to our riad because the twists and turns of the streets are so confusing! Shopping in the souks was quite the experience! Nothing has a price on it and everyone wants to sell you something. Loved seeing the snake charmers in the square...it's something you read about since you're a little kid and to see it in real life is quite the experience!
You Have to Visit the Medina!. Others have said it all. However, I do believe it's a must, love it or hate it! Step back in time and savour it all.

Take a guide as you will get lost guaranteed!. Very expensive compared to China (pashmina $8 in china and $20 in Marrakech). Europe is struggling financially so it is showing in the Marrakesh prices. Lots of rugs, pillows, silver jewellery and heaps of imitation bags, sunglasses and sand shoes. Their hand made leather slippers were very unique. 1 day is more than enough in the old town. I wouldn't take small children to Marrakech due to sanitary conditions or eat salads or fruit.

If you get lost, ask a shopkeeper. I loved it, but then I like being in a place where things haven't changed much for hundreds of years. If you get directed by 'helpful' guides to a distant part of the souk and get lost, don't panic, just ask any of the shop keepers. They are helpful, polite and will tell you how to get out of the souk.

Shops and store are lovely but...... Had a whale of an experience in Medina meeting some lovely people and good bargains in the vicinity. The touting is on another level which borders on harassment but apart from that the buzzing atmosphere is a must visit area. Also let me warn you there is always a bad smell in the area where the open square is I think it is due to the poor drainage system.

300 years back.. Medina activity, views and odors are frenetic; as they may be 300 years ago, today's with the addition of cars and bikes. The ONLY aspect that could be changes is the "over use" of animals for carriage pulling and goods transportation .. animals were not created for "paved" streets .... all the rest is FINE.
Similar to Old city of Damascus. I like it, it's same as Omayyad cities, Damascus, Fes, Meknes, there must be more signs to guide visitors.

Unable to relax and enjoy it. As with a lot of North African cities, the medina of Marrakech is a sprawling, maze-like tangle of tight streets, people and wares. Where the area of the souks is the part most tourists will wander through - getting themselves utterly lost in the process - the medina itself offers a more intriguing mixture of day-to-day life. It's here that the locals shop, here that they buy their meat (from places I'd never touch), their bread and their vegetables. It's a hubbub of local culture and tourist eye candy, and where you'd be a little foolish to pick up some of the "bargains" on offer. One young man had a stack of headphones that purported to be Dr Dre Beats and was trying to tempt westerners with really low prices; none of those looking and listening to his patter stopped to wonder how he'd managed to get hold of stock that would have counted as several years worth of his basic income!Despite the filth that covers more of the ground than it should, the medina would have been a much more interesting spot but for two terrible thorns - traffic and conmen. The former wouldn't be such a big problem if it were just the donkey carters and porters, but the mopeds that drive far too quickly through the narrow alleys are a definite danger, let alone the few random idiots that opt to drive a taxi along routes that are clearly restricted. Relax for a moment and you could very easily be run down.As for the conmen, be alert. Late one evening we walked home on our usual route when a man stepped in front of us and told us the way ahead was closed. I asked why and he simply said that the mosque had closed it. He clearly picked something that most westerners would think twice about questioning before asking us where we needed to go and then offering to take us there . . . along a different route that was much darker, narrower and far less public. Luckily I had my wits about me and said "no". He objected but eventually we just walked away and went along our normal route, which was obviously open and offered no obstacles at all. Not something that solo or vulnerable travellers should have to deal with in the middle of a busy city, but it is one of those things you perhaps have to accept.A fascinating place, but not one that I will be rushing back to any time soon.

Don't get lost!!!!!. Wow!! What an experience. Go for it!! Remember where u entered and don't forget it at least have an exit strategy!!!! Very large market with so many different stalls. Think it is possible to buy anything here?!- bit u have to b prepared to haggle or get ripped off ?! Approach it with a good humour and that will be returned. Many offer to be ur guide and for about £1, that may be best money u have ever spent if you are not part of an tour group?! Fascinating stuff!!

You can always find something interesting!. There is always something intriguing and interesting to lose yourself within the medina... a little turn you find yourself in the metal works area, then the leather works...etc. You need to spend a little more time here as theres lots to see and to get to know the people and culture.

Wow! Tiring, Exhilerating, Frustrating, Breathtaking, Dirty, Is this the maddest place outside of India?. As a couple our first thought was no, we had made a mistake and didn't like it. At the end of our first day we loved it. The start of our second day we hated it again. And so the love - hate experience went on until we acclimatised to the relentless noise and trading of the Medina. For that is what you have to do, it's a culture shock at first. Centuries old methods and buildings mixed with more modern, Donkeys walk the same streets as mopeds, Touareg Saharan nomads will mix with fluent English speaking Morroccans who would do well on an EastEnd market. Everybody wants your money, take a picture someone holds their hand out, get lost, someone knows the way for a price, stand still for a second, someone is shouting for you too look at the goods, point at something and be asked to 'make a good price'...We loved it! We refused help, worked things out for ourselves, and explored safely! Of course, when every stall is similar, and every Dirham is ferociously fought after, people have no choice but to talk to you and try to get you interested in their wares - but we never felt threatened, never too hassled, and if No didn't work first time, a firmer No Thank You a second was always met graciously with a smile and 'maybe tomorrow?'We were lucky, we stayed in the No1 rated (at the time) hotel (Riad khierredene) and were given a mobile phone and the most experienced and gracious guide we have certainly met (Ismail). He advised us to always offer 20% of any asking price and pay no more than 40% as a maximum, advice that we stuck to rigidly and it worked! Ever time I shook hands and said thanks but no thanks at 40%, I was told I must be Scottish and the deal was done. it made me smile every time.Personally, I wouldn't take my kids, they are too young. Older teenagers (17+) would be mature enough to enjoy the experience - for that is what it is, however there maybe reviews here where younger children have enjoyed it. That being said, it's a great place, busy, tiring, yes... But it's not threatening, we felt safe, and it was a fantastic, fantastic experience. 1 off our bucket list. A must see place - Brilliant!

A must and not to be missed - Day or Night!. The medina has two different lives - in the day its the hussle and bussle of the souks but at night Jemaa el Fna comes to life as the shops close down with snake charmers, music and food glorious food! A experience not to be missed when in Marrakech!

Head trip!. Shopping as you have never done it before............a myriad of market stalls selling absolutely everything you could ever want and lots that you would never want! An extraordinary experience, haggle hard, smile a lot and enjoy the interaction and you are bound to go home with some real bargains alongside the inevitable what on earth was I thinking when I bought that.....! Shopping for Christmas just doesn't get to be more fun than this.

Really Interesting but Frustrating. The medina is incredible to wander around and experience medieval Morocco, but be prepared to get lost and incredibly frustrated. Maps and GPS are useless, and you will be told wrong directions and hassled a lot. Kids will offer to show you the way out, but negotiate a rate upfront - they all want money for helping you!
Full of variety. Great place to wonder around in with great variety of interesting buildings, people, food and goods on sale.

Hectic, almost overwhelming, but memorable and worth the trip. While I felt the Medina of Marrakech was wilder than Istanbul's Grand Bazaar and Cairo's Khan El Khalili, it is still worth going. I thought the major drawback here is the ubiquitousness of scooters and bicycles. Maybe the other markets I mentioned do sometimes have people riding through, I actually don't remember experiencing that at all in those other cities. In Marrakech it is the norm and it lends a chaos to the place I did not enjoy. The riders are not at all courteous to walkers: it's up to you to look out for them and their near constant honks. If you can adjust, I suppose it's an amazing place.The touts weren't necessarily aggressive, and some were very friendly, but there was some real rudeness displayed. Sometimes after a full day in the souks, the traveler gets a little run down and cannot politely decline every offer... we actually were screamed at once for not responding to a tout, which I found a bit offensive as we were just walking by, minding our own business on our way back. That said, plenty of shop owners were kind and did not mind us taking photos (I learned quickly to ask permission first) or just watching their craftsmanship. I made a few purchases that were priced so low I didn't bother bargaining and that seemed fine with all parties involved. Stop in to the vegan Earth Cafe for a delicious meal or get some fresh fruit juice from one of the many stands.This is a place of extremes.. people lovely and awful, smells fabulous and gross, sights pleasing and distressing. All in all, an enriching experience of a very foreign culture.

so atmospheric. mopeds whiz around, men whisper in your ear 'hashish' hustle bustle, old narrow streets, carts, scent of wood smoke, the call to prayer. all kinds of things for sale.loved the place and the sights and the smells.also not as much hassles as we'd been led to believe.just keep your wits about you and you'll be fine.it is like something from Arabian nights !

beggars and annoying hustlers everywhere. as soon as we entered the medina an man put a snake around my neck then demand i pay him for the privilage...the medina is not a place to relax and enjoy...constantly on guard for pick pockets and con men

Contradiction in terms. Staying in the old Medina was such a wonderful experience for me. People living in close proximity to each other. Children playing in the streets unsupervised. Neighbours talking to each other across the lanes yet at night time it is so quiet you can hear a pin drop. Incredible.
a pleasant labirinth. Many shops with local artisans, nice walk in a colourful labirinth whre, as usual, each seller push you inside its shop

Shop until you drop. Amazing shopping with all the fun of paying what you think the item is worth. The sellers are full of fun and love to negotiate. The sights and smells of the street food are phenomenal. There is never a dull moment right up until 9:30 p.m. at night. An absolute must if you want to experience the culture and hustle and bustle of the souks and Marrakech
overload. amazing, noisy, fascinating, scary, like an exotic dream. unlike anything i have seen before. I think i liked it.

Very busy, hustle and bustle, hustle & bustle everywhere!. lots of shops selling anything from carpets, key chains to clothes and lots of food & drink stands. Near the middle you get snake charmers and monkey trainers. They normally try to bring you in for a picture and expect some money after. I was warned that the monkeys are trained to steal from you so be aware. Good highlight to visit, friendly people and nice to observe your surroundings. Only downside is some people can have very aggressive selling tactics and a lot of the shops sell the same things. And a lot of beggars.

Beautiful place with too much traffic. We stayed in the medina in a wonderful riad and enjoyed the food, sights, sounds, and smells, but the traffic was awful. The motorcycles and cars should be restricted and not allowed in the narrow souq streets as it is very dangerous. Many times we thought we might be run over!
Crowded. Huge selection of things to buy but very crowded place. We went with a tour from our accommodation, locals also shop there too
What Marrakech is all about. Hustle, bussle, culture, food, souks, brilliant architecture, winding streets - if you're coming to Marrakech, you need to plan a lot of your trip around the Medina.

Sensory Overload. What a great experience. The square has snake charmers and "monkey jumpers" and open air restaurants. In the medina you can easily get overwhelmed by the narrow aisles between the rows of shops that just keep going. Eventually you will find your way back to the square but in the meantime you can find ALL sorts of clothing, spices or hardware to tempt your bargaining skills.Two useful tips: "Than Shoof " - means I'm just looking. "Lah" - means no thank you. These two will help you from being pestered by shopkeepers eager for a sale. Saying "Salaam" as a greeting and "Mas Salaam" as a goodbye is just plain common courtesy and will help you have a great visit.

More space, same hustle. This medina seems "roomier" than those in Rabat, Fez and Casablanca, with the large square and roads coming through multiple gates. However, the quality of merchandise is about the. Same: one has to hunt for well-made items, and run a constant gauntlet of importune vendors.
busy busy!. Wow what an experience, fantastic experience. Visit the souks for some bartering, but stand your ground, they like to get a good price!
Medina - ordinary. The Medina was a large area of alleyways and shops and hammams - and you were lucky if you were not run over by a bike or a horse. Nothing special

Unique Experience. Although at first it might feel a bit crowded which might make you feel uncomfortable, eventually we really enjoyed the experience in the Medina which felt very unique especially when haggling. Most of the time you can get an item at 1/3 of the price they initially ask for. Beware of 'guides' who tend to be helpful at first in showing you the way to a specific place however they will ask you for money afterwards apart from the fact that they will probably take you through a longer route.

A nice tranquil escape from the traffic of the city. A very nice tranquil garden. Well worth the 5 Euros admission price for each person.There are walking paths through the bamboo, trees, fountains. It is very peaceful on the inside. Lots of good opportunities for photos. Inside the gardens is a very high quality souvenir shop as well as a nice outdoor restaurant.

Very crowded and unpleasant. It's dirty, smelly and crowded. Yes, walking through the Medina is a memory for life but don't expect to see anything beautiful. And traffic, mainly mopeds is terrible. In short, go there, look arround and get the hell out

A must visit but takes some getting used to. Having never travelled anywhere even remotely like Marrakech before, the Medina was an enormous culture shock for me. It's nothing like anywhere I've ever been before and my initial impression was just 'madness.'The medina is very busy at almost every hour of the day. It is crowded, noisy and smelly (sometimes good, sometimes bad!), there are bikes, motorbikes, taxis and donkeys pulling carts everywhere and not on any particular side of the road, so DO beware of traffic. As far as we saw, they won't crash into you - they know what they're doing - so don't stop/play chicken with them, just keep going and be aware of who's moving where around you.Locals in the medina LOVE tourists. Tourists are where they make their money. If you need to look at a map, try and do so discreetly as you will be inundated with offers of guides if you show off that you are lost. DON'T go with a guide unless they have been arranged for you by your Riad. The street guides are pushy for money, and while most are harmless, are more likely to get you lost, taking you to small squares and shops where they can get commission rather than where you actually want to go. We made the mistake of using a guide, gave him 100 dirhams, and he harassed us for more quite unpleasantly - not a mistake we made again!Women should dress respectably as the culture in old-city Marrakech still requires many women to wear full burkha and headscarf, so short skirts/shorts and low cut tops will draw unwanted attention to you. Also expect stares if you are blonde - things that make you different attract attention!If you want to buy something, look around at a few places to get prices. When you have an idea of how much it is widely sold for, go for it. DO haggle. We found that most traders were not offended if we offered them half their initial price, and if you start to walk away, they will lower the price even more. NEVER offer more than you are willing to pay. And don't waste their time - don't start to haggle over something you're never going to buy.The medina is beautifully rich with local food and crafts, and is a wonderful place to just walk around and take in the sights. While it can be intimidating to get the attention of every trader you walk past to begin with, they are (from my experience) harmless and are jsut trying to make a sale. Once you get used to where you should be going and work out how to navigate the medina, it's much less intimidating. If you ignore the shouts of traders and other overly-interested locals, they will more often not give up straight away - tourists are good for them and the last thing they want is to get a bad reputation for scaring them away. After a couple of days, you will relax and feel more used to the medina. Then you can really enjoy it and take in the culture and sights.

Must See Marrakech. I have been in Marrakech for about 5 days and I fell in love with the Medina. It's markets, street vendors, juice stands, spice stands burning incense...a thousand lights lit to show their beautiful lanterns. I visited the Medina in Marrakech again tonight and will go back again tomorrow before I return home. It's crowded, it's a bit chaotic and its a jumble of sights, sounds and smells...but somehow my trip to Marrakech wouldn't have been the same without it.

Well worth a visit. Took a guided tour of the labyrinth of the medina ending up in Jemaa el Fna. We started from the outer medina walls and passed through the various sections of the medina which we would not have found on our own, tanneries, bakers, lighting, much to see and very hectic. Well worth paying for a tour.Once in the Jemaa el Fna we were treated to a sweet tea in a cafe overlooking the square and Marrakech. The square was being transposed ready for the evening, very busy location but worth the visit.Time to view and barter the vast array of stalls and find some bargains.

Haggle is the Name of the Game!. The Medina is smaller than the one in Fes and far easier to navigate on your own, and if you want to buy cheap locally made crafts and goods than this is the place. The second the seller see you he or she will know that you are a foreigner and that means to them to you are as wealthy as Bill Gates. The price they give will usually by doubled, tripled or even quadrupled compared to what a local will pay. Now how do you get down to paying the local price or as close as possible to it, this is where haggling comes into play! When you ask the price carefully look for flaws and damage to bring your price down, next take the given price and divide by two and work around that new number. Try to go lower far lower until they do not want to sell it to you. When the seller is so annoyed and angry that they don't want to sell it to you any longer then that is when you have found the local price. This wont always work because you are a foreigner and therefore have money according to local logic, so shop around and don't buy the first one you see as the possibility that the same exact thing is just around the corner at a different price.

It's a zoo but hey -- who wants a Rodeo Drive clone?. The unfamiliar smells, the intense shop keepers, the mini mountains of spices, the unique restaurants tucked away in upstairs locations, the monkey in the square, the watermen who smilingly pose for photos and then demand money from you, the men loitering in alleyways -- this is the experience of the Medina, and the reason you just weren't happy on Rodeo Drive.

Excellent fun. Excellent fun finding out what Marrakech is all about.You have to explore the alleyways and souks, enjoy haggling with the traders, hear all sounds, smell all the smells.You're bound to get lost but don't worry that's part of the fun :)
Fabulous. What a place, the atmosphere is amazing. Cant describe it properly - you just must visit. Throw yourself into the whole experience. Enjoy

Just go in, get lost and enjoy!. Really crazy, smelly, busy, vibrant, historic place. You just have to go in and get lost - there are many signs directing you back to the main square so you cannot go wrong. You do get hassled but a firm but polite 'no thank you' does the trick and they leave you alone. We did not feel intimidated at all. Only start to barter if you are serious about buying, ask for a price and offer about a third you should in general pay about half of what they originally asked for.

Depends what you enjoy. Perhaps I had an overly romanticized expectation but I was quite disappointed. The medina is a dirty and crowed area and quite intimidating. We are not inexperienced travelers and have been to souks in both Turkey and Egypt. I was accosted by a woman who grabbed my arm and despite my objections forced a cheap bangle onto my wrist saying it was a gift. When I kept walking she then approached my husband aggressively trying to sell another.
