Contrary to better judgement, and because of the pressure he gave her 50 dhs. to go away and still she badgered us for more. This was a most unpleasant experience.Many of the souks had similar wares and it is impossible to look around without constant chatter from a vendor trying to instigate bartering on anything your eyes paused on. They would put things in baskets if any interest was shown saying that they would make a good price when you are done. Not at all enjoyable to me. I had planned to visit the souks several times but once was more than enough.

everyone wants a cut. This is where Moroccans come to exploit tourists. Especially avoid vendors who put on Brummie or Jamaican accents to charm you into their food stalls, as you will be disappointed. Everything in the markets is a rip off. My wife bought slippers for £30 which in hindsight would have cost her £5 in primark. We got stung on clothes generally because of failure to carry a calculator and check what we were actually paying. There is no magic in this place. its just noisy and full of people who want something back from the tourists to reimburse them for previous colonial subservience. Its pretty safe to say Moroccan's aren't thieves, and its rare to experience crime, but they are all Hustlers who want a cut.

The maddest place on earth. This has got to be the most mental place ever, and I thought Vegas was mad - this beats it hand down.We went in late afternoon and had a potter around the streets and Medina, most of the shops are the same and sell the same things - don't worry about getting lost - you don't really - you always end up back at the square. It was amazing when the sun went down - it turned into the maddest place with all the noise and smells - just amazing. A have to go at least once.

It is nice place. It is nice area, maybe because i am Egyptian i am not surprised because we have similar places in Cairo but i can say that pepole are really kind and maybe you have to watch every bil you pay and go in long process with the sales man to buy something but over all they are polit and kind.Resturants are nice and prices are affordable but my exprience is that eating in the street is really good, clean and tasty, it makes me feel with the locals life.Over all the area is live and nice

Touristy spot. After having been to the Medina of Fes (very nice, more authentic) and the Medina of Essaouira (colorful), I found this Medina not too attractive. You still need a guide to be able to see what is worth seeing, however there are so many tourists that you lose the authenticity. Roads are large, while there are good opportunities for shopping (particularly metal work). I found the Medina of Fes much more interesting and an experience to make. My experience is to buy carpets/rugs and definetely pottery in Fes and wood work in Essaouira. Marrakech I find it more for metal work and pottery. However, if you want a less touristy experience, don't spend time here.

True Marrakech. This is the real Marrakech. Lots of noise, smells and people. It did feel a bit intimidating at night in places. Stay alert for locals on bikes as half of them don't use lights or the roads! Keep your wits about you and enjoy!
this is what you go to marrakech for!. this is why we visit Marrakech - not because there are loads of Disney type attractions but because you can see real history, real people and real lives

Colorful. The garden has vibrant colours that make a beautiful scenery to your pictures. It also has a lot of beautiful different cactus. It is very quiet, a place to relax, once you can listen to the birds singing. It worth the visit.

Too busy for me. We visited the Madina both during the day and at night and we didn't have the best experience. The medina smells of horse manure and was full of flies, it is rather dirty for my liking. During the day was much better, there was less hustle and bustle and people seem a little bit more relaxed although we had someone beg me to take a picture of them then tried charging me €2 (23dh) I refused to pay them and they got a abusive throwing money at me. Some of the locals are really funny but as I said take them with a pinch of salt because it is all for money. Although it was cheaper at night (from our experience) the night was pretty scary for me. As a young lady I felt a little on edge with my camera and other personal belongings. It was also heartbreaking seeing 3 year olds begging for money and food.There are snake charmers, monkey holders, henna ladies and all they want is your money, you can try take sly pictures but beware! They will abuse you if you don't give them the money they want. Don't kiss the snakes or monkeys, it don't bring good luck it will bring you to a toilet with a bad guts ache! My honest advice would be to keep your wits about you and trust no one, all they want is your money. Make sure you haggle for anything you want, a bag I wanted started at over 600dh and we got them down to 200dh, we could have got it less but that was what I wanted to pay.
Very exciting!. A very bustling area of Marrakech (we stayed in Kesbah which is in the south of the medina) and lots to see and do. Loads of shops, cafés, restaurants and obviously the souks!

Intersting to see. Easy place to wander about - just keep calm - remember "la la shukran" (no thank you)and you will be fine. Do be careful of mopeds without lights at night and also the Donkey carts dont stop as easily!

Mad, crazy, vibrant, exciting - yeah I liked it....a lot. Lots of people, noise and colour: "Ahh - watch out for that horse and cart, and the lad on the scooter.... no I don't want orange juice or a henna tattoo, eh, what's that - a snake?!! Is that a monkey?!"Don't expect a pedestrianised area, everything and anything goes and it is brilliant, watch the sun go down at one of the surrounding balconies before deliving into the throng of activity. Doesn't sound like you're cup of tea, then why are you coming to Marrakech??
Cacophony of everything. Amazing colourful variety and some very good quality handmade items. Endless - wear comfortable shoes.

Total madness but exciting. We were suffering the English weather blues, so much rain followed by a cold winter, started to make me believe that I had developed SAD syndrome. A quick look at holiday destinations within a 4 hour reasonably priced flight with temperatures in the mid 20's C came up with Marakeche.The Medina is an area within the very old walled city and consists of a high walled labarintine arrangement of very narrow alleys where traders thrust their goods at you and try and entice you into the often tiny shops, you really do have to haggle, but we found them to be polite and often of great humour.The Medina opens out onto a huge Square where you will need at the very least a good cup of mint tea at one of the high level cafe.Two tips I wouldn't advise women to do the medina on their own at night it can be a little intimidating, but I'm sure there's a lot of ladies out there who have and had a great time, be firm and polite when haggling, do some research so you what you should pay, we loved the carpets but the number knots involved in the making is all and a mirical oil for skin rejeuvanation called Argan Huile (even comes in an edible version) is fantastic and cheap hear as it is locally grown, ask a tour guide to show you the goats up in the Argan nut trees....crazy.

Hustle and Bustle!. A real experience and very different at night. The Medina at night is a lot busier than during the day, with many more food stalls in particular. You will be encouraged to eat at all of the food stalls, but just take your time and have a wander around - many of the locals eat at the Medina so prices are not excessive at all, but be careful of some double pricing (one for you and one for locals!) Don't be surprised if a snake is placed around your neck, and you are then encouraged to take a photo - you will be asked for money after this, no surprise. Worth visiting day and night for 2 different experiences.
Nice medina. Interesting Medina. I was there during the EID holliday, so it became even more interesting , though the stores were closed ( I returned the next day). a Horsecart drive is worth it.

Fun place to visit. A must in Marrakesh, you must be ready to take a million pictures and to bargain with all vendors, they love doing that and it looks like it´s their favorite sport. Better early in the morning.

Medina. An experience......and absolute must. Don't bother with a guide. Just emmer se yourself in the wonder of the old town. People are very friendly and never intimidating. Beware looking lost as you will get plenty of friendly guides looking to lead you home.

Wonderful for walking. The wall around the Medina is approximately 23km, so you probably won't see half of it. Just remember there are many things to see and do outside the Medina walls, so don't limit yourself, get out there and explore!
Great. Each and every little alley has its own adventure and its own stamina..After visiting the well known, let your feet lead you to the unbeaten spots..make it your own discovery..

Amazing but a little mad!!. First and foremost, this was a safe and comfortable experience and we were not jostled by stall holders who more frequently invited us to 'look for free'. Sadly, items on sale were not generally of interest, but the experience was huge fun and the 'big' square unforgettable (particularly at night) with snakes, monkeys, reptiles, henna painting, many bands and so many stalls to eat at. A complete 'must' when visiting Marakesh.

Market of the markets. If you looking to buy something, or if you want something, but you have no ideia what to buy, you are at the right place (or many many places, because its 800 to 900 little streets) with any kind of vendors, and any kind of merchandise. I even found a place where old tires are transform to clothes !!? Always negotiate with them, sometimes they want only to negotiate to keep you busy. Enjoy your shopping !!!

A different experience. When we went to the medina, we already knew it- we needed a different way of looking for the diferent cultur. That is essential to do, when we look for the meat shops, with lots of flies around the meat...There are other things to look, llike the diferent colours and smells for the spices, the very beautiful and colourful tissues.Shopping there is a dificult thing, if we do not want to discuss prices - they always ask first for an high price, so that we deal with them to a price that it is always an half or less the first price.Be carefully when you take a cab, discuss first the price, and do not acept to be taken to another destination than that one you intend, or you will found you at a berbere pharmacy, doing shops you do not want at a high price - be firm.

You have to visit it. Medina of Marrakech is a must see place. It contains small streets full of chaos and noises and a lot of things to buy. I personally don't like to get stuff from such places but it's important to visit the Medina. Be very careful which restaurant to choose though.

visit. Obviously lively.10 Dirham (75p) will allow you to take a photo of the snake charmers,the snakes do not do a lot.Monkey vendors did not give a lot of hassle.If you wish to buy somethinging in the souks,they now seem to load their prices by 4 times their true value.My advice before haggling is to ask yourself what would you pay for that item at home in a market and then barter to that figure,otherwise they will aim far too high or try to take as much as possible from you.Be prepared to walk away if they not meet or get close to your ideal price.It will be hard tiring work everytime.

the brown doors. if staying in the medina plan the restaurants you wish to visit before travelling there are some excellent riads with restaurants but small and limited numbers. all the places tripadviser recommended can be booked with confidence.

Wonderful, colourful, irritating and fascinating. Any adjective you can think of applies to the medina. The small streets, the smells, the colours, the noise, all different kinds of people you can think of. The soukhs with their shopkeepers who try to make you buy anything with enthusiasm and humour, but seldomnly in a really annoying way. The restaurants - from very good to plain tourist-junk, the shabby houses and the beautifully restored riads. And of couse the Jemaa al-Fna, this amazing square. Go there, look around, use all your senses, enjoy and let yourself be surprised.

I did the Soucks, Medina and History on one day. Due to Eid, we couldn't do the three half day tours do did this in a day and a half. This was a walking tour, very exausting. The tour guides walked very slowly which made us all knackered! Not many opertunities for sitting and if I knew it was a walking tour for as long as it was, I would have brought my water with me, but they never said!! Now you know. Many things were beautiful, but I think this would be better as a half day tour.
must see. going to the medina is an experience its a must if you go to Marrakech to go there I found it very interesting and amusing to see the different culture
an authentic experience. A wonderful combination of a tourist offering set in an authentic, functional local souk.Allow yourself to wander off the beaten path.

Bargain Argan Oil??!. Things cost more here - buy your Argan oil back home and save the hassle and hustle .Also, you don't knwo what quality you are going to be buying - the sales person was in a rush to sell me as much as possible to get onto the next client. I had questions on things having used argan etc for years at home... The tour guide was on a comission too - he took us the long way to the shop and then a miraculously shortcut back to our taxi.

Great atmosphere but got a bit over the haggling. Lots of fantastic sights smells and sounds. Bought lots of nice silver jewellery and a few nice pieces of clothing. But the constant haggling and avoiding the rip off attempts got a bit wearing. Do these merchants really think we travellers are that gullible?
Amazing !!. This is a must do. The sounds the smell are amazing. The souks are lovely and the sellers not pushy. It must be seen in the day and at night.

Confronting. While the experience is one i'll never forget, i would never do it again.
As a woman, everyone was starring at my long curly hair. People kept touching me. The haggling was a pain. Everything smelt so strongly. It was so loud. and all of it only got worse after dark.

Polluted, over-crowded and impolite. I came with higher hopes of the Medina, there is no doubt that it is a really interesting place. However, the is too much of the hard sell, too many people on terrible mopeds spewing out horrible fumes. Also I would not be surprised one day to hear about a horrible fire consuming the place. There are some good spots like the Cafe Arabe, but they are few and far between.

A grand bazaar - but not as unique as advertised. The Medina is huge, bustling, smelly, a great place for haggling. However, it is not that different from other bazaars and its celebrated artisans have only a few real products worthy of buying. Worth seeing once
Busy and confusing - in a good way. A warren of culture! Thoroughly enjoyed walking around, but don't let on if you get lost or you'll be surrounded!

Marrakesh Medina. Went in Sept 2013 with my 2 young children, what a nightmare, firstly do not take children. The medina is very hot, very crowded, very smelly, your constantly hassled, your forever dodging motorbikes, pushbikes and the odd taxi. The snake charmers want 200dh (about £18) to put a snake on your childs shoulder and let you take a photograph, the stalls all sell the same stuff, fake designer goods, candles, light shades etc, and start at stupid prices for which you have to haggle, when you compare stuff with prices at home, you will realise not such a bargin. The market goes into a labyrinth, which is very narrow, very hot, your still dodging motorbikes and pushbikes, watching out for pickpockets bumping into you, its very easy to get lost (follow the blue signs to get out), if you ask a shop keeper how to get out, they normally end up taking you to a cousins 'factory' spice shop. Once back into the main square the smell of horse urine is overpowering, your still being hassled for, taxi tours, horse and cart tours, tour guides, people selling, fake phones, snake charmers, men with monkeys, men with balloons and crappy plastic toys (which they put into your childrens hands), men in fancy dress, you name it, they are there. If you go to Morocco, you have to go the medina, it certainly is a experience.

Bitterly disappointed - it's a dangerous place.. There has been a little confusion in these reviews. The Souks are but a small part of the Medina and those are what most people describe as very narrow and full of small shops and markets.The Medina is the old walled city of Marrakesh and is the size of a small town which is surrounded outside the walls, by newer areas of shops and housing estates. Also in the Medina are countless small Mosques with extremely loud sound systems ( i really cannot describe just how loud!) which waken you up at 05:10 in the morning.I agree with other reviewers, that there is a huge contrast between the accommodation - we stayed in a beautiful calm, riad, - and the streets of the Medina which are the opposite.Even away from the souks, (some of the souks are quite clean because the shop-keepers brush the area in front of their stalls) this is a dusty, dirty, smelly, place. Everywhere there are piles of rubbish, puddles, derelict houses and so many flies. This may, in part. be because of the numerous horses, donkeys, monkeys and sheep etc. to be found in this city.I was expecting the beggars,pestering and rip-offs, particularly in the Jamma El Fna (main) square as I have been to many countries with a 'bargaining' culture. What I was astonished about was the dangers from bikes and motorbikes in the alleys and from cars on the wider streets and also in the alleys. I would actually feel immoral if I didn't point out the dangers involved in walking anywhere inside the Modena. I saw countless incidences of bad food hygiene - for some reason food sellers feel the need to constantly rearrange their unwrapped produce, such as meat, bread, dried fruit and sweets, with unwashed hands.Needles to say there are flies crawling all over.Despite being extremely careful and eating only well cooked, hot food, no ice, sealed bottled water and not from street vendors, I returned with a bad case of diarrhoea.I'm not judging Marrakesh as I don't know why it's in such a poor state - there will be many who find it charming or interesting but I was bitterly disappointed. I consider it a wasted few days and will not return.
Walk the Medina. Walking is the best way. The maps worked - we did not get lost once but that may have just been luck. With hindsight, a compass may have been useful.

You haven't been to Marrakech if you haven't gone here. Daytime it is full of vendors selling foods, snake charmers and then at night it transforms into a center of activity with musicians, outdoor food stands and people of every type.

Medina of Marrakech. After travelling throughout Morocco and visiting other medinas I would have to rate this one lower! It is large, noisey and crowded no matter when you go. Here one can find everything that Morocco is known for...leathers, shoes, carpets, metal wares and yes even cobras! Probably if this had been my first experience with a Moroccan medina I would have loved it but after travelling around Morocco I believe there are better ones.
Very cosy.. There was so much to see. Very colorfull. I really felt at home. Only point of attention is. The motorcycles. They are not very safe for people who are walking overthere.

Great fun, not threatening but full of conmen. Everything that epitomises the bustle of Marrakech can be found here and the medina is not to be missed.....but the traders are so slick even a tough old bird like me struggled to get away from them. Bought some wonderful carpets though at a third of the quoted price and would love to have taken home some terracotta and leather items if I had had the room.

A must see. Whatever is said about this area, it is what it is, the old centre of a beautiful city. Very busy, bustling, but it's here you get the feeling of real Marrakech. Streets are crowded, there is always something going on, the Place Jemaa el-Fna and all the souks are within here. After a couple of days you get tired of being hassled to buy everything you see, but quickly learn there are ways to say no and to laugh and enjoy the whole experience. Brilliant to see and if we hadn't we would have missed out on seeing a wonderful part of Marrakech but glad it's nice to escape as well from it to some peace from time to time.

Like Going Back in Time!. The Medina of Marrakech is crazy. My girlfriend and I stayed in a Riad in the heart of it all so everyday we'd be walking into the 'craziness'. I've been to many places across Europe and visited North and South America but the Medina was completely different to what I was expecting. As soon as our cab (taking us from the airport) drove through the Medina city walls it was like going back in time. If it wasn't for the hundreds of scooters and odd car, the place would seem untouched for hundreds of years. The roads in the Medina are like nothing I've seen before. About the size of a pavement with people walking either-side and scooters and/or donkeys pulling carts going down the middle. It is so busy that cars can only get down certain parts (hence why everyone rides a scooter). There is a lot to see in the Medina but to be honest, I think that two days is all you will need. The Souks are great to experience but you do get hassled non-stop by shopkeepers (which is expected). However, I found it was the teenage boys walking in front or following you and asking "where are you from?", "what football team do you support?" and "the square is this way. I'll show you" (when you're not even going to the square) that I found a problem. This is where you need to be very confident and either ignore them or say "no thank you" without making eye contact (they may even mumble profanities when you politely say "no" to them too). One tip we found if browsing the Souks is that if you see a group of Westerners on a guided tour, slowly walk to the back of it. The shopkeepers and teenagers leave you alone if they think you're part of an organised tour. Apart from the hassle you will get, the Souks are amazing and full of colour and smells. You can also see some people making their products that will eventually go for sale using a variety of instruments, which I thought was great.We got lost in the Souks and each time ended up in the square, which is another main attraction. This is where you find the snake charmers, monkeys on chains, henna ladies, food/orange juice market stalls and plenty of cafes. Again, in here you will likely be pestered but this will be for you to take a photo of someone or their friend. Again, you need to be ruthless and either ignore them or confidently tell them "no" (should you not want a picture). Sitting on the terrace of any of the cafe's is a must as it allows you to take it all in and see the magic that is going on below you. It is from here you can also take photos of whatever you like without someone suddenly demanding money.Overall, Marrakech is a fantastic city and visiting the Medina is an experience I will never forget. However I can imagine it being quite intimidating for some when locals start grabbing you to get your attention. I understand that people are in poverty and need to try everything in the book to make a living but a majority of their approach I found quite rude. If it wasn't for the constant hassling to hand over money, I would give it 5 stars.

A truly Moroccan experience. Visiting the Medina is like stepping back in time. It is wonderful to walk past the local stalls and craftsmen. The culture is so different. There are stalls selling just about everything from meat, fish, vegetables and of course herbs and spices.The people are generally friendly and helpful; however, watch out for the people who come up to you claiming that they work at your Riad or Hotel. They generally don't and they want to take you somewhere to buy goods so that they get a commission.This also happens at several of the attractions. You will get people offering to take you to a particular place of interest but they will most likely take you somewhere entirely different and try and sell you something.The other ruse to watch out for is people telling you that the attraction you are going to is closed and offering to take you somewhere else. Never listen to them as generally it is open. Always check with your own eyes.Although this might sound a little scary, as soon as they are rumbled they will leave you alone. Learning a little Arabic is always useful. Saying 'La shokran' means no thank you...or simply say 'La' a few times and they soon get the hint.
Haggle. Haggle, haggle, haggle and you'll still get ripped off! Its all a bit of fun, just buy small things and go for the experience.

Very picturesque!. Old world romance is to be found in the medina! We loved Place Jemaa which really buzzes at night. Remember that everyone is working to get your money so things like taking a photo of someone or them taking a photo of you will cost you a few dirhams so don't engage with them if you don't want to pay. We ate 'local' food most of the time and didn't have any real trouble but use your common sense. Haggle prices of carriage rides and taxi rides down but we didn't feel like we were ripped off in any way. We did hire a guide to take us into the souks, again, haggle for the price. They will want to take you to rug shops, spice markets etc where they get a small commission--if you don't want to go, just be firm and say no or insist on leaving right away if it's not how you want to spend your time. A guide will keep other guides and hassle away but you can also get along on your own if you don't engage with anyone trying to become your guide. Many of the cafes in the square have free wifi but you may have to ask for the password. There is a taxi rank close to the square and we were always able to get a ride for a reasonable price--ask at your hotel for an idea about what is reasonable.

Crazy. Crazy but fun, take your time and don't buy straight away - you will always get it cheaper - a quick way to cut the banter of bartering is to say you brought one from another souk down the alley for x amount!!!

Worth a look. We visited the Medina in Feb of this year. What a busy place but very much worth a look. The people here are very forward and try to sell stuff at all times. They did make us laugh saying come into Sainsburys and buy!!We sat off the square and people watched, truly amazing. Morocco has the best sky I have ever seen. Sunsets amazing.

Amazing!!. Wow!! What a place! It beautiful, bright and a chance to see the real Marrakesh and meet some of the witty people there that are so friendly, it makes you want to go back again and again!
Don't be afraid to haggle! They will see you coming a mile off being a tourist!

Incredible sight.. An incredible sight. We arrived early evening and the medina was jumping. An enormous gathering of eateries, little children trying to sell small packs of tissues, snake charmers, guys with monkeys, even a dentist with his collection of teeth on the table. Walking around the souks is an experience. The cobblestone paths are full of people, donkeys and carts going past and people on motorbikes.There is an amazing atmosphere here and something I highly recommend. Will never forget our time in Marrakesch.Stay in a traditional riad as it is an experience you will never have anywhere else.Shopping is lots of fun, lots of haggling.Would still advise keeping an eye on purses and wallets.My husband and I were travelling with two adult children and sons wife. Everyone said it was an amazing experience not to be missed.

open wide!!. We went from the opera in Paris the night before to the Medina under full moon with a very unique music ,1 3 multi-stringed instruments, and anything for a drum. We stopped to listen and immediately someone jumped up and wanted money! We moved on, and my daughter said,"I have some change, let's go back." We did, and they pulled out little plastic stools and we listened for some time. What a contrast!! The 100'2 of food stalls all serving variations of the same, good food, all the same price!! Go for it! In the day time it is very different. Exploring the souks and just absorbing the colours, sights, scents and sounds. Take it slow and take days, it is well worth it to become apart of it. I would go back in a heart beat, if I didn't live so far away. We had a monkey on our shoulders, and my daughter, sat with the snake charmer and was charmed by the snakes she held.

Dirty and generally unpleasant. Dirty and generally a unpleasant experience and there was nothing that one could give favourable comment. We have been to the Meknes and Tangier Souks/Medinas which were clean and people were pleasant.In making this judgement we have also been to Istanbul and other Turkish Souk/Medina
Medina and souks. A very different experience. A chance to see the real Marrakech. The sounds and smells are incredible.

Eye opener!!!!. This is such a mad place!!! It's rather dirty where the markets are and people hassling you to buy something it's really annoying but it's an education!!! I bought a lovely mirror for my house but most of the stuff is just old tat! Beware of the men with snakes!! They put them around your neck and demands money!!!

Assault on the senses. What an assault on the senses the Medina is. It is the heart of the city with all the hustle and bustle that you would expect, snake charmers, horse and carriage rides, restaurants and cafes and of course the main souks. The noise, colours and atmosphere is fantastic. Then just as it gets dark the medina changes and out come the food stalls and the story tellers. Locals and visitors mix together, as vendors jostle to entice you to sit down and sample the local food.

Watch that scooter!!. This was a great place to visit, we spent several hours here checking out the shopping and just taking it all in.But as the title of this review says Watch Out For The Scooters!! They seem to be everywhere.We stopped of a few times and found some lovely places to have a drink & bite to eat.It's an amazing place to go to a real must when you visit Marrakech.

An amazing contrast of old and new. The walled 'old' town is a superb place to visit, the 'streets' are filled with motorscooters, donkey pulled cards, and horse drawn carriages and contain the vast maze-like souks and markets.
Something everyone must see in Marrakech!. It's hectic and crazy, but amongst snake charmers and hash-sellers is a whole new world of spices, tagines and culture!

Marrakech Medina. Marrakech medina is an absolute maze of narrow bustling streets dotted with squares and cafes that surpasses its reputation. Once you step inside you are engulfed in a whirlwind of sights, smells and sounds. Its sinewy streets are bursting at the seams with locals and tourists browsing the 1001 wares on offer. Scooters come whizzing by without warning often followed by vendors with donkey driven carts. You have to move fast as they won't attempt to avoid you. Whilst a bit un nerving for the unsuspecting visitor, dodging them becomes a bit of an amusing sport with time . Wonderful smells of spices and fresh olives tempt your nostrils whilst visions of beautifully crafted silverware, earthen ware, jewelry, Djellabas, pyramids of colourful spices and dates get you stopping at every stall. There is so much to see that you could easily spend over a day. My advice would be to do it in 2 or 3 hour sessions as its quite overwhelming for first timers. Prices are expensive and aimed at tourists so bargain as much as possible. Most vendors speak English, French and Spanish and are very easy to engage with. They are very pushy so be firm if you are just browsing. For a lunch time snack you can get a very reasonably priced and tasty sandwich on one of the squares. Aim for the ones where locals go as they are cheaper and food is really good. There are a number of tea houses and eating places destined at tourists which are very expensive and not very authentic.I particularly recommend the Snack de la Place where food is really good, cheap and service is fast. Its an absolute must if you visit Marrakech. Not just for the shopping but just for the experience. I already know what stall I want to visit next time!

Keep your EYES wide open and your EARS be alert!. This is area is a must do in Marrakesh. There are many shopping bargains to be purchased, but the items are similar and the stall sellers continually hounding everyone around for a sale of their goods. It takes a couple of days to see familiar fixtures and get your bearings to what is around, the leather goods are great but the quality of products can vary. There are many 'designer' fakes in clothing and other goods available so be very careful, although tempting at the time these purchases can be found as illegal.The food stalls are good but there tends to be alot of flies about, safer and also cheap and tasty are the cafe/restaurants available. The medina converts to an eating market for dinner and is worth a visit to taste the cuisine of the city and surrounds. There are taxis for transport and horse and carriages available during the day, which are more expensive but worth the experience.I will certainly go back again, now having seen what is available and more first hand knowledge, I know what I want to see, do and visit more thoroughly.

Colourful covered market place. Most stalls are very colourful - varieties of nuts, dates & dried figs, sweeties & cakes, 'Marrakesh' plastic shopping bags, leather goods, sandals, pottery, carpets/rugs, metallic lamps, beautiful wood products - and all I believe, hand made. You are expected to bargain but don't start one if there is no intention to buy. Certainly an experience.

You will love Medina. I really enjoyed visiting this district as you get the feel of the real, authentic Morocco . Rich in culture, food and so many excellent shops ,from almost anything you can imagine. Visited an authentic herbalist who was so friendly and fluent in English. I bought the real authentic saffron as well as many morocco oil products which I'm really using everyday. The locals were so welcoming and the prices of goods were reasonable and good quality. Highly recommended if you go to Marrakech.

Mad, bad and lots of fun. Motorcycle with passengers brusing past you in alleyways? Shouts, snakes and more cats than anywhere else on earth? Smells, enchantment and filth all together? You get the picture. If you really want the experience of travel, this is it.

Fast and noisy. This is the real Marrakesh. The combination of stunning historical and cultural heritage mixed with sellers trying to push their products, scooters zooming trough the crowds and the essence of it all - Jeema el-Fna, the Place. Medina is a maze of narrow streets, arches, gates and souks. Dotted with squares and cafes on rooftops. You're going to love and hate it but definitely be fascinated by it. Just remember nothing is free even if they tell you that it is and avoid self appointed tourist guides.
The walled in city. An interesting experience, containing many of the main sites in Marrakech. The souk has great shopping.

Good for a day. Shopping is nice, vendors are not as annoying as some places. They always start you at 3 times the price of something, but that's what bargaining is all about. The smell is overwhelming at times in some areas and in the center square the locals become a little unfriendly after say 9 pm towards tourist. They would rather take your money during the day and have you disappear by night.

Fascinating place. The best way to visit and enjoy the Medina is by walking everywhere! The maps of the Medina that are made available locally are pretty poor (not completely useless but not far from it!) and we found that only about 40% of the roads are in fact shown, and that the network of what are really only alleyways is quite phenomenal - but don't let that put you off - one way or another, you'll always be able to find your way back to the main market place (Jemaa el Fna)!There's no question that Jemaa el Fna is the heart of the Medina but there are, for sure, quite a few points of interest to visit, not least the many souks, various gardens (many a bit on the unkempt side, it must be said), mosques (if you are non-Muslims, entry is a no-no, by the way - but you can still marvel at the ornate exterior of many), a few museums and palaces...For us, staying right in and seeing as much of the Medina as possible was a must - that's where the real Marrakech is (ie the new town is nothing to write home about).

An experience.. You cant visit Marrakech and not visit the Medina, don't be scared if you are women only group. Be polite and firm. Haggling part of the experience. Take your time and soak all the sight, sounds and smells in.

A Riotous clamour of color...noise and wonderful objects. the Medina is not for the faint hearted...it assaults the senses in every manner...it teems with life, animals noise motorbikes and people competing for the narrow spaces between the shops...however...its also exhilarating...great fun...and its very hard not to come away without a bag full of very beautiful handcrafted items to enhance your home and life....Morrocan's are wonderful artisans...the beauty of the items available here will come at a much higher cost at home...but the tourist dirhams feed whole communities who rely on their business...so spend fairly and wisely...and if the cost seems too great ..walk away with respect...or haggle hard...keep it lighthearted and smile...some people are genuinely living on the edge here but are warm and friendly...so enjoy this unique experience..

very nice. Marrakesh is the most important of Morocco's four former imperial cities. Inhabited by Berber farmers from Neolithic times, the city was founded in 1062 by Abu Bakr ibn Umar, chieftain and cousin of Almoravid king Yusuf ibn Tashfin. In the 12th century, the Almoravids built many madrasas (Koranic schools) and mosques in Marrakesh that bear Andalusian influences. The red walls of the city, built by Ali ibn Yusuf in 1122-1123, and various buildings constructed in red sandstone during this period, have given the city the nickname of the "Red City" or "Ochre City". Marrakesh grew rapidly and established itself as a cultural, religious, and trading centre for the Maghreb and sub-Saharan Africa; Jemaa el-Fnaa is the busiest square in Africa. After a period of decline, the city was surpassed by Fes, but in the early 16th century, Marrakesh again became the capital of the kingdom. The city regained its preeminence under wealthy Saadian sultans Abu Abdallah al-Qaim and Ahmad al-Mansur, who embellished the city with sumptuous palaces such as the El Badi Palace (1578) and restored many ruined monuments. Beginning in the 17th century, the city became popular among Sufi pilgrims for Morocco's seven patron saints, who are entombed here. In 1912 the French Protectorate in Morocco was established and T'hami El Glaoui became Pasha of Marrakesh and held this position nearly throughout the duration of the protectorate until the role was dissolved upon independence of Morocco and the reestablishment of the monarchy in 1956. In 2009, Marrakesh mayor Fatima Zahra Mansouri became the second woman to be elected mayor in Morocco.

exotic sights and smells. Enchanting. What a thrilling experience. It felt as if you were in a different time and world. We were told to use a tour guide, but you would be perfectly safe meandering on your own.

stay in the medina in a riad - no other option. for authentic and pretty luxurious accomodation, choose to stay in a riad in the medina. great restaurants all here, as well as the souks and the medina. to experience some of the traditional Morocco,this is where to stay.

so much fun just to walk around , shoppers dont forget to negotiate. great market in marrakech. you can get anything you want in here for very good price, leather shoes, leather bags, tea pots , lamp to clothes .very colorful and energetic.if you negotiate well, you can get it for very good price :)

Be careful with your camera. This is a tourist spot that you must not miss at Marrakesh. You should see it during the day time and in the evening. Huge square busting with activities. There are food stalls every where, selling exotic food like snails, and sheep heads. There are snake charmers, monkeys, and locals marketing all their tricks. However if you attempt to take a photo, they will demand money aggressively. This is NO good for tourism. I am not prepared to pay for a photo.In the evening, the atmosphere is more electric. Noises of musical instruments, drums .....Just go and experience it.You have to be brave to eat any of those food..... I did not.
market. good to haggle lots to see quaint little cafes in the square. beer was expensive and non alcolic as well.

Moody mayhem. Buzzing local sounds ,smells and sights. Wander through during the early morning or evening to really experience the locals going about there business. On a par with Cairo for atmosphere.

You must check it out. Maybe it's not for everyone, but us two young America girls loved it. The prices are high but are very very very negotiable. It's a fun experience haggling with the store keepers, if you like a challenge. I don't recommend eating at any place that does not have running water. Instead I would choose a place that has an actual store front and is located in a building, not one of those stand alone booths (for lack of better words).

Not relaxing. The medina is not something to be missed in Morocco. We booked a trip with Morocco Excursions from Fez to Marrakech so we saw the mountains, gorges and had a night in the desert before coming to Marrakech. It was wonderful! The Marrakech Medina was a bit of a let down. Many interesting places to see, eat and shop. But you always had to be on guard. If you tried to stop and look at a map, you will be harassed constantly by people want to walk you places. And they do not take no very well. It was hard to look at the wonderful architecture for the same reason, if you pause someone will try to sell you something or get you to go with them. We travel a lot and have found this other places, but not to the extent we found it here. Was very worth a visit, but a couple days was enough.

good but dirty. i visit Marrakesh for two reason 1- Atlas mountain , second old souk.the old souk located in south Marrakesh in Medina area.this place was disgusting, dirt everywhere with like be wise just see & buy the important & strange thing.the place busy & full with people.take care when you buy 95 % of buyer have two price one for the Moroccan & another fortourist for example i saw shop sell Moroccan dress by 2000 Durham when i buy the same dress by 1100 Durham i am sorry for her but most of tourist Italian , Spanish, french i do notunderstand this language.try to bargain if he say 500 told him 100 , take care there are some products Chinese,someproducts low quality,try to be understand the products to give you the best.the food , i can not stand eat there the smell very bad.i suffer from noise,pollution ,motor bike & bigger in the souk.i think living in Medina not safe for solo female traveler ., i am man & fell not safe & secure innarrow street.it is thing must seen in Marrakesh

Take it with a pinch of salt..... Well this is definately a must see, you just have to take the medina with a pinch of salt, expect a man coming up to you with a hat if you want to take a picture of his snakes, expect people to shout and you and pull you into their souks, it just what they do. Grab a seat on one of the balconies in a restaurant around 5.30 just in time for sunset and watch the world go by.Truly magical, but you can feel uncomfortable.

Busy ... but not neat .... It's probably the most important part of Marrakech for normal tourists. The atmosphere is certainly wonderful. The souks (probably a bit like those in Jerusalem as well) were certainly very busy and full of people and shops. But I didn't really feel like buying anything.The food etc. was quite affordable. But I didn't feel I was completely comfortable and at ease. I had to watch out and the place was also not all clean and neat.
absolutely filthy. this place was disgusting, dirt everywhere with like wise places to eat apart from one which was café au de france

Brace Yourself. We went to Marrakech in 2007 and had an hotel in the medina. I remember spending many hours wondering around and eating in the square at night. So when my relatives suggested we go on holiday we thought they might like it as well. I have to say it is not as I remembered. It's a bear pit, certainly at the front. It's largely the same stuff on the stalls and the quality isn't great most of the time. The merchants seemed quite aggressive if you haggled below their expectations. Just about any attempt to take a photograph got a shout from someone. A gay couple were physically attacked by someone who took exception and it took several stall holders to rescue them. The opening prices were so way off the mark that we simply walked away (£110 for a cotton shirt for which I would guess at about £15 in the UK). There were beggars everywhere. We only met a few stall holders who were willing to talk and they were in the much quieter alleys at the rear. I found the whole experience not very pleasant and we left Marrakech the next day. Sadly I think it's in danger of destroying itself through greed and bad manners but as it's been around this long I don't suppose that will be anytime soon. If you are going to Marrakech then you can't avoid it and is an amazing place but don't expect a bargain and be prepared for the fact that the experience may not be the expected or pleasant one you imagined.

Quite an experience....... The medina is a busy and exciting place to be. There are so many souks to shop from and hidden places to eat on a roof top. Be careful since mopeds are plentiful in the narrow streets and they do not slow down for anyone. Be sure to look everywhere before making purchases since many of the souks have similar things...if not the same!

Medina of Marrakech. Very interesting.....make sure to learn your way around. The Medina now has many hidden boutique hotels. Some can be accessed by car and some hotels have a bit of a walk. Do your homework prior to booking.
Good price for You my Friend. Watch your bag and personnal belonging, do not carry jewely and to much money. You can buy all your stuff in these narrow streets
strolling in medina. very traditional, reveals local life, but you could easily get lost, people were constantly trying to sell you things or navigate you through Medina in order to gain money
Don't get lost!. So many stalls and shops to see. As an alternative to all the usual leather/slipper/spice shops, consider looking around the dusty antique shops for a real piece of Moroccan history.

Not for us. We are seasoned SE Asia travellers but never came across anything like this ! Disliked :Beggars with their hands out every 5 metres - "guides" trying to push and grab you, and despite being careful and aware (we thought) we got our phone lifted.Found it a totally draining experience.Liked getting lost in the quiet backstreets and chatting with the kids.

getting tired. Jemaa ElFna once the vibrant heart of the Medina is now a bit of old Morocco that's gone to seed. The watersellers now only hang around for photographs as their previous role is now redundant. The snakes all look half dead and the monkeys on chains all have a hard life and do nothing to aid the appeal of the place.The Medina is now full of tat offered at traditionally ludicrous prices which now don't get reduced to buyable levels - the traders obviously not hungry enough or more likely finding enough suckers.
Simply fantastic.. The 'souk' is a dream. Once you are familiar with the chaos will you love it. Spend a few days investigating the different parts!

Interesting place to visit. Worth visiting. Easy to get lost in the Medina. After a while all the alleys seem the same. People helpful and can usually point you in the direction of the "Big Square". Not sure it was always the shortest route, but interesting. Some people want to take you places for a price so be sure to agree first. Not everyone asked for money.

Amazing place a must to see. You need a few days to explore the Medina, the smells, colours and sights are like a film set, if you can sit on the top floor of a restaurant in the square and watch the sunset and see the transformation of the square into a restaurant.Put it on your list of things todo before you die !,,,,

Smelling but you must visit this. When you enter the medina there is an enormous smell from the horses and because of the crowded city. But it is for sure worth visiting. With his famous jemaa el fna place and the souks where you find everything to buy. There is al day and night ambiance. And you must try eating at the stalls they put up every evening about 17h. Cheap and well tasting, and this between the locals. Super.

A must see in Marrakech. If you go in with a good idea of what you want to spend (the rule of thumb seems to be anything between 1/4 and 1/2 of the first quoted price) and ready to say 'no thank you' repeatedly to the stall owners, you'll have a great time. We didn't find them too pushy, generally going away if you made it clear that you weren't interested or were just looking at something. It feels a little bit like a rabbit warren at times, and you can stumble upon places that you were sure weren't there the previous day! But brilliant fun nonetheless :)
A real piece of Morocco. So much to see and do in a small area. It easy to walk around and get to see all the places of interest

Keep your wits about you and have fun!. A great experience. If you like this medina then think about going to the 'Grand Bazaar' in Istanbul sometime too...just remember you just have to keep practicing the word "NO!" Before you enter these places!

Crazy, chaotic, worth the trip. If you make the least amount of eye contact you've just made a friend. One who will say and do anything to suck money out of your wallet.It's fun and frenzied, but gets tiresome fast as you can't even look at the merchandise without getting immediately hassled by someone looking to offer you a great deal, basically defined generally as, "as much as I can persuade you to pay." Regardless, it is fun. As long as you don't mind negotiating against someone with far superior skill and expertise, then you're OK. Enjoy the experience, and know that even though you will likely pay more than the locals would, you still got a good deal.

Best to go in the morning!. Good to visit the leather markets in the morning when it's busier and the workers are friendlier - in the afternoon the vibe was not good. There's a lot of duplication so pays to look around for a bit if you want something unique, especially if you are shopping on the edges of the markets. Very interesting just poking around the medina if you aren't shopping though. I think I preferred the Fes or Casablanca medina overall.

Great Medina. This is a great place to explore the history and local culture of marrakech, it is a hive of activity all the time, its nice to sit in one of the cafes, go to the top and watch from above while having a fresh orange juice, the food here is good too, its worth trying the local stuff and mixing with everyone. You can get some amazing ice cream here. You can buy anything here, but remember to haggle...pay about half of what they ask.

Be prepared to haggle. This is another world, stalls go on forever. Be prepared to haggle, whatever the price offered, reduce by half and start from there. If still too high, walk away and most times they will come after you and accept the price you offered.

Loved Marrakech just not the souk. I was really looking forward to visiting the souk and grabbing a bargin with my parter who might I add is Arabic and can speak Arabic fluently although soon as we arrived I wanted to go back to the hotel! The poor monkeys on the Caine upset me and I'm prettified of snakes! The place was dirty, men staring at you smiling all the time and people basically talking there way into your wallet! Even though my partner speaks Arabic they wouldn't leave us aloan. Everyone to there own but certainly not for me.

WOW!. What can I say, this is 7 centuries of Marrakesh culture & history concentrated into one area for a truly unforgettable experience! This is why I came to Morocco & would come back again & again....

The medinas and souks. We were on an organised trip, with a local guide. This was great as we went through very narrow passages, turning here and there, and would never have found our way out! The atmosphere is something you have to experience . If you want to take photos of the El Fna square without being harassed for money then go to the rooftop bars. Here you can get fantastic photos and enjoy looking at the world below.
Very dissapointing - not special. Well dissapointed. Not sure what people rave about. Dirty, smelly and pestered from start to finish. Not an enjoyable experience.

Fine if you enjoy being hassled!. This is an historic place, but completely spoilt by people continually hassling you. Note also that pedestrians are clearly the bottom of the food chain so watch out for cycles, motorbikes etc coming at you from all directions. Great pity that the authorities don't appear to care. Outside the medina things become a little more civilised thank goodness!!

wow. The history of the medina iss interesting it is the oldest part of the city and full of life in all it forms ! hard to ignore the pestering from taders you end up having to be rude as they wont they wont take no for an answer women traveling alone or even in pairs beware

Magical. The medina is a fun, crazy, intense, insane, place. So much fun haggling, looking at all the little stalls, taking in the colours, and the antics going on around you, acrobats, monkeys, snake charmers, pigeon racers (yeah really!)... It really is a place that has frozen in time, and is so much fun!

Just WOW!!. What can you say about Marrakech Medina. It's just a mind blowing experience that I wouldn't have missed for the world. From the throng of people, the noise, the street sellers sometimes driving you mad, the food sellers with Essex accents having a great laugh with you and taking the mickey out of you! And everything in between. Everyone needs to go and have a look it's fabulous!

Interesting area to visit. It's hard to be in Marrakech without visiting the medina which is contained with in the big red walls. The main square in the Medina is Djemaa El-Fna. There are endless labyrinths of souks (bazaars) and alley ways in the Medina. Beware though it is almost impossible not to get lost. Djemma El-Fna is a must as there is always something to see there day and night whether it be snake charmers, acrobats, sooth-sayers,or the musicians and food stalls (by night). Don't get caught by the snake charmers who spot the tourists & pounce, then before you know it they are looking for 300 dirham (approx €30). It takes a bit of getting used to but worth persevering with it - I can understand why one could be intimidated by the experience.

An intense bustling old maze. Don't get me wrong, the Medina is definitely interesting and a must see. That being said, be prepared to get lost and have lots of pushy shopkeeps trying to get you to buy from them. We even had one person who followed us from in front, and when we turned away he backed up and came in front again. Eventually we got so lost that we were stuck following him.Definitely visit, but be prepared for severe culture shock, and relax afterwards with some mint tea.

very busy and fussy market place. This is not a resting place. If you look at something in one of the thousands of shops in this place the man in the shop start asking for your budget and want very hard to convince you that this particular item is unique and worth the money. It is not charming at all. It is very stressing. Most of the goods are made in China. You can find a nice place eiteher of one of the roof cafees or in one backyard here you can find peace, The square outside the old town is nivce and when the daylight dissapear the dinnner starts with a litle varity of menues. We had lamb and sheep head coocked and grilled. Cheap and good. This is a tourist place more than anything else and after a week in Morroco I must say I prefer the marked in Casablanca than Marrakesh.

Get an early morning guide and avoid the rush whilst learning about how the old city came to be. If you can book a tour of the medina with a knowledgeable guide then do. We learned about Moroccan life, how the city came to be, why the buildings are painted the way they are, why the doors have little hands on the handles, why some doors have two doors inside each other with two knockers, etc etc etc! Loads of little factoids that in themselves wouldn't be immediately obvious, but with a guide to bring the old city to life it's much more interesting if you get to tour it yourself during the night when it's busier!

An untouched city!. It feels like you are going back in time visiting the medina! Its great for picking up leather goods, traditonal clothing and little bits for your home...and haggling for it makes it fun and you can come away with some great bargins!I have a serious case of germ ocd so this place did test my limits at time and does feel quite dirty and has an unpleasent smell in parts but nothing that anti bacterial hand gel didnt solve!
hold on tight!. It's a bumpy ride in there!! Some really good quality goods (but nothing for cheap) with a lot of humanity in a small space.

new town not as rep said. Mmmm well we thought the 'new town' would be more French and 'boutiquey' as the rep said but bar 'Zara' we didnt find a lot else new......however we did find side streets and shops selling the same goods as in the souks for about the same price but with less hassle and even a few shops that were maybe antique style as they appeared to be far less commercial. Found a lovely cafe and had a mint tea.....something I havent mentioned yet...hot sweet mint tea....it is beautiful and on a hot day is surprisingly refreshing. Even if you dont take sugar in tea try it - completely converted now! Be warned, watch your bag here more than the souks.....i spotted a guy watching me who then proceeded to follow me - I stopped several times and made to look at something in a window - watching his reflection he was clearly looking at my bag! I ended up walking towards him, stopping and just looking him in the face, I wanted him to know I had seen him! I think that local assume if you are going in to Zara you are rich. Taxis - only get them to take you to your destination and if they offer anywhere else politely refuse. Ours said he could drop us just off the main road so it wasnt as busy....then we when got there his friends try to usher you into the conveniently place shopping mall selling leather goods! again if you are polite, refuse and walk away they are fine, never be rude. There is no need.

Marrakech - Medina Magic. When we visited the Medina we got exactly what we expected. A wondrous maize of streets and souks all seemingly never-ending. All sorts of stalls and vendors vying for trade. Yes they encourage you to stop and look but they are not over insistent and I found a friendly 'no thanks' was more than enough to pass by without any frustration or ill feeling. In fact I often got into small conversations which endeared me further to the people and this exciting place. Wander for as long as you like and do not be worried about getting lost as everyone seems to know the way back to the Jemaa el Fna square and as such you are never too far from emerging back into some form of normality. The goods on offer are what you pay for and every now and then you come across a small café or restaurant for a quick refreshing drink or snack which are at very reasonable prices meaning an afternoon just looking round enables you to immerse yourself into this superb part of a truly Moroccan city.

Rubbish. My third visit as I am staying nearby, place is full of hostile men trying to take as much money off you as possible. They are friendly as long as things are going their way . doesn't take much to turn them into angry men.they generally sell tourist rubbish. Place smells of human and horse urine and in 40 degrees. .... why bother ?

Medina Tour. At our recent visit to Marrakech we visited the Medina three time and found each experience different and exciting. Our first visit was early evening and the square was vibrant and exciting just walking around was a totally different experience with so many things going on. We walked around some of the souks but kept near the easily accessible parts as advised by our resort - this was good advice because we'd heard of others being ripped off by unofficial guides. It is also easy to browse the outer circles and there is plenty to see. On another occasion we booked an official tour guide and had a 3 hour tour - this was fantastic as he explained the history of the mosque, showed us palaces the Saadian Tombs and much more. It was good to be guided around the souks he showed us all the different areas and we felt safer with him. My best tip is not to enter the shops, you will find it difficult to get out without buying and the prices are too high. We ate in one of the terrace top restaurants in the evening with a great view of all the activity below. Marrakech is an vibrant and exciting destination but you can see it all in three days - we felt that was enough.
Tour of Medina. A winding tour through the streets of the medina seeing people at work making goods by hand - the real Marrakech

The old city. Fantastic souks with many a bargain to be had. Lots of cultural stuff to do including the Royal Palace, the Bahia Palace, the saadian Tombs to name but a few.You must visit the roof top terrace cafes that overlook the main square - there you will get a really great view of the square and its hectic / manic heart beat.You will get street traders and "guides" approach you - be firm but polite and they will move off to seek others to bother!We loved the old city and so glad we stayed there in the Riad Dubai (Kasbah District).

Spectacular, especially at night. I didnt expect that was gonna be THAT GOOD. Overcame what we thought we were going to find.The atmosphere during the day is pretty cool, mostly at the SOUKS.But at night it was spectacular, a super crowd of people, full of shows, outside dinning... just great.

Back in time. The souk and Medina is a(haggle, haggle,haggle) must with a guide on the first instance just to get your bearings as it is a lambrinth! 60,000 stalls-so much choice -many purchases later...and after haggling...a great experience.

The fun of getting lost. The medina of marrakech can be easily overwhelming bu the crowd, the touts, the sellers and the tourists make it a must do event.All roads lead to the main square so frankly, you will never be lost. If you end up towards less crowded area - just look up and look for the minaret and walk towards it. Alternatively, you can just follow the crowd. The great place to shop. Ask for prices, bargain by starting halfway and moving up. act as if you are leaving the store then see the prices plummet. We thought Fes was a better market and didn't buy much in Marrakech but after looking around in Fes, we felt that we should have bought souvenirs in Marrakech. Keep your documents/cash/id close and enjoy.

Interesting and stimulating. This is a crazy place but well worth a visit.. didn't like the monkeys and snakes on show as looked a bit cruel in uk standards but its great to have banter with the food and tourist shop stall holders.. Be friendly , smile a lot and be firm but respect them.. u will have fun they will earn a living and u may bag a bargain ... bid low though and barter hard...
Fun. Going around Jameea Alfenaa is fun, varieties of traditional Moroccan food. be prepared with small seats if you travel with kids. no enough setting areas.

Loved it!. This was my favorite medina throughout our travels in Morocco. a day in the life, keep your eyes open and enjoy every minute of it! It can be a maze, and you might get lost, but thats the fun part about it. Take a deep breath and just enjoy the atmosphere...sit back, drink some mint tea and enjoy the ride!
Got to be experience. Whether you are there during morning, afternoon or night - it changes character which is part of the magic of the place

Don't take photos, don't travel alone if woman.. I found the aggressiveness of the men to be overwhelming. It wasn't a nice experience. Everytime I tried to take a photo, I was yelled at and everyone wants lots of money. I have been to the souks in many countries, and never have had such an agressive, unpleasant experience. Marrakech needs some tourist sensitivity training before I would spend my time or money there as a single woman traveler. BTW, I have traveled solo all around the planet, from S. Asia, to Central America and the Middle East and Africa. This was a first.

We had a guide. I suggest a guide for the city and Medina. There is so much to see and since it was our last day we had specific things we wanted to see or buy. This made it easy to find exactly what we needed. We wanted Argan products so a particular pharmacy was suggested by our Around Morocco guide. "To 100,000 Spices" on Rue de la Kasbah. We enjoyed the informational spiel given by a lovely young lady. We purchased several items that I am still happy with one of which was the anti aging cream. Let her put kohl on your eyes for immediate beauty. We bought leather ottomans, called poufs, and some pottery. We surveyed all manner of craftsMEN, seamsters, welders without shields, wood carvers with scarred hands, metal workers making the tiniest slits in lamps, on the spot shoe makers, wool dyers with dye stains up to their shoulders. I wanted to buy one of everything. Instead, I offered small tips for allowing me to watch and ask questions. All were fascinating.

Biggest disappointment of my travelling life!. I have travelled a lot and usually spend most of my travels in 3rd world countries so I understand how poverty affects places and people and am very used to it, but most of the popular 3rd world places have some great redeeming features. And I had heard so much about Marrakech, we were so excited about finally getting there. BUT, I hated it.. I just cannot understand what attraction there is in this place? I feel like we must have missed something?? No redeeming features in this dump. Many other cities in all over the world have far more interesting/attractive town centres. Marrakech medina was very dirty (the entrance to the Medina on the Jardin de Marjorelle end is literally a rubbish dump), way too expensive, generally rude people ( some lovely exceptions of course), and impossible to enjoy because you couldn't really look at anything much less take a photo without having to pay someone. Also saw many dead/near dead kittens/cats and poorly treated donkeys, horses, dogs, monkeys etc. I know all 3rd world countries see Westerners as rich, but never felt so taken for a ride as we did here - most of them barely gave you a smile as they tried extracting cash from you. We weren't there to shop (being on a 6 week backpacking trip) so cannot see what else you can do in Marrakech. Even if you were shopping, it really was cheaper to purchase half the stuff back home and Australia isnt cheap! And once you had been in the souk for 5 mins the stores just repeated the same touristy junk, so not exactly what id call interesting. Any cafes or restaurants that had a decent atmosphere were easily Western prices. And the square? yes it really comes alive at night, but its not like you can enjoy any of it, to even stand in one spot and look at a performance for more than a few seconds they want $$. by day its a dusty, half constructed hole with hassles of another type. The only part the we liked about Marrakech was our Riad (Riad Aliya). We actually tried to change our flights to get out of Marrakech earlier than planned to not waste anymore of our holiday time there, but they were all booked up, so have headed out to Essaouira, which is a much more pleasant alternative.
Great place to walk. The Medina and it sourrounding are just great to seize the vibe ! Do not forget to hopen you eyes!!! Enjoy!!!
wow. we went to the medina 4 times was amazing so many different sights and smells we wernt bothered much to buy stuff which was good ,we went at night as well but got very busy..loved it
Hot but worth it. Go deep into the souks where it is less crowded to get better deals....leather goods are a good value as well as the slippers...we,loved the Berber jewelry

The reason to visit Marrakech. In my opinion the Medina and the Souks are the best bit about being in Marrakech! Navigate the maze of the Medina dodging motorcycles and mopeds along the way. Try to absorb the culture and be as one of the locals and embrace the hustle and bustle. The people of Marrakech are very accommodating and seem to have a real sense of community and solidarity. In the Souks you will come across some interesting characters, shop owners putting in long shifts trying to sell there wares. Here you can find a vast array of products, from cosmetics to hand carved wooden boxes. Remember to haggle! Nothing here has a fixed price, you will always be shown respect by the shop owners if you can barter well, often you come away with a price you are more than happy with as long as you can move slightly from your first lowest price. Often upon giving them a low price they will say things such as "you are breaking my heart" but if you stick to your guns there are bargains to be had, even when you walk away they will often have a quick con flab with one of there friends and chase you down offering you your price. The people, the colour, the smells, the atmosphere make this place really magical.

Omg. Eveing trip, the number of people was immeasurable. Well worth the experiene - keep your wits about you, this is not England !!! You will stick out like a sore thumb and be easy prey, learn to say no and quite agressively, our guide told us that !

Hunting for a Bargin. There are some really good bargains to be had here, especially leather goods and silver.Also the restaurants in the main square, whilst cheap and cheerful, were full of atmosphere and the terraces were wonderful places to watch the hurly burly of the market at night.

A fascinating maze to explore at leisure. We took the tourist bus tour and were frustrated that it only really covered one side of the Medina. When we went walking around the other side we found out why!This is a beautiful and wonderful city full of tiny streets and even tinier alley ways. It is a veritable maze, especially when in the souks where all sense of direction can so easily desert you.Stroll around enjoy the fact you aren't entirely sure where you will end up, but if you do get lost the locals are friendly and helpful. Be prepared to take directions, as someone showing you the way will usually expect a tip, even if they were headed that way anyhow!

Great mix of colour, smells, sounds & atmosphere. After the main square, this was our next "pull" to Marrakech & we spent umpteen hours wondering around the various souks taking everything in.If you get yourself a decent map, it really is quite easy to navigate so don't be put off by the maze of alleys/streets. The souks are mainly split into different areas, slippers, leather, spices, clothing, livestock, fabrics, carpets - you name it, they've got it.Haggling & bantering with the shopkeepers is the name of the game because as you walk around, they will coax you in telling you "no price to look". Admittedly, it can all get a bit much, especially in the heat of the summer but remember this is their livelihood & what you're experiencing makes Marrakech what it is today.Hours of fun to be had, plenty to take in & see.
Crazy but great. A warren of brightly coloured alleyways, treasures hidden in every shop, the noises the smells were amazing, an experience not to be missed !
A maze of mazes. We stayed in the Medina and loved it. The old walled city is full of character. Got "lost" a few times but never worried.

Go with confidence and humour!. An experience I couldn't get enough of. Such humour and colour throughout from all we met. Mind out for the bikes and donkeys and walk with confidence - it's safer than you think!

worth seeing at night. we were in August 2013, you can buy lots of spices and oils there, some of them for cooking, massage and body - they are very cheap, but remember to bargain. We waited for price, then suggested half of it, if they didn't agree, we walked away. Most of them shouted at us and agreed on our price. Do not overpay, just be careful. Of course, some people didn't ask us back which meant that we needed to find a new shop keeper - a piece of cake :) talking about medina- it is really alive at night, the light show, music, food - recommended.

A sight to be hold. There's not much I can say that would give the place due justice. Pressurised, hot, overwhelming, busy, jostling. boisterous, hot, rancid, colourful, fun, overbearing, mysterious, magical, friendly, bargains, unusual aroma, spices, hidden depths, charming, adorable, beautiful, elegant, magnificent, old-fashioned, quaintsparkling, unsightly, wide-eyed are a few adjectives to give you an idea.BE prepared to be pestered, be prepared to say no, dont be shy to grab a bargain, immerse yourself in the culture, keep an eye on your money.The animals attractions didn't really appeal to me ( snakes, monkeys etc ) as i expect the husbandry of the such is pretty dire - but this is a cultural juxtaposition and judging by how popular they were by others I can only hope that they get some quality of life.However the Medina of Marrakesh is a world heritage site and no visit to Morocco is complete without sampling this spectacle of spectacles - especially at night.

to medina or not. Stay in a riad or hostel in the medina, that's the best way to get to know the place -- from the inside out. Some treasures, but it's, you know, a big hustle bustle with lots of stuff that gets poorer in quality every year, since craftsmanship is on its way out all over the world, prices are higher, sellers aggressive, even hostile on occasion. Go: it's a scene, and buy for sure -- support the artisans, but pay about 25-35% the asking price. The spices, soap and locally made stuff is great. Yes, be careful of your wallets. I had the most fun when I went with a couple of friends; numbers can distract and we could laugh a lot. When I wander around alone there's too much hassle, too much attention. At night it's a wonderful scene and fun to eat -- the orange juice venders are the best, especially during Ramadan. The olives are fabulous, so many different kinds and tastes. If you like grilled meat, this is the place. Wonderful drumming, and gnaoua performers, amusing stuff going on at night.

Enjoyable and busy. Great experience exploring through here. Lots of interesting things to see, and although you need to be careful it certainly didn't feel unsafe. Good shopping options and you can pick up some genuine Moroccan goods.

Better than Fez. Its just all to much, pushing, smells, and aggresive behavior from merchants. If you stop to look be prepared to be pushed, blocked in and shoved till you buy. Its interesting to see, but for an hour, no more.

A real eye opener. We did an all day Marrakesh Discovery and the Caleche by night riding through the streets on a horse and carriage taking in the sights of the Medina, have to say what an experience. Both day and night were truly a sight to behold. During the day it was a bit more relaxed due to it being the end of Ramadan, but the evening was very busy food stalls everywhere and people of all cultures gathered around the Medina this is one experience that is a must.

Haggle at the Medina. Don't go if you're easily offended. Some of the market traders get abusive if you don't buy off them, swearing and shouting at you. In the few shops I looked in, they will generally come down to about 25% of the first price they ask for.

Hustle and Bustle. Great place to spend an evening/night and to be mesmerised by the all the street entertainers and the souk. It is truly an amazing experience of traditional Marrakech. Remember, not to take pictures of the street entertainers as they will charge you and always negotiate a price beforehand. Go at least 60% of the price they initially quote. Same goes for the souks.

Medina madness. The souks are mad but that's the great thing about them. just be open minded and don't let people get to you. The locals here are trying to make a living and will always try to encourage you to look at their stalls and enter their shops. If you don't want to just smile and say no thank you, be polite yet firm.Bartering is a way of life so just dive in there and give it a go. We had an app on my friends phone which instantly converted which made things easier. if you wouldn't pay that much for something at home you certainly shouldn't over there. Start at around a third of the price they ask and meet somewhere in between!! You'll either love it or hate it - just try and start with an open mind and relax - hopefully you'll love the place as much as I do.

Hot and Exciting. Mind your kids if you have them with you,its very busy!If you go when its very hot get a taxi back to your hotel rather than wait about in the heat...dont feel pushed into buying anything,you will not be to harrassed as they are more interested in German customers who are bigger spenders...just enjoy the smells sounds and colours...it is extremely busy!!!!!! so watch your purse...there is lots of snake charmers and captive monkey's that are just plonked on you,very sad and pretty unsettling if your afraid...would i go back...heck yes :)

Not good!. Me and my husband just returned from our 10 day holiday in Marrakech. Well we're do I start! Sorry I just don't get what ppl are raving about. I agree with previous poster about the square, souks and ppl in general are very intimidating. We went to the souks twice and square couple of times and hated every minute. We never bought one thing as it was horrible cheap tat and crap sorry can get better at home cheaper. Also had conmen on 2 seperate occasions claiming to work at our riad and show us to the souks they are fly cheating Bam pots basically nasty ppl and liars!!! Ate once at the stalls and was ill on the toilet well was ill most days. The smell in there is crazy too not nice at all. The poor monkeys too I just couldn't stand it. Our saving grace was our riad it was bliss and didnt fit in with the rest of the place it was weird.
