Only nice ppl we met was in our hotel, resturants and couple of taxi drivers and they ultimately were ripping you off as most were moody and not nice it was a task just to get a taxi horrible as they were over charging what an experience in itself. I'm sorry Marrakech my advice to ppl is go to Spain for a cheap getaway but not here it just wasn't cool and before you ask we r well travelled its been our worse destination to date.

The Medina is Marrakech's Tourism Heart. If there was no Medina there would be no reason to visit Marrakech. With plenty to do, as well as plenty to buy, the Medina is the obvious place for tourists to flock to

Keep your Patience. Ho my. God is very nice is busy confuse but beautiful Negotiation is the key word Negotiation everything you do like bay. All was they you give to you the high. Price possible, offer. Less less the price and you will bay for a ridiculous. Price kkkkI start negotiation a rug for 4.500D. And I bought for 1.500. Like thisDon't miss the sun set in the square go to have a juice in a terrace around the MedinaAnd drink a lot of Orange Juice a 4D.
A must do in Marrakech. You must go to the Medina when in Marrakech. It's an amazing place. If you feel harassed just say no it is acceptable. Amazing sights to be seen and smells to enjoy.

Very interesting. Visited during Ramadan by mistake so was probably quieter then normalGreat square though and souksLoads of carts selling juices Plenty of restaurantsSherpa brains and heads a common sight Didn't try it myselfPlenty beer available even in Ramadan Very nice place to walk around safe but beware of potential pickpockets but not a big problemTaxis are cheapLots of stuff to buy in souk although most probably not of interest to tourists

A Must. You can't come to Marrakech without visiting the Medina. Its worth getting one of the horse and carriage rides around the outside and you can see the difference between the Medina and more modern parts of the city
Very different at night. Visit the souk during the day is a great experience but is even better at night when the square transforms in buzzing outside eatery

Busy, hectic and enjoyable. Very very hot, very busy but enjoyable - would definitely repeat.
There was nothing there that we didn't expect or that worried us. It was so enjoyable in fact that we experienced it twice on our holiday.
there are no words. medieval, buzzing, noisy, vibrant, raw, sensory overload - unmissable part of any trip to Morocco!!!!

Private tour guide. Fantastic full of fascinating places.
Liked the souk, Ben Youssef, and checking out the wonderful architecture.
magical. loved every second of it, but only if your an explorer. If all youre after is a tan and a pool out of a hoilday, then this is not for you

Another world. Be prepared to be hassled a lot but just smile and say no thank you in French or Arabic if you do not wish to buy. You will also be approached by many beggars so take a lot of change. There is no Welfare State in Morrocco. Just relax and smile and enjoy all the smells and sites, it is wonderful.

Historic experience. The medina is THE place to be for the first-timer to Marrakech. It's incredibly historic and very interesting. It does look like a movie set, except way too real sometimes. You have to just soak it all up, the good and the bad. Beware of motorbikes. I almost got run down more than once. Stay as far to the right as you can and be aware. I'm very glad I experienced it. Already looking forward to going back.

If you like mazes.... Actually at first the maze like structure looks a little intimidating but, you quickly learn the best way around, You also get to appreciate the shade the wall provide in the heat of the day.
Medina. It does what it says on the tin....Very atmosphericMore 'traditional' than I'd imagined. Just the mopeds are a problem...
Like going back in time. Felt constantly like I was on the set of Aladdin lol... Loved the place and always felt safe, so much history and things to look at, definitely recommend

Crazy. This place was crazy! But interesting. Lots of people everywhere.
Stall holders a little to in your face, almost bordering rude! You have to be forceful with them especially if you're just looking.
Otherwise a great experience

a must if in morocco. not for the hygiene freaks. great bargains but you HAVE to haggle to get them.
go at both night and day if you can.

Get me out of here!. Harassed for money, couldn't browse, cursed and spat at! It is better to go in a small group and not with the organised cattle herd! the Square is lovely at night when it comes to life around 830pm.

Super shopping mall - Moroccan style. The medina itself is the old city inside the walls. You have to go through an archway to get inside and you really will feel like you have stepped back in time. Lots of people riding donkeys and bicycles, street vendors pushing carts piled high with fruit or bread, horsedrawn carriages, street performers. I love markets and this one is one of the best. The little pathways can be very confusing so I recommend you use a guide to help you get around, otherwise you will spend an lot of time getting lost and going in circles.What can you see here? Leather goods, jewelry, pottery, yarn, rugs, teapots and tea glasses, clothing, tourist trinkets, shoes, lanterns, tangines, etc. This is not a wet market with food but just about everything else is here for you to buy.Yes, it is touristy but sometimes it's just fine to be a tourist. You are one, aren't you?Just be aware that if you see something that catches your eye, you will be in for a sometimes long interaction with the shopkeeper. There are no prices on anything and you are expected to haggle for everything. Our guide told us to expect to pay less than half of what they tell you the price is. Sometimes this is fun and part of the whole souk experience but after a while it can be just a pain in the neck. Some of these guys are just overbearing and annoying. If they annoy you too much, move on. You will find another shop selling the exact same thing on down the road and maybe a nicer shopkeeper.Be sure to leave plenty of time - at least two days - to fully explore the medina and the souks.

Hated it!!. We couldn't stand the hassle of the Medina, the snake charmers, the henna ladies and the monkeys being touted for photographs. They should be in their natural environment and not being kept as pets. Everyone is out to make a living but many are prepared to lie to make it. Would never go back.

A maze of experiences. By far the best shopping experience in Marrakesh and lots of fun. It is so big and the best parts are away from the obviously touristy entrance areas. Wander through the labyrinth of tiny shops to the many little open squares and get a mint tea at one of the lovely little cafes and just watch the locals as they go about their daily chores. Most of the stores sell the usual touristy stuff but I found that they don't hassle you too much if you give a firm "no thanks" to their requests to part you with your money. We didn't have any trouble with anyone following us probably because my partner speaks their language and they understood us. They are very savvy about tourists because they see so many but enjoy the experience of it all.
Bargaining at its most intense. This is a must for Marrakech where you can buy almost anything if you are prepared to haggle your life away, just so exciting. Watch out for the pick pockets.

Dirty, Scary and over crowed. As many things in Morocco in different cities, The Medina or down town is over crowed with people harassing you for money or trying to take your wallet. Is dirty and not much to see only poverty. Is a really sad experience considering that in the new Marrakesh all the 5 starts hotels are far from reality. In general Morocco looks better in pictures. Is sad the king lives in a beautiful castle in Rabat and people is extremely poor and dishonest. My best advice stay away from Morocco if you dont want to be disappointed

Beautiful place, but not if you're alone and a female:(. It would have been SO much better had I not gotten followed and bothered so much. I understand people are trying to make a living however, it made me sad I couldn't enjoy the ambiance more. When I said "no thanks, just looking" to anyone, they called me "angry" and said I "didn't like Marrakesh." DON'T go here alone if you are a female! In fact, don't go ANYwhere in Morocco alone if you are a female. Thank goodness for the Berber friends I made in the desert who accompanied me on several occasions so I wouldn't be hassled.

Shopping, shopping and more shopping!. Get lost in this beautiful labyrinth of shops selling just about anything and everything. You will get asked to buy anything and everything too - and I have to say no repeatedly. You have to haggle for the things that you do you want. It's all part of the experience! All the sights and sounds can be a little overwhelming at first - I had to come back after my initial visit sunk in. But the whole experience is a wonderful memory and when in Marrakech, you have to go!

An experience, but exhausting. I would advise any visitor to Marrakech to do the Medina, but be prepared to be hassled the whole time. I really think that you have to work on the premis that all the stalls see you as a gullible tourist and their role is to take as much money off you as they can, by doing and saying any rubbish to convince you to part with your money. After three trips to Morocco and Marrakech, though I am not afraid to bargain, I am not really convinced that I have come away once with a bargain, and I know that I have been ripped off several times. Saying that, they have a fantastic range of goods that are brilliant for presents.

Amazing place. I loved that medina. During the day one can brows its narrow streets, visiting shops and endless bazaars. At night the main square comes to life as people navigate toward the exotic aromas and the entertaining sights. There is always something to see: snake charmers, acrobats, sooth-sayers, musicians and food stalls. For more information visit alextravelblog.com

Lunch by the pool. The hotel is lovely and the gardens very attractive- we were offered the "full lunch menu" as not guests who were being given poolside snack menu. In for a very expensive lunch which was beautifully presented and was delicous but let down by state of canopy style umbrellas which could have done with a clean!Visit if you want a romantic meal but be prepared for expense.

Colourful, noisy, intense, chaotic mayhem - but very enjoyable. The medina is very enjoyable and we stayed within the Medina at Riad Nashira. There is lots to see and do to enjoy the Souks and bartering with the locals to buy your items can be fun. Whilst it’s fun at first it actually does get a little tiresome after a few days of it but that’s just the way business is done in the Souk. The Medina is safe and you should have no problems walking around beyond the constant barrage of greetings from traders willing you into their shops. To enjoy the Medina even more, we hired a guide through the Riad who walked us around the Medina on a 4 hour walking trip and took us to lots of interesting places including lots of alleys, streets and areas that I wouldn’t have thought of walking down without a local. But this meant we got to see some amazing parts of the Medina off the beaten track where dyes were being made, and all kind of metal and leather work was being done by locals churning out the goods.

Very busy, colourfull and a real labyrinth. The medina is a must see, because of the variety of goods on sale there. You also see handcraftsmen at work. Pity that you can not just wander around and see for yourself as within some seconds someone comes up to you trying to buy you anything (you don't really need). You also need a guide to find your way through this labyrinth (we did) and take care, anyone seeing you lost in this small streets and coming up to you to help you expects some dirham for their kindness. Even if you didn't ask them to lead you all the way to one or another site, they just go ahead some metres before you, look back from time to times if you are still going in the same direction and at the end ask (demand) a 'contribution'. I suppose when you see the scale of poverty in some parts of this town, its normal that one hopes to earn his living in doing so.

Overpriced & Touristy, But Worth a Visit. Our experience might be a little different than most because we elected to tour the endless stalls of the Medina with a local guide--a tip I'd recommend if you want to get an overview of the area before venturing off on your own.The Medina is a very confusing maze where you can purchase everything from jewelery to olives and lamps. Our guide gave us prices we should pay and found that nearly everything we inquired about was 3-4x more expensive. Beautiful and elaborate caftans, for instance, were being sold for $80-100 here. While in Ville Nouvelle (new town, just 5-10 minutes outside the Medina), these could be purchased for about $20-25.We didn't experience aggressive sales tactics and even though I was wearing a sundress, I didn't feel I was getting unwelcome attention. In general, I'd say 75% of Western female tourists wore shorts and tank tops (if not less) and it didn't really turn heads.

Rip off merchants!. Save your money and go to paris instead. Everyone tried/did rip us off. Not happy jan! And people just continually hassled me, followed me, cornered me into shops. Didn't like it at all. And the quality of the stuff they are selling is crap too. Cheaper anywhere in Europe. And by the way, do these people realise they are in Africa, not europe!

Souk shopping. Get lost in the alleyways and side shops, but get ready to bargain. It's part of the custom and if you really want an item, stick to your guns! The highest compliment is when they tell you that you must be Berber because your bargaining is so good!
Great place to visit at night. Loads of bars and places to eat, can be annoying to be hassled by everyone you walk past but you can't expect any different!

Medina. Shop, shop, shop. But try and remember where you came from, it's so easy to get lost in there!!! And be careful of the ice cream that is made with non pasteurized milk (I ended up with a bad stomach ache).
This is the real Marrakech. Make sure you are well rested and hydrated because the medina can be exhausting in its hustle bustle. But it has to be experienced or you haven't done marrakech properly.

Vibrant at night but still dirty and it stinks. We arrived in Marrakech at night on the first night of Ramadan. The square was heaving with people leaving the mosque and breaking their fast at the food stalls. It was loud, crowded and quite good fun. The atmosphere was very good. However, after a while, it became quite repetitive with shopkeepers almost grabbing us to sell us their wares and not liking it when we said no. At one point, my boyfriend had to shout at one man so he got the message. The orange stalls are a good price and the juice is lovely. During the day, you really do seehow dirty the place is. I wore flip flops and stood in puddles of what I imagine was horse and cat pee. I saw several, emaciated, dead kittens thrown to the side of the road and didn't appreciate seeing monkeys grabbed and thrown about by leads from their collars. At no point would I pay to have photos with the monkeys or the snakes - which were regularly smacked with the lids of the baskets they were in. Also, in 42c, I didn't agree with letting horses drag people around the square. Yes, there's an atmosphere and it is vibrant at night, but inside the medina, the Western and African cultures are poles apart and it's like going back several decades. Don't stop to consult a map - you will be harassed and eventually cajoled for a tip by someone wanting to point you in an direction that they fancy. Don't stop at a stall unless you are willing to haggle 3 quarters of the price off or willing to argue with the stall keeper. Do NOT let women give you henna tattoos in the square! I refused and the woman grabbed my hand, started painting on it & then demanded 200 Dirham. I shouted her down and have her 20 dirham - and for that she was lucky! Also, they use black 'henna' which is cheap and contains a toxin called PPD which can scar - so be warned - it's not the proper stuff !! The food is so so, not brilliant but some of the ice cream is lovely. Don't forget it is a Muslim country so if you want a beer (some places sell alcohol on roads just off the square) you pay a lot for it and can't drink it on the street. Also, a couple of times I wore strapless dresses and no onesaid anything to me. I gave up covering myself when I saw quite a few women hadn't bothered - plus the men look at you even if you are covered. Overall, I liked some stalls and some of atmosphere but the stall keepers are constantly harassing you as are the taxi and carriage drivers! It's so bad I almost lost y temper at times. The place is also filthy and smells of pee (especially closer to mosque where the horses stand). It's a bit of a toilet and I can't wait to go home!
Great cultural tour. Loved staying and being in the Medina, lots to see all the time, loved the culture and hussle bussle

A few useful tips for Morocco travelers!. In Marrakesh: when walking at the Medina we were approached by men asking if we needed help with directions. We tried to explain we didn’t but they were very pushy so we let one of them “help” us. After about 1-2 minutes he “got us to the right way”. We realized that he just took us off the right way, through this very cramped alleys and then back to the way we were at. For this he charged us 20 dirhams, about 2 euros. Actually, first we gave him 10 but he got very angry and said “this is nothing in Morocco”…we were a bit scared, so we gave him another 20. In Jemaa El Fnaa: you can find everything there, monkeys, birds, snakes, food and shopping. It’s extremely touristy, but a must see! The only thing that bothered me was the constant harassment – to buy this, see that… one guy in particular, the snake guy, was very annoying. We took from far a picture from the snakes he then approached us and put on a snake over my husband’s shoulders even though we tried to tell it wasn’t really necessary…he then wanted to charge us 20 euros for that! Of course we didn’t pay that and he got very angry and a bit agressive…How much to tip: at hotels, we read that about 10 dirhams per luggage is fine and 10% service in restaurants. Restaurants: touristy places charge about 120 dirhams per person, but you can find other restaurants just as good for much less, about 80.Dress code for women: in Marrakesh and Fes, they are more used to tourists. I tried to wear at least knee length skirts, but I did see some tourist with short skirts and shorts, up to you! The other cities are a bit more conservative, so with knee length or long skirts I felt comfortable. I also always brought with me a scarf, so when it was hot and my shoulders were uncovered, if I felt the need I just put on the scarf.Taxis: there are 2 kinds, the small one and the large. The small only fits 3 people, the big fits 4. Some small ones didn’t have a meter, so we had to negotiate the price.

Brilliant experience. We had a great time here and really didn't get much hassle. Women should cover up, this is a Muslim country and Marrakech is very old fashioned. I wore a maxi dress with my shoulders and upper arms covered.You have to be strong when moving about the medina, if you are not interested in getting a picture taken with the monkeys, getting a henna tattoo, want a hat, then DON'T engage in any conversation. You are not there to make friends, just say no thank you and keep walking, don't say anything else. If you want to have peak at some items in a shop, keep your sunglasses on and the shop keepers won't know what you are looking at to be able to thrust it into your hands.You must visit this site, you get a real sense of Marrakech, just be strong!The medina is best at night, the atmosphere is great.

Stressful - Do an excursion. I've been here twice on two seperate holidays. The first time we did it ourself and, boy, was it stressful. While I understand that atmosphere and haggling is part of the culture, I do not appreciate being pounced on just because I am a westerner. If you look or point at something, you have bought it. So avoid that. Also avoid walking into the small shops as it's often very difficult to get out. That said, it was me and my mum (two women) so it might be less intrusive if a male was there.The prices are a rip off! Our hotel gift shop was cheaper. You can also pretty much get everything cheaper in the UK and in camden! I paid £30 for a small moroccan lamp last time (being naive) because we couldn't get away. It's very easy to get lost. Therefore this time we went on an organised tour through Thomson and it was (still stressful but) much better. You get to go into the heart of the souks and medina which you wouldn't be able to do without getting lost otherwise.Tips: don't look (wear glasses), dont point, dont pay more than 1/3 less than the price they state, dont get lost...good luck!!!
Marrakech Medina. Great experience, a must do if you visit MarrakechGreat fun haggling, whatever price you are first offered never pay more than 50% of the first price.

It is Marrakech! Where closed toed shoes!. The streets were dirty... It is an experience but it becomes annoying very quickly! The vendors, the monkey handlers, the henna artist, the snake charmers are too pushy and overbearing! Just looking is not and option, they bug you to death! Beware of the guys who want to show you around! They are not being "nice" they will ask for money in the end!

Maze of stalls and vibrant colours. Loved my day here, I was with my sister and we decided to cover up (three quarter length sleeves) and really didn't get any hassle apart from the normal requests to view someones shop. I did spot a lot of tourists not covered up but unsure if they got a lot of hassle due to this. Lovely place, and trust me its okay to get lost just need to go in with a brave face (The trick is to wear your sunglasses so you can at least look at shops without giving that impression to the shop owner) All i would say is don't ask about items unless you really do think you will buy them but people really didnt mind if you walked off just shows they don't really want to sell it - (Start at a third of the price and dont settle for anything more than half thats my motto)

Lovely week in Marrakech. The Medina is where all happens, you have souks, the Jemaa el-Fnaa square and all the other small treasures hiding in every corner.My suggestion start early in the morning and walk it through.It is marvelous experience.

Safe and fun. Visiting or staying in the medina is like going back in time. You will share the streets together with people, donkeys, horses, cars, buses & salesman. It's not a place you can do in a day. Just to walk there is an experience and every day has a new one.

Repetitive. There are a few interesting places around but honestly most of it is replicated further down the road. I'd advise heading down in the evening, as the sun goes down. Far more tourists and feels safer, things are less pushy in places. Can't say I'll be back unless things change drastically.
Different world. Def go and visit, but go with a guide. Got a guide from our hotel concierge recommended excellent choice

Lot of people very crowded and live animals.. I disliked the monkeys on chains and people having their photos taken with them.I did like the place very interesting as we sat in a coffeebar and watched people going about and the sellers and the music were making the atmosphere exciting.

The place to be. The medina of Marrakech is pretty much unavoidable (if you manage to go to this city without venturing inside the walls of the medina, you should be ashamed of yourself). It is the heartbeat of the vibrant city of Marrakech. When people say sensory overload, the medina comes to mind. You can buy all your souvenirs here, magnets for the fridge, and any little tchotchkes your heart desires. This is where many of the highly rated riads are located, along with the must-see souqs and Djema el Fna.I would say that everyone visiting Marrakech (or even another close by city in Morocco) should set aside at least a day to wander the medina. You never know what awesome treasures you may find!

Great place to walk around to observe. A different kind of market for a different kind of world, it was like the world of Aladdin and the magic lamp. It was very colorful, chaotic, noisy, dirty, hot, but fun to watch how the locals carry themselves. All shops sell the same stuff and there's nothing to buy but to watch, observe and learn another culture and its people. Somewhat sad seeing people still living like they were a thousand years ago.
be prepared to huggle prices for any purchase. the minute you look someone in the eye, they will try and sell you something. be polite, say no thanks and keep walking.

The REAL Marrakech!. I was in Marrakech in June 2013 and did a lot of exploring of the Media by myself while my husband was working. Although it can be confusing, it's not really all that big so if you simply keep walking, you'll find your way back to the walls. Pick a landmark to orient yourself -- I chose the main mosque, the Koutoubia, so I could always find my way back. Keep your wits about you, and you'll be fine. As a blue-eyed, blonde woman there were very few occasions where I felt conspicuous, but I kept my head covered (both as a gesture of respect and to keep my hair from burning in the sun) and a "laissez-moi tranquille" when I was hassled, which wasn't often.

Amazing Place. Cobra Dancers, Smelly horses, Dancing Monkeys, Local budget restaurants, Fresh Juices, Full traditional market, music, beggars, families, couples, everything you can imagine that fit or doesn't fit in one place. :) Amazing place and crowd. However, not suitable if you are taking kids with you.

Don't worry about getting lost. Go with lots of water, no time limit and be prepared to smile a lot and say non Merci! Some of the locals will want to entice you to the tannery whilst others will just point you in the right direction and walk on by.

Medina - WOW!!!!!. Well, my husband and I set off for the Medina early in the morning walking, we were told the wrong direction and ended up going through a side entrance and not through the large square, we walked through endless alleyways and we're 'misplaced,' was the word my husband used, I used the word 'Lost,' we were eventually guided back into the square from a guide who then wanted payment, which was far too high and my husband had to argue with him a price and then told him to 'get lost,' in so many words. You have to be really assertive and strong when visiting there with the haggling and everything. It was a great experience, even though I must admit was a little frightened when we got lost....... but there was nothing to fear...... had a great experience and went there two more times to shop during our holiday, however this time did not get lost, really enjoyed Marrakech.

the most beautiful exotic country. yes thats how i call it, Morocco the most beautiful exotic country, if u decide to go there, Marrakech is a must-see city, it is considered the 2nd touristic city in the country, also one of the 4 imperial cities that happened to be all in Morocco (the other ones are : Meknes, Rabat and Fes) it is very beautiful, especially the Medina, which means the old city, the Medina is the old part of the city, where u can enjoy shopping brass, clay decorations, mosaic, clothing (kaftan), food is awesome, and also the Moroccan mint tea, and do not worry about the language, most people in Morocco speaks at least 3 languages, if not 5 or more. you will feel very welcomed and belonged which is what a tourist look for when mingling with other people so as to learn their cultures and enjoy the beauty of it :)

Wonderful, smelly, quite safe and fun. The medina is why you come to Marrakech. Do not be afraid as it is pretty safe and the worse that will happen is you get a bit of hassle and most alleys eventually lead back to the main square.At no time from 8 am until 1 am in the early hour did i feel at all threatened and the people trying to sell to you actually isn't much worse than you get in some European city's Without I guide it is hard to see things as there are few signs and the maps are awful we did a lot of wandering and it was loads of fun. Just say no or ignore people and it will be ok.La shokran tells them to back off Prices need to negotiated very hard , mostly you end up paying 25 percent of the first offer and sometimes that is high. Think how much is this really worth?

Dress respectfully and watch for cons. We stayed in the heart of the medina, 30 minutes walk from Jama El Fna and it was the best time of my life! TIPS:- LADIES dress moderately, no low cut tops, short shorts, short skirts etc because the men will say things to you and it isn't nice. - be prepared to be mobbed if you pull out a map - NO MOSQUE IN THE MEDINA ALLOWS IN TOURISTS, it's a scam. - find your way to Jama El Fna on your one first, do not listen to the locals, get someone from your Riad to take you first and memorise it.. They will try and lead you to commission based shops/get you lost - not nice. - stay to the right hand side. - don't be afraid to say no and be forceful! Follow these tips and you'll be fine, the more you stay here the more it sinks into your heart, it's an experience and a half and personally I loved it!

Fun, but watch for cons. Many reviewers give the fun elements of the medina, and it is!!! The stores, the smells, the foods...but I want to add two cautions:1. When leaving your hotel/riad, if someone says something like "Are you staying at the riad?" And something like "You may not recognize me because I changed clothes" it is a scam. Do not believe him. He will walk you to stores where he gets a commission.2. People will offer you many things, from henna painting to directions, and then ask for money. I'm all for helping the locals if they've done something to help that I wanted, but they are fierce about it. Don't feel bad saying no. In Arabic, "La, shokran" means, "No, thank you." Memorize it and say it strongly when you need to.3. While I felt sold-to and price-haggled beyond tolerable levels, once I strongly said "La, shokran" things got easier.-- Enjoy the medina!

tourist maze. I started my trip in Morocco in the Fez Medina, so Marrakech was pretty tame by comparison...and the shops were all more expensive & a lot of the Moroccan crafts appeared to me to be of lower quality. The main reason I'd go would be to look at the pink walls and doors and walk through the winding streets which are not too crowded. There are also some specific souks which are selling artisan work that's quite different from the cookie-cutter stuff - like Monsieur Michelin. I thought the dynamic between the tourists and the local population here was often hostile and sad.

Overpriced merchandise but a must see an experience @like no other. Lets not kid ourselfs the medina is overpriced you will need to haggle to get good prices, but the sights and sounds are sonmething you cant buy. And yes you will get lost and yes you will have to pay soneone to get you out into the square as all those corridors do end up looking the same..lots of souvenirs lots of sights lots to take in...At the end of it all try taking the horse drawn couch to do more sight seeing of the city and relax

A human circus. A great way to spend your night among exotic dancers, local musicians ,many peddlers and even more tourists.Try the open air restaurants with local food. Great dinning worth ever penny!!

Never-ending warren of streets and stalls. This near the top of the list in Marrakech and a very interesting place to walk around just for a look. Don't be afraid to walk down less well trodden streets as around most corners is something new and interesting. If not you get to see another side of Marrakech, the workshops where goods are made from wood carvings to shoes and leather goods.The stalls, spices, food and clothing are all equally attractive visually and aromatically. It can be intimidating in some places and the persistent chatter of stall owners attempting to sell you goods can be overwhelming.To get a bargain at least half the starting price, another tactic is simply to walk away and the price will quickly come down. Someone told us don't feel bad - they wouldn't sell it to you for a loss so they must be making some profit.Be wary of 'young' people appearing to be helpful and offering directions or 'follow me' - it is bad to generalise this way but in our experience they will just end up asking for money. You can normally find you're own way back to the main square or otherwise we were told ask older stall/shop owners.

Great for a couple of days, but not for the faint of heart. Crazy! Maze-like labyrinth of people and goods!Tips:Watch your bags. Beware of people giving you misleading information or demanding money outright. Avoid going as a solo traveler if you want a less stressful experience. Some people are friendly, in fact a lot were, but the ones who accost you aren't. If they come up to you, they either see you as a $ bag or despise you (a tourist) for being there.

busy but fun. definitely opportunities to haggle a good deal, my trick is to always halve the price and see what happens. If they are disgusted just go to the next guy, loads of stalls are selling the same products.

An experience!. All I will say is you can't stay in Marrakech without a visit to the medina. A good time to visit the main square and the souks is early evening when the temperature drops a bit and as the sun goes down there is an atmosphere that I have not experienced anywhere else! Just keep your whits about you and don't be intimidated by the hustle and bustle.

Take care. Our Riad was not too far from the Medina so we found ourselves being harrassed by the same people. This is one thing to be wary of. They (young or old) will pretend to know you and ask you where you are going and then walk in front of you. When you reach your destination they will hold out their hand for money. A good stong NO usually works after the 3rd or 4th time!! There are licenced guides who will show you round for 20dh, but be careful they do not need to go and pray when the call comes.
Good Fun. You cannot go all the way there and not experience this. Do not take it seriously, keep a look out and keep bags safe and enjoy the atmospher

watch your bag and be ready to say NO. Loved the Medina- crazy, packed, loud, full of energy. You have to like to bargain and be ready to say No a lot- do not let anyone show you where to go, ignore the signs they are meaningless, use a professional tour guide if you don;t like getting lost. And watch your bag- I told my daughter a dozen times to use a bag that zipped, she ignored me and got her iPhone stolen. I know this review sounds terrible but we had a wonderful time. As a rule pay 1/3 of any asking price, if they want to charge you more walk away, there are hundreds of stores all selling the same thing.

No one can prepare you!. Well I thought I was prepared, but it was such a culture shock. Takes a while to adjust, but it is an amazing cultural experience. Prepare to see all sorts- skinned dogs, lizards, snakes, birds of prey.. You name it. Have your wits about you and be firm with what you want. Haggle for everything, you can get some bargains, but it can be hard to just look, as everything turns into a purchase. Eat street food at night to get a real sense of Marrakech, just be wary that additional food, like breads, and olives given to you as freebies all get charged to your bill. It's certainly not for everyone, but if you can adjust to the madness, you can have a great time.

Marrakech. The Medina or old city, founded a millennium ago, is the heart of Marrakech and the attraction for tourists world over. The people, the maze of narrow shopping streets and alleys, and the hustle are an integral part of the city's essential reality...genuinely exotic and in no way contrived by the local tourist agencies. Still completely walled and brilliantly colorful, the Medina of Marrakech is a wonder to explore.

Nice but.... The medina is worth a visit, nice place with a rich heritage. However, after spending some days in Fez, I have to confess that I was not impressed by the Medina, in Marrakesh. Be aware while taking photos, don't’ get tricked by the henna tattoo painters or the snake charmers, it could cost you a lot of money

It's a mixed bag. We found the museums, monuments and gardens worth visiting; Jemaa el Fna (the Great Square) overrated and distressing; the souk interesting; the shopping so so; the merchants thankfully not as intimidating as those at Fes, but the 'volunteer" guides quite a bit on the annoying side. They shouted Japanese phrases after us (we are Asian), frequently came too close physically for comfort. One Young man even got angry when I backed away from him. We love to find opportunities to observe local life and watch craftsmen at their work. This kind of behavior made it difficult for us.The Medina of Marrakech is not as well signed as the one in Fes. But, we walked around the Medina on our own and did not find it too difficult to navigate. I occasionally ask a shop owner to confirm our direction (he can't follow you). A map of Marrakech from one of the hotels I stayed in contains a detaled map of the souk. I will try uploading it.

crasy mad, exciting place. we visited the Medina in Jan 2013 , was at first abit freightening but by night 4 our last night we loved the buss of it so many people so many different sights, go with an open mind, take a drink on one of the roof top bars and enjoy the sunset magical.

Not what we expected!. We were disappointed by what we saw in the Medina of Marrakech. It was heaving, dirty and generally extremely 'hard work'. You can't walk two yards without being approached, hassled and generally harrassed which spoilt it for us

AMAZING!!. We loved it so much and cant wait to visit again very soon. What an amazing and beautify place which you could spend weeks exploring and still find suprises around the corner. We had a fabulous guide for our first day which was a great way to aclimatise and build confidence as could be a bit overwhelming for a less seasoned or nervous traveller
Always fantastic. Despite the crowd, this square is just incredible you'll find it nowhere else. In the evening or at night, the ambiance is terrific. Try a kebab or something else.
Good atmosphere. Just walk around! Get lost, but don't ask somebody from the street the way back! They are after your money, so ask the owner of a shop. He isn't able to walk with you ;)

Fits the perception. Exactly how you would imagine it. A huge open square, a confusing maze of narrow alleys lined with traders winding on for ever, bordered by cafes to sit & watch, rooftop terraces to get the best views of the sunset & have mint tea. Brush up on your French & sadly be prepared for calls like “lovely jubly”, ”cheap as chips”, “better than M&S”….. we Brits have a lot to answer for in spoiling such destinations! Beware of offers of help as they may result in a demand for a fee of 100 MAD; although that is only £10 they may have led you a merry dance to get to somewhere that was only a minute from where you were stood. We got caught but having loudly refused we were immediately left alone; shame they lived up to the bad rep.HAVE THE FRESHLY SQUEEZED ORANGE JUICE! Every stall sells it at the same price 40p/4 MAD, pick one and make it your regular and you will get a lovely welcome and possibly a free drink. You can buy water in the small shops to the right of the square for £1 a litre.If you get there around 5pm you will witness the transformation from empty space to packed, covered street food market, traders with their wares spread out on a mat, henna or fortune tellers sitting on low stools and the ubiquitous snake charmers appear. As dusk falls the hub bub of buskers/social music gatherings, applause for the acrobats & the general hum of diners talking fills the air.Do not be afraid to eat at the street food stalls; personally I would rather see what is being done to my food than go to a café/restaurant where the kitchen could be doing goodness knows what. Also, everything is either blistering hot in a tagine £4.50/45 MAD that continues to bubble when brought to the table, or barbecued on a raging grill; we nor anyone we spoke to had any upset tummies and it is so worth the experience. We tried everything too; even the “soup” & dates deal for £0.50/5 MAD the locals seem to always opt for; sort of vegetable with chick peas. There was also a huge crowd at the stalls with boiled egg rolls!?!?Barter the price for your henna & have the black one as the brown does not last. I got one up my ankle for 50 MAD. Beware the ladies “gifting” you a flower on your hand as you walk by; they will demand a payment & keep complimenting you & hennaring until you remove your hand.Take the horse & carriage for 150 MAD £15 for a “tour” of the Old & new town. Most of the drivers do not speak any English so you will only get to converse if you know any French/Arabic.If you are near the SOUK KAFE the 100 MAD/£10 set menu is worth it on a lovely rooftop terrace. It is within sight of the square but you can easily get lost in the alleyways – we got a taxi there & back for £10 which was over the odds but worth the safety.Sadly, there is a McDonalds (new town, milk shake £1.50/15 MAD) and a KFC; reluctantly, although we did not eat there, the latter which is by the entrance to the Medina, had a great 3 pces chicken meal deal £3.50/35 MAD compared to the ¼ fried chicken & chips £4.50/45 MAD we ate in the street market!This is a dry country; they do not drink alcohol, so you will only get coffee, tea & soft drinks in any public areas. Alcohol is served inside some establishments & at Hotels. This even includes open terraces of cafes/restaurants so you have to sit at an inside table!

you will get lost!. this must be the most difficult place in the world to navigate every turning seems to lead to same place dont go if you have a plane to catch prices quoted for are about three times what is expected any transaction takes time this a real locale experiance not to be missed do not fall for the locale guides who supposadly just want to help they all just wan to take you to the shop that pays the highest commisionjust ignore them

could not be missed!. Interesting,historic heart of Marrakesh. If one can not stay in one of Riads (that is an amazing experience), then should at least walk the narrow streets and feel Moroccan vibe.

A unique experience. If you are good at saying no and don't mind getting lost you can really have a great time wandering around the alleys and souks. Many stores, most selling the same thing, but occasionally you find that shop that makes it all worthwhile.

Great fun, many bargains and great food.. Go further into the Souks, the guys outside seem very disinterested and cba'd to haggle. £12 for a jug isnt a bargain. Tagines are about £3 and are wonderful, a must. Be aware that you will be asked for money, if you photograph the snake-charmers.

Crazy place. It will take you about two days to see everything, bring another suitcase if you want to buy things as there is so much on offer piled high everywhere. It is very safe to lose yourself down ally ways. The Medina is an alcohol free zone with just the hotels selling drinks at highly inflated prices. Cafe No1 in the main squarewas recommended and had good reviews but it would be better to eat in a restaurant. Look on trip adviser before you go where the good restaurants are as you probably won't just find any as you walk round.

Absolute Madness but so much Fun. Snake charmers, story tellers, Berber dancers & musicians, acrobats & henna tattoo artists, fresh orange juice squeezed just for you, performing monkeys, just to name a few of the things you'll experience in the Medina. If you don't like a frenetic pace then watch fom the sidelines, but really a must do experience in Marrakech.

See it once. That's enough.. As other reviewers have said, it is not as clean and organized as Istanbul's bazaar. There is a lot of junk, and everyone is hawking, talking to you and, in short, trying to get your money. You need eyes in the back of your head. It is a maze, so leave enough time to wander. If you ask directions, you'll have to pay. They allow motor scooters, which makes the whole thing more noisy and a little dangerous, when they brush by you going 20 mph. Beware of pickpockets! See it once; that's enough.

Overrated Souks. Having been to the Souks in Dubai and Istanbul these Souks were in my opinion rather overrated, small, very same-y, smelly and all selling the same stuff, I was glad that I was with my husband as I wouldnt have felt safe alone or with girlriends.

dirty dump. Medina is so overrated. In reality it is dirty dump where you can purchase questionable quality items. Do not buy leather items. Color comes off staining clothing. What a waste of time and money.

Impressive labyrinth. Definitely you will get lost! From my point of view it is very safe to walk around and to explore it. Even if you will find yourself on a dark, dead-end alley you shouldn’t get worried. If you do not get lost into the Medina’s maze it means that….you are a local! Nice experience!

Watch for locals giving directions. We found the overall experience amazing but it was slightly soured by some locals offering to give directions. They just want your money. We were on our way to see a tannery when a seemingly pleasant young man just started walking us to our destination. We were then given a private tour of a tannery then ushered into the shop. We were happy to buy something however we were then approached by the owner of the tannery asking for money and thereafter the young man approached us again wanting his money for taking us there. Don't let a few spoil a great experience but be aware and learn a few Arabic words to help you through.

Something for everyone, but be careful!. This is a big Medina with wide square and streets. Something for everyone. Gypsies are around and the Monkey/ snake charmers are everywhere to get your Dinars. Best to come by horse carriage.

Winding Streets and a Sense of Timelessness. The hustle and bustle of narrow streets and life being lived. The pink (red) painted walls and shops and houses all blur into a really great cultural experience. Scooters aside, this is a timeless scene. Be warned however, once into the back streets, getting lost gives adventure a new meaning.
Good Experience. Safe and easy to travel through without fear of theft and corruption. Just remember, you are in an tourist town and not all is as it seems.

Hive of activity and atmosphere.. The square is fantastic by night. All food types available. It becomes alive with locals and tourists as with everything agree a price before you buy anything from them.

Impressive,.... The medina has a reputation of being a chaotic, maze-like warren, but I have to say that with a good map, a bit of attention, and real patience, it is not so difficult to navigate. ...both in terms of the geography and the locals. There are lots of people who want to sell you things (of course -this is why the souk exists), and there are lots of kids who want you to give them a few $ for showing you around... but if you just talk with them and slow down a little to engage then you'll find that they are equally interested in just "meeting" you. I guess it helps as well if you speak a little French... and make a little effort.The medina is a big impressive inner-city, take some time to get to know it, and then you will really be able to enjoy it!

Great neighbourhood. great people, great place & great food. I live in Medina area during my stay in Marrakech. The people are very nice everywhere even though they speak less english. Food is sooooooo cheap and super deliciousssssssss :)

Be careful as no change. Square is great but be careful when paying for anything - for example, when buying a couple of drinks, no change was given. We were told by rep afterwards that this is normal in Marrakech, what you pay is what it costs!

A real adventure - BRING A GOOD MAP!!. I have done some traveling in the US, Europe and South America, but this was something completely different. Narrow streets with crowds of people, scooters, donkeys with carts, people hawking goods, and everyone trying to get money from you via guiding you somewhere - perhaps to the wrong place! - or because you took a picture. It can be pretty frightening, but then you get your bearings and get used to it. BRING A GOOD MAP!! and use a compass - either a real one or one on your phone. If you like haggling with people you will like it. Otherwise, you might like to seek out some of the more quiet places.

Interesting!. Really worth seeing but not for the faint hearted. Some vendors were really quite aggressive and get very annoyed if you take photos and don't pay them. As an independent solo traveler, I wouldn't be loitering here at night. I found the dead frogs around the snakes a bit unsavoury!
riad malika. We stayed in a truly superb RIAD MALIKA a must stay for anyone staying in marrakesh. The service and staff were very friendly and assisted with everything we needed and more

Medina Adventure. There are 3500 souks (shops) - everything from weaved goods, leather, metal, glass, spices and foods - items all for sale in varying qualities. The market at night comes alive with food stalls, snake charmers and monkeys. It is a good idea to have a guide for the first day to help you find particular items in quality you are looking for. The guide cost 400 MAD for a full day. Our guide showed us an Islamic school and the Ben Yousef Mosque. The second day we went on our own. You will see cats everywhere.

Crazy place. It was a bit overwhelming at first... flying through souks at a breakneck pace... but then just relax, block out the noise of the vendors.. and realize you're in an amazingly beautiful city...

Touristy but negotiable. The medina in Fes is much less touristy. The Marrakech Medina was nice, but looks like the markets in most countries. Try to find the hidden areas, like the Tim Tam Tea Garden, etc. It's better then seeing vendors selling the same items in all the stalls.

Manic but amazing. The square, the souks, colours, sounds, smells, tastes - it's got it all. Can be a bit intimidating and pick pocketing is rife so keep your wits about you, but if you go with the flow it is totally unique and a bit of an adrenalin rush

brilliant experience. We went with a guide on our first day, then back on our own on the last! It's brilliant to go with a guide as you see things you just wouldn't do on your own. For us that was a couple of the museums, the leather auctions and the wool dyers. We'd never have found them on our own.We didn't find the souks a hassle at all, despite many reviews saying we would! Yes, if you stop and look they'll try to sell you something but a firm, polite "La shukran" soon sorts it out.Bargains to be had though. My husband got a lovely leather satchel bag for 500 dirhams - so about £43! Be prepared to start low - don't go more than half of the price they say and be prepared to put it down and walk away. A) they won't let you go far before agreeing to your price and if they don't then b) they'll be another shop selling exactly the same around the corner!Not sure I'd want to go there after dark as imagine finding your way back out could be tricky but overall, felt very safe and it was great fun. Just keep your bag close to you, be friendly and polite and you'll have a great time.

Huge and Exciting.... ...and a little intimidating. Very crowded and rife with pickpockets but really fascinating. We took an evening carriage ride into the Medina from our hotel which was very nice. Watch your valuables if you stop in a crowd around one of the snake charmers.

One of the Best Medinas anywhere. What fun! The sights, sounds, smells are incredible. Hiring a guide is probably a sensible thing to do but we were here at the end of a 3 week trip to Morocco and had no trouble just wandering around on our own. It is perfectly safe and people are friendly.The vendors didn't seem too aggressive but maybe we had just become better at interacting with them. At any rate the medina is not to be missed!
Intense. Best time to walk round the Medina is straight after breakfast you get a lot less hassle and can get your bearings.

busy mood of Marrakesh. Medina in Marrakesh is the typical busy environment of any Medina in Arabian towns , narrow streets used like motorways by scooter drivers, shops after shops of typical products while attending to reach the grand Plaza with its typical athmosphere day and night

Maze like. This was truly an experience. The narrow streets are maze like. Some locals offered to guide us and took us in and out of some back streets. We visited the tannery. Be prepared for the overwhelming stench. We were brought to a leather store we ended up purchasing a pouff. I think we got a good deal. People were generally warm and friendly. Remember to say "no" when you want to and don't be afraid to walk away. Picture taking is somewhat risky as people will usually demand money in exchange. Avoid eye contact if you don't want to invite contact. Women should not go alone.

Best medina in North Africa. ...and I have been to all of them over 28 years. There is something for everyone, from the spice souk, to the leather souk, to the tanneries, to the wood working area, etc. etc. I lived there for a year in the 1980s before all the europeans moved in, but its still managed to keep most of its charm.
lively. Quite an experience, noisy, bustling just what you would imagine from a Medina, dont stop and look at anything mind unless you want to be badgered by the shop owner!
Cultural shock. A fanstasmagoria of sights, sounds, smells. The center of Marrakesh life, near the souk and many restaurants and shops. a must see.

No chance to look and browse. Too much hassle - could not make eye contact without being followed around. Take a hat or you will be pestered by hat sellers. Beware of women doing henna tattoos, keep you hands behind you back or they are likely to grab them and start making tattoos. Take a carriage ride great way to see the area.

Just relax and smile. The shops are plentiful and the sellers a little forceful. Be sure to be their first or last sale and you will get a good deal. Another trickIs to say you are leaving and only have some much money left. You will be sure to get lost so have a couple of Durham handy for directions or you can always look for the signs. Red squares that count down in numbers to the square and blue for Ben Youssef. Once you turn a corner just look for another one counting down and you will be alright.
Very safe, if you're sensible. Fantastic labyrinth, bustling atmosphere. The traders were keen to sell, but very few were pushy. Felt very safe, and the riad we stayed in was fantastic.

Experience Marrakech. You cannot go to Marrakech without visiting the Medina . It is like a walk back in time and the history and the culture of the city is everywhere. From the small walking streets to the square, it is all a must see. I recommend getting a local guide if you really want to see it right and go to the right places. You can buy anything from a $3 tote bag to an antique piece for tens of thousands of dollars. It's a great way to really experience old Marrakech

a world in itself. To enjoy the medina, you have to live in it for at least a few days. The marvels you will discover are endless. A unique way of life. Lots of shopping in the souk. You have to watch the men work on the handmade products in a traditional way. Lots of restaurants and terraces to discover. And of course, do not miss the J'ma Fna place at night.
Exotic and exhausting. There is nowhere else like this. Donkeys pulling carts, motos, covered women, old men, hustlers, riads. Try to go with the flow and wander.

Winding Streets and a Sense of Timelessness. The hustle and bustle of narrow streets and life being lived. The pink (red) painted walls and shops and houses all blur into a really great cultural experience. Scooters aside, this is a timeless scene. Be warned however, once into the back streets, getting lost gives adventure a new meaning.
The Square. the openess of the area and mixture of people. We ate at #25 & #29 best food on the square and no stomach illness...
Interesting. Interesting towalk through on your own looking at all the wares - you just need ton say a firm NO to the sellers!

You cannot miss this. The Medina is what most people go to Marrakech for. So much happens there especially at night when it is transformed and packed with story tellers and performers and street stalls. During the day it is nice to sit upstairs in a restaurant watching the activity below.

an experience.. Quite disorientating to start with but you soon get to know where you are. Absolutely amazing and everything we thought it would be. I quite got into the bartering thing in the end but was gl;ad to go to a cafe and pay the asking price too! Start at a 1\4 to a 1\3 and work your way up to whatever you think is fair. Lots of stalls have the same stuff but that's to be expected with so many there. Wouldn't have missed it for the world.
Medina Madness. Day or night, every moment spent in the Medina your senses are bombarded with sights, sounds, scents, tastes! An amazing experience!

Hectic & Interesting. A very interesting experience and quite hectic. So much going on at every point. People coming, going, motor bikes zooming, people shopping, people bargaining, very colorful. People very friendly.

Nice neighborhood. We did the tour of the medina on the horse cart: yes it is quite touristy but you can get a better idea of alleys, squares and streets that you would probably miss on your own. Its is a nice mix of buildings, shops and people and it seems more off the beaten track compared to area right around the main square. Wouldn't spend a whole day here, but it worth a visit to see another corner of the beautiful town that is Marrakesh.

Insanity. Its everything you imagined and more. Hordes of tourists, locals, mopeds flying past, people trying to con you into going down narrow alleyways for easy cash and shopkeepers trying to sell you everything under the sun. It is not for the faint hearted but it's a place like nowhere else. Get stuck in and enjoy. But please be streetwise or you will end up having to part with your hard earned cash.

BEWARE OF VENDORS. The medina was probably the best place to be in Marrakech. It's packed with vendors at night. You'll see many lights flickering in the night. There's live music and kebab and pastry vendors. We ended going to one of the vendors for dinner. Don't be surprised if people hound you to come to there shop or eatery. People will say anything to get you to eat at their place. Look at there food. Prices can be a sham because they'll show you a cheap price but then as soon as you sit down and eat, the bill will be different. They gave us bread and some dippings. We thought it was complimentary but then the vendor said no we charge for that too! Beware of your money, count your change, they take more on purpose!During the day, you'll see monkeys and snakes. We took a picture with a few and it was cool, but once again everyone wants money.. even the guy that referred you to someone else. There are so many places to shop at the medina. You have from jewelry, lanterns (cheap and really nice ones), clothes, scarves, shoes, "argan oil", and souvenirs shops. You can be there all day to shop, however, be prepared to BARGAIN! Bring out bargain 101, because they will expect you to. They will tell you a price that is ridiculous but take them down and be sure not to exhibit too much facial or verbal expression of favoring the product. ENJOY!

nightmare. Having travelled many countries, I went to the medina with eyes wide open expecting anything. well I was so disappointed with this place, it is a tourist trap with criminal activity rife from animal exploitation to pick pocketing to a great degree., we sat in the café france and observed gangs of boys having a great time switching tourists wallets. I understand that poverty is prominent here but I have frequented many countries with high rates of poverty , but the people here so rude , harassing you and scrounging, there are many crooks. we were met by a man from a taxi who led us to believe that he was from the restaurant we were going to, he led us to what we though was the restaurant , only to demand large amounts of money off us . my hubby gave him money and he demanded more only letting us know that if we didn't give him what he asked for he would follow us which he did, we felt very threatened. The place although historical is ruined by its filthiness, and people, I'm an open minded person and have travelled to many cities but cannot for the life of me understand why people go here, I felt also very intimidated by the motorcyclists here who paid no respect to people walking, and would bump you with no remorse at all. no way will I travel here again its to dirty , tourists and people are so disrespectful
Waw! very nice. it's crowdy but people are so friendly. Nice places to see. Behind the wall's you can see so nice things
mad. its just manic but amazing with stalls selling everything a truly fantastic experience and one I would recommend

A great experience.. If you are in Marrakech then it is difficult to avoid visiting the Medina. It is well worth the time taken to visit. It wasn't what we expected but, on reflection, we decided that we were not very sure what we expected anyway. The huge square was vibrant with activity and noise when we arrived. It was full of people so we decided to walk around the edge of the throng. There were crowds of people, locals and visitors, gathered around groups of traditional musicians and dancers performing in the square. There were lots of souvenir stalls in the square but we didn't bother. Apparently visitors have to haggle on every price. We had never seen so many fresh orange juice sellers in one place. The Souk is in the Medina and there visitors will find the narrow streets with thousands of shops selling everything from beautiful pottery, leather and carpets to a variety of knock-off sports goods and trinkets. The spice sellers, who appear to be imprisoned inside their colourful stalls, should not be missed. There are lots of places to eat in the Medina and visitors should shop around for the best value.

Not for the weak traveler.. Come prepared. Money in your pocket, everyone will ask you , the snake charmers, the "musicians", the monkey man, if you even look or heaven forbid take a picture, be ready to pay-up! And whatever you give, they will always ask for more! The food stands call you constantly as do all the other stands you walk by. Exhausting! The traffic is insane, no rules, NONE!Having said that, it is something to see, if only once. The craziness is somewhat entertaining.Try the fresh squeezed orange juice, delicious. Dont try the tea at the stands, its a herb mixed said to have "Special " powers. taste awful too. If you can, go sit in a cafe thats on an upper terrace and enjoy the madness from above!

Was ok, not great. Was expecting more. best was the food stalls, maybe i need to go to experience it again, but it didnt make me want to rush back.
did pick up a nice belt though lol, i have been told to go fes instead

Don't miss this, you cannot go to Marrakech and not see the Medina. We went to the Medina in the daytime which was excellent, but I wish we had had time to visit it in the evening. The markets are very interesting and the amount of hassle reported on Trip Advisor is overstated, we were not unduly hassled, in Morocco you are bound to be approached but it was minimal compared to what we were expecting. The most fascinating part of the Medina was the warren of little narrow streets behind the market with doors in the walls through which people in robes appeared or disappeared, very atmospheric! Don't miss it.

Learn to haggle. Avoid taking pictures of monkey/snake charmers! They WILL charge you. Don't buy from first stall - the next 10 stalls will sell exactly the same thing! But all in all, enjoy the experience and don't be scared.

Be prepared to barter...for everything!. A fabulous experience but make sure you hang around to see it come to life in the evening! You have to be prepared to be pestered, but if you like bartering then you won't be disappointed! If you don't want to talk to them, wear sunglasses and say 'no thank you' quite forcefully! Its 'La choukran {shukran}' is no thank you in Moroccan..I thought it felt more polite saying that! :D

Go deep and get real. The parts of the medina close to Jamaa Fna, what I consider to be a major tourist trap, are the usual bazaresque touristy tout-filled oriental mish mash. Go much deeper, towards the leather makers, the smiths and carpenters near the Almoravid cupola where glimpses of the real marrakech, which have not yet been gentrified can still be seen

Don't be afraid to just wander. All roads lead back to Jemaa el Fna. Or you can at least get back there from anywhere. The medina isn't that big, so don't be afraid to just wander and get yourself completely lost! Be sure to wear your backpack on your front in the medinas. Also, your first offer for a price should be about a third of that quoted by the vendor, and don't ever pay more than half.

A great experience. This will not be for everyone but without this visit we wouldn't really have a got any real insight into the country/city. Worthwhile giving time to go and take in this exciting place.

Scary but nice. Medina by day is a different experience to Medina by night.In the day time not as many tourists so you get a bit more hassle but by night its a bustling city with sounds and smells to alert all your sensors.

Touristy but insightful. I don't think you can go to Marrakech and not go to the medina. By day there's the hustle and bustle of the markets and the juice sellers and by night it's a huge food market with different performers on every corner. There are some fantastic bars and restaurants with roof-top terraces that overlook the whole scene too so if you don't want to be fully among the madness, you can get a bird's-eye view and take some amazing photos.
Spend Days Here!. One could spend enormous amount of time just absorbing the local culture and scene. There is lots to see. Do take a horse carriage ride.

Like going back in time. Marrakech is grest for a historic / cultural break away with the evening food market not to be missed.... like going back to medieval period.Some excellent lamps and ceramics available.. but all very busy and quite a lot of begging sadly.Personally i prefer Essaouira on the coast as a more relaxed feel but still has historic and cultural value....

not to be missed but avoid the tanneries. The Medina is Marrakesh, and you should relax and enjoy it rather than get stressed. Stay in the Medina in a Riad so that you can dip in and out of the excitement. You might get bothered once or twice but just walk away and start again. Its not the end of the world. We got an official guide on the first day through the Riad and saw all the sites and after that we were able to navigate without getting lost. It is well worth the 600 drm we spent for the day and no one bothers you. It was worth it for not having rows about getting lost alone.My tip is not to visit the tanneries. It is a collection of vats of pigeon poo with hide soaking in it at temperatures of 30 degrees plus. The smell is evil and the people there miserable. Why put yourself through it. There is a scam going on whereby you are picked up on the way there by someone saying they are on their way to work and then you are handed over to someone else in the tanneries itself who shows you around. As soon as you are handed a bunch of mint, you are about to be had. If you have not already turned around, do so now. They will try and get a lot of money out of you for taking you round. It is a hellish and miserable place. not worth seeing in the first place so why put yourself through it, If you do get caught stand your ground and say your money is in your hotel and they will give up and take 200 drm which is what it is worth. But my advice is not to bother
Crazy Medina. Love it, would have liked to shop but hassled to much to even look !! wish the locals would realise we just want to be left to browse

not to be missed. I have seen souks throughout the middle east--this one is more comprehensive where all of the articles for sale are made on the spot or near by! The Medina souk is like all hot, somewhat smelly and the vendors are very obtrusive. But it is an order more interesting than those in the Gulf.

Horrible, go to fes. The medina of Marrakech is a nightmare. Never been in a city with such bad atmosphere. Onlu=y money counts. If you are viewing a map someone accompanies you aganinst your will and wants money. People try to sell you something and if you say "no i don't want it they getting serious angry. On Jemnaa el Fnaa people put against your wil henna on you, and you have to pay for that. Very very unpleasant people to deal with. The only city where I saw several streetfights. I think there is a coincidence between those fights and the enourmes deals the street-losers make with shops and restaurants (I heard they get 50%) According to Fes it was very bad. According to the rest of the places I ve seen... Never again. The whole family was glad when we took off from marrakech airport.

Haggle, Haggle, Haggle!. plenty on offer here, bit like an Aladdin's cave. be prepared to say no and shop around for the best deal. the price always starts triple what they want, so the name of the game is ....Haggle, Haggle, Haggle!

Fascinating, meanders-worth. Wow. If you like an adventure, to discover, and see where your feet can take you, this ticks all the boxes. The medina is all the streets inside the old city walls, and it comprises the markets (souks and fondouks), houses, hotels, restaurants, etc. It looks old and crumbly, but surprises are often behind the door. Cavernous shops of wares may behind an entrance, or it may be a luxurious hotel or restaurant. Explore. There's no danger, but do be careful about pickpockets. You may also be pestered by touts, but just ignore them. Look for religious sites as well, such as mosques and pilgrimage spots (specifically for the '7 saints.' Keep an eye out for hammam, too.

wow. plenty of live and interesting things to see and to learn regarding the moroccan way of living / need to get used to the art of negotiating prices which does not seem to give any value to any good because any value is possible for any good...

Another World. This was my third visit to Marrakech and I wouldn't think of staying anywhere other than in the Medina. An ancient, dusty warren of narrow streets, some virtually deserted, others full of shops donkeys carts, scooters, bicycles, pedestrians...like Venice on crack! Has to be experienced to be believed.

the point of marrakech. im sure everyone who travels to marrakech wants to visit the medina and the place doesnt disappoint.i had to visit the square twice,the first time we went as part of a tour and we got to the market at about 6pm and had to leave by 6.30,this was a bit of a waste of time as the place doesnt come alive untill about 9pm.when travelling with a holiday tour guide the vendors know not to waste their time and you get very few trying to sell you anything.however we went back later in the evening after 9pm and it was a whole different experience,and only for the better.from the 100 or more food stalls to the street vendors to the snake charmers nothing prepares you for the atmosphere as you walk into square.every 5 steps someone will try to sell you something,get your custom to buy food,try and grab your hand to put henna tattoos on it or make you pay if you photo anything.but this is the charm of the place and to be expected.a polite no thanks doesnt always work first time but a second usually makes them move on to the next.although it can feel intimidating when you first arrive if you have any doubts about going there at night,bite the bullet and go,it is an experience like no other.

hectic, chaos, full of life and enjoyment. for girls watch what you wear, if you are not modest you risk getting your bum squeezed! lots to see and haggle hard. don't worry if you get lost. don't tip for directions unless you want to, if you don't agree for a guide then you don't have to but some young guys pressure you for money, just ignore and better ask the shop owners instead or the young guys who are hanging around. lots of fun to look around or to shop
souk. We last saw this 36 years ago and a lot of the buzz has gone. It is now safe but tame in comparison. If you hadn't seen it then I'm sure you would still find it colourful.

How to describe it . . .. The Medina of Marrakech is like nothing else. Expect to be shouted at, but remember you are the sellers only way of making money so they want to try and get your attention.Don't be afraid to haggle, barter and walk away if the price isn't right, after all someone else will be selling the same thing around the corner. One of the best maps we found of the Medina was a pop-up map from Waterstones, it's detailed enough to guide you around the hectic souks. Give yourself a day to wander around and get lost, it's inevitable, you will need to stop, turn your map around six times and then give up and carry on without it. But it's amazing fun and you end up with some real bargains.

heart of marrakech. the old city (medina) is exactly what one would imagine it has been throughout the centuries, a trading hub bustling with activity, sights and sounds and smells. There are some modern touristic elements but not so much that it spoils the atmosphere of the place. This is the heart of what defines Marrakech... spend time wandering through the medina and just walk though time.

Crazy place but really fascinating. In the morning you can see the snake charmers or men dancing and playing traditional music. You can have a glass of orange juice (it only costs 4dh and it's really refreshing) .In the evening you can taste some traditional food (prefer number 31) or enjoy the sunset from Cafe de France (15dh for a coffee and 30 for an ice cream).Don't be afraid to get lost. If you don't want to buy something just smile and say no. Make sure you don't pay the asking price.You need to pay in order to take photos (for example the snake charmers).It's definitely the soul of Marrakesh

Wow!. Crazy place but fascinating. The square at night is just incredible. It's noisy and fun. Look out for the people eating snail soup and the tooth pullers. You need to pay the snake charmers and dancers if you want a photograph. Felt very safe even though it was mayhem. Loads of good shopping but make sure you don't pay the asking price. There are many deals to be done!

Old style Walled City-. parts very historic and interesting but with the ever present feeling of being in a tourist area when in the heart of it. If you take a "tour" decline to have the "free" visits to shops etc unless you are a real buyer- we felt a bit pressured with that

A mysterious maze. We found some lovely items, but also that if we were clear we were not buying that we were left in peace. We found it easy to get lost, which led to the odd marital debate, However these are definitely worth a look. Be prepared to bargain hard and if its not worth it. Leave it!

Its everything you have seen in movies and more. It is a definite culture shock but it’s wonderful and amazing all at the same time. A bit scary if you’re not the adventurous type, but not for long, the people are super nice and willing to help, we never ran into a problem. Just say “no shukran” and they will leave you alone.

Inviting, tourist friendly..very luxurious. Compared to other souks in Morocco, particularly Fes this is not that great. Though the manner of the traders is polite, which is not common around the country. This place feels like a tourist site which I didn't like. Very luxurious riads, a square where you will get food poisoning and quite respectably priced goods well if you do haggle they do give in. It still seems to lack soul as too much is geared at tourists.

You Must Stay In The Medina. This is really the soul of Marrakech where you get to see how life really is for the locals. It's best to take it slowly the first couple of days until you get your bearings. After that you can walk almost everywhere.

Get lost in the Medina. What an experience the Medina is, we had a few restaurants ear marked before we arrived, could we find them!!!!. while taking a rest in one restaurant we looked across the road and saw one of the places we had been looking for for three hours, the Souks are amazing, getting lost is all part of the fun, you cant take any direction from the maps of the area.

exotic and a little caotic. Interesting place. Very exotic and very caotic. Tip, unless you want to give money away, carefull when taking pictures. If you really want to do it, try taking without showing.
Have to visit. Although a little intimidating, was a great experience. Very busy at night, with lots to see and smell.

MAD!!. Have your eyes and your mind wide open - it is an assault on all of your senses but is a very enjoyable experience.You do have to be ultra on your guard not to be ripped off and sometimes it does feel as if everyone just sees you as a "cash cow"! but having said that, if you are savvy and careful, you can come away with some incredible bargains.

Not a place for animal rights members. Very impressive as Medinas go. Not too happy seeing monkeys performing and snakes being thrown around but but the shops go on for ever with bargains to be had. If you don't like haggling or being pestered - this is not the place for you.
HAGGLE ALWAY. Start low they will start high. Give a second final price and walk way, mostly worked. Also haggle on the taxi to the Souk/Medina
Great place. Hustle and bustle, camels. Cullture. Food , on the doorstep of lots. Of attractions, people were. Nice, sometime a bit pushy but over all a nice experience.

Crowded!!. So touristy, expensive, poor quality stuff, dirty, awful food, and grasping. It was a miracle that we didn't get run over. Yet, though it was so touristy, many of the people did not speak English...sorry for being so arrogant!

Excellent. The medina is a huge maze of streets, shops and small workshops making all sorts of items. The main square comes Alice at night, and is truly a spectacle. We were able to navigate the 15 minute walk to the square, but getting back was another story. We stopped to ask for help a number of times, but it seems that no one can read a map.
