Eventually, we gave up and were able to get onto a street with taxis, but the driver didn't really know how to read the map or understand where we needed to go. He kept stopping to ask people for directions. Eventually, we made it back to a nearby gate that we recognized. There is a lot of moped traffic within the medina which makes walking tricky. The sights are really interesting. We loved it.
The medina. Great experience, even better if you have a guide as very eady to get lost. If you do get lost , ask in a shop for direction, not someone from the street

Shopping heaven. Wow we love the souq. There is lots on offer and lots of bartering and bargains to be had. You must be firm but fair. If you dont really want something dont get into a conversation over it or you may face some hostility just say firmly No Thankyou. La shukra. and walk away. You can have a good banter with the traders just dont waste their time or they may let you know about it. Not a passtime for shy and retiring people. Lots of fun.

A map won't help, but it's a special place. The medina is a huge maze of streets, shops and small workshops making all sorts of items. The main square comes Alice at night, and is truly a spectacle. We were able to navigate the 15 minute walk to the square, but getting back was another story. We stopped to ask for help a number of times, but it seems that no one can read a map. Eventually, we gave up and were able to get onto a street with taxis, but the driver didn't really know how to read the map or understand where we needed to go. He kept stopping to ask people for directions. Eventually, we made it back to a nearby gate that we recognized.There is a lot of moped traffic within the medina which makes walking tricky. The sights are really interesting. We loved it.
Fascinating place. An absolute must visit...we went on a guided tour and would recommend this as its so easy to get lost.

Friendly people. loved the hustle and bustle. So many interesting things to look at. Great people watching sitting in a cafe watching everything going on. It was great having my brother and sister in law who speak French.
Crowdy but worth to see. Marrakech Medina is verry crowdy with lots of Scooters in the small streets but deffinately worth to see
don't get lost!. Winding alleys, lots of merchants, much repetition of wares, actually cleaner than in some other medinas in Morocco.

So very unique. Nothing quite compares to the uniqueness of the ancient medina of Marrakech, just make sure you are a savvy tourist and read up on all of the street acts before you go, or you will end up paying 10x to 15x the going rate for anything from a picture with a monkey to a taxi ride.

Winding alleyways and market stalls. The medina is a maze of tiny alleyways through which motorcycles somehow manage to slalom through a sea of people. There are market stalls selling everything from mass produced tourist tat to dates and nuts, and on some streets you can see locals do their shopping, which means there is at least some authenticity behind the big carnival put on for the sake of outsiders.
Medina of Marrakech. We actually stayed in the Medina at the Kasbah..busy but people are very nice..very safe and if you like souks and markets...this place is worth visiting...

Amazing Place. This is a full experience of the senses- during the day its a lively trading centre - with traders unashamedly drawing you in to buy their wares. Snake charmers, people selling everything under the sun - including a dentist selling real teeth !!! The freshly squeezed orange is gorgeous. During the evening it's just as lively with Moroccan lamps lit up - dancers and snail soup for sale. We took in the night scene by sitting on a roof terrace having mint tea.

Be sure to have a guide. A wonderful Medina, but be sure to have an own guide as if you're walking alone as tourists, every few minutes some locals bother you wanting to be "your guide". Beware of these, sometimes aggressive, people.With a local friendly guide (ensure price in advance!), ideally recommended by your travel agency or your hotel, you'll learn a lot about this beautiful town and ist history.

An Experience. When travelling to Marrakech you have to have at least a day trip to the Medina.We were 2 girls travelling together so I would definitely recommend a guide. Your hotel can book this for you. Make sure to get the right price before you set out. In the hot weather go early in the morning as it can get quite uncomfortable as you will do lots of walking. make sure you are covered up if you don't want extra attention form the locals. Wear a bag over your shoulder and don't draw attention to yourself with flashy clothes or jewellery.Make sure that you tell the guide what it is your looking for as they will take you to their friends shops where they get commission.You could be shocked at some of the things that you see but its their culture so take the magic from it. You will amazing things but haggle with them. If they wont take your offer walk away 9 times out of 10 they will come after you. I wouldn't recommend going into the medina at night especially if you are girls on your own, it is very very busy and a haven for pickpockets.The only bar worth going to in in the jewish quarter called Cosy Bar again make sure you have booked a taxi to collect you as when dark coming out can be a little scary.Shopping at I would recommend the new city where you will find it lit and safe.Be careful of the drivers as they just don't stop for anything.Get your guide to show where all the hidden palaces are in the souks behind amazing large doors- this is where the rich live.
Nice shopping place. You can walking for hours through the Medina and look to the stuff they want to sell. When you want to rest take a the on the terras.
Just walk and get lost. The best you can do is just to get into the narrow small streets of the medina and get lost...looking at all local shops....

Crowded but safe for turists. I stayed with my husband in one of the medina's riads. We found the medina very safe, and it is crazy to believe because if you walk there at night it's very dark, messy and old, it has a feeling of been in a very dangerous place which is far from the truth. It is a vibrant place, totally worth the visit!!

Scenery for movie!!! . Be prepared for a strange experience. None of GPS and Google maps can show you the way, so leave your hands and senses free and enjoy that strange walk in Medina small streets. Leather, metals, eggs, fruits, Breads, mint, antiques, fabrics, cats and many many colors all over the place. Maybe the smells bother you but for sure your eyes will be full of images. Of source have your camera ready but ask the license of the people to photo them. It's some kind of religious thing that they don't want to photo their faces. Good surprise that you can feel safe, ok take care of your thinks but the general sense is that nobody will try to rub you. People has humor and positive attitude. Of course don't buy to the initial price they will tell you, you must low the prices. Interest art in a lot of small galleries. Don't let something that you want to buy for later because is almost certain that you won't find the same souk again. After the first walk you will know how to handle all the kids that will try to show the way. Or trust them and enjoy the way that will lead you in specific stores before show you the way, otherwise just avoid them. Have fun ;-)
Get a Guide or a good map!. What a place! A must for all travellers to Marrrakech, but very easy to get lost in . We paid for a guide, Marrakech City Tours---well worth it!

Must See !!. Discover, experience, bargain, get lost, have a tea in a cafe inside and forget the outer world! gives you a sense of the old true Morrocco ! to enjoy it, you really have to live it, don't be just a visitor, stay in a Riad in the medina and walk all over it. watch out from pickpockets

Must see but easy to lose your way!. You kind of have to go, for the experience but be prepared to be hassled by people wanting to be your guide. We found our way around ok but it's harder because of the people hounding you. It was easier if you could use a map on your phone because it doesn't attract as much attention as a paper map. Sometimes the GPS gets a bit confused in the tiny streets but on the main bits of the medina, we used a city map app and google maps fine. It is interesting to see but a bit crazy and you sometimes get brushed by cars or bikes. I probably wouldn't recommend taking children here for that reason - really easy to get hurt I would think.

Very interesting place to wander. Having visited the Fes medina first, we thought that this medina was a bit more manageable. The alleys seemed a bit wider -However, pay very close attention when walking around- the one big difference between this medina and the one in Fes is that they allow motorbikes and scooters to drive in the midst of the pedestrians. And they travel sometimes at a speed that I felt was a bit dangerous to folks on foot.

Awesome. Walking through the medina and exploring the alleways with thousands of shops and watching the tradesmen making their crafts. Watching the square come alive at night with snake charmers, monkeys, and thousands of locals strolling around for their evening activity.

A filthy place full of scoundrels. Err...no thanks again. On day 1, led to see tanneries by a couple of men even though we demanded in English and French, we didn't want, then forced to give them money and marched to an ATM. Paid them off but they continued to follow us a few streets later and ask for more. The only way to shake them off was to shout loud "POLICE" repeatedly. So do that, if you get a similar problem. Never let anyone lead you there because most likely you will pay them (which is fine if it is a little and only make sure it is just a little money). Always be sure where you are going or ask another tourist for help. Be with a woman or family and you might not be bothered to such an extent. You will have to pay everyone off - even if you take a photo of a street scene someone may demand payment for being in it. In fact, avoid the whole place - you won't miss much. Perhaps just worth visiting for a morning or afternoon to see a few of the places like the Madressa and a couple of souq streets. Preferably go with a pre-organized reliable, repuable and professional guide.It's a pity scoundrels ruin for those nice people who need to make their living there. And why can't the authorities put more tourist police out there? I only saw a couple of uniforms in the square and they were doing next to nothing.Stay and enjoy the new parts of town.

Lots to see. Be sure you really want something before you look at it, as they will hound you constantly, you need to be ware of pic pockets and fast moving motor bikes through the Medina narrow walkways, many sites to see and things to purchase.

The medina has been made more traveler friendly.. If you live in Morocco, you'll soon tire of medinas, as every city has one. However, the medinas in Marrakech and Fes are don't-miss affairs. There are so many alley ways you will surely get lost, but Marrakech has recently installed signage to help you get around. It is a welcome addition.
Brings history alive. A fascinating experience little changed since medieval times, the sights , sounds and smells are a treat to behold

A place to get lost. I have a talent for this, especially in a complex maze like this one. Nevertheless, I expect that walking about in circles is good exercise. Once one finds the main square, which I eventually managed to do, one is on safer ground.

Hustle and bustle at it´s best. This is the real Marrakech if you ask me, and the best place to stay when you are here. Some might find it too loud and being disturbed by all the vendors trying to get your attention, but everyone I´ve met so far has told me that it is something that you get used to and afterwards, that is part of the experience, Also, there are a lot of small oases where you can rest your tired legs and sip a cup of tea while enjoying the silence before getting back out to the hustle and bustle of the busy streets.
Experience the culture. A real experience of a different culture. Do not follow helpful people wanting to show you the jewish quarter you will end up at their cousin's shop!
wonderful. Spend time shopping, eating, wandering and be sure to visit a couple of riads. Have fun - the people are wonderfu!
busy, dirty but WOW. loved the buzz of the city, food markets. hated hassle and dust in mouth! Avoid eye contact and don't buy what you don't want or need.

Took a while to love. When I first arrived here, I felt stressed by e huge crowds cramming down the alleys along with bikes, motorbikes, cars and the occasional donkey. However, once we got to know the Medina, we soon began to love it's many alleys and atmosphere until finally, when we had to leave it, we knew we'd miss it. If you enjoy a hectic atmosphere, you will love this place. I thought that I didn't like those kind of atmospheres.....but it turns out I do.....

Medieval mall. The smells of two-stroke oil, stray cats, drains and fresh mint, the risk of being mown down by a moped or bicycle, all set in an endless strip mall of leatherwork, lamps and multi-colored cruet sets.If you really want to haggle, Life of Brian style, start at 20% and work up. Don't buy at the first place you see.Google your purchase afterwards to see exactly how much cheaper it would have been in the interior design store back home.And if you need a guide to make it round IKEA, you might need one here... But even Apple Maps should get you back to Koutoubia.
A slice of a life in a different world. Offering a view of life that is very different for the European tourist, it is fruitful to wander around to gain an impression of life in a different world.

The maze. Great to visit and get a feel of the city. But don't get lost. The streets are winding and twisting and very narrow in some places but I must say I enjoyed the journey through. It is a must see when you get to Morocco.
Fun. Take your tablet with Google Maps and GPS and have fun in safety wandering through this labyrynth! Watch out for the odd motorcycle and bicycle, why not hire and bike and join in?
Very busy place. Brillant ,loads to do .Lovely walks and so much going on ,the square was the best place and the evenings there are fun,food good and the noise wonderful.A must see

A really lively place. The old medina is easy to get lost in but being relatively small you soon find yourself again. You see life going on around you but don't let people offer to take you anywhere-IT WILL COST YOU MONEY!
Colourful and the stall holders were fun. I expected to be hassled but everyone was nice. There were some lovely things to buy like sandals and scarves

Better than egypt. Having real disliked the level of pestering experienced in Egypt I was kinda dreading the Medina. I was pleasantly surprised here. I found people were friendly and humorous...my daughters loved comparing how many camels they had been offered! We never felt threatened or unsafe....but do of course always be aware. The biggest pest is the mopeds"

A Wild, Crazy, and fun place!. If your dream is to visit an open market plus a multitude of little open stores this is the place. With a busy hum of people and products on the move,,,,This is a happining place!

Completely unexpected. Not sure what I was expecting in the medina, but I definitely did not see that coming. The medina is huge, noisy and bustling with activity. It felt quite draining going round and trying to avoid all the begging and the calls to buy this and that. The main route leading to the main square is best avoided, it is heavily polluted and you need to watch out for crazy drivers. Having said that, we did find some areas which were unique, the further our you go from the main square through the keather market, the Mellah area or the road leading to the Palace Bahia is auite beatiful. We enjoyed meandering through the narrow and winding streets stopping in the little shops for mint tea - friday morning was quieter and closer to the riads area is quieter, cooler and overall a breath of fresh air. So despite being exhausted from the hustle and bustle of the motorcycles, vedors and bikes, as long as you don't mind getting lost, it is still worth the visit.
Look out!. A fun, harrowing experience. A must-do for all visitors to the city. Motorcycles, donkeys, bicycles, and vendors are everywhere at all times.

Don't Go !!. We just came back from 4 days and 3 nights in Marrakech and this has been the worst place I have ever been. The main square is filthy, chaotic and I am struggling to understand the reasoning behind some of the good reviews on this website, which persuaded me to go there in the first place!! In fact, the whole of the medina is filthy and inhospitable, the place is full of hostile hustlers, crooks and cons and animal cruelty is rife. If you are looking for a nice and relaxing holiday, then by all means do not set foot anywhere in the medina. The foul smells of horse and donkey carriages and air pollution, the incessant harassment from the locals in the square to try and rip you off your money by either trying to help you or give you directions or sell you something or accuse you of taking pictures or because they thought you took a picture of them, the motorcycles and scooters driving past people like they are not there – safety and respect of pedestrians are non-existent - You just couldn't go on for one minute around the main square and the souks without someone approaching you with a shocking attempt to get money in the rudest way possible. And saying ‘no thank you’ isn't enough here, they will keep harassing you and even follow you and try to stop you from walking away. I have traveled to many countries but here the level of deception these people use to extort money from tourist is unmatched! It seemed like the trade of a lot of people inside the medina is ONLY to rip off tourists using pushy and bullying methods!!

The Souks. Don't hesitate to offer 10% of the initial asking price because you might end up buying for 20% of the original price of an Arab or Berber rug. This is crazy. If you can't negotiate, they will rip you off in Marrakech.
Leather good is a must buy. Lots of snake charmers in the square. The leather items are worth buying. Need to spend at least half a day here.

Survival. Wonderful experience of Arabic bazaar that kept its charm from the old ages. The biggest problem were swarms of motor-bike riders that continuously kept buzzing through already packed streets, constantly endangering pedestrians and bicyclists. Not to mention exhaust gases that make breathing in those narrow streets a challenge from time to time.

Aggressive vendors. I have seen this type of markets before. The vendors are so aggressive that one time, a vendor followed us for the next five minutes despite us telling him we were not interested in buying. I understand their life style is something that can't be helped but the medina is filthy and people are just trying to get your money. It becomes too much, I thought.

1001 nights. Love the little streets and the buzz that goes around. Only downside is all the shop owners that really do not have any concept of doing business without being incredibly annoying. But everything else makes it okay :-)

just a passig through area. if you like the environment of dust and zooming motorbikes and donkeys, then you will like this area. i didnt, i would not dare buy any food here out of fear of food poisoning. looks ok for clothes/souvenir shopping though. pretty squallid area. i was shocked to see people watering plants in an up-town part of the city, stark contrasts.

A Great Medina. I loved visiting the Medina of Marrakech with Oussaden Tours. The Medina had wider streets and a wonderful square filled with belly dances, snake charmers, palm readers, monkey's, food, shopping, and much more. The people were friendly and I found the whole experience to be delightful. Yes, we were advised to keep our wallets close to us and being a world traveller, I keep my bag close to me anywhere, and the men on the trip put their wallets in their front pants pocket. I am happy to report, there were no incidents and this is where our tour let us have free time to wonder around.

Jam-packed!. I spent hours in the medina in Marrakech and the labyrinth of corridors and shops left my head swirling. On Friday night, you can go to see the snake charmers in the open air market, or you can slip into the labyrinth and try to find your way out. It's a bit of a sensory overload, but definitely worth a visit!
special atmosphere. nice surrounding and shopsnegativ tourist trap and the people invites you to that places.if you are calm and relaxed no problems

You will be happy when the tour is finished. A unique and unforgettable experience of an Arabic bazaar, Stay close to your guide and try not to get lost. Bargain for everything but keep your wallet close to your chest.
Colour and noise. Loved the liveliness of the medina. The bargaining was fun. The food stalls a revelation - no we did not try the lambs brains or the freshly cooked snails.

Manic Marrakech. We stayed at the Riad Al Badia. They organized a walking tour of the Medina for our first morning. Our guide Mustafa met us at the Riad and took us to parts of the Medina that we would never have seen. He was very well informed and made us feel at ease on our first morning in the City. If you are new to Marrakech a tour like this is a must in order to make the most of your stay.

The Amazing Medina. Unique in the world the Medina is just a total assault on the senses. Everything from snake charmers to high fashion resides in the Medina. Every turn of the oh so narrow streets brings a new adventure. The souks offer a cornucopia of all things imaginable. Keep an eye open for the ambiguous motor bikes, the donkey carts and if possible, try and find one of the many community bakeries that the local ladies go to every morning to bake the family loaf. I can promise one thing it will be an experience you will never forget!

A sensual feast. Loved the buzz, the myriad of colourful silks, leathers, textiles and spices, the donkey laden carts and the variety of goods on offer.Disliked not being able to examine an item without the incessant attention of the stallholders, we would have bought more if we were given a few minutes peace. Haggling, initially rather fun, became tedious and we often felt unsure as to whether we were paying way over the top for items.Consequently, we bought very little.We were also constantly annoyed by the men who wanted to show us the way, expecting money in return. We are well experienced travellers and walkers that learn routes very quickly.When exploring the Kasbah, friendly children and teenagers would shout dead end, to direct us. We never felt unsafe, even walking home late at night. Just annoyed by those trying to extract money from us.Enjoy this sensual feast, it's what makes Marrakech so special.

Carpet bagged.. Essential to have a guide !This is a must. If you can only do one thing while visiting Marrakech, you must go here. Comfy walking shoes are a priority.You will be invited to purchase various items, just say "No" and keep walking.. The goods on show and for sale are absolutelyastonishing. Enjoy.

medina madness. we stayed on the edges of the medina, you will need a couple of days to orientate, a good map and strong shoes. maybe a strong stomach if you end up at the tanneries ! The locals will know with uncanny precision exactly which language you speak and where you are from, walk confidently with your map and avoid requests to help you find your way and people telling you that you are lost. After all its a walled city so there's only so far you can get lost! Expect to feel suffocated with diesel fumes, take care on the roads, they are chaos. whole families on a tiny motor bike with the driver holding the baby !! i found it difficult to cross at times and needed to hang on to my partner. Haggling is expected , and normal, (and yes i haggle in the UK all the time, often with good results!) Alcohol is supposedly not allowed in the walled Medina, however a few restaurants and Riads do sell it, at a high price. Women should dress carefully, sometimes just putting a scarf over the shoulders is enough, and longer shorts, no minis/scimpy clothes. Public toilets are interesting, you will need a coin to give the attendant. Restaurants have normal western style loos. we did see tourists in wheelchairs, so assume everything is possible in this crazy place

Wonderful experience - shopping and all. Once you get through the intimidating Djemma el Fna (and I am a born and bred New Yorker and I was intimidated!) the Medina in Marrakech is spectacular. My husband I had some things in mind we wanted but we bought even more!! The requirement here is bargaining. While am I not comfortable or good at haggling, I engaged in this "sport" throughout the Medina. The sights and sounds as you wind your way through the streets (much wider and easier to traverse than Fes) are spectacular. If you pass a vendor selling local macaroons from a tray while walking, by all means buy one (or two) - they are a delightful afternoon treat! I needed to leave the Medina, only because we had bought too much to carry. Ottomans, wall sconces, a tagine (which I thought we would never get home in one piece) and so much more. My husband and I will treasure this trip forever (even after he finished gluing the tagine togather - oh well!)Salaam!

another world. It's like being in another world inside the medina; the smells, sights... it was an unforgettable experience, but so chaotic. motorbikes nearly running over your feet, constant shouts (especially to young foreign women) and at times being followed. It wasn't my paradise, but it was an experience to see inside the medina.
Sights, sound and smells!. Get a tour guide....not off the street...go with Rachid...you can find him on tripadvisor. That way you won't be overwhelmed, and you'll get an education too!

Magical Medina. The old medina or city of marrakech can be found, like most old cities, inside walls that used to serve as defence and security. Most of what's inside the city is old and unpolished, but it is exactly this that brings out the beauty in it. Un-commercialized, and uncorrupted by the dominant influences of the highly civilized western world, this medina has been able to stay true to itself. the stores along the small winding alleyways are but stalls but with a plethora of authentic moroccan crafts and items that one will not find in walmart or any other department store. The range of handicraft from hammered silver tea pots to the beautiful stencilled and colourful lanterns, hand made jewellery, and handmade bars of solid fragrances (that come in moroccan rose and jasmine ) and arabic kohl, I found it very refreshing and a closer feel to authentic North African culture and lifestyle. The medina, with its winding small alleys is also no stranger to beautiful architecture, littered within it are some of the most beautiful arcs and mosaic works i have ever seen and is really worth a visit. If you're looking for authentic adventures like me and aren't afraid of stepping out a bit from your comfort zone then this is the perfect place for you! with a little bit of courage in haggling, one can get amazing bargains for original artisanal masterpieces offered throughout this culturally rich city. I highly recommend this adventure for friends or couples, but not so much for families with very small kids as it might be hard not to lose them with so many winding alleys and paths
nice guided tour. we went on the guided tour to get used to the people,then can explore on your own,worth the visit,so interesting
A must-see. You simply can't go to Marrakech without visiting the Medina! It's the heart of the city and an assault on the senses - in the good way!

Medina Vists. It's an experience to visit the Souks. If you want to see the real Marrakech avoid the touristy bits and get lost deep in the local areas.But beware, photos of local people will result in a request for money, and don't keep anything in your back pockets.

Has to be Seen !. Interesting to say the least. Some nice parts, some crazy parts, but best to visit late afternoon, when the entertainment hits. The Souks are have to visited although so many selling the same stuff. Entertaining

know somebody....... this is a great place to stay busy but lots going on. need to know someone to know where to go and when and where and why! Yummy foods again and lots and lots to see and buy.......starting to see bad pattern of shopping! coffee is devious!
hustle and bustle - what we expected. nothing to dislike, you will get asked by every other person, whether you want food, you want guide, etc. keep walking and enjoy it all.

Crazy!. On first walk outs a bit scary but got used to the madness of the donkey carts, scooters, taxis and crowds. Streets very narrow and you need to be alert. Noone bothered us and we learnt how to say no to people asking us if we'd like a taxi ride or anything else! Everyone was very friendly. Some great poverty which is very sad.

Could wander for hours. It's the thing you come to Marrakech for, and it won't disappoint - thousands of shops along hundreds of beautiful souks. Somewhat tamer perhaps than some of the reviews had lead us to believe, but still enjoyable. Good value to be had, as long as you do some bartering!
Busy. Extremely interesting and colourful. We went in the daytime and in the evening when it was horrendously crowded

A must!. If you like monkeys and snake charmers, the Medina is the place for you! I could definitely spend days walking inside the Medina, it is filled with historic sites, exotic animals, food, people and smells. It does get a bad rep because of everyone haggling you for money, but as long as you're a savy traveler it won't be a problem. Make sure to visit the souks, cafes and of course Jemma el-Fnaa.

An amazing adventure. We spent 3 days walking around the Medina which is a maze of roads but is absolutely fascinating. We felt very safe although we did get hassled from time to time. The local people were helpful although every time we looked at our map we were offers 'help'. Some of this was genuine, but some were young men who wished to show us around and then expected a generous tip. Walking through the back streets was great as we saw lots of different sights including local markets.

Amazing. Just mooch about anywhere. Helpful friendly people....will show you anywhere for a price so just say politely and firmly no and they leave you alone. You will repeat this every few metres ! A;ways trying to tell you the way you are going has a mosque and the road is closed...don't listen !

not to be missed. An amazing place, best visited after 4 ish in the afternoon as this is when the traders begin to set up their stalls, you will see, snake charmers, story tellers, henna tattoos, food of all sorts, spices to numerous to mention, coblers, belly dancers, jugglers, water sellers (not from bottles, bags), once you have wandered around here then head for the maize of small streets in the market where you can buy just about everything!Be careful though, best not to take a hand bag and jkeep everyting in deep pockets, oh and dont wear jewelery, you will be hastled everywhere, but just be firm and polite, there is a large taxi stand at the end of the Medena where 30Dhs will get you a fair distance across town

Intense. Not for the softies or naive people out there.. Listen to people when they say you better be wary of this place. It is absolutely amazing and you will truly be immersing yourself into a the colorful and energetic culture, but it is definitely not for those who want a relaxing time.I am a single, young female traveler, so perhaps this is only from my point of view, but they will pressure you like hell to buy things. Everyone will. You can't walk 5 feet without someone trying to (literally) pull you into their shop. It's kind of funny at first, but starts get get really annoying and actually starts to make you cautious after a short while. My poor, sappy self who can't barter if my life depended on it, got severely taken advantage of (essentially robbed). A man from outside the souks pulled me deep into the maze for a good 10 minutes, then essentially demanded that I buy shoes from him. Him, along with 4 other men, surrounded me in the shop until I forked over 35 pounds ($55-60) for a pair of shoes I didn't even like. Like, actually took it out of my wallet, counted it, then pushed me away. Then, they attempted to take me to the friend's shop, but I was so angry that I yanked my hand away and figured out how to get out of the maze of souks. Very irritating. Anyway, don't let this scare you. This place is awesome, being full of neat trinkets, music, food, and dancing (especially at night), but get some willpower to say no and be firm with your answers. Even better if you go with someone else to back you up. They will step all over you otherwise.

This is not fun. The crowded alleys, the hawkers, the smells, the general insanity, we enjoyed, but having people riding at you on motor scooters, and even full power motorbikes, is simply not fun. This is emphatically not a place for children or the infirm, or any human beings, actually

Medina. I liked the activity, but did not like how they treat the poor animals. The monkeys are dragged by their collars, the snakes are even mistreated and the poor donkeys are overloaded with stuff. They dont love animals like westerners do. The people in the food stall try to cheat you out of your money a lot so take care when ordering and ask prices. I have never seen such underhanded practices, especially at food stall number 1 in the square. Avoid! When the woman asked us why we changed to a different stall, I told her that she had tried to cheat us out of money the night before.

not for the faint hearted. Loved the energy, bustle and bartering. Less keen on the motorbikes but where else can you have the potential for being run over by a motorbike and a donkey at the same time?. I have no sense of smell so missed this unique aspect (a blessing and a curse I think). We were only there for 2 days so took a caleche around the walls to get a sense of the place. Next time I will think about a local guide - if only to go to those places off the well-beaten path. Always keep a sense of humour and I guess it makes sense to stay alert.

Mad Marrakech.. I was disappointed with Marrakech in general. There was a certain climax building when we entered the general area and Souk that was Marrakech. I didn't mind the traffic, the smells or the noise, what I found difficult to accept was the attitude of the stall holders ( particularly those close to the main square). They very quickly became irritable and angry if we didn't accept their first and very inflated price on a " just looking" walk.Most of the Souk is covered and protects shoppers from the sun,-not sure how well you are protected from the rain.I did enjoy the pastry and sweet shops and displays and took some good people pictures after asking. Had one man ask for money after I took his picture,but this goes on all over Tunisia.Marrakech is worth a look but it's a hard commercial area these days.

Don't stay anywhere else. We heard a lot of advice to stay in the "new city" outside the walls, but that is a mistake. There is no reason to be intimidated by anything you hear about life inside the Medina, and it would be a crime to come all this way and not simply stay in a riad inside the walls so you can really experience the life there day and night...... and it is totally safe. The worse that will happen is that you get talked to death by someone trying to sell you their wares!!!
Interesting but scary. The Medina is a rabbit warren of tiny roads and alley ways. So easy to get lost and become prey to locals willing to guide you out for a price!

This place is Hell on Earth! Can I give it less than 1 mark?. The Souks are part of the Medina and pretty well regulated. They are intense but generally okay. Outside of the souks the Medina is basically a slum and very, very dangerous. I would never stay in the Medina again even though the Riad I stayed at was exceptionally good.Imagine tight alleyways with no logical structure extending for miles. Imagine those alleyways packed with people. Imagine being accosted every single step you take by beggars, shop keepers, restaurant staff, and most intimidating of all male youths between 16 and 25 who harass you for money for showing you the way to where you knew you were going anyway. Imagine those alleyways then populated with hundreds of mopeds, pedal bike, donkeys and carts, all sorts of three wheeler contraptions, hand carts and indeed big powerful motor bikes. You come across blockages so often it makes any movement through the Medina tedious and dangerous, imagine the fumes from mopeds and motor bikes that are years old and never serviced, the fumes at times made me feel like I was going to die.We lost count of the number of accidents we saw, including one which resulted in a mass brawl. Yep your in an alleyway with 30 people kicking off all around you, no place to move. Had to stand in front of my wife arm in arm with a sane Moroccan man who was stood in front of his wife just to protect them from the fray.There were many other accidents as these vehicles drive at mad speeds around corners, swerving around you, often knocking you in the back. We saw one child hit with real force in the leg by a moped, which drew blood and may well have caused breakage for all we know.We cut our holiday short by two days, we could not stand it any more. You may be able to cope for a couple of days, but my advice is stay in the new town and travel into the Souks and square when you want. Forget any nostalgic view you may have of the Medina, it isn't real. Again don't confuse the Souks with the rest of the Medina. The Souks are really good fun but can be energy sapping after a couple of days.

Captivating. We first set out to explore the medina amidst an extremely rainy day. Our Riad was in the Sidi Ben Slimane district of Marrakech and we navigated what would become a routine path for the days to follow through the busy medina stalls – there is always so much going on around you in Marrakech – bikes and scooters whirling past – donkeys – cats – locals plying their trade – the colours and sounds of the souks.Lots of kids or young men approaching offering directions to the square or to the tanneries etc. or to say “keep going – it’s just a little further.” We found our way around largely thanks to the best app for iphone I’ve ever used called ‘city maps2go’ (operates via gps – no internet connection needed) which still performed pretty well despite the complicated local setting. By day 3 we were pretty comfortable with our surroundings and really began to enjoy ourselves.
great time. liked the hustle and bustle, we had a guide which was great.Were able too see places we would not have known about or even that they were there in a little alleyway. Local guide good idea
Souks of Marrakech. So much to see in such a small space, got to haggle but all part of the experience. Can be claustrophobic, probably better at night when alleyways are lit.

Wanna Get Lost. Really fun, but not for the faint of heart;-) Very easy to get lost in the winding streets and alleyways. Watch out for motor-bikes!! Crowded streets can be a little intimidating (especially at night.... Do these people ever go to bed!?!).

what an experience !. I would say visit first during the day - it is a real shock to the system - like nothing i had seen before.Time your evening visit so you arrive before sunset and go up to one of the roof top cafes to watch the sunset and the hear minarets calling people to pray. A different place again in the evening. Bargains to be had and although every stall/shop you pass will try to sell to you they are not offended when you say no.
Amazing Experience. The medina contains the souks, the festival on the square (snake charmers, musicians, etc.) the spice market, the Berber museum, the Madrasa, the tanneries, etc. Amazing place.
not to be missed. if you dont go to the medina you will miss the vibe of marrakech and you might as well have gone to cleethorpes
Not bad. Worth going if you're close, but I did not see the major attraction. Some nice architecture, be warned of the many tourist traps
Exotic and wild. A wonderful adventure. Loved navigating through the narrow streets and enjoying the sights, sounds, and smells of this amazing place!

small change. I loved the ancient and colorful quality of the surroundings just the very reason one travels to Marrakech. Around each corner is a new sight of peoples,wares to purchase,foods to savor.Beware the shop keepers are aggressive you touch it they start to bargain. Bring small coins every photo of a person brought out hand for payment. A memorable experience
Pretty crazy place!. It's quite busy in the Medina, but we knew that before going and if you just relax and enjoy the hustle and bustle, you can have a brilliant time, which we did.
A must see visit. Very colourful and historic with motorbikes , cars, donkeys etc in narrow streets, perfect if you enjoy haggling.

A Jewel of North Africa. A fascinating bustling city, the Souks are incredible. There are Palaces, Riads, Gardens, Mosques, Squares, Tombs; amazing! Be ready to barter, if you wish to purchase anything the final price could be a quarter of the opening price.

Couldn't wait to get out!. Dirty smelly hell hole selling nasty overpriced tat but an experience nevertheless! We couldn't wait to get out but got completely lost and had to endure it for longer than we hoped.would never go back!
Crazy place to be, but must see!!!. Its big market where you can buy evertything, really everything. Very interesting just to walk around and browse :)
A different culture. Amazing spot to people watch...just don't take pics of the monkey handlers, snake charmers or colorful water-men.

No other reason to come here. Alcohol-free Zone though.. The whole area is just so different from a European perspective. However you will be hassled to a degree, but less-so than in Egypt. It is less dirty than Egypt. Watch out for mopeds zooming round corners!
Full of life. Amazing medina. You can just walk inside and around it for the whole day. So interesting to see the different wares being sold. Full of life and excitement.
Mental. Go by day and again by night - it's not a shopping trip it's an endurance test! - but you will be talking about it for weeks

A must. Busy vibrant mostly aimed at the tourists. The spice square is good but haggle if they ask 40 agree on 15 but be prepared to walk away.
Scarfs start at 300 we paid 70.
Remember to keep to the right when walking in the medina. Lots of people will offer directions all will want money!
Amazing. Went into the Medina five times. It is so vibrant & full of life. You get to see the real local life.

meedina. It feels like going into a labyrinth - you can get in but can't get out. Make sure you have a local guide. It's exciting to explore those small alleys in between old buildings! The shopping can be equally crazy - just make sure you have enough space in your luggage

busy busy busy. Busiest place I have ever been in my life. With horses and scooters riding around you makes you feel very werry. Its definitely place you must visit if you go to Marrekesh. When you go you must be up for negotiating price generally you can go half the price they say. Try not to ask anyone for favours because they are bound to ask for money even if they say it is free. Nothing is for free in Marrekesh except the tea maybe. My advice is to think about the things you want to buy before you go look at all the offers then you got an idea on what price you can get it for.

First Stop. This was our first stop upon arrival in Morocco. After leaving snowy Paris - what a treat to sit on a rooftop tea shop overlooking the medina. Sights and smells you will not see elsewhere. Musicians, food vendors, fortune tellers, leather ware, etc. etc.Wonderful people watching. All kinds of costumes worn by the locals.
Tacky and touristy. Smelly, cheap tat for sale, aggressive selling. Smelly, cheap tat for sale, aggressive selling. Best to say it twice.
brilliant. well worth looking around! can get some excellent stuff! wear sunglasses as as soon as you show any interest there all over you!
Dirty, 3rd world. Traffic - no respect for pedestrians. No order to the traffic - chaotic. Poor treatment, at best, of animals.
Tourist trap. The medina is just a market with the usual tourist tat and hassle.If you have never abroad before it might be fun but it gets waring as the hassle means you cannot look round in peace.

This is Marrakech. Walk around, bring a sense of humour, watch your wallet and realize that this is very similar to how it has been for a very long time. If you're being hassled the phrases "I'll come right back" or "I've just eaten, I'll be back tomorrow" work wonders. I don't simply ignore people, just be friendly but very firm and keep up the pace. And if you choose to buy, low balling is the name of the game, younger people tended to give us better prices.

Like stepping back in time. Walking around the Medina is like stepping back in time; it is truly fascinating and there is so much to see. One thing that really struck me was how friendly everyone is. It is busy and chaotic and there are people selling everything from vegetables, meat, fish, clothes, electrical goods etc. Locals weave in and out on their mopeds, which can seem a little intimidating at first. However, they always slow down and if they do drive close they always apologise. We walked around the Medina at all hours and always felt completely safe. The locals would smile and say 'hello' and although some shop keepers would be keen to entice you into their shops, they were never too pushy.

choas. This was a real look at how different the culture is. Lots of pestering you to buy things up to the point of becoming very annoying and resulting it total avoidance of stalls even if I'd wanted to buy things! Worth a look though !

Busy, hassley, interesting and very foreign.. This is what you came for, a busy city offering a different culture and sights and experiences you dont get at home. Try and get as much small change as you can as everyone wants some of your money. Things cost more than you imagine. The experience is rich and interesting. The sights captivating. Make sure you haggle and try not to be distracted away from the task you are doing by people trying to take you places to buy.
Great City. The souk is really a lot of fun! You have to see it. The highlight is the place Fna! You have to go after sunset!
Marrakech and Berber Camp Visit. service and extraordinary cultural experience. The Medina and the camel trek & camp where out of this world.
crazy. no map will help you, route finding is an art form, do not cheat with a GPS, just dive in and enjoy being lost

Medina Trip. We did an organised tour and I would strongly recommend this as it does look easy to either get lost or miss some of the best bits. The tour guides are very knowledgeable and proud of their city

Something to see once. I really found this to be a place where everyone was trying to sell something and it was quite agressive (I had a 3 year old child with me). I wouldn't go back but I do agree it was nice to see once.

Smile, talk and enjoy the medina!. The medina is first and foremost where people live and work. So please remember this when you wander round. Smile and chat, so many times local souk owners comment on the rudeness of tourists - sadly these are the ones they remember, not the majority who find the narrow alleyways and souks fascinating. Soak up the smells, the sights, the shopping - smile, chat and have fun!
Beautyful. I really like this medina because is clean, original, the people is friendly and you feel safe in there.You can walk and is not so anoying like in another cities.

Magical and Bustling. Spices, slippers, gorgeous pottery, cakes, carpets.....everything you ever dreamed of and more.A hawk called Rambo and another called Michael....altogether an amazing experience. Crowded but salespeople pretty cheerful.

Be prepared, but it's worth it.. ARRIVAL. The airport is Chaos. If you don't have a transfer, Taxis to the city will cost 150 Dir (about 15 Euro), or 200 to the outlining resorts.HOTELS. We stayed in a lovely 5 star Hotel, everything was good but the food was not hot (a common theme). If you are not aware, you WILL be charged about 7 Euro per room per day Local Tax when you leave.THE CITY. Medieval meets the 21st Century. The Souks are a bustling rabbit warren full of noise and colour. If you go to the main square in the evening (a MUST), you will be surrounded by noise, entertainers and food stalls. Be aware, if you take a photo of a snake charmer etc, expect to be harassed for some payment, but, to be fair, there isn't a lot they can do if you don't pay. Go see the Bahia Palace, it is amazing. Only to be surpassed, in my opinion, by the Jardin Majorelle. Yves St Laurants garden and final resting place. It alone was worth the trip.DEPARTING. There are some thing they don't tell you about the airport. READ your online check-in voucher. It will probably tell you to have it stamped at the airline check-in desk. If not you will stand in line for security for nothing, they will send you back. They have separate lines for Men and Women through security, it's a big hassle, as you don't find out until you are almost there then have to go join another line. The passport control takes FOREVER, allow enough time. And finally, the Duty Free will not accept Dirhams, so spend them before you leave.Have fun, it's one the Life Tickbox destinations.

Return to the "olden days". Inside the medina is unbelievably busy, the traffic is crazy, if you are trying to cross the road, don't stop - the motorbikes and cyclists will avoid you. The donkeys don't look well treated, so be aware of that, and in the main square you will also see animals chained up. Have plenty of 1 dirham coins as a question such as where is the... will be a request for one!

Very interesting. What a busy place! Well worth checking out. I guarantee that you'll never retrace your footsteps here. It's a pleasure to get lost in here, because you'll always find your way back to the main square.
Medina in Feb. Don't let the stress of haggling get to you. Enjoy the ride. It gets a little cold at night. Be friendly. Keep your wits. Wonderful city.

Great Fun!. Enjoyed wandering through the Medina, an awful lot less hassle than experienced in similar situations in other countries and a stroll in the park compared to Khan el Khalili in Cairo! I agree with a previous reviewer, maps are of little use, it is much better to use landmarks, it is a laugh when you are re tracing your steps, locals will offer help most genuine, some see it as a potential money making opportunity by offering their guidance! politely decline and they are fine. Everything is for sale here, haggle,enjoy! I was warned about the Henna Ladies who may grab your hand and start to tattoo before demanding money, I didn't experience this but did see it, but overall did not feel in the least frightened or intimidated.

Shopping. It is a very good place for shopping. There are hundreds of shops selling different things. You can buy shoes, fabrics, herbs, spices, wood boxes, lamps etc... But bear in mind that you must bargain with them NOT just a little.
Crowded, loud, chaotic, real!. After a few days you really get used to it! It really is how you would imagine a northern african city centre! Don't be afraid, just dive in! :-)

Great if you like being treated like a mug every two and a half minutes. Let me first say that this was by no way my first trip outside of the west so I was expecting everything that comes with being a European in Africa, Asia or wherever. Marrakech takes this to another level though. Most of the locals in the Medina dont hassle you and are fine. However theres a lot of them and a many of the others will. Its never thretening and we always felt safe no matter where we wandered but the hassle and disrespect is never ending and wears thin pretty quickly. Constantly being asked what you want, where you going, come into my shop etc etc. The locals just view you as a walking cash machine and have no respect for anyone foreign. They may come across friendly at first but unless you want to part with money that goes out the window. We were constantly lied to and treated like a pair of mugs. Dont go

Wonderful medina. Despite preception it is possible to learn to navigate the Marrakech medina as a visitor. Traditional map reading is off limited help, but land marks and different souks work. Within a few days we learned to navigate, love and even relax in the labyrinth that the is theMarrakech medina. even my mother,who was initially dubious now loves it and says medina feels homely and safe.

Fun shopping and soaking in the history. Had loads of fun in the souq, haggling over sparkly slippers and chatting in (my) pigeon French. Don't take it too seriously...so what if you are paying 'tourist' prices- as long as its cheaper than you'd pay in your home country it's a good deal! Felt very safe everywhere, only bad experience was being hand-grabbed by a couple of henna tattoo ladies who drew on mine and my friends hands then demanded money even though we had said no. Keep your hands in your pockets when you see them coming in the main square :-)

Magical, wonderful experience. We loved the medina and spent the better part of our four days in Marrakech there, just taking it all in! For our first day, we had a great guide, set up by our travel agent in advance. We highly recommend him - Abdelouahed Chahidi, mobile 0662357588. We toured with him for about 8 hours, including lunch, and became comfortable enough by the end of the day to return several more times without a guide. We haggled successfully for leather goods, spices and scarves. We enjoyed the snake charmers, monkeys, acrobats and musicians in the square. Went back two evenings and at the stalls - wonderful food and so entertaining! The Moroccan people are amazingly friendly - "big welcome" is their common greeting to Americans. An absolutely unforgettable experience, not to be missed!

You WILL get lost! but that is part of the fun!. The Medina is a labyrith and you will likely get lost several times, even if you have the greatest map. But it is safe and fun to just walk around and absorb the Moroccan life.If you are looking for a specific type of item there are different areas of the Medina that you should visit, ie leather goods, metal work, etc.
labyrinth. this is a magic labyrinth where you can spend the whole day hanging around, doing some shopping and seeing the life of morrocan

dont worry. really safe place everyone so polite, just ignore the beggers or give if you wish, no problems eating from the market just be sensible we ate at the stall recommended by trip advisor and had a wonderful cheap evening with lots of fn, remember to haggle with a smile in the markets, everything is negotiable except food

CRAZY!. The central square of the medina has everything you can imagin a trip to Morocco should have, snake charmers dancers, tamed monkeys, rugs and crafts of all kinds, but be perpared to pay for every photograph you take. Some of the crafts are not authentic so be careful what you buy. Have fun if you find something you want to purchase by haggling a bit over the price. They expect to give you a discount and remember to have fun with them. It can be tireing warding off the countless offers for unwanted services, but if you smile and tell them "maybe later" they will stop bothering you immediately.

The essence of Marrakech. The old walled city is what it is all about in Marrakech. Wherever you stay, go there and let it grab you. See the contrasts between the new and old ways of living in this wonderful city, enjoy the markets, try the food, watch the world go by.
Good Fun. Much easier and safer to get around the Marrakesh medina compared to Fez and much prefer it to Fez. Once you get your barrings it is not that hard to walk around without a guide.

Bustling. Be brave and let yourself be led off by a welcoming trader. The Medina is ancient and like a rabbit warren. Discover some great bargains in leather and scarves and spices. The smells and sounds are so evocative of the old trading history of the town. mind your back for the annoying motobikes.

Essential Marrakech. The Medina is the old walled city of Marrakech and if you go to Marrakech you go to the Medina - that goes without saying. In fact I would strongly recommend staying in the Medina itself as that is really where everything happens.The Medina is mostly a maze of small passages where cars cannot go and the only way to get around is to walk. At first it seems very alien to a westerner and perhaps just a bit scary - but there really is no need to worry as it is generally safe and most people are very friendly. It is very easy to get lost in the passageways and if you look lost you will probably get approached by someone offering to help you - watch out though because they will probably want to be paid for any help;The central attraction of the Medina is the huge and crazy Jemaa el Fna square where you will find snake charmers, monkeys, and all sorts of stalls and performers. You have to be careful here - any eye contact will get you embroiled with someone who wants money off you in one way or another. This to me was one of the most annoying things about the Medina as a whole - the people pestering you are like annoying wasps but you rarely get a beautiful summers day without the wasps and that is what the Medina is like - if you think this will spoil your enjoyment then don't go as it is part of what Marrakech is.The other great (possibly much greater) attraction is the souks - the miles of colourful covered passageways with a myriad of stalls selling all sorts of crafts and goods. This place is amazing - I cannot begin to describe the colour. smells, noise etc - it is not to be missed. You will be pestered to buy stuff but polite refusal will usually shrug them off. If you do want to buy anything then nothing is priced - you have to haggle - and remember whatever they ask for you need to at least half it before even considering a purchase. Also shop around as the price can vary vastly from stall to stall. And if you want the best price just start to walk away and they will chase you and offer a more reasonable price. This sort of haggling does not come easy to most westerners but it is quite fun really. Always remain polite - I found nearly all of the sellers to be very friendly - but sometimes painfully persistent.Also in the Medina I recommend you see the landmark Koutoubia mosque, the Bahia Palace, the El Badi Palace and the Saadian Tombs.Things to watch out for are the youngsters who bizarrely keep telling you a road is closed up ahead. Just ignore them - I am not sure what scam this would lead to - probably charging you to be led another way. We felt quite safe - have read reviews mentioning pickpockets and petty thefts and I am sure this happens so take care, I am fairly confident you do not need to be afraid of any sort of violent crime though and we felt quite safe walking around the passageways at night. The biggest danger you will face will probably be from the mopeds that zoom around weaving between the people - best advice is don't try to dodge them - it just confuses things - they will dodge you. Where there are roads in the Medina that have traffic they are hell to cross and there are no crossing so you just have to go for it and hope they wont run you over.The Medina is a historic gem that feels like it has not changed much since the middle ages. It is full of colour, noise, smell and excitement. It is very exhausting and you will feel the relief of getting back to your quiet riad or hotel after a day out. It is a great place to visit , a bit of a culture shock and all the better for it. It may not be to everybody's liking but I loved it.

Claustrophobia and harassment at your door... The Medina is a contained area of a dirty and downtrodden city populated by thieving untrustworthy locals whose sole occupation is taking advantage of tourists. If you like the idea of being walled-in for the added convenience of these folk, then it's a delight! Not for the faint-hearted.

Colorful and noisy medina but a lot of people asking for money. We arrived in Marrakech on a Saturday and left the day after for a tour to the desert. The one day in Marrakech made us decide to stay one day more on the tour and one day less in Marrakech as the people that are costantly asking for money made the stay very stressful. I love Morocco and I have visited many Medinas, but honestly the quality of the products of the souk of Marrakech is quite poor if compared to other cities (ie Fes). People (children and adults) are costantly asking for money, they start walking near you and even though you don't say a word to them they ask for money once you get to your destination to which they supposely "brought" you. Marrakech is indeed a charming city but I would put Fes as the "must see" Medina.

The most exotic part of Marrakech. This is without any hesitation the best part of the city and definitely the area where one should stay to discover Marrakech "as an insider". There you'll find the souks, most of the places of interest as well as the famous riads.In case you look for a really special place to stay we suggest Riad Monceau where we had a fantastic stay in early February.

Vibrant and colourful!. Loved the fact that all of life goes on right under your nose! The old part of town is truly like stepping back in time. The sights sounds and smells, music, stalls, souqs and shops were all a total assult on the senses, but I loved it.

A must see in Marrakech. The medina of Marrakech is a must see when visiting the city. It only takes a few hours to go through. We had a guide and I highly recommend having one. There is no entrance fees to the medina, but there are some small entrance fees for some of the sites within the medina.
Very fun. Could spend days walking around here and not see everything. Teaming with life night and day. Of course, keep your wits about you but we felt very safe and unhasseled here

A slice of another kind of life. After getting lost we ended up at the tanneries, and watched the men dip leather in large vats of liquid, holding mint sprigs to our noses to disguise the smell. We saw Berber women in their colourful clothes, and no end of men who wanted to tell us about their families in the UK, and show us to various places. Do not accept, they will ask for payment at the end. Wherever we went, people were selling things, in kiosks, in the souk, on blankets, you name it. You had to avoid eye contact if you did not want to linger, and walk purposefully on.

Entertainment. Visited both at night and during the day (very different). The night visit was great, vibrant, fun and wonderful aroma's from the many cooking areas. The day visit was less so, there was lots of entertainment like snake charmers but it lacked that evening atmosphere....worth a visit

Great place to get lost. We found the best places by accident, when we didn't know where we were going. All roads eventually lead to Place Jemaa el Fna (or in a circle), and if you know how to get your riad from there, you wil l be ok.

LOVE. I would get lost in its depths for ever.Beautiful colorful loud. Take a road and walk. accept the fact that you will get lost and be approached by "turist guides" which will take you to see their friends work the leather or what not. Very interesting but pricy because of all the tips. DO it.
Great, but a tourist trap. Very festive and worth a visit, but watch your belongings and personal space and the snake charmers, touts and Heena sellers are ruthless.

what a place!. There must be nowhere like this place! The mixture of all the sounds and sights is breath-taking. Constant invitations from the stall owners to come in and "just look" plus others, some very young, trying to get us to buy all kinds of everything.
a maze of little streets. this was a great atmosphere and you get a real feel for how marrakech was in the old days.lots of lovely little shopsand restaurants
An Eye Opener. Liked the vibrancy,the mix,the noise,the smells but keep your wits and your senses about you so easy just to get lost

Amazing experience, but one of the most difficult to navigate.... Just back from 5 days in Morocco, and it was perhaps, one of the most amazing experiences I've ever had. We stayed in the medina, thankfully close to Jemaa El Fna so we could always find our way back to the riad. Morocco is a beautiful country, but the medina of Marrakech is unbelievably challenging. The "streets" aren't marked, what's on one map is not on another, and with the sensory overload you'll experience this area can be too much. Advice for this area? Go in knowing that everyone will be asking for money, it will be noisy, loud, and dirty, and you'll probably wander the same streets again and again only to pass what you've been looking for. But, know that Moroccans are a very generous people and I never felt unsafe. It's bright, colorful, and something you should at least spend a day enjoying.
A wonderful colourful area. Lots of history hassle and fun.Dont get cross be polite and smile its all part of the culture. Horse drawn carriages look fun but in our experience 20 minutes is enough.

For a traveller not a tourist. I found Marrakech really livened the sences, The heat, the spices, the story tellers the pigeon trainers the snake charmers and the old fashioned entertainments. The Place Jemaa el Fna the most amazing night-time experience any where in the world. I felt safe.Restaurants on Ave Med V produced amazing French -Morocc themed food. Water sprays kept us cool on the hottest day. The red Tourist bus showed us around.... to the storks on the chimneys, to the golf course and to Jardin dela Menara..My only regret I did not - I did not take a day trip toOuarzazate and to Essaouira.
a feast for the senses. Lots to see and do wandering around the medina. Not too much hassle, but be firm in saying no! Wonderful shops, great tiles, ramparts, doorways and little workshops to see.

What a place!. I left for Marrakech apprehensive and not really sure what to expect but I have come back loving the city and wanting to return later in the year! I had read all the reviews, good and bad and in the back of my mind I was worried I was going to hate the Medina but I have come back loving it! The Medina has many sights to see including:The Jemaa el-Fnaa (the main square): By day full of snake charmers, men with Monkeys and ladies wanting to draw on you with Henna....all of which we steered clear of. The Henna ladies are a bit of a nightmare and grab you and try and draw on you but a firm 'La Shuckran', no thank you in Arabic seems to do the trick rather than taking in English or French to them. You have to be firm though. The atmosphere is great though and we went to the Cafe France to sit on the terrace and watch the world go by on three occasions. There are stalls selling orange juice and dried fruit and souvenir stalls all around with streets leading to the many Souks. By night the food stalls arrive along with the musicians and entertainers. It's mad but again has a great atmosphere. You will have men coming up and putting their arms around you to have pictures taken....one such group asking us for 100 euros! Keep small notes in a pocket so that you can give them say 20 dirhams and then show them you have no more although they will be pushy. A money belt is a good idea, one guy we met had had his wallet stolen in the square. We were told to eat at the inner stalls but getting there is tough with everyone trying to get you to eat at theirs. In the end we found a simple looking stall on one of the outside corners where it looked like only locals were eating...they didn't try and drag us in and they didn't have a big display showing what they were selling so we decided this was the place for us and had a lovely selection of kebabs, sausages and of course the gorgeous bread. The Square is touristy, my husband described it as the Blackpool of Marrakech, but it's fun and so long as you keeps your wits about you, you'll have a great time!The Souks: Wander and get lost, it's the only way to do it. There is so much to see and buy. We wanted to get a djellaba (the hooded gown the men wear) and went to the Maison du Kaftan which was horrendously expensive. At first we were quoted 1800 dirhams which is over a £100 for a plain one. We got him down to 600dh which was still far too expensive. A little wander further on and we saw a little covered market off the souks selling pretty much the same thing....opening price 200 dh which we eventually got for 160dh, about £12 and we really pleased with our bargain. Shop around for things, it's amazing how much of a difference in price there is from place to place and if you're not happy with the price, walk away. They'll probably chase you down or if not, try the next stall! We did a cooking class and went shopping at the locals food market. The fruit and veg was really good quality and our chicken was killed freshly for us, not for the faint hearted but you certainly knew what you were about to cook with and eat was fresh. The Tanneries: we weren't planning on a trip here but ended up doing a tour. Ask how much your guide wants before you go in. They tried to rip us off here by asking for 300 dh (about £25) after the tour which we refused to pay. You will be taken to a shop and given mint tea and shown all the rugs, bags, shoes and carpets they make and you will get the hard sell. I bought a bag but had been intending to and thought here was as good a place as any, especially after seeing what the men go through to make the leather. If you don't want to buy anything it may be worth trying to get out of going into the shop in the first place! The tanneries stink...pigeon excrement is used to soften the leather...the conditions are poor, men are up their necks in it and apparently the colourants used are no longer natural but chemical and carcinogenic which is a terrible shame but it is a real eye opener and we were really glad we went. We visited the Berber tannery so I'm not sure how this compared to the Arabic tannery.Museum of Marrakech and Ben Youssef Madrassa: the museum is quite small but a great example of the architecture. Everything is written in French so if you are English speaking it may be worth employing a guide. The Ben Youssef Madrassa was an Islamic college and shows how the students lived in small living quarters, apparently the better family you were from, the better room you got but they are all so small. Amazing building, definitely worth a look and quite cheap to get in.There is far more than just this in the Medina, you will have to choose what you want to do as there is so much to see. Some great little restaurants in the back streets and a few up market bars springing up. I can't wait to go back and see more!

Explore the medina. Don't get a guide.. You don't need a guide, but may want one so you aren't hassled. I would argue that you might want to be a bit more adventurous and explore the medina. Don't be ripped off, but get to know the people. It's way more fun.
Great experience. Expect to get lost and do not panic. This myriad of winding streets can cause confusion but the residents will always point you in the correct direction

sit and watch!!!. A fantastic place to wonder around and soak up the atmosphere, but then for your 2nd, 3rd time watch from a terrace with a cool juice in your hand and just watch the entertainment unfold.

It is what it is welcome to Africa. A medina is a square where business is done, there are spice stalls, eating places which serve cheap food and rather nice and loads of shops selling cheap replica rubbish in the main. The stall holders are ok for a while with their cockney accents and jokes but it all gets a little tedious after a while. I felt a little uneasy in places especially the back street areas, there were small gangs of youths simply watching, so have your wits about you, zip bags up keep hold or put wallets in front pockets and put your hands in too.If you're going to buy make sure you get what you pay for, one of our party purchased a bag and when they unwrapped it they got a damaged one. They will try and Sam you if you are naive.At night things are a little frantic and precarious. Mopeds everywhere some with lights often not. The food stalls come into their own tough in a big group you were aggressively targeted which could concern some people. Be firm and say no, don't take offence to banter, the food can be around £3 and is nice, the washing up and drying of plates Nd cutlery should not be watched. There s no alcohol here as it is in view of the mosque. Overall this is Africa and people are desperate for your money. Be careful what you buy as most is junk but go for the experience. One man helped us and took us via his shop, as they do in Egypt, Tunisia etc. we got some great crystals for clearing sinuses for a few pounds. He was a nice chap. Danger wise no different to a lot of cities in the UK keep your wits about you and try it once, that was enough for me.
Eye catching, jaw dropping. The old town is an amazing place, unlike any I have ever been. Shops, restaurants, hammams and hotels are all packed together in the old city walls. Definitely stay here!

Sensory Overload. Liked the vitality, colors & the pleasant aromas of the spices & the grilling of foods, but did not like the fact that those who are selling items, hastle you to the point of stalking you.

dangerous place. the place should probably be better cleaned and policed. Threatening entertainment artists and shopkeepers trying to shame you into buying. I can appreciate its historical importance but for us it was a bad experienceof a smelly labirynth populated by predatory aggressive sellers, animals and various vehicles.
Haggle Hard!. I enjoyed the haggling in the medina and felt safe at all times, remember to haggle hard to get what you want! And bring extra baggage to fit in all your purchases!
nice. look like india. Had a lot of pleasure to discover this place. at night it's very nice, eating outside on the streeets!

Best place to stay!. The medina is the best place to stay if you want to stay in Marrakech. Normally its a short walk to the big square. There are lot of riads in the medina, which are really cheap. A good riad is about 40 euros in the medina. BE careful though , lot of small roads, might get lost.

Barter, Wander, Eat, Drink and dodge mopeds !!. Go for a mint tea in one of the 'bars' before you take on this adevnture and prepare yourself for what is to come. This is not for the faint- hearted and sitting on the balconies of one of the restaurants whilst listening to the call to prayer is a great way to get your bearings.The square becomes alive at night with stalls and shops, lights and sounds to really make this an enjoyable experience. The food markets can be really pushy but you need to make your own choices and not be swayed. We ate at a number of the stalls and they range from the usual tagine, couscous and skewers to brains, calamari and goat. Try one of the smaller stalls where the locals are all sat with mint tea (very sweet) and rolls. The rolls are filled with mashed potato, egg, cheese. salt and chilli and are awesome.(plus they are only 50p and are good for the budget !) and very filling.Whilst wandering around the marlet and square there is also lots of entertainment and bartering to be done - but watch out for mopeds dashing everywhere or you will get mown down ! Also if you do go off wandering, beware of guides trying to 'help' as they will often take you to their own shop or require payment - but dont be over wary as some are very friendly.The main square at night is truly amazing and a definite visit whilst in Marrakech.

Loved it!. The experience cannot be adequately described. Do your research beforehand and come prepared. It can be overwhelming, especially the negotiations. Don't forget to bring a sense of humor and a warm smile.

A mad rush for what's in your pocket by young and old make Marrakech a tough experience to like.. From the moment you enter the Medina (old town) of Marrakech your in a world dominated by the business of getting your business and money. Open a map and instantly more than one child or adult will latch themselves to your side asking or guessing your destination. Even if you are within feet of a place you know well, these "helpers" will, when you try and enter your destination, demand money for the help they claim they gave you. if you do give them something, they then complain that it isn't enough.It's never enough.Merchants or their barkers cut you off in front of most souks. No matter what one says to these persistent fellows, they will continue to harass you until a guy from another souk or restaurant takes over. It makes for a very unpleasant shopping experience to say the least.The taxi drivers are thieves with licenses. Though no trip in or around the Medina should cost more than 20DR, we had drivers ask for 200+!The Jamal El Fna is another place you won't enjoy. Walk past the acrobats and you'll be rushed by two or more of the troupe. They won't ask for a donation, they'll demand money! If you refuse they'll probably jeer "Go home!"The food stalls offer the same kind of assault and are best avoided.My wife and I have traveled all over the world and we both agree that the red city has little to offer. Prices are as high as most of Spain, conditions are meager at best and there is no beauty there. It's hard to believe that we could spend 6 days (if you have to go, 2 should be tops) in a new land ad find it empty of beauty. Yes, the inside of our Riad was beautiful, but as soon as we stepped through the door of this manufactured loveliness, we found ourselves in a town without natural beauty. None.The other aspect of Marrakech that disturbed us was the undercurrent of animosity shown us and other travelers when we strayed into areas the locals claimed we should not be in. Those areas, by the way were the very neighborhoods where our Riad was located!All in all, if you must find better weather or an exotic destination travel anywhere but this place.

The Souks. We had no problems with Haggling but the constant hassling from traders to look at their goods and enter their shops was extremely wearing. As a result we only spent 2 hours at a time in the Souks.

Beware the Snake and Monkey entertainment. Atmosphere is lovely but if you take pictures of the Snake Charmers and Monkey Owners they home in on you for payment. Also, the "unregistered" Guides hassle you at every turn. But the Souk is a nice place to explore
