overload. amazing place - my first time in marrakech & I loved the medina. Bartered, ate, stayed, drank, did it all - a full-on experience of sounds & smells & sights.

An exotic spot!. We stayed in the heart of the medina while in Marrakech and felt that it really added to our enjoyment of our holiday. We were able more clearly, and on a daily basis, how people go about their daily lives. I would recommend staying in the medina rather than in a nice modern hotel in the new town.
Exciting. Exciting but one could get lost but there are many to help you find your way at a cost!!! Lots of colourful shops and some wonder restaurant serving delicious tagines.

Twists and turns but great fun.. Easy to get lost in but someone will set you on the right track. The square is worth seeing during the day and lit up at night with food stalls in their hundreds. Snail soup to kebabs and salads available in different stalls.For shopping visit 144 in the medina. A veritable Aladins cave of household furnishings, furniture and objects d'arts.
Absolute Madhouse. Something no to be missed but completely crazy. Traffic goes in all directions. The noise has to be experienced.

Vibrant Colour and Sound. Plan to do a lot of walking to get the most out of a visit to the Medina. Its a facinating place with lots to see. The stalls are full of colourful and interesting articles and the salemen are less aggressive than in Turkey or Egypt. Be sure to haggle as the first offer is likely to be more than 3-4 times what you can get it for.

It's a must see, but be prepared. The medina in Marrakech is the old city, surrounded by the ancient walls and a cost metropolis of cafés, restaurants, souks, mosques and the Jemaa El Fna. It's your gateway to Marrakech's tourist points, but can be exhausting.The medina is the light that draws tourists in, but it can be exhausting constantly being on your toes with touts, unofficial guides trying to take you where you don't want to go as well as shop keepers pulling you in.I would advise a day to explore when you have no where to be, but be prepared for a barrage of attention.
A wonderful place!. Lovely shops, friendly people. it can be a bit scary with the motorbikes driving up behind you. Just remember keep on the right, don't dodge them let them dodge you! :0

It's where the action is at. If visiting Marrakech for the first time, you're bound to go to the Medina for a visit - it's where the big souks are located. It's quite a spectacle. Make sure you go early when you're energy levels are high as you will be bombarded with sales pitches that can become rather tiresome later in the day.

Strange. You are return to the middle age when you see the environment but well modern due to the scooter in the street that replace the horse. You will also find behind doors some Ryad that will change your view of the Medina. Inside the Medina you will also find some souk where you can buy anything from dress, wood, tea service& spices. To view once in Life!

Unforgettable. The Medina is one of those places everyone should visit at least once - a wonderful mix of shops and booths from fresh food to leather shops and carpet emporiums, and a mix of people from all across Northern Africa and Europe
You can't visit morocco and miss this. It's just like a medina in Malta except more decrepit. What else has Marrakech got so you might as well see.

Eye opening. It's like stepping back in time, a wonderfull place. There is so much to see, but be warned, there are people wanting to act as your guide and they are not doing it for the good of there health, they will want payment.

Dive on in and enjoy. It just has to be done Everything you would expect noisy busy mad but fun Men will just say they want to practice english and are not guides while demanding you follow them to the 'non tourist bits ' for a 'real Berber' market Its all part of the game Just say no

Loadsa Stuff and great atmosphere. I arrived expecting pushy, aggressive salesman, but thankfully it was some friendly banter, the odd mimic of a scottish accent, but on the whole it was a fascinating atmosphere- with everything under the sun in one of the millions of stores.

Very scary but fun. We got a little lost; men try to show you the way, but they only want to take you to their shops to sell you things, so say no thank you.
If you just take your time you will be able to find things yourself; it was really fun.

A proper Medina. Exactly as you'd expect - dark, windy and easy to get lost with lots of little squares inside and the same goods over and over again. Be prepared to haggle hard, and make sure you know the way to the bar when you've tired yourself out.

Full of Life. It is truly a very lively place with a lot going on especially at night with all the lovely food stalls, music, dancers, etc. The people are very lively too. I found that the people in Marrakech were very happy and content perhaps because they are still at some distance from smartphones, internet, and other technological gadgets.
Fun and annoying. The medina is interesting and fun, but it gets tiring having everyone always trying to make money from you.

A glimpse of old Morocco. All large cities in Morocco have a Medina- the heart of the city. Built like an old fortress, they feature small streets, an intriguing labyrinth of merchands' boutiques and tables, loud...and man dominated environment...well except the women that will do the henna design on your body.

Old city of Marrakech. This fascinating old walled city is a maze of winding streets with littles cafes and bars, riads, hammams, which is bustling with life, doinated by the Palce of the King ( Mohammed VI) the kasbah , the great Mosque and the saadian tombs. I went on the guided tour first and then returned alone to esplore by myself.

Old. It's really nice to see the old medina as it has stayed this way for years. Leaving modern and Western Nouvelle city (the new part of Marrakesh) behind you, this will give you the real Marrakesh experience.
best part of marrakesh, dont miss it!. Amazing. We liked getting lost a little but we had a mobile phone from our hotel mk so felt secure that we could call them ...we didnt need to!

Amazing spectacle. Its everything you read and hear about it...like a scene from a biblical movie. Snakes, monkeys, donkey carts, mad motorcyclists, noise, smells, crowds, ....great fun ....just let it happen around you.

WIth motorbikes racing around everywhere this was not as pleasant of an expereince as Fez. Compared to Fez the fumes from all the motorbikes distracted from the experience not to mention the dodging to keep from getting hit by one.
Mental. Truley crazy place.Haggle like mad and get a great price because you can.Get lost because you can.Get taken by someone of the street to show you around for a small fee because you can.

This is the place to stay, not just to visit briefly. There are many fine Riads (mansions) hidden deep inside the Medina. Getting there from the airport can be a little challenging so get your Riad to arrange a pick up.But the experience of arriving and having to make the last part of the journey on foot is unforgettable. Wandering around is just an amazing experience.Why would you come to Marrakech and not stay in the ancient city (the Medina)?

Amazing!. The Medina is the location for so many of the best sights in Marrakech, but it is also a phenomenon in itself. It's great to just wander round, and as you get away from the main square, the Place Jemaa El Fna, you get to see the shops and stalls that ordinary Marrakchis use. Different districts offer jewellery, old-fashioned tailors' shops, crafts etc, and there are some amazing little museums tucked away, like the Dar Si Said. If you get really lost, just ask a passing woman or respectable looking man for 'La Place' - someone will point you in the right direction.

Get Lost in the Medina!. An absolutely wonderful place to get lost... find your way and get lost again wandering amongst all sorts of intriguing stalls... down tiny winding alleyways and finding your way up to a roof top to sip a mint tea and watch the sun set.

Difficult to believe this is 3.5 hours from London!. To find another place as foreign, shocking and interesting as the Medina you need to spend 8 hours on a plane. The Medina is exotic, challenging, fascinating, smelly, entertaining, cinematic and frustrating. It's like being in India but on a smaller scale!

A wonderful experience. A real adventure if you are brave enough to wander around the winding narrow lanes and cope with the never ending offers of "help" which always mean paying someone for directions etc.

The most unique market I have ever see. Take the time to get lost and walk trough the small paths. Even though it doesn't look like, I felt very safe to walk by myself day and night, it's defintily NOT necessary to pay guides. Don't listen whoever tries to convinces you otherwise. Lots of people will try to sell you things, don't stress and remeber you're in vacations, in their country.

Lives up to its reputation!. As with all areas of this sort, one must be prudent against the pick-pocket. Otherwise, a great place to shop and spend a leisurely day browsing the various handicraft stores. Part of the experience is to bargain your purchases. Never accept the first price and offer what you think the merchandise you want is worth. In the evening, take a Moroccan mint tea on the terrace of one of the cafés overlooking the square and soak in this incomparable atmosphere.

Noisy, mad and interesting - be prepared. We have just returned from our first trip to Marrakech - 4 nights for my husband's birthday. Stayed at a wonderful Riad in the Medina (Riad Kniza) and spent a lot of time wandering the streets of the Medina. The markets are intriguing and an assault on the senses ... however, what became quite tedious was the constant hassling by young men, asking if you want directions. If you showed any interest or even asked for help, they would then want money! Be prepared, we tried to be polite but after 3 days of it, it became rather tiring. Other than that, we felt safe in the Medina, despite the hustle and bustle. ...

Amazing place. Allegedly the Spiritual and historical heart of Marrakech. Totally different day and night. Once used to display the heads of executed criminals it now displays some strange and wonderful sights. A must see in daylight and at night.

Very different. Marrakesh is completely different from North America/Europe. Take some time to adjust to the cultural differences first, then wander into the Medina. It's very fun, but very different. Take some time to look around yourself and get familiar with landmarks. It is very easy to get lost, wander outside the medina and then end up paying too much for a taxi. Be sure to bargain for everything - offer half or less of the asking price as a starting point. There is no telling what the actual price for the goods are, and you're likely still getting screwed, but enjoy it - Morocco is a poor country, and it won't hurt that much. Be sure to eat the food, it's delicious and plentiful. Go to the bathroom in your hotel or find Les Bains de Marrakesh or La Maison Arabe - these are up to western standards for bathrooms where the rest are not. Also, wear durable shoes that you can get dirty (blood, feces, water, etc will be on the street). This is overall a fascinating place, so just walk around and enjoy it. La Maison Arabe has a GREAT restaurant and there are several very nice pastry shops in the medina.
Amazing!. We saw everything from snake charmers, herb doctors, donkey pulled wagons to a Palace in the Medina. Definitely a cultural adventure.
Autentic. This is like travelling back in time. Friendly people, who of course try to sell you everything as expencive as possible, so do not forget to bargain. Easy to get lost.
Comentary. Must. A completely different from Western culture.population attentive, very good security, no problem.Prices are great and a magical place.

Crazy place. Marrakech medina is crazy but fun if you set out to enjoy it. Lots of haggling, but if you don't want, don't buy.You will like it. But you will be happy to get back to the calm of your riad at the end of the day.
Amazing. Amazing, short of words to describe the experience. Just make sure you visit the medina, it's colorful in every sense of the word.

See anything and everything. I've seen places like this only ever in movies before and to be fair they do not even come close to doing justice to this busy, bustling place. My expectations we're blown out of the water. It appears to be a scene of complete chaos with all manner of things happening. There is plenty of music happening, some of it from snake charmers, plenty of fruit stalls with a broad selection of local produce, spice sellers with their spices shaped into pyramids, people with monkeys looking to have their pictures taken with you for a small price and of course the local traffic of horses, donkeys, bicycles, motorbikes, cars and trucks all making their way through the Medina. A very interesting place which I could have sat and watch the happenings and goings on for hours.

Could have walked around the Medina for days... and nearly did!. The Medina in Marrakech is simply amazing. There is so much culture hidden away in the endless alleyways that make up this Medina. Many times we had to ask directions out because we had walked in circles and gotten lost... but that is what makes it so amazing! It is huge and you can shop and haggle to your hearts content. A must see and do in Marrakech! We saw families, couples, singles, just about everyone walking around the Medina, so take the kids during daylight hours and have a blast... make sure they stay close by though!

Fun and exotic. Our riad was in the medina, so we had to learn our way about quickly, which we did by being shown landmarks and following good maps. Every step has exotic visuals, though taking pictures of people is not approved (for either men or women). Fortunately digital cameras can pull in people from overall views. Aside from the photo issue, people are wonderfully friendly.

Does not disappoint!. If you have an image of Marrakech as being a maze of winding alleys and souks, then the Medina does not disappoint. Though only making up one part of Marrakech (there is also the 'new city'), the Medina is a huge walled area of old Marrakech, with the Place Jemaa el Fna at its center. One can easily get lost in the alleys, some of which go through market areas (souks) with vendors hawking everything from leather goods to spices to metal lanterns. Here and there are doors of hidden riads (traditional homes, many of which were turned into small hotels).The main square is a raucous assembly of outdoor food stalls, orange juice sellers, vendors with goods laid out on the ground... and at night add musicians, transvestite dancers and other performers to the mix.Be careful with your belongings, as in any crowded area, and don't spend time looking at an item in a stall and bargaining unless you really want to buy it, as you will not be let go easily. As before taking photos of any people.

Thought it would be scary - but NO!. A bustling area of snake charmers, musicians and market stalls. No excessive pressure to buy from the stalls and actually quite friendly. Well worth a visit but be aware of the 'guides' that may attach to your group expecting a tip.

No problems. We had absolutely no problems with persistent locals or attempts to guide (or misguide) us. Nor were the mopeds a problem once we appreciated the need to keep an ear and eye on them. The experience was wholly positive. We thoroughly enjoyed, and thoroughly recommend, a jaunt through the Medina. We even managed to fail to get properly lost - at the end of the day all roads eventually lead back to Jemaa el-Fnaa. A reassuringly high police and military presence - and according to our Riad a fairly high plain clothed police contingent. Not keen on the monkeys and snakes in the square but they are easy to avoid. Obviously if you are in Marrakech you are going to visit the Medina and, on the basis of our experience, there is absolutely no reason not to visit and enjoy the area. Personally I would vote for dressing reasonably - we saw some almost comic postcard visitors from the UK who were missing only the knotted handkerchief but even they received only a bemused and bantering reception.

A Medina where time is trying to stand still. With Africa's busiest Public Square, numerous Souks (lattice-covered market streets) and Palaces carefully guarded, the Marrakech Medina could be 1920 or 1850 if the cars, buses and scooters were prohibited. My fantasy. The big square is a throng of donkey-carts, musicians, Fortune Teller Berber women. Snake charmers and their helpers who will drape a harmless water snake around your shoulders the moment you stop to stare at the swaying Cobras. Fruit sellers and Nut sellers have semi-permanent stands and a fresh squeezed juice is small change. You can rent a carriage and 2 frisky horses for an hour for the price of a decent lunch and trot around the walls of the Medina after you post your cards at the Post Office. In the mid afternoon, cartloads of metal frams and canvas covers begin to erect the night market open restaurants which feed everybody whatever ethnic cusine appeals to them for a good price. The noise is deafening I suppose but around the corner and into a covered street, you can't remember where it was.At night while the Square is still throbbing with life, the streets of the Souks close up and the streets are swept soon to be empty, dark and mysterious. We learned to find a larger street with lamps to get back home to our Riad in the residential area off Dar El Bacha, next to the Queen Mother's Palace, supposedly a pedestrian street but a popular route for scooters, the bain of the Souks.The Medina has become too expensive a place to live for the workers who populate the Souks and shops that line every lane wide enough to permit a stall and a passage in front of it. I was impressed with the lack of cheap foreign-made goods in the Souks. Workshops were everywhere making wooden screens and window frames and doors, traditional footwear, pottery and pictures, dishes and pots and pans. The Museums and historical sites are sprinkled throught the Medina, all within walking distance and every one a lovely oportunity to get out of the sun into the calm of a old Riad or Palace to see the story of the city in photographs and artifacts and costumes. All worthy to visit and most with a quiet place to enjoy a cup of tea preferably Mint hold the sugar! Getting lost in the Medina is an essential part of visiting Marrakech and the friendly people are delighted to help you find your way. Remember that Mosques are not open to non-muslims which is a shame because they are often lovely in their own right.

History of North Africa.. Architecture and artefacts that have survived over many hundreds of years and remain as evidence of a sophisticated culture which influenced and was influenced by many and varied peoples from across the globe.

bustling with life. the medina is THE place to in marrakesh. you can find everything you need there. if you stay in the outer areas, away from Djemaa el Fna you will get a good impression of authentic marrakesh

OMG. ... This place is crazy. Overwhelming fun! Make sure you have an OJ and eat at Stall number 100! Yoseph might have scary teeth but he's super friendly and the food is fab. No stomach aches!!! We went back twice!

Amazing Energy and Confusion. Amazing experience, from narrow alleys to wide open chaos of jemaa al fna square. The walls are impressive, as are the must see katoubia mosque gardens, saadian tombs and museum of marrakesh.

Beautiful historic place.. This is a step back in time, cars, motorbikes and donkeys all travel along the winding streets. If you have never travelled to anywhere like this be prepared, there are people begging, old people, women and children. It's a very safe place though and you don't feel threatened.

Delightful chaos. There is little different about this Souk than any other in the Middle East. Chaos - people trying to show you the way (when you know it) Others trying to get you to buy their products. The most annoying part was those who told you that the direction you were heading was "closed". We took to telling those who tried to direct us by the Main Square that "La Place est Fermee!" This confused many of them - who denied it - but we nodded sagely saying "Oui Oui - Fermee" Some of them realised the joke and burst out laughing - others - looked at us as if we were mad! - but it kept us sane!

different and buzzing... Interesting place to visit, the monkeys, snakes, ladies using henna, Berber dancers etc.. and the old souq.just be warned if you take pics, most people will charge you, even in the public spaces, its how they make their living and they can be very forceful.

A step back in time. A trip to the medina is like going back in time. In the day there are juice sellers, snake charmers, teeth pullers and countless others trying to sell you something. At night it's transformed into a theatre with restaurants, story tellers and women trying to give you a henna tattoo. it's chaotic but well worth it. People do hassle you to buy stuff or eat at their restaurant but generally if you say no they dont pursue you (not like they do in Egypt!) and there are plenty of police in the square at night. Nowadays its more regulated than in times gone by.You do need some coins to give to anyone you do business with whether it be buying something or paying for taking pics etc. They want money for everything but no more than 10 dirhams for a picture. Just stand your ground! And if you don't want a henna tatto you need to be really firm as those women will start to do it even if you've said no so stick your hands in your pockets and walk away - don't debate!For the first visit I advise going up to one of the rooftop terrace cafes and just getting your bearings before you dive in. Cafe Chegrouni is really nice and Cafe Glacier has great views. If you go to Marrakech its a must do.

could go both ways. Positives were that the sites were gorgeous, weather good (day time nice and warm, evening gets a little cold), lots to buy and great places to eat and drink mint tea.Negatives were the constant stream of traffic in really small alley ways, the constant haggling and bartering and pestering of the shop keepers, also be aware of the people who just decide to walk with you and take you places when you look lost-which is frequent sue to the style of the city.Tips: always have change in your pocket rather than your wallet, always avoid beggars, keep bags close and stay together. Never do anything without agreeing a price first and tip everyone who helps 10dh is enough, 20dh they are happy with.The best part was the food.... try mishwe yuuummm

Wonerful city. Just walking in the medina is a big part of the visit to Marrakech. Find time to get lost, avoid "guides" and go on an adventure! The smartphone-app CityMap2Go can give you an offline map with GPS to iPhone if you want to find your way again. Try to go away from the tourist streets and find hidden gems behind small doors.

untouched city. although i had little time to see lots of things, i still find medina more interesting than the new city. especially loved the beauty of Medersa Ben Youssef, amazing tile work, ornaments on walls and ceilings. you can actually walk into this madersa and check out every little rooms where young divines used to study in while many mosques aren't open for non-muslims. you'd better look out and hold your purse tight when you walk along a path as many motorcycles and donkey carts might careen into you. watch out for donkey droppings too.

See it but be focused!. You have to go to the Medina of Marrakech and you must wind your way through all the vendors, snake charmers, beggers, cars, trucks, horses, bikes, motor bikes, all zipping past you every which way with almost no notice that you are there. When you get back from the Medina you will notice your clothes smell especially in the winter. Just smoke, fumes from vehicles big and small, god knows what else. But its the most colorful vibrant place, with everything and everyone! The poorest people in the world then suddenly a women can pull up in a Porche Cayanne and the police watch her car. The shops are cool, the streets that wind all over seem like a giant maze. Cats fighting on the roofs the call to prayer in the Medina is really cool. But most of all I read in a book people will leave you alone if you dont like to be bothered if you have a mission be focused keep walking in one direction and barely glance at things until you feel comfortable. If you see something you want haggle to death for it, but be willing to walk away in a friendly manner.All in all its a fun place but dont let the shear overwelming smells, sounds, activity, and total crazzyness get to you.

A little exhausting place to stay more than one day. My wife and I stayed in Marrakech for 3 days.We were somehow expecting an interesting world heritage. But we finally found it dirty and we were annoyed with many people bugging us for money purposes.Many shops in this medina seemed to be used to travelers. But rather used to ripping off travelers. To be honest, we felt relieved when leaving. I guess one day is enough to see.

Great fun!. Apart from being somehow a "dip in the past" and very pretty to look at, the Medina is fascinating and a great place to shop. Be aware, they will rip you off! Always negotiate the prices... they will still rip you off, but at least not as badly...

Back in time. Just like the movies. Facinating place. The central square is full of activity both day and night. Everything I expected and more. People can be a bit aggresive. If you are taking pictures of the snake charmers from a distance they will run up to you and ask for payment. A small amount will get you up close and personal with the snakes. Lots of activity, story telling, dancing, and music at night but quite daunting being among those many people. Didn't quite feel safe. Guides will tell you hold on tight to your personal belongings and I believe it. Tours through the market are advised. You could get quite lost very quickly. Guides will take you to their favourite places (commission). Watch the prices. They will try to charge you 40.00 euros for a scarf that you can but at the store for 15.00 euros. If you speak French great but most of the people in the market speak their local language. Probably wouldn't ever go back but glad I saw it once. Quite the experience.

Culture shock in the best way!. Exciting, vibrant and evocative, the medina is a wonderful place to spend your days in Marrakech. The streets are full, of stalls, people and mopeds, but pretty safe despite all that! Its a wonderful mix of sights, smells and sensations, and we saw it all, even with a tiny baby. A wonderful place to visit.

Marrakech at it's best. The medina (old city) has so much charm. There are markets, restaurants, night life all close together. The medina is very safe, and people are more than happy to point you in the right direction or help you if you need it! If you are planning to purchase something at the souks I recommend visiting the jewish market close to the Bahia and El Badia Palaces as it is much less expensive, and the pressure to purchase is much less.
Unique. There is nowhere else in the world quite like this old city. Being there transports you into a past way of life, and staying in a riad within the Medina enhanced our stay in Marrakech

Possibly the cleanest place on earth. Clean, interesting, diverse, not to be missed. There is a massive difference between day and night so be sure to go at both times. A pocketful of coins is useful to buy bits and pieces and to give to the sick and needy.

A Bit Wearing. Loved the alleys and peeking into the beautiful courtyards, but we didn't dare stop to look at our map because we were beseiged by people and children wanting to show us the way - unfortunately they always wanted payment and we had to go to the tannery or a carpet shop where they would get a tip from the owner. It is a fascinating place and, despite the "helpers" we loved it.
Ok. The stalls were very similar. owners were too persistant...would not take no for an answer.Very interesting place.

Go and get lost inside. Take sensible shoes. Forget about being guided by a map and have some wit about you. There are lots of police patrolling the medina dressed in civilian clothing. Do not take pictures of stalls as they come and ask for money but you can take pictures of a group of stalls or people without being harassed.

it is interesting to see. If you are a traveler and curious person, you should definitely see it! I probably would not go back, but I am happy I have visited it. It is quite dirty and messy, and smelly, because of all these cars and motorcycles going like racing these narrow streets and animals everywhere. Lot of poor people living on the streets. People were spitting on tourists... I do travel a lot, its the first place I saw things like that, not really welcoming. I saw some tourists with small kids; I would not do this.

Heart of Marrakech. You cannot stay in Marrakech withou a visit to the Medina. If you see something you want to buy do not show any interest in the item and be prepared to haggle like mad, even to walk away.
The Bustle is Friendly. The appeals of such a vast bazaar are obvious. We were especially struck by the innate courtesy of the tradespeople and ordinary residents, though not by the motorbikers.

Intimidating and Mesmerising. It's a mesmerising experience. Not so pleasant however. Young males are hugely intrusive and will aggressively approach with their bizarre banter at any time you stop walking for a few seconds: "...This is closed (a street / alleyway).... Come THIS way......". A few times you can ignore this, but it's all the time.. Young men on scooters are intimidating as they whiz by within inches - or brush you in the narrow lanes. Take a photo - and you're aggressively challenged.Access is difficult because many Riyadh (ours was good: El Mazouar: a haven) are inside the 'no-car-zone'. Taxis?: to get to anywhere outside the Medina they are essential: some drivers are fine, but others, having negotiated a price more than the previous one on the outward journey, are relentlessly intimidating; have the right change, or they will not give you the balance. One day in the Medina, at most two, is beyond tolerance.The real Marrakech? Yes. But think twice about how much you can take.

Experience the true Marrakech. Staying in a riad in the medina will mean you get to see the city and all it's different personalities! It is an attack of the senses and like nothing I had ever experienced before. Getting "lost" in the souks is a must. Have a good small map and you will never truly get lost.People are welcoming and even helpful but will take advantage of a polite soul, i.e. if you look like you have an empty head and a thick wallet they will be glad to help you lighten it. Don't trust everyone who tries to direct you - just consider what their intentions are.

experience of a lifetime. love it, soo exciting, teeming with people and stalls, so colourful and entertaining and yet we felt really safe, we bought shoes and bags and belts and delicately flavoured coconut macaroons, and took lots of photos of the teethpulling man and the waterman,and ate at a rooftop cafe looking down at the crowds and ate tagines and drank mint tea- brilliant

Spend a Day Losing Yourself in the Souks. The medina is crazy and exhilarating but once you get the hang of it it's amazing. So many streets and stores to see. Usually a good idea to plan ahead and get a sense of what you want to see. If you get lost no big deal, you tend to end up at the Jemaa el Fna. There is great shopping - we bought jewelery, bags, tea sets, traditional clothes. Also really good food, either stopping to try snacks or at a nice restaurant.

The heart of Marrakech. I just love the Medina and the atmosphere here. It's the prime reason for my visit. Worth going several times if you can as it's different during the day compared to the evening.
Beautiful and dazzling. The souks are amazing but quite overwhelming, one needs a few days to get used to it. But its a wonderful atmosphere and so much happeing!

Google Maps will be useless. Marrakech is a great place for families to travel. We never felt threatened or worried. Traveling as a family we were welcomed with open arms and big smiles. The people of Marrakech appreciate the tourist dollar and want you to come visit. Both my daughte rand myself dressed appropriately for the local custom, which I feel helped us have a wonderful experience.The Medina is the area you probably want to stay while visiting Marrakech. It is a twisted labrinyth of alleys filled with souks (shops) and food stalls. We never tired of the Medina and enjoyed the haggling, the smells (cat urine usually dominates), the people, the spices, the food, AMAZING!!. This is such an amazing location for a trip. At first it may be overwhelming but just take your time and in just an afternoon you will never want to return.

Medina is the place to be. Medina is the old town. The square Jemaa el-Fnaa is the the center-piece of the Medina. The hotels in the median are called Riads. If you haven´t spent at least one night at a riad you haven´t been in Marrakech.

More than I expected!. The Medina including the Square is magical! We stayed within the Medina and had wonderful and crazy experiences throughout each day there! If you consider yourself a world traveler this place is a must for you! The sounds and sights will be with me forever. My husband of course loved the snake charmers, my son enjoyed the people in all and I think my favorite was the food! At night the lights, the music and the hustle all around create a delightful experience the senses are overwhelmed! We did eat street food as well as food at restaurants that was delicious! The haggling for purchases was not too bad, usually vendors were respectful. Only on occasion were a few snarly guys! It was a huge place, but we didn't need a guide. Just go slow, count your landmarks and watch out for speeding motorbikes!

What an experience!. Better than NYC where I find it overwhelming already. Steel yourself for the constant pitching and polite "no thank you-ing" you will have to endure, but it's well worth your time to engage because this is an incredible place, full of lovely people. Wow. Can't wait to spend real time here.

Life hasn't been lived until you visit the Medina!. A most remarkable Medina ! My husband and I disagree on this one - he prefers the Marrakech Medina for its variety and more level walkways; I prefer the one is Fes for its authenticity - but the bottom line is that you have to visit both !! A great place to see!

Crazy but an amazing place. We visited the Medina twice during our stay and both times we got very lost but everyone does and that is definitely part of the fun. It is a crazy place but there is so much to see and enjoy it is definitely a must-see place if you are visiting Marrakesh. Before I went I was warned about what I should wear and what I should expect and overall I would say most of the accounts are true. I dressed modestly and covered my legs and shoulders whilst in the Medina and the Square and received no harassment. The stall holders will call you in the narrow streets and try to entice you into their shops, many will try very hard to make a sale but on the whole they are friendly and polite so do not pose any threat. We also found that they tend to enjoy haggling with tourists so it is definitely worth it especially as many of the stalls sell identical items so they don't want to lose your custom. Watch out for mopeds and bicycles as they zip through the narrow streets inside the Medina! It is a fantastic place even if it is a little crazy and can be a bit of a culture shock but the majority of people are perfectly nice just don't be afraid to haggle!
Underwhelming. Just not very interesting, or special, you can see this sort of architecture around North Africa in much better places or in Southern Spain
Mannic Medina. Hustle and bustle, hundreds of mopeds, bicycles and people. Lots to look at. Didn't always like to be hassled when 'just looking' A bit off putting, but all part of the show.

Dirty place, touristc city. We spent 2 days inside the medina in marrakech and I must say that if compared to other cities of Morocco the medina in marrakech is a really a dirty place. this is even more true if you wal in the Souq near the main square. The people over there sometimes behave rude with the tourists. People try always to trick and gain some money. Do not do picture of people and market, always demand first or leave them a tip which they will ask you, anyway.The medina preserve good walls which give the idea of the ancient time in the city. It is easy to get lost the first time because the streets are very complicated, but this is just the first time. You will manage alone once you get used to it.

Lost in Marrakech. You will get lost, everybody dose, but that is part of the fun. The locals are mostly happy to help, but a little warning, some of them will demand money, but hopefully you will only fall into that trap once.
Souks. Noise, variety and something new every day! Polish up your bargaining skills! Spices, furniture, jewellery... whatever you want!

s'ha de veure -worth to see it. s'ha de veure, malgrat que tothom et vol vendre coses. Recomanaria comprar al final, quuan ja els saps esquivar.Worth to see it, eventhough everybody tries to sell you something. We recommend shopping the last day, so you know how to avoid some sellers

Hotels or riads. We recently stayed at one of the top rated riads in Marrakesh and found the exuberant rave reviews so untrue and exagerated that we will not trust this for future stays. If we had to do this again we would stay in well known international hotel chains.We paid 4 star hotel rates and received 2 star values at this top rated riad and now wonder how many of the hubdreds of reviews were by travelers or fake
fav bit. we loved being here , the hustle , bustle sights , sounds ,compact area. Liked looking around , felt very safe and everyone was accepted

The best part of Marrakech. This is what a visit to Marrakech is all about. The history of this old city is really tangible once inside the old walls. The streets are a maze and it is easy to become disoriented. On the first day this means you are prey to the endless offers of help to find your way. Be aware, they always expect payment even if they say they don't. However, you soon learn to deflect these offers because you can always find your way by following the outskirts of the old wall.

FABULOUS. The Medina can be challenging and stressful for even Moroccans (so we are informed by some of our drivers). We ventured into the morass on our own to explore and spent a lot of time doding the sales pitches and trying to keep our bearings the first time out.We really got smart the next time and engaged the services of a private guide (see separate review) and the entire area made sense and this history was fabulous. We started on the outer (or more recent) area and wound ourselves into the center (or oldest) areas. We found the most wonnderful place to pick up a quick snack (wonderful Frech pastry and fresh juice). Then we would between the Berber style market area, through the Turkish style area, and then into the Souk (workshop) areas. We wound our way down some familiar passages (neat the tourist area) and then quickly took a few turns to get back into the real Medina. We passed by the oldest (original) restaurant area in Marrakech, where they dropped meat into fire pits in clay pots (old style of BBQ), then wound our way through the huge rug stalls, past the tannery section, and further into the 'organic' produce area, and then into an area reserved for widows who were actually sitting there weaving hats and the like for sale. We learned how the better prices were away from the Market Square and how to haggle for what you want.So far the family has now spent 12 hours roaming around and finding all sorts of novel and unique items and gifts and food.Fabulous to do this with a personal, well respected guide and more than worth the fee for many, many hours of wonderful exploring.
Go in with the right attitude. Being a single traveller I was a little wary but had not problems with the Medina and would recommend people to go and see it.

Get lost in the maze of streets. The Medina, the old city of Marrakech, is surrounded by high walls, all a pink rose colour, the same as the houses in it. More than 1 million people live here and the streets are a maze; if you don't have a map you will get lost. Watch out for cyclists and mopeds which wizz around each corner. Walk single file and stay on the right. Then, if you dare, duck into the souks and get really lost. The streets and souks are full of separate shops and buying anything is a lesson in bargaining.

Very colourful. A great adventure with it's positives and negatives.Positives: Good bargains to be had, good for shoppers and people who love to barter, never accept the 1st price, food and drink stops, great photo opportunities. Safe just use your usual safety percussions as you would anywhere. Only hassled if you allow yourself to be just say 'no' and walk on, you wouldn't walk into every shop in London if someone called you to come in.Negatives: opportunist who try to hussle you by offering to guide you through the medina, pretending to engage you in friendly conversation. This can become annoying as they can ruin the experience.' i know you, i work in the hotel is a classic, one person will engage in conversation 1st and then 2nd person will try and guide you, another is the person greeting you on the street and offering to walk you to the medina. Don't be fooled only part with your money if you want to give or spend it after all it's your holiday.Also watch out for young children begging by cashpoints.

Wonderful place to be and enjoy. The place is amazing and lively, it is noisy, but still you love the atmosphere. Full of music, performers, shoppers and sellers. Small roads leading inside and is a zigzag. Shoppers paradise
good fun in small doses. Vendors friendlier than Tunisia...lots to see and not too much hassle. Good cultural experience. Watch out for guides from the "Ministry of Tourism"!

Not for the feint of heart!. The rating may be unfair because I'd already been through the medina in several other large Moroccan towns and enough it enough. True, Marrakech is probably one of the largest and the center square is famous (although be aware that you will see NOTHING if it's raining as it was when I was there. If this is your first medina, you will have to learn very quickly to avoid eye contact with the merchants and just keep moving unless you really want to buy something. Learn the Moroccan word for "enough" and say it forcefully because the word for "no" is never sufficient! And be aware that much of the stuff they are selling is from China...don't buy any silver unless it is stamped sterling or you see it being made locally because it may contain dangerous metals! If you like this kind of thing, have at it! It just isn't my cup of tea...even mint tea.

A review and tips for future visitors. Stayed in Marrakesh with a good friend of mine, two young boys in their twenties. Our hotel was located in the new area L'Hivernage, a calm neighbourhood filled with big hotels and bars. It was just a fifteen minute walk to the medina. In this review I'll mention a couple of topics that I think are helpful for future visitors of Marrakesh.Jemnaa el FnaThe square is best enjoyed from a rooftopterrace, while drinking a mint tea. It is very busy and for the salesmen, henna artist and other people you're just a walking ATM. In the evening the food stalls enter the square. I do recommend you to have dinner at a stall, the prices are visible and the food is good (Tip: pick a crowded food stall). The annoying part is finding a food stall you liked, we wielded the following technique: If you're annoying we're not giving you any business. SouksI personally do not like to haggle, so this might explain why I bought the majority of the souvenirs in the Hotel Boutique and Airport souvenirshop (terrible, but true). The haggling wasn't the main reason for the fact that I ended up buying the souvenirs in these locations, the constant pushing by shopkeepers ("Come have a look at my store", "Hello, Hello, my friend) and name calling if you ignored them or said "no, thank you" in three different languages (Arab, English or French). Just passing a store and looking at the items caused the shopkeeper to follow you with the items in his hand, for me this does not count as a relaxing shopping experience.SafetyWe, two tall Dutch boys, didn't feel unsafe during the day or at night. Especially Hivernage and Gueliz are safe areas where you will not be harassed and hassled. The Medina is a different place, but other than very annoying we never had the feeling that it wasn't safe. I've read different stories on Trip Advisor, so I think the group you're travelling with a big influence on your perceived feeling of safety. Do not expect anything from the police, since they are hardly visible and I had the feeling that they could do way more to make the stay of tourist much more enjoyable.Drugs While walking on the square or passing a group of young morrocan boys I was offered drugs a couple of times. Just ignoring them or telling them we were from Amsterdam and didn't use drugs so we are not interested in his goods helped. The drugrunners actually were the easiest salesmen to tell that you were not interested, since they are selling illegal products they will not follow you if you've said no.TransportOn the first two days we walked everything, we like to wander around in cities since you're most likely to find fun and interesting parts. I do not recommend this for Marrakech, the slightest hesitation (especially in places near attractions) will cause locals to offer you directions. Saying "No, thank you" becomes very annoying at a certain point and caused us to became very distrustful towards all locals who started talking to you within the medina (which is a pity). The complete lack of roadsigns does not help you either. After these two days we started using the cab if we were going to visit the medina. Which turned out to be quite fun, driving through a vegetable market in an old Mercedes while people are buying their daily groceries isn't something you do every day. ConclusionLooking back on the trip I'm glad we made it and went to Marrakesh. At the moment I'm not sure if I would like to return to this city. But if we would go again we would do the following:- Stay in a nice Hotel in the Hivernage district (we were really happy that we made this choice). - Hire an official guide to show you the interesting sights and take you into the small streets in Kasbah and the Medina. The guide will explain the story behind the attractions and you will not be harassed by annoying locals that want money for pointing you in the right direction. Your hotel can help you to find a good guide.- If you wake up easily I recommend you to bring earplugs, since the minarets first call for prayer is really early in the morning (depends on the season). - Take the cab when you're visiting a touristic sight.

Scary at first. The Medina is hell at first and they can spot newcomers a mile off we were approached by many people offering to be guides and even one stall owner yelling at us calling us gays (which we are but no public display of affection) Took a break in a coffee bar then delved in again with much more confidence, main advice would be to not go early (we went in at 9:30 am) as it is very daunting when you are the only tourists walking around the winding streets. By about 11 am there are many other tourists so you feel a lot safer... as for haggling do your research first. They start with super inflated prices and you can be haggling them down to as low as 5% of their original price. Don't be afraid to start low and be willing to start walking away a few times. I was haggling for a tagine and made it out of the shop and away three times before I agreed on a price, and still I think I could have got it down further. Its all a game, good luck :D
medina delights. medina roughly means walled town its a must visit to marrakech everything is like being transported back in time dont be afraid do what u like no 1 will hassle you ..much

Lovely. This was a lovely trip we took in both day and then at night. At night the Medina is lit up brilliantly and the workers are good people they do try to get you in there stall but if you say no then they would take no for an answer. In the day time they have both Snake Charmers and Monkeys on leads.
Diverse attractions. Lots going on in the medina from the souk and other local shopping areas to historic buildings and gardens.

Frightening. We stayed in a Riad in the Medina, the place was frightening enough during the day but at night it was terrifying. Tourists stand out a mile and are pestered by the locals who offer to show you the way then want money (and they do not go away). On the last night I had my handbag snatched off my shoulder in what was an organised theft. Two lads one on a scooter. Spent our last morning at the Police Station. The Police admitted there were a lot of thefts in that area I think only a matter of time before someone gets seriously injured.

Fascinating, but.... The culture, for us from England, was quite a shock. The poverty was very apparent and you are constantly hassled by people wanting to guide you to places and it is very easy to allow them to do so. Unfortunately it is almost impossible to amble around, browse the souks, watch the street entertainers and generally do things at a pace that suits you. If you stop to look at anything, you are immediately pounced upon and it usually costs you, though not a great amount. My wife happend to stop to look at a man with a monkey and the next thing she knew the monkey was in her arms and pictures were being taken. I had to pay for this and when I gave him a 20 MAD note he demanded more. Nevertheless, the total of 40 MAD amounted to a little over £3.
Very atmospheric and colourful. There was everything to like. The people the country sights smells food it all came together to make a very enjoyable few days

Sensory overload and loved every minute!. Take negative reviews with a pinch of salt. We spent three days in a beautiful riad in the medina and walked through many times each day. As in any city, you have to use common sense, respect the culture and dress appropriately (women: cover arms, legs and use a scarf to drape over your shoulders - men: shorts are not often seen so will call attention). I found the sellers far less aggressive and persistent than other countries such as Turkey, where they are intimidating and rude. Here our approach was to avoid eye contact, don't point to anything in the shops (that, of course, invites them to try to sell) and smile inanely at them whilst walking by. They quickly lose interest, they don't want to waste their time any more than you do! As a middle aged woman I felt totally safe here and feel much more likely to be a a victim of petty theft walking through the Eastern Europeans who infest Westminster bridge or the pick pockets along the Ramblas in Barcelona! Go to the medina, enjoy the cultural experience, if you want something haggle hard then retreat to a wonderful riad to chill out.

This is what Marrakech is all about!. You can't go to Marrakech and not visit the Medina and the souks. Be on your guard for people wanting to give you directions, and always have a good look around before deciding to buy anything as there are hundreds of the same things around. Really nice to just wander the medina and don't forget to look around you.

A real adventure!. If you like haggling, searching for treasures, getting lost in the souks, seeing snake charmers and monkeys this is the place for you. There is no where else like it. pay a small amount to a local guide so the others will leave you alone and then wander.

good to visit but not to stay. Visiting the medina area is a unique experience and is worth spending a day in the medina and the jema el fena area. But avoid booking an accomodation in the medina area as you are constantly hassled for money and intimidated by local touts. The newer part of the city is better and less intimidating
our tour. busy and worth a visit day or night, but having a guide was a blessing, dont leave home without one.

Intimidating for women travellers. I visited as part of a group of 5 women friends. We had arranged for a private tour which, overall, was great. The sights and sounds are amazing and I wish we had felt confident enough to spend more time browsing and making purchases but after a short time we just wanted to leave. We had dressed modestly for the trip, we are all in our 30's/40's, married etc and we just spent the whole time being leered at and being subjected to suggestive comments. Our guide was very apologetic and steered us away from a few potentially worrying situations, he was amazing. We left without purchasing a single thing.

Hustle and bustle. The medina was one of the main reasons for my visit. The place was full of so much to see. The colours, smells and general 'feel' to this was wonderful. The only bit I find tiring is the constant bartering required for anything! Fabulous though - don't be put off!!

Atmospheric, Lively and Overwhelming!. This is exactly what I expected and more from Marrakech. I have visited so many countries that are being drastically modernised leaving their history and charm in the past but this is the real thing. A must for all visitors to Marrakech as the Medina is its heart. Buzzing with life, fascinating and easy to get lost in but so worthwhile as an experience. For the first time visitor it can look daunting but here you cross paths with locals leading their every day lives. In many ways it is like stepping back in time. I loved it. Tips? Don't expect to be given genuine directions from locals as they may head you off in the opposite way than where you wish to go! Also do be careful walking around corners as bikes can hurtle past you at an incredible speed considering the narrowness of the small allies. Do savour the atmosphere and take your time exploring.

all the want is your money. be careful if you look for to long at any of the performers, they will hound you for money. Also be very careful of the traffic especially the mopeds, plus the smog is choikng

Middle East Chaos. Stayed at an apartment in Medina of Marrakech - we live in Switzerland. This is about as opposite of Switzerland as you can get. Absolute mayhem - people everywhere, one woman started trying to tattoo my wife's wrist before I could pull her away. As an American, you stick out - and you have to be rude. The walls are a maze - you MUST have a GPS phone. Everytime I looked at my phone, people come up to you trying to hijack you - "do you need help, where are you going?". We ran into an English couple at dinner who said they were here 2 hours and they got taken to a house where they were forced to pay 7,000 DH to get out. Almost on cue, when we left dinner - two men who tried to appear very sympathetic and helpful were trying to ferry us down a narrow walled pass into a low corridor when I whisked us away. Something out of an Indian Jones movie set. Your senses will be overloaded. A different experience.

Amazing. Our first day was a bit scary as we had no idea what to expect, but once you get used the crazy bikes etc you will soon enjoy getting lost and notice the charm and character that is all around.
Fun and vibrant. If you have an image of Marrakesh this is it. It's as different as day and night during day and night. A must see at both times!
Marrakech Medina. Everything you can imagine can be ofund in th ewalled city of the Medina. It's an amazing area with the Souks, which are like a giant flea market on steroids.

The heart of Marrakech. Marrakesh medina was CRAZY! ABSOLUTE MADNESS!!! [still searching for a fitting comparison]! Aggressive haggling on steroids; like nothing I've experienced! It's absolutely beautiful madness. Unorganized and organized chaos mixed with a sense of old world charm, The old city (medina) is contained within castle walls. The Jamaa el Fna is a huge central square at the entrance to the souk (market place) located in the medina. The Medinas are old neighborhoods contained within castle walls with narrow streets, filled with souks (street markets), delicious aromas, restaurants, carpet cooperatives, leather tanneries and Riads ("house in paradise" traditional homes with open courtyards or gardens). Riads are AMAZINGLY intricate works of architecturally art. Originally made of old stones like clay, Mosaic, marble, etc. Additionally, you’ll find mules, donkeys, carriages, and motorbikes transporting goods in medina streets.

Wonderful to get lost in. Gotta be done! Amazing how you lose a day here. Tiring but very very good fun, You just have to go with it. Central and north Medina are excellent. We was dropped of in the Southern Medina on our first day, and really did not enjoy it, but it might have just been an overload of the senses. We did not revisit the Southern part but sure it would have been more enjoyable after getting into the flow!

Marrakech souk is esssential to visit. We loved the souk with its treasure troves, tiny shops where sellers and artisans worked with metals, dyes, leather, fabrics, jewellery, rugs and so on. There were tiny alleyways and no one was rude, aggressive or hustling. The only problem were the motor bikes which sped through and could easily injure or kill people or animals. They are not allowed in the Fes souk. If nervous, ask your Ryad to organise a guide for your first trip to the souk.
Medina life. Never met the pre expectations i had, but it was still an experiance i wouldn't of missed. I encourage everyone to visit at least once in there life

Exotic for Europeans but not for most Asian tourists. - Liked: Lots of street food and performances to see. Cheap coffee. - Disliked: Every vendor would try to rip tourist off. If you're not good at haggling, then you would end up paying 3-5 times of the normal price. Those women and children were made to beg for money from the tourists at the main square. I hate having to act really cold towards people there, but if I didn't, I would be harassed and forced to buy things.
Amazing medina. We stayed in Riad Granvilier right in the heart of the Medina and loved this area. Different experience totally, and not to be missed.
dive into Marrakech. I like it the way it is. don't try to avoid purchase offers from the locals. you just will not be able to, but consider that as a monument of culture.

A feast for ALL senses. Get lost. . . Please do, you'll be glad you did! Eat everything, drink some mint tea. Hard to describe this place, just get lost and buy some stuff. Plan to check extra bags. Even the GARBAGE you buy will feel worth it when you get home.

Crazy, eye opening - well worth a visit. From the snake charmers & fortune tellers to henna tattooists and monkey men - this is old skool Marrakech at it's best. Expect the snake charmers to want money though if they catch you taking a picture and beware to agree a price with the henna ladies before they start some elaborate design. Try the delicious OJ that's about 10p a cup and be sure to catch sunset from the roof terrace at Cafe France in the main square over looking the whole of the Medina. Mint tea is the drink of choice here

Interesting & Exciting. The Medina is a very interesting place and especially enjoyable in the evening. There are people who shout and try to get you into their shops/stalls but just keep walking if you do not want to go in. The men with monkeies will just put the monkies on your shoulders and expect money - try to agree a price firs! They can be very pushy, do not be afraid to say no. Haggling is an absolute must, they will start off at a high price. Stick to the price you want to pay and even walk away when they say it is too low - they WILL come after you and give you your price. There are lots of bars/restaurants around and some have roof terraces which offer a fantastic view of the hustle and bustle in the Medina.
Its busy!. Stay to the right to avoid the scooters. I'd suggest exploring the spice, ceramic and fabric souks first.

too much begging and overpriced. the medina flea market is quieter and really nice at night with all the traditional moroccan lights shining. A pity that begging has become a national sport there - very annoying. Even if one bargain, prices remain very high due to the number of tourists (higher than in Casablanca for example)

Hectic and fun. Just shop around in the Medina, that's just the most fun. Always pay less then the shop owners ask, about 1/3 is okay! We never felt like we were lost in the Medina, because if you folow the other tourists you will just end up on the Jemaa el Fna. Getting help from locals will only cost you to much money

The only problem with the Medina is the present.. There is a war going on between people and machines. Pedestrians and moto-bikes (mopeds, motorcycles). It's pure polluted chaos till you get deeper towards the souks where there not allowed but come anyways. It's stressful and death-defying. The air pollution is horrid, the honking insane, the vibe shattered by the Present. Fez has enough hills to discourage them, the feeling is SO different. I know there's effort to regulate this, but till then, stay on the outside of the path, wear earplugs, bring a face mask or scarf, and pretend that the past isn't that far away, and that the future will be more peaceful.

Unbelievable Experience!. Loved every minute of it!Did get a woman take me away from my partner to draw henna on me which was slightly scary but she let go eventually.Be aware with small children as it does get very busyThe night time is an unreal experience and the food is amazing!

At times just too much hastle. We were independant travellers who loike to walk and gain the atmosphere at our own pace. Maybe it was because late Nov is in the slack season but the level of attention from touts, etc reached unaccepltable levels. On our first day left early to find a restaurant away from the hastle and pollution.On the positive side we always felt safe whereever we went.Two or three full days will enable you to do all the sights

Discover Marrakech. We did this as part of our excursion, I enjoyed the day and our guide was very good, I think without the guide it would have been difficult to appreciate the importance of the Medina.
Exotic. Certainly a fun place to visit, an exotic experience, felt very safe there even at night, not hassled by anyone except a few children trying to hawk tissue packs.
A slight feeling of being taken for a ride. An experience, must haggle when purchasing but even after getting the price down quite a bit you have still paid too much!

Marrakech Medina a vibrance to experience. The main market and souk area of this historic city is a must to do before you die! A chemistry of medieval practices delivered to a 21st century traveller are a terrific experience. The work ethic and determination of these traders will humble you. Don't be generous with tips or you will lure a hoard of beggars thinking you are a soft touch. The locals do not want their photo taken, or if they do, they want payment for it. 10 dirhams will do ( 80p). Try eating in the square on a night, the food is good, safe and cheap.Look out for the spice area.

Ignore the touts. One is constantly harrassed by touts offering to show you the way for money. Just ignore them, after 30 or so meters walking with you they give up. Wandering around on your own is an experience by itself. An Ipad of IPhone with GPS and a pre-loaded map of the Medina brings you everywhere and safely home.

Mayhem in Marrakech. This place is fun, the sights, sounds and smells are all part of the true taste of Morocco. Tourists prepare to be ripped off......the Moroccans are some of the worst I have come across when it comes to this. I was hassled, grabbed and approached by the market sellers from nearly every stall I walked past- but it's all part of the experience ( I didn't feel threatened at all ) you have to see this place to believe it!!

Crazy and busy. This is a must to visit and stay in if you are visiting the city. Do not be afraid to go into the souks alone the store owners are very friendly and if you get lost they will point you in the right direction. In fact part of the fun is in trying to get lost you will be amazed at what you find!!!!!!

Unique experience. If you like small streets, a lot of people, a lot of noises and smells you have to visit Medina in Marrakech. I visited Medina with my husband and we got a bit lost for a while but definitely enjoyed it. I would recommend ladies to cover themselves up if you do not want to attract any undesired attention. Also, do not forget to buy along the way some of the traditional Marrakech sweet treats. Prepare for adventure!!
A must. A must when visiting Marrakech, one of the places to do, next to jemaa el Fna. You can stay many hours at the medina

Medina. I liked the repartee with the stallholders who are less aggressive than 6 years ago.I didn't like the mopeds riding up and down which cause a lot of pollution in the alleyways and are dangerous to pedestrians.

Madina. very intresting but beware of pick pockets.Keep your bag in front of you I recomend pac safe bags Be prepared to pay if you take photos of the snake charmers etc .The snakes we saw did not want to perform and saw some being hit You can barter for some good bargins but inspect your goods when paying
market. really busy, but good and plenty bargins you just have to barter an get your prices down its better at night
Crikey!. Fun for some, intimidating and stressful for others- Noisy and overwhelming at times and quiet and old wolrdy at others. Walk to the right and avoid getting run over!

It's OK to Get Lost!. We were first brought through the Medina by a registered guide, and very thankful for that! The next few times we charted one road in and out and stuck to the outer walls. It is another world! Stick to the right side of the road, look and listen for motorbikes coming. Be aware that people expect to be paid for photographs of their establishments. Have fun with the shopkeepers, don't take it too seriously. Enjoy!

loud hectic authentic but not as bad as its reputation. loud hectic authentic but not as bad as its reputation - don't be scared and just stroll through it, ignor ethe stares, behave respectfully, dress decently (we saw tourists in hot pants and spaghetti straps, that's rather inappropriate) and no one will bug you,

Full Blown Tourist Trap. I am really bewildered as to why so many people have rated the Medina in Marrakesh so highly. Any magic that may have existed in the late sixties when Graham Nash et al visited seems to have disappeared and has been replaced by one of the worst tourist traps I have ever encountered. Since it is the main (pretty much only) tourist attraction in Marrakech, the Medina, and especially the Jemaa El Fna square is where most tourists head for. Consequently it seems to have attracted the kind of people whose primary purpose is to extract as much money as possible from unwary tourists.I have been to places in the world where you expect pedlars and street traders to be persistent but here it is taken to a whole new level. Make eye contact at your peril and practice saying ‘Non Merci’ with attitude. The Jemaa El Fna is full of hustlers, some of whom can be quite aggressive. If you try to take a picture of almost anyone in the square they will demand money – especially the snake charmers or henna women.I wanted to take a picture of a water seller and agreed to give him 20 Dirhams. After I took his picture he started shouting at me that it was not enough and he wanted 100 dirhams. Sensing that it could get ugly I walked away with him shouting at me but he didn’t follow. Okay, I know it’s a poor country but I found the level of hassle one has to deal with in the square became irritating and tiresome. You are also likely to be accosted by ‘Guides’ offering to show you round the Medina. Avoid these people at all costs. There’s nothing you can’t find yourself without a decent guide book and if you avail yourself of the services of these so-called ‘guides’ then expect to be ‘guided’ to a carpet shop, Argan oil shop or something similar. Yes, it’s busy, chaotic and an assault on the senses as some people have indicated - but not really in a good way. The traffic is insane – especially in the Square but also in the Souks. My wife got hit by a motorbike whilst crossing the square. The woman riding the motorbike didn’t stop and nobody around seemed to care. Fortunately my wife wasn’t badly hurt although she was shaken. Take care using an ATM in the Medina also. Within seconds on me putting my card in the machine a small child appeared from nowhere with her hand out. I suspect she had been sent over by an adult nearby. Very disconcerting.As some other reviewers have mentioned you really have to have your wits about you to avoid being scammed – which, sooner or later, you probably will be. Also, as some other reviewers have pointed out, animals are used to ‘entertain’ the tourists (for money, of course) – monkeys and snakes in particular. If you’re happy to see animals being abused in this way then okay but I found it disturbing particularly as many of the animals (the monkeys especially) looked to be in very poor condition. I am sure that there are many charming and authentic places to visit in Morocco but the Marrakech Medina isn’t one of them in my view. Any authenticity that still exists has been overwhelmed by commercialism of the worst kind. Compared with the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul (a truly magical city) the Souks were pretty disappointing although at least it feels more authentic and the level of hassle you get seems to diminish the further into the Souks you go. One has to venture deep into the centre of the Souks to find any decent craftwork – most of the stuff on the periphery being tourist tat.I know that many people will disagree with my opinions but, on the whole, I found the Medina vastly overrated and an unpleasant, dispiriting experience.
This is really "crazy place". I liked everything! :) The place, the people, the movement, the narrow streets, the same doors, markets. EVERYTHING!

You Will Get Lost. This has to be said. You will have no end of people offering to "help and guide" you...for a negotiated fee once you get to your destination! Can feel a little claustrophobic during the busy times of day and you must be careful not to get run over by a horse,donkey or cart and most definitely the polluting little motorbikes that are everywhere.The air is some of the most polluted I have come across...but WHAT an amazing atmosphere and get ready to haggle to buy that scarf or handbag etc!

Hectic, Mad, Fun. The Medina was great fun and very interesting, we did lots of shopping which entailed a lot of haggling. Just need to be careful not to accept help without making it very very clear that there was no money - unless you want to give everyone money every time you ask for directions!

Ok. This is a place you want to see in the dark as in the light it is quite disappointing. By all means go and sit in one of the cafes that outline the square but just don't expect much in the daytime. Yes there are snake charmers and monkey trainers(?) but you know what...there are only so many pushy and rude ''sales' people you can take before going back to the hotel seems like a great option. Enjoy the place for what it is,a tourist trap.
Very interesting. An amazing mix of old and new, east and west. A must see. The souk is great for shopping / haggling!

Dangerously strolling and shopping. At first we did not mind the pushy salesmen, but after 3 days it was getting a bit anoying. We felt it was a hazard walking because of the numerous motorbikes passing on all sides.
Old town and the people. This area lets you get a feel for the real way of life for local people. A guide is a good idea to get to know your way round.
Crazy. Crazy place, largest barbecue of the world every evening on Main Square, take care about fake guides, just go away.

Amazing.. This was sensory overload on a wonderful scale. The noise, the colours, the entertainment, the foodstalls, the beggars, the monkeys, the snakes. Soak it in then make a quick exit to to the balcony of the Cafe de la France to relax. observe and enjoy.
Only place to be. The medina is the real Morocco. it's mysterious and quite seductive . It's a bit intimidating in the beginning but you get you bearings very quickly.

interesting souk area. but really bargain! and beware of the carpet sellers; they ask you just to come in and take a look, but it's actually pretty difficult to get out. You have to be prepared to see around 20 different carpets, and then one-by-one, they take them off, but you have to point which you like and dislike. And it's hard to "dislike them all". (then they just go and find you 20 new carpets...)

crafts and shops, smells and colors. one must get lost in the medina... but do not let yourself get led by boys who will ask for money! or set the price first! because if you look lost there will always be somewhere ready to take you to all the places and to all the shopkeepers he'll know... so be aware of that and keep small change with you so that you can set the price ahead and say "Ok to the Bahia Palace, 40 dirham" or whatever. Otherwise you'll end up in arguing situations.

Mad, Mad, Mad. It's a full on experience in the Medina but so interesting. The streets are narrow and there is a maze of them. There are lots of people and scooters, donkeys, bikes etc and lots of mouth watering smells from the various food stalls.

Mind blowing. The whole medina is like travelling back in time and the small, cobbled streets are full of colour and smells and notice. It's fascinating seeing people just going about their every day life.

Alive. We went to the Medina in the evening and it was electric, there is so much going on. Lots of food stools, fresh fruit juices, snake charmas, monkeys and entertainers. Venders will talk to you as you walk past and try and to convince you their stall is best, lots of "sales patter" our experience was "lovely ladies from england come to us, come to us" or on finding you are english comments such as " Gavin and stacey, eastenders, Fish and chips!" which made us giggle. We ate chicken tagine and the food was nice and inexpensive. I thought the medina was busy when we went but after talking to one of the staff at our hotel he said this was quiet compared with summer time. I enjoyed the Medina but found it tiring on first visit, I would recommend that everyone who visits Marrakesh makes at least one trip to the Medina.

Great Medina. Loved this medina, better than Fes medina. Could spend days there, and had everything Moroccan. You may feel more comfortable with a guide, but beware, they will take you to 'their' friends shop and tell you to watch the demonstration, etc. but will disappear or become mute when the shop owner starts the hard sell! Be prepared to be tough when saying no or you could be there for a while! But having a guide you will hopefully not find yourselves lost. Otherwise just stick to the main drag and there is no problem at all.
Medina very good. just walking around it really good, taking in the sites, smells and sounds it was truly amazing!!!We loved walking around and loosing yourself..
Day visit. Visited during the day, no problems with hassle which we expected. Understand night time it is much busier.

Compellingly Toxic. We've been to most of the earths depressed areas. This one is no different to most and quite engaging from a cultural point of view. What I don't remember from elsewhere was quite the volume of motorbike traffic combined with charcoal smoke in the narrow often roofed alleyways. The combination must damage health severely. It's other claim to fame is the combination of a total lack of signage in a warren of passages with armies of miscreants offering to guide you to where you don't want to go for money that's not agreed. I don't mind beggars or eager carpet vendors, they are honest. I did not appreciate constant stream of tricksters.

Chaotic but very interesting. I enjoyed the overall experience of the Medina, and its worth a night-time visit. However also found it quite stressful at times as you do get harassed quite a lot, and there are a lot of elderly and child beggers which can be upsetting.

Overwhelming. but worth a visit. Just get out before dark! This place is exactly what others have said for years - whether you are dodging snakes, avoiding monkeys on chains (which can be disturbing) or just trying to avoid the oncoming traffic of bikes, mopeds or horses, this place is overwhelming for all of the senses but has to be seen to be believed. After dark it looks amazing and is even busier but a lot more dangerous.

Amazing, best souvenir buying in Morocco here.. See it during the day for shopping in the Medina, but also see it again at night for the lighted food stalls. Try the fresh squeezed orange juice from the stalls - it's amazing and only 50 cents a glass. You'll have several glasses as it's delicious. Save all of your souvenir shopping for Marrakech as the best selection is here. You might want to save Marrakech for the end of your Morocco trip so you don't have to lug all of your souvenirs around Morocco. Better quality rugs are to be had in Fes though.

Chaos. Look out for bikes,carts and traps as everyone drives like crazy.Keep a tight grip on you money and be prepared to bargain fiercely in the Souks.If you go near a snake charmer they wil throw a snake on you and ask for money.Avoid going to the toilet in the Medina but there are some excellent hotels in the modern sector

You Have to do This. A very interesting and historical area. Again,part of a half day excursion from the hotel but to see the culture and the many nationalities was incredible. To watch the traffic with all the many mopeds is an amazing sight.

Overwhelming But Worth A Visit. Firstly, within ten minutes of being within the Square of the Medina, I was cursed, nearly stabbed on the hand with a henna syringe and gropped. This place is really overwhelming!Go suitably dressed, dont take photos unless you are willing to donate to the begging bowl and don't allow anyone to take your hand.The second time we visited the square, we were more prepared, stayed together as a couple and were aware of people hovering, so avoiding potential negative contact. The square is worth a visit - with caution - you should have a lovely time.The rest of the Medina is full of 'hustlers' who latch onto to you when they identify that you are confused and are unaware of where you are.
