They will take you to 'their shop' to try and get you to buy items - enjoy the experience but, again be prepared. We were very nervous that we might have got mugged or something, but were fortunate that these Moroccans were just doing a job so as they could get commission on what was sold to us.Take a trip around the Medina in a horse drawn carriage. It costs around 150 moroccan for up to two hours. Make sure the horse looks well cared for and that you tell the driver that you only want a tour of the OLD MEDINA - you really don't want to bother with 'New Marrakech' as it is much like any other city!Within the walls of the Medina, is a laberinth of small streets and no where is signposted - that map really is of no use! hahaha! So, enjoy getting lost in this magical space.This really isn't a place for small european children - much too chaotic - but if you want unpredictability, the Medina is the place for you! Check out the museum, the tombs and take in the smells and sounds of Marrakech!

Fab trip. It was an experience but my husband felt a little intimidated. It was very busy and we saw a fight durin the trip. One man hit another man with a rock because he wasn't fasting. It was a bit scary. I would't have liked it without a guide.

Overwhelming. As per usual - keep your wits about you as is very crowded, hot and you do get hassled. As West Australian girls brought up holidaying in Bali though - that didn't upset us at all. Bargain, bargain and bargain and walk away if you feel you are gettting ripped off because you actually do get ripped off in the Medina. I went and bought Argan oil etc in a local Supermarket and it was much cheaper than the Medina. Also... do a treck in the Atlas Mountains and ask your guide to come with you to a little local shop and stock up on spices and tea there... fifth of the price of the Medina!

went to this place some nice shops. liked the shops, no one begging from you just a little messy as regards the rubbish had some mint tea in one of the shops, with the man selling some lovely carved oak furniture

Mad mix of colours, smell, and sights. An amazing mix colours smells and sights, a bit scary in places, but the people are very nice, but you must barter hard, as the initial prices asked are getting ridiculous!

Perfect place to people watch. The Medina has the hustle and bustle that I love about Arab/Asian countries - seeing is believing. Whether you want to soak up the atmosphere of the crowded souks, or enjoy a Moroccan tea on the cafe balconies overlooking La Place, there is plenty to do and see.

No Brainer. You don't need a review on TripAdvisor to tell you to go to the Medina. If you're visiting Marrakesh, you will do it automatically. The Medina is wonderful but be prepared for the hassling, constant selling, and the touching. Be resolute as you walk and do as much research as you can so you know where you're going. As soon as you look lost they will be all over you.

Worth to visit!. Marrakech is one of the most fascinating town in Morocco.Really we enjoyed the old Medina;its palaces,mosques,,madrasas and its unforgettable Jema El Fna Square,its people,its cuisine,its markets,its aromas,its sounds,and so on.If you are preparing a travel to Morocco,Marrakech is a city you definitely should not miss!.

Easy to get lost. I went to the Medina twice, once on a guided tour that took us through all the main souks in the course of an hour. The second time I went by myself and got hopelessly lost, the layout does not seem to bear any relation to the map and it is difficult to find street names, however I eventually found my bearings and quite enjoyed the experience.

A labyrinth to explore!. This place is crazy! We spent all day wandering in and around the souk and soaking up the atmosphere. For woman travellers; some of the men could be intimidating, but generally as a group of guys we found the sellers and entertainers to be great fun. It's not for the faint hearted and you have to be strong when bartering for a price; but it's the most important place to visit in Marakech and appreciate Moroccan life.
Poor people. Found it quite upsetting to see old people having to beg in the streets. being harrased by boys wanting to walk you to the Square and were a real pest.
Shock to the senses!. Just soak up the atmosphere and been amazed by what you see. it will take you out of your comfort zone.

Don't be ripped off. You will find some amazing treasures but don't be ripped off - we were agreeing prices that were 1/5 of the asking price (and still probably paying too much!).At first it was a bit daunting but after a while we would just turn it into a game and have a laugh and a joke with the sellers. One seller even offered us free mint tea after we bought a fair few things off of him. Have fun and don't take it too seriously and take time to take everything in.The only advice I would have is don't walk around late at night; we were going back to our riad and some young boys kept running up and touching us (in the end one of them touched my partners bum and she grabbed the boy to stop and I shouted at him in French - needless to say they left us alone after and we spotted a morrocan man telling them off afterwards).

Overwhelming but Amazing. I spent a week at a Riad in the Medina and walked around everyday for hours. My sense of direction is horrible so more times then not I went around in circles. Other then merchants wanting you to go into their shops I was never harassed or bothered. As a matter of fact, I didn't find the merchants to be as aggressive as I had thought they would be. Eploring the Medina really is a must while in Marrakech! Each day I got a bit braver and explored different areas but I wish I had thrown caution to the wind and just wondered aimlessly even if I had to pay someone to take me back to the Riad. Next time that is exactly what I am going to do. After all isn't that what holidays are for!
Fun Place. What can you say it is a fun place to visit, the sights, smells and atmosphere is like another planet. Just plain fun!

Too many tourists, not enough locals. Compared to Fez and Rabat, this medina is flooded by tourists. In Fez there were obviously a lot of tourists too, but I also saw plenty of local people buying supplies. In Marrakech I was disappointed that the merchandise in the medina was mostly tacky souvenirs. It's noisy and colorful and if you have nothing better to do worth a stroll, but if you can, see the old medina of Fez instead.
Strange facinating depresing. It is very interesting and at the same time very sad that people still have to live and work in such dire conditions.
Medina. Well worth a visit all part of the holiday to see other cultures. It was raining when we arrived, not many places to take shelter, nevertheless enjoyable experience.

Great place - bring GPS. We loved wondering around the Medina but eventually resorted to GPS at times. Beware of the fact that street names on maps, on the streets themselves and as used by locals aren't necessarily the same. Do not let anyone show you the way as they are either trying to take you to a shop or restaurant and/or get a tip. The first evening we walked all over the place with 'helpful' strangers shouting at each other as some were being honestly helpful while others were telling them off for giving us free advice. All this aside, walking around Marrakech is a great joy whether you buy anything or not.
Enjoy colours!. All roads lead you back to medina.Everything is colored.You can negotiate all.You can also have fun all day long!
The essence of Marrakech!. The medina is a must if you are visiting Marrakech. Every path leads to more souks, smells, shops, stalls, noises. . . You get the idea!! Great experience.

Ramble, get lost, have fun. I enjoyed most the souks in the country. They are grouped as most souks are with different items so all the spices are in one area, textiles in another etc. I love this because you can get an idea of what is available and compare without having to traipse back and forth across the medina. I loved the spice area for the smells. They sellers are really generous if you take time with them to visit and purchase something. It's why I said to plan to spend more than three hours here. I bought some harira spices and cinnamon sticks for a few dollars and he gave all of my group free Berber lipstick. Be prepared to be called Fatima or Aisha if you are a woman or Mohammed if you are a man. It's the way they get the attention of people they do not know. They are not trying to force familiarity, it is just their way.Be careful of the donkeys and motorcycles because they are not watching out for you! And if you want a picture you may need to ask. Some sellers and people were techty about getting their picture taken (even though we were taking a picture of the donkey and had cropped out the people).I loved it but I can see how some people think it is sensory overload!

Everybody loves the medina so a few tips and tricks. I just love the place! a few tips to get around: keep smiling and make eye contact. If you don't want to be lurred into every single shop, you need to change your behavior a little bit. Never forget to keep on smiling and say thank you, make eye contact and walk on. The tradesman will smile at you and leave you alone: great way of exploring as much ground as possible. Tip nr one: settle for a price slightly higher then the opening price by returning the first bit by 25% of the original price. Tip 3: If you follow the medina all the way to the north-western most part, you'll notice that more and more tourist make place for locals.. prices drop and the experience becomes awesome.. all the way at the end you can rest a little at terasse des epices... which also offers great meals ...

Sensation overload!!. The medina is bustling, hectic, overpowering and a complete must if you have the pleasure of visiting Marrakech. Each alley leads to more souks, more sights and a more enjoyable experience. Your senses are catapulted into overdrive between the smells of the spices, the sounds of bustling crowds, calls to prayer from the mosques and the sights of stall owners and beggars vying for your attention! Keep your eyes open, ears peeled and haggling hat on and you'll fall into the spirit in no time!!

Medieval mayhem. The intensely fascinating alleys, backstreets and souks with all their raucous wares and often beautiful handiwork for sale are a lifetime must. The J'maa el-Fnaa (Square) is incomparable. The fumes of the mopeds can irritate and you must be careful not to photograph anybody or anything without permission (and even then, you'll probably have to pay).

Step back in time. Marrakech's medina is one of the great, wild, chaotic ancient cities that still lives much as it always has...just walking the streets soaking up the atmosphere will take you out of your routine, and make you forget the cares of your regular life. Marrakech is the antidote to stress.
The Main Event. All roads - and alleyways - seemed to lead back to the Medina. Only visited during the day but still buzzing.
medina by callech. would not like to be a women walking on there own.We thought it too crowded, and a bit smelly & dirty in places.
needs more than one visit. Take your time in this Medina and visit the souks more than once. Spend some time sipping green tea overlooking the square to see how this grand marketplace operates.

Very colourful. Make sure you agree the price before you do anything and don't actually touch anything unless you want to buy it. It sounds obvious but start really low - stupidly low; insultingly low. Especially on taxi's and and horse carriage rides whcih you can get for almost nothing.
so nice to walk around. walking around this place takes you to a different era..its so mesmerizing..u feel like ur heliport-ed to a couple of centuries back..
Hectic but great fun and interesting. The medina is like nothing I've ever experienced before. So much hustle & bustle and people trying to sell all kinds of things, but I loved it!

Djamaa el Fna, Marrakech. The main square in the old city,the Medina,of Marrakech,is huge.Completely surrounded by shops,restaurants,and the souks,its great by day,but amazing at night.A pall of wood smoke hangs over the square from the dozens of stalls cooking food,both for the locals and the tourists.The stalls have people trying to pull you into them,to eat there.The food is cheap and good.There are dozens of stalls selling fresh orange and lemon juice,70p for half a litre..fantastic and refreshing. There are also entertainments all around the square,musicians,clowns,acrobats and novelty acts.All want some money if you watch for long...fair exchange I think!Easy to spend a few hours here,loved it!
My favorite. Medinas are my favorite everytime. I can spend all my days there wandering around, taking pictures and observing poeple.

A great blend of the old and the 21st century.. We did have a guide on one occassion but did explore ourselves. The walls and buildings are all in the same dull mud red colour so every building blends in with the next and they have a height limit on buildings. In some places they have really beautiful buildings and in others some once magnificent buildings have become slightly derilect. Everywhere you went people were friendly and and it was great seeing the frantic traffic of Vehicles, motorbikes, bikes and carts with people carrying sheep or goats on a motor bike. It is an experience not to be missed.

big and lots of choices in the Souk. The medina is quite big and you can't get really lost. There are always helpful people to guide you to main points of interest like the Place Djema El Fna or different museums, mosques etc. you have lots of choices in the Souk but also if you are not in for shopping there are plenty other things to visit / see.

shoppers paradise. get your haggling skills well practised before you go, our guide reckoned about paying half the original asking price. Not too much hard sell either compared to some places I have been although they are still keen! overall though fascinating and enthralling

I kept waiting for Michael Palin to appear.... This is like nothing I've ever seen anywhere in the world! It truly is an experience... If you're feeling brave take the time to discover this without the aid of a guide and allow yourself to be transported to another world. Try to ignore the stall holders calling out "Fish and Chips" and imagine you're back in the times of the Arabian Nights...Be firm, confident and be prepared to walk away and you will have a unique experience. Defnitely worth seeing!
what you really expect from a suq!. wonderful market for "babouches" and leather. ALWAYS negotiate to get the best bargain! Place des Epices is worth a visit.

just keep walking. We stayed in the medina in a Riad not far from Jam el fna and we enjoyed every moment, the best thing to do is keep walking and get lost, when you are tired or want to come out then just head for Jam el fna, you will see many narrow streets with houses on both side with no windows, this was desinged not to show of wealth in islamic world, the street may look dark and scary but they are very safe day or night. If you want to buy genuine Moroccan leather then Fez is the place and not marrakech as marrakech is full of cheap imported leather, you may find genuine leather but one has to be an expert I think to filter them out. If you are not having breakfast in the riad/hotel then head out to the main square in the morning and you should see stalls selling riffa (morrocan flat bread) and other breakfast food which we enjoyed. Just enjoy the culture, orange juice and mint tea when you are there and try to get lost to experience the real medina

Enjoy the experience!. Wow, what a busy place the souks are, contrary to many beliefs the local Moroccan people do not hassle you as much as claimed, yes they want to sell you their goods but be firm, polite and positive if you are not interested. They are really nice and happy people, bartering is part of their life so enjoy the experience, half their offer and meet somewhere in the middle, be prepared to have a final price in your head and be prepared to walk away, you won't get far!The alleyways and cobbled lanes twist and turn and its very easy to loose your sense of direction, keep walking and enjoy it. Don't ask for directions from anyone in the souk who is not a stall holder (so therefore can't leave their shop) and just keep your wits about you.The motorcycles and mopeds are a pain and while they are not allowed inside there seems to be no one stopping them and they zip around at some speed.You cannot come to Marrakesh without visiting the Medina and traversing the souks, keep your eyes open, your senses sharp and enjoy the sights, smells and adventure in this historic city.
nice medina. try to get lost around the medina,its a very interesting things to do holiday.you can explore and see old market,way of life of the people all at the same place

Interesting. Haggle , haggle. Haggle! Don't be intimidated its all a game, and do a bit of research on how to spot fake leather S loads of people try to sell plastic off as leather and do a burning trick.
So busy - not the least for one's senses. All these very busy small streets. Continuously beware of motorcycles passing very closely. So much to see and to smell. A real feast for one's senses.

a must see - no longer than 3 days though!. loved it! it's busy, there's souks everywhere with thousands of lovely things to buy, so different and full of culture!But the noise the crowd and the constant hassle to buy or give money makes you want to leave after 3 days - best thing is to go to the coast after (Essaouira), so quiet and different :)But definitely a must-see and experience!

Medina. We stayed in a Riad in the Medina. Our first visit to Morocco & we found it all fascinating. All the people we met were very friendly, the souks full of beautiful craft ware, fabrics, leather goods, carpets. Too easy to spend money!! Beware - bargain hard as you drink the mint tree you will always be offered!

lived up to what I had expected. The medina is quite large with winding streets and a large square. The streets are full of shop keepers, bikes, motorbikes and donkeys. Everyone we met were polite and friendly. OK they call after you to stop and look at their goods, but compared to, say, India, they don't hassle you as much. Didn't feel threatened at all.

Should be called the MADina. The medina is definitely one of those places that every traveller should experience. We visited in August when the temperarture was insane :well into the 100s farenheit, so would advise not to trawl around during the day. Be prepared if you show any interest in an item on a market stall, you will be hassled, so have a price in your head and stick to it. Most of the time you will get prety close to what you are prepared to pay.At night time is when the main square comes alive. If you approach from the main mosque you will see the lights in the distance glowing, hear the noise from all the pipes, and begin to smell the food being char grilled. Once there you will be amazed at just how many people are wandering around as well as dodging the mopeds. If you have the slightest look of a tourist you will be hassled the minute you arrive either by market stall holders or by the even more persistent restauraunt owners. You then have a choice either take it for what it is ,or get irritated. We chose the former. The noise is constant, as is the smoke from all the restaurants. The food is very basic, as are the menus and you don't get that much of a bargain. But hey, your on a different continent so go with the flow. Are we glad we went? Yes. Would we go back again? No. Its that type of place

UNESCO Heritage Site. Amazing experience to witness and appreciate life of the common people at close quarters. If you can stay in one of the many Riads in the Medina. The best part of your visit should be to loose your way in one of many Derbs or alleys and discover something unexpected! A GPS app would be handy to have on hand to find your way back should you be totally lost.

Marrakesh Medina NOW. Up to two years ago I would have rated the old Marrakesh Medina with a" most fabulous ever" rating. However, the motor scooters driving up your heels every second of your walk were getting to all of us. They might not be "legal" in the Medina but there they are - thousands of them.I therefore prefer Fez and its lovely Medina - the mystique isunhurried and unblemished.
Real Moroc. Staying in the Kasbah and visiting the Medina you can really know this country. Try on the day devoted to the Fête des Moutons and you will feel like nowhere else ...

ALL THE HUSSLE AND BUSSLE. I was told Marrakesh was to in your face and have put off going for many a year , My loss, it is as it should be locals going about their daily routines. very colourful and super busy , but what would you expect . Can,t wait to go again
Medina. The history, and the fab decoration , the tiling is amazing and how the palace was set out , never been in a real harem before shame walls cannot talk!

Good, but not as good as Fez. You'll get lost very easily, and while it's fascinating, it doesn't have the same feel as the Medina in Fez which feels older and less touristy. The Souk in the middle is great fun, but it is for the tourists, not the locals. There are however lots of places around the Medina that feel much more local. There is lots to see here, the museums, palaces and madersas are well worth a visit and generally very cheap to get into

Interesting, but not a place to linger.. This is an interesting square, but the novelty of seeing snake charmers and monkeys rapidly wears off when you get harassed by hawkers at every turn. If you pause or show the slightest interest in any of the stalls you suddenly get surrounded by half a dozen men pestering you for money. In some cases they just demand money for nothing. Cab be very intimidating.

Ancient city. The Medina has stood for hundreds of years and is full of fascinating nooks and crannies. Don't take a map - you will get lost anyway! But eventually you will come out somewhere you recognise!

Vibrante, buzzing and exciting.. Not just a tourist attraction but a place to see people going about their business, displaying and selling their wares, authenticating their very specific life styles and having fun.
Beautiful place. We hired a calash to go there and it was a nice ride.We really enjoyed the visit and the tea afterwards at he café

Priceless. For some reason this area is UNESCO Humanity heritage. I's one of those places where you will find so much true human nature (the good kind and bad kind). The plaza, the souks, the snakes, monkeys and horses, everything is simply unforgettable.

Great for wandering around. We did end up liking the Fez Medina better, but this was still interesting to wander in. If you ask anyone for help in finding something specific, go into a shop instead of asking someone on the street. Otherwise they will insist on directing you there and then expect money.

So much going on!. I loved wandering through the Medina because there was always so much going on. People are everywhere, cars zip around, and there are animals, too. The pace of life and the excitement of the city are awesome. Just beware of teenagers who try to "show you the way" but only get you lost and then ask you for a tip. :/
A Must See. Fun, Interesting and Different.You are not hassled as much as everyone says you are. Delicious food and drink and a great atmosphere.

An experience not to be missed, we loved the smell of the spices, the hussle of the tannery, the enless bargaining. Just accept it is a different world, vendors will not be offended if you tell them 'no thank you' but remember, it is harder to get away once you asked the price

Old meets new. Such an old city, but still has everything that brings local back every day. The night market, food vendors and every sort of shops are all a great fun to hangout in. If you're looking for food, stall 31/32 have great food. Watch what the locals are ordering and order the same, won't be disappointed.

Its and experience!. The Medina and Souks are the heart of the city. Be prepared to haggle - hard!
Its an experience that you have to try - even if its just once.
The downside - the animals, it is difficult as westerners to see some of them as they are.

Crazy experience.. what a truly amazing experience the Medina is, completely different at night to the day time. You have to experience both it understand the Medina.
Just remember the saying 'La Shukran' (no thank you) and then they will stop hassling you to buy something.

Marrakech Medina. A bustling place full of colourful shops selling an amazing variety of things - from the very ordinary everyday necessities to fabrics, lamps, pottery and lots of leather goods. A great place to wander around seeing craftsmen producing all sorts of goods.

Women watch out.. Women please watch out.Just got back from Marrakech and read from Cybamuse's comment on 12/21/07 "You are constantly verbally harassed (with sexual innuendo's) by Moroccan youth" I regrettably must confirm her claim.The first evening at Marrakech my girlfriend and I were in the medina (the main square) and curious to see the shows people circled and watched. We stood by one of the largest crowds and saw a woman fully covered (include most her face) and swinging her body like belly dancer with the music. I did not see much happening and walked away. However my girlfriend waited for there to be more impressive dance moves since the shaking alone could not get all those local men to stand and watch. Then a few young men stood behind my girl friend's and subtley touched her buttocks with their hands. This happened a few times until she realized what was happening, She turned around and said “Good evening” in French quite loudly and stared the men in the eyes. The stopped for a bit, but continued after she turned around each time. The second night as she was walking (with a long sleeved shirt and fully covered by the way) a young man yelled at her “Do you wanna fxxx? etc.” She looked back at him. He and his friends crowded in on both her and me shouting with anger. They hit her in the face and later they walked away, but one man came back to strongly grab her buttocks again. As she walked away she looked back to see who it was and the young man laughed and waved and flipped her off.  The incident caused me to think:1. What if my girlfriend were alone over there. As it was the two of us were far outnumbered by those young boys.2. If the men dare to act so aggressively, he must know there is a good chance no one would anything to stop him.3. I would not advise any women to go out into the crowds alone at night.

Better than expected. Good place to go and visit but beware of pickpockets. The souks is a fun place to be for a bit of bargaining and personally I would prefer coming here than going to the main square
Fascinating!. Charming, old world, dusty, exotic, sun drenched...a true cultural experience. About 20% of the people in the medina still get around by horse, donkey or mule. It is a walkback in time

keep away from snakes and monkeys.. Main square grotty, with touts etc, but the Medina souks were the best I have seen, better than in Istanbul.crowded, but lots to see.1 stallholder wanted 180 dirhams for 1 pashima, but we bought 2 for 170.Should have paid less, as he was happy when we paid, but still a bargain for a little effort.It was worthwhile traversing the outside circle in a narrow alleyway, as there were lots of people selling vegetables, and is an authentic experience, ,The museum was close by.
Five stars if there are less touts. A fantastic place to explore if not for our experience with the touts and scums who targetted tourists with small kids. Beware when visiting with small children.

madness. We have recently returned from a fabulous 3 day visit to marrakech, we obviously went to the old medina and the famous square - has to be done, but nothing prepares you for the experience - a trip back in time, utter complete chaos everywhere - if you survive the scooters and traffic its a miracle!You find it very difficult to look at anything without being hassled - although everyone from Morrocco that we met were delightful - its just their culture to try and sell you anything!!The alleyways are very confusing and chaotic, and in a way a little bit frightening, but do go you wont forget it.

mindblowing. Terrific experience.Force yourself not to buy ANYTHING on the first visit,Walk through it several times and sus out the gems hidden within.Soft pumps made to measure,best spices from an apothecary,tiny tagine pots for presents
Fantastic to visit. In the Medina there is a lot to see and do. It is crowded, dusty, noisy, etc but never a dull moment. If you want to relax you go to the new city.

Negotiate!. Very crowded but fun part of Marrakech beware of pick pockets and negotiate at least half the price of. Don't take pics of monkeys or snakes or you have to pay a lot of money. It helps if you speak French.

Well, it's big..... ....but that's about it. A huge olive grove that may have all sorts of importance, but not a lot to actually see, or do.
The pavilion was nice though.
A taste of Morocco. We liked the way that shopkeepers did not hassle us as much as in other countries we have been to. There are some good restaurants tucked away.

Just what you expect.. Noise, smells, every place trying to get you to look and buy, lots of fun, no one was rude or answered back when we said no.
I would not stay there after dark.
Very hectic, not to be missed.. Very crowded, but must be experienced, barter for bargains. Never seen so many mopeds they are all over so watch out.

frustrated. I found it very frustrating not to be able to take time over purchases as constantly hassled to buy.
when we got lost we were expected to pay for services of a passing citizen to point out our way.
generally though peple were very friendly
It's the place to be. The medina is fascinating and you get a glipse of of ancient Marrakech. You will get lost the first day but within a couple of days you get your bearings.

nothing like it. amazing assault on the senses with a maze of terracotta walled windy lanes, and a very easy place to get lost in! don't go in with a timetable for exit. Mostly very friendly shopkeepers although all wanting your trade, and a wonderful mishmash of donkeys, people and motor bikes moving goods and people around. just be clear that you DON't want help to find your way to the person who wants to be your guide, or take an official guide if you want to see something in particular rather than just to get lost in the surroundings and atmosphere.

Out of this world. Where to begin? The Medina is the whole old (walled) part of the city and covers everything from the souks to the square to riads and hotels and shops. Obviously the square, totally different by day and by night, two visits or one long one that covers both essential, and the souks are must see on any visit.

Mixed experience.. Some amazing things to see, especially well away from the tourist centre of the Jemma El Fna, with some nice friendly people if you engage with them. Speaking French with splatterings of Arabic words, like Shukran (thank you) goes a very long way. On the other hand, there were also a noteable number of people who were aggressive, unfriendly and mercenary, especially the unofficial guides and some shop keepers. I was grabbed a few times even when I politely refused and on a couple of occasions I had to make a very hasty retreat. It was a bit scary!
Must see place. Fantastic souks and amazing to walk around, great things to buy just be prepared to haggle. Great restaurants and bars tucked away.
Beautiful but touristic. It is a great part of marrakesh. Busy , colourfull. Full of bargains, ore not. We liked the atmosphere , the businees is sometimes overwelming
Great place a must do. Great place to visit, you must go here if in Marrakech. you will most likely get people trying to show you the way to other places just ignore them and they will go away.
Marvel at Marrakech. Was an amazing history lesson. See the cobbled roads, ancient walls and chapels. Great to visit @ night with the traders and locals.

This is a magical place. Locals, tourists, donkey-drawn carts, velos and motorbikes all throng the souks. There are no pavements or street names (almost!). Everything vies for your attention (and money) but the overall atmosphere is of calm and friendliness - day and night.

Exciting and vibrant. Medina is busy, manic and mad. It is really good to experience during the day and at night. The motor cycles and scooters seem to dart about between the stores as there appears to be no real road across the square. There are snake charmers and monkey trainers, horse and carts. At night it resumbles a fairground with music, entertainment and competitions. The souks are well worth a visit but be prepared to be hastled. You can easily get lost in the narrow ally ways and helpful people try to show you the way via their tannery of spice shop. They soon give up if you show no interest and walk on but you do need to be quite firm.
Love this place. Great, full of life and character. Try it at least once to see how a daytime feel is so different from a nighttime one. The latter has so much more buzz!

The Ultimate Medina experience. This world heritage listed medina is probably the most unique in all of Morroco. The Jemaa el Fna with its performers,storytellers,dancers.snake charmers etc turns into an outdoor food court at night.Fun,affordable and mainly hassle free if not for the motorbikes,speeding around the throngs of pedestrians. A stay in Marrakech is incomplete without a night visit to the Medina
got to be done. the walled city is fantastic, you can wander all day - that is if you can take the constant barrage of guys wanting to engage you in conversation, and try to visit their uncle's shop.
FANTASTIC. love, cant wit to go back ! beautiful walled city with so much going on. set aside at least a whole day to explore and discover the delights around each and every corner
Bargains. Hot and busy busy but you can get a few bargains. Lots of leather goods and Moroccan style gifts. Be prepared for some haggling to get the best deal.
crazy. nice and different stuff to get and a great view at night..but scary to be in..so many people and hassles and people trying to throw monkeys at you and snakes!ahhh

What an experience!. This place is just amazing! Yes there are people pestering you all the time but they have a good sense of humor and understand the word no albeit eventually. If you say La Shokran that means no thanks so it's quite useful.There were 8 of us. 4 men and partners. We ate at one of the market tables. The food was basic but great. They do not sell alcohol with the food.The whole atmosphere of Medina was incredible. The different smells, the music, the dancing.A truly memorable experience

smart sellers. you have to haggle as they ask you tripple of what they actually sell items for, food places are nice but i found the food very bland . nice fresh orang juice, spice souks not much else to do

Medina Marrakech. We found the Medina to be absolutely fascinating. We visited the first time with a guide and found this to be well worth the money. He explained that some of the stalls/people did not like photographs taken although for a small payment, you are allowed to do so.

An experience to Take ; a must see place in Marrakech. I stayed in a Riad near the Square... The square becomes live after lunch & busy till late night. Many shops and local products .. you need to bargain at least 3 times lower .. don feel bad saying such low price & stick to your price & slowly go up...& don leave the shop immediately.. its kind of slow bargaining... There are monkey & snake that you can take in your hand for photo.. And even with out taking it if you take a picture of it then they will ask you for money.. may be in that case give them 2dirham...obviously they will ask for more then you can walk away.. Its kind of everything needs money & everyone is looking for money.. there are traps as well.. like when you are walking in old medina, someone will say in english Square is not that way.. you are going into wrong direction etc... Keep your camera & wallet safe.... There is a big Mosque near the square.. its old & nice... In the old medina Taxi can not go inside due to narrow roads. so most of the time if you go outside you have to get off at the square then walk to your Riad... however its a lively place.. unlike the new portion of the city...

Medina Madness!. It was an amazing experience to visit the Medina, albeit overwhelming. The noise, the smells, the sights were a lot to take in. There's an abundance of souks and stalls selling everything you can think of. The food is fantastic and must be tried. There are some incredible sights to see, including belly dancers, snake charmers and monkeys. It is definitely an experience not to be missed.

All the world and hassle but facinating and worrying at same time. very interesting but hasstle from many and jostling spoilt occaision traders fine if you firm but not all wish to haggle but thats how it is

We loved the Medina!. We had visited the Medinas in Istanbul and Casablanca before visiting Marrakech. This Medina left those wanting!The best part is the maze of streets and souks. Yes, you will get lost, but there is so much to see. The character and atmosphere is like what you would see in an old movie.We were pleased that most of the things for sale in the shops were made locally (sometimes in the back of the shop) and not just Chinese-made trinkets.

Really a nice medina. What to tell about Marrakech Medina?
A real medina which bring you in the 1001 nights in 5 minutes.
If you don't know, you need to go.
Only one negative point, be careful. It is a bite insecure.
Not dangerous, but take care of your camera or wilet

A unique and unforgettable experience. You cannot truly describe the experience of visiting the Medina. You MUST go yourself see it. It filled with people, noise, smells, motorcycles, donkeys, sellers, restaurants, riads, hammams. It may feel overwhelming to some or absolutely intoxicating. We had chosen to stay in a Riad in the Medina and we were very happy of our choice. It is the place to be, to start and end the end full of life. There is the day experience and the night experience after 7pm. You must try both. Another must is to have a coffee or cold drink from the panoramic terrace of the Cafe de France on Jama El Fnaa place (make sure you seat at the very top level by using a hidden staircase). The view of the Medina is fantastic. It's the best people watching in the world. And make sure to take a caleche and do a full tour (1 hour) of Marrakesh, around 150 diramhs, especially at sunset. Totally worth it.

To live in a Medina is quite an experience. There are a world of colors and smells in the Medina. There is a busy feeling about everything.Streets are really narrow and a smell can envolve you so well that we can dream but it is bad we want to run away and it is not easy.. The riad can be in medina but the you feel a peace living in the riad , lay down in a terrasse and feel the water near you. people are very helpful but there is the hope of receiving money all time. Sorry but it was what I have feel. It is very unique. The colors are really beautifull and make a wonderful journey. That part I love it. Medina looks the place of poor people against the good apartments of nouvelle ville. They are two appart places...it seems to different cities.If I like to live in the Medina I would tell you yes...if i will repeat I don´t think so. It is an interesting experience for once time. It is my feeling.

Blew my mind. Liked that they show craftsmenship more than average junk found in medina; however, cannot encourage child labour found there. If children are working in the afternoon when do they go to school?Recommend going with a guide.
Marrakesh. A wonderfull city that makes you feel you entered a different world! Friendly people and a shopping paradise.
morroccan magic. liked - seeing local people going about their everyday busuness in an intriguing environment. disliked - my own feelings of nervousness as we went into the depths of the souks.

Best seen with a guide. The best advice we were given by our guide was don't eat any of the food it's not clean, don't drink any thing offered to you, don't touch the monkeys they haven't been vaccinated, keep your belonging infront of you, and don't buy products at the front as they are made in china. If you are going to go get a guide, ours was from the tourist office and was 50DM be careful as some of guides want to charge 25€ an hour! With a guide you will get less hassle and be shown the nicer places.Overall it was good but the smells of leather, petrol and horse poo was over pouring after a while.

Crowded, chaotic & fascinating!. A mind-blowing maze of tiny densely packed alley ways bustling with donkey carts, cycles, scooters and children playing football. Hundreds of stalls about as big as a cupboard, hawking everything from traditional slippers, carpets, aromatic spices, wooden artefacts and cycle workshops. Bargain for everything and never show that you like something! If you lose your way beware of "helpful" locals only too ready to put you on the right track and demand money. They don't just want your coins either! Keep a sense of humour!! You are in a different culture and the experience of being in the Medina is worth it! Tip for finding your way - rather than a ball of string take a photograph to identify any streets you turn down, that way you will find your way back more easily. It's chaotic, it's fun and it's an experience you will never forget! Well worth a visit!

Exotic and Chaotic!. WOW! All that I had expected and more. Bright and lively, an excellent opportunity for people watching, as well as appreciating the skills of storytellers and snake charmers. At night it comes alive with tents and tables for dining al fresco.

Most friendly salespeople on earth. The shopkeepers have learnt their lesson. As long as you do not ask for information they will leave you in peace. The atmosphere is very friendly and you feel safer than in many European cities,

Fantastic, but don't forget the other streets. The Medina (Jamee el Fna) is fantastic, but from our experience, isn't the best part of Marrakesh. The Medina is chaotic and an assault on your senses, but during the day, does feel a little like it's more of a circus than a true Marrakesh experience. In the evening however, it's all Marrakeshi's and it comes alive with the smells and light (oils,spices, flames, candles etc) of true Morocco. One thing I would say is, don't eat here. The food is very low quality, even in the nicer looking restaurants. Eat instead in the surrounding streets or in one of the amazing restaurants such as the Pepe Nero or the Dar Moha. Also, don't focus to much on the main square itself, use it to explore the surrounding streets, they are far more interesting and you get better, more authentic photos that you won't get charged for . .

good fun. this was so much fun, some good bargains to be had and shop keepers like to joke and have a laugh with you, try to settle on half what they are asking for, at night you could come home with one legged trousers !! always shop in daylight, the Medina at night is very crowed but sitting with a coffee and watching it all happen is such good fun .

Great Market Experience. I love Marrakech's medina, have visited here Morocco several times and its one of my favorites. Its very lively, they sell everything you can imagine, and its a great experience to just wander around and see what you'll stumble upon.

Life!. The old walled town of Marrakech where you will experience a very different way of life. Visit the Souks, a network of narrow streets where artisans carry out their various craft and sell their goods. Haggling is the expected way, so stand firm, give it a go and walk away if you don't want to buy.

Wow - a real insight into Moroccan life. We went on a night trip organised by the hotel. It was great. We went up to this little cafe that overlooks the square when we had a free 30 mins and got some great photos. I would highly recommend getting out there and doing some bartering!

Great vibe, bit overwhelming at night. Great historical city centre, watch out for the "guides"! The old market, the square and leather "fabric" are nice to visit. Make sure you negotiate on the price when you buy something in the markets, we easily could get discount of up to 70%, just as long as you play along with the game and keep smiling.

An experience. There is a lot of poverty in Marrakesh and the Medina has it's fair share of beggars and unofficial guides ready to pounce on you. Being a lone female did make me a target for anyone seeing a quick buck. I would suggest walking purposefully for as soon as you look lost they come out of the woodwork. One man wanted my watch for pointing me in the right direction and followed me demanding cash for about 50 metres which was a little unsettling. But overall it is a great experience that you would not like to miss.
Fantastic and vibrant. An amazing atmosphere and a great place to visit and be. The sort of place that everyone will enjoy, no matter of age or interests.Thoroughly recommended.

Wouldn't go back..... I went to the medina, who doesn't on a trip to Marrakech! Cannot say I was overly impressed with the behaviour of the local people. I found a number of them to be quite aggressive and lacking in hospitality and was quick to make a speedy exit. It was not my cup of tea but everyone should make the trip and form their own opinion.
Not for the faint hearted. Didn't feel comfortable walking around but probably would have been better with a guild or friends as not sure really what to do. Certainly an experience.

An Adventure!. WOW!! A bit overwhelming at times but truly an amazing experience. Be ready to negotiate - start with an offer of 25% of what they are asking. I was called a "berber" because I had great bartering skills. Do not be ashamed to low ball them, its a part of the culture.

where am i?!?. The Medina of Marrakech is a maze of unique sights and smells. The winding laneways uncover many great treasures. There are wonderful foods and many, many shopping opportunities so pack light and prepare to be coming home with stuffed bags.
A guided tour for a half day could be helpful to know which buildings to see the inside of...
Exciting. Do not be afraid to haggle. We enjoyed experience. A coffee on roof terrace overlooking square is a must
Crazy but fun. An exciting, vibrant market. Full of anything and everything, from leather jackets, lamps, nock off designer gear and food.

do it yourself.. We followed the guided tour and then did it ourselves. Go round the medina and then sit on the top floor of one of the hotels and watch the real Morroccan life go by. In the evening when they bring the snakes out is amazing.

The old but the best of Marrakech. The medina is where it is happening, it is the real city with the hussle and bussle. Donkeys and carts, street food, street sellers, souks, you'll find it all. The architecture is amazing and worth many photo opportunities.

Crazy fun!. Whatever you want, they have it here. Such a huge variety off good to buy, and the medina is fairly decently planned and organized. I found the shopkeepers to be pleasant and they were humorous with their bargaining tactics :) Pay attention to where you are going, but most anyone can direct you to the central square should you lose your way.

Turning back the centuries ...... An amazing place where you are immediately immersed into the sights, sounds and culture of Morrocco. This thriving and noisy network of lanes, alleys and squares includes the retail and business heart of the city, and visitors would be well advised to track their progress carefully so as to avoid getting lost. Expect to receive some approaches from over confident street sellers (be firm and polite of you are not interested), and be aware of the variable hygiene conditions that we noted in some (but by no means all) of the fresh food outlets. If you are tempted to buy fresh orange juice, ensure you see it being squeezed rather than produced from a container which may have been watered down. You can spend hours in this exciting place, and you should!
Atmosphere - and more!. Great atmosphere lots going on, places to eat and drink - and shop! A bit of hassling, but with care it's fine.
You could spend hours here. Takes a while to work out where to go and what you are seeing. A complete but wonderful assault on all your senses. Well worth the trip.

A Shoppers paradise. Don't even try to use a map to find your way around. Instead, rely on markers to find your way about and then relax and enjoy a true shopping experience. You no doubt will get lost at some point but if you can locate the square or one of your markers you'll be fine.

The old original city........ Now populated by at least as many tourists as Moroccans. The French had the good sense to move into a neighboring piece of real estate to leave the denizens to their own homes. A beautiful maze of housing and retail that has light patterns that confound the senses.

Enchanting. The medina was such an exciting place to visit. It was full of life and beautiful people working and enjoying the nightlife. My husband and I loved walking around the medina and watching the different entretainers. Also, there were so many places selling food, it was hard to choose a place. Everything was delicious and smelled great. I also did some shopping here and I found so many unique gifts. At last, it was so nice to enjoy such a beautiful place with the locals. We hope to go back soon.

Loved it. This is what Marrakech is all about, amazing, like going back in time. People were not too pushy, we enjoyed the good natured banter with the stall holders, and the food stalls at night were fun.
An interesting souk. Not as good as the Grand Souk in Istanbul but still interesting with a varied selection of goods at reasonable prices(if you are prepared to barter)

Not overly exciting. There were a few snake charmers and Henna ladies, but no atmosphere to the square. Markets all sell the same stuff - gets very repetitive and it's not even very interesting stuff!

Very touristy but good prices. I felt this medina was set up for the tourists, rather than a working medina as we had seen in Fes. The shopkeepers were very pushy and we walked quickly through until we found what we were looking for. The best shopping in Morocco and great deals if you are willing to bargain as many of the shops carry the same things. Keep walking if you don't get the price that you want or see what you are looking for.

Exciting, Alive and Shocking. Loved the Medina, the colour the smells and people. However, I detested seeing the poor Altas monkeys and snakes being subjected to such humiliation. The food in the centre of the medina at the stalls was amazing. Also loved the fresh orange juice. Make sure you ask for no water or ice in your orange juice.
fun!. Theres very little that wont satiate any kind of appetite in the magical place. Loads to do but watch your bag and be pleasantly assertive with the sellers
A really good experience. A whole different experience! A crowded and lively place with lots of things to be look at. I recommend at least 2-3days to explore the wonders of this place!

Nice to see,but watch out for the motorcycles!. Not the Medina in Fez, but still worth seeing. As in most medinas, the shops and shopkeepers are very interesting to see and chat with.We were able to get a little deeper into the souk and see some of the painting,weaving and other handicrafts being done.

A must do. A visit to Marrakesh is not complete without a visit to the Medina and the Souks, although you should take your sturdiest shoes to avoid walking in something unpleasant. You will be 'invited' into lots of shops but a firm 'no thank you' and a smile should save too much hassle. If you do go in be prepared for them to persist in trying to sell you something. Several shops sell almost identical things so don't rush into buying from the first shop you see. If haggling isn't your style there is a fixed price shop (a bit like a massive superrmarket) called EB something... I am sure you r hotel can arrange a taxi for you. Very different but very pleasant!

Narrow alleys of Marrakech. It is an experience to walk around the Medina and get lost in the narrow side streets. It is not necessarily near the Square and you can see a host of different types of artisans and craftsman, such as tannery in their quarters plus the usual array of shops.The Medina, the ancient habitat, represents an outstanding example of a living historic town with its tangle of lanes, its houses, souks, fondouks, artisanal activities and traditional trades, hence why it is also on the UNESCO heritage list.If you get lost yo will come across a 'faux guide', showing you the way out not before he points you to a shop selling the various medicinal oils.
Mysterious and Sensual. You go back centuries by wandering in the medina. You just never know what is behind those doors. A must see.
Senses onslaught!. Wonderful. Busy, hectic, noisy, smelly. Do not allow males to be your guide unless you wish to pay them money to do so.
Ancient Energy. It felt like I was back in the ancient days of Arabian nights. Very hot and crowded. Better to come here in Winter.
exotic. Our stay in Marrakech was in the medina. Although we ventured outside into the new city, we thought the medina was much more interesting and exotic by far.
dusk in the medina. get to a roof top cafe and take pictures from dusk its amazing to see the colours change and the centre liven up

AWESOME!. Utter chaos but absolutely fantastic, keep your wits about you. Snake charmers and Guys with monkeys will approach you and try to put the animals on you, be straight with them if you say "no" they will leave you alone but be assertive and all is good.

a cultural experience that you cant escape. This is the heart of Marrakech. there is no way you can escape this. the very heart beat of life in this region is here. Just sit, have a cool drink and watch the life of the Sahara meet the life of the coast within the curiosity of the tourists. AMAZING

{easy to get lost}. It's so easy to get lost in space, in time, in the smell, and in the charming beauty of all the tricky eyes trying to sell you something. One of the best places I have visited, ever.The part of the game are the sellers, and the hustlers... but it can get stressful so that in one moment you just want to escape from it! And then you want to come back... and so it continues. :)

Amazing experience, but the aggressive "guides" and sellers made it stressful. The agressive nature of the souks and the medina is not for everyone. I've been to many places, and this is one of the more aggressive, and often hectic, town centres. It is a once in a lifetime experience, but it is not easy. If you are from the UK or the States, then expect to stand out -- and expect to be approached almost every minute by someone who wants to sell you something, or by someone who wants money. I live in NYC -- I'm used to a fast pace. The medina center is stressful -- more so than I imagined.Either way -- a great experience.

Great browsing and shopping!. Shops of every kind, crafts of all materials, bustling alleys filled to the brim. The Marrakech medina is a haven for bargaining, yet the shopkeepers are gracious - many said, "Looking is free", and if we did not buy, they still thanked us for coming to visit their country!

Intricate. Well, we thought the taxis were ripping us off by not taking us directly to the destination but the medina is like a maze in which cars cannot go inside. It is such an experience to go. There are many shops in which if you like something, just buy it as you probably won't be able to find it again. Haggling is a must and fun, but can get quite tiresome as they believe foreigners to be rich. Most shops sell tahini pots, argan oil, lamps, bracelets. Be careful not to buy fake argan oil.

magical. A truely magical, beautiful place. Once you get use to the culture and be stern in regards to saying no thank you to those wanting to sell you something or those trying to pretend they are tour guides or work in your hotel, you feel very much at home and in all honesly, feel very safe. Haggling is great fun and not to be missed out on! Please note: the locals respect you more if you cover your shoulders and knees, and in all honesly you are in their environment and so this is only fair.

Madness in the mayhem - but worth it!. Amazing to wander around the tiny, winding streets of the Medina. Just be aware of people approaching you wanting to sell to you and steer you into shops, learning how to say 'No thank you' in French or Morrocan Arabic is extremely handy.The people are very friendly but remember there's real abject poverty here, you are perceived as 'rich' if you're a westerner, people are just trying to get by. The cost of living is cheap, be respectful and don't over do it on the bartering - you'll still walk away with a good bargain!

Medina maze !. We walked around the medina several times during our stay in Marrakech, we managed not to get too lost. However, if you see something you like in a shop buy it, because if you are like us you will not be able to find that shop again, its like a maze in there.
Seven Saints. I always love the visits to the tombs of sacred figures and Marrakech has a host of them. Start with Sidi Yusuf bin Ali and complete the tour with Imam Souhaili.

One of Morocco's best medina's. If you like shopping, discussing prices, finding souvenirs like babouches (in house leather slippers), textiles in all forms, spices, wooden masks, t-shirts etc, the Marrakech medina is just great. Mostly covered against the scorching sun, the medina is a reasonably cool place to be during daytime. During nighttime the place starts packing up. Of course don's forget to start or end your visit on the place Jemaa el Fna!

Busy busy busy. Interesting shops, smells and sounds-but spoiled by people constantly trying to sell or show you something. Be prepared to get lost but don't accept help from people coming forward and don't look at a map or guide book. Spice souks were amazing but also a fair amount of tat being sold nearer the square.

Another world, another time, another everything. The moment your transfer drives through a gate in the centuries-old walls, it's like a switch has been thrown and flipped you back in time 200 years or more. Donkeys jostle with scooters jostle with cars jostle with pedestrians jostle with a man carrying sacks on his back bigger than himself, pushing past an ancient woman selling bread under a shade.No more roads and pavements, just flat space there to be travelled on in any way possible, and none-flat space there to have products fastened to in the hope of a sale at a price yet to be agreed in a ritual repeated a million times a day, every day, since before time was time.If you think you're prepared for your first trip to the Medina, you're not. Every sense will be overloaded, fizzle out, then come back to life reconnected in a slightly different way. The Medina may not have changed for a thousand years or more but everyone who visits it is changed by it, and the Medina is different every day even though it never changes.Some will love it, some will hate it (just read the reviews here) - but underneath it all, this is a relatively safe place with lots of plain clothes police, and every shopkeeper understands that their livelihood depends on people like you coming back time and again - so if it all gets too much, step into a shop and explain your problem - you'll soon see the true hospitality and friendliness of the people of Marrakech (and the next day you'll go back to the same shop and buy something ;) )This is an amazing, unique, fascinating place, and one I can't wait to visit again. My main piece of advice? Don't fight it, let it happen to you, keep a hand on your common sense and enjoy every second - all too soon you'll be home and it'll be a distant memory

Hustle and Bustle. We visited the Medina 3 times. Firstly we went on the last day of Ramadan when it was busy with expectation of that feast and the holiday. On that day it was a little scary but that was only because it was all new to us. We went back on a caleche trip at night and this had a different flavour again. It was mesmerizing with the variety of open air restaurants and the other offerings including boxing of all things. In the evening there were no snakes or monkeys. We returned during the late afternoon to buy stuff to take home and had much hard haggling, usually settling roughly at half the starting point! A very special place.

an experience. loved the medina for variety of sight & smells, a great experience and we found the locals more friendly & less agressive than when we visited Tunisia some ywears ago - helps if you know a little French
would recommend. To see how the locals live it comes alive at night, you do get a bit hassled but thats morocco for you,

Welcome to Marakesh. The old medina is what makes people like me and you visit Marakesh. No words can describe the feeling u get when u visit the old medina and jamaa el fna. You can spend days in this chaotic, hot, and maize of people but as all other reviewers said - get a guide it will cost you not more than usd 30 but he or she will be your savior from all sorts of troubles. Try to go with guide gutting the day and at night walk to jamaa el fna and enjoy. Don't listen or get into discussion with cheaters. It is a must in Marakesh - welcome to Marakesh

Magical Place ….. Straight From The Time Of Ancient World. This place is not only a UNESCO World heritage Site, but also the most popular touristic area of Marrakesh for both foreign and local tourist. The place in one word is magical and seems it came out from the pages of Arabian Nights, especially at night. During day time, the Medina is full with snake charmers and tribal waterman. Most of the time the snake charmers encourage the foreign travellers to hold snakes for photos. Once photo taken, they start to ask for good amount of money and there is no escape. If you want to take a picture with snake, first fix a price with the snake charmer and then take photo. I have 15 dirham to a snake charmer and took many photos of him with snakes. Same goes with waterman, they also encourage people to take photos of them and start asking for money. But you can still enjoy the place is you keep your eyes open and be bold. At evening the whole medina turns into a magical place with 100s of food stalls. I smell of the food is overwhelming and intoxicating. It is difficult to resist the temptation of trying the foods. So be bold and try anything you like. The stalls sell chickens kebabs, lam kebabs, fish, sea food, vegetables and many more food items. There are few stalls selling freshly squeezed orange juice and they are nice and cheap. Few stall sells snail soup as well. The sail soup stalls are popular among the locals. I will recommend this place strongly as trip to Marrakesh is incomplete without going to Medina. Be hold and enjoy the atmosphere.

Marrakech Medina. I liked everything, but two things were special: when I was there it was Ramadã. At 7:45 pm many bells rang at the same time announcing the end of fast. Another thing was the negotiation habits: you want to buy something, they tell you a price, you offer less money for the product, they offer another price, until you get a consensus, that is goog for both. It is very funny!!!
Chaos!. This should be the main reason you visit Marrakech. The messiness is something you can't find in European cities. Hated it at first but loved it within a day.
A bit scary. A site to see and very atmospheric. Felt a bit intimidated. Well worth a visit. Felt sorry for the monkeys, they looked terrified.
Typical exotic a must see. What a pleasure to walk its streets talking with merchants and especially to see the colors and the multitude of handmade items
Fun But Exhausting In The Heat. I love to bargaain, but not in the extreme heat. The souks are alive until late in the evening which is a cooler time to do shopping.

Unlike anything in Europe. The Medina of Marrakech, the old city, seems like something out of an Indiana Jones movie. Clay homes line narrow streets filled with pedestrians, cars, mopeds, vendors, playing children, donkeys, camels, and all other manners of stuff. Be prepared for your senses, and your sanity, to be overwhelmed by this amazing site.

Living history. Wow, wow and wow again - an absolute must if you are in Marrakech - it is just enthralling and extremely hectic and canbe a little over the top - but this is North Africa and integral to the culture and experience.

Nice restaurants around. and only ones open if you go during Ramandan so choose your schedules well. We found a tour guide there that gave us a 20 Euro tour to the city the next day and saved us quite a bit!
Must see. Busy and chaotic, and absolutely brilliant, this is the real marakech, you get to see such a wide range of people actvities etc, all I can say is you need to visit it and see yourself,

Stayed in the Medina... We were travelling as a group of 3 girls aged 24-26 and we stayed in a Riad in the northern Medina. The first time we ventured out we had a guide with us but after that we felt confident enough to go by ourselves.It is unfortunate that the whole Medina gets tarred with the brush of Jemaa el-fna, which is a different place entirely and has it's own reviews if you wish to seem them on here!The Medina itself is traditional, winding, quiet, bustling, everything!! Just walking through the archways and past mosques NOT in the souks but in the northern area was a delight, we were not hassled, we barely even got a passing glance from the locals. We would smile at the children and get a cheery "Bonjour" or "Bon soir" back and a delighted grin when we replied as such. It is just a wonderful, magical place. Don't count what you see in and around Jemaa el fna as the true Medina as others seem to have done in their reviews, that is tourist central!

Not what I expected. The moment I arrived a woman squirted henna on my arm and then wouldn't let me pull away. She then insisted she was allowed to finished and made me pay her. When I got out what little I thought it deserved she stole a wadge of cash from my purse and disappeared into the night. I got hit on the arm with a snake and there are literally people everywhere after your money. It smells and there is human and animal excrement everywhere. The street food we had was great but they wouldn't let us leave until we gave a tip which was difficult as we only had large notes so again ended up with losing loads of money. Went back during the day and there was nothing to be seen apart from more henna tattooists. A great disappointment, was so looking forward to it, nothing like the pictures I had seen or read about.

Tortured monkeys, beaten donkeys, pestering locals, filth. We spent a lot of money coming to Marrakech based on the Tripadvisor top ten 2012 traveller choice cities, which placed Marrakech a spot ahead of Istanbul... but it pales in comparison! The jetset are gone and if there ever was any real glamour so has that! The poverty here is staggering, people harassing, sorry i should say begging you for money constantly... everywhere... it is quite sad... if you are able to look past that then you are confronted with filthy neighbourhood after another, rancid smells, piled up rubbish and an unkept environment all around. Prices are on par with other major cities and if i got what other top cities had to offer then i would not mind paying but i didn't... the locals that do not feel the need to harass you are rather nice, gentle and smiley and easy to comunicate with in various languages. The main square J el and is described in many poetic ways in literature but my take on it is that it could be fun if only the locals allowed you to take it in, but vendors clammer over one another to try to get your attention and if they don't get it it turns ugly, they start insulting you and can turn aggressive, even against one another... lots of brawls... The overwhelming number of motorbikes are dangerour and willing to run you over. The souks could be fun too but should you even dare to glance at any item, again vendors will swoop on you and not let it go... and i do not mean like in Istanbul where they will in fact get the hint and back off, these people do not take no for an answer... Perhaps the saddest part are the animals, monkeys that have had their teeth removed and are viciously reprimanded and choked should they not comply with the onslaught of petting and torture... i am a primatologist and it was evident that they were highly disturbed, but you need not be an expert to notice this... you will see starved donkeys being beaten with thick wooden and metal rods... the ones that could not physically go on got the brunt of the abuse... the horses are generally well fed but again nowhere close to being treated well... the snakes do not have it any better either... sheep seemed to be the healthiest of the animals i came across... the dogs and countless cats all look sick and near death... riddled with parasites... it made my heart sink really! :( Most attractions leave a lot to be desired... poorly maintained and overly hyped up. No real entertainment in terms of theatre or spectacle.It is possible to have a good time, just be ready to spend a lot of money, stick to the top 5*L hotels and spas, sip cocktails, ignore the bills, hire luxury cars to take you past the city walls to Majorelle gardens, Ourika valley, the spectacular Ouzud falls and Richard Branson's gem of a hotel well outside of town and tucked away in the mountains (for €170 they will send a range rover to whisk you away). But then do you really want to spend that much and get so little? This is the most negative review i have ever written and i am sorry for that but i think it is important that you know this so you can be aware of what to expect; a relic of good days gone by but with some potential still there
The Medina is Marrrakech. A trip to this city would simply not be worthwhile without exploring the medina. It is ancient and has old Moroccan famlies living right along side of chic Europeans.

Best district to stay. Marrakesh is splited in 2 parts : old city and new city ; as a traveler the only part you'll probably interested in is the old city which is called the medina ; this is where you find lovely little hotels set in traditional houses (riads) like Riad Monceau where we stayed. This is also where you'll find most places of interest like the souks and the museums. Most of the historical district is pedestrian only.
very touristy but fun. This was an experience! We stayed in a Riad in the Medina and walked through allies and avoided motor cyclists!

An experience!. A walk around the medina is an assault on the senses, so many sights and sounds and smells. It's interesting but becomes tiring quickly as you are constantly hassled by shopkeepers and people trying to act as guides. It's a shame as you can't really stop to appreciate it.
The souks. we loved this at night when all the food is being prepared. Have a drink at Cafe de France and watch the action. It's a must!

Intimidating but fun!. The medina was kind of how I expected. It's very fun but yes prepared to be quite harassed. No matter how many guide books we read we still managed to fall into some of the locals tricks to get our money - oh well! We did get a lot of comments of *fish and chips* and *spice girls* etc etc, somehow they knew we were brits even though we said nothing! Also two blonde girls going alone - even though we were very covered up we still ended up being spoken to and actually people could be quite intimidating if you did not want to listen to what they wanted to say or sell you! I ended up buying a scarf I've never wanted but an in the moment sale I suppose! Didn't go in many of the shops as felt very pressured of a sale of course but still nice to look around and cool as most is in the shade! Prepared to be a little harassed, get very lost, get loads of people trying to show you around for money and inhale some rather unpleasant smells as you walk around but just take in the sights and go with a clear mind, try not to feel too scared! :)

Get lost and enjoy. Like everyone you must go and see the Medina with all its history, culture, buildings and of course the Souks. The main square is arguably the largest of its kind in Africa and includes men with snakes, others with monkeys (rather sad I think), acrobats and many stalls where you can get orange juice for 4 dirham (a bit watery with some of them), and - in the evening - lots of traditional food. Behind the square, the Souks of Marrakech offer lots of merchandise though I think much of it is not of a great quality, and uninspired nowadays. I saw several traders bringing stuff from China and Europe to their stands. Be prepared to be approached by many traders and to haggle over the prices of the items you want to buy. Best decide before how much you want to spend on any particular item. A good guide for prices can be found on wikitravel.Another characteristic element of the Medina are the many Riads and Dars; traditional houses, sometimes small palaces, that are like oases within the busy city and that are bed & breakfasts, hotels or restaurants. I did not stay in a Riad but it certainly looks very enchanting and I had a lovely dinner in one of them.It is not at all needed to get a guide to explore the Medina. Yes indeed you easily get lost in the maze of little streets but just enjoy and don't worry, you always get out again. I found the entire area safe, and if you don't mind the hassle of the many locals offering you merchandise or services such as giving directions, all is good and great.All in all the Medina is a must see... Busy, crowded, chaotic and colourful. Intimidating to some, maybe, but just stay cool and enjoy the culture shift!

Beautiful chaos!. Stunning, exciting, enthralling. Be willing to get lost - you'll find your way out again eventually. Use your nose to locate the leather souk - you can smell the tanning dyes. Watch out for motorbikes by keeping to the right. Have fun bartering and wear trainers if you want to avoid getting dirty feet!

Most overrated medina in the middle east.. If you have never been to the middle east I guess this is a decent introduction into the markets and old medina life style. There are plenty of "different" things to see but:-Always go in large groups, you have a high chance of getting hassled more by people trying to rip you off for no reason.-If you are a women avoid walking around the medina on your own.-NEVER EVER ask for directions or listen to any of the locals when they say you are going in the wrong direction. They will just try to rip you off and will not be afraid of ganging up on you if you don't want their help. If you are lost stop by a bar buy a drink and ask for directions.-Be worn of drugs being sold around the medina even by young kids.-Don't buy stuff there unless it is really different from everything you see and you've paid 1/3 of the original price asked.-Don't go during ramadan all the above get much worst as people are in bad mood.

The very heart of Marrakesh !!. Unfortunately we didn't stay in the old quarter of Marrakesh and it was a pity as this is really the place to stay to "live Marrakesh" fro; the inside. Will definitely try to have a hotel in this quarter next ti;e we come here. That's where everything happen and where all interesting places are located like souks and so on...

Go for it!. Walk through the medina, through the souk, hang out in Djemma el-Fna, don'nt get hung up when everybody hits you up for money or triple the price of things (always offer 1/3!), learn to say no or to ignore it, but soak it all up and remember the sights and the colors and the sounds and the endless mosaic of everything that is going on. It's fantastic!
fasanating. the square,madinha and souks are so magical, you must go there in the day and night .it is so different in the light and darkness.

typical, must see. this is something you have to experience when going to marrakech, typical, beautiful but at the same time chaotic, and there are many people begging for money, people trying to sell you stuff overpriced- negotiate always!!! you ll need a good map!! lots of tiny streets easy to get lost in.

Way overated but interresting. It is a nice place to visit, there is a lot to see but it is fill with tourists (they are everywere and the salemen are just waiting for them and can be kind of annoying). We had some issues with the way animals are abused by a few. Still, it is a place to see, but you're better be ready and very patient.
Market. Haggling with Shops and buying stuff less than half price was some times was fun and some time very annoying.
Busy, chaotic, fun. Must do on a trip to kesh, make sure you start haggling at 20% and be in for the long haul when you do.

A must for any visitor to Marrakech but beware of the Henna Women!. Such an amazing experience, and a must if you visit Marrakech. Dont be afraid to barter with the market stalls- as they see it as a sport and enjoy the bartering themselves. Be aware that the first price they give you is very inflated, and you should come back with at least half/third of what they ask- then the bartering will begin! Beware of the Henna women who are like vultures- if you are female you will have a really hard time with these, as they grab you and hold on to your hand, and before you know it they have started tattooing it- claiming its free. As soon as they finish they then ask you for money, and follow you until you pay them. We learnt very quickly that they ignored me saying 'no' but they listened to my boyfriend when he said no, and immediately left us alone. Make sure you get a fresh orange juice from the sellers- they are delicious and nothing like the juice I have ever tasted in the UK.
Brilliant. The walls are wonderful and some of the babs, gates, are beautiful. They are very long so walking all round is not possible, but take a bus or caleche and enjoy.

Animal cruelty. If you care remotely about animal welfare, avoid this area. Also, you need a thick skin to avoid and ignore the constant calls for you to 'look, buy, see'. Be careful with your bag/ourse, keep it close to you and try to find your bearings quickly so that you don't have to ask a boy to help you find your way. They will pester you until you shout 'gendarmerie, gendarmerie'.
a really good experience. glad we visited the area and enjoyed mingling and seeing first hand the area. Amazing amount of cats

Manic but enjoyable. First night here I thought omg what am I doing but went in twice more and enjoyed haggling with the locals and drove some hard bargains.
