Get the price, work it out and then get a price you are willing to pay and drop a little and stick at it. Walk away and they will beg you back at your price, maybe with a kiss as the clincher. You do get hassled though and have to be firm and some do try to take advantage if you don't have your wits about you.
Dont miss this!. Wander around and be surprised at every turn. Don't be afraid to get lost, there will always be someone willing to point you in the right direction.
Great!. Much better by night but so much going on and a real must. Don't be sucked in by the illegal guides who want to take you around the souks.

Everything it was described to be.... We liked the medina in Marrakech, but not as much as the medina in Fes. While Marrakech is busy, sparkling, and full of life it is way more overwhelming than Fes...There are a ton of things to see and do...Also remember haggling is a way of life and if you go for first price you've missed half the fun.

Good. It is great to wander around the medina, though except to get lost at some point. This is all part of the fun- if you do get lost ask a fellow traveller to help rather than a local youth as they will expect a payment and may take you somewhere else ( and you will get more lost!!) Enjoy a bit of haggling and then find Cafe Arab in the medina for a drink - fabulous Mohitos on the terrace!

Lively streets. It's fun to walk around the Medina - it's even fun to get lost a bit and just walk until you find your way again. But be aware of "faux guides", people who offer you to give you directions or to show you a sight. Almost all of them will ask you for money in the end. Even if they insist that they won't. That's really the downside of Marrakech's wonderful Medina.

Marrakech Medina. I had visited the medina before but this time i was hassled a lot more. I felt quite unsafe at points particularily as people kept grabbing my wrists and trying to put henna on me. I had heard bad reviews before about how you can have allergies to the henna and then they try and charge you for a design you didnt even want. On the plus side we did some good shopping but i did not like the general atmosphere. We also ate some terrible food at a "french" restaurant overlooking the square. Don't pick the first place you see to eat at!

Must go but.... The old city of Marrakech, Medina is a place to go just to say that you have been there. Visit the Shouks to make purchases of all local kind of products. Have a walk around Jeema El Fna Square & visit Koutubia as well.

a trip back into old times. it seems like you are travelling back in the old times...! I just didn't give it max score because I still think that Fez medina is much more charming and people were nicer over there. People here tried to explore us to much, which was overwhelming after one day we wanted to get away just because of that...

Such an enchanting adventure!. Before I traveled to Morocco, a lot of nay-sayers thought I would have a tough time as an American and a woman. Fortunately for me, they were dead wrong. The medina in Marrakech is a cultural treasure and was the highlight of my entire trip to Morocco. The medina is dirty, convoluted, crowded, and utterly delightful. I found Moroccans to be some of the friendliest people I have ever met. None of the hustlers were pushy to the point of worry or even annoyance. As in any foreign country, be vigilant of your surroundings and use common sense. Be smart, but don't be overly suspicious. Otherwise, what is the point of traveling? Other guests at our riad despised the locals and the bustle and grit of the medina. How sad for them. Go shopping! Talk to the shopkeepers! Bargaining was a very entertaining experience, and not one shopkeeper seemed upset or angry if I lowballed them. In fact, they all took a gleeful pleasure in crossing out their original offers and haggling on price until an agreement was reached with a handshake (and if you are lucky, some hot mint tea). Ask to learn a couple of words in Arabic, and don't be afraid to make friends. You might be very surprised how far it takes you!

When in Rome....... Granted the first night we went to the medina we were a little out of our depth getting grabbed and so forth around the food stalls which I just took as part of the experience ....However my girlfriend decided to dress appropriately covering her head etc and we were not bothered at all for the rest of our holiday. We had done a little bit of research about people giving directions etc and charging money for it which we just always ignored. If you walk with a bit of purpose and don't worry too much about feeling rude by just walking away and not engaging too much in unwanted conversation then you will find the experience fantastic in the medina. I think British people (of which I am one) find it difficult to interact this way. Pick your food stalls from a distance, be polite when looking at goods and just smile and walk away if the price is ridiculous and the prices will drop 50% instantly. ( the same goes for the taxis)If you want a shopping experience minus the "hassle" as most people call it then go to Essaouira as you don't get bothered the same way at all.I also found greeting locals with 'salaam alikum' was MASSIVELY beneficial, you seem to get much more respect. When we started trying to engage people this way we never got ripped off for anything. (taxi journeys that started costing 50dh ended up costing 20)Enjoy it!!!!!!

Don't ever miss this in your life !. The medina of Marrakech should be high on your bucket list ! An unbeatable experience with lots of fun, haggling, millions of products, people from everywhere and culture.Just plunge in and enjoy. Have diner on the Jemaa el Fna, after 16:00.

Interesting place to visit. Has narrow streets and very confusing. One could get very easily lost. People speak very little English but after a couple of hours one gets used to the place. If you do not have much time then hire a guide.
Medina. everything you ever read about the souks and the medina are true evry hospitable people not in your face and not the bother that i expected

Surreal and Fun. This place is crazy and a little scary... but FUN. Makesure you say NO firmly to anybody who starts to follow you, or call's you 'Friend', tries to 'show you around' as they will expect money. Also, don't take photos of people around this area unless you ae prepared to pay. You will find if you pluck up the courage to haggle, you will get great bargains. And make sure you on a tour with a certified guide to the medina and they will take you to the medical centre which is a fantastic experience and they sell you all sorts of natural remidies.

Outstanding - like nothing on earth. There's nothing not to like in the Medina - you can eat and shop like a king on a shoe-string - the food stalls which appear in the square after 7pm serve some amazing dishes. The locals can be lippy but it's in the nicest of ways - you'll never feel awkward in the slightest. We were family of four with a 10 and 13 year old and were relaxed throughout after getting used to the basicness of life in Marrakech. The souks are also out of this world - a blend between camden market and Life of Brian...! Don't hesitate to book in..!
Amazingly Friendly. First impressions of the medina are a little scary, but within a day or so we realized that it was very safe and quite friendly.

Intens, warm and alive. Crowded, noisy, but alive! This is sure a place you have to visit if you are in Marocco/Marrakesh. People, animals, Scooters, cars, bicycle mixed all together. Avoid people trying to get money for helping find your way around, ask other tourist or try by yourself and a good map!

Crazy and fascinating!. Love what the other reviewer said --"dirty and beautiful" describes the Medina exactly. Be prepared for an amazing display of humanity. The dress, the culture, the performers, the goods for sale--like you're on another planet. Be prepared to haggle for what you want to purchase in the souks. Our rule of thumb is cut the price given in half, then take 20% off that, then get ready to bargain a bit. And be prepared to shrug and walk away if your price isn't met...they hate to lose a sale and will usually come on down to your price, or close enough. The snake charmers, the henna artists, the people selling snakes and lizards and argan oil and spices and fresh orange juice and djellabahs--whew! It's astounding and exhausting, so when it all gets too much, go to one of the restaurants with a second or third floor terrace and relax over a nice meal. We DID eat dinner from one of the open air stalls in the open stalls of the Jemaa el Fna on our last night with no ill effects, but I was a bit nervous. Getting lost in the maze of the souks is a once in a lifetime experience. If you go, embrace the experience--and keep a hand on your wallet, just in case!
A Slice of Moroccan Life. There seems to be a medina in every major city. The one at RAK is second largest to the one at Fes.Rustic humanity at its finest.

Hustle and Bustle. This is an experience like no other, I just loved it! Everything is done at a fast and furious pace. Don't be intimidated by the sellers just say no and they leave you alone, don't forget to barter for your goods and walk away if you're not happy with the price, they'll soon call you back for the sale. One thing I would say don't get drawn into someone being your guide, they'll want to be paid for it and just wander the souks yourself. If you are not sure how to get back to the main square just ask everyone is friendly and helpful and will set you off in the right direction. If it all becomes too much go onto one of the roof top cafes and chill out looking down on everyone else.
Crazy but a Must do. Crazy, crazy, crazy. A natural film set. It's like you've been transported onto the Indiana Jones film set. The noise and hustle and bustle. Great

medina. check out the difference day time vs night timeduring the day its chilled out take advantage of the cafe's and meet localsthen during the night return and see all the stalls soak up the atmosphere the food stalls and do some shoppingbe aware of the men with monkey's they will place them on you and take photos then ask you for money also be aware of the henna ladies who try to grab your hand do henna then ask for money
Fasten Your Seat Belts. You must of course experience the medina as it is the traditional soul of the city. But be rested and well hydrated or it will tap on your nerves.

Souked out. I think its good to see a few times. However be prepared for the hasseling and batering. There is a lovely passtisaire in the entry of the souk worth going to. Try and speak french if you know it as soon as you speak english the prices inflate rapidly. Overall you need to see it for yourself!

Dirty & Bautiful!. Many have asked me about this experience, and I always say, "dirty & beautiful!" the medina is built like a maze with wonders, beauty, and displays of real life every we're you turn. If you travel for attractions and sites, skip Morocco all together, but if people fascinate you, you should not miss the Medina!
Madness!. Great fun. Don't go on your first day as it is overwhelming. Don't be intimidated!

Amazing place. AMAZING... if you are fascinated by Marrakech. Medina is what it says on the tin... crazy but intriguing ... dysfunctional but captivating ... loud ...I absolutely loved being there just seeing the world go by...

And suddenly.... Your in another world. This is what you call a holiday experience. Everything in Marrakech is different and screams "I'm away from home!" but this is just superb. Suddenly you're in another world. It's where locals and tourists mingle. there is everything for the rich and the not so rich (despite what our taxi driver told us I still don't believe this is where locals buy their supplies).there is so much to see... you can spend hours just wandering round and taking it all in.It's beautiful and exotic but like everywhere you go in marraakech, you need to haggle. You might not get the best prices but you will get a once in a lifetime experience.

A Must-do in Morocco. You don't need a guide to take you shopping through the souk, but it's worth it to pay a guide a few dollars for the rest of the medina to better appreciate where you are. This place was amazing, it felt like stepping centuries back in time, or a scene from Indiana Jones. From the narrow maze-like alleys, men wearing Berber robes (much like the Jawa outfits), to the donkey carts, spice vendors, figs, dates, olives, snake charmers (Cobras!!), Moroccan lanterns, carpets, stalls brimming with mint, mint, and lots of mint, grilling kebabs, orange juice vendors, musicians, street acrobats--there's a lot to take in. It is worth experiencing the central square (Jemaa el Fna) both in the daytime and at night.If you want pictures with the snakes, expect the "charmers" to try to get the equivalent of about $20 from you. Don't feel bad for giving a few dollars instead. $20 is absurd. Don't be taken for a fool. A couple dollars is plenty sufficient, if not too much.We were given advice to watch for pickpockets, so keep your valuables secure and out of sight. We were also warned by the proprietor of the riad we stayed at to avoid food from the open-air stalls in the central square, as he said he's had guests get very sick, even having to go to the hospital. A friend of ours also said the sickest he's ever felt in his life was after eating food from the square, but it was also among the best food he's ever eaten. With this advice in mind, we decided to avoid eating food from the square until our last night in Morocco, figuring that if we got sick, it would be at the end of our vacation. It was cheap, delicious, and we managed to escape any food poisoning. Locals largely dress very conservatively, with many women wearing headscarves. So, while there were many European women wearing very skimpy clothing, it seemed untoward in that environment. While I would wear tank tops and daisy dukes in the States, capris and covered shoulders is probably the skimpiest outfit I would feel comfortable wearing there. I made an exception for a tank top while hiking in the Atlas mountains when it got really hot, and I got some stares. Just something to keep in mind while packing for your trip.

Unique walled city in the heart of Marrakech.. There is nothing else quite like it! Not for the feint-hearted, but a treasure of interesting old buildings, palaces, mosques and of course the souks. To appreciate this spectale, it;s best to stay in one of the Medina's small riads, to sak up the real atmosphere of this unique place.
Beautiful. This is beautiful and unique place... go in the morning and you may even have it all to yourself. It's worth taking your camera too!... watch out for the hundreds of stray cats!

Amazing experience but dont forget to always bargain for prices!. It it's crowded, dirty, loud people all over and trying to approach to sell you something. If you don't make eye contact and you ignore them you will be acting on the safe side. just remember that when they give you a price you can literally negotiate over 50%. Don't take pictures Without permission and don't ask for directions, these people don't do anything for free! Don't trust anybody, be cautions and you will have a fun time sopping at the medina!

Expectations unfulfilled. Just too much like a car park full of hustlers! Having lived in the Middle East most of my life, the Jemaa el Fna did not live up to my expectations, and the wonderful Medina was spoilt by hordes of weekend tourists and even more aggressive hustlers selling overpriced knick knacks. There are many more authentic and original medinas around the region, which still retain their original character without the blatant commercialism.

Not to miss experience. The medina of Marrakech is an experience that must not be missed. Whether it is looking at the old buildings, shopping in the souks, pampering yourself at a Hamman or eating at a stall in Jemaa El Fna. Of course you must also try the orange juice which is fantastic.

Crazy, and I loved it!. Medina is noisy, busy, colourful and manic, just what I was hoping for! The souks were amazing, so bright and full of life. Everyone wants a deal but there is no aggressive selling. They love a Westerner who can bargain so go for it!
medina. amazing place full a mix of medieval and modern western culture

A Time Machine. But for the many zipping motor scooters, you can imagine yourself transported to the 12th century. The many small streets with shops and craftsmen were fascinating. Sure, some of it is aimed at tourists, but these are the same craftsmen that are producing for their residents. The medicine men and snake charmers and storytellers may want you to pay for pictures of them, but they are charming and selling, and storytelling in Arabic for local consumption as they have for centuries.
Immersion in the culture. Most of the history it's inside those walls.Discover every corner.There is surprises awaiting behind doors!
deals. We had a guide and got a number of good deals to finish out our souvenir buying

Medina Experience. Do not take any hassle. Stand your grounds. I know I have visited before but make sure you have decided how much you wish to pay for any items and don't feel intimidated by those that try and intimidate you. I had a lot of agro from the women in the Square trying to give me some henna tattoos. Although they continued to 'tattoo' me, whilst I was saying that I was not interested and they kept asking for money, I stood my grounds. They got really nasty and in the end scraped the tattooing liquid from my arm back into their 'pen'.

Crazy mopeds..... This would be a lovely street to shop, there's clothing, food, lanterns and everything you would expect from a Marrakech shopping area, except there is no footpath and legally no public right to walk, it is a road, and a narrow road, and two way traffic is permitted, and for the most part this is a steady stream of mopeds! On my first night one collided with me as he passed by, he wasn't looking where he was going, he was chatting to someone on the otherside of the street! The experience left me shaken.They come through continually and at speed, often on their mobiles, and I even saw one guy texting.It's difficult to stop and look in a shop-sad for the store owners who must lose out as people rush through to the more open 'square'.Certainly would not recommend to families with young children or disabled folk. They speed around as I f they have no comprehension that the vehicle they are riding can injure...bonkers!!

Urgh.... Well well well..If you want to buy something it is really impossible here without the "thrill" of haggling.Now, I was looking forward to this part but soon it takes its toll. I used to do sales as a living and these people can be quite impossible. Something that should cost 250-300dh they will start at 800 like its fine, so I did same and started at 50dh. They dont like that.Put a price in your head and stick to it,start 60% below and work up gently, they will start to crumble. Not working? Just simply say its above your budget and walk away slowly. They will let you but soon shout you back. When your ready to name your final price offer a handshake and say your price clearly and shake. IF they say anything slightly higher, repeat your price once more and say its final, they will agree.If someone starts at 100dh they will normally accept around 20-30dh. Be strong and uncaring and they will give in.We got lost at one point and between dodging motorbikes and locals I was STRESSED out! But always smile.. that makes the locals think your not lost and don't bother you.Do not accept anything someone gives to you as they will charge, and if anyone offers to take you somewhere or talks as you walk, go away from them as they will expect payment. People offering Henna will try and grab the girls hands and start without talking. A strong NO does the trick. Remember, no matter where you are from no one can touch you without permission and let them know this.Its a place you HAVE to go... but also a place you have to not spend long in as it does get very stressful.Learn some basic French as it will serve you well! No Merci is one I said a lot.So if you are gonna go for it, hard hats on, chest puffed out, protect girls you are with as men Lear at white girls and go out and go for broke and enjoy the sights in front of you!

Aggressive sellers, little charm, animal abuse. Not the charmimg city of the 1960s when mick Jagger and the jet set chilled here. A medina with little charm due to the aggressiveness of sellers who are only interested in your money. Fake guides abound and pick pocketing is a worry. The monkeys are not treated well and are there for picture taking. Not many interesting buildings and certainly no feel of the exotic. Food also variable. Go to Fez instead.

Bustling hive of activity. Like all Medinas it was overwhelming with stalls and people, but would rate the one in Fez more highly. A guide will give you a much better tour if your time is limited, but don't be afraid to wander around by yourself, though you will get lost.

Animal cruelty. I found Marrakech to be a fascinating place although I was not impressed with the Animal cruelty I witnessed in the square with the apes and the snakes, we are in the 21st century now is there any need for it, I would hope that if enough people contact their tour operators about this the practise will stop, Morocco earns many millions from tourism, I spoke to many people who were so upset they vowed never to return
BUSY. Its is just fantastic spending time in the souks - Just fantastic

Worst city in Morocco. As some other reviews who rated this city 'Terrible' would say - this place is a night mare. If you want anything authentic then stay away from Marrakech. If you think visiting this city makes you 'cultured' or experienced in the orient way of life you are mistaken. As Edward Said once said, reverse Orientalism is now coming true. Where people of the orient are turning back to strong stereotypes of themselves in order to benefit. Either from tourism or something other. Marrakech is as authentic as tortillas are mexican. Ok not great example but yes.The main square where you end up - is it. It is the place for everyone with foreign currency to gather and blow their money. During the day it is so hot you cant walk around so you end up lost in the covered markets. Everyone wants something from you and will not always be polite. We avoided certain streets after passing them once as people remember you and come after you.We once had a child who followed us begging for money for a good 20 mins. She just had her hand up looking for money and refused to leave. She was then joined by her sister who both followed us without mercy. Ignore them and NEVER make eye contact. If you think you're helping a poor child you are greatly mistaken. This is part of a larger criminal organisation and these children are the front for collections. During the night the food market can get hectic. I quite enjoyed the chaos but once you have eaten do NOT walk inside the foot stalls area. Everyone will have their menu in your faces. I politely declined each offer by saying i have already eaten and that seemed to work. What was offensive was how people would chant things to you in a language they believe you understand. I am brown but i'm not Indian. After hearing this 10 times it became old and quite frustrating. I dislike this treatment and its not because im a sensitive person but because basic mannerism just is void in marrakech.Food here generally is rubbish outside of the market. Thats my personal view. Not a fact. After seeing 5 cities in Morocco marrakech was my least favourite. If you want to go somewhere go to Fes. The tourist police are very active so you are not bothered and can enjoy yourself down streets and markets and talk to who you want to talk to.
Real labyrinth. Real labyrinth. Good to have someone who will show you around! But feeling was great!

Not the stress you think!. Keep your wits about you, stay away from the snake charmers and monkey men and you will have a wonderful experience. Absorb the smells, colours and sounds and take your photos very discreetly - you will have a fab time.

Vibrant and exciting. Much to see and do. From the splendid historical buildings to the souk to the Jemaa El-Fna, the Medina has a great deal to offer. We spent a eeka dncould have stayed longer. Magical.
a bit of a rush,. Interesting but our thompsons guide rushed us and as it was hot we got tired very quickly. Interesting to see though.
Nice. Have to see it and wander for hours, but in the end is tiring, and nice to get back to quieter place

Fez is better. We spend weeks travelling through Morocco and by the time we hit Marrakech perhaps we were bit over the souk medina thing but even if we were `I would go back to Fez anytime before Marrakech. Just a tad too tourist hectic
Amazing!. Definitely worth a visit but choose your guide carefully! The shops they take you too obviously pay them commissions and this is clearly added on to the price you pay for anything.

You can buy anything & everything here. I recommend wandering around through the walls of the medina and allow yourself to get "lost" in there. Eventually, all roads lead back to Djemaa el Fna. There are so many things to look at and the quality is rather good for almost everything. We went to over ten cities in Morocco and I have to say this is one of the largest and best places to shop. Salesmen are pushy so just say no with a smile if you're not interested in purchasing and just want to look. Bargaining is part of the process, so expect to politely bargain them down to at least 30% less than their first quote. There is a post office in the big square, Djemaa el Fna, so you can ship your purchases home.

Not the best medina but still in top 3. The best medina in Maroc is in Fez, All the medinas are look smilar you can find lots of souks ( small shops ) which are still used by local citizens. Just Bargain Bargain Bargain before you buy something

Another world and an experience you won't forget. My wife and I spent 6 days in the Medina at a Riad in May. Nothing like pulling your suitcase through dog and chicken poop, and muddy holes while dodging scooters and beggars. That being said, it was a cross-cultural experience I will never forget. The smells, unique foods, beautiful handicrafts, calls to prayer, and simple kindness of strangers. Not many places like this left in the world!
No Guide Needed - Getting Lost is Fun. Have a blast & tour the Medina without an escort. But watch out for aggressive shop keepers and unofficial guides. A firm "La" ("no" in Arabic) does the trick.
Exotic. Its here where the modern & ancient meet, strolling here will take you back hundreds of you years back...Definitely a must do while in Marakeh
loved it. its got real character and its not as difficult to navigate as some say !!!!! scooters are a hastle but one gets used to it after a day of walking around
Bustling heart of the city!. Make sure you agree on a price first, haggle, and enjoy the maze of souks as well as the quiet and views of the rooftop terraces around the square.

Friendly souk and old city. This is the heart of Marrakesh. The souk is well organized, the merchants are friendly and won't yake offense if you don't buy. Friendly and humoristic atmosphere. I especially enjoyed the Palais de La Menara "Ali-Baba" gallery and the instructive visit at the Herboristerie.
Much fun, enjoyable shopping!

Amazing. Just go for it, get lost, relax, and have a laugh with the locals. They're after your business obviously, but just stay calm and relaxed, polite and smiley, and you'll have a shopping experience to remember.
The heart of the city. The only place to stay in Marrakech and experience the rhythm and flavours of the city.

Day & night. We first went in the day it was pretty quiet compared to when we went back on a night. It does come alive at night.Liked the energy at night the drums and the hustle and bustle. Didn't like the use of animals; monkeys in collars and some wearing nappies. I am opposed to animals being used in this way. there are many snakes there too, beware of having one draped around you & being expected to pay for the privilege. Be careful of taking photos they will demand money off you, so beware! Same in the Soukhs they don't apprciate photos either. I am not sure I came away with as much of a bargain as I'd have liked, some of the stalls were happy to barter hard, others seemed to accept the low proce but be offended at the same time, I think its all an act. Don't feel initimated by anyone there, be confident and firm but not rude.

Very hectic but an awesome experience !. The old part of Marrakech is definitely worth a visit. Many sights foreign to people from other countries - a great experience. You will be hassled by people trying to sell you things, take you places etc. A firm "no" will do the trick for the most part, but there is one person after the next. That is really the only downside though. The smells, the sounds and the things to see are so amazing and so worth it. Deffinitely a "must-see" while in Marrakech.

The hasle going around easpeshley at night. The place was great but with the moterbikes weaving in and out of the crowards was not good if you wair there on your own go as a couple or as a group. The view from the reastarant balconey,s was grear day and night.
A great new world to explore. A great cultural experience. Be prepared to get lost and try not to get angry getting unlost!

This is Marrakech!. This is the real Marrakech and it is fantastic. What an atmosphere and what a buzz. SO much going on. The souk sells everything but can be intimidating initially because of the maze of tiny streets lined by bartering merchants. The square comes alive at night in a magical way that will thrill even the most experienced traveller.

Must see but watch you don't get lost!. Incredible experience, bit nervous the first time but then you get used to it and start buying stuff! We did get lost but partly cos my husband doesn't do asking for directions!
Not as unique as Fes but still interesting. A little dodgy. Watch your pockets and purses. Very interesting to see the working conditions of this place, quite a culture shock.
A Must. You can get lost, but if you just think of the Place Jemaa el Fna as the center you just go back and you'll know where you are.

magical. What a wonderful place to visit, expect to get lost even with a guide book, the sigths, sounds & smells of this place are wonderful. Expect to haggle quite a lot & expect people to bother you but it all adds up to a great place to visit. At night it is even better.

Getting Lost is Fun. Touring around the Medina is like a maze, and just as much fun. Go beyond the Jemaa el Fna and roam around the whole Medina. The salespeople can be very pushy, but that is their way of life. The farther from the tourist spots you go, the more they leave you alone. The Kasbah is very nice area, with small cafes and the palaces to see. Their is also a fabulous cooperative there, with high quality wares and no pushy salesmen. So just enjoy the fun of getting lost in Marrakech.
Great visit. Just loved the whole trip the culture and bustle Looking forward to returning in oct
Wonderful..... Brilliant such wonderful smells, flavours and sights to see.. buy and get lost in!!

Great atmosphere. it was very lively, especially in the square after dark. Watch out for the ladies who grab you to henna your hands. They can be very persistent. Most people did not pester us if we said that we were just looking.

Be firm and it's great.... Haggle haggle and HAGGLE! Start at what you'd expect to pay for the items quality, and be reluctant to increase our price. People hassling you to visit their shop will stop if a woman tells them firmly 'no thank you' - my boyfriend got ignored and pestered until I spoke up. Beware ladies - henna tattooists WILL grab your arm and decorate it before you even realise and then demand payment. We refused to pay as she literally wouldn't release my arm and it got a little ugly. Walk away swiftly before they get the ink out!!

World Heritage Delight. This place is phenomenal. In a world of new new new, old here is still beautiful. The organic, eco friendly, pink clay walls are standing hundreds of years and you feel as if you've travelled back in time but in a good way. My grandfather had a picture from moorish spain of a dark senorita in a pink old town archway with kittens playing at her feet. I now realize it was Marrakech and she was a Berber miss! The ladies are covered but theres no pretence to it. Everything is relaxed and easy and genuine.

Madness. A total assault on the senses and, if you are not careful, on the wallet. Make sure you haggle well and don't be put off by the shop keeper seeming distraught or offended at your first offer - which should be as rediculously low as his was high - it's all part of the "act"

Must stay inside the Medina!. Staying in the Medina allows one to easily go out to shop/sightsee and return to a gorgeous Riad for relaxation without the need to take taxis. Some of the best restaurants are located in the Medina. It is not a huge area so you can walk everywhere in less then 20 minutes.

Fantastic. Really walkable. If you get lost, look for the Koutoubia minaret to orient yourself. Pay attention to the other reviewers: do not take photos of the snake charmers, dancers, or monkey handlers. They have assistants who will rush you and demand the equivalent of 20 euros for the privilege of taking a picture. If you must take a photo, I suggest bargaining before you take it. Same goes for the "guides." There are two types: those who want to guide you in order to get a commission on the items you buy; and those who want to charge you for guiding you to certain landmarks. The former aren't too bad -- we were taken interesting places -- to the textile dyers, to the women who grind argan, etc. The latter are like the snake charmers and their ilk in Jemaa el Fna -- once you ask for directions they'll run ahead of you to guide you. The only way to avoid being harassed to pay an exorbitant "guide" fee is to negotiate a fee for giving directions -- thus, we paid the equivalent of 2 euros instead of 20 euros. We found the best people to ask for directions were the older men, preferably not proprietors of shops. They were friendly, gave directions without harassing us for money -- just nice people.

Hectic, a maze of souks, colourful, smells. The theatrics (snake charmers, monkeys) in the square, the orange juice carts, the colourful stalls, the water peddlers, horse carriages, entrance to the souk maze, colourful shops, loads of restaurants, lots to see and experience in the characteristic fortress.

Impressive. You HAVE to hire a guide to visit all the historical sites. This part of the world is so different from what we are used to.Be respectful of the "dress code", and be careful with the tourist traps that the guides take you to buy stuff... they double the price of things because they have to give the guide a BIG commission (30 to 50%)!!!!.
Historic and fun. Get lost and have fun trying to find you way....only the path stop and enjoy all the shops
Just Remember Your Direction. Actually rmember the number of lefts and rights and you won't get lost. The kids are always ready to help for a few dirhams

Must do in Marrakech. When in Marrakech, I stayed in the Medina. The Medina was essentially the old part of Marrakech. Its basically a bunch of narrow streets enclosed by a really cool (and old) city wall. I loved strolling through the Medina, shopping and taking photos. I would note that the Medina can be frustrating and its easy to get lost. You may wan to hire a guide for your first venture in - maps aren't reliable.

Beware of motorcycles and bicycles. Loved the vibrancy of the souks. It was a bit stressful as pedestrians staying out of the way of fast moving motorcycles and bicycles in the narrow streets.The vendors are constantly encouraging you to visit their shops. We found that after a while we stopped looking at anything because we didn't want to be harassed into buying or looking at something. We may have purchased more if we had been allowed to look in peace.Pictures of people are not always welcomed, and if they are expect to pay for that.The night food stalls were interesting and we tried some of the food, which was quite good.

Amazing!!!. Marrakech was the last city we visited in Marrocos, and what a surprise!!! A cultural journey and an amazing experience. We stayed near the souk area and walked all over on foot or taxi and was very safe. It was very interesting to know a little bit about their culture and religion. The souk was fascinating, full of colours, smells and different people.We loved!!!

Great...if you love haggling!. I really enjoyed walking around and taking in all the sights, sounds and smells...but I did not like the feeling that everyone might be trying to scam me. I'm sure some people don't mind this sort of thing, but it just wasn't for me. I did end up buying some nice stuff, but I did so knowing I paid more than I should have.

Colourful. Worth a visit, but be warned there are terrible examples of animal cruelty- monkeys in nappies, with chains round their necks, harshly treated, snake charmers whose snakes have their mouths stiched up, terribly thin and sore infested donkeys and mules and overworked horses bearing SPANA anklets. Its an unpleasant place if you like animals. We ate at the food stalls, didn't get any problems, but orange juice tasted "off" and watery. Took our own cultery,plates, straws, napkins everywhere we went and would advise this as a precaution for health and safety! Food not good value including the famouse No1 Ayisha's stall- would get more and better in London for the price. Stall holders as too be expected- pushy and vaguely aggressive, and alot of tat there too. Spice exposed to the elements, so who wants them then? Don't forget if you buy in a shop, you get a receipt and if you spend over 2000 Dirhams collectively you can claim 13% tax back, and the shops are not more expensive than your eventual price in the Medina.

Souks of Marrakesh. do the souks in the morning as it gets very hot and stuffy after 1pm. the people are very friendly and always want to help but be aware they will lead you to their uncles/brothers/fathers/cousins/long lost relations - stall!!! but they do it in a very friendly manner and we never felt under pressure.

Medina. We stayed in the Kasbah area of the Medina which I would highly recommend. The Medina is a must visit and I can't imagine going to Marrakech if you do not stay in the traditional heart. It is surprisingly clean and you can just walk and experience the culture without it costing you anything at all.

Cultural shock!. A massive cultural shock for anyone who visits here! I am used to travelling to random places and even this shocked me! If you head to the old town Medina then be prepared for salesman running at your with monkeys and snakes trying to get photos and money from you. There are thousands of people here at one time so also not recommended for those who dislike crowds!A must visit for anyone visiting Marrakech as there's fantastic opportunity to get some unique items and see the real culture.

Visiting Marrakesh without going in the Medina is next to impssible. Unless you want to live in luxury hotel I'd highly recommend staying in one of the many riads within the medina walls. And the medina is more then Jemaa El Fna.
A Must!!!!. Amazing sights, sounds, smells! One amazing experience!
an interesting chaos. very chaotic but very interesting to see....people very nice with tourists
Awesome!. So much to take in. Amazing place. Loved it. Really want to go back next year with my kids. Fascinating culture. Lovely people.
an experience!. Semi organized chaos!! Small alleyways everywhere so very easy to get lost, all sorts going on in the main square,day and night. An interesting experience.

magical. Like nothing I've experienced before - we agreed we felt like we were on a movie set! Take time to explore the streets and alleys, it's much more exciting when you stray a bit away from the more touristy areas. Orange juice in the main bit is a must - very refreshing in the heat. Avoid snake charmers, monkeys and ladies with henna unless you want to pay. Rooftop restaurants are great for the view, especially as the sun sets, but very touristy and food poor.
Mental, but fun. A must visit, and something out the of the norm ! Plenty to see and experience.
Astonishing. For such a small area the Medina changes constantly - enjoy getting lost - its all part of the experience.
A bit worrying at first.!!!. It really is a maze of life. Wander around,be amazed. But be aware ,it gets really crowded at times.

A must see when in Marakesh, but expect non stop pestering, crazy mopeds, & heat. A fascinating place to see - but not to relax. As long as you go to the Medina expecting it to be a relatively crazy place, that you'll probably be narrowly missed by mopeds, and wont get 5 seconds to yourself without being harassed to buy something or give someone money then you'll get something from this frantic trading hub. We didn't experience any of the aggressive behaviour described by some reviewers - just very very persistent stall holders. That being said it does strike you as the type of place to keep your wits about you, negotiate all prices up front, and don't be nieve!

be carefull. on visiting marrakesh last dec 2011 we stayed at a hotel opposite the medina we had four days in this city the first night we had a walk to find a bar that we could have a drink most dont serve alcolhol, but we found one it was in fact near the royal gardens the next day we ventured into the medina with no guide as they want extortionate rates what an experience,we witnessed police beating up young boys with canes and was threathend if we took photos then we were lost in this maze of alleyways all looking the same three hours we were trying to find our way out witnessed two muggins of westerners who joined with us to try to get out and for security when we came across this boy of eleven whom spoke good english he helped us find our way out it was dark when we did so we gave him five euro he was elated although he never asked for money only a meal of soup was we happy , the couple whom were mugged went to the police the police said it doesnt happen in morroco what a laugh!by the way if you ever go and get your own flight if you get a cab from the airport over thier only pay tham £5 they will charge you £30 and drive around the city to confuse the one mile distance it is and watch your back after dark and in any drinking place we meet a couple whom were beaten up in one of there pubs and robbed because they refused to buy locals a drink

sensory overload. In a way, just as I had imagined - bustling, narrow lanes lined with shops and restaurants and filled with hawkers, touts, exotic aromas and sounds. Also filled with speeding scooters belching fumes and apparently trying to run you over.

The Real Marrakech. The experience is truly memorable, the bustle and winding streets with surprises around every corner. It is invaluable you hire a guide to take you round as you will certainly get lost as there are no street signs! Guides are reasonably priced and will help you haggle for goods in the souks, make sure your guide is official through the Moroccan tourist board. They will wear a badge if they are official. I would advise you to hire one on the first day as they can give invaluable advice on what you can and can't eat and drink plus where you should go. Official guides can be arranged through your Riad or hotel.

Good. It was an old Medina - but the view from it was lovely, There was a gorgeous old building with loads of architecture and designs inside, on the roof, on the doors, it was beautiful. The garden to it was small but pretty. Worth a look.

Prepare yourself to have your eye's dance with pattern and colour. The visual over load is over whelming. Be prepared to be constantly hassled for money. The Morroccan Men are charming but verbally aggressive for a sale and money. Try and stay calm and enjoy the experience. there is no place like it.
must visit. when in Marrakech absorb the old city with its marketsquare and narrow streets full of life.

Love the hustle and bustle!. Great bargains if you haggle, and I love to haggle. All stall owners very friendly you can have a good laugh with them, didnt feel intimidated like you do in some other countries.Beware of the henna woman she gets your hand and there is no getting away. We had lunch on the roof terrace, food great value but got ripped off with the drinks 3 waters and 3 oringinas about £30!

Atmosphere, atmosphere, atmosphere. And maybe a bargain if you are lucky.. Unmissable part of the Marrakech experience. An assault on all the senses at once! But don't expect that your haggling will produce real bargains; its the experience, stupid.
Ok - if you dont mind being harrassed!. It is okay just bear in mind you will be harrassed, if you dont mind, then its okay to visit souks, if you do, then ask for fixed price places.

STYED INSIDE THE MEDINA. To enjoy the real Marrakech we reccomend you stay in a Riad, within the Medina. A bit daunting at first but wonderful and truly Moroccan as opposed to " International Hotels" outside the Medina.

Awakens your senses. When walking round the souks it is important to keep your wits about you. The sights and smell of the medina are outstanding, every alleyway has a different aroma and the most amazing display of colour. Bargins are to be had but need to be haggled for, one street vendor wanted 800 dirham for a tagine, which I got later in the Atlas mountains for 170 dirham. Definitely visit but stay alert and don't take photos unless your willing to pay!

Eye-Popping. It's hard to take it all in in one visit. Amazing juxtaposition of old and new. The sights, the smells, the sounds...snake charmers, monkeys, horse-and-carriages, donkey carts, brilliantly colored fruit stands, plenty of ways to get delightfully lost. Worth exploring.
Exciting. I could never dislike anything about the Medina of Marrakech. It is what you make it but it is exciting, vibrant and colourful

Overwhelming. Must see when you visit Marrakech but a bit overwhelming with people comming up to you to sell stuff from all corners possible. Can be a bit heavy if you have to discuss prices with every taxi driver, every sales person etc.. especially when it is 35 degrees!!

Fantastic, not to be missed. This is the real deal. Seeing the seething mass of humanity, the donkey carts and mopeds competing for space in the narrow roads just shows the respect and tolerrance the locals have for each other. Stay at Riad in the Medina to get the best out of your trip.
Interesting Experience. There are spice stalls, rugs, lamps etc. etc and they all look lovely, but there is a lot of hassle although not unfriendly.

Greed and intimidation and cons. I realise that I am probably in a minority of people who commit their negative impressions of the Medina and main square of Marrakech to a review, but I am going to anyway on the basis that perhaps more travellers will be better informed when they go to this place.The Djemaa el Fna is one of the busiest trading squares in Africa, and is essentially the place that you will probably end up spending a lot of your time in if you take a trip to Marrakech. There is a day and night market, the day is mostly orange juice and dried fruit sellers, the night is the food market with lots of acts such as snake charmers, monkey ... keepers? etc etc.Here are my impressions:Greed - Everyone wants something from you. Literally, everyone that you meet or interact with would like some of your money. Sometimes for a product or service, sometimes for nothing at all . Another reviewer has put it more eloquently than I could here http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/ShowUserReviews-g293734-d324126-r130611838-Medina_of_Marrakech-Marrakech_Marrakech_Tensift_El_Haouz_Region.html#REVIEWS but I will do my best to add what I can.Young men - will offer you directions or some sort of advice, and even if you politely decline, will demand (Yes, demand) money from you. If you give them something, hoping that they will go away and leave you alone, they will look at it in contempt, and say that it is 'nothing ... baby money' and wait for more. There is a very sinister undertone, this on it's own, once it has happened a few times, is enough to ruin your experience. I would not go back to Marrakech ever again, mainly for this reason. If the 'tourist police' (Where they were I do not know) do not deal with this problem, I don't think Marrakech has a very good future as a tourist destination of choice.The thing to note here as well is the fact that the people who give you the most trouble, are not the most needy. They are well dressed young men, not the really poor blind and lame beggars who abound throughout the city. There was one particular instance when my girlfriend and I were walking back to our Riad, and we were offered directions to it (It was only a few hundred metres away) by two young guys. I stupidly said ok, just to get them off our backs, and when we got to the door, they demanded 200 Dirhams (About £15) each for the help (Hourly rate in Marrakech is about 12 Dirhams per hour) Then, the two became 5, as three more materialised out of nowhere and also started asking for money .... I said no to all of these, and gave 20 Dirhams to the first two. One looked at it in disgust, and (as I had come to expect) told me that this was nothing, and that I should pay more. It was a very uncomfortable situation, and my girlfriend and I stood there, surrounded in a deserted alley, hoping that someone would come to the door soon, before these guys stopped asking 'nicely'.The kids - Lots of little children who will follow you about and ask for cash ... perhaps for a trinket or toy that they are selling. I am sure that there are more sinister adults behind them, making them go and beg, but to give them cash just makes it worse, as more and more will seemingly see that you are a soft touch and come to you asking for more. They are very persistent and you have to say 'no thanks' about 8 or 9 times on average before they will give up.The taxis - Insanely greedy, and outside of the friendly barter system that everyone seems to think is the norm in Marrakech. Example - we got lost (Big mistake, but totally inevitable in a city that must have only about 3 or 4 street signs in total in it!) trying to get to Kosy Bar ... hailed a taxi and asked how much to get to Kosy Bar (A very well known bar near the Place de Ferblantiers) £50 Dirhams, was the answer. Way too much, but he, maybe its miles away. Got in, and drove aimlessly for 5 minutes, until the driver turned to us and said ..... "Kosy bar? What is Kosy Bar??' Turns out that it was only a few yards from where we were standing when we got into the cab.Con Men (And women)Ah the hubbub of the square. Largely made up of the following -Henna tattoo women - who will aggressively grab any girl's hand and try to start working on it before being given consent to do so. Will offer a 'free sample' and then immediately demand money from you for it. Avoid them.Various animal keepers - snakes and monkeys etc. Will catch you unawares and drape a snake around your shoulders, ar plonk a monkey in your arms. Will then immediately demand an outrageous sum of money from you for this.People dressed as Berbers .... wait to see you get your camera out to take a picture. Will grab the camera, and take pictures of you that you didn't ask for. Our one started by saying ... 'don't worry, it's free!!" and then aggressively demanded 100 Dirhams for his time. Gave him 20 dhs, about the equivalent of an hour or more work for 30 seconds, and he looked at it in disgust, and said that it was nothing. When it was pointed out that he told us it would be free anyway, and if the money was 'nothing' then why not give it back, he went off muttering what I can only assume were unpleasant things in Arabic under his breath. The souks - Actually not as bad as the main square, surprisingly. Yes, everyone wants your business and will ask for it, and yes, you will need to haggle, but I think because of the number of police that are in plain clothes in the Souks now, to make the shopkeepers less aggressive with tourists, this was the most enjoyable part of the medina.The drugs - I was offered 'Great Hash' at least 10 times in my time in or near the square. This was usually at the same time as having money demanded from me for nothing. Great to see so many drug dealers in a tourist area - really gives you confidence!Well, I think that just about wraps it up .... it's a great shame too, as the real locals seem like nice people, and Marrakech is undeniably a beautiful and ancient city in its way - it is just a pity that 1% of the population seem determined to wreck the experience for anyone who comes to visit. The King of Morocco pledged to attract I think 10 million tourists to the country to boost the tourist industry and improve the lives of Moroccan people .... he may well achieve this, but if this behaviour is allowed to continue, many of those people, including myself, will not be going back again.

hustle and bustle in the different style. the medina of marrakesh is totaly worthvisiting!you gonna get lost but do not worry that is how you will explore the city (we did the same in medina of fez )its the labirynth of souks offering you all type of products , thats how you can feel the marrakesh spiritif they give you price of soemthing do not pay NEVER more than a half of the price (i recommend even 1/3 of the firts price )its annoying at the begiing but later its only fun

Greed!!!. The Medina should have been a great experience. Exotic local, different culture, things to buy, good food -what could go wrong? In a word - GREED!!! Oh, and add to that cheating, lying, Baksheesh, ignorance and a culture that has gone way wrong.In a way the Medina reminded me of Montego Bay , Jamaica years ago when the cruise ships used to dock regularly. They stopped visiting Montego because it was unsafe and the residents were so overly aggressive that nobody was comfortable and no one wanted to visit and shop. We were there 6 or so years ago just after the ships stopped coming and the merchants were starving. Tourism was dead.and nothing was selling. I see this in the future for Marrakech.You cannot go ten feet without someone in your face being very aggressive. We were in Istanbul 10 days last May and the Grand Bazaar has some pushy salesmen but nothing compared to the souks of Marrakech..Examples:First day - We stopped at an orange juice trolly in Jamaa El Fna .. I had no dirhams so I went an ATM and get all shiny new 100 dirham bills. We went back to the the orange juice stand. the OJ cost 8 dirham and I gave him a 100. He gave me back 12 dirham in coins and went on to the next customer. I knew there was something wrong but it took me a while to read the coins so I ask for the rest of my change. Reluctantly he gave me back 60 dirhams. Still wrong!!! I insisted and after a long hesitation he gave me back 20 more dirham, Not a spot of embarrassment or shame on his face.Taxis - I asked a taxi driver how much to a particular hotel.? He said 13. I wrote the number on my open palm with my finger, he says yes, 13. when we arrive he says no it's 30 not13 . What can you do, call the police??? We paid.Candy stand - My wife wanted a taste - just a small taste of a bit of fudge from a street vender so we agreed on 3 dirham for a tiny piece. I give him a bill and he give me change that was not even close. I objected and he grabbed the change, switched the dirham coins for euros and shamelessly says that the change was correct. My God, do they think we are stupid???That's not the worst of it. The worst is the kids, unbelievably -- the children. When you get lost in the souks( note - when, not if, you get lost because you WILL get lost ) you will have a confused, maybe worried look on your face. In a very short time a young man in his early teens will appear and offer assistance or to show you around. When he shows you to your place he will ask a ridiculous amount of money and by implication cause a fuss is not paid. Most pay. One kid whom I had told to get lost was so insistent he followed us home and when I offered 10 dirham just to leave, he said it wasn't enoughOne of the little boys on our street to whom i gave candy announced the next day I had to buy him a soccer poster. Just Because. A merchant close to where we were staying whom we saw every day stood in my path one day and said I should gift him the Brazil soccer shirt I wore the day before. Asked why, It was Just because, no other reason. Just Because.And on it went.They were otherworldly in their persistence and the conviction that they should have your money. Truth did not seem to matter. I've read about this huge cultural gulf , About the Arab / Bedouin mindset and the effect of Islam (we are the infidels) and but I thought in 2012 this would be gone. Unfortunately all the negative stereotypes came vividly to life.So, what to do?Get everything in writing. Negotiate every little thing first. Carry a pad of postits and write fares, prices , everything down so you don't cheated - including the teens in the souk. Don't get intimidated. There are tourist police to protect you. Inform your intimidator that you know about the police.

Crazy busy. Amazing place and experience, very busy with a lot going on, you have to keep your wits about you, but definitely worth a visit, just to see all the food stalls and markets and the labyrinth of side streets and souks

Get Lost. The whole Medina area is great. Get lost in the souks and take time to chat to the shopkeepers who tend to be really friendly and like a laugh. Offer about a third of what they're asking and work from there and remember to keep it fun and good natured. Enjoy.
special setup. Great to walk around in the evening and have some nice food at the stands. Beautiful display!Beware of the 'faux guides'! and those who ask money if they see you taking a picture

Great shopping experience. Hustle and bustle with great shopping without pestering from spices, oils, to leather goods, babouches of any colours, carpets, lovely silver ware, incents sticks and cloth. Even seen a dead camels head hanging outside a butchers shop!!! Drew the line there!
A world of its own. "The courageous belongs the world". In case you get lost, don't ask little boys on the street, they will misguide you and ask for money, the best is to ask shop owners.
a real treat. great hustle and bustle, and surprisingly not too much in the way of being pestered. got some good bargains on leather bags.

The Red City Medina. The Medina of Marrakesh is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and not to be excluded from any trip to Marrakesh. It is absolutely amazing! The entire medina is walled in red mud brick. There are so many highlights it is hard to pick just one. The main square is Place Djemma-El-Fna. In the square you will find makeshift dentists, snake charmers, henna artists, fascinating storytellers and the Coke bottle game. There are vendors of anything and everything and the orange juice sellers. This is just the daytime. The night time is even better. Just before sundown the food stalls begin setting up tents and makeshift restaurants. The food was eclectic and delicious. I didn't try the sheep brains though and I am an adventurous eater. Drummers and chanters, monkeys, donkeys whirling traffic,horse-drawn carriages, scooters everywhere, traditional costumes, smiling people. Djemma-El-Fna is an assault on all of your senses. Yes there are touts and beggars and you will have to pay to get a picture of the snake charmers but it is only a few Dirham. You will never see anywhere else like this in the world. The square is surrounded by restaurants and the terraces above have a commanding view over the square. I had my first mint tea of many and my first tajine in the square. Both incredible! The view to Koutabia Mosque and the towering minaret are also a highlight. So after all of this, and you can spend hours here just watching, you have just made your first few steps into the medina. Adjacent to the square are the souks. They are another assault on your senses, almost literally. They begin fairly wide and as you make your way through the winding derbs they get narrower and narrower and branch off and back in to each other. Getting lost is advised! Everything is for sale. Do watch your purses and wallets however. Buying items in the souk is a great experience. You have to be a good haggler or at least enjoy the experience of it. It is customary and expected. You will be asked where you are from, do you need a carpet, would you like some tea, do you need a carpet, taste some herbs, have some more tea, do you need a carpet? I bought a teapot and some candleholders and had a sensational time with the seller. He spoke four languages and I do too but barely any of the same. I spent three hours in the same shop and had an incredible conversation in a mixture of four languages and hand signals and lots of mint tea. I went back again the next day and got more presents. He had seen me coming through the souk and had a platter of tea waiting. What an experience. The medina also has a few palaces, El Bahia and Badii Palace. Both are worth going to. Storks inhabit the outer walls of Badii palace and seeing their nests is a major draw. The Saadian tombs are located in the Kasbah area of the medina. It was so crowded when I went it was hard to move around though. I would recommend going in the morning or if you see a tour bus move onto El Bahia Palace as they are fairly close together. The Kasbah area has a lot of good restaurants and coffeeshops, lots of stores too and the Imperial Palace is also in this area of the medina. The whole medina has lots of stores in general. The tanneries are in the back section of the medina away from the more touristy areas. Any of the neighborhood kids will take you there for a few Dirham. Bring fresh mint with you! The Ben Youseff Medresa was an Islamic school and should be on everyone's list. I don't know how to get there as I almost stumbled on it but again getting lost in the medina is recommended. The Museum of Marrakesh and the Photography Museum, housed in beautiful riads, are very close to the medresa and the Photography Museum has a cafe and a terrace from which you can overlook the medina and a bathroom. It's a great museum with some amazing photographs of Marrakesh from years ago as a trade route for caravans crossing the Atlas mountains from the Sahara. Accommodations in the medina are the riads and there are hundreds to choose from. I stayed in one for my last two days in Marrakesh and was pampered with tajines and a hammam. It was two days of utter relaxation and is a welcomed respite from the chaotic alleys outside of them. I did not visit the Mellah, the Jewish quarter of the medina, but had read that there is a fascinating synagogue there. There are several imposing gates into the Kasbah and Medina and they make great photo ops as well. Any trip to Marrakesh without visiting the medina is a mistake and this will be the highlight of your time there.

Busy busy Medina!. The Medina was extremely busy in the evening, unfortunately we missed out on seeing the snakes and snake charmers as they only perform in the daylight. The souks are all under cover, however they are made up of tiny alley ways and mopeds and motor bikes ride up and down and there is very littel room so you are often jumping out of the way or falling in a doorway to avoid being run over as they dont stop for pedestrians! Never agree to the price a trader says, you must go in with a price a lot less. Don't be afraid to say something ridiculous, but ensure you know exactly how much you want to spend and if you cant agree then walk off. They will either run after you or you will find the same goods in one of the others. I bought a small handmade rug and got the price slashed by half. They are still making a profit so stick to your guns, you should go in with at least a 60% less price and go from there. never shake hands until they say the price you have agreed on either. We didn't eat in and around the Medina as there was an awful smell of drains and dirt, but we saw plenty of tourists eating from stalls and sitting at long tables with cooked food. Spices are a good buy, you can get almost anything. 50g was the minimum you could purchae we found, our friends bought cinnamon sticks and 35 spice which was so fragrant. The whole Medina and souks is a must see!

Exactly how it is on the TV!. Very busy, hustle and bussle. Watch out for scooters and horses as you may get runner over. Have some coins in your pocket if you want a photo of the snakes (10 dirhams, 20 max). I did well haggling, asking what the best price was then halfing it and working my way up. Definately worth a visit!
Sights, smells and Orange Juice. The best Orange Juice I've ever tasted! Wish we had taken the plunge and eaten at one of the stalls one evening.

Amazing. When visiting Marrakech, you can not go without visiting the Madina! It reminds you of scenes similar to Aladdin, little stalls, shops everywhere with the smell of spices and leather, shop owners wanting to pursuade you to buy something from them even if you dont need it. You turn a corner and your in the square with lots of restaurants. Worth a visit to find that special gift.

Exotic real life bustle. First visit can be quite daunting, especially navigating the souks, but just go with the flow, don't worry about getting lost and just enjoy the experience. Its like stepping back in time.
great experience. Really good.....one of those places that encompasses so many experiences, from rip off merchants tosnake charmers

A must see!. Take your time to explore the Medina in detail! It's well worth it and the best way to get to know the city and its history. There are some official tour guides who know how to explain things and where to take tourists, but anyone can adventure on their own safely inside the Medina. A must see!

Marrkech is superb and the Medina houses many attractions. Take a map and a camera and just wander around. People are generally friendly and helpful and not everyone expects a tip. You need a couple of days to cover the main attractions adequately. Registered guides are plentiful if you prefer to be accompanied or are on your own but ask at your hotel beforehand.
Night market. Chaos,but very interesting,beware of traffic flying everywhereTake lots of loose coins as change,makes it easier

Prepare to get lost and have a blast. I used a great book called "Shopping in Marrakesh" It was the best guide to find the most unique items and great shops....the shop keepers were so proud to be in the book. Kif Kif, the Marakesh Caftan Shoppe all in the book and as great a described....also the best, most accurate maps. Well worth 13 euros.

Great experience day or night. The medina can be a little intimidating for those who are new to the whole experience. The stalls are full of great bargains for those who are willing to haggle. Haggling is activly encouraged but don't be too cheeky with your offer as it can offend.The Square really comes alive at night when the sun goes down. The place has an electric buzz about it and even if you are unsure I would recommend you try the food from the stalls. If you are a little cautious ask at your riad or hotel which stall is best they will be happy to tell you.One of the best things in Marrakesh is the mint tea!! If offered some it is seen as an insult not to accept it. Its a lovely fresh taste and much welcome when you have been walking around the town all day. The pasties are also nice as well as the fresh figs you can buy from the stalls.
A Must in Marrakech. A real feast for all the senses - cant visit Marrakech without visiting
Living history. So different and alive ...this urban area of living history has layers of interest for any visitor.

Wait till the sun goes down. We visited in the evening as a companion was wary of the crowds. The place was less busy, but the banter and barter were great, and she felt got a bargain or too without getting heated. Having seen the square on endless cookery programmes it was great to actually experience the food and the entertainment for ourselves.
You know you're alive!. Loved the old city and it's winding streets, the souks, the buzz of the place. Was not so keen on the crazy scooter drivers and the pollution.
Medina One of the Better Arab Bazaars. Tremendous variety of stuff to buy including antigues, but hard bargaining is the rule.

shocking. This is he shocking part of oud trip. Po or, dirty, a bad attitude from the Lo als. Asking for money from 3 years old ho 90 years old. It's like whe are a money machine. Everything had been put on the floor nobody cleans up his mess. Very sorry

Organised chaos!. Fantastic experience - definitely visit during evening time, and we attended on a Saturday evening so I can't comment if all evenings are the same, but it had an amazing vibe and sights, sounds and smells that you just have to experience for yourself!

Not the nicest Medina and too touristic. A lot of small streets, very crowded!. The sellers here are a but too pushy for my taste and although this medina beats casablanca in all ways this is certainly not the best medina!. A nice experience for the tourist, but not as genuine as you might expect for a world heritage site as you might expect!. a lot of the houses in the old medina have been turned into Disney houses rather than the real old Moroccan houses, a pity.For me the best old medina is Fez (or Essouira).. and for the more modern ones you have to go to Rabat!.Avoid all the tourists and don't go here...it is a big tourist trap!.

Another world altogether!. The Medina is where you should spend at least half your time when you visit Marrakech. Its a totally different world, with thousands of shops selling every thing from spices, silverware, paintings, local artefacts, carpets and what not. Take a local guide (else you are sure to get lost in the maze that's the medina!) and tell the person what you need to shop for. Bargain hard every where you shop - if the shopkeeper starts at 1000 MAD, you start at 200 and work your way up...you'l probably end up buying it at 300-400! But the stuff you get here is amazing.Warning - Don't expect pristine conditions...it's a market place in North Africa! And be careful of your belongings...though we never had a bad experience!Note: We stayed at Riad Kheireddine in the old city and they arranged for a guide both days we went to the medina.
i love the medina. the town of old marrakech is rare its touristy but alive from mint to olives shoes wooden things jewellery you name you can find it or can you ?

Where to Stay. We stayed in a fantastic riad in the Medina - Riad Alyia - superb rooms, with air conditioning for the hotter weather. Very friendly staff, with English and French speakers.I would heartily recommend staying there, and eating if you have the chance. They have a superb terrace, and the food is cooked freshly, everyday. In fact, the proprietors asked what we would like to eat, and then went to get the ingredients from the market.We ate brochettes, tangier, tagine - all absolutely superb, and just what you need after a days sight seeing.
Busy but Unique. Still I want to pay another visit to enjoy such old city, you got the feeling that you been transported back to 19 th

Something for everyone. If you like to see many beautiful things, this is the place. The colors, the smells, the sights, the people, all come together as you go through the pathways. It's always best to have a point of orientation so you know where you're headed.

Medina, mayhem and magic. You can't go to Marrakech without taking a stroll through the Medina but it's not for the faint hearted. You will get lost; you will get harassed by young men wanting to 'guide' you; you will lose the will to haggle over prices yet again. Despite all of that this is a must do experience. Just don't forget, there is no such thing as a 'free look' unless you are prepared to say the word 'No' many, many times.

I had a terrible experience. ok-- I knew that I am going to discuss a price for a every single item, but I didn't know that it will take ages to find something in a good quality and good price..old,fake,made in China,dirty items ...when the sellers were unhappy with my offer they become rude and they used a bad language in Arabic..when we got lost and tried to find a right way we had to pay for a help -thats ok---but---some boys did it in purpose to make us confused!!!! they were giving us wrong directions, and when we had no power to walk longer their price to help us to find the way back was very high !!!! I have bought a tunic and in the hotel I have realised that there was a hole !!!! the sellers have no idea about prices in other countries and they try to charge tourist very expensively!!! the atmosphere is not as described in the travel books !!!

Get lost!. You will always find your way out so just explore and enjoy the experience. Not as hassled as I expected to be, everyone seemed laidback and friendly, especially as I passed them for the third time as I tried to exit the maze!
hustle and bustle. Be careful of the mopeds and the very friendly locals insisting that you should visit the Berber markets "only here today!" Every day!! Beware! Fun though!
The gathering of people. Story tellers, street theatre, monkeys, snakes, spices, henna tattoos, food and much laughter. Friendly happy people.

over run with motorcycles outside the souks. I advise the upper souks, not the ones near the big place. Some good merchandise, but aggressive haggling. I much prefer the medinas of Rabat and Fez and even the Quartier des Habous in Casablanca. Do not plan to return to the Marrakech medina.

Easy to love but pass on buying from Souk vendors. It's easy to love the crazy mix of sound, smells, sights and tastes around Marrakech's Medina. What isn't so great is the attitude of many vendors in the adjoining Souks. On a recent visit I heard (and experienced) heated negotiations where souk vendors were enraged when a customer wouldn't buy something for 10X the price you can pay without much negotiating in other places like Fes. Maybe the souk vendors don't realise that people do talk and share stories on the Internet. If you can wait, buy your souvenirs elsewhere. Otherwise accept that you WILL overpay.
The only place to stay. We stayed in the Medina in 2 different riads. We wouldn't have wanted to be anywhere else.
another way of life. This place is amazing, just wandering round for hours eating and drinking street food and looking at the sights.

Friendlier than expected. Having read a lot about the Medina, I expected quite a tiresome time walking around in these alleys. Wayfinders, henna tattooers, salesmen not letting you go - there seems to be no end to all the things to be aware of. However, I really don't agree with this description. Yes, young men will ry to point you in all kinds of directions (usually the wrong one) no doubt wanting to make money. And yes, the small kids would run after you begging for money. And yes, the salesmen would offer you to enter their shop. But only once in a week did I experience that a friendly "Non, merci" was not respected. Enjoy your stay in the Medina!

arabian adventure. Prepare for an experience so unlike anything you have seen before. You feel you're in a different century! Narrow alleys with houses built of clay, hiding the most amazing courtyards in the riads with beautiful tiles, amazing carvings and blue pools. Also you will find yourself getting lost in the souk - where no map will be of any help.Traders will sell you things you have never seen or heard of before - or actually, a visit to the spice souk with the Berber pharmacies will actually reveal what myrrh and frankincense is. The smell is fantastic.Is probably for a more seasoned traveller as you will be chased by sellers, snake charmers, unlicensed guides for the first couple of days until you get the proper glased look which will turn away any shopkeepers. Arkwright would have a good run for his money in this place.

Prepare to get lost... literally. Everything you have heard is true, you will get lost no matter how clever you think you are. But thats half the fun! Its an amazing melting pot of colour, smell and noise. Just go with it, you will eventually get out, but a tip, dont stay too late or you may get locked in, gates close around 8 PM.Be careful of slick young men offering to 'help' you find your way back to your riad/hotel. They appear very friendly until the money demand comes, then they can be quite aggressive if you dont give them what they think its worth to get you back.Ask a shopkeeper for help if you need it, I found most were very helpful when we did get lost.
Fez is much better. medina is nice but the constant scooters zigzagging the road ruin the experience. Fez is more real, a bit quieter, less aggressive and overall classier.

great fun. Not to be missed, the highlight of our trip particularly after 18.00 hrs. Great fun, but be aware if you take photos of certain people they will expect to be paid!!Bargaining was quite an experience.

Medina very authentic. This was just what I imagined Marrakech would be like - no sign of a Macdonlands and very authentic. But found some of the hot food stands pretty gruesome so stuck with the upmarket cafes !

Very Large and Interesting. If you have a walking problem then forget it, there is a lot of walking to do. We went on a day trip from Agadir its a long journey by coach. On arrival we had to get off the coach outside the walls as coaches are not allowed in. Once inside it is very vast, there are stalls for everything and it would be easy to get lost. We had two guides our tour guide and a local guide who kept us altogether. There was little problem with the stall holders or beggars. Beware of the snake charmers as if you want a photo with a snake you have to pay to get it off and they never have any change, its best to have small change and pay first saves a lot of hassle. This tour took in many other places. the downside was we visited a non working Mosque which was just a bare room a great pity as we have been to many Mosques thoughot the world. There is a law in Marocco that prohibs visits to Mosques except for prayer. A visit to the Madina is a must together with a visit to MarraKech.
Amazing experience. The medina is such a special and unique part of Marrakech.
Medina madness!. Loved the hustle and bustle and the variety of the stalls but the constant approaches from stallholders and beggars can get a bit wearing!

Surviving the Marrakech Medina!. My husband and I visited the medina/souk/square of Marrakech in February this past year.
