I thought I might put together a "tips" review of our experience that may help future travelers.(We are experienced travelers, not scared off by a little adventure!)The SouksAs EVERY reviewer will tell you...you better put your best haggling hat on. Prices in the souks are often marked up by HUNDREDS of percent. They sell 5 types of goods in the medina/souks - Leather Goods, Rugs (EXPENSIVE), Lanterns/Metal work, Tagines/Pottery & Spices - so the competition is fierce, and the shop owners are very persistent in getting you into their shop.If you look...be prepared to be lead inside! The souks in the square are ENDLESS and there are often "recruiters" standing on the outskirts ready to lead you deep into the maze to "help" you find a particular good. If you are lead in by someone, the item/s you ultimately purchase WILL be marked up to tip the "recruiter". They are not helping you out just to be friendly, they are earning a living. YOU CAN GET LOST inside...and better believe it's going to cost you to get out if you need directions! There are lots of shops outside the official "souks", many with better prices and even some along side streets that are marked with prices.It is also considered rude by many to take photographs of someone's shop without their permission. I found if I purchased an item (that I already wanted) from a shop owner, I would kindly ask their permission before leaving to take a few pictures of their "beautiful shop". This small courtesy is appreciated.The Square1 word - CHAOS! Motorcycles whizzing by nonstop, horses and donkeys pulling carts, snake charmers, monkey on leashes, performers...it is a CIRCUS! I found we could only handle the main square in small quantities. Again - as far as goods sold, it is VERY repetitive and the merchandise is nearly identical shop to shop. So it can be tiring saying "no thank you!" 1000 times in a row. I recommend taking a day to wander around (don't linger too long!) looking at the goods for sale, and come back a day later to make your purchase after you've had a good look around, and again - don't be afraid to haggle!! They are expecting it!In terms of food...eat at your own risk! Everyone's stomach is different, but if you're not the adventurous type, check out some of the fresh baked bread and freshly squeezed orange juice. It is delicious and incredibly cheap!Be VERY careful taking photographs! The snake charmers, monkey handlers, and other performers will approach you with big smiles and open arms for photos, then will turn on a dime if you are unwilling to pay the sometimes extortionate rates for a photo, and can be very aggressive. They are not afraid to demand 20eu or more for just ONE picture. We were approached by a group of 4 men with leashed monkeys, and before we knew it...all FOUR of them were on us, and the men had our camera taking pictures. Once our camera was returned (I was ready with cash for them, but had not anticipated so many!) I was told it was going to be 200dh PER MONKEY. They wanted nearly 80EU/100USD for those pictures, and were EXTREMELY offended by the amount we offered them (60dh each). I later spoke with a shop owner we came to know who laughed HYSTERICALLY at the notion of paying 200dh for a picture, and said they often BUY the monkeys for less than 50, and can live a WEEK on 200dh, so do not be fooled by the feigned offense and stand your ground!The performers and handlers are also VERY aware of having their picture taken from afar, so unless you are at a good distance (try one of the terraced restaurants with a 2nd floor!), be prepared to be approached demanding payment for the photo you took!Cabs/TransportWe found walking to/from the medina to be very easy. If we weren't fussed with making our way through the madness of the main square, we found cabs to be readily available during the day and you can get anywhere in the Medina area for about 30-40dh each way. SafetyWhile we never felt unsafe during our trip, there were definitely moments (day and night) where we were harassed in one way or another. As a young woman, I got more than my share of "unsavory" comments (in english too!) while I was walking around...fully dressed in conservative clothes WITH my husband. Did not make a difference. Best to just hold your head high, ignore it and keep on walking! Common sense will tell you not to wear flashy jewelry and keep cameras and wallets safely tucked away. I found it best to carry small chunks of cash in my pocket, instead of my wallet (100dhs broken into 20s) for tips and small purchases, so I did not have to pull out my wallet and show a huge wad of dirhams (not alot in USD but a TON in dhs)and draw unwanted attention, or potentially raise the price of the item!For an escape, I HIGHLY recommend visiting the outlying palaces and gardens. They are truly beautiful, admission is no more than $1 or 2 and the scenery is beautiful and QUIET. It's well worth it to duck away for a little R&R.Overall - I truly enjoyed Marrakech. Even for an experienced traveler, it takes a little getting used to to find your way around and adapt to the way of life. It is a beautiful place with lots of lovely people, but is definitely not for the faint of heart!!!
Quite the experience!!. Shop til you drop, A little touristy but still worth spending a few hours and getting something to eat.
Fascinating. So many sights - most within walking distance. Get a good guide book. Traffic can be a bit hectic.
Frenzy. The whole world on the move, by foot, scooter, caleche or petit taxi. A feast for the eyes and ears.
100 times the same. Once you have seen 5 stalls in the soeks, you have seen them all.Go for a local taxidriver, give him a tip and ask him to drive you around
old walled city. vibrant old city with street markets, donkey carts competing with motor bikes & cars, something to amaze round every corner
hustle and bustle. Compared to Fes it is much better organized (some would say less authentic but that is fine with me) and fun to wonder around. Love the artifacts.

Wildly over the top - Morocco's MUST. Yes it's really touristy but it is so wildly over the top, you won't care. Every imaginable colour, smell, sight and taste. Shops selling junk to gorgeous crafts. Stalls vending liver sandwiches to spicy onion crepes to fluffy pastries. Tanners and thread makers, shoemakers and bead sellers. Go, and go again!

it's a must. the mix of old and new, the many markets to explore, the horse & carriage ride, lunch at one of the many restaurants, the fresh orange juice - disliked the henna tatoo women, they were rude if you dont want to support them.
souks. be careful not to go too deep into the madina its easy to get lost

Very busy. The place is amazing but make sure you go during the day and at night because at night it's a totally different place. Watch out for the motorbikes and be aware that you may get hassled by the locals but a firm No and they leave you alone. It's hard to get alcohol in the medina so it's worth researching this before you go. Remember to look up because your see some lovely restaurants / bars with roof gardens.
Busy busy busy. Extremely busy. Didn't like people demanding money.
A must see. A great place to experience Marrakech - just make you watch out for the motorbikes!

a red maze. even though at the begining it looks impossible to get your bearings in the medina, it is not that hard. the medina is rather small and you might end up coming to the same point over and over again. it is worth knocking on the road doors and taking a peak of all the interesting interiors. go to dar cherifa for tea or lunch and visit the gallery net to the medressa. all the museums are worthwhile even though a little derelict!

A Feast For The Eyes and the Smell. What is great about Djemaa el F'na the fact the place is popular for both locals and foreigners. It is a melting pot of stimulations of senses, smell of the food, the taste, the sound of tambourine, the dances, the sights of different colors of people... It is everything you can ask for of an experience. The variety of the food is actually not much, almost all of the food stalls are offering the same things. Kefta, cut let's of beef or chicken, salads, breads, all the local signature. The way they are presented to the passer bys are totally entertaining.

A feast for the senses. The square comes alive at sunset.....with the scent of grilled meat and spices, and with the sideshows of fortune-tellers, snake-charmers, performers, etc, and the stalls selling freshly-squeezed orange juice. The souks are fascinating. What an experience...!!!
Crazy place - loved it!. What an ecletic mix of people...start here and then discover everything else.
An adventure. A real adventure. Keep tight hold of ur handbag and watch out for the thiefs. The smells and colours are amazing. Wouldnt say it is very cheap but a real experience.

A mediaeval rabbit warren. Very crowded, lots of shops. Perfect if you like shopping and haggling. Not so good if you just want to browse. Wonderful sights and smells. However, I didn't like seeing the women with babies and small children and the old men setting up their sheets of cardboard to sleep on in the corners when the shops closed.

Medina. It's like stepping back in time! Just a wonderful authentic atmosphere. Also great to see traditional arts and crafts continuing. Behind the old walls of old buildings are wonderful places you wouldn't imagine being there from the outside!
Too much traffic. Glad I saw it but not fun to walk around and nowhere to eat safely in the medina except a few places in the square

Looking beneath the surface / enjoying the music of commerce. There is nothing to match the medina for its color, life and blend of buildings, material goods and the atmosphere of a Moroccan souk. You have to look beyond the tourists (most of you will be the tourists other call tourists) but in doing so you will see much, especially if you enter into bargaining and the ritualized intimacy that comes from this practice. And never far away is the Djamm al Fna, the fantazim where commerce, art, folk practices, theatre, talent, hucksters and ecstasy meet. In its own way, it reflects the complicated aspects of human nature, the sublime, sacred and farcical.

Pleasure of the eye, mouth and nose. Get lost in this incredible labyrinth and discover colours, tastes and smells you did not suspect to exist. Be careful - walk on the side of the streets even if they are narrow to allow traffic to flow.

Step back in Time. Absolutely loved it. 9500 alleyways so the guide said. The atmosphere, small shops, wonderful architecture and decorated doors, and of course the tannerys. Looked like a scene from medieval times and probably was. Would liked to have spent more time just wandering and people watching. Deserves it's World Heritage status.

Busy, busy but atmospheric.... Lots of hustle and bustle but definitely choose to stay in an old Riad here rather than out of town. Watch out for the unruly motorcyclists and bicycles but enjoy haggling in the souks. Decide what you would be willing to pay first and then try not to deviate!!
1001 nights!. Loved the winding streets and many shops. Here you can see the real Morocco.
One of the main reasons to go to Marrakech. Just what we were expecting. Busy and bustling. Felt quite safe - even at night.
Wild place. Snake charmers in the morning and musicians at night. But more of a touristy medina than Fes, so if you've just got one to go to, go to Fes.
very intersting. Bit crowded but great atmosphere. Be aware of your surroundings at night. It is natural when you are in different country. People are courteous and friendly.
fun shopping. The shopping is fun, but sometimes the vendors tend to become a bit aggressive.

The Medina is a must. You have to experienc eit to believe it. It is centuries old yet you have modern chic Euopeans living side by side with the locals. Nice friendly atmosphere - once you get used to it.

busy. We preferred the medina in essouira...this one is just too busy, too pricy and pushy. But worth a visit, but don't rely on this for your main source of shopping...you can buy it elsewhere at a fraction of the price.
Market square. Polish up on bartering and never pay the price asked. We disliked the way the shopkeepers kept badgering us to step into their shops when were clearly not interested.

Visit is a must. You have to go,but take a guide! Great experience,not to be missed.Would not like to visit a night however, very busy and the traffic in Marrakech is like nothing I have seen before. It makes the Italians style of driving look good!!!
Historic and fascinating. Love the buzz - hate all the tourists!! We love getting lost in the medina and there's always someone to guide you back to the square.

Experience not to be missed. The Medina of Marrakech is insane, amazing and overwhelming. There is an endless array of gorgeous crafts, fruit, dates, olives and spices as well as cheesy western-style souvenirs. The self-appointed "guides" and store keepers can be pushy, but overall this is an experience central to visiting Marrakech.
Huge and amazing.......... The hub of Marrakech and it all starts around 7pm..........story tellers, snake charmers, food and sellers of all items........magic magic and more magic

An experience. This medina is a warren so take a map and follow it. The constant smelly motorbikes wizzing past are a pest. The medina of Essaouria is so much more relaxed as motor bikes are banned. We found that shops where the locals are buying are much cheaper. We gave up saying where we came from and made up somewhere obscure and that usually stopped the questions. A must see but keep your wits about you.
Hasstle. Just look confident and don't be afraid to walk away... 'Guides' in marrakech are not so much a problem as elsewhere but don't be afraid to insist on 'NON'
Great shopping experience!. Lively and full of people. Didnt like the constant beggars.
Back in time. Noisy, sometimes smelly, but what a world. I defy you to get bored there.
Stay in the Medina if you can. The amazing sights, sounds and smells of Marrakech all here in the old town, a week wasn't enough.

Pure atmosphere. The majority of locals are genuine, friendly and they made our first experience of Morocco a holiday of a lifetime. Expect to be approached enthusiastically by traders eager to sell their wares, however, if not interested just smile and walk away. Say no if you need to. The Medina is a charming place to explore, though watch out for the crazy motorbikers who ride (too fast) though the narrow streets.

intimidating. So easy to get lost here and too many people are just waiting for you to pull out your map so they can 'help' you get to your destination. (For a fee, of course) Very pushy salesmen. Dirty alleyways. Did not feel comfortable here.

Mayhem in Marrakech. I guess you will either love the chaos and hustle and bustle here or you will be thankful to find some peace and quite in a museum or garden area. It is certainly a different atmoshere compared to the new part of the city but one you must experience, why else come to Marrakech. We love walking around cities but the Medina to me is not somewhere I necessarily enjoyed as much but nevertheless a must do.

Amazing. I have been twice to Marrakech now, I find it an extraordinary city and I love the vibrant energy of the medina. Its an experience in itself in the main square as the dusk falls and the square springs to life with all the stalls selling food, the dried fruit and orange juice, the men with their monkeys and snakes and the ladies with their henna tattoos. The atmosphere filled with smoke and lights with that unforgettable aroma (more unforgettable in the heat of summer). It was one of the highlights of my time in Marrakech. In the day it is no more tranquil, the medina is filled with souks and craftsman all trying to sell you good, bartering well is a skill that I have still yet to master, however it is expercted when in Marrakech.
Truly Wonderful. Marrakech Medina is a truly wonderful place, somewhere that should be on everyone's itinerary.

An interesting... place to walk around and experience the sights and smells of Marrakech. Also interesting to see where and how some of the locals live. There were too many beggars on the streets and it is difficult to deal with the poverty in which too many people are living.
Hectic. Loved the tradition, the hustle and bustle. Fasinating people, lots to see , lots to buy in the souks.

Chaos and annoyance. From the moment you enter the square of the medina you are pestered non stop by men and children asking to take you wherever you may be going. Despite saying NON MERCI repeatedly, they would walk a few paces in front of you until you stopped and then they would demand money for taking you there. This is a complete disappointment as I think without this the Souqs could be explored and enjoyed for days!
Bustling and colourful. Loved the traditional feel. Did not like the sight of donkeys being over loaded, the dentist or the snakes.
Impressive. Sunday night in the main square. Like going to Wembly stadium to watch a first class gfootball game
nothing like this place in the world. loved the drums, and the madness of the whole place

Old city - Sensory overload. I can't think of one of my senses that wasn't blown away by the mayhem that is the Medina. The smells of scooter exhaust and spice stalls, the sounds of merchants, musicians, car horns and the sound of hooves on the cobbles. The sights of tranvestite dancers, snake charmers, and a family of 4 crammed on a little scooter (no helmets). The feel of silk scarves in your face walking through the souks, the odd puddle on your foot as everyone washes themselves and their doorstep at prayer time. It is facinating to see how the people live in the old city and in such contrast to the new city which feels very western in comparison.

So different. Such an experience that it wil be hard to forget. Barting was new and hard to get used to but quiet fun in a way. Suprisingly easy to navigate around too thanks to the tall building to keep you orientated.

Exotice Experience that isn't found anywhere else. If you are from the North America or Europe you probably haven't experienced anything quite like Marrakech's Medina. A huge open square that is filled with snake charmers and henna tattoo artists by day, but by night it transforms into a crowded bustling center filled with food, story tellers, entertainers, and small street shops, filled with exotic aromas and sounds. If you truly want to experience Morocco it is a must see.Beware that everything has a price; if you want to take pictures of the snakes or have someone gives you directions they will demand payment. It also it would be wise to keep an eye on you belongings and I would suggest that you travel in groups.
Manic. Busy, bussling, wonderful smells, true morrocan life! Loved it!

Won't be going back. I was looking forward to going to marrakech, my boyfriend booked it all for my Christmas present. I was looking forward to relaxing and getting away from work, exploring the markets, eating good food. Unfortunately, this has been a terrible holiday. The first day, we headed into the central market and the souks. We were able to shrug off being pestered, but then we got terribly lost in the souks and ended up in some exceedingly dirty streets selling food that smelt very off. People were pestering us to sell us the way home, which we eventually found by ourselves. After that, people tried to sell us pictures with monkeys, and a lady asked and asked and asked if I wanted a henna tattoo, I walked away and she drew on me anyway. It was all a little upsetting. The whole experience has been awful, people only want to sell you things, if you say no, they try again and again, I just end up getting a little cross. I won't be going here again, it's been madness to say the least. Im looking forward to getting on that plane...thank god we only booked five days!
Amazing. Just visit it and you'll understand why it's so amazing! All life is here – stunning and mind-boggling and memorable. Enjoy!

Beautiful............ The medina was full of different cultures.but be aware of the hand readers they have people who explain what they do and trick you into doing it they also say the hand readers take anything which means money,when we tried it we gave her a reasonable amount and the guy said she wants paper which meant a note,when we said well no this enough the guy swore at us in English.On a positive note the medina was gorgeous at night
Must be seen. Exciting, smelly, noisy and different. Good to see there are still clashes of cultures so near to the UK.
Interesting smells. Great sites, unusual smells and badly polluted by all the scooters.

The Must See part of a Marrakech visit. We visited the square four times on our three day visit to Marrakech, both during the day and in the evening (when we ate, too)The square is like nowhere I have ever been, bustling with life, with people in traditional dress alongside the younger people who by and large are in western clothes all going about their business. Yes, there are scooters everywhere, but while they are alarming at first, and you need to be sure to keep away from what seems to be an unofficial road running through the Medina, the riders are skillful and will avoid you! (and it is fascinating to watch them drive the scooter, with a passenger on the back (frequently she is holding a baby too!) while they text and maybe hold on to their shopping. All done with no crash helmets!) The stalls and souks round the square are fascinating to visit and to shop in.You seem to be able to buy pretty much anything, although handbags (Morrocan leather and fake designer) and shoes seemed to predominate around the edges. The stallholders hassle you to buy, but they are friendly and want to talk to improve their English. You have to barter, but we found we got a better price if we just walked away - they followed us lowering the price at every step!During the day, the square is filled with attractions such as snake charmers, at night, stalls for eating are set up and the sky is alight with blue flying toys. It would appear that some of the stall holders would accept payment in Euros as well as the local currency.You pay a premium for a soda to drink while you sit in one of the balconied cafes to watch the activity in the square but it's worth it. I wouldn't recommend eating in those cafes though - we did and got overpriced westernised food which was very disappointing. If I went again, I'd try the stalls in the market to eat at night or maybe go into the souk area a bit deeper to find somewhere there.It would be nice if there were decent toilet facilities available. I used a few in the cafes which varied in quality, if you see what I mean. But I guess that is part of the 'charm' of a visit to a place like this!I would certainly go back if I ever find myself in Marrakech again. It is the heart and soul of the city and if you like shopping - it's bliss!

A journey back in time. A crowded, noisy and colourful place with a huge variety of products sold, all that a medina should be. Take care with the prices and be prepared to negotiate them with joy, as the morrocans do.
Old world Marrakech.. Stay in the Medina in a Riad and experience the real Morocco.

Dont worry about getting lost. If you explore into the medina or Marrakech, the one thing that will happen is that you will get lost. I would say not to worry about this and take it as part of the experience. I have found that just randomly walking around once I am lost, I find things that I would never have come across if I was sticking to the normal paths. The people are very friendly and if you want to get back to the main square then just ask one of the shopkeepers the general direction you should be going in, they will all tell you the way. Try not to ask one of the children or somebody who is just "hanging around", if you do, then the chances are they will show you the way and ask for a payment at the end (even if you have not agreed to pay them at the start).A great place to explore, it is like going back in time by a few hundred years, I love exploring the medina, it is very big and you will always find a new place to go there. A "must do" if you are in Marrakech.

Great place awful motor bikes. Really fun to visit, colourful, lively, largely unspoiled. great variety of good stuff, food and tourist tat. All really fun except for smelly and assertive motobikes that clogged the lanes. But I would go again.

Heart stopping Medina. the most mind-blowing experience is to be in the middle of the Medina. The colour, the smell , the excitement of the market in full flow , set out along ancient narrow streets, selling a billion weird and wonderful things aswell as a stunning array of home-crafted goods - dishes, bowls, plates, candle holders, candles , glasses, teapots, jewellery, carpets, textiles and peopled with locals in traditional dress as if from a bygone age. This feels like a site from a bygone age and which one is privileged to witness. Its breathtaking and i cannot wait to return.
Not to be missed. The buzz and bartering. Colour everywhere and the whole atmosphere was captivating. Join in and just make sure you do not give them anymore than half what they initially ask for!
The medina is the soul of Marrakech.. You really cannot feel this city except in the Medina. It's something to experience but look out for the motorbikes.

Buzzing place. Just a quick review
This place is a decent busy place with so many people trying to rip you off. However thats the fun of it and if you like haggling, you will get amazing prices for things.
The square has a lot of entertainment. Its good to spend two days there

Terrible Place. If you like constant hassle, tourist rip offs, manhandling, motorbikes trying to hit you .. All in a dirty wasteland ...then this is for you ! And don't tell me "it's their culture" as I didn't see any morrocans getting the same treatment...basically if you look like a tourist your fair game ... Hated it big time
Medina at night. Amazing on Saturday night. Great for shopping or just people watching

Crazy. Fascinating ,scary,. Fascinating , mad , crazy ,real Marrakesk. The food is what you see, grilled or not grilled, hygine would not be high in the pop up stalls, But where else can you see , snake charmer,moneys on lead ready for photo shots , snall stalls , cooked sheep head stall and people selling all kinds of nik naks and some not selling any thing! just expect money off you, because your from Europe
Mad house. It was a frantic sensory expeience that I will never forget
Lovely to look around. Be careful not to get lost, very big but lots of shops and cafes.

Lovely - The REAL Marrakech!. if you are planning on visiting Marrakech, the Medina is the place to go! staying in the Gueliz (new city) is nice, but the medina (old city) is definitely the place to stay if you want to experience the real Marrakech!

Hot, tiring, but fascinating!. Loved the Bahia Palace, the decoration/architecture is amazing, and it was a cool haven in the heat of the day. The Sadian tombs were also worth a visit for the mosaics. The souks were fascinating but it was fatal to linger . . . the stall holders are very persuasive (but friendly!). We saw round the artisans quarter (with a guide) - wow - real craftsmanship, but they haven't heard of 'health and safety'. We were taken round a house, which was interesting to see - very different from ours! The whole place is pretty busy, and not very pedestrian-friendly - you have to keep your wits about you, but it's an experience not to be missed.

There is Magic in the Air. Imagine yourself in the footsteps of people who tread this path, narrow alleys, various flavours and sounds and calls. interspersed with modern galleries and restaurants. one can get lost here just wandering around not knowing what is around the corner. Highly recommended
Fantastic. Just gave a whole new dimension to the way people live

Nothing like it.... It is like stepping into another world! The narrow streets are packed with people, donkeys, cars and lots and lots of motorbikes weaving in and out of the crowds. A map,is of little use here, we navigated our way around by remembering landmarks and learning 2 routes from our riad to the square (one in each direction from the front door). Doing this on the first day there made life so much easier, even when we went off the beaten track we were still able to get our bearings. It is essential to get your bearings fast, even if you have no idea, fake it, otherwise the local boys will be swarming around you leading you in circles and demanding money for it. I found it overwhelming when we first drove in through the medina walls, but with a fantastic riad to escape to when necessary I began to really enjoy the energy of the place and miss it now that I have gone...I hope to return really soon
Truly Amazing. So such vivid colours. So rich in culture. Loved it!
Pop up markets. Eat in number 26, the pop up Market at night is lots of fun and the meat is beautiful, as is the aubergine, wash it down with fresh oj.
Crazy, but brilliant.... On first sight, the Medina can be a bit scary - but it really just takes a little getting used to before you realise that it is simply fantastic.

Not a pleasant experience.. We booked to stay at a Riad Hotel in the Medina for 3 days, it was a nightmare, we would never go back there again, we were violently accosted in the souks, this may be rare but it happend to us. Our experience was not pleasant at all, i am sure if you stay at a hotel away from the medina it may be pleasant enough for some. We came home after just one night, please be aware of what you will be experiencing if you plan to stay in a Riad in the medina.On the hotel, it was rated as 4 star but we would have placed it around a low 2, the ceiling fan was nearly falling down , one light fitting was totally hanging from the ceiling, the bedside lamp was faulty, the bed was ok and it was a clean room, although we didn't get clean towels as you would expect from a 4 star hotel.It was a very poor area and poverty at a level we have never seen in our lives. There was not one redeeming feature for us. If you want to see how fortunate we are to live in UK this must be the place to go. We were just happy to get back even though we lost the Holiday and the £600 we paid to go .There were plenty of happy people on the flight home that seemed as though they had enjoyed it but I guess they were not in the Medina or they enjoyed feeling like a rich Westerner. We wouldn't go again even if it were free.
different. its so different at different hours through out the day,if you go in the morning please go back in the evening as it changes but dont forget your camera

Stepped back a thousand years. It was a great experience to really get a sense of what the souks have been like for thousands of years. But the agressive tactics of the vendors was very annoying. Made laid back vibe in medina of Essouria much more enjoyable.

Over crowded and too much hectoring. Narrow streets I expected, idiots riding motorcycles in amongst the pedestrians at breakneck speeds I did not expect. Can't imagine how many people get injured by them each year.Hard to navigate due to lack of signs.Hectoring by 'guides' and shop owners deterred us from stopping, it might be the North African culture, but it can be a serious 'off put' to some.

Busy and fascinating. Very traditional in some areas, but touristy near the square. Everyone wants money - to guide you around, to show you things, to let you take photos - have some coins always available. Everyone is very friendly and good natured, but they are after your money!!! However once you get used to it it is fun. Don't buy anything on your first day - get used to it first and watch out for the motorbikes zipping in and out, and the donkeys!

Lively and interesting - but be prepared. Having visited Fez, and enjoyed seeing the tannery and weaving co-ops, was less enthralled with Marrakesh - did not offer the same range of goods, quality or prices and the atmosphere in Marrakesh was altogether different. Perhaps it is because the sheer volume of visitors makes the stall holders feel they must compete but they are altogether less friendly or amenable, verging occasionally on being unduly aggressive and pushy. Its also not an easy place to walk around like Fez due to the motor cycles which go at break neck speeds. It was the one place where when 2 of us females went out alone we were treated with with behaviour which was at best indifferent and at worst contemptuous. References were made to one of us maybe being Jewish and hating Arabs. Both of us have had experience in similar enviroments, but this felt uncomfortable. the night life in the square, and street stalls for eating were great - some of the best food we ate during the tour

What a place!. The medina is very scary if you are on your own. We had a guide and I think this is worth it, especially if you are a woman. I loved seeing all the things for sale and all the bright colors and hearing all the noises. I was terrified of the snakes and monkeys in the middle of Jamaa El Fnaa square but I am so happy that I got see that in real life. We sat out in the sun on a rooftop terrace and it was beautiful to drink mint tea and think that this same thing happened to other people many years ago, and will probably happen in the same way hundreds of years from now...
visit with a guide. very interesting but far better to visit with a guided tour as your questions will be answered

Chaotic, charming old suq. Very charming, very chaotic and disorienting suq, but after a couple days we found our way nicely by the help of the owner of our Riad. I saw some reviews before travelling saying that one should be careful to wear proper shoes because of the waste... but I actually prefered good flipflops and just took a foot wash when returning to the guesthouse :))

Temptations for all the Senses!. Loved the colours, smells of the spices, and the general hustle and bustle. Most of the sellers were warm, friendly and helpful.Some were a little persistent and be careful not to pick things up before bargaining. Our lovely hostess at the Riad El Souk advised us in advance of the prices of things so that we were not ripped off. This way, we were able to bargain without causing offense.

Chaos. The main parts of the Medina are enjoyable to walk through and see all the weird and wonderful goings on and things being sold. However some parts away from the main tourist bits are intimidating and the constant hassle does start to wear you down after a while. Don't accept directions off of anyone, they will expect you to pay and also watch out for all the mopeds that hurtle down the tiny streets at a ridiculous speed with no care for anyones safety.
Beautiful madness. This is a place you should not miss, the #1 site of Morocco, but: bring pocket money (to pay for monkeys and snakes)

Mad!. You will never experience any thing again quite like this! Unique! Yes I felt a lot of the attractions there were for tourists but it is sooo full on that you are left totally exilarated by the experience . I have never laughed and shrieked so much in my life!
Madness. Madness, Get lost and explore, lots of things to buy and interesting things to see!
beautiful. fantastic sights, great walking, safe and friendly people.
No children !. Don t bring your children here...it s dirty and quite dangerous with all the motorbikes everywhere. The place in itself is quite crazy and loud...

Crazy fun!. Although overwhelming at times, it is always interesting. It's narrow alleyways, insane traffic (motorbikes in the souks?!!), tiny shopfronts, crush of people, noise, music, snake charmers, trained monkeys,tarot card readers transport you to another time and place.

Fantastic History. The whole of the Medina was a sight to behold, IF you like the history and take into account this city was on the spice trail. The Souks were fabulous and I really enjoyed the bartering.
An absolute must to get to really experience the city.. The people, shops, eateries are a must to visit and see if you are to develop an appreciation of the city.
Hectic Medina of Marrakech. Overwhelming, crowded, busy and vibrant place. Do try to eat out at night at the square, value for money and a true experience!

Unique atmosphere. Worth seeing if going to Morocco and Marrakech, a day is enough for most of the city with museums and etc. Would recommend to stay in a riad in the Medina, to experience the atmosphere, but always be alert for tricky Moroccans!
Out of this world. Noise, chaos, hassled but bartering is great fun and , in our experience, carried out with dramatic good humour.
hustle and bustle. great food, plenty of bartering and a bit of fun to be had
Bustling, animated, friendly. Yes, walk through the narrow streets, ignore the many who want to take you to a cousin's shop; but do not miss the Saadian Tombs, a jewel of Moroccan culture.
Vibrant, noisy, smoky and alluring. So much to see, all of life id here. Just go and experience it for yourself. No picture can dojustice

Difficult to enjoy your walk. We visited the Medina many times, we saw beautiful buildings, shops and handcrafts but it was hard to enjoy our walk because we had to watch continuously and protect ourself against cars and motorcycles whose drivers generally don't care about pedestrians. The motorcycles were the worst and the donkey drivers were the less dangerous. Essaouira Medina was much more pleasant to walk around. Furthermore, we did not find a map of the Medina and we had to ask continuously our way.

be prepared!. It was bedlam! BUT it has to be experienced. You can browse but be prepared to be harrassed at every step. After a day you do get used to it. there are monkeys for you to have your photos taken with, snake charmers, ladies doing henna, music and general stalls. At night it turns into a mobile restaurant fest. Enjoy it. Have at least one meal or drink in a restaurant overlooking the square.
Great fun. Love ths place vibrant full of life , diffrent colours and smells and on the whole friendly people
Very Interesting and lots of photo opportunities. very clean and nicely kept site with lots of historical interest.
chaotic and hassly. exciting but intimidating, couldn't browse due to constant haranguing
Exceelen but busy. everyon is expecting a tip even for walking in the street or saying hi to u

Medina of Marrakech. A fantastic piece of history here within the walls of the medina. Get a guidebook and work out where you want to go as you can get caught up (and lost!) in the souks and miss some of the wonderful attractions and historic places it has to offer.

The real Marrakech experience!. You can't have been in Marrakesh without visiting the Medina: hearing the Koutoubia calling every body to prair, eating the delicous meals form the food stalls on the Jemaa El Fnaa and leaving a lot of money in the souks!

A must see when visiting Marrakech!. Great place to haggle with the locals! Lots of things to see and do. Could spend all day walking around. Lots of good restaurants and stools to eat from. 'The real Marrakech'!

World's largest living medina, enough said. The medina of Marrakech is a pulsing, vibrating, thing of wonder to behold and enjoy. Still alive with Moroccans, and so big that even with the enormous growth in tourism of the past few years, it has lost, little, if any, of its authenticity. What a great thing to have so close to Europe, that a short flight to Marrakech can give you something that is so radically different than a daily European life that it is completely de-stressing.
A must see. authentic and teeming with life, do not miss it, go in the evening when the whole of Marrakech is there, no need to ask the way,just follow the crowd

Mad, mad, mad. Everythings on sale and negotiable. Bargain hard and then half it ! The shopkeepers are relentless so avoid eye contact and ignore every word or they will sell you something before you know it. Great fun !

Experience not to be missed. walking where people have been walking meeting living for a 1,000 years. the focal point of one of the great trading routes is not to be missed .Do not expect pristine sounds sites or smells but go to immerse your self in the history of the passed.
Feels like walking in a movie. I like the atmosphere. Sometimes it gets to crowded and busy, then get a cup of tea in a nice road, relax and coninue your trip of discovery

A different world!!. Its like being in another world, scooters everywhere, rubbish all over the place, people pestering you with directions, getting lost, etc. You've got to experience it, all part of the fun of being in Marrakech!!

mad bustling experience. The snake charmers, acrobats and many stalls were amazing to see although it would be easier to enjoy them without the continual buzzing of small motorcycles which you have to take care to avoid and the hassling of traders, which means that if you stop to look you are immediately pounced on for money, I would have stopped more and paid more if it was't so pressured. Having said that most people are funny and charming and Marrakech is all about the souks and square and not to be missed
life of Brian. drop into a world like the set of life of brian a bit too over the top for me

Bonkers. Crazy, crazy place. We got lost, visited the same square a few times (not out of choice!!) and bought a carpet. Lose your Western values and beliefs, forget time and immerse yourself in the zaniest shopping experience.

Marvelous Medina. amazing, chaotic, a kaleidoscope of colours, sounds and smells: loosing yourself in the Medina of Marrakech is an experience like no other. Just make sure you don't stop in a shop if you have no intention of buying; it is not polite and could spoil your experience. You will be asked a thousand times to stop, look and offered to be brought from a boutique to a "cooperative". Know that if you accept, you're in for a very different experience that might take more than an hour and a great social interaction. Again, be sure you want to bu something before you acept the invitation.
busy, a festival of colours. So many beautiful things to buy....To bargain could be a painful at times..

Very Large Medina. This was like all other Morocco Medina, except much larger. It had better night life and restaurants at night, but during day the motor bikes just ruined my visit. They keep beeping behind me and smoke me up, not to mention the terrible noise. So, in this area I like the Fez Medina better.As always in Medinas in Morocco,Avoid wanna be guidesAsk direction only from shop keepersLearn some French or ArabicReject all unsolicited assistance, or you will end up paying for itDon't worry you getting lost. At the end you can start finding a way out. If you look confuse or lost, then you will make unwanted attraction. So, don't look lost, even if you are.

Interesting. the Medina, is the walled part of Marrakesh, the original part, you should go with a guide if its your first time, as it is a warren of streets and you can get lost if you are not careful

Fun! Marrakech is all about the atmosphere.. The souks, Jemmaa el Fna square, & the mint tea are all things one must experience here! Grab a seat at a terrace cafe at sunset & watch Jemmaa el Fna square come alive! It's great to meander the streets & alleys within the medina.
good to see but a little scary. it was very good to see but a little scary with so many people

An experience. Interesting, but the locals don't leave you alone if you look lost, they will direct you for a fee and become your unofficial guide also for a fee. Toilet facilities none existant or primitive.
Crazy real life. TheMedina is so stuffed full of life and vitality - take a few precautionary steps with your riches and step into a world of bartering, scents and colours...
A enlightening experience - definitely a must see. Enjoyed the hustling, bartering and liked looking at all the produce being sold

Medina. The Medina is the absolute heart of Marrakesh you cannot go without staying here and walking around. All the winding roads that cars can't fit into and the people its amazing. It was fun to walk around the souks and jemma el fnaa square. It looks like it would have thousands of years ago like nothing has changed and that's what I loved about it. Amazing definitely walk around and just enjoy the different way of life. Only irritation was the motorbike/scooters that kept going by since cars can't fit in.

Nothing can prepare you for this. Within my first few hours on the streets of Marrakech I had a snake thrown around my unsuspecting neck, an argument with a cafe waiter and been cursed by locals who resented me trying to take their photos. I had not expected a place so in your face.Marrakech is like a street market on hallucinogens. I have been to markets all over the world, but I have never known a city which is almost one endless market. The tourists souks selling textiles, lamps, shoes, carpets and more merge into stalls selling foods, spices and clothes to the resident population. The maze of alleys and streets is confusing - even with a map - a compass on my phone seemed the best way to navigate. There are of course the many people offering you guidance back to your Riad or the central Place - but you need to pay them.The experience is intense and there seems no escape from the noise and smells and people. The people of the Medina often seem intolerant and aggressive - especially when you try to take their photos. But , when you take the time to visit their shops, they are always interesting and often extremely hospitable.The Riads of Marrakech, both those converted to Hotels and B&Bs, and those that have been reserved as museums - seem a world a way from the bustle of the Medina. In these Moorish palaces, you feel at complete peace and in touch with the stunning art of a special people.Marrakech is a unique world of its own. Even other Moroccans we met outside of the city looked at it with a sense of bafflement. Prepare yourself for an adventure.
Medina. Rather run-down but nevertheless historically interesting
WHEWWWWW. Such a huge place. Deffinately need more than one trip to enjoy it all. Fantastic.
DON'T VISIT MOROCCO IN JANUARY - YOU WILL FREEZE. I am just cutting short a trip to Morocco because of the intense freezing cold air. Difficult to breathe.

Shopping Heaven. Its like shopping heaven, so many wonderful stalls and a diverse range of goods from leather bound books to plastic singing camels. Some delightful finds of Berber silver and leather goods of every colour imaginable.

Buzzing!. Lively, exciting and diverse. Sit and watch the hive of activity and be amazed to see the young and old going a out their business. Great for food and shopping. Steer clear of the snakes and monkeys, if you take a photo be prepared to pay for the privilege!
Sensory overload. exotic, bustling, interesting and fun. Fantastic people watching and food stalls were simple but super tasty

Intense. We stayed in a lovely riad in the Medina and spent all day every day there. It is a riot of colour and activity and a fun experience. But, they need to do something about the mopeds that zoom through the narrow alleyways with no regard for pedestrians, and about the young boys who try to get money for guiding you to places where you're already headed. We got sick and tired of having arguments with them, as they tried to follow us, and lead us the wrong way - so you feel more grateful when you eventually get there - no amount of "non merci" had any impact on these boys. Then when we had decided to let one show us the way he demanded ten euros for the service at the end and was threatening to us, in front of our three year old daughter, who got extremely upset. Wandering in the medina was a great experience at times, but more often stressful and unenjoyable. For reasons of the mopeds and chaos, we would not recommend a holiday to Marrakech for families with young children.
Go there. I liked it all really. The sounds, atmosphere, smells, it was the very best of what experiencing a life outside of my own was about.
Hire a guide!. Hiring a guide for a half day to get your bearings is really important. Be prepared to be hassled a bit.

Exciting and a must see. Walking the streets of the Medina transports you to another age. This warren of alleys and paths, lined with shops, house, restaurants and stalls, is vibrant, friendly and fun. I stayed in a Riad here, and got used to the hustle and bustle surprisingly quickly. The locals remember you, and you soon feel a part of the place. Don't miss a walk through - nor be afraid to wander of the beaten track. it's worth it for the wonders you'll see.
amazing. It was like no where else I have ever been...It was a very different experience as an American being in a foreign locale.

Marrakech, one to avoid.. Awful place. Dirty, terrible food, nothing to do. And anyone who finds it interesting and beauitful and enjoys getting ripped off really needs to expand the places where they go on holiday. I've been to some poor depressing places but this tops the list.
okay. it was during the Eid holiday so very few shops were opened
Crazy.... A complete maze which can be a little overwhelming at first but soon makes sense. Make sure to bargain hard as some of the vendors start with 'ambitious' prices.

For the full Marrakech "we're not in Kansas anymore" feeling, check out the Medina!. I had done the research, and had read how different, how unique the Medina experience is. But after staying in a Riad there, and spending most of a week in Marrakech exploring the various neighborhoods within the Medina, I could honestly say that is was not like anywhere I had ever been before.The chaos, the motorbikes, the dust, the crumbling buildings, the energy, the spirit, it's overwhelming, exciting, truly a unique and thrilling place.At first, I was a little put off by the style of negotiating, by the fact that everyone you speak to seems to be wanting to sell you something. But then when I took Therese's advice that it's a kind of game, I was able to relax and enjoy the give and take. If you want pristine paved streets and orderly behavior, you can visit any one of a number of cities anywhere in the world. But if you really want to experience something like nowhere you've ever seen, go to Marrakech and experience the Medina.
Heady Madness. Not for the faint-hearted. An eye-opening, life-affirming, belly-filling, mind-expanding, nostril-scouring, awe-inspiring distillation of the madness of life.
just enjoyed taking everything in. It can be very confusing & crowded, a little over whelming at first. But once I got use to it & just enjoyed taking everything in I would go back.

Unspoiled Morocco. We stayed right within the Medina at Ryad Joya. Fantastic roaming the small alleyways losing our direction, negotiating is an expected custom so don't let them down. I didn't feel harassed at all by the vendors as I have in other Moroccan medinas.
Very nice experience. Another "must see" in Marrakech. It looks like houndreds years ago. You have to feel and smell it ! :-))

Clean, much to see. You just get the oriental feeling here and sometimes just the present you were looking for. People are friendly but persisting to draw your attention to their goods. Just give a friendly smile and walk on if you are not interested.Watch out for the bikes and small cars. Thei own the road.

A must visit. Difficult to add to the comments of others. My partner preferred this medina over Fes, it has far more hustle and bustle. I tired of the constant hawking here, compared to the more traditional nature of Fes. For eating in the main square, stall number 1 appears to be the most highly recommended by the various hotels (based on our discussions with other western tourists on our wanders)
total madness in a good way. The medina has so much more charm than the new city, yes it is quite hardcore at times but that is all part of the fun, this is no western market

Chaos. Donkeys, motorbikes, bicycles... These are some of the obstacles you will dodge in the medina, but it is well worth the near death encounters for the experience of daily Moroccan medina life. Be sure to eat all sorts of delicious treats!

good trip. culture was interesting, only complaint is that there were beggers everywhere. Even a payment was expected if you took their picture, if you dont pay your in trouble with their tourist police.

So much fun. We spent three days in Marrakech, and pretty much all we did the whole time was explore the Medina and souks. There are people everywhere. Most of them are trying to sell you stuff, but they weren't as pushy as in Egypt. You can get your picture taken with snakes and monkeys. Just know that you will have to pay every time you take a picture. Even if you just take an un-posed picture of an animal in the medina, it's owner will want you to pay, and he will argue over it loudly. Set a price before you take any pictures.

Embrace the experience!!. Hustle and bustle, hectic and crazy!! A wonderful experience like no other I have had. Be prepared to be demented with sellers of henna tattoos, snake charmers, monkey handlers and people selling all manner of things. Just smile and walk on if you are not interested, it doesn't work to become agitated with them. Its just their way of life which we have to embrace. Enjoy the sights and smells and sounds!!
Interesting and Colourful. Sound, smell, sights and food....FAB Interesting place to spend a day/night

If you do nothing else do this. Do a thorough tour before you purchase. Many stalls have the same goods and prices get lower the farther from the Jmma El Fna you go. Realy fun and if you get lost it is not a big deal part of the enjoyement
It is essential to stsy here to see Marrakech. At least for a couple of days. Careful with the pollution. A dust ridden city not ideal for people with airborne allergies

A great experience. This is the place to be! The life, the music, the souks, the touts, the array of stalls... you name it, everything is there. I loved the medina and getting lost in the souks. You can eat on the streets, drink freshly squeezed orange juice and observe and tune in the buzz. Enjoy a quiet moment in one of the cafes over a cup of mint tea and stay in the terrace for the sunset.
A Magical passage back in time. It is facinating and you feel like you are in an Indiana Jones Movie. A glimpse into another life.

Medina madness. It's great... Very authentic...beware mopeds driving throughout medina and lots of pollution as a result. People are generally respectful and friendly - just trying to earn a hard living! Barter hard! Prices at airport on way home 3 times price you can buy at in medina. Once you start you won't stop!

Incredible and Insane in equal measure. The Medina is utterly beguiling, confusing and beautiful, the smells, noise, colours and confusion make your head spin and it feels like you are walking in a film set... Once seen, never forgotten
Amazing place. Some of the museums and places to vist are amzing. Visit the old Koranic Boarding School, the Museum de Marrakech, the Palais de Bahia and Dar Si Said. THe buildings are works of art.

chaotic exotic beauty. it´s worth a visit once in a lifetime, but to be honest , i don`t want to came back. It´s too confusing and dirt and most of all, they alow motocicles in those tiny little roads, it´s impossible to breeth, normaly. after an hour we just want to run away from there.
Shopping in Marrakech. Expect it to be what is - busy, flavoursome in both food and the culture.

A must see. Hustle and bustle, colourful and so different from at home. Take a guided tour, we learned SO much and would not have understood everything that was going on, or seen half as much without a guide.

Bustling and brimming with real life!. Really liked the fact that this was not just a tourist attraction, but also a place where the people of Marrakech went about their daily routine.
Would have found it less manic if there were fewer mopeds!
What to say. Go, walk yourself to the small streets and loose yourself. Smell, look and listen, feelings for every sense!

What Marrakech is all about. The Medina lives up your every Orientalist fantasy with its narrow, cobbled alleyways, teeming with the fascinating trivia of traditional (and sometimes modern) everyday life. Don't even bother taking a map with you. We just wandered the streets for an hour or two, getting gloriously lost, minding our business, being discreet with our photo-taking, and completely ignoring the baksheesh-hungry-but-harmless kids who want to be your completely useless, broken-English guide. Of course, if you're a single female, a little more care should be exercised, I guess. But even females in twos shouldn't have any problems.
Lively, colourful and mysterious. Full of life, colour, hustle and bustle. Definitely worth a couple of visits. And the mystery? I don't know how so many traders can make a living.
Loved It!!. Brilliant, so much to see and do, just soaked up the atmosphere and watched their way of life.

People, all about people!. Moroccan people are soo nice! It's unbelievable, so respectful, caring. They saw i was afraid of snakes, even fake ones, and they would hide them from me. Ps, really bargain the prices, they're are a bit high, plus the sellers love it!

Average excursion. I had the priviledge of also visiting the medina in Fes. In my opinion the medina in Fes is not as commercialised and I felt a lot saver! We got harassed quite badly outside our riad in one of the alleys in the middle of theMarrakech medina! After that experience we even changed accomodation in a closer to the outskirts of the medina, in a busy street where we still got harassed one evening!
True Marrakech. Finally felt like I'd stumbled into the real Marrakech

great food, shopping, chaos. the square outside the medina is great, especially at night when all the food stalls open and the lights turn on. we came back for a couple of day and did some shopping through the medina. great for presents. came back with too much stuff we had to buy an extra suitcase!watch out for the snake charmers in the square, they're a rip off. but we did get some good photos with the cobra.
Get lost!. Facinating 'old city' section of Marrakech. Impossibly confusing, mysterious, and beautiful. I think I could spend a week just exploring the medina.

A fun medina. The Marrakech media is highly atmospheric, a lot of fun do get lost in, and is excellent for buying crafts (much better than Fez). Unfortunately, motorbikes spewing exhaust fumes (which have been banned in other medinas around the country) pollute the experience. Yuck. The food in northern medians tends to be better as well, though this medina has some restuarants turning out authentic tangines. Look for the ones full of locals, not tourists.

You have to visit but its hassle all the way. busy busy and bikes flying everywhere be carefull, if youwant to eat at the stalls try to fight your way into the centre, better prices, but it takes some getting in,ever stall worker will grab you,

Medina. Nothing could have prepared me for this.OUr Riad was located in teh heart of the Medina. We arrived late at night to be met by one of teh staff from teh Riad at the outskirt of the Medina from where we had to walk. Thought we'd been transported to Beirut!

Don't go, the people are horrible!. The hassling to buy things is unbearable. The people are sneaky, extremely pushy and rude. It is impossible to buy anything, it's almost impossible to shake off men trying to get you to part with your money and you just can't even look at anything in the Medina.

The quintessential medina in Morocco. It's the place to be ... whether the souks, the palaces, or the main square (Djemaa el F'na, among other spellings). From the snake charmers in the day, to the food stalls of the night market, to the tiny passageways of the old city, to the gates in the city wall, to the charming riads, to the souks (the markets), this is a thriving and vital place. And with the exception of some pick-pocketing, it's safe, even at night.
What an experience. You have to experience this...no words can describe the Medina.The smell...oh i could sit on a balcony and watch the market sqaure all day with a cup of mint tea! Amazing!

It took a couple of days to get used to the place, but it was all fun!. I don't think there's any need for a map of the medina, unless you really want to get to a specific shop or cafe and even if you do, one of the local boys will show you the way, in exchange for a few dirhams. You've got the time, you can just wander around an eventually you'll work out where everything is. If I ever did get lost, I would note the direction of the shadows and then always walk in the same direction in relation to the shadows, at least then you know you probably won’t go round in circles!Spices are marked up per kilo, sometimes the stallholders in the centre of the medina will tell you that this is the price per 100g! I went to the local shops on north and towards the edge of the medina, I know that some of the purchases were underweight, but I think that even though I paid more than a local person, the quality will be better than at the spice stalls which are aimed specifically at tourists. Whatever you might want to buy in the medina; spices (e.g. paprika, harissa, ras el honout, lavender, linseed, saffron, turmeric, nigella seeds), alum rock natural deodourant, incense sticks, silk scarves, rugs, wooden toys and instruments, tagine, etc, it’s worth investigating the price in the UK before you go so that you don’t get swept away in the moment when haggling. I found that if I wanted to get away from a shop without buying something, I would politely offer an extremely low price, then only budge by a few dirhams and the stallholder would realise that it wasn’t worth continuing the conversation and it was easy to walk away with pride and good humour intact on both sides.As a woman travelling on my own I had no trouble at all. I wore long sleeves and long trousers at all times, although there’s no need to wear a headscarf. The locals in the medina are overwhelmingly young men and I found that they were polite and mainly just wanted to exchange a few words, a polite “bonjour” or “how are you?”. If we want the waiters and shopkeepers to be able to speak a foreign language, this is the way that they are going to learn. Once I had worked out where my hotel was in relation to the medina I was happy to walk around on my own at night.
the best place. the best place i've seen in my life, very exotique, people are vey nice.best place for shopping

Busy, bustling medina. Great markets, bargins to be had if you're not ripped off by the locals.. Its a wonderful place of culture. Great market, but locals can be very intimidating and duplicitous. Hold your ground and know the worth of what you are buying.

Wonderful médina to get lost in at will. The médina offers a very large variety to the traveller, though it does have a more tourist-orientated feel to it than for instance the médina of Fès. Disappointingly, some traders do get a bit rude when a decision is made not to buy. One can spend hours getting lost in the small streets, but help is always at hand - albeit probably at a small price!

Great place to stroll around and shop. World Heritage Site - takes you back a few years - loved the colors, smells and sounds. Don't get pressured to buy anything you don't want - enjoy the shopping and haggling experience even if you don't end up buying what you want or end up paying a little more than you wanted. The women selling souvenier leather camels will bother you but that ended up being one of our best purchases!Spent an hour at a rug co-operative, saw some beautiful rugs but decided they were too expensive for our budget. Overall can be a great experience if you don't get too overwhelmed by the bargaining.

lovely little place to browse and eat. This is a quiet, charming little gallery showing old photographs from around Morocco. On the roof is a hot little terrace cafe which serves one dish (lemon chicken tagine, very good) and cans of pop. It is cheap and has a stunning view of the mountains and across the Medina. Recommended.
get lost in it!. it's an amazing place. lots of things to be seen. people in the streets sometimes are a bit too pushy and they offer for indications, but you will manage.
A City of Marvels. A hustling and bustling milieu of chaotic uniform. Each stall an experience. My most wonderful human interaction of old and new culture and tradition.
The medina is the life and breath of Marrakech. I enjoyed every minute spent in the medina and hopefully will be revisiting there in a few months.

Amazing....just amazing. Loved the Medina! All the little stalls / shops and alley ways where getting lost was a very real possibility!After a while, you realize everyone is selling the same stuff, but this does not take the enjoyment out of looking. The Medina is fasinating, ever changing. Everyone hawking their wares and trying to make a deal with you. Bartering is par for the course, but don't make a deal, have the seller agree and then not buy. This is not only rude, but insulting to the vendor. Most vendors do not like their picture being taken, or want money if you do take it. There are some great restaurants in the Medina, along with some very unique stores / stalls.One word of caution - watch out for the motorcycles (and your handbags as well!)
Life as it has been for centuries. Wander around narrow streets where people are still going about their day to day lives as they have done for hundreds of years a taste of old and new

Buzzing!. Loved the energy of the place and really enjoyed being there. Was hassled too much to buy things. I felt that I couldnt even get an eyeful of the sights without being pushed to purchase. Towards the end, i started walking with my eye lowered just telling people I had no money. Great place to eat food, though! Again, was harrassed to eat at one place or another or another.

It is like you are going back a few hundred years. The Old Medina is one of the best things about Marrakech. You can stroll around and some of the things you will see will blow your mind. All of your senses will be used, the sights, the smells, the hussle and bussle of the place is just extra-ordinary. When you are strolling around it is like you have been taken back in time. You can spend hours walking and looking around, there are hundreds of photo opportunites and some of the architecture will inspire you. Be confident and if anyone approaches you and tells you they will show you around then just tell them you dont need any help, else at the end they will demand money off you and this may spoil you experience. Be strong and tell them you dont need their help, even if you get lost you will eventually find you way out (getting lost is one of the best things as it almost always takes you to parts of the medina that you would not ordinary have seen).

Interesting market for shopping & eating. First time for me to see the snake dance (even though they were just standing or lying down as weather was probably too cold for them), you have to pay if you want to take picture with snakes wrapped around your shoulder (it was $300) for one person and we bargained to $200. During the day, it's mainly for shopping and seeing those performances, and in the evening, those will be replaced by food stalls, so you can just have dinner there. We even tried the snail soup (taste a bit weird for us), the stall with lamb meat & a sheep head - it was just really tender lamb meat, was sooooo good!) and all the local stuff :-) It was quite an experience. Keep in mind they don't use forks but only their hands for eating, so if you really mind then you should bring along your own utensils when eating in local food stalls. *Orange (or probably Mandarin Orange) juice is a MUST - only $4 each and taste so so good!
Fantastic place to visit!. Loved the medina, the sights and sounds, the bustle, the friendliness, the organised chaos. It's an unmissable city.

Great medina experience. The Marrakech medina is filled with a million sights, sounds, and smells. We had a wonderful time just walking and admiring all of the goods for sale. The best time, however, was when we went at "off peak tourist times" (i.e. in the evening) and wandered into areas where locals shop. Don't worry about getting lost - if you orient yourself to Djemaa El Fna and the Koutoubbia Mousque, it's fairly easy to find your way around. You will definitely get tons of people calling to you to buy things, which does get old after a while. It helps a lot to learn the basic phrase "laa, shukran" (no, thank you) and smile - be polite but stand your ground. Also, don't listen to boys who tell you that the streets ahead are closed - they are just looking to take you back to the main plaza for a few dirham. All in all, a must-do in Marrakech.
Get lost in the souks and medina for hours. It is a job trying to remember your way round the souks. It is fascinating and yes put your haggling skills to test. people friendly and safe.
Another world. I loved the souks of the Medina, as I can speak some Arabic I purchases some nice items such as two large glazed tagine pots for 160dhms (£12)... recommended!

Awe-inspiring stimuli for the senses!. Perhaps synthesized in part for tourists, but rich in real tradition, the center of Marrakech is a must see/experience for anyone visiting Morocco. Entering the Medina you will hear snake charmers, Berber musicians, smell rich spices from the food vendors, and see every color imaginable in the fabrics at various shops. Getting lost is an adventurous concern in the labyrinthine market system as you pass by merchants calling out in sometimes five or more major languages for new customers. This is an incredible place and should not be missed for any traveler of North-West Africa.

Enjoyed the experience. We like the whole idea and place, really liked bartering with the small stall owners as they went along with your experience. Didn't like the bigger stores that seemed to try and bully you into purchasing even though they were the richer set. We felt they were greedy and made the experience boring.Spend your money at the smaller stalls deeper in the Medina you pay a lot lot less.

A magical old city. The historic medina is colourful, exciting, but rather exhausting!! Worth seeking out some of the historic sites and being prepared to get lost in the narrow streets. We had a magical walk through the back streets one evening as we went from the Mellah back to the Jemaa el Fna. We ended up in a really quiet residential area of little narrow streets; it was beautiful and felt really timeless.

Labyrinth. Labyrinth is a very appropriate word for this place. Its very different from the other medinas in the large cities and if you have a few days in Marrakech it is worth it to just wander aimlessly for a day

What an amazing place!. The medina is that part of Marrakech enclosed by the old city walls. Life within it is chaotic and full of activity. We stayed at Riad Lakhdar which is a short walk from the square and souks. It is interesting to visit these more outlying areas as they are (slightly) less touristy and you can see and meet locals. A visit to the fixed price super store - Bouchaib in Rue de la Kasbah is a must (just south west of Badi Palace). It gives you the best idea of what to pay in the market and is often cheaper anyway. It also has an amazing variety and quantity of stock - mind blowing. Walk back to Fna Square through the Jewish quarter souks. Avoid the annoying guides by saying you want to get lost or simply walk away from where they direct you. They will ALWAYS want money for "helping". The beggar ladies are just about always 'actors" and go home to bed after their days "work". Donate to the disabled - they probably need it. If it all gets too much take a walk or taxi to the French quarter north of the medina at the Plaza on Ave Mohammed V (where Mcdonalds is). Up there is a more modern cosmopolitan Marrakech - even alcohol in the restuarants! Absorb the Medina atmosphere - there is nowhere else like it!
different world. you must have visit this place. It just banish you. The best ist when you take advantage of the freshly squeezed orange juices at the market.

The best part is where the local shops. A good part of the Medina are shops for the tourists near the main square which gets old and repatative after a while. However, a much larger part of the Medina are narrow ally ways and shops for dail living for the locals, and I find that to provide a real glimps of the real life there. So when you go there, don't focus on the arers near the main square, pick a direction and go until you hit the old wall of Medina, and get a taste of what the resident do.
great. The smells, sounds, sights are as incredible as I imagined. Touts can be a bit OTT tho.

My Favourite place in Morocco. the Medina of Marrakech is the best place i find myself to enjoy the brilliant local Culture, meeting new people visitors locals or forgieners, you can enjoy the lights, people, smells, and evrything surrounding, but one thing that make my being in it a bit scary is when i get inside the narrow roads, i feel a bit not normal and keep aware from everyone, other thing everything is expensive around you, anyway; Marrakech Medina really a wolrd Heritage Site, as i feel safe and special when im hanging around by myself or with other friends but i can advice not to go alone and if you go alone just look at someone to go with so you can enjoy and not feel lonely to get bored.i highly recommending Marrakech Medina for everyone.
Morocco madness. The medina is great but the vendors are used to tourists and quote u outrageous prices that I would never even spend in the US. I walked away many times.
culture. if ypu want tp see how moroccan lives are, go here!

The market s were busy and smaller then we had imagined. It had been raining so it was slightly messy around the walkways.
also didn't realise that the locals used their mopeds right through the middle of the alleyways
Nice places aggressive people. The Medina and souks are nice. People are very aggressive in their approach. We have seen few people laughing.
great place. liked everything about it, def is a must to visit, can't leave marakkesh withouth this

Only for the brave. Take a map and a COMPASS this is the only way to negotiate the area without having to employ a guide. Take a bearing before you enter and you will always be able to find your way back. Saw other tourists lost even with sat nav. Mopeds wizz everywhere to be safe obey the rules and stick to the right hand side when walking.
Stunning - wish I'd had more time to explore it. Bustling, full of colour, many interesting things on sale - I bought a tagine.

Nothing short of spectacular!. Seeing the entire souks and medina was amazing, a completely different world to the UK, but not to be missed. We started off with a tour round the souks and medina, looked at some ruins... then to the old university, a mueseum, followed by the old palace. Stopped off for a horse ride round the city walls, and then went to a restaurant, that to be frank looked awful from the outside, but once we walked through the doors it was amazing, and I couldnt beleive we got it included on the price! Well worth anyones money...
Fun to wander around. I love the sites and founds of this medina. From the fabric to the copper- get lost and have fun!

one of the world's great experiences. Dining amidst the chaos and charm of the Jemaa el Fna, Marrakech, has to be one of life's great eating experiences. Dinner of grilled lamb chops, sausages and no less than five entrees with juices came in at under 110 dirhams. Take the persistent sellers in your stride - they want you to get a bite of their best. The more adventurous should try the sheep's head. Best to hop from stall to stall to savour their offerings.
Funky cold Medina. The medina would be a highlight of your trip to Marrakech and i would recomend this to everyone who comes the city.
not as many beggars since our last visit. the touts and trained monkeys grabbing me were a bit off putting but still an amazing place
A must-see. The atmosphere is great especially after dark but be prepared to politely reject the approaches of souvenir sellers, directions providers and other interruptions.

Touristy, yes...but oh so good!. A good place to stroll and soak up the sights. We ate at a street stall, although we were a bit worried about catching something...we didn't. The vendor gave us the "tourist rate" for the food...but it was not a lot to begin with so we let it pass.
chaos!. but wonderful chaos! so many things to see and eat!

a maze nice to get lost into. the medina is a nice stroll to take. It seemed slightly less crowded in the morning. Stop and sip a mint tea at the roof top terrasse of "cafe des epices", at place des épices (spices square), to have a nice view of the koutoubia mosque.
Dirty. What I expected really. dirty, smelly in places , twice saw men peeing in road.

mayhem. the medina is the main attraction for the city and rightly so. the only thing to be careful about is the mopeds. they ride up the streets flat out so beware if you are a bit unsteady on your pins

Chaotic old market ! Love it!. I love the medina of Marrakech even some people would find it too turistic. Marrakech has been turistic for a very very long time as it was one of the spots for the trade trail from Asia to europe. Still used by Moroccan for shopping you will find the best gifts and souvenirs you can ever think of! Leather bags, suitcases, belts, lamps, glass lamps, jilabbas, drums, wallets, ceramic plates, and counting! Get lost in the souqs and use the sun or the mosques as reference. You can also save a couple of dirhams and the kids will help you to get around but dont encourage such actions with the kids as they get used to the easy money! get your bargain going in the market!

Busy and good to people watch or shop. Easy to walk round - didnt get pestered - I would recommend to go with a guide and then go alone - during day snake charmers and monketys at night entertainers and food restaurants

Exotic chaos!. Be prepared for the noise, colour, excitement and general chaos of the entertainers and vendors - including snake charmers, monkeys, henna girls, food sellers, music players, moped riders, horse and coaches, tourists and locals. A 'must do' if you are visiting Marrakech!

A MUST SEE!. This is Marrakech--OLD, EXOTIC, SNAKE CHARMERS, FOOD STALLS, HAGGLING IN THE SOUKS, AND ON AND ON AND ON!!! I loved the main square within, Jemaa el Fna and the souks best of all...No need to go anywhere else in Marrakech!

Central side. This area of Marrakech is where we stayed and is definitely the best part of the city. It is so lively and much more in keeping with old Marrakech than the New City which is very much more 'tourist focused' and also expensive!
A number of surprises. Important is to walk inside Medina sometimes without directions, discovering continous surprises like refined shops, people, artisans, doors and tunnels.
