Manic. Get a good guide to show you where to go and what to avoid. Be ready for the dreadful diesel fumes and enjoy the obligatory haggling in the souks

Fantastic experience. Not to be missed - it's another world. It's like stepping back in time to something that existed in the middle ages. The square comes to life as the sun goes down - the drums, the snake charmers, the food stalls and the call to prayer from the mosque makes it an unique experience.

Chaos, colourful and crazy!. So much fun, so much going on. Great at both night and daytime, although fun as the sun sets and you see the transformation. If you go to Marrakech you must visit the Medina!
beware. beware the guides the are very persistant and demand payment for anything they do wether you want it or not just say no walk on and ignore them do not let them ruin a great day out
Wow. We called this the 'mad market' as it was wow, the noise, the scenes where just fab.
Mystical!. You will just want to buy, buy, buy!!! So many things to look at. Just brilliant.

Chaos at a high level - but exciting!. If you go to Marrakech, you must visit this market. In fact, if you go to Marrakech, you will very soon end up in this market, whether you like it or not. But believe me, it is well worth visiting. My advice is that you have plenty of time because you'll need it! Try to bargain and try your chances. I am amazed at all the things that are for sale in this market.

It's the only place to stay in Marrakesh.. The new hotels outside the medina are soulless. The medina is the heart of marrakesh and has acommodation to suit every pocket. Nor are there any great tourist attractions outside the medina.

i stayed in side the medina. its a colourfull sight exciting and so busy, you do have to watch the motor cycle its like warrens inside the narror roads and a stream of push carts,motorbikes donkreys and horse and carts selling fruit,clothing. theres monkey, snake charmers, ladies who want to put hennan up your arms and hands you have to be quick to not let them do it. in the eve its packet, there a very good restaurant there with belly dancers not exspencive, lots of stalls sellin dates andand other fruits, fresh oranges juice cost about30pence, you can eat here on stalls, snails /grilled kebabs and terrines,(stewes)

definitely the place to stay !. There are many places to stay in Marrakesh (Palm grove area, Hivernage area, ...) but the only place that really allows you to live Marrakesh from the inside is the medina quarter (historical center).The most interesting place is the world famous Jamaa El Fna square and if you get there at night the best to have dinner is restaurant "Riad Monceau". Best Moroccan restaurant in town ! We had a fab dinner there !

Really interesting. We visited the souks once, just to see, as we had done most of our shopping at the Berber markets. It was an experience but I did find that after a while, the hissing and grabbing was too much and we had to be a little bit rude while we were trying to get out. I found some traders comments inappropriate and am wondering if you should even bother covering up as I did not see others being harrassed in the same way (I had face and hands on show only!)

Mad but brilliant. It's like going back in time walking down the narrow streets of the souks closely followed by mopeds and mules, didn't feel intimitated the people I thought were really kind and helpful, our trip to the Atlas mountains was breathtaking
The Soul of Marrakech.. A "must do and see." Feel the real Marrakech, bustling by day and very sensual and mysterious by night.
Not an awful lot to see :(. Souks were better for shopping but worth going to see the daily lives of locals as they go about their day to day duties.

Not my cup of mint tea. I don't get the idea of viewing poverty and deprivation as a tourist idea. I wouldn't visit favelas or townships - but if I did I doubt if I would see animals being killed in plain view.
medina rulez. if you go to marrakech, choose a hotel in the medina! it is really worth it! you discover "Secret gardens" behind very simple doors. Go explore it and relax!

So much to see. The medina is really a great place. It is so different than anything I am used to seeing, The walkways are old and narrow, at times and the shops change like a roll of film spinning in front of you. Each step takes you to a different smell, sound, or beautiful merchandise. From a shoppers point of view, this is the best chaos ever.
hustle bustle. Not my cup of tea - to many people, not enough space - I get enough of that commuting in London. Would have been different if I wanted to by a rug or other homeware.

Have an organised guide, the locals will try and get you lost on purpose to make money out of directing you.. Do not get lost as you will be ripped off, make sure you have an organised tour, you will be shown the wrong direction so that you become desperate so that you pay someone to show you the right way.
Frenetic!. Ace, colours, smells, characters, sights, suprises, monkey's, snake's, foods, people...you name it, you'll find it here!

Demands for money overwhelming. The medina and the main square are definitely worth visiting, fascinating place with a rich heritage. I didn't mind the constant bustle, sounds and smells. In fact, that added to the fascination and interest of the place.Unfortunately it is deeply marred by the constant demands for your money. It's not just the regular hawking and demands I've found at any place that is a tourist destination in a developing nation. That is expected when the differential between the wealth of the visitors and the residents is large. For that matter, there are tourist traps and demands for tourists' money everywhere in the world, no matter the nation.But Marrakech felt like it added a new dimension to this. Perhaps it was aggravated by the fact we were still jet lagged, or that Marrakech is not a quiet place, but let me recount a few experiences:* at one point we were lost (well, several points) and were quickly approached by some older kids to help us find our way. We already knew that these weren't purely friendly 'out of the goodness of their heart' offers of help, that a 'tip' would be expected. The first time a teenage boy spent about 5 minutes helping us find a restaurant. We gave them 50 dirhams (about the equivalent of 6 US dollars) which I thought was quite generous, and he demanded more. Not just simple demanded more, but insisted on it all the way into the restaurant. If this was a one-off kind of experience, I would have just written it off, but it wasn't. The three times we were offered directional help and took it, we gave them anywhere from 5-10 dollars for their trouble and each time were obnoxiously pressured to give more.* when in the main square we stopped to listen to some music being played. My husband, I and our daughter found it interesting. As would be expected any where in the world, some men came with plates for donations. We had been there only a couple minutes and were planning to spend some time walking around, so I gave 50 dirham. They were obnoxious on insisting on more, so I gave them 20 more (total of about 8-9 dollars). That did not placate them. The insistence became so exhausting, we left. Unfortunately, every where we stopped on the square was the same experience. It completely marred the experience of the square for us and we left disappointed. We were more than wiling to contribute monetarily to entertainers, even generously, but when the monetary transaction becomes the main experience, I'd rather not experience it. We never went back to the square.These experiences repeated themselves over and over in Marrakech and it colored the entire experience.THis is not to say there weren't highlights. Several shop owners were delightful and were fun to talk to and bargain with. Our riad was absolutely wonderful and the tour the riad owner gave us as part of our stay was very interesting and fun. Some of the sights were fascinating.

Atmospheric. Exiting and atmospheric. Some of the Medina looks as if you have stepped back in time 2 thousand years. Architecture fantastic. if you are a shopper then you will be in paradise. Great for a good haggle when you can pick up amazing bargains. Beware though, they see a tourist and see £ signs. We are backpackers so we didn't appear to be flush :)

Medina Mystique. Loved the architecture, hustle and bustle. Disliked the hassle from young boys trying to 'guide' you despite the fact you know the way!! They are however easy to shake off if you are firm
nice market to visit. loved it all specialy the market and the old city

The Square. The old school/college was very interesting and as the dusk came so did the main square come to life. The night time is probably best for the square after an afternoon in the historic sights.

You have not seen Marrakech, if you have not been here!. The Medina was the pulse of Marrakech. One of the few touristy places that is very touristy and one still enjoys it. I went to Medina around sunset and could see the transformation from light to darkness, to light again, and it was brilliant. Some of the music being played in the square was lovely. The souq (market) was colorful and seemed to have something for everyone. The food in the stalls was good and the orange juice simply out of the world.After our shopping we visited one of the roof top cafes which provided an amazing view of the square, a great place to chill out and take pictures.

Good to experience once..but NEVER to return!. I had always wanted to visit Marrakech and was extremily excited about walking around the Souks and trying out the food. I expected it to be slightly run down and not the cleanest place on earth...but I hoped it would be an interesting experience and nice to walk around...boy was I mistaken!!!! Firstly the souk was the BIGGEST RIP-OFF tourst trap you could ever dream of entering. You get non-stop hassle and you can't look at anything without being pounced upon. They charge disgraceful amounts for things you can find a fraction of the price in the UK, and if you dare look at something and not buy it in these barbarian's shops they will literally call you stupid, tell you that your ''husband needs viagra'' and hurl abuse at you. In addition to being pounced upon you have to try and avoid getting run over by bikes constantely as they are racing up and down the narrow roads (which should and look like they should be pedestrianised). The streets are filthy and smell awful. And as for the food stalls, the people operating them look like they have not had a bath in weeks and there are flies crawling all over the food they sell, and they pick it up with their unclean hands. We would not eat anything from the roadside and even finding cafe's or restaurants that looked clean was like searching for a needle in a haystack. NOTHING is priced, not even water from the kiosks and they charge you what they feel like wherever you go and you cannot even bring out your wallet to buy anything without a peasant behind you holding out their hand for money.Next to no-one speaks English and the people here are the WORST I have ever encountered in all my travels (and I have been to many places). TRUST NO ONE. They are all scroungers and out to get your money....even something as innocent as asking someone the way when you are lost will cost you. They will offer to show you then ask you to pay them, so refuse any of their so called ''help'' at all costs. They also approach you if you are looking lost to try and show you the way so they can take your money. Despite all these negativities I would say that I am glad I experienced it, but 5 days was way too much and drove us mad. My fiance and I glad we have been there, but we will never go again (and I have never been so happy to return the gloomy UK). Visiting such a place makes you appreciate the ''normal'' Europeon countries and I will say, beautiful countries such as Greece are mis-understood - people avoid going there as they believe it is 'expensive'.....but when you are there things are priced, you get charged the same price as the Greeks, you can walk in peace without getting hassle or called names, there are plenty of clean cafe's and restaurants as the people there have standards and are honest civilized beings. Marrakech charges its TOURISTS as much as Greece and Italy would charge, so it may be a country with a bad economy - but they make up for it by ripping us off everywhere we go and treating tourists like idiots.
Beautiful!. A trip to Marrakech isn't complete without a walk through the Medina. There are so many beautiful details to capture through the lense of your camera. Enjoy!
best way to experience old Marrakech. Loved the atmosphere and antiquity, the peace and mystery

Overly Aggressive Vendors and Locals Hounding Tourists. We REALLY did not like how aggressive the vendors and locals were toward tourists. We felt that Fes was much more enjoyable. Marrakesh feels like a battlefield and exhausting from fending off men trying to lead you in the wrong direction, insisting on money for leading you in the wrong direction, and vendors that never give you the option to peruse merchandise. Not be mention cars, motorbikes, mules, and pedestrians all trying to squeeze in the little alleys.
Such a unique place. The medina has a lovely honest and authentic feel, like much of Marrakech. You don't get the feeling that any of it is a tourist trap- it's just interesting to see.
A place to see.... ...hear, smell, taste and experience! next time maybe with a walking guide for a while
Crazy place!. If you like hoards of people from all round the world, mopeds, donkeys, carts, trucks, snakes, monkeys and horses all vying for space then you will not be disappointed!
Bedlam at its most interesting. This is exactly what you read in the books and on Trip Advisor. Hectic, busy, noisy, muddy (if raining) all facinating to watch, listen to and smell

Interesting, if intimidating. The medina was interesting. It's an experience walking around, getting a bit lost, and exploring the nooks and crannies of the medina. The medina of Marrakesh is big enough to be interesting, but small enough it's not scary to get a bit lost. The sellers here are a bit more aggressive than I experience elsewhere in Morocco. They can easily be ignored, but be prepared if you're only with women, as the male sellers can be a bit rude.
Old City!. Loved the fountains, the smell of spices, and small markets.
A great experience. But dont get ripped off - really do bargain - its easy and they like it.
Go Visit. Well worth a visit it was so peacefull. The meuseum you can give a miss but the gardens lovely
Medina. Something you will not see anywhere else, great for soaking up the atmosphere, people watching and relaxing over a coffee.
Bargain hunters paradise. Be prepared to haggle - don't be put off. The souks are great and the locals friendly.
Fascinating, vital place. The Medina makes you think you are part of the One Thousand and One nighs, from snake charmers, to beggars, to food vendors, to souks, the place is full of life and colorful
Don't take your money with you!. Persistent haggling and no real idea about the worth of things can make this daunting.
Buy Buy Buy. You can buy anything and everything here. just be prepared to haggle. Don't pay more than you want to for anything, just walk away. Have fun and smile.
Great fun. Brilliant place to explore and to see local craftsmen at work.
very busy. an awful lot of the same goods but a huge variation on the prices asked, don't be afraid of being cheeky with your counter offers.

madina. this place is a must see but the constant hassle from 'guides' and stall traders is tiring.
dont get caught by the henna painters or the snake charmers could cost you a lot of money
Exciting. Mayhem all the way, busy, frantic exciting a real hit on all your senses

Loved it!. The medina was the whole reason we went to Marrakesh. Lots of action, sights and sounds. Wished they banned the scooters and cars though like Fes. Got hit twice by scooters. Have dinner in the square at night.
Crazy but Cool. A must see experience if you visit Marrakech, best time 8-10pm
Killer Mopeds!. As with the square...watch out for the killer mopeds!!

Not as big as you would think. Some areas are a little emelly, but you are in a main town.
Easy to walk around and safe. A little while before you become orientated and work out where you are going, but someone is always on hand to point you in the right direction - for a few coins

Experience a different era. Visiting the Medina of Marrakech is a truly unique experience. It's like travelling back in time to a different era. It's well worth visiting, we spent hours every day of our stay just walking, taking pictures, shopping here and there, having a quick bite or a coffee.

Awesome - spend a few hours getting lost. Amazing place to walk around; like a time warp back in time.Start at the square and go north through the souks. They reminded me a lot of the Grand Bazzar in Istanbul. Go north to the madras, then go east to visit a tannery (seperate Trip Advisor section on this). Go back to the madras and this time go northwest to the Bel Abbes mosque. Go even ruther north to the top where the "locals" do their business. It is gritty up there, but very authentic. If you get lost, kids will lead you out :) I gave them 10 dirhams for this.And to the south of the square, see the tombs, and the 2 palaces. Quite a lot to see. Give it 2 days if you want to take your time. And make sure to see the square both during the day and at night.

A unique experience. The Medina fully justifies and deserves it's place as a world heritage site because it's like nothing you will have seen before. The souks are mazes deeper than you can imagine serving all kinds of shopping desires and food tastes and it really gives you a sense of life in the old city and how hard the craftsmen work to produce the items you see for sale in the souks.

The Berber Market. This market is located in a small square en route to Djemma el Fna from the north (off Rahba Kedima). Unusually for the souks it is not a covered market and is called in French " La Criee Berbere". We were told that slave auctions (sub-Saharan Africans traded by Arab slavers) occured here until the French occupation in 1912.Nowadays it a busy spot with Berber women selling a variety of goods, especially embroidered sheeps' wool hats and other mountain clothing (from the High Atlas). Also rugs, carpets and kilims. It's not frenetic and there is no "hard sell". Bordering the square are apothecaries (very wary of photographs) and various other shops including one selling land snails from plastic basins - which the molluscs are continually escaping! Spice and herb shops add to the general colours and aromas of this market. There is also a small cafe with roof terrace.

Hard to believe!!!!. I'm not going to write much as the reviews say most of it. What I will say is if your from a busy city like myself you really havent seen anything until you have been to the medina and souks. And if you miss is it you will have missed something in your life that you would never have forgotten. This place is a marvel of madness

Fast and furious.. The medina of Marrakech is very large and sprawling and you will get lost, use the central market place square (Djemma el fna) as the point from which to navigate to and from. The square is much less claustrophobic with many established restaurants and banks with cash point machines (once you insert your card you are offered instructions in English)If you do get lost there will be no limit to the number of helpful people happy to show you the way back to the square but they will expect a "gift"If you go to visit any of the tanneries, you will also be expected to provide gifts and you might have to endure a visit to a leather shop where you will be encouraged to part with some money.Haggle hard in the medina but do not get angry, if you cannot agree a price, do not worry, just try your luck in the next shop.The place really comes alive as it starts to get dark with lots of mobile restaurants and orange juice stalls, prices are reasonable with very little variation between stalls, the banter between the mobile restaurants and tourists is very good.Watch the taxi's, they don't like to use their meters and will ask for inflated prices, feel free to haggle the price down, walk away from the square towards the tourist information offices and the taxi prices charged become more competitive.From Marrakech you can take a tour into the desert, usually with an overnight stay, although described as fully inclusive you will have to pay for lunch, drinks and the services of guides at sites of interest, if you are including a trek into the desert on a camel make sure you take a scarf or head cover, the camel treks often start from the agency office in Zagora where the staff will pressure you into buying a head scarf at an inflated price (be forewarned, take your own) All in all, it can be a culture shock but it remains a safe place for tourists.

Simply AWESOME. This place is an experience for all your senses. The sights and smells are overwhelming! It's crazy, exotic, unusual, and there's something interesting around every corner. You can find everything in this medina - beautiful tapestries, rugs, music instruments, leather, metal work, spices, produce, meat, restaurants - and so much more. I was here 3 days and I still don't think I saw everything! The medina of Marrakech has got to be one of the best places on earth!

Stunning but exhausting. The medina and it's souks are amazing but be prepared! Everyone will try to sell you something and there are NO fixed prices. There are amazing items and deals to be had but I would recommend reading up on bargaining techniques before hitting the shops. One good suggestion I wish I had taken: get a guided tour of the souks (most riads offer this) and just window shop to see what you like, where to buy it, and decide what you want to pay. Other than shopping, be culturally prepared. We were there during Ramadan so westerners were the only ones eating and drinking while the sun was up which means some places were closed or only open after sundown. Also, the roads of the medina are busy and dirty (despite the regular upkeep of business owners) and some sights may shock the unprepared westerner (an incredible number of street cats, many beggars including mothers with children, etc). However there is an energy and a beauty to the medina that is very much worth seeing. Don't worry about hitting all the attractions and just soak it in. Doing some research before going will definitely make your visit more pleasant.

Wearing a different lens. The title of this review reflects what I think is necessary for westerners when they visit the Medina of Marrakesh. Your senses will be assaulted with sights,sounds, smells, and images to which you are not accustomed;but to fully enjoy the medina you must leave the known and wander in the unknown.The medina is rich in history. Read before you come to fully understand where you are standing. My personal recommendation is that you need more than a day. I spent a total of six days broken up into three and three with a trip to Essauoria in the middle. DJemaa el fan is an experience unto itself and to be truthful where I spent a great deal of time. Go to the Souks it is a shoppers haven but be ready to bargain - it is what is expected. It would be rude not to haggle. Know that there are areas for Babouche, Dates, Olives, Leather, Silver, and the list goes on. Make sure you grab a glass of orange juice from a vendor- nothing like you've ever tasted - delicious ! It is important to go during the day as well as go in the evening. The place comes alive you feel somewhat transported back in time. If you are part of a tour or you have hired a guide, I am sure he will direct you to the best spots. If you are solo - then wander, get lost, there is a way out !I visited during the month of July - a bit toasty but I strongly recommend bringing wicking, linen, or cotton clothes. Leave Polly at home as synthetics will make you feel as though you are wearing an oven. Flip flops are fine at home but for the amount of walking.. you will do much better in a good pair of Keens, walkers, or sneakers; leave the cute shoes at home. Exchange your money at the airport makes sure you know the exchange rates. If you don't like crowds do djemaa in the day- at night you get thousands versus what I perceived to behundreds in daylight. You will see cats,cats,cats every where - it is what it is. You will also be approached by adults children often late at night selling tissues or asking for alms. Follow your instincts. Often I would just buy a meal rather than give money if hunger was the issue. But don't judge or compare- just accept that this is what it is there.Do buy some Babouche your feet will never forget you. Learn some basic Arabic and Berber phrases it goes a long way in getting what you want or need. Make sure you have travel size TP and wipes. There are restrooms to be had but finding them is an adventure unto itself and when you do those items will come in handy. And lastly, have fun and enjoy.You will be forever changed if you allow yourself to experience the Medina of Marrakesh.

Most interesting medina in the world. Marrakech Medina is a real medina. Still look the same it was (almost). I was born there and grew up listening everynight to Gnawa drummers and folk music at my grandparent house which is 3 min walk from the square (Jamaa El Fnaa). I will always love Marrakech and hope I will have a Riyad there when I retire!

Safe and fun. If you go to Morocco you have to experience the shopping at the Medina, and this one is a great example. Hundred of small streets to get lost, safe and great shopping opportunities: food, clothes, shoes, souvenirs, antiques...and mandatory to bargain.Just chill out and enjoy the real taste of Morocco!

Amazing sites, smells and sounds. We live in Marrakech and visit the medina regularly. Sometimes I go alone and sometimes with the 2 year old and 4 year old. When going with children, I believe it is easier and safer if they are in the stroller. Wear comfortable shoes that you don't mind getting wet, some areas inside have puddles from the shopkeepers cleaning, especially in the morning. Parking is difficult if you don't have a driver or come by taxi. If you have a car, you may want to get a driver or take a taxi when you visit. So many amazing shops. You just need to be patient and get through all the junk. If a door is closed, knock and attempt to enter. These are normally the nice surprises. Lunch at Cafe Epices or Kosy Bar.

No Bargins Here.... We visited the medina twice in our visit its intresting to look at but not to buy, My friend picked up a bangle one that you could buy in primark for £2 and was advised that it would be 4500 di that about £45 it was made of tin!! when we advised we would only pay 50 (£5 which is still a rip off) he told us we were crazy and to leave, after trying to get a bargin on alot of over items and being told we were crazy for the price we offred we gave up.Here are some of our crazy offers and some of there even more carzy pricesBags the ones you can get down the market for £5-£10 there price £65Belly dancing skirts which are £5 in england at my zumba class, there price £45And dont think walking away will make them drop the price because it dosnt.So unless you like having your picture taken with monkeys or snakes or you really want some henna done i wouldnt bother.Quick note i was in the medina telling my friend about the henna ladies and dont give them your hand wise there mark it and your have to pay them, and as if buy magic one appered and tryed to jab her hand. We did find that funny and wrong!!! dont let them get you!!The last photo i have posted is from the balcony of the resturant that got bombed two weeks ago!!!

if you were not born there, you won't find your way. While most tourists see only a small section of the Medina from the square Jamaa al Fna through the Soukhs to the Qoubba, Medersa Bin Youssef, etc., if you leave the "beaten track" you will get into the real medina, a convoluted labyrinthine set of open or half-covered alleys, no street names, corners every 10 meters, shops washing their floors onto the street selling things at Moroccan prices. If you ask the way, you are likely to be doggedly tagged by a presumably well-meaning resident who does not speak English, hardly any French, so that he will most likely not take you to where you want to be. If you realise you are being led around in circles, look for anything which resembles a pharmacy and ask the way there. Cars are too wide for the alleys so in the areas where there are shops and shoppers, you can get lots of two-stroke mopeds creating a pungent stench. In these ares you will also find lots of bicycles.The residential areas are by contrast often eerily quiet and much cleaner.The wider streets allow cars to mix with the pedestrians, bicycles, mopeds, donkey carts and more.If you do not like getting lost in a maze, don't leave the "beaten track"

All a bit meh, sorry. Having just spent a week in Marrakech, I was a little underwhelmed by the Medina. It was mildly diverting, but nothing as wondrous as I was led to believe. All the hustlers get on your nerves very quickly. That said one guy imitated and expanded upon my accent to hilarious effect - "There's nothing of you, you need a good meal guvnor, innit" etc etc lawl.As it was I went to the tried and trusted stall 1, which was excellent as everyone says. From ordering to paying I was there 10 minutes - now that's what I call fast food! (I had a starter and a tajine). The downsides are widely known - monkeys on leashes, being assaulted by blokes bearing snakes, henna tattooists. I found it more annoying during the day actually. It's interesting to observe from a higher vantage point, but the whiny music grates as much as the England football supporters band blaring out 'come on England' on trumpets every 2 minutes. You do get a sense of the history, but a diluted sense, as though it's somehow not authentic now, just a show for tourists.

Nothing you´ve seen before. Visiting or staying in the Medina is like going back in time. You will share the streets together with people, donkeys, horses, cars, buses and salesmen. It´s not a place you can do in a day. Just to walk there is an experience and every day has a new one.

A personal challenge on many different levels. This is a city that cannot be done in a day and does not revolve solely around the Souk's or the Jemaa el Fna, although fascinating. There is a lot more to see and experience in other areas of the Medina and some places outside. Be prepared for hassle, ignore unwanted attention, be confident and avoid hesitation. Don't be bullied into anything at the end of the day you are on holiday. Food:If venturing to the Jemaa el Fna at night hit the stalls. We would recommend choosing the ones that specialise in one particular food type and are frequented by locals rather than tourists. For example, there is a stall for just lentils and beans, another for slow cooked lamb (referred to as meat) another for sausages etc. etc. We preferred these over the mixed menu stalls and restaurants. Bread is automatically given at all eateries but anything else you need to order. You don't have to buy the water that can sometimes appear on the table without asking (that's if you don't open it). Café palias el Badia: was a good place to watch the Storks of the Kasbah. However if you order anything but a set menu you'll be treated with disdain. Café Che Chegrouni: Great views of the Jemaa el Fna, the best salad Mmorrocaine in town and extremely reasonable prices. We returned almost daily at varying times. See timings.Language:We found that although we paid reasonable prices to access the Medina's main attractions information had not been translated into English therefore we would recommend investing in a guide book.Security:A money belt is a good investment. Keep your valuables at your accommodation if secure. We met someone who had their passport pick pocketed whilst out in the Souk's around the time school's finished for the day. Timings:Early morning is a great time to wander the streets whilst people are setting up for the day and hassling is at a minimum. Lunchtime (1-2pm) is more subdued again. We found that waiters were more relaxed outside peak times. Friday's are quieter whereas Saturday's are manic, in fact the the weekend is manic full stop. Watch out for school closing times when you can suddenly find yourself in a sea of tiny people. Money:Don't be surprised if cash machines have run out of money on Monday morning in and around the Jemaa el Fna. There is a tendency for people to flit from Euro's to Dirhams whilst negotiating prices in the same sentence, so keep pace with what currency you are working with. Be aware of:People providing false information with regards to directions, opening times and other random stuff. One man appeared to offer us directions but led us to a taut. Another man went out of his way to tell us that the Jardin Majorelle was closed when it wasn't. We were also told but chose to ignore the advise that we were walking towards a dead end when we obviously weren't. Be aware of bored youths in the streets at night. Don't shake traders hands or accept anything, even “presents” or business cards unless you're prepared to buy their wares or services. Expect to pay for posed photos with anything ranging from Monkey's to orange sellers to wearing a Jellabah. We would recommend avoiding all, unless that's what you want. Keep your hands to yourself to avoid unwanted and aggressive Henna ladies grabbing your arms and keep pointing to a minimum to avoid attention. Attractions: After a week in Marrakech we would recommend The Palais Bahia:- Very pretty and calmThe Madersa Ben Youssef:- Fascinating place, beware of the faux guide within the complex who demands to see your ticket already shown at the entrance.The Musee de Marrakech: Calm place with an excellent Hammam, easily missed. The Musee de la Photograhie:- knowledgeable staff, great exhibition and amazing terrace for unparalleled view of the Medina and the Mountains. The Jardin Majorelle:- A walk from the Medina through the dull Gueliz, but worth it. Great use of colour and planting. Don't rush through it.The Kasbah:- A great alternative to the Jemaa el FnaMamounia:- Great to see how the other half lives when visiting Marrakech, dress smartly and approach confidently to gain access at main gate. Once in you will be treated as if you were a guest. Places to avoid:Le Comptoir; Possibly the worst food we have ever had....ever. Overpriced and overrated.

An assault on the senses. The medina of Marrakech really is an assault on all the senses, When you first enter the square you are overwhelmed by the colours, the sounds, and the smells. Then you enter the souks with their stalls and shops and the bikes and scooters all trying to fit into the maze of narrow streets. The best way to enjoy the souks is just to wander, to get lost you will always find a way out if not under your own steam but there will always be someone to help you for a few dirhans of course. Enjoy the banter with the stallholders, try bartering - most of the stallholders join in the game. Those that don't just walk away and don't look back.My only criticism is outside the medina at the general level of rubbish that is left around, it appears that there in not much pride in the city. I know it is a different culture and in a dry dusty climate it is difficult to avoid the dust but would it really be that difficult to at least clear up the litter. That said it should not stop you from going to Marrakech and enjoying it

Stimulates all your senses. How anyone can say Marrakech can be done in a day or that there is nothing much to see is incredible. There is so much that you could spend a week just soaking it all in. Sure you could "do" the main attractions in a couple of days if you rush round trying to squeeze it all in but you will never understand Marrakech or Morocco this way. Set out in the morning to see a couple of things, take your time, stop for coffee, sit on a cafe roof terrace and watch the herds of tour groups snake past. Once you get past the three day mark and can relax into it Marrakech becomes a very different place and the medina is at the heart of it. Get lost in the souks; someone will always point you back to the square (ask a shopkeeper if you don't want a "guide" to lead you). Visit the square both during the day and at night to experience the amazing contrast. Talk to the people living and working in the medina, have some fun, laugh with them, you can really get to know some of the culture if you just take the time.

crazy crazy crazy. where do you start? firstly i'll say i was a female solo traveller [over 40] and at no time did i feel threatened or uncomfortable. the square was clean and the souks also. yes you get a certain anount of hassle to buy but not aggressively. the souks meander forever and it's very easy to lose sense of direction but the store holders will point you to Le Place. life is fast and frantic or slow and relaxing; it's whatever you want it to be. escape into a side street cafe bar and get up on the roof to relax in peace or join in the bustle and hustle of the market along with the scooters, cycles and donkey carts. an amazing experience that you need to just absorb. i think those that are disappointed may just be the kind of person to enjoy Benidorm!!!

Marrakech can be done in a day. Hi,just came back from Marrakech and there wasn't much to do or see. Few advice=20dirhams to travel anywhere in Marrakech city. From the airport the taxis charge 150d that's extremely expensive but all the taxi drivers have alittle pack to rob us travellers,going back to airport cost me 50dirham. Jemm el fna the square is over rated,was expecting chaos but was ok,the souk is endless....think westend price....better to shop in agadir. Which was the next place I went....the beach is not sandy but full of peoples rubbish,the food was lovely....eat in le flore...AMAZING. Travelling in agadir 15dirhams anywhere. Went up the kasbah mountains for 50d, always travel in a petit taxi,the grand taxis are pay per seat!! Note:if u hate cats...be warned they are everywhere!!! Other than that I was really disappointed,was expecting so much more. Good points-wifi everywhere for people who can't live wivout technology. Sheesha places are rare n secretly done indoors- agadir- place called baghdad cafe and diner spectacles. Do not stay at the Meryam hotel...grand entrance but rooms r standard in Marrakech. Hope I was helpful n not tooooo negative but that's just my opinion. Oh last thing brush up on ur French....everyone speaks it,soooo annoying. No1 knew English nor was the menu in English. I was French overdosed!!

Amazing experience!. If you like absolute mayhem then this is the place for you!The streets are very small and narrow and it is very very easy to get lost in the crowd but boy is it fun!! It is absolutely crazy with all the people doubled up with motorbikes whizzing through the crowds, people pulling carts through with allsorts piled on, everyone shouting, the colours. Its madness. The Moroccans are very friendly people and you will get asked in most places to have Moroccan tea while they dress you up in their traditional Moroccan clothing. If you dont want to do this (as there are only so many times a day you can sit in and drink Moroccan tea) you can politely decline. You can get such a variety of items from the markets but remember, never pay more than half their initial asking price. Also shop around first, you can always go back (if you find the place). If you seem interested in an object but are walking about their shop, they will more often than not keep lowering the price - great way to bargain them down :)Be wary of those asking you to buy Marajuana though. The hotel manager told us that most of the time the police are in on it and if you buy, they soon swoop in on you. SO be warned. They kept pestering my younger brother and friend, following them through the streets but you just have to be very firm.The streets are also quite dirty but I still managed to wear flip flops without getting my feet dirty.Also, be wary of buying fresh fruit. So many times i seen the fruit on the floor of the market and they would just pick it up off the floor and place it back into the fruit basket - YUCK!!!But a great and hectic experiance had by all and I cant wait to return next year!

wow.. Nothing will prepare you for this, weird, wonderful, annoying, fasinating. Watc out for the begging children, their grasp of english will amaze you. One wee boy about 5 years old shouted *uck you to my husband when he gave the sister the money and never had any change left to give him as she wouldn't share her's Ladies handbag gallore not cheap though they wanted 1 hundred euros for a med sized bag. I was terrified of snake so was wary about going to the medina, but all the snake charmers and monkeys are in the middle of the square so don't panick . Sit up stairs in the cafes and watch it all you will be amazed what you can get there. One man was selling a baby eagle, he tried to sell my husband leaches and a scorpian. Watch you wallet and bags as the children are the best pick-pockets in the world. Food in our hotel was'nt good but Mc Donalds in marakech city centre was good. Hope this has helped.
enchanting. My boyfriend and I had a tour through the medina and the souks and were amazed. The tiny alleys and tiny shops. Yet crammed with some many amazing things. Words cannot describe!

Five Days in the Medina .... It was an amazing adventure, offering a glimpse into Arab and Muslim culture. Staying in the Medina was an intense experience, tending toward sensory overload. The hustle, hubbub, and heat; the hassle from hopeful guides and shopkeepers eager to sell, the dodging of potholes, donkey -pulled carts, horse-drawn carriages, mopeds, bicycles, taxis and fellow pedestrians along the maze of narrow, winding passageways. The crumbling walls, Jemaa el Fna Square, the colorful souks, the mosques, ancient ruins ... The clatter, the clamor. Definitely not relaxing! Then, venture into one of the numerous riads within the medina to encounter the beauty of the interior courtyards and rooftop terraces. (We stayed in two.) The peace and quiet of the riads offered welcome respite from the jostle and tumult outside. In the riads and restaurants, there was the opportunity to sample the delicious mint tea, Moroccan pastries, Moroccan tagine cooking, and other specialties. A number of sites on the internet suggest that travel in Morocco is cheap. We did not find this to be the case. In the riads of the Medina, we were paying as much or more for lodging and food as we do in the United States and in Europe. (We were also surprised to find that most of the riads and restaurants were owned and managed by Europeans, while service personnel were invariably native Moroccans.) Photos and narrative don't adequately prepare a visitor for the reality of this ancient Muslim city. Was it a worthwhile experience? Definitely! However, for us, three days would have been enough.

Medina offers a wonderful and unique experience. Wow, what more can I say, the medina of Marrakech is a real must for all visitors to Morocco. I have been to several other Moroccan cities, but none compare with this one. The streets leading up to Djemma el Fna offer excellent stalls with a good variety, as long as you enjoy bartering, you will come away with some great souvenirs. The square itself is action packed, where ever you look there is something happening - great smells, sounds and action.I travelled with children and would recommend that you ensure they stay close by (or if young on straps), whilst not at all threatening, it is the sheer number of alley ways, stalls, etc that mean it could be easy to loose one. We always ensured ours had a card on them with our mobile phone numbers and details of Riad Africa where we stayed. The Riad was an ideal 10 min or so walk away giving peace and quiet yet good access to the medina.

Totally mad dirty and filthy.. I hated it but do see what some people get out of it apart from stomach cramps and lots of trips to the toilet. The people despise us, you can tell the way they look at you. You cant trust anyone, they just want to scam you. The food is dirty and will probably make you ill. But when you come back to your lovely oasis of a hotel from slumming it in all the madness out there. Wow it just makes your head spin. The hotels are cheap really cheap and you can get good value for money in this country. The hotels are far better than anywhere else I have been for the money. Lots of guests just stay at the hotel and hardly venture out, and if your into that its a great value place to go.The market is full of tourists looking but not buying much. I didnt like it I feel sorry for these poor people. The goods on sale were awefully nasty made for touist rubbish that isnt worth taking home. If you want to go and gawk at poor people making a spectacle of themselves for a few pennys like at a freak show then this is for you.

You have to go. It's a different there. I read loads of reviews of Marrakesh before I went but found when I was there they were all wrong. We were two girls and we had a really good time with no hassle. Tip 1: Don't be scared of them and treat them like people! Tip 2: When asking for directions don't ask a child or shop keeper. Ask a local.Tip 3: When talking to locals speak as much french as you can! Tip 4: For girls if guys talk to you ask them for a few tips like how much things cost or where things are. And if you don't like them following, tell them politely you are going where else now with your friends or whatever.Tip 5: Girls create a husbandYeah some people get hassle but thats because they give the locals hassle. Don't and you'll be fine. I really felt safe in marrakesh. When buying things in the Medina watch out for pick pockets of course and try haggling. It can be quite fun. Keep in mind that you shouldn''t pay more than 50 or 60 dirhams for shoes or 100dirhams for a bag. Things are cheap don't believe them when they start going on about asda price and primark. They are proud people so if you upset them they will tell you directly to get out their shop. And most of the shop keepers speak french and bits of spanish and english. Theyre alll so friendly. But it's really handy to use french if you know it or can get a few places and or a map so you can point out where your going. We were in Morocco for 3 nights. From Marrakesh we went to Rabat and then Casablanca and had a returning flight from there. Explore using the train it's safe and reliable. There are over night trains (we didn't take them) which you can go to other places and safe money on nights. You can check time tables and prices here to plan your trip but you have to get tickets at the station:http://www.oncf.ma/index_en.aspx I was happy with my days. I saw everything I wanted to see. If your with young children I wouldn't recommend such a quick trip. Good luck! :-)

A full 4 days of stress. My partner very nicely decided to take me on a nice romantic weeks holiday.He was thinking of Rome,I however had always always wanted to visit Marrakech so I managed to persuade him.After four long weeks of searching and reading review after review I was full of excitement to set off on what I imagined would be a magical,romantic adventure for our first holiday together.How very very wrong I was.I had decided that if we were doing Marrakech then I'd want to see the real Marrakech.The idea of a riad in the medina was where I wanted us to be.Our arrival was a bit scary but I tried not to let the filthy streets and chaos put me off.The owner of our Riad seemed very nice and showed us the general direction of Djemaa el Fna which turned out to be about a ten min walk away.It was all very exciting ...for about an hour We were out for 3 hours ,three hours of my life I'd Never want to get backi had been prior warned by my sister who had visited a year before for a day about the hassle tourists get.She'd already warned me about the typicle tourist traps so I felt somewhat prepared not confident but prepared.I managed to dodge quite a few burka clad ladies offering henna tattoos and felt accomplished that I'd made it out unscathed however we decided to eat at one of the stalls in the la place and thats where the nightmare starts.Kids begging hords of them ,not one or two but ten....or more.The worst thing I could've done looking back on things is even just talk to them.So to cut a long storey short.....The kids are there to set you up to get fleeced ,a shame yes but sadly thats how it was.one small boy did off with 200 dirhams . I now know you never ever give anyone a large note for anything....he was selling me a leather camel ,so as im trying to get my money back whilst eating food I turn around and there's a lady who has tattooed half of my arm.We get into a bit of a conflab she DEMANDS 800 dirhams from me ....for the tattoo I never wanted and when I've had more than i can take I give her 50 and decide its time to leave........15 mins later this woman is still following and pestering me for more before leaving with her 50 dirhamSo we're back in the souk trying to find our way back after a shakey start to our holiday.I'm a bit unsettled by my double rip off but trying to keep up good spirits and when we come to a bit of a crossroads in the path back to our riad and are undecided which path to take some much appreciated friendly local lads come to give us some directions.After about 20 mins of walking down and around the most dismal alleys (one of which had a local man beating up his wife) i get the impression we're being taken on a bit of a dodgy tour of the medina and also a lend of.By this time I am very upset my partner is feeling very responsible and quite intimidated.30-40 mins later we find our riad.The very friendly local lads very quickly turn very nasty and DEMAND! 300 dirhams =the thick end of £30 for there services .We don't have the 300 to give them and offer them what we have ...they decline ,we go into our riad ,they bang and ring on the door shouting all the time for half an hour ............................................ 3 hours in Marrakech,to be honest,it realy did'nt get any better.We left on day 3 to go to Essaouira which was heaven in comparison. The sadest day was when we knew we had to leave and spend the last two nights back in the madness of MarrakechI know that my experience may be an unfortunate one ,maybe I had the worst luck.I have since read lots and lots of amazing reviews of Marrakech and I realy realy wish mine had been as lovely as others have found it but for me.........it realy was just DISMAL

Amazing!. I have always wanted to visit Marrakech and of course Djamaa el Fna so this was my 40th birthday present from my husband.I was not disappointed! I admit I did get a little fed up of the constant hassle from stall holders and kept getting comments like "hey you are Gavin and Stacey" (yes we are Welsh!!) which I found very amusing! I did get a little freaked by one guy as myself and my husband wandered down a few alleys (getting lost is all part of it and is fun!) and felt a little out of my comfort zone as he was trying to lead us to the tanneries (where I had no interest in going) and said he was taking us there for free and I needed to chill out (as I was getting a bit hacked off with him). My husband was cross with me for being rude to him but I did just get a bit nervous but I apologised to him and we went on our way with no problem.My advice is to completely relax as the people are lovely. We bought some scarves from one stall and the guy was the nicest, friendliest and funniest chap we had met, and we were not ripped off at all and haggling was really good fun (and he gave me a free keyring!!).All in all, the best experience ever and we can't wait to return - maybe for my 50th?!

Be on your toes at all times. Our first.... Be on your toes at all times. Our first hour in Morocco was in the Souks in the medina and it was full on! Be prepared and don't buy ANYTHING the first day!! Get used to the haggling and the average price of goods as lots of stores sell the same things.Although it might sometimes feel frightening we had no problems, some shopkeepers were VERY persistent though. A ferm but friendly approach worked fine.

very poor quarlity and over priced good. i was very excited about this trip we were constantly harassed i had read reviews on read advisor and was cautiouscoming out of our hotel on our way to the medina my husband was on his phone i noticed a man trying to get my attention he introduced himself to me by asking me if i recognized him as he worked in our hotel and that he was on his way home and would show us the way he then proceeded to take us down lots of alleyways saying all the time that we were not far by this time we knew that we were in a bad situation i was very frightenedand we offered him money to take us back to the square which he took and quickly disappearedi told the hotel who said that this happens all the time

Getting lost and hassled are part of the fun!. The medina is the ancient, walled, inner city of Marrakech. I've explored it on 2 different occasions over the past couple of years, and nothing has changed. It's composed of narrow, dark, winding alleyways and high, rose coloured, crumbling walls...Hoards of people, scooters, fluters, monkeys, donkeys, horses, hawkers, mockers, bicycles, shady characters, story tellers, potion sellers, snake charmers (who aren't very charming at all), stray cats, funny hats, henna ladies, suspect food stalls, bargains, jargons...and is the pulsing heart and soul of this 11th century city.Almost all the alleyways and trinket stalls look the same so it's very easy to get lost...sort of...Because in reality, you're not lost at all...You're in the medina! The "jewel" of this place is the wide-open Jemaa el Fna, which becomes a vast, smokey, open-air food market by night, surrounded by terraced cafes and restaurants, with the ever-present Koutoubia Mosque looming over the western edge.Behind almost every seemingly non-desript arched, wooden door is a small, luxurious palace called a "riad", but you'd never know it from the outside! Be prepared to be approached by faux guides and vendors trying to sell you everything from apples to zebra skins. You need to have your wits about you and enjoy a good adventure in order to enjoy this place. It's not for those looking for a relaxed, sheltered atmosphere.The intricate, gigantic archways display ancient Moorish architecture and mosaics, and you never quite know what may happen next! If you've ever been wanting to visit a place that Indiana Jones himself may have enjoyed searching for lost treasures in, then you need to go here to see for yourself.

what a fantastic place to visit. We stayed in the Kasbah itself and the Medina was wonderful, full of so many photos opportunities, colour and atmosphere. It felt like stepping onto an Indiana Jones film set! People are so friendly in Marrakech and we didn't feel at all uneasy when walking around after dark.

Old medina, absolutely vast, nice cultural experience rather than monuments. Morocco holds much more in terms of its cultural diversity then in monumental or architectural heritage. The pinacle of Moorish Art and Architecture is in Spain. Though there are definately some things to visit in Marrakech, namely: 1) Saadian Tombs, Baadi Palace, Bin Youssef Medressa and for muslims (as non-muslims not allowed in the following) Koutoubia Mosque, Kasbah Mosque, Qessain Mosque.What I love is to wander through the streets of the Medina away from the Souqs amidst the Donkey ridden streets, sample some sugar cane juice, and try to navigate narrow streets. At night you can wander endlessly around the square of Djamma Al Fanaa (Place of Transient Gathering) which offers some street performing entertainment but more importantly lots of people watching and delicious meals. I would particularly recomend Lamb Brain, Lamb head, and Moroccon snails for those that want to prove and test their culinary metal.

Jama Al-fna - experience the culture jazz. Jama Al-Fna is a magical place and the culture jazz will take you to an awe inspiring new dimension which will stay with you for the rest of your life. Start off with a horse carriage to the square which will set you in the right frame of mind as to what is to come : Acrobats, monkeys, snakes, musicians, lizards, tortoises , dancing, prancing ,horses and spices , haggling and buying which will captivate you and the children. The juice stalls and food stalls, the balcony restaurants, the hustle and bustle of traders and customers, the drumming, the smoke , the scents and smells. Things to see , things to buy , some expensive , some cheap but make sure you control your money as you can easily get carried away. No trip to Morocco is complete without a visit to this magical "square". Take a trip to the adjacent souks and haggle to your hearts content and remember they have two prices one for locals and one for tourists which are ten times higher. Some warnings, don't have black hena applied to your body as some are contaminated and can affect your health. Also if you take photos they expect money and its best to negotiate a price before rather than afterwards. The natives are very friendly people but remember tourism is their livelihood and some of them can get a bit greedy. The police are extremely friendly. Visit it during the day and night as its character changes completely at night.

Activities to do in Marrakech. Just back from our trip to Marrakech where we had a wonderful half-day trip to the Atlas organized by Isango. The guide was friendly (and happy to speak French for once!) and customized some of the attraction for us (we visited a "berbere"house on our request). Since we did not encountered any travel agency while in the Medina (we slept in a Riad), we were very happy to have booked in advance with Isango.

What they don't tell you!. Just back from Marrakech and although it was an amazing experience we found the haggling a bit much at times! Trying to get a taxi driver to take you to where you want to go almost impossible. Always agree a price first and be prepared to haggle over it. They almost always insist on taking you to the "Pharmacy" first - although having said that it was interesting! Taxi driver waited outside for us and then insisted on taking us to a "general market" - not the Medina. We gave up in the end and paid him but he followed us insisting on us going inside - we just had to ignore him and he eventually gave up. Sweet boy appeared and said he would take us to the Medina - we gave in a followed him and he took us back to the "Pharmacy"!! Gave up and asked a woman who told us the right way without asking for payment. The souks are amazing but be prepared to be continually hassled. What they don't tell you is that you can't spend Dirhams in the Duty Free Shops at the airport - I had some left! Even the ordinary shops there give you Euros in change for Dirhams so be warned and don't bother to save any for last minute shopping. By law you can only take 1000 Dirhams out of the country and you can't exchange them back in UK . 5 out of 12 of us spent two days hugging the loo and another friend recently suffered the same fate - thank goodness for Imodium!! Exciting and fun trip nevertheless.

I loved it!. It was beautiful, noisy, fun, exiting and nearly everything else. You know you need to be open to different place in the world. Not every country is the same there is a different system and people are different. I found the Moroccans a lovely bunch. Always and I mean always willing to help, without asking for money and make you feel welcomed, they all say ‘welcome to Morocco’ I didn’t get that anywhere else in the world. The souks the sites the activities are just incredible. I would recommend Marrakech to every one of my friends and I will definitely go back to medina of Marrakech.

My experience of marrakech. Just been to Marrakech and stopped right in the heart of the Medina. Great Riad Choui Choui, a two minute walk to the Jemma el Square. We really enjoyed the trip, just be aware if you look lost the people may take advantage of you and try and persuade you to follow them to a shop etc. The lastest trick is to tell you the musuem or the palace is closed , when in fact they are open. Opening times for all attractions are 9 till 12 and 2.45 till 5.30. We found if we planned where to go and how to get there nobody bothered us at all. do try eating in the square at night time, best of the traders was number one stand, ask for potatoe cakes and aubergine, great stuff.

Not the best place to experience a true african market/ medina. The medina was an interesting and colourful experience where you could easily and happily get lost taking in the sights. But I am afraid as the sights are really all you want to take in. The locals are used to lots of tourists and you will pay quite a high price for the goods on offer (when they offer ASDA price as to show cheap you know its England prices). I was honestly shocked at the few places I tried to barter in the Medina that they were giving prices 2 to 3 times what you would pay in the U.K and you could at best barter to 90% of what you would pay here. My advice would be to browse in the Medina and then go to the shops nearer the tombs in Marrakech and buy what you want there at a heavily reduced price.  Also realise that whilst an amazing sight and sound the Medina is now not a true reflection of Medina's (markets) thorughout africa

A walk through the medina is a must. ...and probably the only way to explore the true moroccan culture or atleast of marrakech. Its best to start at a fixed point in the medina such as one of the main gates and head to one of the main sites such as the kotoubia for example so that you can ask people along the way for directions while also exploring the medina. When I went to marrakech, we didnt plan to explore the medina like this, but it just so happened that we never found the site we wanted to go to in one go and ended up having to walk through the tiny streets in the medina asking for directions along the way. It was great though! Just be prepared to walk long distances in the heat and it'll be OK!
